DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Premier Vincent Siew rejects Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Peng Tso-kwei's resignation over farmland policy.
The China Times:
Agriculture chief resigns in protest over ruling Kuomintang decision to ease rules on farmland use.
The United Daily News:
Top agriculture official tenders resignation to protest the Cabinet's demand for the COA to lift the ban on the use of farmland for residential purposes.
The Liberty Times:
Premier Vincent Siew wants agriculture chief to stay on post.
The China Post:
Health officials refute anthrax exposure scare.
The Taiwan News:
As trade officials try to talk, protesters press their points outside the Washington State Convention Center in Seattle, venue for WTO meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISLANDWIDE RUSH FOR LOTTERY TICKETS

TEXT.P: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China (CBC) went on sale on Wednesday, causing a buying spree around the island.

At 7:30 a.m., the Bank of Taiwan and all of its 105 branches on the island began selling the lottery tickets at wholesale price to licensed sellers. Later, people swarmed to lottery tickets stands, railway stations, department stores and cinemas to purchase the lottery tickets in the hopes of winning prizes.

The so-called "two-in-one" means that ticket buyers have two chances at winning prizes with a single ticket. First, they can immediately scratch their tickets to reveal six sets of numbers. If three sets of numbers match, the number represents the prize money, with prizes ranging from between NT$100 and NT$2 million.

In addition to the first chance, ticket buyers can wait to see if the seven numbers on their tickets match up with a set of numbers drawn at a later date. If the numbers all match, they will win a top prize of NT$500,000, and if only the last of the seven numbers match, they will win the minimum NT$100.

Lottery regulations state that people under the age of 18 cannot purchase tickets or claim prizes, while those authorized to sell the tickets, most of them from low-income families, aboriginal people or disabled, must have their licenses displayed in a highly visible place.

A total of 17,949 sellers have been licensed. The general public can also buy lottery tickets at nine financial institutions, including the Land Bank of Taiwan, the First Commercial Bank, and Taipei Bank.
CBC officials said on Tuesday that the lottery will be held every month, with the first issue comprising 30 million tickets at NT$100 apiece.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN RULES OUT POSSIBILITY OF COOPERATING WITH ANY OTHER HOPEFUL

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday ruled out the possibility of cooperating with any other presidential hopeful.

"I'm confident in my odds to win the 2000 presidential election," Chen said confidently, adding that any speculation concerning the possibility of his cooperation with any other contestant is just a campaign gimmick of rival camps.
The outspoken lawyer-turned-politician stressed that he is unlikely to take any post in the Kuomintang administration if Taiwan's current ruling party manages to retain its grip on power.

"Nor is it likely that I cooperate with independent presidential candidate James Soong," said Chen, who often trailed behind Soong but ahead of KMT presidential candidate Lien Chan in the support rating in numerous public opinion polls.
Chen made the above remarks while meeting with a group of international media correspondents stationed in Hong Kong and Beijing.

In an apparent attempt to allay fears in some quarters that Chen might declare de jure Taiwan independence following his election, the ex-Taipei mayor told the visiting journalists that if elected, he will not do anything that might shock or panic anybody.

Nevertheless, Chen reiterated that any attempt or proposal to change the status quo that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are two separate independent states must be determined by the 22 million people of Taiwan through a plebiscite, and cannot be determined by any single political party or individual.
"Therefore, if I'm elected, I will not make any unilateral announcement that might ire or panic anybody," Chen stressed.

He went on to point out that the people of Taiwan cannot accept the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification scheme. Quoting the results of a recent survey by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, Chen said less than 10 percent of those interviewed support the formula, while the majority of 80 percent oppose such a proposal.
Chen said confidently that he believes that the disputes between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party will come to an end if he manages to win the 2000 presidential election.

Noting that the DPP is very likely to replace the KMT as the ruling party following the election, Chen said that under his leadership, the DPP will prove itself to be a "strong defender of Asia-Pacific security and peace, not a troublemaker as some people have alleged."
Touching on relations with mainland China, Chen said parity is the most important prerequisite for cross-strait dialogue and negotiations.

"To show goodwill, sincerity and accountability, if I manage to win the presidency, I would like to visit the mainland before my inauguration to lay a foundation for normalization of cross-strait relations," Chen explained.

He further pointed out that he has advocated a new "middle-of-the-road" policy to resolve cross-strait confrontation and hostility, adding that he believes normalization of cross-strait ties can start from normalizing bilateral trade and economic relations.

Chen recalled that a foreign reporter told him during a recent interview that Beijing thinks it may be easier to communicate with Chen than with the KMT's presidential candidate, Vice President Lien Chan.
"It interests me why Beijing has such a feeling," Chen said, adding that he is willing to do his utmost to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Stressing that the DPP has its roots in Taiwan, Chen said the party does not have any historical grudge against the Chinese Communist Party. "It was the KMT that once had a civil war with the communist party."
Chen said the DPP will forge relations with Beijing with an "open mind," adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should engage in "peaceful competition," not in "military confrontation."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEES RUSSIA AS Y2K BLACK SPOT

TEXT.P: Australia has identified Russia as one of the world's Y2K black spots and is reducing its consular presence in Moscow as a temporary measure at the end of this month, according to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

A DFAT spokesman told reporters the department has authorized the departure of non-essential consular staff and their dependents from Moscow by December 28 due to fears of widespread disruption caused by computer problems when January 2000 arrives in Russia.

The department has also advised Australians to delay non-essential travel to Russia and warned those living there to carefully reconsider any travel plans due to limited seats as fewer commercial aircraft are likely to be operating as a result of Y2K problems.
Other countries expected to have a higher rate of computer problems related to Y2K are Poland, the Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FINANCIAL FIRMS URGED TO EXPAND IN ASIA

TEXT.P: The Australian government has urged its nation's companies to follow steps taken by their US, European, and Japanese counterparts and take advantage of the unprecedented opportunities for expansion in Asia.

The call came in a 350-page book launched in Sydney on Tuesday by Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, who said Australian institutions should take advantage and expand their operations in banking, capital markets, funds management and life insurance in Asia.
He said Australian financial institutions had shown a "laudable sense of caution" in their approach to expansion in Asia but they had been less active than institutions from the US, Europe and Japan.
Only three Australian banks haven taken the chance of expanding their operations in Asia and others should follow suit, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA MANUFACTURER SUES AUSSIE GOV'T

TEXT.P: Pfizer, manufacturer of Viagra, is suing the Australian government for its refusal to subsidize the cost of its drug, used by males to combat impotency.
The government has decided not to reimburse Viagra buyers in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBAC) because it regards Viagra not as a medicine, but as a stimulant.

"Pfizer regrets that it has had to take this action, but unfortunately this is the only avenue of appeal available to pharmaceutical companies who feel that due process has not been followed by the PBAC," the company said in a statement released to the media here on Tuesday.
Pfizer is the first pharmaceutical company to challenge the government's decision in court and its challenge will be heard in the Federal Court in Sydney on December 8.
Viagra is available by private prescription in Australia at a cost of about A$70 (nearly US$47) for a four-tablet pack.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SET TO REAP NEAR-RECORD WHEAT HARVEST

TEXT.P: Australia's wheat harvest in 1999-2000 is expected to reach a near-record high of between 20 and 22.8 million tones, and the optimism for its exports, including those to Taiwan, remain high, according to the Australian Wheat Board.

The previous record was set in 1996-97 when Australia's wheat harvest hit about 23 million tones, of which more than 15 million tones were exported to Taiwan and other countries, according to a board spokesperson.

Last year, Australia's wheat exports totaled 16 million tones of which 42,000 tones were sold to Taiwan, down from 60,000 tones sold in the previous year. The spokesperson said sales to Taiwan will continue to fluctuate.

"Taiwan is a potentially lucrative market for Australian wheat. But it will take time to promote the market because Taiwanese importers are still not fully aware of the advantages of Australia's quality wheat. They are accustomed to buying wheat from the US," she said.
Trade Minister Mark Vaile is now in Seattle fighting for the removal of government subsidies on agricultural exports. The US and the European Union, at present, heavily subsidize their farm exports.
"If we can remove government subsidies, then our wheat exporters will be in a better position to compete with their US and European rivals," the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE ROC MOVIES CHOSEN AMONG `THE BEST OF THE 90S'

TEXT.P: Five Republic of China movies were chosen as among the best movies made during the 1990's by a prestigious film group in Toronto on Tuesday.

Cinematheque Ontario, the Toronto International Film Festival Group's year-round screening program, conducted an exhaustive poll of almost 60 programmers at such well known organizations as New York's Museum of Modern Art and the National Film Center in Tokyo.
The poll gave rise to a series of "the most acclaimed and neglected films" of the past decade, including works by venerable masters such as Jean-Luc Godard and Victor Erice.

Among the top 25 vote receivers were five films made in Taiwan. These included Hou Hsiao-hsien's "Flower of Shanghai," Edward Yang's "A Brighter Summer Day," Tsai Ming-Liang's "Vive L'Amour," and Hou's, "The Puppet- Master" and "Good-bye South Good-bye."

France ranked first in terms of the country with the most movies in the "Top 25" list with nine, followed by the United States with eight. Taiwan and Iran shared third place with five each. Fourth place went to Japan with four films.

Taiwan's Yang and Tsai, along with Hong Kong's Wong Kar-wai ("Chungking Express"), Denmark's Lars von Trier and Iranian Mohsen Makhmalbaf were lauded as directors who "broke into the international scene in the 1990s."

Spanish director Victor Erice won the top honor (garnering 57 votes) for his "Dream of Light" (El Sol Del Membrillo). Another surprise was Abbas Kiarostami, the Iranian director who finished far ahead of any other in the voting with an astonishing four films in the top six. The scores show he is "the most influential and revered filmmaker of the decade," according to Cinematheque Ontario.

Poll participants include representatives from some of the world's most important film institutions, such as the National Film Theatre in London, American Cinematheque in Los Angeles, Cineteca Nazionale in Rome, The Royal Film Archive in Brussels, and the Cannes Film Festival.

"Cinema Scope," an internationally distributed magazine published in Toronto, is publishing a special issue focusing on the poll and featuring more than 100 contributors including Kent Jones ("Film Comment"), Robin Wood, Berenice Reynaud ("Cahiers du Cinema") and many of Toronto's most influential critics

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DOESN'T ACCEPT COA CHAIRMAN'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew didn't accept the resignation filed by Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Peng Tso-kwei, returning his written resignation late Tuesday evening.
Government spokesman Chao Yi quoted Premier Siew as saying on Wednesday that the Executive Yuan has always supported the COA's stance on the country's farmland policy and will continue to do so.

Peng formally submitted his resignation to the Executive Yuan on Tuesday after several Kuomintang legislators submitted a draft amendment to the agricultural development plans to allow residences and other structures to be constructed on newly-acquired farmlands.
In his three-page resignation letter, Peng said he decided to quit the office because he could not condone what he considers to be a wrong policy shift.

To back up Peng, Chao said the Executive Yuan will accelerate lobbying at the Legislative Yuan so as to discourage lawmakers from adopting an amendment to the agricultural development draft. Instead, the government will help push for the passage of another Executive Yuan-revised version of the agricultural development draft, he added.

Peng, as Taiwan's top official in charge of agricultural policies, remained firm on the Executive Yuan-version of the new agricultural development draft which insists that no residential or commercial-purpose structures should be built on newly-acquired farmlands so as to maintain a balanced ecological environment and prevent farm yields in rural areas from being polluted.
The draft amendment proposed by Kuomintang legislators was viewed by some political observers as a scheme to win electoral ballots as the presidential election scheduled for March, 2000 approaches.
Peng said in the letter that as a cabinet minister, it is his responsibility to put forward policies aimed at improving people's lives rather than at "soliciting ballots."
Commenting on Peng's resignation, Hung Yu-chin, executive-director of the Kuomintang's Policy Coordination Committee, said Peng does not need to deal with the problem by resigning his post.

Hung said while the Legislature has made moves aimed at reflecting the opinions of farmers as well as of the general public, the Executive Yuan has the right and the responsibility to insist on its stance on issues. The most important thing is to coordinate and to exchange views when differences arise, he added.
Meanwhile, Kuomintang spokesman Huang Huei-chen denied that the proposal made by some Kuomintang legislators on the draft amendment was a "turnabout in policy" by the ruling Kuomintang.

Huang said what makes democracy so precious and worthy is that it allows for and tolerates differences. Besides, he said, the amendment has not passed yet and there is still room for debate at the Legislative Yuan before it becomes law.

Huang declined to confirm whether ROC President and Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui was behind the draft amendment proposal. He only said that Lee, an agronomist-turned-president, has spared no effort in taking care of farmers' interests while trying to maintain balanced economic development in society.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT DECLINING IN MAINLAND CHINESE PORT CITY

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis which broke out two years ago in Southeast Asia has caused many Taiwan firms to scale down their investments in the city of Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian Province, according to a Hong Kong-based newspaper.

Over the past two years, a number of Taiwan businesses have decreased or withdrawn their investments in Xiamen by an annual rate of more than 20 percent as a result of sluggish operations, the Hong Kong Commercial Daily reported.

Quoting Fujian provincial government officials, the newspaper said higher production costs in Xiamen have also led to a withdrawal of Taiwan capital from the southern mainland Chinese coastal city. It said Xiamen's rising labor costs and factory acquisition costs have made it difficult for Taiwan companies, mostly labor-intensive businesses, to maintain their operations.

Under the current circumstances, the Fujian provincial government has worked out a series of measures in an effort to persuade these outgoing Taiwan businesses to relocate in the eastern and northern parts of the province, the newspaper reported.

However, a Fujian economist said he was taken by surprise to find during an inspection tour to the southern part of Jiangsu Province that many Taiwan businesses have already shifted from Fujian to Jiangsu's Kunshan City, according to the newspaper. Taiwan investors in Kunshan were quoted as saying that the investment climate in Jiangsu is much better than in Fujian.

Because of Taiwan's historical links and geographic proximity with Fujian, Xiamen has long been one of the favorite investment targets among Taiwan enterprises over the past decade or more, and Fujian authorities have set up four investment zones, three of which are in Xiamen, especially for Taiwan businessmen, a move expressly designed to court greater investment from Taiwan.
Currently, one-third of the foreign investment projects in Xiamen are funded through investment by Taiwan enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SCIENTISTS JOINTLY DISCOVER IMPORTANT NEW FOSSIL

TEXT.P: a group of scientists from both sides of the Taiwan Strait have discovered the first craniate chordates with a clear head and a large brain which might be the original ancestors of all vertebrates on earth.

At a press conference held in Taipei on Wednesday, Prof. Li Chia-wei of the Hsinchu-based National Tsinghua University in northern Taiwan announced the discovery of the some 300 specimens of 530 million-year-old fish-like fossils which may rewrite the history of the origin and evolution of vertebrates, including humans.

The discovery of the fossils will provide scientists with a clear picture of the distant ancestors of all vertebrates, said Li, who made the discovery with his mainland Chinese coworker, Chen Junyuan of the Nanjing Institute of Paleontology and Geology, Chinese Academy of Science, and his assistant, Huang Diying.

Announcing their discovery to the world simultaneously in Taipei and Nanjing, Li and Chen named the fossil Haikouella, because the specimens were collected from a hill in Haikou, in southern mainland Chinese province of Yunnan.

The fossils are all under 4 cm in length, but the excellent preservation, including admirable minute details, are deeply inspiring, said Li. "With these genuine materials, we are able to trace, in exquisite detail and for the first time, vertebrates back to their ancestors without backbones," he said.
The prestigious British journal Nature will carry Li and Chen's discovery in a five-page report in its Nov. 4 issue, labeling it as an "exciting, major scientific discovery."

In the article, Li and Chen point out that due to a dearth of fossil evidence, human knowledge in the past had mistakenly assumed that the cephalization and full endoskeletonization of the vertebrates was an event accomplished at one swoop.

"Now Haikouella shows us that there is a prolonging history of cephalization before the origin of backbones. The animals in the pre-backbone history that have a clear cranium but no clear indication of endoskeletons or backbone as "vertebrates" clearly transgress the manifest taxonomic principle of naming the organisms "vertebrates" based on the existence of a backbone," they say.
The discovery will also be carried in the latest issue of the US periodical Science, according to Li.

In 1998, Li and Chen jointly discovered and announced the oldest-known fossils of complex animal life forms on earth, known as "pre-Cambrian sponges with cellular structure," in Guizhou, southern mainland China.
That finding moved back the date of the earliest appearance of complex and varied forms of life on earth by 40 million to 50 million years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WANTS INTERVIEW MECHANISM FOR WOULD-BE MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is seeking to establish an interview mechanism to screen the entry to Taiwan of mainland Chinese spouses of local residents, MAC sources said on Wednesday.

Through the interview, a system which has been used for years by advanced Western countries to screen new immigrants and visitors, the government should be able to more effectively curb the surge of bogus marriages used as pretexts for people coming to Taiwan to work as prostitutes or take on other kinds of work, said Johnnason Liu, director of the MAC's Department of Legal Affairs.
However, such interviews would have to be conducted outside Taiwan, ideally in mainland China, but there are currently no suitable locations for the interviews, said Liu.

He added that the MAC will consult with relevant agencies from the ministries of the interior and justice to try and establish the content of the interviews and appropriate venue where they could take place.
To meet an increasing demand, the MAC has expanded the annual quota for mainland spouses allowed to enter Taiwan to 3,600 beginning this year.

Currently, mainland spouses can obtain visas for three months at a time, extendible for a further three months. After that, they must leave the island and return to the mainland before reapplying to enter for another three months.
The MAC is also mulling whether to extend the visa to six months, extendible by six months, according to Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR RISES TO TWO-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar continued its surge against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, hitting a two-year closing high of 31.669.
Wednesday's closing level was a 0.3-cent increase from that of the previous day.
The yen's bullishness on international markets contributed to the general appreciation of major Asian currencies, including the NT dollar.

The NT dollar broke through the 31.7-barrier on Tuesday. It is expected that the local currency will soon surge to 31.5 against the greenback amid the continuous inflow of foreign funds into the domestic stock market, dealers said.
The NT dollar opened on Wednesday at 31.648, the highest level of the day, and was traded between 31.648 and 31.673.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$287 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES UP, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices climbed 0.6 percent on Wednesday in a day of inert trading.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 45.33 points higher at 7,766.20, while turnover shrank again to NT$81.54 billion (US$2.57 billion) due to a lack of new incentives to boost investors' sentiment, with 1.92 billion shares changing hands.

Financial issues have posted sharp gains in recent sessions following Monday's announcement of a merger of two leading local brokerages, Yuanta Securities and Core Pacific Securities, but dealers said the influence of this was wearing off, with buyers' interest shifting to technology shares.

Among the eight major stock categories, the foodstuff sector enjoyed the largest gains due to new favorable government policies, posting 3.4 percent gains. Financial shares experienced consolidation and reported 0.2-percent losses following recent gains.
Decliners outnumbered advancers 243 to 218, with 78 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market edged up 0.09 points to close at 187.49, on a turnover of NT$15.31 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, with the exception of next September futures, which had no transactions recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 56 points to close at 7,820, with 1,408 contract transactions. Those for January rose 42 points to finish at 7,828, with 51 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March advanced 44 points to close at 7,869, with 10 contract transactions, while those for next June jumped 22 points to close at 7,880, with two contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,764 points for December, 7,786 points for January, 7,825 points for next March, 7,858 points for next June, and 7,868 points for next September.

Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, reported gains and mixed results, respectively.
December TE futures rose 3.45 points to close at 389.95, with 889 contract transactions, while January TE futures moved up four points to finish at 390, with 14 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.
December TF futures climbed 0.2 points to close at 999.8, with 294 contract transactions, and January TF futures dipped 22.6 points to 992.4 with five contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Nov. 1, or the 24th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese drive out the Spaniards under the leadership of John IV.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan negotiate the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party (CCP) leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Chinese communist troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration, and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1963: Raul Leoni is elected president of Venezuela.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: Jose Lopez Portillo is sworn in as president of Mexico.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading US companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the Taiwan-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be founded in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County, and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1990: Food rationing is imposed in Leningrad.
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI PRESIDENT ACCORDED MILITARY HONORS, CHAIRS OPENING OF EMBASSY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui presided over a welcoming ceremony for Malawi President Dr. Bakili Muluzi on Wednesday at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei.
Muluzi, who arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a five-day state visit, was accorded full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute.
Addressing the ceremony, Lee first extended a warm welcome to the Malawi head of state on his third visit to the Republic of China.
He said the ROC and Malawi have maintained close cooperation in various fields based on equality and reciprocity since the two countries forged diplomatic ties in 1966.
Lee said he will take advantage of Muluzi's current visit to exchange views on matters of mutual concern and discuss new cooperative projects.

For his part, Muluzi expressed gratitude for the hospitality extended to him and his entourage by the ROC government. He also offered condolences to the families of Taiwan people killed in the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

Muluzi further said he will do his utmost to help boost bilateral cooperation for mutual benefit in the new millennium. He also reaffirmed his country's firm support for the ROC's bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Trade Organization.
Later in the day, Muluzi and new ROC Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen jointly presided over an inaugural ceremony for the Malawi Embassy in the ROC.
Muluzi said the inauguration of the embassy symbolizes that relations between the two countries will be everlasting and that bilateral cooperation will be further strengthened.

The Malawi embassy is located in a diplomatic enclave in the Taipei suburb of Tienmu, and Muluzi said he appreciates the ROC's efforts to provide such a good environment to accommodate foreign embassies.

Speaking on the same occasion, Eunice Kazembe, Malawi's first ambassador to the ROC, said she has already begun studying mandarin Chinese with a view to facilitating her work here and boosting her understanding of Chinese culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SETTLE OVER 10,000 QUAKE VICTIMS IN MILITARY BARRACKS

TEXT.P: The government is to temporarily resettle more than 10,856 quake survivors still living in tents as soon as possible now that a cold front has swept across Taiwan, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said on Wednesday.

Liu, who is also executive chief of the government's post-quake reconstruction promotion commission, made the announcement in a report at the weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee on the action under way in the areas devastated by the Sept. 21 earthquake.

Among the 10,856 quake victims still living in tents, 1,202 have still not received promised rent subsidies, 2,405 are still afraid of temblors, 1,844 are awaiting resettlement in prefabricated houses, and 4,788 are awaiting the repair of their own houses, Liu said.
Liu said that the Executive Yuan will settle the issue with assistance from the military, and will allow the tent-dwellers to move into military barracks before the weather gets any colder.
Vice President Lien Chan, who chaired the meeting in his capacity as KMT vice chairman, spoke highly of the government's action in the rescue and resettlement of the quake victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD NOT IN FAVOR OF UNCONDITIONAL CROSS-STRAIT LINKS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman (MAC) Su Chi said on Wednesday that the more Taiwan's politicians advocate "unconditional cross-strait links," the more reluctant mainland China will be to negotiate on the issue.

At a gathering of legislators, Su was asked to comment on the "unconditional three-cross-strait links" and the "one-way cross-strait transportation link" advocated recently by presidential hopefuls Hsu Hsin-liang and Chen Shui-bian, respectively.

Hsu, an independent candidate, and Chen, who is carrying the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) standard in the presidential race scheduled for next March 18, have made the three direct links -- trade, transport and postal -- the pillar of their mainland China policies.
Taiwan refuses to accept the mainland's terms for the three links between Taiwan and the mainland because it is afraid of compromising its national security.

Su said that Chen's proposal for "a one-way direct Taiwan-mainland transportation link" does not take national dignity into account, an issue which needs to be solved through negotiation, although it does safeguard the security of the nation.

On whether the top cross-strait negotiators of both sides -- Taiwan's Koo Chen-fu and the mainland's Wang Daohan -- will meet at a ceremony to mark the handover of Macau to mainland Chinese rule on Dec. 20 in the Portuguese enclave, Su said that Taiwan has so far received no invitation to the event.
Saying that Taiwan would welcome a meeting between the two at any time and on any occasion, he added however that "it would be better for them to meet in Taipei rather than in Macau."

Beijing has postponed a scheduled 1999 visit to Taiwan by Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait in protest against Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Commenting on the recent offer of Koo, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, to make another visit to the mainland to invite Wang again, Su said that Taiwan has fully demonstrated its goodwill on the issue, and that it will not make any "unnecessary" move without a positive response from the mainland side.
Koo last met with Wang in October last year during an ice-breaking trip to the mainland, where he invited Wang to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan, which Wang accepted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES 500 WHEELCHAIRS TO SOUTH AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By C.H. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to South Africa Du Ling on Tuesday donated 500 wheelchairs to South African handicapped people on behalf of the Republic of China government and people.

The ceremony, witnessed by nearly a hundred South African disabled citizens and social welfare workers, took place at the Nan Hua Temple some 50 kilometers east of Pretoria. Essop Pahad, head of the South African Presidential Office, received the donation from Du on behalf of his government and people.
The 500 wheelchairs were jointly contributed by the Taipei Representative Office in the Republic of South Africa and the Taiwan-based International Fukuangshan Buddhist Foundation.
Du said the donation was in response to South African President Thabo Mbeki's appeal to help handicapped people, and also serves as a demonstration of fraternity between the ROC and South Africa.

Master Huilee of the Nan Hua Temple said the people of Taiwan have so far donated more than 4,000 wheelchairs to various African countries, and will continue to extend their charity in the future despite the fact that Taiwan suffered tremendous loss and damage as a result of the Sept. 21 earthquake.

Expressing his appreciation for the donation, Pahad explained that the major purpose of the South African government's policy on assisting disabled people is to help them upgrade their quality of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF HIV CARRIERS ESTIMATED AT 10,000 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) issued a sobering set of new statistics on HIV carriers in Taiwan on Wednesday, World AIDS Day.
DOH tallies show that 125 people tested HIV positive in the past three months alone. Among these newly found HIV carriers were three couples and an 18-month-old baby.

Tu Hsing-tze, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said that a decade ago, HIV was transmitted mostly among homosexual men. "This shifted to drug users, and now heterosexual transmission is the most common," he warned.
Tu further said anti-AIDS campaigns should focus on young people, particularly those in the 15-25 age group, since they are the most vulnerable.
According to DOH statistics, a total of 2,375 Republic of China nationals have so far been confirmed as HIV carriers, 841 of whom have developed AIDS.

Tu said as one-third of local HIV carriers did not learn of their infection until after they had developed full-blown AIDS, the number of actual HIV carriers is believed to be four to five times the number of confirmed carriers.
Based on this estimate, Tu said the actual number of local HIV carriers should be somewhere in the region of 10,000 people.

"More worrisome is that heterosexual transmission has been increasing rapidly in Taiwan in recent years," Tu said, adding that the number of married couples infected with the virus has increased to 87.
Worse yet, Tu said, five young children have also tested HIV positive.

According to DOH data, the mother of the fifth HIV baby is a foreign bride. "After more than a year of tracking and examination, the baby is confirmed as having been infected with HIV from his mother," Tu said, adding that six other young children are still being closely monitored to determine whether they have been infected with the killer virus.
Tu further said health authorities should intensify HIV testing on foreign spouses with a view to preventing the further spread of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TRIPLE-DRUG AIDS THERAPY MIGHT SLASH COSTS

TEXT.P: Research in Singapore into a new triple-drug therapy for Aids patients is going well and could slash their medical costs drastically, The Straits Times newspaper reported on Wednesday.
Further tests of drugs to combat HIV, the cause of Aids, are due to start next week.
The new therapy, initiated by doctors from the Communicable Disease Center (CDC) in Tan Tock Seng Hospital, combines a drug for cancer and another for arthritis with an HIV drug.
If it works, the new therapy would cut a patient's monthly medication costs to about S$300 (US$178) from the current monthly average of more than S$1,200.
Dr. Nick Paton, who heads the CDC's department of infectious diseases, said he hopes the studies will yield results by the middle of next year.
Dr. Leo Yee Sin, head of HIV Medicine at the CDC, said tests had been conducted for a month on several patients, but it was too short a time to determine how effective the drugs were.
Only about one-sixth of Singapore's HIV-infected patients can afford current drug cocktail therapy, which is not subsidized by the government as the drugs used are "non-standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RATED WORLD'S 11TH FREEST ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was rated the world's 11th freest economy in an analysis of 161 economies around the world released on Tuesday.

The survey, compiled by the Heritage Foundation and the Wall Street Journal, ranked Hong Kong as the world's freest economy. The territory has remained on the top spot since the foundation began the annual survey in 1995.
Taiwan's 1999 ranking was four slots lower than its 1998 rating mainly because of increased government intervention in the economy, according to the survey.

The annual study ranks the freedom of national economies on the basis of several factors: trade, tax, government intervention in the economy, banking and monetary policy, capital flows and foreign investment; wages and prices, property rights, regulations and black market activity.
The rating uses a 1-to-5-point scaling system. One point represents the freest and five points the least free.
Taiwan got a score of two points in the 1999 rating, a bit worse than its 1998 rating of 1.9 points.
In all the four previous similar surveys, Taiwan ranked in the "fully free" category. But in the 1999 rating, it dropped to the "mostly free" category for the first time.
Taiwan ranked 8th in the 1995 survey, seventh in 1996 study and 16th in the 1997 report.
Among the 10 factors gauged, Taiwan received the highest marks in three factors -- banking and monetary policy, property rights, and regulation and black market activity.
In the 1999 survey, Singapore and New Zealand were ranked as the world's second and third freest economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNTY MOST SEVERELY POLLUTED BY GANGSTERS: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The political climate of southern Taiwan's Yunlin County is most severely polluted by gangsters among the 21 counties and cities of the Taiwan area, according to the results of a survey published on Wednesday by an opposition lawmaker.
Chien Hsi-kai of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the eight-month survey was jointly conducted by himself and professors Chen Ming-tung and Chen Tung-sheng of National Taiwan University.
The survey results show that the top five counties and cities whose political climates are the most severely polluted are Yunlin, Changhua, Kaohsiung, Tainan and Pingtung counties, in that order.

The results also show that the financial situation of Pingtung County in southern Taiwan is the worst among the 21 counties and cities of the Taiwan area. The other four counties and cities on the top five worst financial situation list are Taichung City, Kaohsiung County, Changhua County and Tainan County.

The definition of the extent of political corruption was described as the number of serious criminal cases in which local parliamentarians are involved, the number of such cases which involved guns, and the number of shootings reported, according to Chien.
The definition of the financial situation depended on the financial institutions' overdue outstanding loans, and the number of bad debts in the various counties, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HAILS ARMED FORCES' QUAKE RELIEF EFFORTS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday praised the excellent performance of the Republic of China Armed Forces in the wake of the earthquake which devastated parts of central Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,400 lives.
Lee described the rescue and reconstruction efforts of the armed forces as "a war without an enemy or weapons."
"This was a great challenge for you (the armed forces) and your triumph over the battle has won respect and admiration at home and abroad," Lee said.
He made the remarks at a ceremony to award armed forces personnel for their quake-relief efforts which he presided over in his capacity as supreme commander of the three-service forces.

The president said he was deeply impressed during inspections of stricken areas by the armed force's brave work in carrying out rescues, resettling survivors, and building temporary bridges and roads in the quake-affected areas.

"Your well-organized and systematic implementation with strict discipline and efficiency have proved that the ROC Armed Forces can overcome any battlefield test," Lee said before presenting awards to Gen. Chen Chen-hsiang, commander-in-chief of the army, Gen. Chen Chao-min, commander-in-chief of the air force, and Lt. Gen. Chen Ban-chih, commander of the marine corps, among others.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSIDERING PHILIPPINE PROPOSAL FOR RESUMING AIR LINKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is considering the possibility of resuming air links with the Philippines suspended by Manila on Oct. 1, a senior Republic of China official said on Wednesday.

Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng confirmed that he has received an official letter from the Philippine authorities affirming the 1996 air Taipei-Mania agreement that was unilaterally suspended by the Philippines side.
"Taipei-Manila flights can be resumed any time, as soon as we give the nod," Lin said.

The Philippines scrapped the Taipei-Manila air pact after Taiwan refused to accept its request for a slash in the number of passengers that Taiwan airlines could carry between the two sides from 9,600 per week as agreed upon in the 1996 pact, to 3,600.
The Philippine government made the move in a bid to save its debt-ridden national flag carrier, Philippine Airlines, from continuing crippling losses.

Lin said that under the terms of the 1996 pact, the maximum number of seats offered to the two Taiwan airlines which formerly plied the route -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- will be maintained at 9,600 weekly, and that one-year prior notice must be given if either side wants to suspend the pact.

The letter was transferred to Taipei through Taiwan's representative office in Manila. It is believed that Manila was forced to make the concession under strong pressure from the 100,000-strong contingent of Philippine laborers working in Taiwan, many of whom want to return home to spend Christmas with their families.

Since the suspension of direct Taipei-Manila flights, Filipino workers in Taiwan have had to travel via Hong Kong while traveling between the island and their home country, greatly increasing their expenditure and travel time.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZ'S BRING $ 36 BILLION IN SURPLUS FOR TAIWAN IN 33 YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export processing zones (EPZs) have created US$36 billion in surplus since their establishment in 1966, Director Pan Ting-pai of the EPZ Administration said on Wednesday.
Pan said that the exports and imports through the EPZs totaled US$83.9 billion and US$47.9, respectively, over the past 33 years.

He went on to say that the EPZs are now in the midst of an expansion project to accommodate more export-oriented manufacturers, especially those in the high-tech arena, including those involved in IC manufacture and testing, and liquefied crystal display (LCD) production.
He added that once the project is completed, the total land area of the EPZs will have increased to over 1,000 hectares.
Terming the EPZs the stars of Taiwan, Pan said that "the stars will be even more brilliant tomorrow." The island has three EPZs -- in Taichung, Nantze and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS RIGHT TO EXPAND INTERNATIONAL ACTIVITIES: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said recently that Taiwan has every right to expand its activities in the international community.

In an exclusive interview with the Austrian Broadcasting Company (ABC), Lee admitted that Taiwan has difficulty forging diplomatic ties with foreign countries under Beijing's efforts to isolate Taiwan from the rest of the international community.
"If Beijing wants to win respect from Taiwan, it must give Taiwan room to play in the international community," Lee said.

An ABC reporter visited Taipei in early November at the invitation of the Government Information Office (GIO), during which he interviewed government officials, officials of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and scholars, on the cross-Taiwan Strait issue.

Lee pointed out that Taiwan, with its population of 22 million people, ranks as the world's 19th-largest economic power and the world's 14th-largest trading nation. However, because of Beijing's pressure, the country maintains diplomatic relations with just 29 countries.

Asked how the escalating diplomatic tug of war between Taiwan and mainland China in Central and South America, Africa and Oceania can be resolved, Lee said that Beijing would be better off letting Taiwan have some international space than spending huge sums of money to engage in the diplomatic battle.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that Taiwan renounced the use of force to recover mainland China in 1991, but pointed out that the mainland authorities have yet to reciprocate by renouncing the use of force to take Taiwan.
He said that this intransigence has invited criticism and anger from Taiwan.

Chang Ping-nan, deputy director-general of the GIO, claimed that over 80 percent of the people of Taiwan back the government's current mainland China affairs policy, while more than 70 percent are opposed to Beijing's "one country, two systems" reunification proposal.

Yen Wan-chin, director of the Mainland China Affairs Department of the opposition DPP, said that Taiwan is a completely independent and sovereign country. From the DPP's point of view, he went on, Taiwan should strengthen economic, trade and cultural interchanges with mainland China on an equal footing.

Chang Chih-ming, a professor of sociology at National Taiwan University, said that the education system today emphasizes the awakening of the "Taiwanese consciousness," in contrast with the past emphasis on "Chinese consciousness."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE VOWS TO HELP WITH MALAWI'S NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Wednesday that Taiwan is willing to share its development experience with Malawi to enable the people of the two nations to enjoy the fruits of prosperity and progress.
Lee made the remarks before a state-banquet he gave in honor of visiting Malawi President Dr. Bakili Muluzi at the Presidential Building.

Lee said that since assuming office in 1994, Muluzi has vigorously pushed ahead with various political and economic reforms to eradicate poverty, maintain social order and upgrade his people's standard of living.

He went on to say that Muluzi again led his party to overwhelming victory in Malawi's presidential election in June and a parliamentary election in October, showing that he has won the trust and respect of the Malawi people.
Lee pointed out that relations between the ROC and Malawi have been very close since they established diplomatic ties in 1966.
The cordial relations were further evidenced by the opening of the Malawi embassy in Taipei earlier in the day and the appointment of the African country's first ambassador to the ROC.
Muluzi, for his part, thanked Lee for the assistance that Taiwan has offered his country in the fields of agriculture, medical services and transportation over the years.
He also extended his sympathy to the families of the victims of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.
Muluzi reaffirmed that his country will always stand behind Taiwan in its bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
Muluzi arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a five-day state visit, his third trip to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW LAUDS OUTGOING NICARAGUAN ENVOY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Wednesday spoke highly of outgoing Nicaraguan ambassador to the ROC Salvador Stadthagen for his valuable contributions to the diplomatic relationship between the two countries.
Stadthagen has spared no efforts to promote cooperative relations between the ROC and Nicaragua during his posting in Taipei, Siew said in a farewell meeting with the outgoing envoy.

Siew told Stadthagen that the ROC government has also worked hard to help Nicaragua promote various reconstruction projects through regional multilateral mechanisms. "Moreover, we have ourselves directly carried out several cooperative projects in this Central American country," he went on.
In response to Siew's remarks, Stadthagen pointed out that his government attaches great importance to multilateral cooperative programs which can speed up Nicaragua's economic development.

Expressing his great appreciation for the cordial friendship the ROC government and people have extended to him during his three-year tenure here, Stadthagen described serving as his country's envoy to the ROC as an unforgettable experience.
He also voiced his hope that cooperative bilateral relations will be further expanded in the near future, especially with regard to the opening of Taiwan to laborers from Nicaragua.
Lee also conferred an Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon upon the outgoing ambassador, in recognition of his contributions to bilateral friendly relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG LEADS IN KINMEN PRESIDENTIAL SURVEY

TEXT.P: Independent presidential hopeful James Soong has a runaway lead in his support rating among the residents of the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu, according to a joint survey by the Journalist magazine and a Taipei cable television station.

The survey results show that Soong enjoys a 52.7 percent support rating compared with 12.5 percent for Vice President Lien Chan, the ruling Kuomintang's candidate, and 3.3 percent for former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's nominee. About 27 percent remained uncommitted.
The survey was conducted via telephone among 1,113 eligible voters aged above 20 years on the islands between Nov. 25 and 26.
When asked which candidate is most capable of carrying out reforms, 51.1 percent selected Soong, with 8.5 percent and 7.8 percent going for Chen and Lien, respectively.

As to who can best protect Taiwan's interests amid the threats from mainland China, 37 percent stood behind Soong, while Lien gained support from 14.6 percent and Chen received a 3.1 percent support rating.
The presidential election is scheduled to be held on March 18, 2000, and six teams have registered, four of which are currently seeking required public endorsement of their presidential bids.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang will respect public opinion in formulating farmland policy.
The China Times:
Violent protests halt the WTO meeting in Seattle.
The United Daily News:
The ROC will gradually ease trade with mainland China.
The Liberty Times:
The ROC will be willing to negotiate direct shipping or air links with mainland China if Beijing renounces its attempt to use force against Taiwan.
The China Post:
Seattle vows crackdown on WTO disruption.
The Taiwan News:
Protests obstruct WTO opening.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC SET TO HIKE OIL PRICE NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is poised to announce another oil price hike next week, by an average of 3 percent, CPC sources reported on Thursday.

CPC officials said the price hike, probably to come on Dec. 7, is inevitable due to price surges in the international crude oil market and a pre-tax profit for November that is lower than the government projection.
The cost to the CPC for imported crude oil reached US$22.21 per barrel in November, a 35-month high, and US$0.42 per barrel higher than the average in October, according to CPC officials.
The last time the CPC raised its prices was on Nov. 10, hiking them 2.91 percent over the previous levels. The CPC has raised its prices by a total of 17.27 percent so far this year up to Nov. 30.

CPC originally planned to announce two separate oil price hikes in October and November, with a combined price increase to the tune of 6 percent. The plan was dropped after a devastating earthquake wreaked havoc in central Taiwan on Sept. 21.
More than a month of post-quake price stability has made oil price hikes possible in November, they noted.

The officials forecast that international crude prices may increase further in the months to come as there is no sign that oil-producing countries are attempting to raise output, and potential supply shortages may keep prices sizzling.
As of Dec. 1, the price of West Texas Intermediate surged to US$25 per barrel and there is no sign that the price will ease any time soon, they pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Thursday, Dec. 2, or the 25th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: US President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1921: The first American helium airship has a successful test flight in Portsmouth, Virginia.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with US Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1954: The US Senate votes to condemn Sen. Joseph McCarthy for conduct unbecoming a senator, ending four-years of anti-communist hysteria in the United States.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference closes. More than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attend.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister in India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial-level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six-and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.

Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA HEAD'S RESIGNATION MAY UNDERMINE KMT ELECTION HOPES IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: The resignation of Taiwan's top agricultural official may undermine the Kuomintang's prospects of winning ballots in the northern county of Hsinchu in the presidential election next spring, local political sources said on Thursday.

Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), submitted his resignation to Premier Vincent Siew Tuesday in a move showing his disapproval at the ruling Kuomintang's shift in farmland policy.

Peng decided to resign after Kuomintang legislators submitted a draft amendment to the agricultural development statutes that allows residences and other structures to be constructed on newly-acquired farmlands, a move which he considered a decision by KMT higher-ups.

A professor at National Chungshing University's College of Agriculture, Peng was recruited into the Cabinet by the then Vice President and Premier Lien Chan in early 1997. Since then, Peng has played a major role in winning votes for the Kuomintang in several major elections, particularly in his hometown of Hsinchu, which is home to many Hakka people.
Some folks back in Hsinchu support Peng's resignation, describing the action as a reflection of the Hakka people's "hard neck" spirit.

However, some people disapprove of Peng's action, saying that his resignation will adversely affect the Kuomintang's operations in Hsinchu at a crucial time in the lead-up to the presidential election.
Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew didn't accept Peng's resignation and will meet with him shortly for close-door talks in an attempt to convince him to stay on at his post, Siew said.
It was learned that Peng moved out of his Taipei office on Tuesday and is now staying at his previous residence in Taichung near National Chungshing University.

Peng has been avoiding the media, only saying through his aides that the chances of him returning to office are slim unless the Legislature opts for the Executive Yuan's version of the new agricultural development draft which insists that no residential or commercial-purpose structures be built on newly-acquired farmlands.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CAN LEARN TECHNICAL MANAGEMENT FROM E. ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia can still learn about technological management from Taiwan, Singapore and South Korea in order to help its exporters compete in the world market, a leading Australian expert says.

In his article titled "Innovative Asia Leads Way" and published by the Australian Financial Review on Thursday, Associate Professor John A. Matthews of the Macquaire Graduate School of Management, says Australia can learn some valuable lessons from its East Asian neighbors.

"In Taiwan, industry is kept under constant pressure to maintain its innovative activity -- to keep renewing itself technologically. This does not involve firms being required to generate 'new knowledge' but aims to ensure that they have access to the latest and most important technological breakthroughs, and that they actually implement them in their products and processes," he says.

"The key to relentless technological upgrading, which keeps firms innovative and competitive, in Taiwan and elsewhere in East Asia, is not just a focus on the technicalities of knowledge generation, but on the creation and operation of institutional machinery for managing the process of diffusion of new techniques throughout the economy," writes Matthews .

"The rapid rise of countries such as Korea, Taiwan and Singapore as technological powers demonstrate that painstaking attention to the institutions of diffusion is every bit as difficult, and important, as attention paid to traditional knowledge generation," he says.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA REITERATES KEY TIES WITH FOUR COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has reiterated that Indonesia, mainland China, the United States and Japan are the cornerstones of Australia's foreign policy.
In a statement faxed to the CNA on Thursday, Downer said Indonesia, China, Japan and the United States "are the four most important relationships for Australia."

When Downer released the White Paper in 1996, he set the relationships with these four countries as the most important for Australia. Commenting on present policy, he said that "we have not changed that assessment at all."
Downer mentioned that Australia has no plans to downgrade its ties with Indonesia as a result of the friction caused by Australia's leading role in the UN operation in East Timor.

On the topic of mainland China policy , Downer reiterated that Australia does not have a special relationship with that country, saying that "using the rubric of special relationships simply sets up false expectations."

Last week, Downer told a business gathering in Sydney that Australia has mature and broad relations with China. But at the same time, Australia will vigorously continue its commercial ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION A HISTORIC CHANCE FOR DPP: DPP CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's 2000 presidential election is a historic chance for the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), party chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said here on Wednesday.
Lin made the remarks in a speech to more than 100 people at the American Enterprise Institute, a think tank, on the DPP's policy toward mainland China.

He said it is "highly possible" that the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang will lose the election, and added that the DPP can play a responsible and constructive role in Taiwan's future.

Lin reiterated the DPP's point of view that based on the consideration of air security over Taiwan, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can start a "one-way direct air link" from Taiwan and let both sides share the profits resulting from this link, or even allow mainland China to solely enjoy the profits.
However, he went on to say that while the DPP has been making an effort to express goodwill toward mainland China, Beijing has not formally responded.

He said that the DPP stresses the importance of an all-out cross-strait dialogue, adding that prior to finding a solution to the disputes that both sides can accept, Taipei and Beijing should establish a normal communication channel and confidence-building mechanism in order to lower the possibility of the occurrence of misjudgment and conflict.

Lin declined to directly talk about the DPP's expectations of the US role in the cross-strait issue, but indicated that if Beijing intends to forcibly unify Taiwan, it will cause great instability and even conflict and war in the Asia-Pacific region. And once war breaks out, the United States, based on its position of maintaining human rights, democracy, freedom and peace, will make the "best decision" to cope with it, he added.

With regard to Taiwan's status in the international arena, Lin noted that the DPP sees Taiwan as an independent sovereign country and it is up to the people of Taiwan to decide on the future development of cross-strait relations.

During his visit in the United States, Lin also visited the Brookings Institute and the Nixon Center, two other think tanks. At the Nixon Center, he met with various experts on China and cross-strait affairs, and also exchanged views with officials of the US State Department, Defense Department and Congress on issues of mutual concern.

He wound up his three-day visit to the United States and left for the Canadian capital of Ottawa on Wednesday evening to continue his first US-Canada tour since he took the post of chairman of the DPP more than a year ago.
