DOC.HEADLINE: FOSSIL OF POSSIBLE ANCESTOR OF ALL VERTEBRATES ON DISPLAY
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Recently discovered fossils of the first craniate chordates with a clear head and a large brain which might be the original ancestors of all vertebrates on earth went on display in Taichung City on Thursday.

The display at the National Museum of Natural Science in downtown Taichung coincides with a prominent report in the prestigious British journal Nature in its Nov. 4 issue, said Prof. Li Chia-wei of the Hsinchu-based National Tsinghua University.

A day earlier, Li had announced in Taipei the discovery of the 305 specimens of 530 million-year-old fish-like fossils which may rewrite the history of the origin and evolution of vertebrates, including humans.

Li jointly made the discovery recently with his mainland Chinese coworker, Chen Junyuan of the Nanjing Institute of Paleontology and Geology, Chinese Academy of Science, and Chen's assistant, Huang Diying.

The discovery of the fossils will provide scientists with a clear picture of the distant ancestors of all vertebrates, Li said at a press conference which coincided with the opening of the exhibition.

Li said the discovery proves that some 530 million years ago, on a beach which today is in the central part of the southern mainland Chinese province of Yunnan, there lived a wide variety of numerous "sophisticated-structured" animals, some covered with shells, some with naked tender bodies, leading widely diversified lives.

However, these animals without backbones died suddenly en masse over a very short period of time, which world paleontologists have labeled the Cambrian explosion. The cause of the big explosion remains unanswered, Li said.
Announcing their discovery to the world simultaneously in Taipei and Nanjing, Li and Chen named the fossil Haikouella, because the specimens were collected from a hill in Haikou, Yunnan Province.

The fossils are all under 4 cm in length but excellently preserved in clear and minute detail, allowing Li and his research team to trace, in exquisite detail and for the first time, vertebrates back to their ancestors without backbones, Li added.

The exhibition, which will run until April 9, 2000, will allow Taiwan residents the opportunity to view for themselves one of the most likely possibilities of how the earth's vertebrates, including humans, evolved from low-grade craniate chordates without backbones.

DOC.HEADLINE: `TALK FIRST, RESUME FLIGHTS LATER,' SAYS ROC TRANSPORT MINISTER

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng said on Thursday that the Taiwan-Philippine air links unilaterally suspended by Manila on Oct. 1 will be resumed as long as relevant bilateral talks are completed.
Lin said his office has notified the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to arrange for the talks, paving the way for formal resumption of air links between Taiwan and the Philippines.

Lin said he received a letter on Wednesday from his Philippine counterpart notifying Taipei that Manila had changed its mind and had decided to recognize the 1996 air-link pact, under the terms of which Taiwan carriers China Airlines and EVA Airways can offer 9,600 seats on their flights every week, while the "sixth flight right" -- the right to transport passengers from Manila to a third destination via Taipei -- should be settled through further negotiations.

He added that since the Philippine authorities have now demonstrated goodwill in the dispute -- a two-month period of agony for the affected parties, particularly airline companies and Filipino laborers working in Taiwan -- Taipei is willing to return to the negotiating table.

In addition, Lin stressed that the bilateral agreement should be adhered to, saying that one of the factors that led to the dispute was the fact that the Philippines disregarded a stipulation in the 1996 agreement that one year's prior notice must be given if either side wants to suspend the pact.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar closed at 31.667 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, rising 0.2 cent.
The local currency opened at 31.660, the highest level of the day, and had a low of of 31.674.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$240 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNREPENTANT ARMORED VEHICLE DRIVER ARRESTED FOR THEFT

TEXT.P: Police announced on Thursday the arrest of four men suspected of being involved in a NT$53 million armored van heist that took place in Taipei County on Tuesday.
Hung Jen-mao, the driver of the Guardforce Security Co. van and alleged mastermind of the robbery, said after his arrest on Wednesday night that he did not regret his criminal act.

Hung, 40, allegedly colluded with his three accomplices to abscond with the NT$53 million which he was transporting on Tuesday. The accomplices, who have also been nabbed, were identified as Hung Chu-meng, 46; Hsieh Ching-yu, 31; and Chang Yi-teh, 40.
Police also managed to retrieve NT$51.92 million from one of the four suspects' hideouts in Tahsi, Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

Taipei County Police Bureau Director Liu Chin-chang said he appreciated assistance offered by informants. "Information provided by (the informants) helped us to break the case in less than two days," he pointed out.

Initial investigations show that Hung drove away in the armored van, carrying six security boxes containing the NT$53 million in cash, while two other Guardforce security guards were collecting more money from a soft drink firm in Chungho, Taipei County.
With the assistance of his three accomplices waiting nearby, Hung transferred the cash to another vehicle and abandoned the Guardforce van in order to avoid the police.

Hung confessed to police that he and his accomplices had planned the theft for three months, as he needed money to repay gambling debts and support his family. Hung had been employed by Guardforce Security Co. for just a year.

All of the four suspects came from Kinmen, a Taiwan-held military outpost which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan. They originally planned to remit the stolen money in several installments to the mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen opposite Kinmen before sneaking over to the mainland themselves in fishing boats.
Hung told police that they had contacted a human smuggling ring to arrange for them to illegally enter the mainland. However, the quick police action thwarted their plan.

Police first arrested Hung Chu-meng in Neili, Taoyuan County at 8 p.m. on Wednesday. Acting on information he provided, police managed to nab Hung Mao-jen, Chang and Hsieh in separate raids in Chungli, Neili and Tahsi in the wee hours of Thursday.
The four suspects, all of whom had previous criminal records, had spent slightly more than NT$1 million of their huge haul.
It was the fifth private cash van theft case reported so far this year, and the third to be cracked. Two of the cases remain unsolved.

Police said they believe that their speed in cracking the most recent case will help deter others from attempting similar crimes. They further said security loopholes in the Kinmen area should be plugged to discourage criminal suspects from trying to get to the mainland to evade prosecution in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN VISITS CANADA TO ESTABLISH COMMUNICATION CHANNELS
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) flew into Ottawa from Washington on Wednesday night for a three-day visit to Canada, the first such trip by a DPP chairman.

Lin said the main purpose of his visit is to establish a communication channel with Canadian political circles and to introduce Taiwan's recent situation and DPP policies to Canadian political figures and Taiwan compatriots residing in Canada. He said he hoped this will signify the beginning of a friendship between Canadian political figures and his party.

Accompanied by Chiou Yi-jen, the DPP's representative in the United States, Hsiao Mei-chin, director of the party's international affairs department, and Chen Yi-chia, the DPP's senior specialist, Lin was scheduled to visit the Canadian Parliament on Thursday for a luncheon with parliamentarians before watching a debate in the House of Commons.

Fang Chin-yen, the Republic of China's representative in Canada, will also attend the luncheon party to be hosted by Liberal Party parliamentarian Sarkis Assadourian. Lin will introduce the development of the DPP and exchange views with Canadian parliamentarians on issues of mutual concern.

Later on Thursday, Lin and his entourage are scheduled to visit the headquarters of the Canadian Liberal Party and invite the party to participate in the Liberal International Congress to be held in Taipei next February. It will be Canada's turn to organize the 2001 Liberal International congress.

They will attend a dinner hosted by Canadian political, academic, diplomatic and overseas Chinese circles and will sponsor a forum on Taiwan affairs to exchange views on Taiwan's future and on Taiwanese residing in Canada.

Lin and his entourage will visit Toronto on Friday to attend a roundtable seminar on Taiwan affairs jointly sponsored by the University of Toronto and York University. They will also attend a dinner party attended by DPP members and Taiwanese living in Toronto.
On Saturday, the group is scheduled to proceed to New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE WRITER PRAISES ROC'S QUAKE-RELIEF PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: A well-known Japanese writer has said that the Japanese people have given high marks to the Republic of China government and people for their post-quake relief efforts.

In an article to be published in the January issue of the monthly magazine "Shogun," Yusuke Mukata says several Japanese writers want to translate President Lee Teng-hui's "Quake Relief Diary" into Japanese and present it to Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi for reference.
Mukata recently visited Taiwan and had an exclusive interview with Lee on the devastating earthquake which rocked central parts of Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,400 lives.

During the interview, Mukata said, Lee first expressed heartfelt thanks for the assistance and donations made by the Japanese government and people in the wake of the earthquake, using a Chinese proverb relating to "timely assistance."

Speaking on the government's reconstruction plans, Lee stressed that some aspects needed to be implemented immediately, while others need to be accomplished gradually over time. He added that the most important thing is to accomplish all the plans with ceaseless efforts until the work has been completed.
He also said Taiwan and Japan should establish closer relations on measures to cope with such natural disasters, because both Taiwan and Japan are located in the same temblor-prone region.

Lee pointed out that many of Taiwan's civic organizations engaged in post-quake relief work have encountered financial, personnel training and experience problems. If Japan can render assistance to help train Taiwan's rescue teams, local rescue teams could rush to Japan in the event of another earthquake there, he said.

The president went on to say that people should face the disaster and keep hope alive to fight for a better tomorrow. Taiwan went ahead in hosting the Johnnie Walker Classic Golf Tournament just 50 days after the quake with the aim of showing the world that Taiwan had arisen from the rubble.
Founded in 1969, "Shogun" is one of the most widely read magazines in Japan, with a circulation of 120,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BACKS WTO PLAN FOR POOR COUNTRIES
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will fully cooperate in a plan unveiled by US President Bill Clinton to help the world's poor countries under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said here on Wednesday.

Wang, leader of a Taiwan delegation attending the WTO's ministerial-level meeting, responded enthusiastically to the consensus reached among the world's rich nations, saying Taiwan has always been supportive of such a stance in all WTO meetings and gatherings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum it has attended in the past.

As Taiwan has been listed by the WTO as a developed country, the island is expected to share a greater responsibility in the plan in the future, but Wang described this as a great honor for Taiwan, and recognition of Taiwan's progress and economic clout.

According to the economics minister, Taiwan has always been active and cooperative in offering trade, investment and technical assistance to poor countries around the world, and the island will move in compliance with WTO agreements on issues related to providing favorable customs duties to the world's least developed countries.
Wang made the remarks following a speech delivered by Clinton at a lunch party sponsored by the US Trade Representative Office and attended by trade ministers from all over the world.

Clinton announced that the United States is joining forces with the European Union, Canada and Japan to work out a package to help the world's poorest countries by offering greater market access to products from these countries and integrating them into global trade systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA TO OPERATE TAIPEI-SYDNEY FLIGHTS AFTER ANSETT SUSPENDS SERVICE

TEXT.P: EVA Airways announced on Thursday it will operate Taipei-Sydney flights after Ansett Australia stops flying the route in February next year.

EVA said it will dispatch its MD-11 passenger planes for flight services between the two cities. "We'll maintain three weekly flights in order not to affect passengers' rights and interests," said an EVA spokesman.

EVA, a wholly-owned offshoot of Taiwan's Evergreen Group which operates the world's largest container shipping fleet, made the emergency announcement after its partner in operating Taiwan-Australian flight services unexpectedly announced on Wednesday that it will suspend Taipei-Sydney flights from Feb. 12, 2000.

At present, four carriers -- Taiwan's EVA and Mandarin Airlines and Australia's Qantas Airways and Ansett -- operate flight services between Taiwan and Australia. They offer about 4,000 seats per week in total. Intense competition and big differences in passenger volumes between peak and off seasons have prompted Ansett to decide to withdraw from the market, airline sources said.
According to the sources, Ansett will shift focus of its operations to the Hong Kong market and will raise the number of its weekly flights between Hong Kong and Australia.
Following Ansett's withdrawal, the number of seats on the Taiwan-Australia flight route may drop to about 3,000 seats per week.

EVA, Ansett and Air New Zealand have jointly operated Taiwan-Oceania flight services through a code-sharing system since last year. Under the cooperative system, EVA focuses on flying the Taipei-Brisbane route, while Ansett flies the Taipei-Sydney route and Air New Zealand operates Taipei-Auckland services.

As the period from December to the Chinese New Year holiday is the peak season for the Taiwan-Australian aviation market, Ansett will not stop its services on the route until after the lunar New Year holiday which will start from Feb. 4 through Feb. 8.
EVA said the schedule for its new Taipei-Sydney flights will be unveiled later.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN RED CROSS COLLECTS 2.1 BILLION YEN FOR TAIWAN QUAKE RELIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of Japan announced on Thursday that it has so far collected 2.09 billion yen (US$20 million) as of Nov. 18 for the victims of the earthquake which rocked central Taiwan on Sept. 21.

The society and the state-run Japanese Broadcasting Corporation (NHK) launched a joint fund-raising drive immediately after the quake, a spokesman said, adding that the Red Cross also sent a seven-member medical team, 30 million yen, 30 generators, 4,000 flashlights, 16,000 batteries and 4,500 sleeping bags to Taiwan to help the stricken victims.

It also offered 502.9 million yen to help the Red Cross Society of Taiwan build 1,700 temporary houses, another 353.1 million yen to help equip 5,000 of the houses, and 791.8 million yen to fund the reconstruction of 12 primary schools and two junior high schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUNKEN DRIVING FINE EXPECTED TO BE RAISED TO NT$ 60,000

TEXT.P: A draft act to increase the fine for drunken driving to NT$60,000 and prohibit the use of hand-held cellular phones while driving on freeways and expressways was passed at a weekly meeting of the Republic of China Cabinet.
Car drivers caught using a mobile phone will be fined NT$3,000, while bicycle or motorcycle riders will be fined NT$1,000.

The amendment also added several new regulations to govern gravel truck drivers, notorious for the high rate of serious accidents they cause, and the focus of loud complaints and deep anger among the general public.

Since new regulations governing punishments for traffic violations were announced and implemented on March. 1, 1997, serious offenders have come under intense public scrutiny, and in order to further protect public safety, the Ministry of Transportation has been working to reinforce traffic rules and re-examine the deficiencies in existing regulations.

Central to the amendments is a further crackdown on drunken driving, with fines from between NT$6,000 and NT$10,000 to between NT$15,000 and NT$60,000, along with suspension of offenders' driver's licenses for one year.
The amendments still have to be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI PRESIDENT AWARDED HONORARY DOCTORATE

TEXT.P: Visiting Malawi President Bakili Muluzi was awarded an honorary doctoral degree in political science on Thursday by National Chengchi University (NCC).
NCC President Cheng Ting-wong said the award was in recognition of Muluzi's outstanding contribution to promoting democracy and human rights in his country.
Muluzi said he felt greatly honored to become an honorary alumni of the NCC, alma mater of both ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen and ROC Ambassador to Malawi S.C. Chen.
Muluzi, 56, the first Malawi president elected by a popular vote, terminated a one-party dictatorship of more than 30 years after winning the presidential race in 1994.

Since assuming the presidency five years ago, Muluzi, dubbed "Malawi's Mr. Democracy," has dedicated himself to advocating party politics, education and economic reform in his southeast African nation.
The award ceremony was witnessed by more than 100 guests, including an entourage which is accompanying Muluzi on his fourth visit to Taiwan.
The Malawi president arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a five-day visit at the invitation of President Lee Teng-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACEFUL SOLUTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTE MISSION OF NEW US PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: US Republican presidential hopeful George W. Bush said on Wednesday he believes that pushing for a peaceful solution to the cross Taiwan-Strait issue should be a mission of the next president of the United States.
The incumbent Texas governor made the remarks in a speech to the Republican Jewish Coalition.
Bush said that if he manages to win the US presidency next year, he will help Taiwan defend itself against mainland China in the event of a military action against the island.
"I believe that the issue between Taiwan and China must be solved peacefully," Bush stressed, adding: "It's (a peaceful solution) got to be the mission of the next president of the United States."
Bush further said it's important that if mainland China makes it into the World Trade Organization, Taiwan ought to follow.
Bush also said he supports the "one China" policy, but stressed that the United States should not regard mainland China as a strategic partner.
"Our relationship is not one of strategic partnership, but one of competition," Bush explained.
He continued that the United States should tell both Taiwan and mainland China that it wants peace in the Taiwan Strait.

"We must say to both parties that we expect there to be peace. But should China decide to move on Taiwan, I will help Taiwan defend itself. I will adhere to the Taiwan Relations Act as president of the United States," he added.

Speaking on the same occasion, another Republican presidential hopeful, Senator John McCain, also said that if elected, he will uphold the "one China" policy, but he was quick to add that he could not accept Beijing forcing democratic Taiwan to unify with it under its own terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKERS BLOCK NATIONAL HIGHWAY FOR TWO DAYS IN CHINA

TEXT.P: About 1,000 Chinese workers of a state-run factory in southwestern Sichuan province blocked National Highway 318 on Tuesday and Wednesday because they had not been paid for a whole year, a human rights group said here Thursday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the workers of Hong Jiang Silk Factory in Pengxi County also staged demonstrations before the government office of the county in the past two days, carrying placards saying "Against Corruption," "Against Graft," "We Need to Eat," and "Our Children Need to Go to School."

The workers took to the street amid rumors that the factory may go bankrupt soon due to corruption and mismanagement, the information center said, adding that at least three farmers were arrested and five others were injured when police tried to disperse the demonstrators.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PAKISTAN ICE-BREAKING TALKS MAY LEAD TO OPENING TRADE OFFICES
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang held "ice-breaking talks" with Pakistan Trade and Industry Production Minister A. Dawood on Wednesday in Seattle.

After the meeting, the Pakistani official expressed his interest in exchanging trade offices in each country's capital, according to a source close to the Taiwan delegation attending the World Trade Organization (WTO) ministerial-level conference.

The source described the Wang-Dawood meeting as "ice-breaking talks," given the fact that Pakistan, along with Sri Lanka, India, Bangladesh and Cuba -- all with a long-held pro-Beijing stance -- spoke against Taiwan's WTO entry at an unofficial working meeting held in Geneva in July.
Taiwan therefore tried to alleviate the obstacle by approaching all five nations with the hope of building a better understanding of the situation.
During the 30-minute meeting, Wang briefed Dawood on the current situation regarding Taiwan's WTO entry, the ROC's current economic development, and its outbound capital investment.

The Pakistani official expressed surprise to hear that Taiwan is among the top capital investors in Indonesia and Malaysia, according to Wang, and added that he hopes Taiwan and Pakistan can build up trade relations.

Wang also met with representative of Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Peru and Switzerland, as well as with WTO Deputy Director-general Ablosse Ouedraogo, the former foreign minister of Burkina Faso who assumed his current post two months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HAILS RELEASE OF DETAINED TAIWAN SHIP, PART OF CREW

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Thursday it welcomes mainland China's release of a detained Taiwan freighter and part of its crew.

The council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, also urged mainland authorities to release as soon as possible the two remaining crew members who are still being detained in Fujian province.
The MAC issued the statement after the Keelung-based Hsinhua cargo ship and eight of its crew returned to the Republic of China-held island of Matsu, which lies closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

The "Hsinhua" was intercepted by mainland customs officers in waters near Matsu on March 31 when it was chartered by ROC military to transport rice, gasoline and canned food to troops stationed on the offshore island. No military personnel were aboard.

Mainland customs charged the ship's crew with smuggling goods along the southeastern mainland coast. A mainland court ruled not to indict the crew on Oct. 22. As mainland customs authorities were dissatisfied with the ruling, the crew were still banned from movements and communication with the outside world.

Through the assistance of some Taiwan businessmen in mainland China and several Taiwan politicians, mainland customs authorities finally agreed to release the ship and eight of its crew. The released crew members included an Indonesian national. However, the ship's captain Kuo Tai-sheng and administrative affairs chief Chen Yi-chou are still being detained in Fujian.
The ship's owner, Hsinhua Shipping Co., denied mainland customs' smuggling charge and called for early release of the freighter's captain and administrative executive.

Tsao Yuan-chang, a National Assembly deputy elected from the Matsu constituency, and a Hsinhua Co. boat captain flew to Fujian on Wednesday to sail the "Hsinhua" freighter to Matsu and accompany the crew home.
In its Thursday statement, the MAC expressed its regret that mainland China has delayed in releasing the cargo ship and its crew members.

It further said the incident has once again signified the necessity for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to establish a mechanism to resolve problems and disputes arising from increased bilateral civilian exchanges and to better protect the rights and safety of ships and their crew sailing in the strait.
Against this background, the MAC said the two sides should resume dialogue as early as possible and work hand-in-hand to fight smuggling and other criminal activities across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN'S AUTOBIOGRAPHY LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Former Taipei mayor and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian on Thursday published his autobiography titled "Son of Taiwan."
The book, which chronicles the first part of Chen's life, also sets forth his vision for the nation and his philosophy for running the government.
Business tycoon Y.C. Wang wrote a preface for the new book and Yuan T. Lee, president of Academic Sinica and Nobel prize laureate, also wrote some words in the foreword.
Presiding over the launch of the book, Chen thanked the citizens of Taipei for not re-electing him mayor and thereby allowing him the time to finish the book.
Chen lost the mayorship of Taiwan's largest city to Kuomintang candidate Ma Ying-jeou last year.
Elaborating on his political career, Chen said he rose from nowhere, and is consummately capable of using limited resources to create unlimited possibilities.
Saying there are must be many others who share similar experiences to him, Chen urged all the "sons of Taiwan" to dedicate themselves completely to the motherland.

He also used the occasion to pay tribute to the memory of former DPP chairman Huang Hsin-chieh, who died on Tuesday of heart failure, saying that Huang is the single person other than his parents who has had the deepest influence on him.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HEAD URGES EXCHANGES WITH ARATS

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu called on Thursday for continued dialogue between the SEF and its mainland Chinese counterpart to promote cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

Only through systemic exchanges between the SEF and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) can Taiwan and mainland China maintain direct communication channels and hold bilateral negotiations on an equal footing, Koo said.

Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, made the remarks after being re-elected SEF chief for the fourth time. SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow was also re-elected to his post.
The SEF and ARATS are the semi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Voicing his desire that all the SEF staff will work with him to boost positive exchanges with the mainland, Koo expressed his hope that his mainland Chinese counterpart -- ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan -- will visit Taiwan "the sooner the better."

Wang should visit Taiwan without any conditions attached, just as he himself visited mainland China in October last year, the SEF head said, adding that Taiwan has not suspended the arrangements for Wang's planned visit.

Although Wang's Taiwan trip, originally slated for autumn this year, was put off by Beijing after President Lee Teng-hui aired his "special state-to-state" theory to describe Taiwan-mainland ties in July, Koo said both Taiwan and the mainland should understand the importance of persistent SEF-ARATS exchanges, and that the two sides should incorporate more rationality into their efforts.
"Taiwan has not halted its preparations for Mr. Wang's visit, and we still hope that Mr. Wang will realize his planned Taiwan trip at an appropriate time," Koo stressed.

Claiming that cross-strait relations are "special in nature" because the two sides share the same racial and cultural roots, Koo emphasized that Taiwan has not changed its policy toward mainland China and that neither side has shifted away from its goal of eventual unification.
Against such a backdrop, all doubts arising from Taiwan's stance on China's unification are unnecessary, and the accusation by Beijing that Taiwan is a "troublemaker" is unfounded, he added.

As to speculation that both Taiwan and mainland China are expected to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) simultaneously sometime next spring, the SEF chairman pointed out that admission for the two sides will help the mainland boost its economic reform and serve as a chance for the two sides to forge an opportunity for two-way cooperation.

He voiced the hope that Taiwan and the mainland will treat each other with goodwill during the process leading up to WTO entry, and work together to create an opportunity for Taiwan to review its economic policy toward the mainland.

Turning to doubts as to whether or not Taiwan and mainland China will have to open direct trade, transport and postal links across the Taiwan Strait following their WTO membership, Koo replied that this will not be necessary.
Since the "three direct links" are not just economic issues, Koo said, any breakthrough must be achieved through bilateral negotiations between the SEF and ARATS.

The fact that sea traffic and service industries will be issues covered by the next round of WTO negotiations which will begin next year, Koo gave his assurance that the two sides will have to conduct talks on this front eventually, which means that the SEF and ARATS will have to contact each other for such talks.

Regarding the question of whether Taiwan's and mainland China's admission into the WTO means that Taiwan will enter the "middle stage" set forth in the National Unification Guidelines, Koo argued that conditions are not yet ripe for such an adjustment.
"Nevertheless, we expect that Taiwan-mainland relations will enter the middle stage at some point, which will mean bilateral ties have heralded in a new era," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONDITIONS FOR WANG'S TAIWAN VISIT STAND, SAYS BEIJING

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese official said on Thursday that the two conditions set by Beijing for Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to visit Taipei remain valid.

The official made the remarks in a telephone interview with CNA, which was seeking a comment on a statement by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) following his re-election as SEF chairman on Thursday, when he reiterated his earlier invitation for Wang to visit Taipei at an appropriate time.

However, the official stressed that the two preconditions for Wang's Taiwan trip, spelled out by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin during his official visit to Australia in September, remain effective.

These are that Taiwan must retract President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship," and that Lee must receive Wang only in his capacity as Kuomintang chairman, not as president of the ROC.

Wang was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan this fall to reciprocate Koo's visit to the mainland in October last year, but the trip was suspended indefinitely by Beijing after Lee voiced his "special state-to-state relationship" view last July.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU, TAIWAN INK AVIATION AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Thursday signed a formal aviation agreement in Taipei with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries, said an official with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The bilateral aviation pact was jointly inked by ROC Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng and his Palauan counterpart after visiting Palau President Kuniwo Nakamura met with Lin and other ranking MOTC officials, and expressed interest in an air link agreement which would make Taiwan the first country to sign such an agreement with the Pacific island nation.
Under the terms of the agreement, several carriers can be designated by either country to operate the Taipei-Koror route, with four flights per week.

Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Co., which already provides chartered flight services on the Taipei-Koror route under the terms of a memorandum of understanding signed on April 1997 and renewed in July and November the same year, will be allowed to continue its flight services, while Palau will designate its flagship carrier to ply the route.
Officials with the Tourism Bureau under the MOTC forecast growing tourist exchanges between the ROC and Palau as a result of the signing of the aviation agreement.
According to tallies compiled by the Tourism Bureau, a total of 8,864 people from Taiwan traveled to Palau as tourists between January and October last year.
