DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS' MAXIMUM STAY TO BE EXTENDED TO SIX YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is considering extending the maximum period of stay for foreign workers here as part of its efforts to further improve the management of alien employees who are allowed to enter to help alleviate labor shortages.

The Executive Yuan on Thursday approved an amended draft of the Employment and Service Statutes, allowing foreign workers to stay in Taiwan for up to six years, three years longer than the current limit.
Premier Vincent Siew said foreign workers have made positive contributions to the country's economic development since they were first introduced in 1992.

As Taiwan develops into a business operations center in the Asian-Pacific region, Siew said, the government should establish a single-office administrative system to simplify foreign workers' application and employment procedures.

In addition, the amended draft also allows foreign nationals to apply for jobs offered by employers other than the one that sponsored their entry into Taiwan. Currently, foreign workers are legally bound to their employers and cannot seek employment elsewhere on the island.

According to the amendment, foreign nationals will be allowed to work as English teachers in private, experimental and bilingual schools, and as crewmen on commercial ships, work ships, and ocean-going fishing boats.
Meanwhile, the amendment also stipulates that the interests and welfare of aboriginal people should be protected while allowing for an extension of foreign workers' length of stay in Taiwan.
Aboriginal people as a whole have an average unemployment rate of 7 percent, compared with 3 percent among other ethnic groups in Taiwan, according to the Executive Yuan.
The amendment will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for review before it likely passes into law.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-AMERICAN TO HEAD ASIAN TRADE OFFICE OF S. CAROLINA

TEXT.P: South Carolina's Secretary of Commerce Charles S. Way this week appointed Chinese-American Y.Y. Kwok as director of the state's newly established Asian Trade Office in Hong Kong.
"By promoting South Carolina exports-- both products and services-- into primarily Chinese speaking countries in Asia, we will have new access to expanding markets," said Way.

The Asian Trade Office will handle trade opportunities for South Carolina-based products to mainland China, Australia, New Zealand, India, Taiwan and Korea and will augment South Carolina's Far East Office in Tokyo.
"We see this as a way that South Carolina's small and mid-sized companies can achieve the same level of success in the global marketplace that our state's bigger companies enjoy," he added.
Governor Jim Hodges, in a press release, added that "by opening an Asian Trade Office, we will gain an international advantage for South Carolina's products."
Kwok spent 23 years in international trade with the US Department of Commerce and the US State Department's base in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: RADIO AUSTRALIA ASKS FOR GREATER BROADCASTING ACCESS TO ASIA

TEXT.P: The Australian government has refused to guarantee Radio Australia's access to a broadcasting transmitter near Darwin after it sells the station to a private operator early next year.

RA network manager Jean-Gabriel Manguy said he made the request for broadcasting access to mainland China, Vietnam and other Asian countries, but the government refused the request by saying it must compete on a commercial basis, according to a report by the Australian Financial Review on Friday.
The government closed the RA transmitter near Darwin in 1997 as a way of cutting costs, depriving its millions of listeners in Southeast Asia, particularly China, of its programming.

RA presently broadcasts short-wave services to the Pacific from Townsville in north Queensland and to Asia from the central Victorian town of Shepparton. However it misses large areas of Asia from India to China and parts of Indonesia, Manguy said.

He noted that RA had to pay to use transmitters in Taiwan and Singapore in order to broadcast more clearly into East Timor and Southeast Asia recently. He complained that Australian politics limited the types of programs the RA could broadcast to large areas of Asia.

"There is still a dire need for short-wave (transmission) into Indonesia, Malaysia, China and Vietnam," he said. Millions of people in the region rely on short-wave radio transmissions for independent current affairs, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO STOPS ON MRT MUCHA LINE SUSPEND OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Trains between the Chunghsiao-Fushing stop and the Chungshan Middle School stop on the Mucha Line of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system were suspended on Friday due to an error by maintenance workers.
Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. officials said that the workers placed a jack in the wrong position while trying to realign a tilted bearing plate, causing a crack in one of the support pillar caps.

The officials said the crack is not expected to affect the safety of the MRT, but they nevertheless suspended trains between the two stops as a precautionary measure, and were unable to say when the system would return to normal.
They noted that posters advising passengers about the change had been put up, and that free shuttle buses were running between the two affected stations.
It is estimated that 41,900 passengers have been affected by the closures, and that MRT revenue losses will amount to around NT$400,000 (US$12,620) per day during the closure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 3, or the 26th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the US presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He is the author of "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde," and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1919: French impressionist painter Pierre Auguste Renoir dies at the age of 78. His paintings depicting sunlight through leaves and a series of pictures portraying bathers are among his best-known works.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: US forces cross the Saar River in Germany.
1948: ROC government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Chinese communists.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir; India declares state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy, and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the US 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 contested seats in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats, while independents take three.
1984: In Bophal, central India, hundreds are reported dead and several thousand injured after inhaling poisonous cyanide gas which leaked from a Union Carbide insecticide factory.
1989: US President George Bush and USSR leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, ending the Cold War and entering a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help tide South Korea over its financial crisis.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FOR BILATERAL WTO TALKS IF BEIJING SHOWS 'GOODWILL': SIEW

TEXT.P: Taiwan wants to conduct "win-win" bilateral economic consultations with mainland China under the World Trade Organization (TWO) framework if Beijing is willing to adjust its unfriendly attitude toward Taiwan, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.

Siew said Taipei would not exclude the possibility of engaging in WTO-style bilateral consultations with Beijing after both Taiwan and mainland China enter the world trade regulatory body. This, however, hinges on the premise that Beijing shows goodwill first, Siew noted.

Asked by legislators what is his definition of "goodwill", Siew said Taipei would consider that Beijing were showing goodwill if it were to stop suppressing Taiwan in the international community, stop threatening Taiwan militarily and if it were willing to face the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are distinct political entities.

As to whether and when Taiwan will review its "be patient, no haste" policy toward mainland China, which Siew said was devised to slow down the pace of Taiwan's big conglomerates and high-technology manufacturers relocating their operations to the mainland, Siew noted that it will be reviewed once Beijing removes its hostility toward Taiwan.
Siew added that once Beijing shows goodwill, Taiwan will also consider opening the so-called "three direct links" -- direct trade, post and transportation links -- with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER DENIES REPORT ON TIES WITH ALBANIA

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen on Friday denied a foreign wire service report that the Republic of China has offered to give the impoverished Balkan state of Albania US$1 billion in exchange for diplomatic recognition.
"I have not heard of such a thing," Chen said in response to a press inquiry about the report, adding that judging from common sense, the situation is unlikely to resemble that claimed by the report.

Noting that the ROC currently does not have any special relationship with Albania, Chen said he has not received any report to indicate that the ROC is going to establish diplomatic ties with the Balkan state.

"I have not been informed of any development that would lead to the establishment of formal diplomatic ties with Albania in the near future," said Chen, a seasoned career diplomat who just took the helm of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday.
The ROC and Albania have not exchange representative or liaison offices and bilateral trade is limited.

A Reuters Dec. 2 report quoted Peilumb Shullazi, an Albanian legislator and deputy chairman of the Association of Friendship between Albania and Taiwan, as saying that he and several other Albanian parliamentarians met with ROC envoy to Macedonia Peter Cheng earlier this week to discuss measures to promote Taiwan-Albanian relations.
During the meeting, Shullazi said, Cheng implied that he has been authorized by his government to offer Albania up to US$1 billion in exchange for diplomatic recognition.

"During the conversation, held two days ago in Macedonia, it was implied that their condition is for us to recognize them politically," Shullazi was quoted as having told a private Albanian television channel.

According to the Reuters report, Albania, one of the poorest countries in Europe, received the same amount of money -- US$1 billion -- from international donors for seven years starting in 1991, when communist rule was toppled in the country.
Commenting on the report, MOFA officials said the news came as a surprise and that they are still checking the reliability of the report.

Meanwhile, Minister Chen said while ROC officials stationed in neighboring Macedonia have had contacts with Shullazi, none of them has ever mentioned that the ROC would be willing to offer Albania US$1 billion in aid in exchange for diplomatic recognition.
Chen pointed out that some Albanian parliamentarians are friendly toward the ROC. "We are more than willing to forge ties with any other country wishing to make friends with us," he said.
The minister further said the ROC is currently endeavoring to develop relations with many other countries. "But we have not made any cash offer for forging ties," he stressed.

Reliable sources said ROC Premier Vincent Siew and former Foreign Minister Jason Hu met with an Albanian political heavyweight in tight secrecy when Siew made an official visit to Macedonia this summer. At that time, the ROC Cabinet would neither confirm nor deny the report.
The ROC managed to forge formal diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January this year, which gave the ROC a second foothold in Europe other than the Vatican.

ROC officials said the establishment of diplomatic ties with Macedonia is expected to help facilitate the ROC's efforts to forge friendships with other countries in the Balkan and East European areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA OUTLOOK FORUM TO OPEN IN TAINAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Asia Outlook Forum is scheduled to open in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan on Saturday, with more than 100 scholars and political observers from Japan and Taiwan participating.
The Japanese delegation, led by Masao Kamei, a senior adviser to Sumitomo Electric Industries, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on Friday.

Koo Chen-fu, leader of the ROC delegation to the forum, and Mineo Nakajima, president of the Tokyo University of Foreign Studies, will jointly preside over a ceremony to be held at the Tainan City Assembly on Saturday morning to kick off the two-day forum.

This year's meeting will focus on relations between marine civilization and technological networks; Japan's development trends and Taiwan's new political identification; and cross-Taiwan Strait relations and Asian-Pacific security in the digital age.

The Asia Outlook Forum, founded in 1989, is aimed at pooling the wisdom of the elite of business, political and academic communities in Taiwan and Japan to help boost bilateral substantive ties as well as regional prosperity and stability.
The forum holds its annual meeting alternately in Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO RESETTLE TENT PEOPLE IN TWO WEEKS

TEXT.P: The government will resettle people still living in tents in the wake of the massive Sept. 21 earthquake in two weeks, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan announced on Friday.
Liu, who is the executive officer of a post-quake reconstruction committee, made the remarks as he presided over a working meeting of the committee in Taichung, central Taiwan.

He said that among the more-than 10,000 quake victims now living in tents, more than 2,000 are people afraid of aftershocks, and more than 4,000 are those whose houses were damaged by the devastating earthquake and are currently under repair.

Therefore, he went on, that leaves around 3,600 who need government assistance for temporary resettlement to tide them over the winter, and these people have first priority in the government's resettlement project.

Liu said that after some discussion, the government has decided to offer military barracks, warehouses, and shipping containers as temporary accommodation, so that they will not have to spend the winter in tents.
He also noted that the prefabricated housing units under construction should be completed by the end of the month as scheduled.

Liu said that the last batch of materials used to construct prefabricated housing units donated by Japan have arrived in Taiwan, and that the military will help complete construction of the housing units by the end of December.

He said that the government is constructing a total of 5,100 prefabricated housing units in quake-stricken areas. Among them, 3,900 have been registered for use by quake victims, and the remaining 1,200 will be used for other relief purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC & MALAWI SIGN ACCORD ON VOCATIONAL TRAINING COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and its African ally Malawi on Friday forged an accord to promote bilateral cooperation in technology and vocational training.

Chairman Chan Hou-sheng of the ROC Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and Brown Mpinganjira, Malawi's minister of foreign affairs and international cooperation, jointly signed the agreement in Taipei.

Under the terms of the accord, the ROC will dispatch experts to the African nation to assist in upgrading the country's vocational training equipment and expertise in the fields of computer technology, carpentry, electronic engineering and automobile repair.
The program is scheduled to be implemented next March, Chan said.

In an address at the signing ceremony, Mpinganjira said that although Lilongwe has spared no efforts in the improvement of civil education, it is still unable to surmount the difficulty caused by a lack of training equipment for human resources.
He thanked the ROC for its generous offer, and vowed that Malawi will continue to support the ROC's efforts to obtain memberships of the United Nations and other international organizations.

According to the CLA, since the ROC generated an overseas vocational training cooperation program in 1999, it has assisted 54 countries around the world with vocational training, and has helped five nations set up their own training centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES CANADA TO HELP PROMOTE PEACE ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday urged Canada to help promote peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Lin, who is on a three-day visit to Canada, urged Ottawa to voice the call for a peaceful solution to cross-strait issues on various international occasions.
Speaking at a luncheon presided over by Canadian Liberal Party parliamentarian Sarkis Assadourian, Lin stressed that the people of Taiwan are sincere in wishing to improve cross-strait relations.

He said the DPP not only encourages Taiwan students to study in mainland China but also advocates providing scholarships to allow young mainland Chinese to come to Taiwan to study in order to foster reciprocal understanding.
Lin reiterated that the DPP welcomes mainland Chinese sportsmen, cultural and academic representatives, and officials, to visit Taiwan.
He said that while the DPP's goodwill gesture may not necessarily receive the same goodwill response from Beijing, the party will continue to make efforts to achieve the goal of improved relations.

Replying to a question raised by one Canadian parliamentarian as to the main obstacle hindering cross-strait communication, Lin said the blame lies with mainland China's hegemonious attitude of wishing to play the leading role in the unification of China and the lack of the concepts of freedom, human rights and peace among the Beijing regime.
Asked what Canada can do to help Taiwan, Lin proposed four points:
-- to provide legal help to Taiwan immigrants and investors;
-- to frequently invite Taiwan's parliamentarians to visit Canada to exchange views on issues of mutual concern;
-- to support Taiwan attempts to join international organizations; and
-- to strongly call for a peaceful solution to cross-strait issues in the international arena.

Prior to attending the luncheon, Lin, accompanied by three DPP members, also visited the ROC representative office in Canada to exchange views with officials there on the difference between ROC-Canada relations and ROC-US relations, the DPP's policy toward mainland China, as well as the issues concerning Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.
Lin pointed out that the DPP has garnered more than 33 percent of the vote in recent Taiwan elections, and he expressed confidence that his party will win the 2000 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZ CELEBRATES 33RD ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Taian's Export Processing Zone (EPZ) celebrated its 33rd anniversary on Friday with a commitment to developing hi-tech industry and warehousing businesses in tune with the nation's regional operations hub project.
The celebration was held in Nantzu EPZ, presided over by Administration Director General Pan Tin-bai and attended by 600 representatives from the Taichung, Kaohsiung, and Nantzu EPZs.

Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien, who also attended, presented outstanding business awards to Philips Electronics Building Elements Industries (Taiwan) and other companies located in the EPZs.

Pan noted that in response to the economic development of the nation, the government set up the first EPZ in Kaohsiung on reclaimed land in Dec. 3, 1966, adding that the target at the time was to attract industrial investment, promote foreign trade, introduce the latest technology, and increase employment opportunities, all of which was achieved.

As the response to the EPZ was so enthusiastic, other EPZs followed, Pan said, and they attracted more manufacturers. In the meantime, they also helped promote industrial automation and the upgrading of industry, with a lot of semi-conductor manufacturers investing in the EPZs.

Statistics show that there are currently over 200 manufacturers in the country's three EPZs, 80 percent of which are hi-tech businesses. The combined export value totals US$83.86 billion, while the combined import value totals US$47.9 billion, with a surplus of US$35.96 billion.

To deal with possible cross-Taiwan Strait development and cooperation in the international community, Pan said the EPZs will continue to push for warehousing transshipment zones in Kaohsiung and Taichung which have already attracted investment from many manufacturers.
Pan estimated that the plan will create an annual production value of US$100 billion and 100,000 job opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND CHINA DONATE TO QUAKE RELIEF

TEXT.P: A Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) official on Friday presented NT$101.24 million (US$3.2 million) from Taiwan businessmen in mainland China to Republic of China Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake.

SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow said that shortly after the temblor, Taiwan businessmen on the mainland began to raise money and collect relief materials such as batteries, blankets and tents for the victims.
Taiwan businessmen in Shanghai donated 2.7 million renminbi (US$325,000), and the donations by Taiwan businessmen in Ningpo amounted to NT$1.7 million (US$53,000), he said.
However, owing to Beijing's control on the flow of foreign exchange, Shi said, the donations could not be remitted to Taiwan.
Huang expressed his appreciation for the kindness shown by the Taiwan businessmen, and said that the donations will be used for post-quake reconstruction.

The 7.3-magnitude quake, the strongest to hit Taiwan in nearly 100 years, left 2,400 dead and 10,000 others injured, and the government estimates it will take five years to complete the reconstruction work.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES BOTH UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices soared 1.6 percent on Friday, boosted by an overnight rally on the US technology-heavy NASDAQ index and a government stimulus package for the conventional manufacturing industries.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 126.91 points higher at 7,933.17, with turnover swelling to NT$124.87 billion (US$3.94 billion) amid active trading.

The government on Thursday announced that government-related funds will be invested in mutual funds designed to trade conventional stocks, and that a six-month loan extension for non-technology firms is also being considered.
The traditional manufacturing sector reacted immediately to these favorable policies, in general posting gains.
Among the eight major stock categories, the cement sector enjoyed the largest gains of 3.6 percent, followed by textile issues, which rose 2.5 percent.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 363 to 108, with 79 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market moved up 2.33 points to close at 191.11, on a turnover of NT$12.20 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, with the exception of next September futures, which had no transactions recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 126 points to close at 7,974, with 2,320 contract transactions. Those for January rose 130 points to finish at 7,990, with 141 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March advanced 120 points to close at 8,020, with two contract transactions, while those for next June jumped 70 points to close at 8,066, with five contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,848 points for December, 7,860 points for January, 7,900 points for next March, 7,996 points for next June, and 7,952 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported gains.
December TE futures rose 8.85 points to close at 395.85, with 899 contract transactions, while January TE futures moved up 7.3 points to finish at 395.3, with 80 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.
December TF futures climbed 7.2 points to close at 1010.2, with 369 contract transactions, and January TF futures rose three points to 1,015, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose to its two-year high of 31.647 against the greenback on Friday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.
It was the fifth appreciation in a row the currency has sustained thanks to the stronger yen, the majar currency in the Asian market.
The local currency opened at 31.661 and was traded between 31.642 and 31.666. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$297 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 TAIWAN INFORMATION EXHIBITION MONTH KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 1999 Taiwan information exhibition month opened on Friday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with information products from 319 manufacturers on display at the site.
Wang Chao-ming, chairman of the Institute for Information Industry, Taiwan's information industry promoter, presided over the opening ceremony.
The theme of the exhibition was described as "accelerating the construction of national information infrastructure -- welcoming the coming of the e-commerce era."

In his opening speech, Wang said that e-commerce is set to become the mainstream of trading in the future, and noted that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has begun pushing for this type of trading in order to ensure that Taiwan remains competitive.
The exhibition will continue at the Taipei World Trade Center until Dec. 12, when it will move to Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung for the remainder of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL LEAVING FOR EUROPEAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to leave on Saturday for a three-country European trip as part of his efforts to promote his new "middle-of-the-road" policies.

London will be the first leg of the Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate's trip. While there, he will deliver a keynote speech titled "Taiwan's new middle-of-the-road policy; a complete new political vista" at the prestigious London School of Economics and Political Science, on Dec. 6 at the invitation of Anthony Giddens, president of the school.

Chen will also meet with staff of The Economist magazine, and various scholars, to exchange views on his political position. He will also call at the London-based International War Strategy Institute and other academic institutes before traveling to Belgium, where he will deliver another keynote speech at the European-Asian Research and Study Center of the European Union.

Chen will then move on to the Netherlands, where he will call on Hans Dijkstal, president of Holland's Liberal Party, and Michiel Patijn, convenor of the Foreign Relations Committee of the Dutch parliament.

He will also meet members of the Chen Shui-bian Supporters Association in Belgium and Holland before returning to Taipei on Dec. 9 to attend DPP-sponsored activities commemorating the 20th anniversary of the Formosan Incident scheduled for Dec. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER ADDRESSES WTO MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang delivered a speech at a ministerial-level meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Seattle on Thursday, urging all WTO members to support Taiwan's early entry into the organization.
In his address in English, Wang also echoed US President Bill Clinton's call for helping the world's less or least developed countries develop their economies under the WTO framework.
Wang said the ROC is more than willing to share with other developing countries its experience in improving trade regime and economic system.
The ROC is attending the WTO ministerial meeting as an observer.

Noting that the current Seattle meeting is aimed at working out an agenda for a new round of WTO trade talks, Wang said he hopes all WTO members can support for early entry of those who are still shut out of the world trade regulatory body, particularly those who have almost completed all accession procedures.
Wang said the ROC, which has completed all bilateral negotiations on its accession terms, earnestly hopes that it will be able to take part in the WTO's new round of trade talks as a full member.

The economist-turned-minister pointed out that the ROC became an observer of the WTO's precursor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1992. Over the past seven years, Wang said, the ROC has revised its trade regulations in line with the WTO requirements so as to improve its overall trade regime.
By now, Wang said, the ROC is fully prepared to become a formal WTO member and is willing to carry out all obligations as a WTO member.
Wang further said the ROC is willing to help other developing countries improve their trade regimes through technological cooperation and to help poor countries survive under the WTO system.

Touching on topics to be included in the new round of WTO talks, Wang said the ROC supports the proposal to continue reducing tariffs and removing trade barriers through negotiations in order to realize the long-term goal of trade liberalization.

The ROC, Wang went on, also agrees to include the "sustainable development" concept into the agenda for the new round of WTO talks in order to ensure consistency in WTO measures and multilateral protocols on environmental protection.
The ROC applied to join the WTO as an independent customs territory in 1990. It expects to be admitted to the Geneva-based trade regulatory body by next spring.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION BY NON-FARMERS ON FARMLAND UNFAIR: POLL

TEXT.P: About 87 percent of the people of Taiwan think it is unfair to allow non-farmers to purchase farmland for construction use, according to the results of a poll released on Friday.

Kuomintang Lawmaker Chen Shei-saint called on the ruling party not to "offend" the majority of voters in the coming presidential race in March 2000, as the survey indicates that only 10 percent of the island's farmers believe that the government's planned farmland use liberalization package will produce positive results for the KMT's presidential candidate -- Vice President Lien Chan.
Chen made the remarks after making public the results of the public opinion survey which covered 1,122 Taiwan residents, including 219 farmers.

Analyzing the poll results, Chen said more than 70 percent of the respondents are aware of the current government policy that only farmers can buy cropland, and around 66 percent of them also know that the government is planning to ease this restriction. But even if the plan goes ahead, over 40 percent of the people still believe that farmland should be used exclusively for farming, Chen pointed out.

At the same time, 66 percent agree that the farmland reform bill will have a negative impact on Taiwan's long-term agricultural development, while more than 60 percent expressed concern that new construction built on farmland will bring disorder to the countryside, according to the survey.

In addition, nearly 77 percent are concerned that allowing housing development on cropland will become a money-making tool for special interest groups, although over 80 percent agree that housing construction on farmland must be restricted to "high-class" residential communities.

Among the 219 farmers surveyed, more than 70 percent know that the government is planning to ease restrictions on farmland purchase, but 50 percent said they will not buy more cropland. At the same time, nearly 60 percent said they will not sell their farmland, while 53 percent expressed the opinion that there is no need to place a lower limit on the smallest parcel of farmland permitted to be sold.

On the issue related to building construction on farmland, more than 90 percent of the farmers expressed the hope that there will be no restrictions in this regard, while 45 percent voiced support for collective construction of farmhouses on farmland.

The government's plan to relax the current farmland policy to allow non-farmers to purchase farmland and to allow construction on such land caused Council of Agriculture Chairman Peng Tso-kuei to resign on Wednesday because President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui is said to agree with the plan.

It has been reported that KMT lawmakers are preparing to push for the passage of the new farmland use bill next week in the Legislative Yuan, a move which detractors accuse of being simply an expedient way of gaining votes for the ruling party in the coming presidential contest, with no thought for the future of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI AND ROC SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE TO RECONFIRM FRIENDSHIP

TEXT.P: Visiting Malawi President Bakili Muluzi and his Republic of China counterpart Lee Teng-hui reconfirmed on Friday the two countries' bilateral cooperation and vowed to join hands in promoting international peace and prosperity.

In a joint communique signed by the two heads of state, Muluzi expressed his satisfaction with bilateral cooperation on economy, trade, agriculture, infrastructure construction, medicine and vocational training, and thanks to ROC for aid rendered to his country.
Malawi, situated in southern Africa, is one of the world's most impoverished countries, with an annual per capita income of just US$200.

Muluzi reconfirmed his country's firm support for the ROC's bid for membership of the United Nations and other international bodies, and promised to advocate the ROC's right to play an appropriate role in the international community.
Lee for his part expressed thanks for Malawi's firm support for the ROC, and welcomed the opening of the African state's new embassy in Taipei, describing it as a milestone in bilateral ties.
The communique was signed in Lee's office with ROC government leaders and members of Muluzi's entourage looking on.
Later in the day, Lee presided over a farewell ceremony with full military honors for Muluzi, and the two leaders inspected a guard of honor before bidding farewell to each other.
Muluzi, who arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday for a five-day official visit, is slated to leave on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BECOMES JAPAN'S NO. 5 SOURCE OF IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported US$9.6 billion-worth of goods to Japan in the first 10 months of 1999, an increase of 25.9 percent in comparison with the same period of last year, making the island Japan's No. 5 source of imports.

Statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that the market share of Taiwan-produced goods also increased by 4.1 percent during the same period, an increase of 0.5 percent against the year-earlier level.

The same statistics also show that the trade deficit between Taiwan and Japan has drastically reduced to US$15 billion, resulting from the continuing devaluation of the new Taiwan dollar against the yen, and the continuing export expansion.

In terms of the value of Taian's export to Japan, machinery items topped the list at US$2.9 billion, representing a 59.4 percent increase over last year, followed by electrical equipment at US$2.3 billion, up 39.3 percent.
Taiwan imported US$24.6 billion-worth of goods from Japan during the January-October period, up 9.4 percent over the same period of last year.
Machinery equipment topped the list with a total value of US$7.4 billion, an increase of 21.7 percent over last year, followed by electrical equipment at US$5.9 billion, up 3.7 percent.
Japan-produced accounted for 27.2 percent of Taiwan's market in the first 10 months of the year, an increase of 1.2 percent over the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HONORS FOREIGN ENTREPRENEURS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China on Friday honored several foreign entrepreneurs for their great contributions to Taiwan's economic development by conferring upon them the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon.

At the award ceremony which took place at the Presidential Office, Lee praised foreign investments as one of the key factors that led to Taiwan's remarkable economic development, creating numerous jobs and helping local manufacturers to upgrade through technology transfers.

The foreign businessmen who were decorated with Taiwan's high civilian honor included Teruo Tani of Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Hideji Toyota of Toyota Motor Corp., Edward B. du Pont of du Pont Co. of the United States, Peter Baumann of the US Citybank business group, and Michael A. Stephen of the US Aetna group in the insurance sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE OTTER APPEARS IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: A rare Euroasian otter has been discovered on the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.

The otter, believed to be less than one year old, was spotted by a Kinmen civilian resident in the backyard of his home on Thursday night. The resident kept the small creature in a cardboard box to protect it from being hurt by stray dogs before handing the creature to the Kinmen National Park Administration on Friday.

Park administrators said the animal belongs to one of the world's five threatened otter species. It is widely regarded as an "index animal," as its presence or absence from a maritime area can serve as a gauge of the environmental quality for that area.

The Kinmen island group is a natural habitat of the Euroasian otter, a small animal with brown fur, short legs and a long tail. Otters swim well and eat fish. The Kinmen National Park has selected the Euroasian otter as its representative animal.

The park has also commissioned National Taiwan University associate professor Lee Ling-ling to conduct an otter-related ecological study. Lee will travel to Kinmen on Saturday to decide either to release the newly found otter after implanting it with a computer chip to allow it to be tracked, or to raise it until it matures enough to survive in the wild.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER JUDICIAL YUAN CHIEF UNCOMMITTED ON PRESIDENTIAL SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan, who is running in the 2000 presidential election on the Kuomintang ticket, met with former Judicial Yuan President Lin Yang-kang in Taichung on Friday.

Lien visited Lin with the apparent motive of soliciting Lin's support for his presidential bid, but Lin later declined to disclose what he and Lien had discussed, saying that he would remain publicly neutral, as "all the candidates are talents of the country."
Lin teamed up with former Premier Hau Pei-tsun to counter the KMT's Lee Teng-hui-Lien team in the 1996 presidential election. He was then expelled from the KMT and failed in his presidential bid.
Asked by the media whether he would consider returning to the KMT, Lin said that he has no intention of resuming his party membership at present, adding that the timing would be wrong.
Though long retired from active politics, Lin still has some influence in elections, and independent candidate James Soong has also visited him to seek his support and advice.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOLDS TALKS WITH BEIJING ALLIES AT WTO MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang a series of talks on Thursday in Seattle with representatives of Bangladesh, Uruguay, Germany, Brazil, Italy, Austria, and Hungary.

All the chief delegates on the sidelines of the World Trade Organization (WTO) ministerial-level meeting who met with Wang expressed their willingness to support Taiwan's WTO bid, the minister said, adding that he was especially encouraged by the goodwill response demonstrated by the representative of Bangladesh, a long-time Beijing ally.

The meetings followed an "ice-breaking" meeting between Wang and Pakistan's trade minister on Wednesday, during which the Pakistani official expressed interest to exchange trade offices in each nation's capital.
Wang is scheduled to meet with the representative of Cuba, another staunch supporter of Beijing, on Friday.

Representatives of Pakistan, India, Cuba, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka opposed Taiwan's WTO entry at an unofficial working meeting held in Geneva in July, thus hindering Taiwan's efforts to complete WTO entry procedures.
Wang, who is heading a 20-member delegation at the Seattle meeting, met with the five nations' representatives with the aim of alleviating this opposition to the island's WTO entry.

Commenting on remarks by mainland China's foreign trade minister ,Shi Guangsheng, at the WTO meeting, Wang said that mainland China should deal with Taiwan's WTO entry with a more open-minded attitude.

At a press conference, Shi had reiterated that Beijing insists that Taiwan is part of China and that Beijing should enter the WTO before Taiwan, which is the largest obstacle barring Taiwan from WTO entry, Wang said.
Cross-Taiwan Strait relations will only develop smoothly as a result of good competition and reciprocal respect on an equal footing, Wang said.

Speaking on workers' rights, a controversial issue at the ministerial meeting, Wang said that any changes to the law will have only a slight impact on Taiwan as the island has adopted high international standards in this regard.
Beijing is opposed to covering labor rights under the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE AQUATIC FIREFLY SPECIES FOUND IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A rare aquatic firefly species -- the stripe-back firefly -- has been found in Taiwan, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced on Friday.

Researchers at the COA's rare biological species study and conservation center said they are very pleased to discover the stripe-back firefly on the island because there are only 20 aquatic firefly species in the world.

Two aquatic firefly species -- the yellow-margined firefly and the yellow-chest, black-wing firefly -- have long been found in Taiwan. With the discovery of the stripe-back firefly, COA officials said, Taiwan now boasts three species, matching the number found in Japan.
COA researchers said the stripe-back firefly swims backstroke and has some other special features that have not been found in other firefly species.

Previous records show that stripe-back fireflies were once common in the coastal areas of mainland China's Fujian province, just opposite Taiwan. They have also been spotted in Taiwan-held offshore defense outpost of Kinmen Island.

In April 1998, COA researchers spotted the creature for the first time in Hsinhua, a small township in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan. The researchers later also discovered the species in mountain regions bordering Taichung and Miaoli counties in central Taiwan.

The researchers have since discovered that stripe-back fireflies usually hatch in April and that they are most active between May and June. However, even in October, some stripe-back fireflies can still be spotted at night.
Researchers said they once recorded more than 200 stripe-back fireflies in a single night. "This indicates that Taiwan is still a good natural habitat for fireflies," said a COA official.
The official added that some Japanese insect experts have traveled to Taiwan to watch the newly discovered fireflies.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN ANNOUNCES `JOURNEY OF PEACE TO MAINLAND CHINA' IF ELECTED

TEXT.P: Vice President and Kuomintang presidential candidate Lien Chan said on Friday that if elected president in March, he will embark on a "journey of peace to mainland China" to meet Beijing's leaders.

"If elected, I would like, either before or after my inauguration, to tour the mainland on a journey of peace to meet mainland Chinese leaders, as long as the interests and dignity of the 22 million people of Taiwan are ensured," Lien said while meeting representatives of international journalist organizations stationed in Beijing, Hong Kong and Macau.
"It doesn't matter where we meet, and if Beijing's leaders consider it (Lien's mainland trip) inconvenient for them, then we could meet in a third location," he said.

Lien stressed, however, that it is most important that both sides should demonstrate goodwill and a sincere wish to resolve the existing cross-Taiwan Strait problems before any such meeting can take place.

Lien, who initiated the KMT's "three noes" -- no rush toward unification, no Taiwan independence, and no cross-strait confrontation, and the "three wants" -- peace, exchanges, and a win-win situation, said that both sides should first improve their relations across-the-board, and engage in dialogues and negotiations at an appropriate time.
"Any topics can be put on the negotiating table," Lien said, adding that on the issue of national unification, Taiwan has no timetable and no preset stance.
"We are more than willing to conduct substantial and reciprocal discussions with the mainland on any issue, as long as such discussion are on an equal footing," Lien stressed.

He suggested that both Taiwan and the mainland should set aside their dispute on sovereignty. "We should not let the dispute continue troubling us and should instead try to seek a breakthrough," he added.

To begin with, Lien said, both sides can join hands to fight crime, crack down on smuggling and forge agricultural cooperation and sci-tech exchanges, then resume dialogue, and move on to discuss issues on ending cross-strait hostility, the signing of a truce accord or even a peace agreement.
Lien, hand-picked by President Lee Teng-hui as his successor, also defended Lee's definition of Taiwan-mainland ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."

It is just a depiction of the reality that has existed between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait over the past 50-odd years, Lien said, adding that Taiwan "will definitely not withdraw the theory in any way."
Of the other presidential hopefuls, Chen Shui-bian, the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's candidate, has made a similar offer to visit the mainland if elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER P/E RATIO AT 43.8 FOR STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: The average price earning ratio for all listed shares in the Taiwan stock market was 43.8 as of the end of November, down from the 51.92 recorded for October, the Securities & Futures Commission (SFC) said on Friday.
The drop in the P/E ratio in the local bourse was due to declines in stock prices, resulting in a smaller total market capitalization, according to the SEF.

Among all the major categories of the shares, textile shares posted the highest P/E ratio of 99.58 last month, while automobile stocks posted the lowest P/E ratio of 9.74, the SEF reported. The figure for non-financial issues was 58.36, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-HIGH-TECH INDUSTRY GRANTED EXTRA GRACE PERIOD FOR LOAN REPAYMENT

TEXT.P: Following a meeting with Minister of Finance Paul Chiu on Friday, domestic and foreign banks in Taiwan have agreed to grant an extra grace period of six months to non-high-tech industry borrowers, the minister announced after the meeting.

At a press briefing, Chiu said all financial institutions, including banks and bill finance firms, agreed to extend the deadline of loans to non-information-industry firms by six months, a suggestion set forth in a package of measures worked out by the Cabinet on Thursday to promote the competitiveness of these firms.

Taiwan's non-information-industry firms have been feeling the bite of cash-shortages recently since their stock prices were sent into a tailspin, with many share prices sinking below their face value because of local investors' overwhelming enthusiasm for equity in the island's information industry.

As a result, many non-information-industry firms which borrowed money against their stocks have seen their stocks, deposited with their creditors as collateral, being dumped on the market as their creditors scramble to recover the loans before the stocks have totally lost their value.
Chiu said the Cabinet measures cover only those firms which are still operating and are up to date with their debt repayments.

Meanwhile, Governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC) Perng Fai-nan, who was also present at the meeting, urged the bankers to use the NT$100 billion (US$3.12 billion) credit line provided by CBC to finance housing reconstruction and repair after the Sept. 21 earthquake, saying the move will hopefully prop up the island's sagging construction industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS WITHOUT RESIDENT PERMITS TO BE FINED, DEPORTED

TEXT.P: Foreigners who reside in Taiwan without permission will now face fines of between NT$1,000 and NT$10,000 (US$31-US$312) under new rules laid down by the Ministry of the Interior, the National Police Administration said on Friday.

The rules, effective on Friday, will impose fines on foreigners who fail to apply for residency within the prescribed period; those who are 14 years old or above and are caught without their passports or resident permits; and those who fail to update their address or workplace with the police when they move or change jobs in Taiwan.

Offenders will also being ordered to leave Taiwan within a specified period unless they have entered Taiwan legally and are eligible to stay; unless they are stateless because they are in the process of acquiring new nationality; unless they are Taiwan-born foreigners; or unless they have entered Taiwan legally and are applying for visas which will permit their residence in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA'S 2000 CHINESE WORLD ALMANAC TO HIT SHELVES THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: The "2000 Chinese World Almanac" and "Who's Who in the Republic of China," published by the CNA, will roll off the presses at the end of this month.

The 2 million-word almanac will contain renewed data on a huge variety of items, and over 40 articles on various topics, while the who's who will list more than 2,000 outstanding personalities from all areas of Taiwan society.
The articles deal with important domestic and international affairs, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, chronological events, as well as an introduction to 191 countries round the world.
CNA began compiling the Chinese almanac in 1990, and separated the "who's who" section into an independent volume last year.
A set of both volumes will be available at bookstores at the end December for NT$750 (US$23.50).
