DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR DENIES REPORT OF CHECKBOOK DIPLOMACY OVER ALBANIA
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-hueng and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Macedonia Peter Cheng on Friday solemnly denied allegations that the ROC is planning to pay a large sum of money to buy diplomatic recognition from Albania.

According to foreign wire reports, Cheng told an Albanian parliamentarian that he had been authorized by his government to pay US$1 billion to Albania in a bid to establish diplomatic relations with the European country.

In a later interview with CNA, Cheng categorically denied the report, and described it as "incredible" because the alleged sum quoted far exceeds that of the annual budget of ROC's entire Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

According to reliable sources, a certain Albanian political figure is indeed interested in the promotion of ROC-Albania relations, but not as far as the establishment of diplomatic ties. Albania is said to be hoping for the development of economic and trade relations with the ROC in an attempt to attract Taiwan businessmen to invest there, but it is determined to continue to maintain diplomatic ties with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was up 1.5 cents against the US dollar on Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at 31.632.
The local currency opened Saturday at 31.642, the day's lowest level, and was traded between 31.618 and 31.642.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$258 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA, US TO CONDUCT JOINT RESEARCH IN UNMANNED AERIAL SPY

TEXT.P: Australia's air force role in revolutionizing its aerial reconnaissance is set to be boosted substantially when it jointly conducts research and exercises with the US Air Force in early 2001.

The Australian Financial Review on Saturday reported that the USAF has decided to test its futuristic "Global Hawk" unmanned aerial vehicle in joint military exercises in northern Australia in April 2001.

Australia's Defense Science and Technology Organization has so far invested about US$20 million in helping develop the Global Hawk's sensor technology, the daily reported. Global Hawk, which is in the size of a large business jet, has a range of 23,000 kilometers, a ceiling of 20 kilometers, and can stay aloft for up to 38 hours.

With radar, cameras and an infrared sensor, the jet can survey up to 137,000 square kilometers a day and it can fly above most fighters and outside the range of most surface-to-air missiles, the daily reported.
With Global Hawk, Australia's surveillance of its 37,000 kilometer coastline and monitoring of its millions of square kilometers of land will be substantially boosted, aerial experts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF MAINLAND CHINESE FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is trying to improve its management of mainland Chinese fishermen employed by local ship owners, officials of the Fisheries Department under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Saturday.

The officials said that since the government began allowing local skippers to hire mainland crews to help alleviate a labor shortage on Taiwan fishing boats, problems have arisen with the management of the mainland fishermen.

He cited as an example the fact that the "floating hostels" in which the mainland fishermen are forced to live when not working are shabby and overcrowded. The hostels, mostly dilapidated scows anchored just off Taiwan's coast, are necessary since the mainlanders are not allowed to set foot on Taiwan soil.

The officials said that the department is now working out ways to improve the management of these fishermen. Measurers under consideration include the establishment of a comprehensive databank on the mainland fishermen by asking local ship owners to report relevant information to local fishing associations which can then be used by marine police as reference during at-sea inspections.

Other measures being considered are that the floating hostels should stay at designated berths, should keep their engines running, and should demolish any temporary buildings on board. Management personnel should also be stationed on the hostels, who should report regularly on the situation on their vessels to local fishing radio stations.

The officials estimated that the Taiwan fishery industry hires about 31,000 mainland fishermen each year, but added that the actual number of mainlanders working on Taiwan ships far outnumbers the reported number.

The officials noted that if calculated by the pay of mainland fishermen of about US$400 a month, then mainland China should be earning about US$148 million in foreign exchange per year, underlining the interdependence of Taiwan's fishery sector and mainland fishermen.
The officials said that after the implementation of the proposed measures, the Fisheries Department will ask maritime police to step up crackdowns on illegal mainland fishermen.

The department is also trying to diversify the sources of fishermen, and is now in discussions with labor brokerages in Vietnam and the Philippines to gauge the possibility of introducing fishermen from those countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEATTLE MEETING HELPS BOOST ROC'S WTO BID: MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Friday that the just-concluded World Trade Organization (WTO) ministerial meeting in Seattle has helped boost the ROC's bid to join the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

Wang further said no problems arose over the designation issue concerning the ROC's WTO membership. "We'll join the WTO in the name of `Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu (TPKM) Independent Customs Territory,'" the minister said, adding that the abbreviation of the ROC's full WTO title will be "Chinese Taipei."
The ROC adopted the TPKM designation when it first filed its membership application with the WTO's precursor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), in 1990.
Wang also told a news conference held at the conclusion of the WTO meeting that the ROC will make some adjustments to its trade and economic policy after being admitted into the WTO.
"The adjustments, however, will not include issues related to transport links across the Taiwan Strait," Wang noted.

Wang was responding to mainland Chinese Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Minister Shi Guangsheng's remarks that Taiwan will violate WTO regulations if it continues to ban direct "three links" with the mainland after both sides join the WTO.
As mainland China remains hostile toward Taiwan, the ROC government still bans direct trade, transport and postal links, commonly known as the "three links," across the Taiwan Strait.

Wang said the ROC will make some adjustments to its trade policy in accordance with WTO regulations following its entry to the organization. "But we'll not consider shipping or aviation link issues, since no existing WTO rules regulate such issues," the minister added.

During the four-day WTO meeting aimed at launching a new round of global trade liberalization talks, Wang said the ROC delegation managed to hold bilateral trade consultations with 21 countries, including Pakistan and Bangladesh, that have never had contact with the ROC in the past.
"During the talks, we solicited their support for our early entry to the WTO," Wang said, adding that all of those countries gave positive responses to the ROC's request.

Wang said some of the countries plan to upgrade the level of contacts with the ROC, and several others said they hope to learn from the ROC's experience in small- and medium-business development, trade management and high-tech industry development.

In addition, 18 ROC lawmakers also attended the Seattle meeting, during which they met with their counterparts from the United States, the European Union, Japan and Canada, to seek their support for the ROC's WTO bid.
"Through the concerted efforts of our executive and legislative branches, I believe that the Seattle meeting has helped push forward our WTO bid," Wang explained.

The ROC attended the Seattle meeting as a WTO observer. During a plenary session, Wang delivered a speech urging all WTO members to support the ROC's early entry in line with the organization's "membership universality principle."

Wang also echoed US President Bill Clinton's call for international assistance to less-developed countries under the framework of the WTO, saying the ROC is more than willing to share with other developing countries its experience in improving its trade regime and boosting economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE PARTY SEEKING ENDORSEMENT FOR PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: After two weeks of effort, the Taiwan Independence Party announced on Saturday that it has gathered more than 50,000 signatures to support the presidential bid of its chairman Cheng Pang-chen in the March 2000 election.
The party is confident that it will gather sufficient signatures from the public to surpass the 220,000 eligibility threshold set by the government, according to a party propaganda official.

At the same time, Cheng announced a "Taiwan independence declaration" in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs before launching a caravan in downtown Taipei to promote the tiny radical opposition party's notion of Taiwan independence.
According to the declaration, Taiwan should relieve itself of its political disputes with mainland China and enjoy an equal and independent status as do other countries around the world.
"Taiwan's 2000 presidential race will mark a starting point for the Independence Party to embark on its task of building an independent nation," Cheng claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STEP UP CAMPAIGN TO LURE FOREIGN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The government is stepping up its campaign to attract foreign visitors to Taiwan in the wake of the massive Sept. 21 earthquake, a tourism official said on Saturday.
Hsu Wen-sheng, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, made the remarks at a seminar in Taichung, central Taiwan.

Hsu said that due to widespread reports by the international media on the earthquake that devastated parts of central Taiwan, foreign tourists are under the mistaken impression that the entire island is a quake-stricken area and are staying away, casting a pall over the usually booming tourism business which has seen hotel occupancy rates plunge by an average of 60 percent.
The number of Taiwan people scheduled to go abroad or travel around the island has also dropped by 50 percent and 70 percent, respectively, he went on.

The Tourism Bureau has initially estimated that as of November, international hotels had lost NT$1.06 billion in room and restaurant revenue, while smaller hotels had lost about NT$600 million in canceled bookings, private resorts had lost about NT$1.21 billion, travel agencies had lost about NT$2.54 million, while 210,000 international airline seats had been canceled as of December.
Total losses incurred by the tourism industry have been estimated at NT$30 billion, bureau officials added.
Hsu said that in order to help revive tourism, the government has provided low-interest loans to tourism operators, and is stepping up an international campaign to attract more foreign visitors.
The government has also planned trips on the theme of lessons to be learned from the earthquake, and has worked out four routes with local travel agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONFIRMS MEETING WITH ALBANIANS, DENIES DIPLOMATIC RUMORS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday that while he did meet certain Albanians who are friendly to the ROC during a visit to Macedonia in August, neither side touched on the subject of establishing diplomatic relations.
Siew was responding to recent foreign wire service reports that the ROC has offered to give the impoverished Balkan country US$1 billion in exchange for diplomatic recognition.
Both Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen and his predecessor Jason Hu also categorically denied the reports.

Siew elaborated on his statement, saying that one of the Albanians he met told him of his wish to increase trade and economic relations with the ROC, but did not touch upon anything relating to foreign aid or monetary assistance.
The premier said he replied that bilateral relations could indeed be strengthened, but that the ways of achieving this would need to be further studied.
Siew did not confirm whether the Albanian official was Peilumb Shullazi, an Albanian legislator and deputy chairman of the Association of Friendship between Albania and Taiwan.
The ROC and Albania do not have representative or liaison offices in each other's countries, and bilateral trade is limited. Albania is a long-time supporter of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 4, or the 27th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to be Pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: General Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: With Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles, Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" is premiered on Broadway.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang Army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular instead of Latin in the Sacraments.
1963: A Kuomintang Central Standing Committee meeting approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng (concurrently vice president), and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7" which orbits the earth for a new record of 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han, and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a week's visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has been nearly quintupled in the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing all aboard.
1989: East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign. Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down, only six weeks after he replaced a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1991: Terry Anderson, the last of a group of Americans held hostage by Shiite kidnappers since March 16, 1985, is released in Beirut, Lebanon.
1994: US Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first US secretary to carry out the new US policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise (ruler) lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ELITE SAID STANDING IN WAY OF EDUCATION REFORM

TEXT.P: Resistance from the elite of Taiwan society, who account for no more than ten percent of the population, is standing in the way of the country's education reforms, an activist claimed on Saturday.

Although the island has come a long way in revamping its education system, there is still a long way to go before the goals of those in favor of education reforms are realized, said Huang Wu-hsiung, a psychology professor at National Taiwan University and an education reformist.
He made the comments at a symposium organized by the China Times newspaper on educational reform.

Huang said that so far, deregulation of the education system has seen a breaking of the monopoly held by teacher training schools on the nation's new teachers, an introduction of an Education Basic Law which shields the education system from political meddling and guarantees an education budget, a mechanism to accredit educational level via examinations, and the formation of local government-level educational councils, said Huang.

However, there has been little change in the educational infrastructure and much work remains to be done in this regard, such as a two-pronged educational system of private and public schools, the establishment of pilot private junior high schools which prepare local students for study at foreign universities, popularization of community colleges, and the relaxation of the academic degree-awarding system.

Huang, who is also the chief organizer of the community colleges in Taipei County, said that one of the problems which has foiled the efforts of the reformist groups is students' obsession with higher academic titles and their "abnormal" devotion to studying merely for high examination marks.

Another hurdle to education reform is the education leaders' tenacious grip on the right to shape the educational system for the public. Their reluctance to return this right to the people has seriously impeded the reform, said Huang.

However, Minister of Education Yung Chaur-shin, who was present at the symposium, ruled out the prospect of awarding academic degrees to graduates of community colleges, saying that requirements stipulated in the Academic Degrees Awarding Law will stifle the flexibility for which community colleges were created.
Skills learned from community colleges should be certified by an accreditation system rather than by academic degrees, said Yung.

He outlined the four targets of reform being pursued by his ministry as easing the strain on junior high school students who vie for limited chances to enroll in prestigious senior high schools; establishing proper nursing schools and a pre-kindergarten education system; promoting community colleges as an alternative channel of study; and taking care of underprivileged students such as those who cannot afford the cost of further education.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Buoyed by overnight gains on the New York Stock Exchange and the government's positive stance toward the bourse before the crucial presidential election next spring, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its bullishness on Saturday.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 31.32 points higher at 7,964.49, with turnover expanding to NT$149.40 billion (US$4.72 billion) amid active buying.

Among the eight major stock categories, the cement sector posted the largest gain of 1.9 percent, followed by textile issues, which rose 1.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares, which went up 0.7 percent.

Paper and pulp issues closed down 1.2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues, which dropped 1 percent, financial stocks, which fell 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks, which declined 0.1 percent.
Construction stocks remained unchanged.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 245 to 236, with 71 shares remaining flat.
The over-the-counter market moved down 0.41 points to close at 190.7, on a turnover of NT$13.07 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 48 points to close at 8,022, with 2,012 contract transactions. Those for January rose 43 points to finish at 8,033, with 154 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March advanced 14 points to close at 8,030, with 20 contract transactions, while those for next June jumped 21 points to close at 8,084, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next September futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 7,974 points for December, 7,990 points for January, 8,016 points for next March, 8,063 points for next June, and 8,078 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, closed mixed.
December TE futures rose 5.15 points to close at 402, with 977 contract transactions, while January TE futures moved up 5.7 points to finish at 401, with 77 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.
December TF futures declined 1.4 points to close at 1,008.8, with 329 contract transactions, and January TF futures remained unchanged at 1,015, with 12 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI PRESIDENT LEAVES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi left Taiwan on Saturday after concluding a five-day state visit, and was bade farewell at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport by Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen.

In addition to visiting cultural and economic establishments and being awarded an honorary doctorate in political science from National Chengchi University, Muluzi and President Lee Teng-hui also signed a joint communique on Friday affirming that the two countries will cooperate closely to promote world peace and prosperity.
This was Muluzi's fourth visit to Taiwan since he assumed the presidency five years ago as the southeast African nation's first directly elected head of state.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND URGES CAUTIONS ON DIRECT TRANSPORTATION LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Direct transportation links with mainland China will jeopardize Taiwan's security by throwing the country's doors wide open to its long-standing rival, a defense official claimed on Friday.

You Liang-hui, deputy director of the Department of Joint Operations under the Ministry of National Defense (MND) told a hearing at the Legislative Yuan that direct links with mainland China will increase the difficulty for the armed forces in monitoring Taiwan's airspace and territorial waters, and will stretch the troops too thin.

Direct shipping links with mainland China would provide mainland Chinese freighters the opportunity of secretly mining Taiwan's harbors -- which often double as military ports -- while mainland Chinese survey vessels could masquerade as fishing boats and map Taiwan's sea lanes, he said.
Mainland Chinese fishing boats, if allowed to operate in Taiwan territorial waters, could be used to ferry troops and heavy military equipment without being detected, the officer claimed.

To address Taiwan's security concerns, You said, his ministry would suggest limiting direct links with mainland China in the preliminary stage to specific harbors via fixed shipping routes and during prescribed times.

Although the armed forces is stepping up its air and sea surveillance, a 24-hour notice to the armed forces of each mainland Chinese vessel entering Taiwan waters would be necessary for effective military supervision, said You.

Meanwhile an official from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Taiwan will not be obliged to set up direct shipping lines with mainland China immediately after its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

However, Fu Teng-chen, director of the Economic Affairs Department under the MAC told the hearing that shipping links with mainland China should begin by 2003 under WTO rules, while direct air links will be inaugurated only after an aviation accord is in place.
Legislator Cho Jung-tai, organizer of the hearing, said the government should be cautious about opening transportation links with the mainland, given Beijing's hostility toward Taipei.
Citing a claim in the Hong Kong-based Chinese-language newspaper Min Pao, Cho said the mainland navy was arming mainland Chinese freighters to make them also suitable for military purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARCHITECT, FOUR OTHERS CHARGED FOR SUBSTANDARD BUILDING

TEXT.P: An architect, a civil engineer and three others were charged on Saturday in connection with the collapse of an apartment building in Taichung County during the Sept. 21 earthquake.
A total of 80 residents were killed after being buried alive in the rubble of the Golden Paris building, said the prosecutor's indictment.

The indictment said that Chiang Shih-hong, architect of the high-rise apartment, failed to monitor the construction of the building which was built in a perfunctory manner without following safe construction practices.
Civil engineer Lo Jen-lung was charged with neglect in his inspection of the building before signing an application form for the building's certificate of residence.

Lai Cheng-far and Ling Tang-chun were each charged on one count of fraud and one count of forgery for helping Chang Ming-chen, owner of the unqualified construction firm which built the apartment block, to borrow a construction license from a qualified company.

Chang emigrated to Canada before the quake and has refused to return to face prosecution, but the owner of the construction firm who lent the license to Chang, Hsu Rung-chu, was named in the indictment.
The Sept. 21 earthquake claimed the lives of about 2,400 people, most of whom were crashed to death in collapsed buildings.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESPECT 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE RELATIONSHIP'
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan, also the ruling Kuomintang's presidential candidate, urged mainland China on Saturday to respect the "special state-to-state relationship" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lien made the appeal in his speech to the opening ceremony for the 11th Asia Outlook Forum being held in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan.

Noting that the division and separate rule of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is a historical and legal fact, Lien said both sides must respect this cold reality and hold regular dialogue with goodwill and on an equal footing.

"Only by so doing can the two sides transcend their political differences and forge a relationship that will contribute to China's eventual peaceful unification under freedom and democracy," Lien said, adding that this is why ROC President Lee Teng-hui has defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Lien pointed out that as the Republic of China fully understands the extreme importance of Taiwan Strait stability to peace in the Asia-Pacific region, the ROC has spared no effort to promote cross-strait rapprochement in a pragmatic manner in hopes of helping safeguard regional security and stability.

Following the end of the Cold War, Lien said the world community has developed new concepts on national security and international relations. The most important change has been abandoning military confrontation and advocating regional cooperation to maintain peace and stability.
Against this background, Lien said all Asia-Pacific nations hope to forge a relationship that signifies peaceful competition and mutual cooperation with a view to achieving "co-prosperity."
Lien further said Beijing's resistence to drop its ideological boundage and hegemonic mentality has made it a potential threat to regional security.
The scholar-turned-politician also expressed his regret that mainland China has not made any goodwill response to the ROC's call for renouncing the use of force in resolving cross-strait issues.
Even so, Lien said, the ROC will continue doing its utmost to ease cross-strait tension and boost steady development of bilateral relations.

Touching on ROC-Japanese ties, Lien expressed gratitude for generous relief aid offered by the Japanese government and private sector after Taiwanwas rattled by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21 this year.

Lien further said there is still ample room for the ROC and Japan to expand cooperation, including defense technology, manpower training, information technology, infrastructure construction and management.
More than 100 scholars, business executives and political analysts from Taiwan and Japan are attending the annual Asia Outlook Forum.

The ROC delegation is headed by Koo Chen-fu, a senior adviser to President Lee and Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, while the Japanese delegation is led by Masao Kamei, a senior adviser to Sumitomo Electric Industries.
Koo and Mineo Nakajima, president of the Tokyo University of Foreign Studies, jointly presided over the opening ceremony, held at the Tainan City Council auditorium.

The agenda for this year's meeting will include relations between marine civilization and technological networks; Japan's development trends and Taiwan's new political identification; and cross-Taiwan Strait relations and Asian-Pacific security in the digital age.

The Asia Outlook Forum, founded in 1989, is aimed at pooling the wisdom of the elite of business, political and academic communities in Taiwan and Japan to help boost bilateral substantive ties as well as regional prosperity and stability.
The forum holds its annual meeting alternately in Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD GAUGE MILITARY CONTACT WITH BEIJING: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The United States should gauge its military contacts with mainland China carefully, according to a former American military attache to Beijing.

It should adopt a simple standard to govern future military cooperation: "Do nothing to improve the People's Liberation Army's capability to wage war against Taiwan or friends and allies of the United States," Larry M. Wortzel, director of the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, wrote in a new analysis.

Wortzel said that US armed forces need to conduct a security dialogue with mainland China, but the Defense Department must make clear during these discussions that the United States will continue to support the efforts of Taiwan's armed forces to maintain its defenses; view Beijing's missile activities and nuclear proliferation as a grave threat to its security; and seek a theater missile defense system to protect its forces in East Asia and offer that system to its friends and allies.

He said Americans should welcome Washington's recent agreement with Beijing allowing mainland China admission to the World Trade Organization, but pointed out that normal trade relations do not mean normal military relations and "relations with China must be kept in the proper perspective."

Under the Clinton administration, military-to-military contacts, or "engagement activities, allowed mainland Chinese military officers broad access to US warships, exercises and even military manuals, he pointed out.

But once it became clear that Beijing had obtained US nuclear weapons technology through espionage, Congress felt compelled to caution the Clinton administration to limit such contacts by adding a restriction to the 2000 National Defense Authorization Act.

This prohibited the secretary of defense from authorizing military exchanges that "create a national security risk," seeking to ensure that military contacts with the PLA would not improve mainland China's ability to wage war, project force, threaten Taiwan, or repress its own people, noted Wortzel.

Unfortunately, he wrote, it is not clear whether the Pentagon understands the seriousness with which Congress considers the risk. But the Pentagon can no longer ignore the fact that the "strategic partnership" heralded by President Bill Clinton is, for Beijing, strategic competition and "any military-to-military contacts must be structured with this development in mind."

In 1996, Wortzel said, mainland China's military leaders were embarrassed by their inability to respond to the presence of US aircraft carrier battlegroups off Taiwan, which were responding to Beijing's military exercises in the Taiwan Straits during Taiwan's presidential elections.

In the years since then, the PLA has worked harder to find ways to deter US military involvement in the area, such as improving its capabilities in information or electronic warfare; extending the operational range and capabilities of its air force with airborne early warning and control systems, new missiles, and air-to-air refueling systems; and making new missile threats against Taiwan.

Wortzel stressed that "reopening normal military exchanges with China as though it was just another Pacific region security partner is the wrong approach." The Pentagon should establish clear standards for future US-mainland China military contacts. There should be no further "joint exercises;" the release of US war-gaming or combat simulation computer software to the PLA should cease; and the Defense Department should talk only with those leaders in Beijing who will make the decisions governing when mainland China uses force or goes to war.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WILLING TO DISCUSS ALL TOPICS WITH BEIJING ON EQUAL TERMS: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said on Friday that Taiwan is willing to discuss all topics with mainland China on an equal footing, so long as Beijing demonstrates goodwill toward Taipei.

Speaking on the "Face the Public" program on the Taipei-based Broadcasting Corporation of China, Su said that Taiwan welcomes discussion of all the issues facing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, including direct trade, transportation and postal links.

He said that most of the problems surrounding the establishment of postal links have already been resolved, and that the volume of cross-strait mail and telephone calls now surpasses that between Taiwan and the United States, although all mail must travel via a third country.
The MAC chief said that indirect trade links between Taiwan and the mainland are also well established, while direct transportation links will be implemented in the future.
Taiwan is planning to further ease its restrictions on trade with mainland China in compliance with World Trade Organization regulations, if Beijing displays goodwill toward Taipei.

Su admitted that conditions are not yet ripe for establishing direct transportation links, but added that Taipei will discuss the issue with Beijing on the premise of upholding national security and national dignity.

He predicted that direct shipping links may be achieved fairly easily, perhaps within the next three years, while negotiations on aviation links will be conducted once shipping links have been established.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAILURE OF WTO TALKS WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The failure of the latest round of the World Trade Organization (WTO) ministerial-level meeting will not hinder Taiwan's efforts to join the organization, a member of the Taiwan delegation to the talks said on Friday.

Although the meeting wrapped up without having achieved progress on several key issues on labor, the environment and investment due to sharp differences between developed and developing countries, the Republic of China official pointed out that the just-concluded meeting had virtually nothing to do with the question of Taiwan's membership, and will not affect the country's bid to enter the world trade regulatory body.
"Taiwan's top priority at the present stage is to enter the WTO, and the fiasco of this round of negotiations will not hamper Taiwan's prospects of becoming a WTO member," he stressed.

The hastily concluded meeting -- a result of fierce protests from anti-WTO demonstrators in the streets of Seattle -- is not expected to have an immediate impact on global trade deals, and thus will not affect Taiwan's foreign trade or its trade policy, the official went on to explain.

As the next round of WTO negotiations, originally slated to open next spring, might be postponed as a result of the failure of the Seattle talks, the ROC official predicted that Taiwan will probably be able to attend the next round as a full WTO member.
The Taiwan delegation attended the Seattle talks as an observer.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG'S POPULARITY HIGHEST, BUT LIEN LEADS IN ABILITY RATING: POLL

TEXT.P: The results of a recent public opinion poll show that independent presidential hopeful James Soong remains the most popular candidate, while ruling Kuomintang presidential candidate Lien Chan is believed to be the most competent.
Poll results released on Saturday show that if the next presidential election were to take place the following day, 32.9 percent of the respondents would vote for the Soong-Chang Chao-hsiung ticket.

In contrast, the KMT's Lien-Vincent Siew ticket received the support of 22 percent of those interviewed, while 20.2 percent threw their support behind the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ticket of Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu.
An additional 23.6 percent of the respondents either declined to answer the question or said they have yet to make a decision on their choice.
The telephone survey of 1,199 adults was conducted from Nov. 27-29 by the ROC Association for Public Opinion Research.

According to the survey, the Chen-Lu ticket was the least popular, with 26.5 percent saying they would least like to see a victory for the DPP candidates in the 2000 presidential election. This was followed by the Soong-Chang ticket, with a 22.6 percent disapproval rating, and the Lien-Siew ticket came in third, with only 16.8 percent saying they would least like to see success for the KMT ticket.

The same poll also found that 29.4 percent of the respondents believe the Lien-Siew ticket to be most capable of maintaining Taiwan's stability and security, followed by the Soong-Chang team, with 24.9 percent, and the Chen-Lu ticket, with 12.2 percent.

In addition, 32.4 percent said they think that the Lien-Siew team would be most capable of expanding Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers, while the Soong-Chang team trailed at 21.9 percent, and the Chen-Lu ticket came in third, with 17.8 percent.

Meanwhile, 30.2 percent said they believe that the Lien-Siew ticket would be most competent in governing the country, followed by the Soong-Chang team, with 29.9 percent, and the Chen-Lu team, with 19.5 percent.

The Lien-Siew team also led in terms of ability to maintain Taiwan's economic prosperity, with a support rating of 41.2 percent, followed by the Soong-Chang ticket, with 20.5 percent, and the Chen-Lu team, with 11.8 percent.

An interesting finding was that only 5.9 percent said they think the Lien-Siew team would be likely to make a decision which violates Taiwan's interests at a critical juncture, compared to 21.4 percent who believe that the Soong-Chang team could make a decision against Taiwan's interests. Meanwhile, 12.8 percent said they think the Chen-Lu team could make a bad decision at a crucial moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Special state-to-state relationship conducive to 'win-win' ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, says Vice President Lien Chan.
The China Times:
Disputes on 'three direct links' between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait escalating.
The United Daily News:
Ministerial-level WTO meeting in Seattle fails.
The Liberty Times:
WTO negotiations in Seattle end in failure.
The China Post:
WTO talks fail in wake of protests; Seattle meeting helps boost ROC's WTO bid: minister.
The Taiwan News:
No sound from Mars -- Polar Lander descends but sends back no signal; Scientists keep trying to make contact.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE CHEN SHUI-BIAN VISITS UK

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bian, the Democratic Progressive Party candidate for Taiwan's presidential election next March, starts his two-day visit to the UK Sunday to promote his version of "the Third Way" politics.

The former dissident lawyer and Taipei mayor from 1994 to 1998 will give a public lecture Monday at the prestigious London School of Economics and Political Science on "the Third Way for Taiwan: a new political perspective." The lecture will be chaired by LSE's director and author of "The Third Way", Professor Anthony Giddens.
Chen is expected to outline his hopes for Taiwan's future development and "Third Way" solutions to crucial issues in Taiwan.

While in London, the former human rights lawyer will also meet scholars and experts at such institutes as the Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies, the Chatham House, the International Institute for Strategic Studies, the Fabian Society and the Economist Intelligence Unit. Chen also plans to meet UK scholars who have conducted field studies in Taiwan.

Before he leaves early Tuesday morning for Brussels to continue his European tour, which will also take him to the Hague, Chen is expected to squeeze in a call at the Parliament to meet with members of the All Party Taiwan Group, and will give interviews to journalists at the BBC and the Economist.

DOC.HEADLINE: NA DEPUTIES CALL FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF NATIONAL DISASTER CENTER

TEXT.P: A group of National Assembly (NA) deputies on Sunday called for the quick establishment of a national disaster management center in Taiwan in order to better deal with emergency situations.

The establishment of the disaster management center, which is expected to be similar to the United States' Center of Excellence in Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance (COE) and the Pacific Disaster Center (PDC), both located in Hawaii, will also be conducive to promoting Taiwan's "emergency-help diplomacy," said the NA deputies.

At a press conference about their recent visit to the PDC, the NA deputies said a Taiwanese version of the COE or the PDC, to serve as a counterpart to the US agencies, will provide a proper channel for normalizing and accelerating cooperative exchanges in emergency management between Taiwan and the United States.

NA Deputy Tsai Chih-hung said the PDC has expressed a willingness to render relevant assistance to help Taiwan further strengthen its rescue and emergency management capabilities, and the PDC director would like to visit Taiwan sometime to expedite cooperation.

Specialists and personnel from the COE and the PDC pitched in with emergency work after the 1995 Kobe earthquake and after the Tokyo subway sarin nerve gas attack launched by the cult group Aum Shinri Kyo.

The COE and PDC were established in 1990 separately under the auspices of the US Congress and the Pentagon, mainly for the purpose of analyzing and dealing with natural disasters, including typhoons, earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, in the Pacific Rim and other areas around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 5, or the 28th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1594: Gerhardus Mercator, originally Gerhard Kremer, the great Flemish cartographer who developed the Mercator projection in 1568, dies at the age of 82.
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1901: American animated film producer Walt Disney is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1904: The Japanese destroy the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun).
1906: Russian Admiral Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship "Chaoho." His attempt fails the following day.
1926: French impressionist painter Claude Monet, who was born in 1840, dies at the age of 86.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of Prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, passed in 1919.
1945: Six US Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without trace in the Atlantic near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang, as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw south.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens its branch office in Taipei.
1974: A five-member mission of the Central Committee of the Democratic Republican Party of the Republic of Korea led by Vhang Kyung Soon arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1975: Campaign activities for the December 20 Legislative Yuan elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, California, to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1976: Dr. Guillermo Putzeys Alvarez, the Republic of Guatemala's minister of education, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1977: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt severs links with Syria, Libya, Algeria, Iraq and South Yemen.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishment on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to jail terms, ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years, by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, for conducting direct trade with the Chinese communists.
1995: Javier Solana, Spanish foreign Minister, is appointed secretary-general of NATO.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLDEN HORSE AWARDS PRESENTATION SLATED FOR DEC. 12

TEXT.P: The annual Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony is scheduled to be held on the evening of Dec. 12, with stars and film professionals from Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong and other Asian countries participating.

Several dozen of the hot stars and popular singers as well as senior actors and actresses of Mandarin-language motion pictures from Taiwan and Hong Kong will attend the presentation to receive or to present Golden Horse Awards, the Taiwan equivalent of the Oscars, said staff of TVBS, which will sponsor the presentation ceremony.
Among the stars presenting awards will be the dream pair of Taiwan-born sex symbol Ching Cheng Wu, also known by his Japanese name Takeshi Kaneshiro, and Japanese actress Rie Miyazawa.

During the gala-style ceremony, which will be televised live, Hong Kong's "God of Singing" Jacky Chang, Taiwan's supreme singer A Mei, and other popular singers will add color to the gathering of stars by performing.

Many Hong Kong films are expected to win awards, while several Taiwanese films have also been nominated for awards, including nominations for best actor, best actress, best supporting actor and best supporting actress.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN SPEAKS IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By David Wang, K. C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman of Taiwan's largest opposition party, the Democratic Progressive Party, said in New York over the weekend that the party's mainland China policy will be to be patient and not rash.

Lin expressed the hope that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will continue having exchanges so that the mainland understands that the wish of the people on the sovereign independent island of Taiwan is to live in peace with the mainland and maintain mutually beneficial relations.

With respect to the upcoming presidential election, he said that although the DPP's poll showed that independent presidential hopeful James Soong leads both DPP presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian and the ruling KMT's presidential candidate Lien Chan, Soong's support rate is gradually slipping while Lien's is rising.
He said that only Chen's support rate has remained stable, which he said will be favorable to Chen if Soong and Lien play off against each other in the presidential election next March.
Lin made the remarks in a speech to a Taiwanese businessmen association in Flushing, New York, on Saturday.
While answering questions after the speech, he said that he does not favor a direct confrontation with mainland China given the vast difference in the sizes of the two sides.

Earlier in New York, Lin reiterated the party's mainland policy, saying that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should engage each other and maintain "sincere" dialogue so as to enhance mutual understanding.

He told more than 300 overseas Taiwanese and mainland pro-democracy activists during a luncheon that it is a historical fact that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state and that all related issues should be discussed based on that fact.
Any changes to the status quo should be decided upon by the people of Taiwan through a referendum, Lin said.

He criticized Beijing for being impractical in trying to have Taiwan unify with the mainland and expressed the hope that Beijing might understand the people of Taiwan more and increase exchanges between people on the two sides.
He said that he believes that if peace in the Taiwan Starit can be maintained, it will greatly benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait and contribute to peace in Asia and the world.
Lin, who flew in to New York from Toronto on Saturday, is scheduled to leave for Houston to attend the inauguration ceremony of the DPP branch in the southern US.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% IN POLL DISAGREE WITH SOONG'S MAINLAND POLICY

TEXT.P: A recent poll showed that 60 percent of respondents disagree to the mainland China policy of James Soong, the independent presidential candidate for the election next March.

The survey, with a posted error margin of 6.97 percent, was conducted by the New Image public survey center from Nov. 30 through Dec. 2, interviewing 1,092 qualified voters in Taiwan in order to gauge public opinion on the mainland policies of the six presidential hopefuls.

Merely 21 percent of the people surveyed supported Soong's view that Beijing has shown goodwill toward Taiwan by proposing the idea of "peaceful reunification through a `one China, two systems' formula," and it is only that Taiwan has not noticed the goodwill.

Seventy-eight percent of those polled said they support the ruling Kuomintang presidential candidate Lien Chan's mainland policy that states Taiwan will adjust its defense strategy and opinions if the mainland demonstrates goodwill and respect.

On Chen Shui-bien's proposal of promoting active and cooperative exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in order to develop deeper mutual trust, 72.9 percent of the respondents registered their support.
Meanwhile 45.8 percent said they support independent candidate Hsu Hsin-liang's idea of opening the "three-links" with mainland China with no conditions attached.

Chen is the presidential candidate of Taiwan's largest opposition party -- the Democratic Progressive Party, which has introduced to Taiwan the concept of the "Third Way," a new political trend in several places around the world.

As to the New Party candidate Lee Ao's view that mainland China's "one China, two systems" formula is not a bad proposal, 74 percent of those polled expressed strong disapproval, while only 15 percent said they support Lee's argument.
Over 50 percent of the citizens polled expressed their opposition to the pro-Taiwan independence policy of Chen Pang-chen, presidential candidate of the Taiwan Independent Party, the survey showed.

Commenting on the survey, both Professor Pan Hsi-tang, an expert on mainland China affairs at Tamkang University, and Professor Lee Teng-ko of National Chengchi University indicated that the "one China, two systems" policy seems to have affected the popularity of some of the presidential hopefuls.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INCINERATORS SAID TO BE RELEASING HIGH LEVELS OF DIOXIN

TEXT.P: Incinerators in Taiwan have been releasing an alarmingly high level of dioxin, a carcinogenic chemical, into the air, Professor Chang Chang-chuan of National Taiwan University said on Sunday.
Professor Chang made the remarks after analyzing a report by the non-profit Environmental Quality Protection Foundation.
Chang said that the amount of dioxin released by the five incinerators in Taiwan is between 9.35 and 32.09 times higher than levels in the United States.
The five incinerators are located in Neihu and Mucha in Taipei City, Hsintien and Hsulin in Taipei County, and Wenshan in Taichung, central Taiwan.

Chang said that according to the report, the biggest carcinogenic threat comes from the oldest incinerator in Neihu, with risks 494 times higher than those of the US. The second most dangerous incinerator is the one located in Hsulin, with levels 189 fold higher than the US, followed by the one in Mucha at 163 times higher, the one in Hsintien at 78 fold higher, and in Wenshan at 42 times greater.

Chang said that, in addition to dioxin, other carcinogenic chemicals such as chromium and cadmium are also present in the emissions and that based on calculations, the cancer risk is between 9.35 times and 32.09 times of that of the US.

The people of Taipei City's exposure to carcinogenic substances is more than 2,000 times higher than the average exposure level of people living in the United States, while the exposure level for people living in Taipei County is more than 1,000 times higher than that of people living in California.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA'S NATIONAL CONGRESS PRESIDENT VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Guatemala President of the National Congress Leonel Eliseo Lopez Rodas and his wife are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Sunday for a week-long visit.

During their stay, Lopez and his wife will call on President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew, President of Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, President of Control Yuan Frederick Chien, Minister of Foreign Affairs Chen Chien-jen, and other government officials.
They will also visit several cultural and economic establishments of the Republic of China. They are scheduled to depart from Taipei on Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA INCIDENT SAID TO HAVE BEEN A SOCIAL REFORM MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Local political critics said that the Formosa Incident which occurred on Dec. 10, 1979 was not purely an opposition movement but instead a wider social reform movement.

The Formosa Incident refers to the turmoil which broke out after opposition groups rallied in Kaohsiung to mark World Human Rights Day, resulting in the arrest of 61 political activists, including Huang Hsin-chieh, Shih Ming-teh , Yao Chia-wen, and Lin I-hsiung. A total of 51 activists were eventually sentenced to prison terms ranging from a few months to life.

Shih Ming-teh, one of chief activists, said all the reforms they had proposed 20 years ago have already been passed into law, which has not only vindicated the incident but also brought about the hope of a brighter future for Taiwan.
Shih made the remarks at a symposium jointly sponsored by the China Times and the New Taiwan Educational and Cultural Research Foundation to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the Formosa Incident.

"We should reevaluate the Formosa Incident and its impact," Shih said, adding that "after reviewing it, the movement should be divided into three stages -- the organization of an opposition for the election in 1978, the incident in Kaohsiung (Formosa Incident) in 1979, and the judgment of these events that followed."

Shih said that in the first stage, an opposition force emerged to challenge the main-stream conservative force, while the Kaohsiung incident helped encourage the rebuilding of the Taiwanese opposition spirit which disappeared after the incident of Feb. 28, 1947, in which hundreds of people were killed and thousands disappeared.
The public judgment of the Formosa Incident in the third stage pointed Taiwan on a democratic course, Shih said.

Shih went on to say that the entire platform put forth by the anti-government activists at the time has since been totally implemented. President Lee Teng-hui's recent redefining of cross Taiwan strait relations as special state-to-state relationship completely echoed their proposal made 20 years ago, Shih said.
Political commentator Nan Fang-shou added that he hopes that Formosa incident activists will put the past behind them in order to focus their efforts on democratization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER RETURNS FROM WTO MEETING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Sunday that Taiwan will certainly make due adjustments on cross-strait trade after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization.
Wang made the remarks at a press conference after he returned home from the latest round of WTO ministerial talks in Seattle from Nov. 30 to Dec.3.
Responding to remarks by a mainland Chinese delegate to the talks, Wang also said that if there is enough goodwill shown by Beijing, Taiwan will make wider adjustments.

Mainland China Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Minister Shi Guangsheng said in Seattle that Taiwan would violate WTO regulations if it continued its ban on direct trade, postal and transport relations with the mainland, commonly referred to as the "three direct links."

He said the ROC will make some adjustments to its trade policy in accordance with WTO regulations following its entry into the organization, but added that "we will not consider shipping or aviation links issues, since no existing WTO rules regulate such issues."

Wang said that as of the present time, there are no plans to impose exclusion clauses on any of the WTO members, which must be done before WTO accession and requires the approval of two thirds of all WTO members.
Wang also said that although the latest round of WTO talks ended in failure amid protests, this will not affect Taiwan's bid to enter the world trade regulatory body.

He also said that during the WTO meeting, the ROC delegation managed to hold bilateral trade consultations with 21 countries, including Pakistan and Bangladesh, that had never had contact with the ROC in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11TH WORLD CUP AMATEUR SOFT TENNIS CHAMPIONSHIP TO OPEN DEC. 10

TEXT.P: The 11th World Cup Amateur Soft Tennis Championship will be held at the National Physical Educational College in Linkou, a suburb of Taipei, from Dec. 10 to Dec. 14.
More than 200 players from 17 countries, including the host country -- the Republic of China will take part in the five-day competition.
This will be the third time the ROC has hosted the international competition, having previously sponsored the second and fifth tournaments.

In addition to the ROC, players from Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan, Thailand, Vietnam, the United States, Brazil, Dominican Republic, Mongolia and Kazakhstan will compete in the tournament.
The tournament will be divided into six categories, namely group, single and double divisions for men and for women competitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN RESERVES TO SET NEW RECORD

TEXT.P: Propelled by continuing export expansion and capital inflow, the Republic of China's foreign exchange reserves are expected to set a new record high at the end of 1999, but will remain third on the list of world's largest foreign reserves behind Japan and mainland China, an official of the Central Bank of China(CBC) said on Sunday.
The foreign reserves have increased monthly since levels broke the US$90 billion mark at the end of 1998. The reserves set a record of US$102.67 billion at the end of October.
Chou Ya-ting, director of the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department, attributed the increase to the continuous export expansion and the inflow of capital.
Chou estimated that the nation's foreign exchange will break the US$105 billion mark by the end of 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR CARIBBEAN CONFAB

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang on Sunday left for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
Chang will deliver a speech during the meeting on Taiwan's trade and the relief and reconstruction work after the Sept. 21 earthquake that devastated central Taiwan and claimed more than 2,400 lives.
He will also host a cocktail party in honor of the heads of state and ranking officials participating in the meeting.

The conference was established by the top 100 enterprises in the United States under the proposal of the Rockefeller family. The heads of state and ranking officials of the Caribbean countries have been invited to take part in the meeting.
Taiwan began participating in the annual conference in 1986.
Panel discussions will be held to cover such issues as textiles, telecommunications, e-commerce, finance, trade, tourism and transportation.
The presidents of Venezuela, the Dominican Republic and Haiti will take part in this year's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: 200 NEWSPAPERS IN CHINA TO BE CLOSED DOWN

TEXT.P: Beijing has issued a decree to merge all of the so-called "small newspapers" in each province into one newspaper, and place it under the management and control of the communist party, a human rights group said here Sunday.

The decree will effectively eliminate at least 200 tabloid newspapers in China in the first half of next year, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China reported. There are 2,160 newspapers in China at the present time.

The tabloids are mostly published by provincial public security authorities and other government departments. In addition to government-approved news and propaganda materials, they carry reports on crimes, accidents, and other matters that can hardly be found in staid party newspapers.

The government wants to eliminate the tabloids, because their rapid growth in recent years have reduced the influence and circulation of the party newspapers, which are the government's tools to control news reporting and public opinions, the information center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang presidential ticket forms campaign team.
The China Times:
The Chiayi county government will sign an agreement with state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. on the establishment of a new naphtha cracking plant.
The United Daily News:
Economics Minister Wang says indirect trade will stay put even after both sides of the Taiwan Strait enter the WTO.
The Liberty Times:
Foreign capital will be banned from entering Taiwan if threatening Taiwan's national security.
The China Post:
ROC minister calls on PRC to 'loosen up' policies.
The Taiwan News:
Why the WTO talks in Seattle failed? Big US partners joined with poor countries to defeat Clinton.
