DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIA-ROC TIES EXPECTED TO BE CLOSER AFTER RE-RUN

TEXT.P: Bilateral ties between Macedonia and the Republic of China are expected to become even closer after the Balkan state held a partial election re-run Sunday, reconfirming the victory of president-elect Boris Trajkovski, officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Monday.

The partial re-run, held in areas populated mainly by ethnic Albanians, took place in order to put to rest allegations of vote-rigging in the first run of the presidential election held on Nov. 14 in which center-right Trajkovski tied with Social Democrat Tito Petkovski. A run-off was held on Nov. 15.
In Sunday's re-run, Trajkovski was still victorious, winning by a wide vote margin, garnering 133,667 of 161,174 votes cast.
The ROC will send a congratulatory mission to Macedonia for Trajkovski, probably to be headed by ROC envoy to Macedonia Peter Cheng, according to MOFA officials.
Trajkovski had been instrumental in pushing for formal diplomatic ties with the ROC when he was Macedonia's deputy foreign minister.

He and Macedonian Assembly President Savo Klimovski, leading a 26-member mission from Skopje, visited Taipei in early March following the establishment of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries on Jan. 27.

During his stay in Taiwan, Trajkovski showed a keen interest in Taiwan in many areas, according to Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu. He was particularly interested in the ROC's system of government and its Constitution, asking for a ROC 1999 Yearbook for his personal study, Hu added.
Trajkovski's victory in the presidential election will facilitate Macedonia's push for reforms and bring it closer to the European Union, Hu noted.
Hu added that Trajkovski's victory also gives a shot in the arm to bilateral ties between Macedonia and the ROC since Trajkovski has always supported increased exchanges with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MME. CHIANG KAI-SHEK CONCERNED WITH ROC DEVELOPMENT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Mme. Chiang, wife of the late Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek, is deeply concerned with the ROC's development in various fields and often prays for the welfare of the people of Taiwan, one of her granddaughters-in-law said here on Sunday.

Fang Chih-yi, wife of the third son of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, told the CNA about how Mme. Chiang has been doing recently during a Kuomintang's gathering to celebrate the party's 105th founding anniversary.

Fang, who recently went to New York to spend Thanksgiving Day with Mme. Chiang, said Mme. Chiang, 102, is in good health and high spirits. Her mind is completely clear and she concerns herself with the question of the ROC's development in various fields through news media.
Fang said Mme. Chiang, of course, hopes that the ruling Kuomintang can win the year 2000 presidential election. However, she declined to comment on issues concerning the election, Fang said.

Fang said Mme. Chiang is a sincere Christian with a very peaceful mind and often prays for the welfare of the people of Taiwan. The founder of the National Women's League, ROC, and former chairperson of the organization, Mme. Chiang had instructed members of the league to do their best to assist the 921-quake victims and help in the reconstruction of the quake-stricken zones, Fang said.
Mme. Chiang, who has lived in New York for years, will exhibit 10 of her paintings in New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles beginning in January, 2000.
With the next century approaching, Mme. Chiang thanked God for his kindness in letting her live such a long life and said she is now blessed with the ability to view things with a peaceful mind.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEN LOSING WITH COLLAPSE OF WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: Australian exporters are expected to lose up to US$15 billion a year in new exports thanks to the collapse of World Trade Organization (WTO) talks in Seattle last week while Canberra has vowed to continue its push for further liberalization in agricultural trade.

In a statement faxed to the CNA on Monday, Trade Minister Mark Vaile said that "naturally I am disappointed with the outcome. ... Australia will continue to push hard for the further opening of markets for agriculture and processed foods, for the elimination of export subsidies and for cuts to trade distorting domestic subsidies."

"Agriculture was a key focus for Australia at this meeting. We made some significant progress on developing a detailed agricultural mandate ... but unfortunately we were not able to bridge some of the final gaps with the US, Japan and others," Vaile said.
He said other contentious issues such as investment, competition and labor had also complicated the agenda.

Government officials believe the trade talks will be renewed next year, but the delay in reaching agreement on the further liberalization of agricultural trade this year is expected to cost Australia up to US$15 billion in new exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL CONTENDER VOICES CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: US Senator John McCain (R-AZ), a Republican presidential contender, stressed Sunday that Washington has to make it very clear to Communist China that any aggression committed against Taiwan is "a violation of the `one China' policy, which calls for peaceful reunification," adding a warning to Beijing that the consequences of aggression against Taiwan "would be very significant."

During an interview on NBC's "Meet The Press" program, McCain pointed out that he does not believe that Communist China is America's strategic partner as President Bill Clinton stated in 1998 when he went to Beijing. "Our strategic partner is Japan," said the senator.

The Arizona Republican, however, added he is very optimistic that, with the advent of the Internet and the increasing flow of information, "if we can keep the pressure on the Chinese to improve their human rights, to stop the terrible things that they are doing in Tibet, that we will see democracy and freedom eventually come to China."

Earlier this year, when tension ran high across the Taiwan Straits following President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relations" remarks, McCain said that "if the US is to abide by the `one China' policy, we must be no less committed to the other basic principle that is supposed to govern our relations with China and Taiwan -- that the reunification of China must only occur peacefully, in other words, voluntarily."

"Strategic ambiguity will not serve US interests or values in this current crisis. We must be very clear with Beijing. The United States will do what it must to help defend freedom and stability in Asia," he emphasized.

McCain agreed that America must engage Communist China "if we are to maximize our influence over how that immense nation emerges as a world power." Therefore, he has opposed efforts to revoke normal trade relations status for mainland China or freeze US diplomacy toward Communist China.

But he said "while we should hope for and work toward the best end -- that our relationship will influence China to become an internationally responsible and politically enlightened country, we must also prepare for the other contingency, that China emerges as the primary threat to American interests and values."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CHILD POVERTY RATE TENTH LOWEST IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's child poverty rate is the 10th lowest in the world, while Russia's is the worst among industrialized nations, according to a study commissioned by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Monday reported that the study on Child Poverty Across Industrialized Nations, which covers Taiwan and some Eastern European countries for the first time, shows Russia is the worst among a list of 25 countries. Trailing behind Russia are the US, the UK, Italy and Australia.

The study, co-authored by Dr. Bruce Bradbury, senior research fellow at the Social Policy Research Center at the University of New South Wales in Sydney, used two different measures to define poverty.

One method was to use the US poverty line as a common reference converted into the currencies of each country analyzed. It is a measure of poverty based on people's real purchasing power, the daily reported.

Using this method, Taiwan's child poverty rate was calculated at 4.3 percent, compared to 20 percent for Australia and 98 percent for Russia. Switzerland's child poverty rate was calculated at only 1.6 percent while Sweden's was 3.7 percent.

The study also used a measure of relative poverty to compare how far the poorest children have fallen behind the living standards of the average person in a country. By this calculation, 17 percent of Australia's children were defined as poor, compared with 6.3 percent in Taiwan, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN TO NAME ANNETTE LU AS RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to formally name Taoyuan County chief Annette Lu on Friday as his running mate for the year 2000 presidential election, DPP sources said on Monday.
Although it has been widely rumored that Lu will be Chen's running mate, no formal announcement of the arrangement has yet been made.

According to Lee Yi-yang, Chen's deputy campaign manager, Dec. 10 was chosen as the date to announce the Chen-Lu ticket in order to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the Formosa Incident, which occurred on Dec. 10, 1979.

The Formosa Incident occurred in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and was labeled as one of the most prominent opposition movements in Taiwan's history. It resulted in the arrest of 61 political activists, including many who later became founders or heavyweights of the DPP, which was formally established in 1986.
As political dissidents, both Chen and Lu served prison terms for their opposition activities.

Carrying a slogan of "A New Taiwan Team, A New Hope in the Century," the Chen-Lu ticket also signals a major re-start of the DPP, which has played a major role in checking the ruling Kuomintang over the past decade, said Lee.

Meanwhile, Chen is currently in London where he has met with Prof. Anthony Giddens, author of "The Third Way," a book which has had a tremendous influence on Chen's own political outlook, as witnessed by his slogan: "the third way politics for Taiwan: a new political respective."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HAILS BUILDING OF 8TH NAPHTHA CRACKER AS `MILLENNIUM PROJECT'

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday said that the building of the eighth naphtha cracker in southern Taiwan will be "the major construction project of the nation as it enters the new millennium. "

Siew made the remarks in Chiayi County as he attended the signing of a letter of intent for the NT$600 billion (US$18.93 billion) project between Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) President Pan Wen-yen and Chiayi County Magistrate Lee Ya-ching.

The premier said that after the island's entry into the World Trade Organization, it will face a new situation in regional economic development, and the building of the eighth naphtha cracker will signal the nation's economic development as it enters the next millennium.
He backed his statement by citing as an example the building of the sixth naphtha cracker in Miaoliao, Yunlin County, pointing out that the project helped boost prosperity in the area.
Magistrate Lee lauded Siew, saying that "Chiayi-born Siew knows the local needs best."

Lee stressed that the county government will keep tabs on the environment as the work is carried out, and he invited representatives from local communities to also take part in the monitoring activities.

The county chief was elated about the choice of the Putai Salt Field as the location for the new naphtha cracker, saying that the project will create jobs, increase tax revenue and enrich the county coffers.

But while Lee said the building of the naphtha cracker will help boost across-the-board development of the county, anti-eighth naphtha cracker activists from Putai said that Lee's welcome of the project can be likened to "making a deal with Faustus."

They said that the invitation for the "high-risk and pollution-generating" petrochemical industry to set foot in residential areas of Putai will jeopardize the lives and property of the people living there.

They pointed out that once the naphtha cracker sets up in Putai, the coastal areas of Chiayi will fall prey to greedy conglomerates. Not only will the ecology be destroyed, but lives and property will be subject to "an unprecedented threat."

They noted that the prosperity to be created by the petrochemical complex will be "phony." With disadvantages far outnumbering the merits of the project, they said they are not opposed to local prosperity, but have the welfare of their progeny as their major concern.

The project was first planned by CPC and a score of other petrochemical companies four years ago with the purpose of increasing supplies of petrochemical materials and sharpening the competitive edge of the domestic refinery and petrochemical industry.

The group had originally wanted to build the naphtha cracker in Nanchou, in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County, but did not obtain approval from Pingtung County. Later, Chiayi County Magistrate Lee and other local heavyweights showed keen interest in hosting the project, and the site was eventually switched to Chiayi.
It is understood that the petrochemical complex will also set aside two areas to develop a hi-tech industrial park, sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 6, or the 29th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years, and although he was indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1905: Roald Amundsen, Norwegian explorer, lands at Fort Egbert, Alaska, after a two-and-a-half year voyage along America's Arctic coast in his 14-meter cutter.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in US history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Teheran Conference.
1957 : The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of ROC military service to muster the number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1971: South Korea's President Park Chung Hee warns of the danger of invasion from the north and declares a national emergency.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: US President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for US air and naval basses there.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Chinese communists ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members to the National Assembly are newly elected in the 1986 Parliamentary by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislature revises the "Labor Standards Law" so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN STRESSES TAIWAN SECURITY IN BBC INTERVIEW

TEXT.P: Presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian said in a Chinese-language interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. on Sunday that Taiwan's security should take precedence over all other issues.

Chen, fielded by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to run in the March 2000 presidential election, said he supports the establishment of any dialogue mechanism conducive to relations between Taiwan and mainland China, so long as the island's security is not compromised.

Questioned by an audience member during the interview on whether Taiwan will withdraw President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" theory on cross-Taiwan Strait ties, Chen said that although he supports the normalization of relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the island's sovereignty is an issue which cannot be bargained over.

Emphasizing that Taiwan should stand firm on its stance, and need not dance to Beijing's tune, Chen said it is important to pool wisdom on the issue. However, he pointed out that the British government's agreement to the "one country, two systems" formula designed by Beijing to rule Hong Kong is not a good example for Taiwan to follow.

Taiwan and the mainland should step up contacts, dialogue and negotiations in order to reduce the possibility of misjudgments and misunderstandings, Chen went on, but he stressed that Taiwan is an independent sovereignty, and that the island is not a local government of the People's Republic of China, nor is it a region or a part of mainland China.
"Taiwan does not want to be ruled by Chinese communists and disappear from the face of the earth," he said.

Chen had arrived in London earlier in the day at the start of a two-day visit to the United Kingdom. He will proceed to Brussels and The Hague before concluding his current three-country European tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEEP LIEN CALLS FOR BETTER CARE OF ELDERLY DEMENTIA PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Monday that the government will join forces with the private sector to offer better health care and economic security for elderly people.

Lien made the pledge at the opening of an international conference on the care of dementia patients, co-sponsored by the Taipei City Hall and the Catholic Foundation of Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementia.
Noting that the number of local residents aged over 65 has exceeded 1.8 million, Lien said numerous national surveys show what elderly citizens need most is health care and economic security.

In addition to implementing a national health insurance program to offer better health care for senior citizens, Lien said the government is also planning a financial mechanism aimed at ensuring economic security for the elderly.

Lien, also the ruling Kuomintang candidate for the 2000 presidential election, further pointed out that the government needs the assistance of the private sector in improving health care and welfare services for senior citizens.
Lien said he admires the Catholic foundation's efforts to help upgrade care for elderly dementia patients over the past years.

Lien revealed that the Catholic foundation is now pushing for the establishment of an activity and day-care center for elderly dementia patients. "The project has been listed by Pope John Paul II as one of the Holy See's 100 most important development plans around the world for the year 2000," Lien said, adding that he believes the foundation's achievement will inspire the government and other relevant agencies to pay more attention to the care and welfare services for old dementia patients.
Speaking on the same occasion, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Taiwan became an aging society back in 1991 when the ratio of elderly people exceeded 7 percent of its total population.

By now, Ma said the number of people aged over 65 has even surpassed 9 percent of the island's total population. "Taipei alone has 230,000 senior citizens and 7,200 of them suffer from senile dementia," the mayor noted.

Ma said the Taipei city government will design more activities or programs catering to the need and taste of the elderly and will also help unlicensed elderly people care centers improve their facilities and management so that they can acquire legal operation permits as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER, FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 0.9 percent on Monday as the market in general was dragged down by electronics shares, financial issues and chemical and plastics stocks.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 70.03 points lower at 7,894.46, and turnover was narrowed to NT$119.81 (US$3.79 billion), with 2.73 billion shares changing hands.
According to dealers, investors were disappointed by the fact that it is still uncertain exactly when the new law on mergers of financial institutions will be passed by the legislature.

Finance Minister Paul Chiu said that there will be at least one merger among local banks before the end of this year following the passage of the new law, triggering heavy buying in financial issues in recent sessions.

Among the eight major stock categories, shares in the traditional manufacturing industries, such as foodstuff issues, cement shares, textile stocks and construction issues, all posted gains, with the foodstuff sector enjoying the largest gains of 1.8 percent.
Financial shares reported 2.2-percent losses, while electronics issues posted 0.7-percent losses.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 303 to 169, with 74 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market moved down 2.33 points to close at 188.37, on a turnover of NT$11.04 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 93 points to close at 7,929, with 1,850 contract transactions. Those for January declined 94 points to finish at 7,939, with 137 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March dipped 35 points to close at 7,995, with 11 contract transactions, while those for next June shed 61 points to close at 8,050, with three contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 8,022 points for December, 8,033 points for January, 8,030 points for next March, 8,111 points for next June, and 8,126 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported losses.

December TE futures shed eight points to close at 394, with 789 contract transactions; January TE futures moved down eight points to finish at 393, with 45 contract transactions; next March's TE futures dipped six points to close at 406, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

December TF futures dropped 23.8 points to close at 985, with 249 contract transactions, January TF futures dipped 20 points to close at 995 points, with 14 contract transactions, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SUSPECTS ARRESTED FOR SMUGGLING DIET PILLS

TEXT.P: Two suspects have been arrested in connection with diet pills smuggled into Taiwan from Thailand, agents from the Investigation Bureau said on Monday.

The agents reported that Yen Ching-hsiang, 32, and Tsai Ya-yu, 31, claimed suspicious luggage at CKS International Airport last Friday. Agents later found that the two had smuggled in 300,000 diet capsules.
Agents estimated that the capsules, most of which contain the controlled stimulant amphetamine, had a market value of about NT$25 million (US$78,860).

The bureau had stepped up its efforts to detect smuggling of diet pills from Thailand after nabbing Lee Yung-ching in October for smuggling in more than 100 kilograms of diet capsules from the same source.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar continued to appreciate against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday following a rise during the previous trading session.

The currency opened at 31.626 in Monday's session, and was traded between 31.609 and 31.626. By the end of trading, the local unit had sustained a 1.8-cent growth to close at a two-year high of 31.614.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$337 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-JAPANESE ECONOMIC CONFERENCE OPENS IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo. Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China official urged Japan on Monday to help lead the economic rebound in Asia, and expressed the hope that Japan will continue to support and take part in the quake-reconstruction efforts in Taiwan.
Lin Chin-chin, chairman of East Asian Relations Association, made the remarks at an ROC-Japanese Economic Conference which opened here on Monday.
Lin first expressed appreciation for Japan's assistance in the wake of the devastating earthquake that hit the island on Sept. 21.

He noted that his Japanese counterpart, Reijiro Hattori, chairman of Japan's Interchange Association, had delivered a letter from Japanese Primer Minister Keizo Obuchi to ROC President Lee Teng-hui in September to express sympathy toward the Taiwan people, and also acknowledged the extensive donations made by the Japanese people to the Taiwan quake victims.

Lin urged more cooperation between the ROC and Japan to help revive the Asian economy, adding that Taiwan enjoyed economic growth of just 4.7 percent last year as a result of the regional economic storm.
Due to the massive quake, he said Taiwan's economic growth this year will be adjusted downward from 5.7 percent to 5.4 percent, but added that growth is expected to reach 6 percent next year.

Lin said that while Japan should take the lead in reviving the economy, the economic rebound should not be shouldered by one single country alone, and that the ROC and Japan could step up cooperation to achieve an early revival.
He suggested that more cooperation projects should be tabled and discussed at the two-day conference.

Lin also expressed hope that Japan will support and take part in Taiwan's reconstruction efforts, saying that the earthquake has resulted in massive damage to houses, public buildings, transportation and the power supply system in Taiwan.
Hattori, who heads the Japanese delegation, also expressed his admiration for the rapid reconstruction efforts made by the Taiwan government and people.

He also said that trade relations between the two nations are smooth, with two-way trade in the first 10 months of this year reaching US$34.18 billion, up 13 percent from the same period of last year.

He noted that business and technology cooperation between the two nations in semiconductors and liquid crystal technology also showed dramatic growth, although Japanese investment in Taiwan in the first eight months declined by 24 percent from the same period of last year.
He also admired the rapid rebound of Taiwan's electronics industry after the temblor.
Participants in the conference included officials from Japanese government agencies who attended as observers, and ROC government officials.
Topics under discussion included cooperation relations under the framework of international organizations such as World Trade Organization, and the protection of intellectual property rights.
The economic conference has been held each year alternately in Japan and the ROC since the two nations severed diplomatic ties in 1976.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAICHUNG STUDENT LEADERS UNDECIDED ON PRESIDENTIAL CHOICE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Sixty-six percent of the heads of student organizations of central Taiwan's colleges have not yet decided on whom they will support in the 2000 presidential election, according to survey results released on Monday.

The Hsiang Lin Outdoor Life Cultural and Educational Foundation, which conducted the survey, distributed 300 questionnaires to the heads of student organizations of central Taiwan colleges and received 209 replies, with an error margin of 5 percent.
According to the poll results, 50 percent of the respondents said that they will be able to "more or less" influence the voting behavior of their members in the presidential election.
Asked whether they will side with a particular political party, 17 percent replied "yes," while the remaining 83 percent gave a negative answer.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG EPZ MULLING USE OF HELICOPTERS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone (EPZ) is considering using helicopters for its transport operations to increase the competitiveness of the businesses based in the complex, the Kaohsiung EPZ Branch Administration said on Monday.

As most of the more-than 90 factories headquartered in the Kaohsiung EPZ in the southern Taiwan city are from the high value-added semiconductor and electronics industries, the administration said helicopters are very suitable for quick transportation of their "light and small" products.

The administration admitted that the planned move is due to increasing demand from companies for shorter delivery times. Delivery time for cargoes of electronic products has already been reduced to about three days from the original five days, it noted, but added that more and more businesses are now demanding next-day delivery.

As Kaohsiung Port, Taiwan's largest, is close by the Kaohsiung EPZ, the administration said it will soon apply for government approval to run a short-haul helicopter cargo and passenger transport business. Enterprises in the EPZ complex will be able to use their rooftops as landing pads, so additional infrastructure will be unnecessary, it pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN KILN CREATING WORLD'S LARGEST POTTERY VASE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan kiln is creating a ceramic vase that will be the largest of its kind in the world, the Guinness Book of World Records Museum in the central Taiwan city of Taichung announced on Monday.
The museum said it has approved an application by Snake Kiln in Shuili, a mountainous township in Taichung County, to create a 6-meter-high thrown vase.

According to the museum, the largest thrown vase on record is one measuring 5.66 meters in height which was completed on Feb. 10, 1996 by Ray Sparks of the ESK Creative Clay Co. in Queensland, Australia.
Tai Sheng-yi, chairman of the Taichung museum, said the unique hand-made vase will have a special twin-mouth design, which in some ways resembles an ancient Greek amphora with a double spout.
Two veteran potters at Snake Kiln will work together to create the vase, while the company's president, Lin Kuo-lung, will design a larger-than-usual traditional kiln to fire the piece.
The Guinness Book of World Records stipulates that no more than three people can be involved in the production of a record-setting ceramic item to be listed in the book.
A ceremony marking the start of the vase's creation was held on Monday morning at the Taichung Guinness Book of Records Museum, at which the three craftsmen were present.
The work is scheduled to be completed by the first half of March 2000, museum officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RAILWAY ADMINISTRATION REMAINS DEEP IN RED

TEXT.P: The government-run Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) is continuing to suffer heavy losses, despite a steady increase in the volume of passengers, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Monday.
MOTC statistics indicate that in the past decade, TRA's passenger service registered an average growth rate of 3.4 percent.
However, because of the heavy burden of personnel costs that have accounted for 58 percent of the annual expenditures, the TRA continues to run at a loss.
For instance, the MOTC said, the TRA's revenues in fiscal 1998 totaled NT$22.18 billion (US$693.1 million), but its expenditures amounted to NT$31.28 billion, leaving a deficit of NT$9.1 billion.
In order to redress the deficit, the TRA said that it will take steps to save on expenditure by increasing its operational efficiency and perhaps raising fare prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER DEFENDS REPLACEMENT OF TROOPS WITH COAST GUARD

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei on Monday once again defended the government's decision to replace marines stationed in the Pratas (Tungsha) and Spratly (Nansha) islands in the South China Sea with coast guard officers.

Tang stressed at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's legal, interior, defense and financial affairs committees that the replacement will in no way affect the Republic of China's sovereign claim to the two remote island groups.

The legislative committee meeting was originally designed to screen a Ministry of National Defense-proposed bill on the establishment of a coast guard administration to take charge of coastal patrols and anti-crime operations in offshore areas. However, lawmakers focused their interpellations on the so-called "Tungsha, Nansha troops withdrawal" issue.

Opposition New Party Legislator Hau Lung-pin said the government should not lightly replace marines with law-enforcement coast guard personnel because such a move may mislead the world into thinking that the ROC has forsaken its sovereign claim to the two island groups.
In response, Tang said a change in garrison personnel does not imply abandonment of sovereignty.
Noting that disputes in the Tungsha and Nansha areas are mostly related to fishing issues, Tang said replacement of marines with coast guard officers will facilitate a solution to those disputes.

For instance, Tang said, 15 mainland Chinese fishing boats have illegally operated in the 12-nautical mile area of Taiping Island, an ROC-held islet of the disputed Spratlys group, over the past week. To avoid causing international disputes, Tang said, ROC marines stationed there have refrained from taking action to disperse the intruding mainland fishing boats. "And this is an important reason behind our decision to replace marines with coast guard officers to facilitate handling of such disputes," the minister added.

In addition to Taiwan and mainland China, several other Southeast Asian countries -- the Philippines, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia and Brunei -- also claim sovereignty to the Spratlys, either in whole or in part.

Tang said the circumstances under which the ROC decided to station troops on Taiping Island have changed significantly. "The Spratlys have become a complicated and delicate international political issue," Tang said, adding that the world community generally hopes that the issue can be resolved through negotiations, not by military means.

Even if Taiwan continues to station military personnel on Tungsha and Nansha islands, Tang said he does not think that Taiwan will be able to defend the two islands now under its control because of the geographical distance between the islands and Taiwan proper.

Therefore, Tang said, he hopes the legislature will pass all related bills as soon as possible to pave the way for the inauguration of a new coast guard administration to take charge of coastal patrols, fishing dispute investigations and crackdowns on smuggling of drugs, firearm and humans in offshore areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, CANADIAN OFFICIALS CONCERNED OVER CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Monday that US and Canadian officials are concerned over the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.

Lin Yi-hsiung said they also believe that Taiwan and mainland China may boost mutual cooperation once they join the World Trade Organization (WTO), and that their WTO participation might benefit the two sides, which have been hostile to each other for decades.
Lin made the remarks at a press conference in San Francisco at the end of a North American visit. He was accompanied by the DPP's representative to the United States, Chiu Yi-jen.

Revealing that he had contacted various US and Canadian officials during his visit, Lin said that although Washington has been closely monitoring Taiwan's upcoming presidential election, he felt that it appears little interested in the eventual outcome.

Lin claimed that Washington's view is that the campaign is an internal affair of Taiwan in which only the Taiwan people have the right to be involved. He added that the US authorities have indicated that Washington will not adjust its Taiwan policy unless the new Republic of China president alters the existing political policies of the country.

In addition to meetings with government officials, the party chairman also held talks with members of American think tanks and representatives of overseas Chinese groups on issues centering on cross-strait relations, Taiwan's political development, and the March presidential election, according to Chiu.

Asked about his opinion of reports that the DPP will harm cross-strait relations if it becomes the ruling party, Lin said that is the wrong image of his party, and one which has been created under the Kuomintang's long-term administration.

The DPP will follow the country's consistent cross-strait policy, and will not make a "dramatic, extreme" change once it takes the reins of power in Taiwan, Lin stressed, noting that no US politicians have released any special warning or concern over such a scenario.

He declared that the DPP has never changed its stance that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should build up ties in order to mutually support each other and seek prosperity through contact and negotiation.
Lin arrived in San Francisco from Houston on Monday. He was scheduled to leave for home later in the day after meeting with leaders of Taiwanese organizations in the Bay area.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCES OF ANTHRAX OUTBREAK UNLIKELY: DOH

TEXT.P: None of a group of 31 people who had contact with a horse which died recently of anthrax have been infected with the deadly disease, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reported on Monday.

The DOH had collected blood samples from the 31 people, staff members at the Plum Flowers Horse-Riding Club in the Taipei suburb of Peitou and the Livestock Health Research Institute in the northern town of Tamsui for tests shortly after a mare kept at the equestrian club died of anthrax on Nov. 24.

"Blood tests show that none of them have been infected with Bacillus Anthrax, the bacterium that causes anthrax," said Dr. Tu Shing-jer, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control.
Tu said this initial test result indicates that the possibility of an anthrax outbreak has been reduced.
"Nevertheless, as the disease's incubation period can last for up to one month, we'll arrange for these persons to undergo further tests," Tu added.

Meanwhile, he said, blood tests on 71 other people who had visited the Plum Flowers club before and after the anthrax-infected mare's death are still on-going. "The test results are expected to come out in the near future," he said, adding that relevant agencies are still investigating the source of the mare's infection.

Anthrax is an acute infectious disease normally found in certain livestock and wild animals, and sometimes humans. It is known to affect the skin, the respiratory system or the intestinal tract, depending on the mode of transmission.
The last reported episodes of anthrax in animals and humans in Taiwan were said to be in 1953 and 1972, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-RANKING ROC FINANCE OFFICIALS TO VISIT US

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Vice Minister Sean Chen, along with other high-level officials, will begin a 10-day visit to the United States on Dec. 8 to explore Internet security technology.

The 15-member group will include officials of the Finance Ministry and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, representatives of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation, and representatives of banking, securities, electronic business and information technology organizations. It will be led by the Commercial Section of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the US liaison office in Taiwan.

The group has been commissioned to secure US technologies in the field of e-commerce financial infrastructure systems and Internet security, in order to keep pace with Taiwan's rapid advancement in business-to-business and business-to-customer e-commerce, electronic banking, and Internet securities trading, according to a press release from AIT.

It is considered essential that Taiwan seeks further development to bolster secure channels, to create gateway systems for secure money transfers, to design and implement certificate authorities and certification procedures, and to fortify firewall security technologies, according to the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EXPELS 21 SOONG SUPPORTERS FROM PARTY

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's Evaluation and Discipline Committee on Monday decided to oust another 21 party members who support independent presidential candidate James Soong rather than the KMT-nominated Vice President Lien Chan.
Among those to be expelled are seven legislators, two national assemblymen, and two local assembly speakers.

The decision, which will be formally approved by the KMT Central Standing Committee at its regular Wednesday meeting, marks the second time in recent weeks that the ruling party has acted to oust party members who support the former Taiwan provincial governor's bid for the presidency on March 18, 2000.
Soong, who also previously served as KMT secretary-general, was expelled from the party together with six other supporters last month.

The seven ousted legislators are: Liu Wen-hsiung (Keelung City); Chou Chi-wei (Taipei County); Cheng Chin-ling (Taipei County); Shen Chih-hui (Taichung City); Hsieh Chang-chieh (Changhua County); Chen Chao-jung (Changhua County); and Chung Shao-ho (Kaohsiung County).

The expelled National Assembly members are Lin Yuan-yuan and Lee Chi-sheng. Ilan County Assembly Speaker Lin Jung-hsing and Hsinchu City Council Speaker Cheng Cheng-kuang were also given their marching orders.
Recent public opinion surveys have indicated that Soong continues to lead in terms of support rating over Lien and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's candidate, Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUDDHIST GROUP PROVIDES FOOD FOR NORTH KOREANS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Association said on Monday that it has dispatched a 50-member delegation to North Korea to provide food for needy people there.
This is the first time the Pyongyang authorities have allowed a large group of foreign volunteers to engage in relief work in the country.

The venerable Master Cheng Yen of Tzu Chi told the media that although Taiwan is still involved in its own post-earthquake reconstruction phase, assistance for foreign countries should not be suspended.
The association will provide 2,600 metric tons of rice to some 87,000 people from more than 40,000 needy North Korean households.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DIOXIN EMISSIONS TO BE `IMPROVED' BY END OF 2000: EPA

TEXT.P: Following reports that Taiwan's incinerators are spewing out dioxin levels which are hundreds of times the amounts considered safe in developed countries, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) promised on Monday to bring waste emissions up to standard by the end of next year.

The EPA said that of the island's eight existing incinerators, five meet with local environmental protection standards in terms of dioxin emissions, and the other three will be brought up to standard by the end of 2000.

The EPA pointed out that Taiwan had no limitations on emissions of dioxin -- a carcinogenic gas generated by burning plastics -- when it built its first incinerator in the Taipei City suburb of Neihu, but increasing environmental awareness later prompted the EPA to set a limit of 0.1 ng TEQ\Nm3 on Oct. 6 this year, by which time there were already eight incinerators running in Taiwan.

Incinerators at Shulin and Hsintien, both in Taipei County, met with the O.1 ng standard after being retrofitted with active carbon injectors, while two others in Neihu, Mucha, both in Taipei City and one in Taichung, are under the process of renovation and are expected to be brought up to the new standard when work is finished in June, 2000, said the EPA.

Another three newly built incinerators, one in Peitou, Taipei City, and two in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, were designed to meet the strictest limitations in the world. In particular, the EPA went on, the two in Kaohsiung which were completed in March and October, have dioxin emissions of 0.003ng 0.0017ng, respectively, said the EPA.

The EPA attributed the huge volume of dioxin in Taiwan's atmosphere to the large amount of plastic waste generated in daily life, and urged the public to separate dioxin-producing waste from other flammable waste as a way of cutting emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: `TRADE CLUB' UNDER EIB INAUGURATED TO HELP PROMOTE FOREIGN TRADE

TEXT.P: The Export-Import Bank (EIB) of the Republic of China on Monday inaugurated a "trade club" as a measure to help local small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs)to tap emerging markets around the world, said an EIB official.

Because local SMEs are often unfamiliar with certain emerging markets, the official noted, the EIB decided to set up the trade club with the aim of integrating their efforts to explore trading opportunities in new locations.

According to the official, the EIB will engage experts to research political and economic situations, analyze trading risks and investment climates, and conduct credit ratings on more than 20 emerging countries in East Europe, Southeast Asia, South Asia and South America.

Local exporters admitted into the club will gain access to its Internet Website to improve their understanding of the basic data required for doing business with importers in those countries, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER AGREES TO ACCEPT RESIGNATION OF HEAD OF AGRICULTURE COUNCIL

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew agreed on Monday to accept the resignation of Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA) after failing to persuade Peng to stay in his Cabinet.

After meeting with Peng for about 40 minutes, the premier agreed to accept Peng's resignation letter which was expected to be presented to Siew early on Tuesday morning, said government spokesman Chao Yi.
Peng's successor will be named after Peng's resignation becomes effective, said Chao.
Peng announced his decision to quit on Nov. 30, after the Cabinet decided, despite his opposition, to allow farmers to build houses on their newly acquired farmland.
He warned the ruling Kuomintang against wooing farmers' support in the presidential election at the cost of the country's long-term agriculture policy.

In the first press conference after his resignation announcement, Peng defended on Monday his objection to the lifting of the house-building ban, saying it will undo the government's long-established policy of "farmland owned by farmers only and used for farming exclusively."

Allowing farmers to build houses on newly acquired farmland is tantamount to transforming the island's farmland into de-facto construction land, while allowing it be exempt from construction regulations and virtually free from taxes, said Peng.

Doing away with the ban is like opening a Pandora's box, and although might rise the price of farmland in the short term, it will dampen the price of construction land to the detriment of the country's economy in the long term, he said.

Disputing criticism that the COA shapes the country's agriculture policy in air-conditioned offices without consulting with the rank-and-file farmers, Peng said his council has organized presentation meetings around the island to sell its policy and has won support from farmers, especially in northern Taiwan.

Most of the opposition to the ban comes from southern Taiwan, where farmers, as well as the banks run by farmers associations, are trying to use farmland commercially to solve the problems of a lack of liquidity faced by farmers' banks.
"Financial problems should be sorted out by financial policy rather than by agricultural policy," said Peng.
As a politically appointed official, Peng said, he should be responsible for what he preaches and has no reason to hang on to his job when his policies are rejected and his ideas discarded.

After leaving the administration, the professor-turned-politician said he will return to teaching at National Chunghsing University where he served as dean of the Agricultural School before being offered the job as COA chairman in 1997.
Although at odds with Siew over the government's agricultural policy, Peng reiterated his support for the premier's candidacy for vice president in the general election.
Peng said that if asked, he would stump for Siew and his running mate Vice President Lien Chan, the KMT's candidate for president, in the 2000 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:

The China Post:

The Taiwan News:
The KMT expelling 21 more; action against Soong backers comes after futile party efforts to keep them in line.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 7, or the 30th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts to achieve Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin, prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the imperial summer palace by invading troops.
1887: The first US hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: US President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men, and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat to Taipei.
1951: Chinese communists launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: Unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC) formally opens in Shanhua, in Taiwan's Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: US President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese rulers of three centuries leave the colony.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan cables independence day felicitations to Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Bishop H.H. Brookins, Dr. James G. Blake and Bishop W. Hilliard, members of a US religious group visiting Taiwan.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1985: The first summit meeting of the seven South Asian nations opens in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: Massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes constitutional guarantee of communist supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1989: A revolt in the Philippines ends when 400 rebel troops abandon their siege of Manila's business center.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1994: In Namibian national elections, President Sam Nujoma's ruling Southwest Africa People's Organization wins more than two-thirds of the vote.
1996: Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after nearly 18 days aloft, ending the longest space shuttle flight ever.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PAPERS REPORT ON ROC PRESIDENT'S DESIRE TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: Major Japanese newspapers on Tuesday gave prominent coverage to reports that Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui hopes to visit Japan next year.
President Lee told a group of Japanese visitors on Monday that he hopes to attend the 12th Asia Outlook Forum to be held in Japan's Nagano prefecture in December 2000.

Nearly all influential Japanese dailies, including Yomiuri Shimbun, Asahi Shimbun, Sankei Shimbun, Nihhon Keizai Shimbun and Tokyo Shimbun, carried reports of Lee's statements on their international news pages on Tuesday.

The Sankei Shimbun, a major business daily, quoted Lee as saying that if he manages to attend next year's Asia Outlook Forum, he will deliver a keynote speech on Taiwan's political reforms and democratization in the 1990s.
Lee, a graduate of Kyoto University, has long hoped to visit his alma mater. However, he has been unable to visit Japan because of strong opposition from mainland China.

Lee's presidential term will expire in May 2000. When the Asia Outlook Forum, an annual gathering of scholars, business executives and political and economic analysts from Taiwan and Japan, holds its next meeting in December 2000, Lee will no longer be the ROC's head of state.

Nevertheless, it remains uncertain whether Lee can realize his wish to attend the 2000 Asia Outlook forum because Beijing has said that it does not want to see Lee visit Japan even after his retirement from the presidency. Lee will still be chairman of the ROC's ruling Kuomintang after his presidential tenure ends.

The Asia Outlook Forum, founded in 1989, is aimed at pooling the wisdom of the elite members of the business, political and academic communities in Taiwan and Japan to help boost substantive bilateral ties as well as regional prosperity and stability.
The forum holds its annual meeting alternately in Taiwan and Japan. Its 11th conference was held from Dec. 4-5 in the southern Taiwanese city of Tainan.
The Japanese visitors whom President Lee met on Monday were participants to the just-concluded 11th Asia Outlook Forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
