DOC.HEADLINE: LOW CRIME RATE AMONG FOREIGN LABORERS IN TAIPEI CITY: DBAS

TEXT.P: The crime rate among foreign laborers in metropolitan Taipei is low, but many of them do not have clean bills of health, the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DBAS) of the Taipei City Hall reported on Tuesday.
Department tallies show that the city had 21,882 foreign laborers as of the end of October this year, most of whom were from the Philippines, Thailand and Indonesia.

Taipei's foreign laborers accounted for 7.51 percent of the total number of blue-collar foreign workers in Taiwan and made up about 50 percent of Taipei's overall foreign population at the time the statistics were compiled.
According to the municipal statistical agency, 70 percent of Taipei's foreign laborers were housemaids or family helpers.

The department further said a total of 1,615 people were involved in alien-related law enforcement cases in Taipei last year, 1,114 of whom were foreign laborers, accounting for 68.98 percent of the total. The figure marked an increase of 300 people from the 1997 level.
In the first 10 months of this year, 720 foreign laborers were involved in law enforcement cases, accounting for 59.85 percent of total alien-related judicial episodes.
Ninety percent of foreign laborer-related cases fell under the category of violations of the Employment Service Law, and few were criminal cases, according to city government tallies.
In 1997, 22 foreign laborers were accused of having committed criminal activities in Taipei, compared to nine in 1998 and 10 in the first 10 months of this year.
Meanwhile, four foreign laborers were victims of criminal cases reported in Taipei in 1997, compared to eight in 1998 and only one in the January-October period of 1999.
DBAS officials said all these figures indicate that the major impact of foreign laborers is in the city's job market, not in its public order.

The officials further pointed out that foreign laborer-related health management should be improved. The city's health agencies conducted a total of 34,010 physical checkups on foreign laborers in 1998, and 421 of them, or 1.24 percent, failed to meet requirements.

In the first 10 months of this year, the failure rate surged to 1.72 percent, up 0.68 percent from the same period of last year. The failure rate was the highest among Indonesian laborers, and 90 percent of those who failed to obtain clean bills of health were found to have parasites in their intestines.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TENTATIVELY AGREES TO SELL AIM-120 MISSILES TO ROC

TEXT.P: The United States has tentatively agreed to sell AIM-120 advanced medium-range air-to-air missiles to the Republic of China, the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) announced on Tuesday.

Shen Yuan-tai, deputy chief executive of the AFGH's Weaponry Acquisition Office, told a routine news conference at the Ministry of National Defense (MND) that the United States has agreed to integrate the software of AIM-120 missiles into the firing control system of the ROC's F-16 jet fighters.

"The move indicates that we have obtained `admission tickets' to enter the realm of the sophisticated missile system," Shen explained, adding that the ROC Air Force expects to acquire the new missiles in the near future.
The radar-guided active missile is 3.65 meters long, with a diameter of 1,078 mm. It weighs 157 kilograms, has a range of 50 kilometers, and is installed mainly on the US-made F-16 fighter.
Shen's remarks came amid reports that Russia will sell modified R-77 missiles -- under the export name of RVV-AE -- to mainland China within the next year.

According to the US Defense News, the R-77, and its export variant the RVV-AE, are more sophisticated missiles in the AIM-120 class. The use of an active-radar seeker, rather than a semi-active radar seeker, allows the launch aircraft to engage more than one target at a time.

The defense weekly also said the ROC Air Force has two active, medium-range air-to-air missiles -- the French-made MICA and the Taiwan-developed Sky Sword II. Neither, however, are integrated for use on the 150 F-16s purchased by Taiwan from the United States.

Meanwhile, the Defense News quoted Russian sources as saying that Russia and mainland China have not yet signed a formal contract on the RVV-AE deal. The report also made no mention of the number of RVV-AEs that mainland China plans to purchase, saying only that the RVV-AE deal may be part of mainland China's SU-30 MKK Russian-made jet fighter procurement plan.
Commenting on the reports, a senior MND intelligence officer noted that the ROC military has always closely monitored mainland China's missile development and deployment plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WTO PROGRESS LIKELY UNTIL AFTER US ELECTION: CANADIAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: There will be no real progress on World Trade Organization issues until after the next US election, said Canada's Trade Minister Pierre Pettigrew on Monday.

The minister made the comments during a media briefing on the failure of last week's WTO meetings in Seattle, which were supposed to set the agenda for the next round of trade talks. Instead, the 135 member countries went home empty-handed after deadlocking over farm subsidies and labor standards.
Pettigrew said Canada must now work behind the scenes to try to establish a new way of negotiating trade issues.

"You know there is no fast track authority in the United States, there's a presidential election, it would be very difficult to really get strong movement forward before that election takes place," he said.
"But a lot of work can be done in the meantime, and that's what (WTO Director General) Mike Moore has to do right now."

Pettigrew noted that the next round of talks, on agriculture and services, will go ahead as scheduled in January. He also hinted that Canada would lower or abolish the remaining tariffs on goods produced by the world's poorest countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TURNS TO ASIA-PACIFIC REGION IN ITS FREE TRADE PUSH

TEXT.P: Australia is making a major shift to the promotion of free trade with the Asia-Pacific region through bilateral agreements after failing to accomplish further trade liberalization at the ministerial conference during World Trade Organization talks in Seattle last week.

Trade Minister Mark Vaile said there was little hope for progress at the global level until after the US presidential elections in November 2000, adding the delay in reaching an agreement at the WTO talks could cost Australia up to US$15 billion in new exports.
Australia's Deputy Prime Minister John Anderson on Monday criticized US President Bill Clinton for allowing domestic political considerations interfere with the talks.

Anderson's predecessor was even more blunt in his criticism of Clinton. "The sooner he, if not the administration, departs the trade policy arena, the sooner the WTO will have a chance to re-rail for the millennium round," Tim Fisher told reporters here.

Vaile said Australia will bank on the ministerial meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum next year and on free trade discussions between Australia, New Zealand and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, hoping these talks provide opportunities for regional and bilateral advances in free trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON CRITICIZES RUSSIA AND CHINA ON HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS

TEXT.P: US Presdient Bill Clinton warned Monday that Russia will pay a heavy price for its rocket and artillery attacks on largely civilian areas in Chechnya and also criticized Communist China for its crackdown on peaceful Falun Gong followers.

Speaking at the presentation of the Eleanor Roosevelt Human Rights Awards, Clinton pointed out that in addition to Russia, another country about which the United States must continue to express human rights concerns is mainland China.

Although Communist China is progressing and opening to the world in many welcome ways, including its entry into the World Trade Organization, "its progress still is being held back by the government's response to those who test the limits of freedom. A troubling example, of course, is the detention by Chinese authorities of adherents of the Falun Gong movement," said the president.

Clinton added that the Beijing regime's targets are not political dissidents, and even though the practices and beliefs of Falun Gong followers are unfamiliar to Americans, "the principle still surely must be the same- freedom of conscience and freedom of association."

"And our interests surely must be the same -- seeing China maintain stability and growth at home by meeting, not stifling, the growing demands of its people for openness and accountability," stressed Clinton.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA, N. KOREA AGREE TO DISCUSS NORMALIZING RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia and North Korea have agreed to hold talks in Pyongyang in February to discuss normalizing their diplomatic relations, which were broken by the withdrawal of North Korean diplomats from Canberra almost 25 years ago.

In a dispatch from Seoul, the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday reported that both sides have agreed to the talks on the resumption of ties and on additional issues, including humanitarian assistance, human rights, security and the prospects for future bilateral relations.

The daily on Monday quoted Foreign Minister Alexander Downer as confirming the talks were being planned and saying that Australia has "always insisted that North Korea must prove its credentials as a responsible international citizen before we move forward in any tangible way to the resumption of diplomatic relations."

The daily reported that the talks were proposed by North Korean Foreign Minister Paek Nam Sun when he wrote to the Australian government three months ago. Encouraged by North Korea's cooperation on missile control in return for Washington's easing of economic sanctions, Australia agreed to the talks in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.014 to close at 31.6 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday.
The currency opened at 31.609, and was traded between 31.583 and 31.619. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$744 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES SET RECORD HIGH OF US$103.53 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves had reached a record high of US$103.53 billion as of the end of November, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Tuesday.

CBC officials said it is the forth consecutive month that the figure has topped US$100 billion and the third consecutive month that a record has been set. The reserves are also the third highest in the world, behind only those of Japan and mainland China.

The officials noted that foreign exchange reserves in November showed a dramatic increase of US$15.46 billion from the same period of last year, or the 17th consecutive month in which an increase has been recorded.

They attributed the record high to the continued increase of trade surplus, the cancellation of foreign exchange deposits by depositors, and the continued inflow into the stock market of foreign capital.
Foreign exchange reserves in August, September and October registered US$101.13 billion, US$101.65 billion and US$102.67 billion, respectively.
Looking ahead to December, the CBC officials said they are expecting another record high, and are not ruling out the possibility of hitting US$105 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE COMPLAINS ABOUT DUAL PASSPORT PROCEDURE

TEXT.P: An overseas Chinese holding both Republic of China and US passports on Tuesday urged the ROC government to end the practice of making a note of the ROC passport number in a holder's US passport after stamping both passports when they enter or leave the ROC.
The overseas Chinese, surnamed Chen, made the demand at a public hearing organized by Legislator Ying Chih-hung.

Chen claimed that some overseas Chinese have had their passports confiscated by US immigration officers when they re-enter the United States because the notes reveal that the passport holder is breaking the US law which stipulates that it is forbidden for a US citizen to own a passport other than the one issued by the US government.

At present, the ROC government recognizes dual nationality for overseas Chinese, and those who show both ROC and US passports when entering or leaving the ROC have both their passports stamped by ROC immigration officers, and their ROC passport number is noted in their US passport.
Ku Fu-chang, director-general of the Bureau of Consular Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said that he is aware of the situation, but has yet to receive a formal complaint on the matter.
He also claimed that ROC immigration officers stamp both passports and note the ROC passport number in the US passport only when specifically asked to do so by the passport holder.
Representatives of the National Police Administration, the Bureau of Immigration, and the Civil Aviation Police Bureau attending the public hearing suggested that the government review the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER, FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 0.9 percent on Tuesday as the market continued to experience consolidation due to a lack of confidence among investors.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 67.41 points lower at 7,827.05, and turnover narrowed to NT$115.19 (US$3.64 billion), with 2.40 billion shares changing hands.
According to dealers, the reduced volume, which was a result of defensive investors who were bracing for possible selling by institutions and fund managers, was not enough to push up the index.
Many institutional investors have already completed their investment portfolios for next year and there is no reason for them to trade in the market before the year-end holidays, the dealers said.
Foreign fund managers were also advised to adjust their investment strategies in some Asian markets, including Taiwan, to avoid any potential computer malfunctions caused by the Y2K rollover.
All of the eight major stock categories closed lower, with the cement sector suffering the heaviest losses of 1.9 percent.
Financial shares and foodstuff issues both reported 1.5-percent losses, while electronics issues fell 0.8 percent.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 343 to 131, with 76 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market moved down 3.01 points to close at 185.36, on a turnover of NT$10.43 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 59 points to close at 7,870, with 1,719 contract transactions. Those for January declined 59 points to finish at 7,880, with 155 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March dipped 83 points to close at 7,912, with seven contract transactions, while those for next June shed 74 points to close at 7,976, with two contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,929 points for December, 7,939 points for January, 7,995 points for next March, 8,050 points for next June, and 8,033 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported losses.
December TE futures shed 0.2 points to close at 393.8, with 830 contract transactions, and January TE futures moved down 0.95 points to finish at 393.5, with 35 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

December TF futures dropped 15.6 points to close at 969.4, with 164 contract transactions, January TF futures dipped 13 points to close at 982 points, with 24 contract transactions, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S NUCLEAR SUB EFFORTS SAID TO BE LINKED TO TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: There are indications that Communist China has started to build its new-generation nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed strategic submarine (SSBN) and that by constructing the Type 094 submarine, it is trying to prevent the United States from interfering in the Taiwan Strait, according to a recent issue of the Toronto-based Kanwa News.

The paper quoted a Chinese official report as saying General Zhang Wannian, vice-chairman of the Military Commission of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, recently visited HuLu Dao Shipyard where the SSBN is apparently being constructed.
Judging from the ranking officials that accompanied him, the inspection was seen as being related to the construction of the SSBN, the military intelligence report said.

It noted that among the 200 officials who accompanied Zhang, were the elite of the Chinese army and the military scientific and technical development industry. Also present were the heads of the Navy, the nuclear industry, the aerospace industry, the General Staff, and the heads of several committees related to industries engaged in military research.

During the inspection, Zhang emphasized that the shipyard is facing an arduous task, but that production, especially military production, must be completed in time with a good quality, Kanwa quoted Zhang.

Kanwa quoted a Western source as saying China had originally planned to start construction of the second generation SSBN in 1997, but because the ground trail of its nuclear power system had not been completed, it turned to improving the IA-class SSBN.
It has been reported that the improved IA-class SSBNs have already been rearmed with 12 JL2 SLBM, in order to strengthen the nuclear deterrence against the United States.

Zhang's inspection shows once again that China attaches great importance to nuclear deterrence forces, with which Beijing hopes to prevent the US from intervening in the Taiwan problem, the Kanwa News said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON CROSS-CENTURY NATIONAL SECURITY TO BE HELD ON WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: An academic seminar on cross-century national security and military strategy, sponsored by the Armed Forces University, is scheduled to be held on Wednesday at the National Central Library.
Ten papers on the international situation, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, national security and national defense will be presented and discussed at the one-day seminar.

The Armed Forces University will also invite scholars and experts from government organizations, private academic groups, as well as parliamentarians and media representatives, to participate in the seminar in a bid to establish a consensus of "national defense by the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA PLANS TO CANCEL 122 FLIGHTS AROUND Y2K ROLLOVER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautic Administration (CAA) is planning to cancel 122 domestic flights and 57 international flights between 9 p.m. on Dec. 31 and 12 noon on Jan. 1, 2000, a CAA official said on Tuesday.

The official of the agency under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said that the move is designed to remove the possibility of Y2K-related flight security risks during the rollover period between the end of 1999 and the start of 2000.
He stressed however that the move is purely an additional precaution, as all aviation control and service stations, and all domestic airliners, are fully Y2K-compliant.

Flight frequency will be cut by half from 35 flights to 18 flights per hour during the period, he went on, adding that the 57 international flights projected to be canceled will include four flights to Asia, 19 flights to America, 22 flights to Europe, and eight flights to New Zealand and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS STAGE PROTEST TO URGE PASSAGE OF FARMLAND REFORM BILL

TEXT.P: Waving banners urging the government to lift restrictions on cropland use, farmers from central and southern Taiwan staged a mass protest in downtown Taipei on Tuesday.

Led by officials of the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association, more than 10,000 farmers from 21 counties and cities gathered at the plaza outside the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to demand that the government permit free purchase of farmland to help local farmers associations resolve their financial problems. Only the counties of Hsinchu and Miaoli were not represented.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung and Vice Finance Minister Sean C. Chen met the protesters at the plaza on behalf of the government, with Lin vowing that the government will fully protect farmers' interests.
More than 30 lawmakers, including Legislative Yuan Vice President Wang Jin-pyng, were also present on the occasion to show their support for the farmers.

Independent presidential candidate Hsu Hsin-liang and his running mate Chu Hui-liang also attended the event, and declared that they back the government's planned move to allow the free purchase of farmland for construction use in order to protect farmers' rights and interests.
A declaration distributed by the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association made public four major appeals from the farmers to the government:
1. Totally ease restrictions on the purchase of farmland;
2. Lift restrictions on the division of farmland;
3. Permit housing development on farmland; and
4. Draw up a feedback plan for farmers whose cropland is assigned for farm use only;
Some 3,000 of the farmers, accompanied by Lin and Hsu, later marched to the Legislative Yuan to deliver a petition in support of the farmland use reform bill.
The legislature is slated to screen the bill on Wednesday and Thursday.
President and Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui has been reported to have allegedly agreed with the package, prompting COA Chairman Peng Tso-kuei to resign last week.

Peng, a scholar-turned-Cabinet member, said he stands firm on his stance that the nation's farmland should be reserved for farm use only. "Lifting restrictions on building housing on cropland will be like opening Pandora's box, and will cause endless damage to future generations," he asserted.
Peng officially left his post at the COA on Tuesday morning after his resignation was approved by Premier Vincent Siew the previous evening.

At the same time, the local academic spectrum expressed strong opposition to the government's planned farmland use liberalization package at a seminar sponsored by National Taiwan University (NTU), voicing concern that allowing housing construction on farmland will lead to the abuse of cropland by special interest groups and that farmers themselves will suffer the most damage.

Citing Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, NTU Professor M.C. Chen pointed out that Taiwan's food production will be greatly affected if construction on farmland is allowed, and that Taiwan's cropland will become even more polluted by waste water discharged from additional households.

C.C. Huang and C.J. Liu, both professors from National Chungshing University, claimed that local farmers associations' wishful thinking that the farmland reform bill will allow them to resolve their financial troubles is killing the goose which lays the golden eggs, the results of which will be even harder for farmers to take.
Protection of farmland should go hand in hand with the development of national territory, and relevant measures should be worked out to effectively regulate the use of cropland, they said.

As the government's past policy of "industrialization in the countryside" has already caused disorder among the island's rural areas, they warned the government against its planned move to liberalize the use of farmland, pointing out that it will have a terrible impact on Taiwan's long-term agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 13 MILLION VISA CARDS ISSUED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A total of 13.09 million VISA cards had been issued in Taiwan as of the end of October, representing an annual growth of 45 percent, according to statistics released on Tuesday by VISA International Service Association.

Turnover on VISA charges in Taiwan hit NT$354.7 billion (US$11.22 billion) during the period from January to October, and VISA officials have predicted that the turnover on VISA charges for the whole of 1999 will reach a record high of NT$420 billion.
Turnover in 1998 on VISA charges in Taiwan was registered at over NT$360 billion.

There were 4.12 million VISA cards issued between December 1998 and October this year, which means that around 343,700 VISA cards on average were issued per month during the period, according to the statistics.
The figure ranks VISA in the top position in Taiwan's credit card market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND KEEPING TABS ON BEIJING'S DEVELOPMENT OF NUCLEAR SUBMARINES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is keeping tabs on the development of nuclear-power submarines in mainland China, an MND official said on Tuesday.

Chao Lien-ti, assistant deputy chief of the ministry's General Staff for Intelligence, said at a regular press briefing that the MND has kept abreast of Beijing's development of nuclear weapons for more than a decade, noting that it published articles about mainland Chinese development of submarines and missiles launched from submarines as far back as 1986.
Judging from the progress of its development, Chao said, it is certain that Beijing will complete the deployment of nuclear-powered submarines by 2005.

Chao made the remarks in the wake of a Washington Times report on Monday that Beijing is beginning work on a new submarine that will be targeted against US nuclear forces and will carry missile warheads built with stolen US nuclear technology.

Chao said that Beijing has developed five "Han-class" submarines, one "Hsia-class" submarine, and is now working on two new models with the code numbers 093 and 094, and added that the MND is keeping abreast of developments on the mainland as they unfold.
The Washington Times also said that Beijing will start construction in the next several weeks on 094-type missile submarine.

The JL-2 missile which will be installed on the 094 submarines is based on the DF-31 International ballistic missile, but has a longer range of around 8,000 kilometers and would be able to reach the west coast of the United States if fired from the southeastern coast of mainland China. Each submarine will be armed with between 12 and 16 warheads.
Chao said that the MND believes that the submarines are intended as a strategic deterrent, and to provide the mainland with a second strike capability, and will not target Taiwan.
Meanwhile, a legislator from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party on Tuesday claimed that the recent Washington Times reports are aimed at influencing Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.

According to Legislator Trong Tsai, the reports on the construction of the 094 submarine are untrue, but he noted that the authoritative Jane's Navy Review reported that Beijing had begun to develop 094 submarines almost 20 years ago.

Tsai said he suspected that one of Taiwan's presidential candidates may have orchestrated the reports to drum up voter support by employing US public relations companies to prod US officials into speaking to certain news media. He did not elaborate, either on the identity of the candidate.

But he urged the presidential candidate not to play with fire as the people of Taiwan are getting used to Beijing's military intimidation and verbal attacks. Moreover, he went on, Beijing has already stated clearly that it will not use military intimidation as a means of intimidating Taiwan's voters as it did in the last presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES OIL PRICE HIKE

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) on Tuesday announced this year's sixth oil price hike, saying that prices will be increased by an average of 2.99 percent.
The CPC said that prices for gasoline and diesel will be raised by NT$0.4 per liter from midnight on Tuesday, while the price of fuel oil will be hiked by NT$394 per kiloliter.

The CPC also announced an increase in the price of natural gas at an average rate of 2.94 percent, but added that only industrial customers, electricity generating customers and co-generation customers will be subject to the hike, while domestic customers will not see an increase.

The CPC explained that the price rise is necessary to keep pace with the continuing increases in international crude oil prices. Purchasing costs for the CPC in November climbed to US$22.21 per barrel, a new high since February, 1997, and almost US$4 up on the October price.
This will be the CPC's sixth price hike since the beginning of the year.

Because the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the authority which supervises national corporations including the CPC, stipulates that the upper limit for oil price raises in three months is 6 percent, the CPC is not expected to increase prices again in January, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN OUTLINES TAIWAN'S POLITICAL VISION FOR NEW MILLENNIUM
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Normalization of relations across the Taiwan Strait will be the most important mainstream value for the early years of the new millennium, a presidential candidate from the Republic of China said here on Monday.

Chen Shui-bian, the standard-bearer of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the 2000 presidential election, said that if elected, he will be willing to sign a peace agreement with mainland China based on the principles of "mutual respect and parity."

Chen made the statements while fielding questions from the audience after delivering a speech on Taiwan's political vision for the new millennium at the London School of Economics and Political Science.

The lawyer-turned-politician said he believes that so long as mainland China refrains from trying to set Taiwan's future status and is willing to negotiate with Taiwan on an equal footing, normalization of cross-strait relations will not be a pipe dream.
Even if Beijing declines to treat Taiwan on an equal footing, Chen said he will wait patiently for the right time to resolve bilateral disputes naturally and peacefully.

Noting that Taiwan Strait peace and Asia-Pacific stability will benefit both sides, Chen said he is convinced that Taipei and Beijing can work out their differences. "We can sign a basic treaty to regulate bilateral relations on a `parity' basis," he added.
In his speech, the former Taipei mayor also outlined his new political vision under a new middle-of-the-road policy to cope with the problems facing the country.
Chen said his new policy is aimed at establishing a full-fledged democratic system under which major political parties take turns in holding power.
If elected, Chen said, he will push for the establishment of a "partner" relationship between the central and local governments by delegating more power to local-level governments.

Chen also vowed to establish a president-centered, three-branch government and a unicameral parliament, strengthen financial security management, eradicate vote-buying and the influence of money and gangsters in politics.
Chen further promised to develop Taiwan into a "green silicon island," by accelerating development of biotechnology and information technology as well as developing new "network" communities.

Touching on cross-strait relations, Chen said he expects to forge friendly ties with Beijing based on goodwill. "We are hopeful that Beijing can overcome all difficulties and transform itself into a moderate giant in the Asia-Pacific area."
If elected, Chen said he will be willing to conduct regular dialogue with Beijing and work together with it to overcome all obstacles to bilateral exchanges.
He also called for establishment of a military exchange mechanism and normalization of bilateral trade, saying the two moves would mark major breakthroughs to normalization of cross-strait relations.
Chen is the first foreign presidential candidate to be invited by the London School's president, Anthony Giddens, to speak at the school's "public affairs forum."

His speech attracted a packed audience, including many students from both sides of the Taiwan Strait. At one point in Chen's speech, Taiwan and mainland Chinese students publicly argued over cross-strait issues and even traded insults.

Witnessing the brief episode, Giddens said afterward that although he knows cross-strait issues are very sensitive, he did not expect that they could so easily trigger a flare-up between the people from both sides.
Following his two-day London visit, Chen will travel to Belgium where he will deliver a speech on Taiwan's political vision at the European Union's Asia-Pacific Research Center.
He will also visit the Netherlands before ending his three-leg European tour and returning to Taipei on Dec. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE RATTLES EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a magnitude of 4.4 shook eastern Taiwan at about 5:30 p.m. on Tuesday, with its epicenter located in north of Hualien County, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
There were no reports of damage or casualties.
The quake's intensity was measured at 3 in Hualien city, and 1 in the northeastern city of Ilan, CWB officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, CANADA CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN'S PRESIDENTIAL RACE: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said on Wednesday that the United States and Canada are concerned about Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.
Lin made the remarks upon his return from a visit to the United States and Canada which started on Nov. 28.

During his visit, he held talks with scholars in various US and Canadian think tanks. He also met with officials and parliamentarians in the two countries to discuss Taiwan's security and the US-proposed Theater Missile Defense system.
Lin also spoke about the DPP's efforts to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations and seek a breakthrough in the diplomatic blockage imposed by Beijing on the island.

He noted that some scholars suggested to him that Taiwan's security depends not only on military and economic security, but also on the democratization of Taiwan and the sympathy and support of the international community.

Lin said he found many of the officials with whom he spoke to be very concerned about the March 18, 2000 presidential election, but added that they assured him that as democratic countries, the United States and Canada believe that a president elected through the democratic process should be respected, and that the two countries will not dramatically change their policies toward Taiwan, no matter who emerges victorious in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA DEVELOPMENT TO RAISE VENTURE FUND FOR INVESTMENT IN BRITAIN

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China Development Industrial Bank (CDIB) has decided to establish another venture fund overseas to raise US$50 million which will be mainly used to invest in high technology industries in Britain.
The announcement was made on Tuesday, when the CDIB signed a letter of intent with Young Associates of Britain to make them partners in the new venture fund corporation.

Upon inking the letter of intent with Lord Young, founder and CEO of Young Associates, CDIB President Benny Hu said Young's personal career background will benefit the joint-venture, pointing out that Young has served as Britain's industrial secretary, and that he held a variety of other Cabinet positions before becoming chairman of Cable and Wireless, the second-largest telecommunications company in Britain.
Britain was chosen as the major investment target of the new venture fund because of its sound development of high tech industries and its geographically strategic location, Hu noted.
In addition to Britain, the venture fund may also invest in Israel and Europe, he added.
Meanwhile, the CDIB also announced on Tuesday plans to initiate another venture fund in North America.
The fund, expected to be to the tune of US$100 million, will target its investment at Internet and telecommunications-related industries in North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS IN DECEMBER SET NEW RECORD

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Tuesday that exports in November totaled US$11.55 billion, setting up a record high in a single month.
Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$1.44 billion, or the fifth time that trade surplus topped US$1 billion this year, in November, the MOF said.

Statistics showed that exports totaled US$110.62 billion in the first 11 motns, while imports totaled US$100.4 billion, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$10.22 billion, surpassing the trade surplus recorded both in 1997 and in 1998.

The MOF estimated that export growth in December will be 15 percent, while imports will be 10 percent. Judging from the estimate, the export growth this year will reach between 9.3 percent and 9.6 percent, setting up a new high since 1996.
The MOF estimated that import growth will be around six percent this year, with trade surplus estimated at 10.5 billion, or a new high since 1997.

The MOF attributed the double-digit growth to the rapid rebound of Taiwan industry in the wake of Sept. 21 earthquake and the entering of hot export season, adding that exports to major trading regions such as the United States, Hong Kong , Japan, Europe, and Association of Southeast Asian Nations all increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUP ISSUES REPORT ON TAIWAN'S HUMAN RIGHTS CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan should further improve its human rights conditions as it still flunks evaluations by local elite groups, the Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR) said on Tuesday.
The association has compiled a report on Taiwan's human rights conditions annually since 1991, based on the results of opinion survey of elite members in local society.

The association managed to collect 2,544 valid replies this year. It used a one-to-five-point scaling system to gauge human rights condictions in eight categories -- political, economic, women, judicial, children, elderly people, social, and cultural and educational fields.
Survey results show that none of the eight major indices received the minimum passing score of three points.
Compared with last year's tallies, the scores for political, social and children's rights declined slightly, while the scores for the remaining five categories all posted gains.

Political rights received the highest score of 2.98. Although the score still fell below three points, it indicated that local political rights situation has gradually become acceptable to elite members.

Nevertheless, the CAHR report pointed out that rampant political apathy and consolidation of democratic system remain major problems. Moreover, the report said debate on Taiwan's future status and abuse of political power for personal interests may eventually undermine local people's civil rights.

Political rights received a score of 2.83 points. Many scholars and lawmakers responding to the survey said the government should reduce unnecessary intervention into economic activities while strengthening its "service" functions.

The average score for children's rights conditions declined slightly to 2.69 points. The report said the government should pay more attention to uderage corporal punishment, peer and domestic violence, and rape issues.

Judicial rights received a score of 2.66 points. Quoting survey results, the report said, Taiwan made improvements in criminal investigations, law enforcement, and protection of law enforcement officers' rights. Nevertheless, the report said there is still ample room for improvement in court procedures.
The score for social rights stood at 2.81 points, down slightly from last year's level. The report attributed the decline mainly to alleged interference in communications freedoms.

Women's rights received a score of 2.67 points, the second lowest among all major indexes. Nevertheless, the score was higher than last year's. The report said physical safety remains a major problem for local women.

Rights conditions for elderly people received the lowest score of 2.58 points. The report said much work should be done to improve elderly people's basic human rights, participation in public affairs, care, dignity and self-realization.

Cultural and educational rights received a score of 2.91 percent. The report said rights to receive eduction and protection of cultural and educational workers received more recognition, while human rights education, students rights and participation in public affairs should be further improved.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BUDDHIST ASSOCIATION DONATES RELIEF GOODS TO SENEGAL

TEXT.P: The International Fokuang Association of the Republic of China has donated 400 boxes of clothes and 136 wheelchairs to the poor and disabled of Senegal, earning the gratitude of the people of the East African country.
According to information from the ROC embassy in Senegal, the donations have been distributed by local authorities to the needy in 10 areas of the country.

ROC Ambassador to Senegal Tu Chou-seng, along with other embassy staffers, held 11 donation ceremonies throughout the country, reinforcing the relationship between the two sides, embassy sources said.
Another batch of donations provided by the Buddhist association is expected to arrive in Senegal soon, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LISTED COMPANIES CAN APPLY FOR TAIEX LISTING: MOF

TEXT.P: Foreign listed companies can apply to be listed on Taiwan's Stock Exchange (TAIEX), just as local listed firms can be listed on stock markets in foreign countries, sources from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Tuesday.

Following news that Trend Micro Devices, a local software company, has been listed on the Japanese stock market, a reporter asked Ting Ke-hua, deputy chairman of the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) under the MOF, why foreign firms have not been listed on the TAIEX.
Ting pointed out that according to ROC law, foreign firms which have been listed companies for more than one year in their own countries can indeed apply to the SFC to be listed on the TAIEX.
However, he went on, no foreign companies have chosen to do so, although relevant regulations were enacted and passed by the legislature in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW COA CHAIRMAN NAMED

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday officially accepted the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), and assigned Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.

Ling, incumbent COA vice chairman, was born in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, in 1936. Holder of a master's degree in politics from Chinese Culture University, Ling served as deputy director of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Department of Central and South American Affairs before assuming his COA post in 1989.
Ling, who has been named as one of the top 10 Outstanding Young Persons of the country due to his remarkable performance in social services, has served under four COA chairmen.

Peng announced his decision to quit on Nov. 30, after the Cabinet decided, despite his strong opposition, to allow farmers to build houses on newly acquired farmland. A 40-minute meeting with Siew on Monday failed to change his mind.

Allowing farmers to construct houses on their land is tantamount to transforming the island's farmland into de-facto construction land, while allowing it to be exempt from construction regulations and virtually tax-free, Peng claimed.
He also warned that lifting the house-building ban is like opening a Pandora's box, and will cost the country's long-term agricultural policy dearly.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN TAIWAN FOR ROUTINE VISIT

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday night for an eight-day routine visit.

Bush was greeted at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport by T.J. Liu, chairman of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, Liu Chih-keng, director of the Department for North American Affairs, and Steven Young, deputy director of the AIT Taipei office.

Bush declined to speak to reporters upon arrival, but an advance announcement issued by the AIT Taipei Office said he will meet with the three principal candidates for the 2000 presidential election -- Vice President Lien Chan of the ruling Kuomintang, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian, and independent candidate James Soong, former Taiwan provincial governor.
He will also inspect the AIT offices in Taipei and in southern Kaohsiung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL URGES EU TO SET UP OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday called for the European Union (EU) to set up a representative office in Taiwan as soon as possible.

Chen made the appeal during a meeting with George Jarzembowski, president of the Taiwan Council of the European Parliament, who the former Taipei mayor visited shortly after his arrival in Belgium, the second leg of a three-country European trip.
Chen expressed the hope that Taiwan will be able to set up its own representative office in Brussels, the site of the EU, on a reciprocal basis.
However, Jarzembowski pointed out that it will be difficult for the EU to set up an office in Taiwan because of financial constraints.
Jarzembowski went on to say that the EU will consider setting up a Taiwan office once the island is given World Trade Organization membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS FALL IN BEHIND PARTY'S VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Annette Lu, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate for vice president in the 2000 presidential election, paid a visit to the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday.

The Taoyuan County magistrate told DPP legislators that her selection as running mate by DPP presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian will be announced on Friday, the 20th anniversary of the Formosa Incident, when a group of Taiwan dissidents, who later formed the DPP, marched with their supporters in Kaohsiung City in defiance of a government ban on political demonstrations, and clashed with military police.
Lu said that Chen chose her to underline his campaign promise to "make Taiwan a place where women are well-treated."

DPP Deputy Legislative Whip Chen Chao-nan said the fact that Lu, who served as a DPP legislator before being elected Taoyuan magistrate, was greeted by legislators belonging to various DPP factions, scuttled rumors that Chen Shui-bian's choice was not endorsed by the whole party.

Legislator Chen Chi-nan said the party's legislative caucus blesses Lu's candidacy just as a father blesses his daughter on her wedding day. The caucus will "prepare for her an ox-wagon loaded with dowry," he added.
Lu was accompanied by Chen Shui-bian's campaign manager Chang Chun-heng on the visit which was designed to build support for her candidacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui says democratic Taiwan has "walked out" its own road.
The China Times:

The Taiwan News:
