DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 8, or the first day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: The United States Labor Union is established.
1914: Britain's Royal Navy destroys a German naval squadron off the Falkland Islands.
1938: "The Count of Chaplin," the first German aircraft-carrier, is launched at the port of Kiel.
1941: Japan invades Thailand.
1941: The United States, Britain, and Australia declare war on Japan.
1944: US forces attack Iwo Jima, 750 miles south of Tokyo, to begin the longest, fiercest battle in the Pacific War.
1949: The United Nations National Assembly asks world powers to recognize the political independence of China, as the ROC government moves to Taiwan.
1953: The United States proposes the international control of atomic energy in the United Nations General Assembly.
1958: The first African People's Convention opens in Accra, the capital of the Republic of Ghana.
1959: The ROC Legislative Yuan amends Article 12 of the Organization Law of the National Assembly to enable the president to appoint an acting secretary general of the National Assembly when it is not in session.
1962: Rebellion in Brunei fails after British intervention.
1966: A Greek ferry sinks near Melos Island, killing 234.
1974: Greece votes to become a republic, abolishing a 142-year-old monarchy.
1975: Yu Chi Chien, South Korean education minister, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Hsieh Min-nan and Kuo Chi-hsiung return from Bangkok after taking second place in the 23rd World Cup Golf Championship.
1976: Abdullah B.H. Mohamed, a member of the Asian Amateur Athletic Association, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles R. Anderson, professor emeritus of American literature at John Hopkins University, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1978: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revised Foreign Exchange Management Regulations under which the new Taiwan dollar is no longer pegged to the US dollar.
1978: Golda Meir, who resigned as Israel's first woman prime minister in April 1974, dies at the age of 80.
1980: John Lennon, one of the four Beatles, is shot and killed in New York.
1980: Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Leonid Brezhnev visits India.
1986: The ROC and the United States reach agreement on tobacco and wine tariffs. The ROC's Ministry of Finance announces that from January 1987, US cigarettes and alcohol are free to enter the Taiwan market.
1990: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan resigns, but is re-appointed within 24 hours.
1991: Russia, Belarus, and the Ukraine form the "Commonwealth of Independent States" with its capital in Minsk.
1993: Kao Chun, a young mainland Chinese, hijacks a Northern Airlines flight to Taiwan.
1995: Communist China enthrones a new six-year-old Panchen Lama, pressing Tibetans to accept its controversial choice for Tibetan Buddhism's second-ranking monk one named by the Dalai Lama, the exiled religious leader.
1995: The World Health Organization announces that a new outbreak of the Ebola virus, which killed 250 in Zaire earlier in 1995, has been confirmed in the Ivory Coast.
1995: Flight services between Taiwan and Macau begin.
1997: US President Bill Clinton welcomes Wei Jingsheng, mainland China's noted democracy activist, to the White House.
1998: Japanese scientists report that they have cloned eight calves from the same dead cow.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO JOIN WTO UNDER NAME `CHINESE TAIPEI'

TEXT.P: Taiwan will join the World Trade Organization (WTO) under the name "Chinese Taipei," Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday.

"Chinese Taipei" is the brief and contingent form of "Independent Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" -- the name that Taiwan used when it applied in January 1990 to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which was superseded by the WTO in 1995, said Wang.
Taiwan began to use the title "Chinese Taipei" in 1991 when it joined the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum as a full member.
Wang predicted that the most likely time for Taiwan's accession to the WTO will be in mid to late 2000, given the relevant pre-accession procedures.

He added that although Beijing did not oppose Taiwan's entry into the WTO under the name "Independent Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu," it has insisted that it enter the world trade regulatory body before Taiwan.
Yielding to the situation, Wang said that Taiwan's accession to the WTO will most likely come after Beijing's, probably only a few minutes later.

According to Wang, the United States, Canada and the European Union did not think that Taiwan's accession should be linked to mainland China's accession. However, a large number of the other countries of the 135-member WTO insisted that Taiwan's entry should come after Beijing's.

Over the past four years, Taiwan has completed bilateral consultations with almost all the relevant countries and signed agreements paving the way for Taiwan's entry. The one exception is Hong Kong, with whom Taiwan has concluded WTO talks but hasn't signed any agreement yet, said Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10-MONTH-OLD BABY BOY WAITING FOR LIVER TRANSPLANT
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A 10-month-old baby boy is waiting for a fresh liver to replace his failed liver, caused by inherent gall tube blockage and cirrhosis, the liver transplant group at China Medical College Hospital (CMCH) said Wednesday.

Yang Mei-tu, director of the surgical department at CMCH, said the baby boy, surnamed Tsai, was stricken by continuous jaundice two months after birth and was sent to CMCH. He was diagnosed as having a blocked gall tube, resulting in cholangietic jaundice.
Yang said preliminary surgery was performed on the baby boy after being sent to CMCH, but cirrhosis of the liver resulted in recent liver failure, a poor appetite, and hindered growth.
After further tests, the liver transplant group decided the only way to save the baby's life was to replace his liver. The hospital has therefore completed all the preparations for surgery.
Yang urged the families of people who have recently died accidentally to exalt the spirit of fraternity and donate the deceased's liver to help save the baby.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY ENTER WTO IN MID-2000: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to be admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in May or June next year, Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen said on Wednesday.
Judging from the current circumstances, Chen said, it is widely believed that Taiwan and mainland China will be able to enter the Geneva-based WTO in the first half of next year.

"But many other factors may influence the decision of the international community, and we really hope that Taiwan can be admitted into the WTO immediately following mainland China's accession," he noted, adding that "we will exercise the greatest caution in the lead-up to Taiwan's membership."

Meanwhile, an official with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs revealed that about two weeks ago, a US official "in charge" of the issue told the Taiwan side that the island should be expected to be allowed to enter the world trade regulatory body in May or June 2000.

Nevertheless, the official warned that a number of uncertainties still remain in the way of accession. Many matters, including issues related to mainland China's most-favored nation trade status and the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act in the US Congress, can influence the outcome, he said.
American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush, who arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday for a nine-day visit, will also discuss issues pertinent to Taiwan's WTO membership with relevant local officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA'S 1ST HUMAN RIGHTS MONUMENT TO BE INAUGURATED ON FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The first human rights monument in Asia will be inaugurated on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan on Friday, to coincide with World Human Rights Day.

Senior government officials and monument promoters, including President Lee Teng-hui and Bo Yang, a noted writer who spent nearly 10 years in a tightly-guarded jail on Green Island as a political prisoner during Taiwan's martial law era, will attend the inaugural ceremony.

Bo Yang, chairman of both the monument preparatory committee and the Human Rights Education Foundation, said he hopes the new monument will help promote the concept of human rights and cultivate a climate conducive to respect and protection of human rights.

Bo Yang, the pen name of Kuo Ying-tung, expressed his gratitude for President Lee, who donated NT$20 million in proceeds from sales of his book "The Road to Democracy: Taiwan's Pursuit of Identity," toward the monument's construction and the promotion of human rights education.

"I also appreciate Premier Vincent Siew's assistance in land acquisition, as well as donations from other government officials and business executives for the NT$38 million monument project," said Po Yang.
The monument was designed by Han Pao-teh, a renowned architect and president of the National Tainan College of Arts, with the assistance of calligrapher Tai Lan-tsun and art designer Hou Jung-ling.

Po Yang said the monument sports a very special design and is made of high-quality limestone imported from Europe. "Generally speaking, the monument looks elegant and offers feelings of warmth and tenderness," he said.

The names of 500 political dissidents who were jailed on Green Island at one time or another during the repressive martial law era are inscribed on the monument, along with a poem by Bo Yang which reads: "During that grim period, how many mothers were crying in the darkness of long nights for their children jailed on this island?"
Bo Yang said the monument preparatory committee has taken great pains to collate the names of the former prisoners and persuade their families to agree to have their names inscribed on the monument.

"Many former Green Island prison inmates and their families were still reluctant to have their names engraved on the monument for fear of `trouble,'" Bo Yang said, adding that their hesitation reflects the depth of the psychological wounds endured by political dissidents and their families during the "white terror" era.

Bo Yang said the monument will be donated to the government after its inauguration. The Tourism Bureau's Green Island office will be responsible for management and maintenance of the monument, which is expected to become a new tourist attraction for the offshore island. "The area surrounding the monument will also be developed into a human rights park," Bo Yang said.

Meanwhile, the Human Rights Education Foundation will sponsor a workshop on Green Island on Dec. 10 to train human rights instructors. "We'll launch a human rights education campaign, with Green Island as the starting point," Bo Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET SET TO COME TO ELEVATORS

TEXT.P: In a move that will transform the experience of riding an elevator, Otis Elevator Company has signed letters of intent with Next Generation Network (NGN) and IBM to use Internet technology to bring news and entertainment into elevators throughout the US and around the world.

Otis, the world's largest elevator manufacturing company, intends to install in new and existing elevators an "e-Display," a monitor similar to a flat-panel computer screen, Stephen F. Page, President and CEO of Otis Elevator Company, announced Wednesday morning at a press conference held at the Waldore-Astoria Hotel.

The monitor will provide news, entertainment, and targeted advertising to elevator passengers in some of the more than 1.2 million elevators Otis operates around the world, and will enable managers of apartment complexes, hospitals and commercial buildings to communicate, quickly and efficiently, with residents, tenants, and members of the community--alerting them to critical information.

E-billboards by NGN currently provide information, e-tainment and targeted advertising via high resolution monitors to over 40 million consumers who wait in line each week. The monitors are currently located in over 5,000 coffee shops, lobby shops, convenience stores, Hispanic and Korean markets, gas pumps and transit hubs around the United States.
"Through e-Displays, we're bringing news and information to new heights, and elevator passengers are going to love this medium the way consumers do today," said Gerard P. Joyce, Chairman of NGN.

The relationship announced today will bring together the out-of-home media, content management and digital technology experience of NGN, and the hardware, software and networking capabilities of IBM's e-Business Solutions unit, and the global reach, brand equity and customer relationships of the Otis Elevator Company.

Otis Elevator Company--a subsidiary of United Technologies Corp.-- is also currently servicing more than one million elevators in more than 200 countries around the world, including Taiwan. (David Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE EMPLOYERS FACE HEAVY PENALTIES FOR HIRING ILLEGALS

TEXT.P: The Australian government will impose harsh new penalties on employers found to be employing illegal immigrants in its attempt to discourage illegal entries into the country and foreigners overstaying their visas.
Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock on Tuesday announced that employers will face fines of up to A$66,000 (US$44,000) and up to two years in jail for hiring illegal immigrants.
The harsh measures were immediately condemned by Australian business groups, particularly farmers, who often hire refugees during the harvest of citrus and other fruits.

Ruddock said the new measures are necessary for curbing the influx of illegal immigrants. "Each year my department locates a significant number of people who have been working without permission. They are taking jobs away from Australians." he told reporters.
But Mark Paterson, chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Australian farmers criticized the new measures.
The number of illegal immigrants surged substantially with the entry of about 2000 people from the Middle East and mainland China since July.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEROIN OVERDOSE CAUSE OF ONE IN 10 DEATHS OF AUSSIES AGED 15 TO 45

TEXT.P: Heroin overdoses now account for nearly one in 10 deaths among Australians aged between 15 and 44 with younger people within the age group accounting for more than 80 percent of the fatalities, according to a new survey released by the University of New South Wales in Sydney.

The survey shows that 737 Australians died from heroin overdoses in 1998, up 23 percent from 1997. New South Wales led all other states and territories in Australia with 358 deaths, up from 292 the previous year.
All states except western Australia recorded increases in the number of heroin overdoses with NSW accounting for nearly 49 percent of all deaths.

Shadow Special Minister for State Della Bosca described the heroin fatalities as an epidemic and asked the government to try harder to curb drug use among citizens in order to reduce the number of deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS PROPOSE NEW THEORY ON THE ORIGIN OF URANUS AND NEPTUNE

TEXT.P: Researchers have used computer simulations to show how the solar system's seventh and eighth planets, Uranus and Neptune, may have been formed.

Theorists have struggled to explain how Uranus and Neptune formed at their present locations in the Solar System because, at such distances, the disk density would have been low at the time that they began to form and the time required for them to grow is thought to be longer than the age of the Solar System.

Astronomers Edward Thommes and Martin Duncan of Queen's University in Canada, along with Harold Levison of the Southwest Research Institute in Boulder, Colorado, used computer simulations to propose a solution to this problem, according to the Dec. 9th issue of Nature magazine.

Their computer simulations begin with the assumption that Uranus and Neptune started out as rocky cores in the Jupiter-Saturn region, and were violently tossed out by gravitational scattering from those two planets when one or both accreted large amounts of gas.
The ejected planets remained in highly chaotic orbits for a few hundred thousand years, after which they settled down and gradually migrated to their present nearly circular orbits.
The authors begin their simulations with four rocky cores embedded in a narrow zone of the solar nebula and find that in 50% of their trials, the giant planets end up more or less where they are now.

The model is unusual in suggesting that all four giant planets originated in the same region of the solar nebula -- within a ring 5 to 10 astronomical units in distance from the Sun. 1 AU equals the distance from Earth to the sun.
This is substantially narrower than previous estimates of 10 to 20 AU for the birthplace of Uranus and Neptune, and far inward from their present locations of 19 and 30 AU, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD BANK FINDS POVERTY RATE IN ASIA DECREASING

TEXT.P: Despite the financial crisis in 1997, Asia remains well-placed to halve the number of its people living in absolute poverty by 2015, according to a new World Bank report.

The Australian on Wednesday quoted the Global Economic Prospects 2000 report as saying that the number of East Asians living in absolute poverty (less than US$1 per day) dropped to 265 million in 1996 from 432 million in 1993.
The outlook report for developing and under-developed regions found that at the end of 1998, the number of people in absolute poverty jumped to 278 million.

China, which accounted for more than 80 percent of East Asia's poorest people in 1996, has continued to grow strongly over the past three years, though the World Bank notes a worrying 2 million rise in the absolute number of people living in poverty between 1996 and 1998, the daily reported.

In South Asia, the moderate decline in the proportion of the population living in poverty, mainly due to India's booming economy, also has not stopped the absolute number of people living in poverty from rising.
The bank predicts that about 1.2 billion people in Asia will be living in absolute poverty by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE MOBILIZES NA DEPUTIES TO DRUM UP SUPPORT FOR LIEN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, on Wednesday called for an across-the-board mobilization of KMT deputies of the National Assembly (NA) to drum up support for Vice President Lien Chan, the party's candidate in the 2000 presidential election.

Lee said the presidential election at the turn of the century is crucial to the future development of the Republic of China and the KMT. Seeking victory in the election is currently the pivotal mission that party members should strive to accomplish, he added.
Lee called for the NA deputies to gear up in the next 100 days to create greater momentum and efficiency for the KMT so as to enable the ruling party to win the century election.
"We will fight in the upcoming 100 days to the last ditch," he appealed.
Lee made the remarks during a ceremony marking the swearing-in of Tsai Cheng-yuan as the new NA secretary-general and 18 others as deputy secretaries-general.
Tsai's predecessor, Chen Ming-jen, resigned in September after the then NA Speaker Su Nan-cheng rammed a vote through the NA for a controversial amendment to extend NA members' terms.
Su had since come under fire by both NA deputies and by the general public, leading to his being expelled by the KMT on Oct. 30.

The KMT charged Su with violating the party line and public opinion by forcing the passage of the self-serving bill allowing the incumbent NA deputies to extend their tenures for two years to May 2002.
NA Deputy President Chen Chin-Rang was appointed by President Lee Teng-hui as acting president of the NA on Oct. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE INSTITUTE MAKES SECOND DONATION TO TAIWAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Delegates from Japan's Institute of Moralogy on Wednesday brought to Taiwan a second cash donation from the society since the 7.3-magnitude earthquake which struck Taiwan on Sept. 21.

The donation of 16.43 million yen (US$164,300) was presented by Toshio Ozawa, a standing director of the Hiroike school, an offshoot operation of the institute, to the National Cultural Association (NCA) of the Republic of China.

Receiving the donation, NCA Secretary-General Huang Shih-cheng relayed President Lee Teng-hui's gratitude to the institute for its compassion, which Lee described as "warm as burning coal in deep winter."

Just five days after the devastating earthquake struck, Mototaka Hiroike, the fourth-generation descendant of Chikuro Hiroike, founder of the Institute of Moralogy, donated 4 million yen to Taiwan which was remitted through the NCA to a unified account under the Executive Yuan, according to Pai Yung-chuan, director of the Spiritual Reform Committee under the NCA.

Before making the donation on Wednesday, Ozawa and his aide, Eichi Jishima, visited central Taiwan, where they spent two days familiarizing themselves with the latest developments in post-quake rehabilitation efforts.
The Institute of Moralogy, an important arm of moral education and spiritual reconstruction in Japan, was established by Chikuro Hiroike some 70 years ago.
The institute has made tremendous contributions to moral and social education in Japan through its Hiroike school, providing long-term and short-term educational environments and facilities.

Ozawa is also vice president of Reitaku University in suburban Tokyo, one of the many educational functions of the institute, and a popular university among students from Taiwan, with a current roster of 70 students from the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10% OF LOCAL HIV-CARRIERS FOUND BY BLOOD DONATION CENTERS

TEXT.P: More than 10 percent of the Republic of China nationals confirmed as being infected with HIV, which causes deadly AIDS, were discovered by local blood donation centers, the Department of Health (DOH) said on Wednesday.
DOH tallies show that 254 of the 2,350-plus confirmed local HIV carriers were diagnosed after being screened at blood donation centers.
"This ratio is too high," said Tu Shing-jer, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control. "It is immoral to use blood donation as a channel for HIV testing," he added.

He was referring to a local practice whereby certain members of the public who suspect they may have contracted the virus go to blood donation centers because they believe it affords greater anonymity than going to a testing center at a local hospital.

Tu explained that there is "window period" for blood from an infected person, during which it is impossible to detect whether it is contaminated with HIV. As a result, the possibility exists that patients might receive a contaminated blood transfusion and become infected with the deadly virus.
To date, Tu said, nine local people have been infected with HIV after receiving blood transfusions.

Tu urged those in high-risk groups, including homosexuals, bisexuals, drug addicts and people who have sex with prostitutes, not to donate blood. "They should instead go to designated hospitals for anonymous HIV testing as soon as possible."
Tu reminded those in high-risk groups that blood donation centers now no longer inform individual donors of their test results, and added that HIV-infected blood donors can also face punishment.
According to DOH statistics, 125 of Taiwan's HIV carriers are students. The same tallies also show that sex is the main route of transmission among teenage HIV carriers.
Meanwhile, 87 married couples are confirmed to have been infected with HIV, including 12 of which one member is a foreign spouse.

DOC.HEADLINE: `AVOID WAR BUT BE NOT AFRAID OF WAR' -- ROC DEFENSE POLICY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan on Wednesday summed up the country's defense policy as "Avoid war but be not afraid of war."
Lien made the remark at the opening ceremony of an academic seminar on cross-century national security and military strategy sponsored by the Armed Forces University at the National Central Library.
In light of Beijing's military buildup and its hostility toward Taipei, the ROC cannot remain self-satisfied simply with the renovation of existing weapons and related outfits, Lien said.

Instead, he went on, the country's military strategy and national defense construction should be subject to appropriate adjustment according to changes in the international climate and the advancement of science and technology.

Lien stressed that the ROC should keep abreast of digital sci-tech in the development of national defense, strengthen anti-missile ability, and establish a reliable deterrent force, as well as strengthen its second-strike ability.

The ruling Kuomintang-nominated candidate for the 2000 presidential election said he favors the establishment of a militarily reciprocal trust mechanism between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait which could dissolve conflicts through communication and mutual understanding.

Lien said he also favors the establishment of a military exercise reciprocal notice and verification system across the strait, and a hot line between Taipei and Beijing in order to prevent unnecessary overreaction from either side.

As to the issue of joining a theater missile defense (TMD) system, Lien said that whether or not the ROC joins such a system in the future, it should strengthen the establishment of anti-missile advanced warning, interception and destruction systems in order to ensure national security.
Ten papers on the international situation, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, national security and national defense were presented and discussed at the one-day seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, SENEGAL TO SIGN LOAN AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Senegal are slated to sign a loan agreement on Thursday under the terms of which Taiwan will agree to provide credit to help Senegal develop its small business sector.

Loh Ping-cheung, secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and Senegal Industry Minister Magued Diouf, will clinch the agreement on behalf of their respective governments.

The accord states that the ROC government will offer a loan of US$4 million directed to Senegal's small businesses, and dispatch a 30-member delegation to the West African country to provide technical assistance and consulting services to the local food-processing and garment industries, the ICDF said.

Senegal President Mamadou Lamine Loum said in his inaugural speech in July 1997 that the Senegal government had selected eight industries, including the food-processing sector, to try to attract foreign capital in order to boost the country's economic development, according to the ICDF.

The Senegal government then approached the ROC government for assistance, whereupon the ICDF decided to provide a loan and work out a package to help the African country finance and boost its small business sector, it noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 0.2 percent on Wednesday over Y2K concerns as the end of the year approaches.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 16.03 points lower at 7,811.02, and turnover expanded to NT$135.99 (US$4.3 billion), with 2.40 billion shares changing hands.
The market opened higher, boosted by the US NASDAQ composite index which again hit a record high, but late selling, especially in the financial sector, erased the early gains.
Buying in Internet and telecommunication-related issues remained strong as their future outlook seems prosperous.
Dealers predicted that the local bourse will experience consolidation at between 7,500 and 8,000 points because Y2K concerns are likely to ward off investment.
All of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with the exception of the textile sector, which enjoyed a 2-percent gain, and the electronics sector, which remained unchanged.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 344 to 140, with 69 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market moved up 0.1 points to close at 185.46, on a turnover of NT$13.70 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 30 points to close at 7,840, with 1,352 contract transactions. Those for January declined 14 points to finish at 7,866, with 177 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March climbed 18 points to close at 7,930, with seven contract transactions, while those for next June rose seven points to close at 7,981, with three contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,870 points for December, 7,880 points for January, 7,912 points for next March, 7,974 points for next June, and 7,974 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported losses.
December TE futures shed one point to close at 392.8, with 428 contract transactions, and January TE futures moved down 0.4 points to finish at 393.1, with 73 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

December TF futures dropped 7.8 points to close at 961.6, with 129 contract transactions, January TF futures dipped five points to close at 977 points, with 11 contract transactions, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT STARTS `100-DAY BATTLE' FOR PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang, led the party's presidential nominee and core members on Wednesday in an oath of allegiance as they joined a "100-day battle" for the Republic of China presidency.

During the ceremony, Lee, whose tenure as president will expire next May, harshly criticized so-called "supra-party" politics as Nazi thought which will undermine party politics and harm the very basis on which the island's democracy is built.

Implying that independent presidential candidate James Soong is an ingrate for deserting the party, Lee called for support for the KMT's presidential candidate, Vice President Lien Chan, who he described as "honest and talented."

Soong, the former Taiwan provincial governor and a one-time KMT stalwart, was expelled from the KMT because of his decision to run for the presidency in the 2000 election despite the party's decision to nominate Lien with Premier Vincent Siew as his vice presidential running mate in the March 18 election.
Lee issued an all-out mobilization order to his party, calling members to stick together in the face of the upcoming fight for the KMT's continuing administration of the country.
"If the Kuomintang loses next year, it will jeopardize the stability of Asia, and even the whole world," Lee said.

Most public opinion survey results to date have shown Soong to be enjoying the largest popularity ratings among the six presidential candidates, who include former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, and independent candidate Hsu Hsin-liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER OPPOSES PULLOUT OF GARRISON FORCE FROM PRATAS ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Former Premier Hau Pei-tsun said Wednesday that he is opposed to the Ministry of National Defense decision to pull out the garrison force from the Pratas Islands (Tungsha Chuntao).
Hau said that although the Republic of China has not needed to develop nuclear weapons, ROC development of conventional weapons is necessary.

Hau, who stepped down from the premiership in 1993, denied previous news reports that he had a political struggle with President Lee Teng-hui. He stepped down because of differences of opinion with the president, Hau said.

In an interview with a local radio station, Hau said he has recently been pulled back into the public spotlight by developments in the upcoming presidential election after separate visits by Vice President Lien Chan, the ruling Kuomintang presidential candidate, and Premier Vincent Siew.

Hau was reluctant to make known which candidates he will support. He described Lien as a honest man and said it is unfair that former Taiwan Governor and independent presidential candidate James Soong, has been called a "crafty and cunning man." Hau said it is better to say that Soong is a person of contemplation.

Speaking on his meeting with Lien, Hau expressed caution about President Lee's redefinition of cross-strait relations as "special state-to-state" ties. He also urged the ruling party to resolve the constitutional crisis and the self-extended tenure of the national assembly deputies as soon as possible.

Hau stressed that Lee's proposed theory of special state-state ties was very dangerous and said it would bring a great disaster to Taiwan. He insisted on the one China principle, with Taiwan and mainland China each having the right to its own interpretation.
Hau said that he is worried about the growth of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). The more votes the DPP gets, the more danger for Taiwan, he said.

Although he praised the president's contributions to promote Taiwan's democratization in the early 1990s, he criticized Lee's role in five instances of constitutional amendment which have completely destroyed the constitution. On the surface, Taiwan is democratic, but actually, Taiwan's democratization has suffered setbacks in the past 10 years, he said.

Hau also confirmed that the ROC originaiily had plans to develop nuclear weapons and mid-range missiles, but in yielding to pressure from foreign countries, the ROC was forced to abandon the projects.
Hau, who was once vice chairman of the Kuomintang, was ousted by the party in 1996 for running as vice presidential candidate in defiance of the KMT in Taiwan's first direct presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar posted a drop against the greenback on Wednesday after sustaining appreciation over the past nine consecutive trading days.

Taipei Forex trading saw gains on the local unit at the start, but then sustained drops because of the US dollar's rebound in the international market, which affected the yen, an influential currency in the Asian market.
Dealers analyzed that the devaluation also probably resulted from interference by the Central Bank of China aimed at maintaining stability of the currency value.
The NT dollar opened at 31.55, and was traded between 31.605 and 31.55 before closing at 31.605, posting a 0.5-cent drop compared with the previous session.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$652 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE ADDRESSES EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By P. C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Republic of China's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), delieved a speech to the European Parliament's democratic liberal party caucus on Tuesday.
Chen was the second Taiwan politician to deliver an address at the European Parliament after former Foreign Minister John Chang, who now serves as presidential secretary-general to the President.
In his speech, Chen said the DPP has managed to take the helm at 13 local county and city governments in Taiwan after 15 years of development.
"We hope to grip power at the central government level by winning next year's presidential election," the DPP's standard-bearer for the 2000 presidential election said.
Chen urged the European Parliament, the legislative arm of the European Union, not to disregard Taiwan while promoting relations with the "People's Republic of China."
Stressing that the "PRC" has never ruled Taiwan, Chen said Taiwan's future, regardless of moving toward independence or unification, should be decided by its people through a plebiscite.
The lawyer-turned-politician said even he manages to win the presidency next year, he cannot personally decide whether Taiwan will go toward independence or unification with the Chinese mainland.
If elected, Chen said he will give the top priority to seeking nromalization of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Touching on foreign policy, Chen said if elected, he will devote even more efforts to strengthen relations with the EU, in addition to promoting ties with Taiwan's two major traditional allies -- the United States and Japan.

"I believe there is still ample room for Taiwan to forge closer cooperation with the EU," Chen said, adding that he thinks Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises can form strategic alliances with their EU counterparts.
Meanwhile, Chen expressed welcome to a decision by the executive commission of the International Alliance of Liberal Parties to hold a board meeting in Taiwan next year.
"I regard the meeting as a support for the DPP and my presidential bid," Chen said, adding that he is confident of his presidential bid.

Chen arrived in Brussels on Tuesday after a two-day visit to London where he delivered a speech on Taiwan's new political vision at the London School of Economics and Political Science's "public afairs forum."

During his whirlwind visit to Brussel, Chen met with many influential European Parliament (EP) members, including Georg Jarzembowski, chairman of the EP's Taiwan Association; Bertel Haarder, deputy whip of the EP's liberal democratic parties caucus; and Elmar Brok, chairman of EP's Foreign Affairs Committee.

During his meeting with Brok, Chen said Taiwan's current biggest difficulties are mainland China's military threat and failure to enter major international organizations even it meets all requirements.

Chen told Brok that Taiwan's security is important not only to the United States and Japan but also to other areas around the world. Chen said the EU should set up an office in Taiwan to facilitate bilateral exchanges and help boost regional peace and stability.

Chen was originally scheduled to meet with Beligian Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt, a former leader of Belgium's Liberal Party, on Tuesday afternoon. However, the meeting was canceled due to Verhofstadt's tight working schedule.
Chen said later that he felt regret over failure to hold private talks with the Belgian prime minister as scheduled.
Chen will also visit the Netherlands before ending his three-leg European tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T EMPLOYEES NOT TO RECEIVE PAY RAISE NEXT FISCAL YEAR

TEXT.P: The Central Personnel Administration of the Executive Yuan said Wednesday that due to effects of the killer Sept. 21 earthquake, the government has decided not to adjust government employees' salaries next fiscal year, which begins Jan. 1, 2000.
Chang Tse-tsen, director general of the CPA, said the year-end month-and-a-half bonus and the one-month service grading award for good performance will remain unchanged.

Asked whether salaries would be adjusted in the 2001 fiscal year, Chang said it is premature to say whether or not pay raises would be offered. The government will reconsider the situation after the its financial situation improves, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI THANKS INT'L FRIENDS WHO HELPED THE 921 QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: On behalf of the victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake, Master Cheng Yen on Thursday expressed her appreciation to the international community and to individuals who have extended helping hands to the victims.

"You have lifted the spirits of the victims and given them great strength" in their reconstruction effort, said the master, who founded the Taiwan Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, at a press conference in honor of the international friends.

Yao Ren-lu, the spokesman of the Tzu Chi Foundation, revealed that in its relief efforts, the foundation received a lot of help from abroad. Some helped by making donations, and some by putting in their time and effort.
"Their actions fully exemplified their belief in `reverence for life' and that `great love transcends all borders,'" he said.

He noted that special thanks should be given to: ABN Amro Bank, the American Chamber of Commerce, AmeriCares, the Australia Commerce & Industry Office, the British Trade and Cultural Office, the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, the Europe Council of Commerce and Trade, Fairton International Group, Goodyear, IVUSA, Lucent Technologies Foundation, Mercy Airlines, US GE Co., World Daily and many others.
Yao explained that Tzu Chi's relief plan for the 921 earthquake victims consists of three phases: emergency relief, resettlement and Project Hope.

In the emergency relief phase, the Tzu Chi Foundation mobilized 100,000 volunteers, set up 31 relief stations in the disaster areas, and provided NT$220 million (US$7 million) in cash to the quake victims.
In the resettlement phase, Tzu Chi mobilized 200,000 volunteers who worked at 17 sites to assemble 1,713 prefabricated houses, the estimated cost of which is NT$1.2 billion (US$40 million).
The goal of Project Hope is the reconstruction of more than thirty schools with an estimated cost of NT$4.5 billion (US$150 million).
The total budget for the relief plan is estimated to be NT$6 billion (US$200 million). Tzu Chi expects all phases to be completed by August 2001.

David Coates, director of the British Trade and Cultural Office, also spoke at the conference. He praised Tzu Chi as one of the most effective and respected international humanitarian aid organizations in Taiwan.

"That Taiwan has such an organization is a testimony to the generosity and spirit of the people of Taiwan and to the determination and practicality of Dharma Master Cheng Yen in putting Buddhist ideals into daily life," he said.
He expressed his belief that with the spirit and determination of organizations like Tzu Chi, Taiwan's reconstruction will be solid both in practical and humanitarian terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER CALLS ON WHO TO ACCEPT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew has called for the World Health Organization (WHO) to accept Taiwan as a member nation of that organization.

In a commentary published in Tuesday's edition of the Chicago Tribune, Siew stressed that the Sept. 21 killer earthquake has resulted in much closer relations between Taiwan and other members of the international community.
Siew called ROC entry to the WHO "most urgent."

In his article, Siew expressed heartfelt thanks to those countries that rushed disaster-relief personnel to Taiwan to carry out rescue missions after the killer earthquake jolted the central part of the island on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,400 lives.

Taiwan learned a great deal about the importance of humanitarian spirit and cooperation in face of disaster, Siew said, adding that this kind of spirit is in accordance with the principles mapped out by the WHO.

Siew went on to say that Taiwan has completed the first phase of rehabilitation work in areas stricken by the earthquake. The issue of public sanitation was the most urgent one faced by Taiwan, Siew said.

The sanitation issue not only affects victim's health but also that of people in neighboring countries, he warned, adding that member nations usually appeal to the WHO for help and technical assistance in such situations.

Taiwan, however, has been excluded by the WHO since 1972, when the organization yielded to pressure from Beijing, and Taiwan has subsequently only been able to secure assistance through unofficial channels.
Siew urged the WHO to remove all obstacles, including political barriers, so as to carry out the ideals and principles of the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ISSUES STATEMENT TO COMMEMORATE FORMOSAN INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) issued a statement Wednesday ahead of the 20th anniversary of the Formosan incident, and expressed its hope to replace the ruling Kuomintang to further promote democracy.
The DPP noted that "the Formosan incident created a historical wave and resulted in the construction of the nation of Taiwan."

The largest opposition party on the island pointed out that it is still not fully satisfied with the development of Taiwan, and it will strive for further democracy and prosperity for the island by taking the helm of state.
The Formosan incident, which is regarded as a milestone of Taiwan's democratization, occurred on Dec. 10, 1979, when opposition leaders gathered in Kaohsiung to mark World Human Rights Day.
Many opposition leaders were arrested and tried by military courts after the incident.

The statement said that the movement initiated by Formosan Magazine 20 years ago was intended to achieve democracy and reform, adding that it awakened public consciousness and formed the spiritual foundation for Taiwan's democratization.
The DPP stated that "Taiwan is a country" and "the Formosan incident 20 years ago was the starting point of a huge construction project for this country."

DOC.HEADLINE: NARRATIVE HISTORY OF FORMOSAN INCIDENT PUBLISHED

TEXT.P: A narrative history of the 1979 Formosan Incident was published by the New Taiwan Cultural and Educational Research Foundation and China Times Publishing Company on Wednesday.

Shih Ming-teh, former chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that he began to devote himself to collecting accounts of the incident when he stepped down as DPP chairman two years ago.
At one time, he said, he fell into financial difficulty because of the project, but "thanks to the help of others, the precious data of the Formosan Incident have been preserved now."

Hsu Hsin-liang, former DPP chairman and an independent presidential candidate, praised Shih for his efforts to safeguard first-hand data on the Formosan Incident, which is regarded as a milestone of Taiwan's democratization.
He said the new challenge for the leading figures of the Formosan incident is whether they can re-create a new history.
Yao Chia-wen, who is also a former DPP chairman, expressed his hope that the experience of the Formosan Incident will be used to work out a plan for Taiwan's future development.
Chen Fang-ming, a history professor at National Chi Nan University, said the narrative history will serve as important data on the study of Taiwan's modern democratization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FM LAYS OUT GUIDELINES FOR FOREIGN POLICY

TEXT.P: In his first appearance at the Legislative Yuan as foreign minister, Chen Chien-jen on Wednesday laid out three guidelines for Taiwan's foreign policy.

Chen, who was the director general of the Government Information Office before being tapped to replace Jason Hu and take the reins at the foreign ministry early this month, outlined the following three pillars of diplomacy for the future:
-- diplomacy carried out on all fronts rather than in the conventional domains of politics, security and economy, with the purpose of increasing the country's presence around the world; and
-- engaging with countries around the world irrespective of their geographic distance from Taiwan.
The new minister also advocated sincerity, practicality and thoroughness in diplomacy.
In response to questions from legislators, Chen denied news wire reports from Albania that Taipei offered aid amounting to US$1 billion in exchange for diplomatic recognition by that country.
"The ministry just doesn't have the budget, which is closely supervised by the legislature, to make such a promise, let alone to buy diplomatic recognition," said Chen.

As for a statement in Hong Kong Tuesday by US 7th Fleet Commander Walter Doran that Washington would likely seek allies if conflict between Taiwan and mainland China required military intervention, Chen said the ROC welcomes any state's assistance that proves helpful for maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait, although he is checking out whether Doran's remark reflects the official US view.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE DELEGATION TO PROMOTE SALES IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: A ranking executive with the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will lead a group of representatives from the local information technology industry to tap Japan's market, according to a CETRA-issued news release.

The trade mission, comprising executives of nine leading information technology companies, is scheduled to leave for Japan in mid-December, with CETRA Secretary-General Ricky Y.S. Kao leading the delegation.

This is the first time that CETRA, a quasi-official organization in charge of promoting economic and trade exchanges between Taiwan and other countries, is organizing a group of information product manufacturers to expand their exports to Japan.

The news release stated that the group will attend a series of sales promotion activities, to be cosponsored by CETRA, the Ministry of Economic Affairs' task force for promotion of the information technology industry, and the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association.
The event will be held at the Tokyo Palace Hotel and at the offices of Keidanren, the largest business association in Japan, on Dec. 15 and 16, respectively.

Among the promotion activities will be an exhibition of information products and a seminar on the development of LCD-related products, said CETRA in its news release, adding that a ranking executive from the Japanese semi-conductor industry newspaper will be invited to lecture at the symposium.

Meanwhile, a CETRA official revealed that next year the council will sponsor a series of similar activities abroad to help local manufacturers of notebook- and palm-sized computers and modems to expand their global market shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-JAPAN TRADE CONFERENCE CONCLUDES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Japan concluded their 24th bilateral economic and trade conference with the singing of the conference minutes on Wednesday.

Speaking at the signing ceremony at the Tokyo office of the Japan Interchange Association, Lin Chin-chin, chairman of the Association of East Asian Relations and head of the ROC delegation, hailed the conference as a success.
Lin said the conference provides a valuable forum for trade officials of both sides to exchange opinions and has a positive impact on bilateral ties.
The day-and-a-half conference was held in Tokyo with Lin and his Japanese counterpart, President Reijiro Hattori of the Interchange Association, serving as the top negotiators for each side.

The 63-member delegation from Japan included 45 officials from Japan's ministries of foreign affairs, health and welfare, agriculture and forestry, international trade and industry, and transportation. Eleven of them are mid-ranking officials.
Representing the ROC were 35 government officials and advisers.

At the conference, the two sides discussed 42 issues including bilateral trade, protection of intellectual property rights, technological cooperation, and joint exploitation of agricultural and fishery resources.

Among the results, Japan has agreed to: extend the business hours of the customs office at Haneda airport in Tokyo to facilitate importation of eels from Taiwan; participate in the fourth negotiations on the temporary admission accord for imports later this month in Taiwan; and invite Taiwan to participate in a seminar in Japan on export of high-tech products next spring.

Japan also promised to: open negotiations with Taiwan for a transit agreement on waste from specific industries; work out joint policies on trade liberalization at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and on agricultural issues at the World Trade Organization; and promote industrial alliances among small- and mid-sized business of both countries.
The Japanese delegation also reiterated Tokyo's support for Taiwan's speedy entry into the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui blames party turncoats for trying to use a Nazi-style supra-party alliance to destroy Taiwan's democratic party politics.
The China Times:
KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui sharply attacks 'someone'; KMT turns up the heat in last 100 days of presidential campaign.
The United Daily News:
Vice President Lien Chan calls for long-range missiles, cross-strait hot line.
The Liberty Times:
Veep Lien says Taipei and Beijing should adopt confidence-building measures.
The China Post:
The ruling Kuomintang launches '100-day war' for presidency.
The Taiwan News:
Veep Lien calls for long-range missiles, saying surface-to-surface weapon needed to deter assault from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 9, or the second day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1625: England and the United Provinces agree to subsidize Denmark's King Christian IV in his campaign against Germany.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the child-labor act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti-communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany, and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: US Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the government on President Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The UN General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun, and his wife.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with US President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the US-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1988: West Germans want curbs on NATO military flights over their country.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1992: US forces land in Somalia, and 35 nations take part in the "hope restoring" military action.
1994: The Irish Republican Army talk peace with British officials after 25 years of violence.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONSIDERING INVESTMENT IN PANAMA CROSS-OCEAN BRIDGE PROJECT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By H.T. Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Officials from the Kuomintang (KMT) Business Management Committee are currently in Panama City exploring the feasibility of pitching in investment in the building of the proposed cross-ocean bridge near the Panama Canal.

The KMT business group, together with representatives from the newly-privatized Ret-Ser Engineering Agency (RSEA) and several other Taiwan-based engineering firms inspected factors pertaining to development of the cross-ocean bridge so as to prepare themselves, as a group, to take part in open bidding for the construction project.

Members of the Taiwan group, since arriving in Panama City on Sunday, have met and exchanged views with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso, Public Engineering Minister Meises Castillo de Leon and officials from the Panama Canal Authority on matters concerning the proposed cross-ocean bridge.

The Panamanian authorities welcomed the Taiwan group's interest in the bridge project, which will be open to bidding by all qualified engineering companies from around the world for contracts. So far, companies from Japan, South Korea, Italy, France, the United States, Sweden, Mexico and Taiwan have shown keen interest in pitching in.

Also on Tuesday, ROC Ambassador in Panama Lan Chih-min, on behalf of the government of the ROC, donated US$1.4 million to Panama to help finance a major river recoursing project in Los Santos province in central Panama.

At a ceremony marking the donation, President Moscoso expressed gratitude to Taiwan for its goodwill which she said will greatly help curb land problems in Los Santos related to the annual floods there.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON SIGNS BILL SUPPORTING TAIWAN'S WHO MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton on Tuesday signed into law a bill requiring a report to Congress from Secretary of State Madeleine Albright by Jan. 1 2000 regarding the Clinton administration's efforts to secure Taiwan's appropriate and meaningful participation in the World Health Organization.

Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-OH), who sponsored the legislation, said this law compels the United States to abide by its 1994 Taiwan Policy Review to more actively support Taiwan's participation in the WHO and other international organizations.

"For too long, Taiwan's 21 million citizens have been denied access to the WHO and its medical expertise. The question is not whether Taiwan belongs in the WHO, but whether we support improving health care for children, the elderly, and the most vulnerable people in Taiwan. These are goals that our nation should support," he said.

Brown, the top Democrat on the House Commerce Health and Environment Subcommittee, added that "denying Taiwan's participation in the WHO is an unjustifiable violation of its people's fundamental human rights. Instead of worrying about offending China, our government should help Taiwan gain its rightful place in the WHO and other international organizations. This law is a step in the right direction."

Last fall, the Brown-sponsored resolution urging Taiwan's membership in the WHO was unanimously passed by the House. Brown spearheaded the drive in Congress to win official US support for Taiwan's entry into the WHO.
Taiwan, last a WHO member in 1972, requires a majority vote of all its members to be readmitted into the Geneva-based health organization.

The Formosan Association for Public Affairs on Wednesday thanked Rep. Brown and all the members of Congress who pushed for this bill and House Resolution 3427, also known as the Foreign Relations Authorization Act.

On November 30, Clinton signed into law HR 3427, which requires a semi-annual report detailing a list of the international organizations in which the US government supports Taiwan's membership or participation, as well as the efforts of the US government to achieve Taiwan's membership in each organization listed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON REITERATES CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton reiterated Wednesday the principles of American policy on China, saying that the US believes there is only one China, that disputes have to be resolved through cross-strait dialogue, and that Washington opposes and would view with grave concern any kind of violent action across the Taiwan Straits.

Clinton was asked at a presidential press conference if he was concerned about America's ability to defend Taiwan with Communist China building a second short-range missile base allowing them to attack Taiwan with little or no warning.

He responded by saying Communist China is modernizing its military in a lot of ways, "but our policy on China is crystal-clear. We believe there is one China. We think it has to be resolved through cross-strait dialogue. And we oppose and would view with grave concern any kind of violent action. And that hasn't changed."

Although there are tensions across the Taiwan Strait, Clinton said he is convinced that "if you look at the amount of Taiwanese investment in China, it's obvious that eventually they're going to get this worked out because they are too interconnected by ties of family and increasingly by ties of economy."

Regarding the Panama Canal, Clinton stressed that "it's important for the American people to understand that the canal itself will be operated and controlled entirely by the government of Panama, through the Panama Canal Authority. It is completely and totally within the control of the Panamanians."

He noted that the Hong Kong company which got the concession to operate the ports at both ends of the canal "will be responsible for loading and unloading ships. They also do this in three or four ports in Great Britain. The managing director is British. Most of the employees will be Panamanian. So I feel comfortable that our commercial and security interests can be protected under this arrangement."

DOC.HEADLINE: TESTOSTERONE MAY INCREASE LIKELIHOOD OF VASCULAR DISEASE

TEXT.P: Testosterone has an adverse effect on blood vessels and can increase men's risk of developing vascular disease, according to a new study by the Heart Research Institute in Sydney.

The study, led by Associate Professor David Celermajer, shows testosterone increases the stickiness of blood vessel walls, allowing cholesterol to build up on them more easily, and also making it more likely that the cells in the walls will load up on fats.
"This means that maleness is a risk factor for heart disease, like diabetes, and high cholesterol and high blood pressure and obesity," Celermajer told reporters on Wednesday.
He said the hormone that gives men their facial hair, muscles, and bone strength could also be giving them heart disease.

He said women have a much lower rate of heart disease than men. A woman in her 40s has a one in three chance of developing coronary disease as compared with a one in two chance for a man of the same age.
Celermajer said that even in their 70s, after they have stopped producing estrogen, women still have lower rates of heart disease than men.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SUPPORTS RUSSIAN CHECHNYA CAMPAIGN AS INTERNAL AFFAIR
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is scheduled to arrive in Beijing on Thursday for a two-day visit to strengthen ties between his country and mainland China. Russia has become an important source of high-technology weapons for the People's Liberation Army but foreign analysts said China remains highly dependent on the U.S. and the West for exports and investment to keep its economy growing fast enough to prevent social unrest or a political challenge to the Chinese Communist Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OPEN TO STRATEGIES TO BEEF UP DEFENSE CAPABILITY: LIN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) would welcome any strategies or measures that are conducive to strengthening Taiwan's defensive capabilities, a senior MAC official said on Thursday.

MAC spokesman and Vice Chairman Lin Chung-ping said seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China and maintaining stability across the Taiwan Strait have long been set policies of the MAC, but it welcomes all measures that could beef up Taiwan's defense muscle, given that Beijing has never renounced using force against Taiwan and has continued to mount missile deployment aimed at the island.
Lin made the remarks to echo Vice President Lien Chan's calls Wednesday for long-range missile to deter assault from mainland China.
Addressing a seminar at the Ministry of National Defense's Armed Forces University, Lien said Taiwan needs long-range surface-to-surface missiles that can discourage an attack on Taiwan.
Lien said that in order to ensure the Chinese communists don't dare invade Taiwan, the country must establish a credible deterrent military force and bolster its second-strike capability.
"That includes developing the potential force of long-range surface-to-surface missiles," said Lien, the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for the 2000 presidential election.
Commenting on Lien's missile calls, Lin Yu-fang, an associate professor at Tamkang University, said that seeking development of ballistic missiles is by no means an easy task.
Lin said all plans to develop ballistic missiles are limited by controls established by international treaties.

Moreover, he added, mid-range missiles fired from Taiwan would have a sufficient range to cover the entire mainland. Taiwan's talk of building long-range missiles would be meaningless, except for the purpose of astounding the United States and European countries.
"Lien should read more before speaking," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC SINGLES OUT POSSIBLE POST-MACAU HANDOVER PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China must work out measures to cope with mainland China's intensified propaganda war after it takes control of Macau from Portugal later this month, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Thursday.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said mainland China will certainly take advantage of the Dec. 20 Macau handover to promote its so-called "one country, two systems" scheme for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, the MAC said, mainland China will step up efforts to sway pro-Taiwan social groups in Macau, such as associations of alumni of Taiwan universities and colleges, the Sun Yat-sen Society and the Taiwan General Chamber of Commerce. Those moves would make Taiwan's work in Macau even more difficult after the enclave's handover.

The MAC also reiterated in its report to the weekly Cabinet meeting that after the handover, Macau residents who hold Portuguese passports can still make 14-day visa-free visits to Taiwan in accordance with the Schengken Convention.

As many recent mainland Chinese immigrants to Macau have traveled to Taiwan for either work or sightseeing, the MAC said relevant government agencies should study whether an increase in the number of visitors from Macau would have an adverse impact on Taiwan's national security.
The MAC went on to say that it is also worth studying whether mainland China-financed companies in Macau have made their way into Taiwan and any possible impact of such activities.
In preparation for the impending change in Macau's status, the ROC government has legislated a special statute to regulate exchanges with the enclave in the post-handover era.
The MAC will also inaugurate a new department on Dec. 20 to handle post-handover Taiwan-Macau exchanges and other related affairs.

In related news, MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chon-pin said mainland China's insistence that all cultural and academic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait must serve political purposes has seriously hindered positive cross-strait interaction.
Lin told a news conference that mainland China has intensified obstruction of cross-strait cultural and academic exchanges this year.

"The scope and frequency of mainland obstruction of cross-strait cultural exchanges have unreasonably expanded this year," Lin said, adding that in the past 11 months, eight cases have signified mainland China's intention to fend-off bilateral cultural and academic exchanges.

Lin further said seven of those cases took place before ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station on July 9.

As for cross-strait relations, Lin said the ROC originally hoped that Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), could visit Taiwan this year and that the two sides could resume regular dialogue.
"As the year is drowing to an end, chances of realizing these two goals are getting slim," Lin regretted.
