DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE KITTY SEEMS TO HAVE NINE LIVES

TEXT.P: There seemed to be truth in the saying that cats have nine lives when a weak, wasted kitty was found Wednesday under the rubble of a destroyed building in Taichung City, more than 70 days since the 7.3-magnitude earthquake struck Sept. 21.

The cat was discovered by a group of construction workers under a wooden board when they were clearing furniture out of the remains of the building. The cat, lying besides the corpse of another feline, could not walk or even stand due to weakness and possible injuries.
It is believed that the cat could not escape because of the weight of the wooden board, but it managed to survive, for 70 days, by feeding off of the dead body of its companion.
The cat was rushed to a nearby veterinary hospital where vets found it so weak that it could barely move.

The veterinarians, after injecting liquid nourishment into its mouth with a syringe in an attempt to keep it alive, declined to speculate whether the cat would survive, since it was diagnosed as suffering from dehydration and kidney failure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER, FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 0.92 percent on Thursday over Y2K concerns with the approach of year's end and fresh signs of a Taiwan-mainland China arms race.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index, ending lower for four consecutive trading sessions and shedding 2.8 percent in total, closed 72.18 points lower at 7,738.84, and turnover expanded to NT$139.69 (US$4.42 billion), with 2.68 billion shares changing hands, of which selling exceeded buying by 12 million shares.

The market opened 13.41 points lower, dragged down by moderate losses on Wall Street, and closed even lower as the electronics sector and financial sector, which attracted most of the turnovers, both reported shoddy performance.

On Wednesday, Vice President Lien Chan urged the military to fortify the island's deterrent missile forces, which, according to dealers, added uncertainty about relations between Taiwan and mainland China despite the unlikeliness of immediate cross-strait tensions.

Sentiment was also chilled by worries that institutional investors, including foreign funds, might gradually slow their investment in Taiwan ahead of the year 2000 to avoid potential losses caused by any computer malfunctions, dealers added.
Among the eight major stock categories, the textile sector suffered from the largest setback of a 2.9-percent loss, while the cement sector posted the largest gain of 3.3 percent.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 288 to 176, with 82 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market edged down 0.22 points to close at 185.24, on a turnover of NT$16.75 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 70 points to close at 7,770, with 1,570 contract transactions. Those for January declined 84 points to finish at 7,782, with 317 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March climbed 87 points to close at 7,863, with six contract transactions, while those for next June shed 19 points to close at 7,941, with 17 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,840 points for December, 7,866 points for January, 7,950 points for next March, 7,960 points for next June, and 7,940 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported losses.
December TE futures shed 2.3 points to close at 390.5, with 809 contract transactions, and January TE futures moved down 2.3 points to finish at 390.8, with 73 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

December TF futures dropped 8.6 points to close at 953 with 174 contract transactions, and January TF futures remained unchanged to close at 977 points with 38 contract transactions; no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH VISITING GUATEMALAN CONGRESSIONAL LEADER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met with Guatemala National Congress President Leonel Eliseo Lopez Rodas and his wife, and Lee extended his welcome for their visit to Taiwan.
Expressing his admiration for the ROC's remarkable political and economic achievements, Lopez inquired about the country's efforts in its pursuit of democracy and liberalization.

Lee told his guests that democracy and liberalization have played a crucial role in the ROC development of a self-sufficient economy, and have helped Taiwan win its space in the international community.

Promotion of a democratic system has also led to a stable society on the island, while the effort to seek liberalization allowed all people the chance to be involved in fair market competition, struggling for themselves for wealth and happiness.

Lee said it was not a smooth road that the ROC has walked in the hope of developing a democratic system. Describing the process as similar to the pain that every mother bears during childbirth, Lee said that after long-term hard work, the Republic of China has finally implemented the principle of democracy advocated by ROC founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen, which assures each citizen the right to exercise the political and civil liberties due to him or her.

With the performance, Lee noted, the ROC has won much support and friendship in the international community, despite the fact that its rival, communist China, has never ceased exerting pressure on other countries, aimed at isolating the ROC from the greater global society.
Lopez, who recently assumed his post, expressed that his country's solid support for the ROC will never soften and that he will pool more efforts for maintenance of Taipei-Guatemala relations.

The parliamentary leader said the ties should be further enhanced, and not only in the areas of politics and diplomacy. In terms of economy, he noted, he hopes Taiwan businesses will launch further investments in Guatemala, while the two countries strengthen cultural exchanges and cooperation to promote increased mutual understanding.
Lopez and his wife arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a week-long visit and are scheduled to depart on Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL TV EMPLOYEES CALL FOR PRESS FREEDOM

TEXT.P: Disputes between two factions of the domestic television cable company Global TV regarding business operation rights continued Thursday with the company's wire communications disrupted in the early morning hours by members of one side.

A clash broke out Wednesday at the news office of Global TV between Tsai Hao, the company's new board chairman who was hastily chosen at a meeting of a temporary board of directors, and Wu Tzu-chia, the current board chairman, when Tsai and his aides forcibly entered the office to post a bulletin of intent to take over operating rights.
The act angered Wu, who claimed that he was still board chairman of Global TV, as well as his aides and some reporters, and resulted in a violent clash that injured four.

Tsai, a non-party legislator, led his aides and broke into Global TV's engine room early Thursday morning to remove some computer mother boards, causing two hours of disruption in wire communications.

Tsai claimed that he took the action to protest Global TV's broadcasting of Wednesday's clash, saying that the dispute over operating rights should be solved through negotiations. He thought the airing of the incident has given the public the impression that he is a violent person.

In a press release, Global TV employees on Thursday condemned the violent behavior of Tsai and his aides, saying that no matter who takes charge of the operating rights, freedom of the press should always be protected.

Both Tsai and Wu held news separate conferences on Thursday to insist on their respective operating rights. Tsai extended his apologies to the public at his news conference for the clash that had an adverse effect on society.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF MEETS INDEPENDENT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE SOONG

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush paid a visit to independent presidential candidate James Soong for wide-ranging talks on Thursday.

Soong, a former Taiwan governor who was ousted by the ruling Kuomintang last month for his insistence on running for the presidency against the KMT-nominated Lien Chan. Soong is the first presidential hopeful to have met Bush.

Soong said after his 80-minute meeting with Bush that he has told the top US liaison officer with the Republic of China that Taiwan's democratization is important not only to its people but is also conducive to East Asian development.

"I also reiterated to Bush that our people cannot accept mainland Chinese rule and are strongly concerned about Taiwan's security and freedom," Soong said, adding he had told Bush that any change to Taiwan's status quo must receive prior consent of the people of Taiwan.

Bush arrived in Taipei on Wednesday for a routine visit to inspect the AIT Taipei office's operations. The AIT is a quasi-official US organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

According to a Soong-Bush agreement, Soong would not reveal what Bush had said during their talks. Bush will express his opinions on Taiwan-related affairs in a press conference to be held at the end of his visit.
During their meeting, Soong said he had told Bush that mainland China's constant threat to use force against Taiwan has caused backlash among local people and even affect regional security.
Against this backdrop, Soong said he believes that Taiwan's new president is obligated to help maintain freedom, peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region.

As for his stance on President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" theory concerning Taiwan-mainalnd China ties, Soong said he had made it clear to Bush that the ROC is an independent sovereign state, not a local government under the "People's Republic of China."

Soong further said the ROC is willing to maintain peaceful exchanges with mainland China, but that the people of Taiwan cannot accept mainland China's rule at the moment. "Mainland leaders should understand Taiwan people's insistence on sovereignty, security, dignity and long-term interests," he stressed.

Soong said he had exchanged views with Bush on Vice President Lien Chan's proposal that Taiwan develop long-range surface-to-surface missiles to protect its own security in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat.

Soong would not reveal Bush's opinion on the issue. He just explained his own views, saying that the ROC is a peace-loving country and has no intention to take any offensive action against any target.
Nevertheless, Soong added that Taiwan cannot afford to rule out any possibility of development in order to maintain adequate defense capabilities.
According to Soong, he and Bush also discussed Taiwan's democratic reforms, its 2000 presidential election and the two events' possible impact on East Asian development.

Soong said both he and Bush agreed that Taiwan's second direct presidential election scheduled for March 18, 2000 will be an important milestone to Taiwan's democratic development and national security. "Both of us hope the election will proceed smoothly and peacefully," Soong said, adding Bush had assured him that the United States will provide Taiwan with adequate, appropriate defensive arsenal in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.

Durning his stay in Taipei, Bush will also meet with two other major presidential hopefuls -- the KMT's standard-bearer Lien Chan and opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian, in addition to senior ROC government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY URGES GREATER EXCHANGES WITH INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan should conduct increased trade, commercial, cultural, and sporting exchanges with Indonesia to boost bilateral relations, Republic of China Representative to Indonesia S.C. Lin said on Thursday.

Answering questions at the Legislative Yuan, Lin said he has already visited newly inaugurated Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid, who expressed a keen interest in Taiwan's experience in developing its agriculture and small business sectors.

The government should continue urging Taiwan businesses to invest in Indonesia, in order to strengthen bilateral economic exchanges and step up efforts to boost two-way activities in a wide range of areas, he noted.

In response to the great importance Wahid attaches to Taiwan's investment in Indonesia, Lin said his office -- the Taipei Trade Office in Jakarta -- sponsored a seminar in early November in which Taiwan businessmen and Indonesian officials exchanged opinions on the issue.

Taiwan investors pointed out that discrimination against ethnic Chinese by Indonesian people will hamper Taiwan's investment willingness in Indonesia, but the Indonesian officials denied that ethnic Chinese are discriminated against, describing the behavior instead as "envy." The ROC representative office vowed to extend necessary assistance to Taiwan businesses wishing to invest there.

According to Lin, Taiwan should also forge closer ties with Indonesia's parliament and strengthen exchanges of visits by opinion leaders of the two countries as a way of further promoting substantial bilateral ties.

Taiwan investment in the Southeast Asian country totaled US$16.7 billion as of the end of September, making the country Taiwan's top investment target in the region. At the same time, Taiwan is Indonesia's fifth-largest foreign investor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SETS UP ITS 2000 NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: Speeding up post-earthquake rehabilitation has been listed as one of the government's four major administrative goals in the coming year, Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Thursday.

The Executive Yuan has passed the National Development Plan for fiscal 2000, which includes other key programs aimed at securing national safety, to further strengthen the stable basis on which Taiwan society has been built and to improve government efficiency.

Siew said at Thursday's Cabinet meeting that with the unified efforts of all units of the government, Taiwan has this year overcome all the difficulties sparked by the Asian financial meltdown and the Sept. 21 earthquake, evidenced by the fact that Taiwan's 1999 economic growth rate rose to sixth-highest in the world compared to the 16th position it reached in 1998.
He also noted that the annual growth of consumer prices registered 0.2 percent this year, the lowest level since 1986.

In the coming year, Siew went on, his Cabinet will be able to achieve the targeted economic growth rate of 6.1 percent, as the recovering international economy is expected to increase investment on the island, a key factor in boosting domestic economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES SINO-US AERONAUTIC METEOROLOGICAL COOPERATION PACT

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan at its weekly meeting Thursday approved the third executive accord under the Sino-US Aeronautic Meteorological Technology Cooperation and System Modernization Agreement proposed by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

A MOTC official said the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States and the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) signed the agreement on behalf of the Civil Aeronautic Administration, MOTC and the US Federation of Atmospheric Science Universities in February 1998.
The first and second executive accords were previously signed.

A draft and an amended draft of the third executive accord were jointly signed on Sept. 10 and Sept. 23, respectively, by an AIT representative and an official of the ROC Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States.
Under the agreement, the United States will help the ROC modernize its aeronautic meteorological technology and related systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES SINO-PANAMANIAN VOLUNTEER WORKER PACT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet at its weekly meeting on Thursday approved the Sino-Panamanian Volunteer Workers Accord proposed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Under the accord, the non-profit International Cooperation and Development Foundation will send a volunteer mission to help Panama with agricultural, cultural and other development.
The accord was signed by Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Panama Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman on Oct. 28 in Panama City.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE-MAINLAND CHINA TOURISM LINKS STRENGTHENED

TEXT.P: Singapore and mainland China are to work together to develop and exploit tourism opportunities in the latter's southwestern region and Australia.

This collaborative approach was agreed upon by the China National Tourism Administration (CNTA) and the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) at the 3rd STB-CNTA High Level Bilateral Meeting, which concluded Thursday in Singapore.

Both national tourism organizations agreed on efforts to work together in areas of tourism development in regions where mutual interest lie. Specifically, a Marketing and Promotion Event will be jointly held in Australia to explore the twinning potential of Singapore and Sichuan. The event is planned for the first half of the year 2000.

During the recent Singapore-Sichuan Trade and Investment Committee meeting held in Singapore Dec. 1-3, the STB also helped Holiday Tours and Travel, a local travel agency, sign a letter of intent with the Sichuan Tourism Bureau to launch charter flights to Chengdu, the capital city of Sichuan.

The STB has also, through its Tourism Development Assistance Scheme, given grants to two ground operators in Singapore, the East West Executive Travelers and Chan Brothers Travel, to develop regional tour packages using Singapore as a hub to the southwestern regions of China, such as Yunnan and Sichuan. The STB hopes to encourage more travel companies to do likewise.

In the last five years, mainland Chinese visitor arrivals to Singapore grew 77.8 percent from 164,893 in 1994 to 293,166 in 1998. Visitor arrivals from Singapore to mainland China grew 13.5 percent from 472,171 in 1994 to 535,685 in 1998. For the period of January to August 1999, this figure grew 32 percent on a year-by-year comparison.

Singapore is the second largest investor in tourism-related sectors in mainland China, with total investments amounting to US$618 million to date, representing 10.5 percent of foreign tourism investments in that country.

Such investments include hotels and service apartments, theme-parks, tour transport facilities and theme restaurants developed or managed by Singapore companies, mainly in the coastal regions of Shanghai, Guangdong, Jiangsu, Shandong and Fujian. (by Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH COMPANY WINS ROCSAT-2 CONTRACT

TEXT.P: France's Matra Marconi Space has replaced Germany's Dornier Satellite System (DSS) to jointly build the ROCSAT-2 satellite along with ROC scientists, the National Science Council announced on Thursday.
DSS outbid Matra earlier this year with a NT$2.79 billion bid for the contract to build the satellite, part of Taiwan's 15-year space program.

Huang Chen-tai, chairman of the Cabinet-level NSC, said that because DSS was unable to obtain an export permit from the German government due to pressure from Beijing, the NSC awarded the NT$2.37 billion (US$75 million)-contract to Matra on Nov. 29, 1999. Matra has already got an export license from the French government, he went on.
Huang said that construction of ROCSAT-2 will begin on Dec. 15, and that the satellite will be in orbit within three-and-a-half years.
He added that the NSC's Space Program Office notified DSS on Nov. 5 of the cancellation of its contract and the confiscation of the US$600,000 performance bond put up by the German company.

Matra has subcontracted six local Taiwan firms, including Acer, Tatung, Shihlin Electric & Engineering and Tay Yung Engineering Co. to supply components such as flight software, S-band antennae and other computer equipment for the project.
Taiwan put its first science research spacecraft, ROCSAT-1, into orbit in January this year, following the launch in 1991 of its NT$13.6 billion space program.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ISSUES STATEMENT ON 20TH ANNIVERSARY OF `FORMOSA INCIDENT'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday issued a statement on the eve of the 20th anniversary of the 1979 Formosa Incident, also known as the "Meilitao or Kaohsiung Incident."
The statement, titled "From Beautiful Island To Beautiful Country," said the Formosa Incident helped nurture Taiwan's independent nation status.
DPP Chairman Lin Yin-hsiung, who read the statement at a news conference, said the movement initiated by Formosa Magazine 20 years ago was a call for democratic reforms.

Noting that the "Formosa" movement was based on the achievements of several opposition movements led by "Taiwanese martyrs" in the wake of World War II, Lin said the movement was fully rooted in Taiwan and carried a deep Taiwanese historical sense.

Lin further said that during Taiwan's repressive martial law era, the Formosa Magazine played an important role in reflecting concepts and values that had wide popular support. Even the then-authoritarian regime felt the heat and threat of the Formosa Magazine-led pro-democracy movement, he noted.

The DPP statement described incident as Formosa Magazine-organized human rights demonstration in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung on Dec. 10, 1979 which was crushed by riot police. An ensuing government crackdown was followed by a series of arrests, brutal murders, courts-martial and long jail terms for many pro-democracy activists.

In the process, the statement said, the Formosa activists' courage and firm conviction in democracy awoke the collective conscience of the people, and inspired the spiritual strength necessary to pursue democratic reforms.
"This strength also stimulated identification with the island of Taiwan and encouraged the pursuit of Taiwan's national identity," the statement continued.

It further said the DPP, founded by key figures in the Formosa Incident and lawyers who later defended them in courts-martial, has taken great delight in Taiwan's progress as an "independent state" over the past two decades.

While marking the 20th anniversary of the Formosa Incident, the statement said, the DPP also hopes to win the 2000 presidential election to push for further maturity of the country's democratic system.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE WOMEN'S GROUP DONATES CHRISTMAS GIFTS TO QUAKE CHILDREN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A Japanese women's group has decided to donate 1,000 Christmas gifts to the children living in earthquake-stricken areas of Taiwan, according to news reports in Tokyo.

The reports said that Yukiharu Sato, who has a Taiwan-born husband, visited Nantou in Central Taiwan, the area worst-hit by the Sept. 21 earthquake in mid-November and saw that many schoolchildren were having to attend classes in makeshift temporary classrooms.

While in Taiwan, she was moved by the relief efforts of the Genki Village volunteer group from the Japanese city of Kobe, who had traveled to Taiwan to offer assistance to the quake victims. She then hit on the idea of forming her own group to launch a gift collection drive in her home town, in order to help the students of Chungfong Primary School in Nantou.
She was soon surprised to find that more than 1,000 gifts were pouring in from various prefectures within a week of the launch of the drive.

She was also moved by 32 Christmas cards made by Hajime Murada, a primary school student, and translated them all into Chinese with her husband's help, so as to share their Christmas spirit with those less fortunate.

Sato said that a private transport company will transport the gifts free of charge to Kobe, and will ship them to Taiwan along with relief materials and other gifts collected by Genki Village in Kobe.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATOR HEADING TRADE MISSION TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: US Senator Larry Craig arrived in Taipei for a three-day visit on Thursday at the head of a trade mission from his constituency of Idaho.
Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui received Craig and his wife, and expressed his hope that the mission's visit will contribute to the promotion of substantive bilateral relations.

Craig expressed his concern over the heavy casualties resulting from the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, and Lee voiced his appreciation for the prompt dispatching of rescue and relief missions to Taiwan from the United States in the wake of the disaster.
During their visit, the visitors will also meet with Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen, Defense Minister Tang Fei, and will visit the Council of Agriculture along with various other organizations.
Before coming to Taipei, the Craig mission visited mainland China and held talks with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and other high-level Beijing officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES ROTARY INTERNATIONAL PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday received Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and its former president, Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross, at the Presidential Office.
Lee extended a warm welcome to Ravizza, Caparas and Kinross, who traveled to Taiwan to attend a seminar sponsored by the Rotary Club in Taipei.
He also expressed his admiration for the good work performed by the Rotarians in the post-earthquake relief effort.
In return, Ravizza expressed his concern and condolences to those who suffered in the Sept. 21 disaster.

Lee went on to say that although the ROC suffered a lot of human losses and material damage from the earthquake, Taiwan managed to rise again from the rubble within a month, which indicates the energy and strength of the people of the ROC.

He hailed the Rotarians for their promotion of social welfare around the world, and said that the ROC, as a member of the international community, will strengthen cooperation with Rotary International to further promote social welfare around the world.
Lee also extended a welcome to the heads of Rotary Clubs around the world who will attend a world Rotarian meeting in March, 2000 in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTMAS CEASE-FIRE IN OFFENSIVE AGAINST PHILIPPINE REBELS

TEXT.P: The Philippine government will call off offensive operations against the communist New People's Army from Dec. 10 to Jan 9, 2000, in observance of the Christmas season, a presidential spokesman said on Thursday.

With regard to the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), a Muslim rebel group which operates in the south of the country, the spokesman said the government signed a cease-fire agreement with the group in 1997 which still stands.

Earlier, President Joseph Estrada reminded the military in southern Mindanao to respect the traditional Muslim festival of Ramadan observed by members of the MILF, but stressed that violations of an existing cease-fire should not be tolerated.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO ANNOUNCE TAOYUAN MAGISTRATE AS RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian will on Friday formally announce Taoyuan Magistrate Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
Chen chose the day to make the announcement because Dec. 10 is the 20th anniversary of the Formosa Incident, regarded as a milestone in Taiwan's democratization.
The Harvard-educated Lu has already obtained the endorsement of influential DPP senior members to team up with Chen.
Following the formal announcement, Lu will deliver an acceptance speech, accompanied by 12 "outstanding" women and 12 women legislators.
DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang and some other senior DPP members will also speak on the occasion to recommend Lu.

The presidential election will be held on March 18, 2000, and Vice President Lien Chan, who will represent the ruling Kuomintang in the election, has already named Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate.

Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who will run as an independent, has selected Chang Chao-hsiung, former director of Chang Kung Memorial Hospital, as his running mate in what promises to be a hotly contested race.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RATED SECOND BEST CITY IN ASIA
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taipei is ranked the second best city in Asia in terms of working and living conditions, tied with the Japanese city of Osaka, according to the results of a survey conducted by the English-language Asia News weekly.

Owing to the city's success in curbing air pollution and improving traffic, Taipei moved up from its fifth-ranked slot in a similar survey last year, to a position just behind Japan's Fukuoka, which topped the list.
Tokyo came in fourth, while Hong Kong and Shanghai tied for ninth place.

The weekly, which is the English version of the Chinese-language Yazhou Zhoukan, rated 40 Asian cities according to their economic development, education level, health and sanitation, transportation, personal security, property prices and entertainment.
Hong Kong has dropped for two consecutive years on the list, lagging behind even Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur and Brunei's Bandar Seri Begawan.
Although Asia News blamed Hong Kong's worsening economy and environmental contamination as the causes for its slip, local scholars blamed the publication for "unfair treatment" of Hong Kong.

Hong Kong's living environment might be worsening, but its higher educational level and economic development should earn it a better ranking than Bandar Seri Begawan or Kuala Lumpur, while property prices are far lower than those of Tokyo, said the scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPLACING TROOPS, NOT RETREATING FROM SOUTH CHINA SEA ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The government is replacing marines stationed on islands in the South China Sea with Coast Guard Command (CGC) personnel and is not withdrawing from the area, Republic of China Defense Minister Defense Tang Fei said on Thursday.

In response to criticism from some presidential candidates that the Ministry of National Defense is withdrawing troops from the Pratas and Spratley islands, Tang said the move is a replacement rather than a retreat.

Although the marines stationed on the two islands, which are at the center of territory disputes between Taiwan, mainland China and various other Asian states, will be replaced by CGC forces, the ROC's determination to exact sovereignty over the islands is not changed in any way.

In any case, the defense of the islands lies more in the hands of the air force and navy than in those of the troops posted on them, Tang said in an attempt to parry criticism that the CGC troops are not sufficiently well-armed to protect the islands.

Claiming that the two tiny islands, located some 800 nautical miles from Taiwan, are impossible to defend, and not terribly relevant to Taiwan's security, Tang said replacing the elite marines with CGC troops is a realistic move.
Movements of the CGC troops, which are not equipped with heavy equipment, will not require warship escorts, thus substantially reducing the cost of their transfer, Tang went on.

The plan to replace the marines has been studied since 1996, and its implementation was timed in line with the proposed establishment of a Coast Guard Headquarters under the Cabinet, said Tang, in an attempt to dismiss allegations that the plan is an ill-thought-out whim.

In an unrelated development meanwhile, anonymous US sources claimed in Washington on Wednesday that Taipei raised a request for US help in its missile development programs in bilateral preparatory discussions on military sales in November.
However, the sources said, Washington is unlikely to help Taipei to develop offensive weapons.

The sources pointed out that it is a longstanding US policy to sell to Taiwan only defensive weapons which cannot be used to strike mainland China, this is why the United States has consistently turned down Taiwan's persistent requests for submarines and mid-range air-to-air missiles.
The sources also noted that it is established US policy to oppose any country's development of missiles with a range of more than 300 kilometers and tipped with warheads of more than 500 kilograms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AGREES TO REOPEN AIR LINK TALKS WITH MANILA

TEXT.P: Taipei will reopen talks with Manila on the resumption of Taipei-Manila flights, but only if Manila dispatches government-level officials to discuss the issue, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng said on Thursday.

Lin said that as the issue must be resolved through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), Lin said the Philippines should send the relevant officials as soon as possible, but added that there is no set timetable for the reopening of flights stalled since October.
He made the remarks while paying an inspection visit to the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to gain an understanding of the airport authorities' handling of Y2K-related matters.
Taipei-Manila air links were suspended on Oct. 1 after Manila unilaterally scrapped an aviation agreement signed by the two countries in 1996.
Meanwhile, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said the Philippine government has already agreed to send officials to Taipei for talks on the rekindling of flight services based on the 1996 aviation accord.

Chen's remarks came following a meeting called by the MOFA with officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, at which all attending officials decided to resume the talks.
It is understood that Filipino civil aviation officials may come to Taiwan next week at the earliest.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL PASSES Y2K-RELATED FLIGHT TESTS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest air carrier, on Thursday successfully completed a flight test which simulated potential problems which might be caused by the Y2K bug, according to airline officials.

The simulation was conducted on Flight CI2000, with 72 reporters and CAL general manager Liu Ke-ya on board, the official said, adding that both clock and aviation software were set at 11:15 p.m. on Dec. 31, 1999 before the plane took off at 11:34 p.m. from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan.
After a 26-minute flight, the Boeing 747-4 jetliner successfully rolled over to Jan. 1, 2000 over Tainan in southern Taiwan, with no problems at all, the officials said.
After CI2000 passed the test to see how the millennium bug could be overcome, chief pilot Chou Tien-sheng said travelers can fly without anxiety on CAL planes during the rollover period.
Meanwhile, Liu pointed out that the airline has invested NT$300 million (US$9.5 million) in its project to cope with Y2K-related problems.

Fears are widespread that the dawning of the new millennium will affect older computers and computer programs which read only the last two digits of the year, and might mistake 2000 as 1900, possibly causing the computer to shut down.
Taiwan's Civil Aeronautic Administration is planning to cancel 122 domestic flights and 57 international flights between 9 p.m. on Dec. 31 and 12 noon on Jan. 1, 2000, just to be on the safe side.

DOC.TEXT:

US President Bill Clinton reiterates that cross-Taiwan Strait disputes should be solved through dialogue and that the United States oppose any kind of violent action.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 10, or the third day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: France, led by Napoleon Bonaparte, annexes the German territory of northern Hanover, Bremen, Hamburg, Lauenburg and Lubeck.
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War, ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: The Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1919: Australia's Smith brothers complete the first long-distance flight from England to Australia.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the communist party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The government of the Republic of China drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang to be acting secretary general of the National Assembly.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1967: The world's first commercial thermonuclear blast takes place in the US state of New Mexico, providing access to natural gas from underground deposits.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1974: Fourteen scholars, including Dr. T.H. Shen, former chairman of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, leaves for Washington to attend the fourth Sino-American Seminar on Mainland China.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1975: A 24-member mission comprising delegates to the 21st conference of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League arrives in Taipei from Tokyo for a week's visit. Among the members are Wasfii Nirza, a Jordanian senator, and Avei Sabit Osman, the first vice president of the ruling party of Turkey.
1976: The Soviet Union stakes its claim to a 200-nautical mile economic sea realm.
1976: Leon O. Ty, director of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League Philippine chapter, arrives in Taipei to attend an executive meeting to prepare for the 23rd APACL Conference in Taipei the following April.
1979: Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo opens the 4th plenum of the 11th Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
1979: Calcutta's Mother Teresa is awarded this year's Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is a joint winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in Chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The indigenous defense fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named by President Lee Teng-hui as "Ching-kuo" class fighters.
1989: The first non-communist government in 41 years is set up in Czechoslovakia, as Vaclav Havel succeeds Gustav Husac in the "Velvet Revolution."
1993: ANC leader Nelson Mandela says he and President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, EVA AIRWAYS CANCEL DEC. 31 NY-TAIPEI, TAIPEI-NY FLIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By David Wang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) has decided to cancel its Dec. 31 Taipei-New York and New York-Taipei flights in consideration of the possible outbreak of Y2K problems that might effect flight safety at the turn of the year.

CAL's branch company in New York said CAL's Dec. 31 flight CI012 from Taipei to New York and flight CI011 from New York to Taipei will definitely be canceled, while the airlines' Jan. 1 Taipei-New York and New York-Taipei flights will operate as scheduled.
At present, CAL operates a total of five to-and-fro flights between Taipei and New York each week, with no such flights on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
EVA Airways has also decided to cancel three of its Dec. 31 to-and-fro flights between Taipei and New York. The airline plans to add a New York-Taipei flight on Jan. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA REMAINS AT LOW END OF OECD'S LIST OF AID DONOR NATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia ranks 14th and is at the low end of the list of the 21 aid donor countries in the Organization of Economic and Cooperation Development, according to a recent OECD review.

The OECD review, faxed to the CNA on Friday by Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs, said the percentage of Australian gross national product devoted to aid dropped to 0.27 percent in 1998, well below the UN target of 0.7 percent and below the OECD's average of 0.4 percent of GNP.

Australia ranked 14th out of the 21 aid donor countries on the OECD's development assistance committee in terms of its aid-to-GNP ratio and 13th in terms of billions of dollars donated annually, the OECD review reported.
But Downer, in a statement faxed to the CNA on Friday, said the aid/GNP ratio would rise to 0.28 percent during fiscal 1999-2000 to the tune of more than A$1.6 (US$1.07) billion.
The OECD review said Australia's aid program has gone through an impressive process of restructuring and renewal since the last review in May 1996.
Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Thursday described the review as "a very positive report card." He said he wanted to see Australia help reduce poverty and to achieve sustainable development.
Australia's aid goes to about 30 countries and its major recipients are Papua New Guinea, East Timor, mainland China, Vietnam, Burma and South Pacific countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH CRITICAL OF BEIJING'S HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD

TEXT.P: Human Rights Watch on Thursday criticized Communist China for tightening its controls on basic freedoms during the year, in part because of Beijing's desire to ensure stability on several sensitive dates, including the tenth anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

Presenting its "World Report 2000" in Washington, the New York-based organization pointed out that judicial independence took a battering in Hong Kong, while religious persecution was a major issue and corruption remained a major obstacle to respect for human rights in mainland China.

Human Rights Watch noted that following former Premier Li Peng's announcement in late November 1998 that Beijing would not tolerate any political system that would "negate the leadership of the Communist Party," three organizers of the opposition China Democracy Party (CDP) received heavy sentences a month later.
Some 30 CDP members were still in custody as of mid-October, and the crackdown on the CDP had extended to some 20 provinces, cities and autonomous regions.

Communist China's restraints on religious belief also increased significantly during the year. The peaceful demonstration by some ten thousand members of Falun Gong in late April clearly shocked the Beijing regime.

While authorities took no immediate action, they began a systematic crackdown three months later, labeling Falun Gong an illegal organization, detaining thousands of practitioners for reeducation, and issuing an arrest warrant for Li Hongzhi, the group's leader who had been living in the United States.

On the political front, President Jiang Zemin's determination to bolster the Chinese Communist Party, to placate hardliners, and to secure his own place in history contributed to heightened intolerance of any organization openly critical of the Party's platform or attempting to function outside Party control," wrote the annual report.

Individuals and groups suspected of ties to "hostile" foreign organizations and those disseminating sensitive political information overseas were particularly targeted by Beijing. State control of religious affairs in Tibet intensified while dozens of judicial executions were reported from Xinjiang, where some ethnic Uighur groups were advocating a separate state. Other alleged "splittists" were sentenced to long prison terms, said the report.

Judicial independence and the rule of law in Hong Kong were "seriously undermined" when the Special Administrative Region government asked Beijing to interpret a ruling by the Court of Final Appeal on right of abode in Hong Kong.

Municipal councils, the middle tier of elected office in Hong Kong, were abolished by Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa this year, "in a transparent effort to weaken the influence of pro-democracy political parties in Hong Kong," added the report.

Meanwhile, The two key human rights treaties signed by China in 1997 and 1998 remained unratified. But for the most part, the West and Japan continued to use bilateral dialogue rather than pressure as their method of choice in addressing mainland China human rights issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS MONUMENT INAUGURATED ON GREEN ISLAND

TEXT.P: The first human rights monument in Asia was officially inaugurated on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan on Friday.

About 300 people participated in a ceremony to unveil the monument, including President Lee Teng-hui, Human Rights Education Foundation Chairman Bo Yang, and former political prisoners and their families.
The monument, which stands near the beach, is inscribed with a poem by Bo Yang, himself a political dissident who was incarcerated in a notorious maximum-security jail on the island for a decade.
"During that era, how many mothers cried in the long dark nights over their children jailed on the island?" the poem reads.
The names of 500 other political dissidents who were jailed on Green Island at one time or another during the repressive martial law era are also inscribed on the monument.

Speaking at the inauguration ceremony, Lee paid his highest respects on behalf of the government to those who made such efforts in the pursuit of democracy on the island, and extended his deepest apologies to those who suffered in their pursuit of human rights.

In a choking voice, Lee stressed that "we will face the historical trauma squarely, and we have made a solemn commitment that democracy will not backpedal, that authoritarian rule will not resurface, and that the next generation will not go through the same fear and pain."

Bo Yang, which is the pen name of renowned writer Kuo Yi-tung, who was imprisoned between 1968 and 1979 on Green Island, said that the inauguration of the memorial does not represent the end of these efforts, but rather symbolizes the beginning of one major goal.
He also extended his thanks to Lee, who donated NT$20 million toward the funding of the memorial in proceeds from sales of his book "The Road to Democracy: Taiwan's Pursuit of Identity."

Bo Yang said that the mistakes made by the government can be understood and condoned, but should not be forgiven, adding that if they are forgiven, history will repeat itself and bring suffering down upon our offspring.

The monument, which was completed in one year after breaking ground in Dec. 10, 1998, was designed by Han Pao-teh, a renowned architect and presdient of the National Tainan College of Arts, with the assistance of calligrapher Tai Lan-tsun and art designer Hou Jung-ling.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT HEAD VISITS HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED INDUSTRIAL PARK

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush said on Friday that he was impressed following a visit to the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan.

This was the first visit to the high-tech park by the top US liaison official with the Republic of China, who arrived here on Wednesday for a routine visit to inspect the AIT Taipei office's operations.

Bush met with Huang Wen-hsiung, director-general of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, visited United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) and met with UMC Chairman Robert Tsao and President John Hsuan.

There had been speculation that Bush might have invited UMC to invest in the United States, as UMC said that in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake, the company is considering setting up an overseas plant to try to diversify investment risks. Hsuan also said earlier that some overseas chip manufacturers have contacted UMC.

However, Bush said that he visited UMC mainly to learn about the company's development experience, and that he had not persuaded UMC to invest in the United States. Nevertheless, he pointed out that the United States has many locations suitable for setting up plants, and welcomed investment by Taiwan manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WARNS OF POSSIBLE VISA DELAYS FOR TRAVELERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) suggested on Friday that local people planning to travel abroad over the New Year period should apply for visas before Dec. 25.
A MOFA official warned that if applications are made any later than this, they might be delayed by the effects of the Y2K computer bug.
Clark K. H. Chen, director of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, said during a news conference that the ministry also advises people to avoid traveling to Russia during the Y2K rollover period.

Russia is regarded as being ill-prepared for the Y2K problem, Chen noted, adding that those living in colder areas are expected to suffer more than those in warm regions if they are affected by the computer bug which might disrupt power supplies and transportation systems.

Chen said that MOFA's representative office in Russia is prepared for any possible incidents caused by the millennium bug, which could crash older computer systems that use two digits to record dates and
might therefore confuse 2000 with 1900.

In addition, he went on, the liaison office has also advised Taiwan people living in Russia that they ought to consider a trip home or a visit to the United States or western Europe in advance of the New Year period, in order to minimize the risk of Y2K problems.
The MOFA Bureau of Consular Affairs said it will also implement a full alert for the Y2K bug from Dec. 15 to Jan. 5, during which period there will be provisions made for urgent requirements.
