DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES EDGE DOWN, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices edged down In Friday's trading session as most investors stayed on the sidelines.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index, after an opening surge, closed 5.06 points lower at 7,733.77, on a market turnover of NT$114.49 billion (US$3.62 billion).
A total of 2.2 billion shares changed hands during the three-hour session.
Decliners outnumbered advancers 236 to 231, with 80 shares staying unchanged.
The eight major stock categories had mixed fortunes, with construction issues posting the largest rise of 1.1 percent.
Financial stocks climbed 0.2 percent, while textile issues posted a slight growth of 0.1 percent.

Cement shares fell 1.1 percent, followed by plastic and chemical issues which dropped 0.4 percent. Foodstuff issues fell 0.2 percent, while technology and paper and pulp issues each declined 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market slid 1.4 points to finish at 183.84, on a turnover of NT$11.84 billion.
The TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December rose 30 points to close at 7,800, with 1,326 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 42 points to finish at 7,820, with 441 contract transactions, while those for March fell 12 points to 7,851, with four contract transactions, and those for June slid eight points to 7,882, with 10 contract transactions.
No trading was recorded for September futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY BIDS FAREWELL TO HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong should set up a more systematic and efficient communication channel to forge better relations between the two sides, the outgoing Republic of China envoy said on Friday.

Although the current channels between Taiwan and Hong Kong remain smooth, ROC representative Cheng An-kuo said the two sides should establish a more positive mechanism for mutual communication because the special and close ties between them.

Cheng, head of the Hong Kong Affairs Bureau, made the remarks just prior to his departure from Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok International Airport. He has worked as the top ROC representative in the former British colony for the past four years, and has now been promoted to the post of vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, the highest-level ROC government agency in charge of charting Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.
Cheng was seen off at the airport by more than 200 ROC nationals and government officials stationed here.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL NAMES FEMALE RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday formally named a female political heavyweight as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.

Chen Shui-bian named Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu as the DPP's vice presidential candidate in an announcement timed to coincide with International Human Rights Day and the 20th anniversary of the Formosa Incident (also called the Kaohsiung Incident).
Present at the announcement were 10 outstanding women, five female legislators, and various DPP officials including Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, Chang Chun-hung, Yao Chia-wen and Su Cheng-chang.

Following Chen's announcement, Lu gave a speech in which she slammed President Lee Teng-hui's assertion that cross-strait ties are "a special state-to-state relationship," describing it as "vague," and adding that if elected vice president to Chen's president, she plans to try to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to exchange views on cross-Taiwan Strait development.
Also at the announcement ceremony, Chen put forward three pledges to the public as his political platform for the 2000 presidential election:
-- to insist on independent sovereignty for Taiwan;
-- to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait; and
-- to eliminate corruption and level the playing field for all business sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRONOLOGY OF THE 20TH CENTURY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By David Hsu) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: 1900: Sigmund Freud, Austrian physician, published his book on psychoanalysis. He theorized that the symptoms of hysterical patients stem from forgotten and unresolved infantile psychosexual conflicts.
1901: The first Nobel Prizes, worth $30,000 each, were awarded in Oslo and Stockholm on Dec. 10.
1902: The Boer War, which started between the British and the Boers of South Africa in 1880, ended.

1903: The Wright brothers (Wilbur and Orville), who invented and built the first successful airplane, made the world's first flight in a power-driven, heavier-than-air machine near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, on Dec. 17.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War broke out after Russia refused to withdraw from Manchuria, leading to conflicts of interest with Japan.

1905: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, made known his theory of relativity at the age of 16. His theory revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical basis for the exploitation of atomic energy.

1906: San Francisco was hit by the most violent earthquake ever recorded in its history on April 18. First estimates suggested that as many as 700 people were killed and a further 250,000 made homeless.

1907: Pablo Picasso, Spanish artist, completed his masterpiece "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon." He is one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th Century. With Georges Braque he launched Cubism.
1908: Britain's Robert Baden-Powell, who started the Boy Scout movement in 1907, published the first Boy Scout manual.
1909: Hirofumi Ito, Japanese politician who helped draft the Constitution of 1889 and served as prime minister until 1901, was assassinated in Harbin in northeast China.
1910: Japan formally annexed Korea as a colony. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD URGE SIMULTANEOUS WTO ENTRY FOR TAIWAN, PRC: POLICY ANALYST

TEXT.P: To ensure the US-PRC agreement on Communist China's entry into the World Trade Organization advances US commercial interests without compromising significant US security and human rights interests, Washington should insist on Taiwan's simultaneous accession to the WTO, said a US expert on Asia Thursday.

Stephen J. Yates, a senior policy analyst for the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, wrote in an analysis piece that it is critical for US policy-makers to view the conclusion of 13 years of negotiations over the PRC's entry into the WTO as "the beginning of a long period of implementation."

"The success or failure of this agreement rests upon as much details as on the determination of American leaders to continue to press for progress on security issues, human rights and Taiwan," said the analyst.

In reality, Yates pointed out, Communist China's membership in the WTO is not likely to dramatically increase US investment and participation in mainland China's market in the near future, nor is it likely to ignite a passion for liberal democracy within mainland China's borders. But neither will it hinder US ability to protect its national security interests or promote freedom in mainland China.
He is convinced that the US-PRC agreement is a step in the right direction, despite the fact that it will take several years before Communist China's market-opening pledges are realized.

But Yates said, to ensure that the US-PRC WTO agreement would advance US commercial interests without compromising significant US security and human rights interests, Washington should insist on Taiwan's simultaneous accession to the WTO.

He went on to say that the United States should also find a new forum to address human rights and national security concerns, continue national security-based export controls, establish non-sanction methods to address human rights issues, and hold Communist China to WTO discipline.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME ISSUE IN WHO FLEXIBLE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will seek to first join the World Health Organization (WHO), after which time the ROC government will adopt a flexible stance toward the island's name in the world body, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

Answering questions from reporters at a news conference, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said it is not yet the time to consider the name issue because the government will first do its best to join the WHO.

Responding to media reports that US President Bill Clinton on Tuesday signed Resolution No. 1794 submitted by the US House of Representatives, which supports Taiwan's efforts to enter the WHO, Chen replied that it is an indication that both the US administration and Congress back Taiwan's WHO bid.
The major purpose of Taiwan's bid to join the WHO is to seek greater benefits for the health of the island's 22.3 million people, he noted.

Citing sources from Washington, the local media also reported that Beijing may agree to a proposal to be raised at a WHO meeting slated for May next year that Taiwan join the WHO under the name "Chinese Taipei."

DOC.HEADLINE: US WON'T SUPPORT TAIWAN IN DEVELOPING GROUND-TO-GROUND MISSILES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: An official with the US Department of State indirectly said on Thursday that the US government would not encourage and would not support Taiwan in developing long-range ground-to-ground missiles.

John Holum, senior adviser for arms control and international security, made the remarks while answering a question about mainland Chinese missile buildup and Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan's statement that Taiwan should develop long-range missiles.

Holum said, "I would echo the president's statement that we view with very serious concern any buildup and any threatening gestures that suggest a violent approach to the Taiwan Strait and to the issue of China and Taiwan relations."

He went on to say that "the president has also made clear that our policy remains that of recognizing one China. But at the same time, consistent with the three communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), we believe that the future of Taiwan should be determined in a peaceful way between China and Taiwan, and we view with grave concern any indications or preparations for military action."

The official said that under an international accord on arms control, the US government would not encourage and would not support any country's development of missiles with a firing range greater than 300 kilometers and capable of carrying warheads weighing over 500 kilograms.

In reference to Taiwan's security, Holum noted that under the TRA, the US has "provided a great deal of defense technology and support to Taiwan, consistent with its security," adding that "we will continue to evaluate requests and programs in that light."

He stated that "it seems to me the right direction for both Taiwan and China, and certainly consistent with US policy, is to draw back from more ambitious military programs rather than embark on new ones."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICTIMS OF FORMOSA INCIDENT SUE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE FOR SLANDER

TEXT.P: A group of seven people who were sentenced to prison 20 years ago for their involvement in the Formosa Incident filed criminal complaints against independent presidential candidate James Soong in Kaohsiung City on Friday.

In the complaints brought before the Kaohsiung prosecutors office, Chou Ping-teh, a national policy adviser to the president, and six others accused Soong, then general director of the Government Information Office under the late president Chiang Ching-kuo, of slandering them as traitors and violent criminals in a statement to domestic and foreign news media.

They also accused Kung Ling-chen, then director general of the National Police Administration; Wang Ching-hsu, then commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command (TGC); and Chang Chih-hsiu, then southern Taiwan commander under the TGC, of violating their freedom by ordering or implementing the crackdown on a demonstration on Dec. 10, 1979, which led to a violent clash between law enforcers and protesters.

The clash triggered a series of subsequent arrests, and many of those who organized the demonstration in the name of the now-defunct Formosa Monthly, after which the incident was named, were given prison sentences ranging from eight months to six years for treason or for hiding fugitives.

The seven plaintiffs, who were arrested separately after Dec. 13, 1979, filed their suits just ahead of the expiration of the 20-year statute of limitations on criminal cases, according to their lawyer. Earlier on Friday, Huang Chih-chuan, speaker of the Kaohsiung City Council, urged the government to apologize to those convicted for their part in the Formosa Incident, and to officially clear their reputations.

In a meeting with Chou and his fellow convicts in the incident, Huang lauded the contributions to the island's democracy made by those involved in the Formosa Incident, claiming that history has vindicated them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OF LATIN AMERICAN PARLIAMENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Juan Adolfo Singer, president of the Latin American Parliament, and his wife will arrive in Taipei on Dec. 12 for a week-long visit, said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday.

During the visit, they will call on Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, Minister of Foreign Affairs Chen Chien-jen and other government officials, said the ministry in a press release.
They will also visit several cultural and economic establishments of the Republic of China, before departing Taiwan on Dec. 18, according to the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA WINS 68 PERCENT APPROVAL RATING FROM TAIPEI CITIZENS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and his municipal team have won an approval rating of over 60 percent from Taipei citizens, according to the results of a survey released on Friday.

Ma, who took over the mayorship a year ago, scored an approval rating of 67.6 percent among Taipei residents who said they were "very satisfied" or "satisfied" with his performance. At the same time, nearly 60.3 percent of the respondents also expressed satisfaction about the performance of the city government's staff.

Responding to the public opinion results released by Taipei City Councilor S.F. Chen, a humble Ma said he was not content with the results and expressed the desire to be able to perform better on the job.

While answering questions from Taipei City councilors at an interpellation session, Ma hailed the Formosa Incident, which occurred 20 years ago in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung, as a milestone in the process of Taiwan's democratization.

Citing a quote by former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman and lawmaker Shih Ming-te, who said the Formosa Incident is a memorable event belonging to the entire people of Taiwan, Ma called on the public to judge the historical event from a broader viewpoint.

Ma admitted that he was deeply touched by Shih's words and appealed the public to ponder the true meaning of the event. Although Taiwan is moving toward democracy, each citizen still should be concerned about the quality of Taiwan's democracy, he suggested.

Shih, one of the prominent leaders of the Formosa Incident, was arrested by police in a crackdown on dissidents and sentenced to a jail-term of more than ten years. At that time, Ma was studying at Harvard University in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION STANDS AT 22 MILLION

TEXT.P: The population of Taiwan and its offshore islands totaled 22,077,000 at the end of November, according to statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior on Friday.
The figure represents an increase of 164,000 over the same month last year, with an annual increase of 7.53 per thousand. The number of males stood at 11,306,000 and females at 10,770,600.
The number of households increased by 165,700 to 6,521,000 households.
In terms of population density, Taipei City topped the ranking with 610 persons per square kilometer, followed by Kaohsiung City and Taichung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE OVERSEAS WORKERS LOSING TAIWAN MARKET OVER AIR DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The deployment of Filipino contract workers to Taiwan has slowed considerably since the suspension of direct flights between Manila and Taiwan by the Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) two months ago.
As a result of the Oct. 1 abrogation of the 1996 Air Pact between the Philippines and Taiwan, around 2,000 job orders for Filipinos were canceled by Taiwan brokers and employers.

At a joint press conference on Friday, the Freedom to Fly Coalition and the Filipino Manpower agency expressed their apprehension that an additional 10,000 jobs could be lost over the next three months if the government does not take action soon to resolve the present air crisis.
Most of the jobs were canceled due to additional airfares and longer travel time and were diverted to Thais and to Vietnamese, who have just entered the labor market in Taiwan.

Currently more than 30,000 Filipinos who wish to go home for holidays are unable to make travel plans since most seats on the Hong Kong-Manila route are booked for Christmas. It is feared that if those workers cannot return on time, they face possible fines by their employers and might even lose their jobs. (by Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF ROC LEGISLATIVE YUAN INVITED TO PANAMA CANAL HANDOVER CEREMONY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Wang Jin-ping, president of the Republic of China Legislative Yuan, has been invited to attend Sunday's ceremony marking the handover of the US-administered Panama Canal to Panama, said the Panamanian Foreign Ministry on Friday.
Wang and four ROC legislators are expected to take part in the handover ceremony and a state banquet given by Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso on Sunday.
During his stay in Panama between Dec. 12 and 17, Wang will also join his Central American counterparts at a forum of parliamenary speakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui plans to grant general amnesty to all political prisoners.
The China Times:
PRC, Russia oppose the US proposal to build anti-missile defense system.
The United Daily News:
President Lee orders study on the feasibility of granting blanket amnesty to all political prisoners.
The Liberty Times:
The Asia's first human rights monument is inaugurated on Green Island; President Lee apologizes to those who suffered in the struggle for democracy.
The China Post:
The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party names female vice presidential candidate, Annette Lu.
The Taiwan News:
Annette Lu officially matched with Chen Shui-bian as DPP vice presidential choice.
The Taipei Times: Rights Monument unveiled on Green Island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 11, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton), resulting in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy in World War II.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin elected as speaker.
1961: Two US helicopter companies arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier in the first direct US military support for South Vietnam's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and misfeasance.
1972: The US Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the US Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: A South Korean naval training flotilla with 618 crewmen aboard leaves Kaohsiung after a three-day visit.
1974: The Executive Yuan of ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Col. Ernesto P. Goles, secretary of the Philippine chapter of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League, and Dr. Fethi Tevetoqlu, secretary general of the Middle East Solidarity Council of Turkey, arrive in Taipei to attend the 23rd APACL pre-conference executive meeting.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrent director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the poll that selects Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1996: Incumbent President Jerry Rawlings is declared the winner in Ghana's presidential election.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: COLD FRONT TO HIT TAIWAN NEXT TUESDAY

TEXT.P: A cold front from mainland China will hit Taiwan next Tuesday with the temperature dropping to as low as 13 degrees Celsius in the northern and central parts of the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Saturday.

CWB forecaster Wang Yao-hua said that people on Taiwan will probably not feel too cold initially when the cold front arrives on Dec. 14. However, he added that temperatures around the island will gradually decline with the lowest temperatures probably appearing early Wednesday morning.

It is expected that the cold front will last at least until Dec. 17. It is estimated that the lowest temperature will be 13 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, 13-14 degrees in central Taiwan, and 16 degrees in the southern part of the island. The CWB urged people to make sure they dress warmly.

DOC.HEADLINE: HI-TECH CRIMINALS HURTING E-COMMERCE

TEXT.P: Canadian police are warning the public that high-tech criminals have come up with a clever new way to steal money from bank accounts, hurting the prospects of the much-touted e-commerce.

Detectives said fraud artists have started tapping into counter-top pads many consumers now use instead of paying with cash or checks. When a customer sweeps their bank card across the automatic sensor, automatically debiting money from their bank account to pay for goods, crooks can record the information encoded on the back of the card, police said.
Even more, it now appears that they can also steal your personal identification number (PIN) as well, and then quickly wipe out your savings, police reported.

Royal Canadian Mounted Police Superintendent Ben Soave, called this form of fraud a "frightening" development that threatens electronic commerce. He said the problem is too big for police officers alone to solve.
The situation is so serious that Canada's entire debit card system may now be compromised, according to the RCMP.
"The financial institutions, the Canadian Bankers' Association, they are all working on this, doing damage control," Soave said.

The latest scam was uncovered this week after police broke up what they say was an Eastern European crime ring operating out of Toronto. Dozens of people were arrested on Thursday and charged with a variety of offenses, from money laundering to drug trafficking.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT CRITICIZES CHINA IN HUMAN RIGHTS DAY STATEMENT

TEXT.P: US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on Friday criticized Communist China for its crackdowns on the China Democracy Party and Falun Gong, and for its continuing repression of Tibetan Buddhists and non-government-sanctioned religious groups.

In her Human Rights Day statement, Albright said that these actions demonstrate that "the (Beijing) government still fails to recognize that everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion."

She pointed out that the United States embraces the spread of human rights around the world and celebrates the emergence of new democracies, but "there are still too many places where human rights and democracy are still elusive."

In addition to Communist China, Albright cited Russia, Belarus, Burma, Cuba, Iraq, Sudan and Afghanistan as countries that fundamentally disregard the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights' promise that everyone has the right to dignity, to security, and to life and liberty.

She noted that "in Kosovo, we learned that the international community can come together to prevent wholesale human rights abuses. In East Timor, we learned that concerted action by the United Nations can prevent military units from overturning the will of a people. In Indonesia, Nigeria and elsewhere, we learned that no nation, no religion, no culture is immune to democratic values."

"The United States remains determined to work with all those who love freedom to ensure that the next century will see continued progress in the promotion of democracy and respect for human dignity and rights," claimed Albright.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL BAUER SPEAKS ON CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: US Republican presidential hopeful Gary Bauer on Friday stressed that there would be no absorption of Taiwan into China during his administration because the people of Taiwan will not agree to it, saying unification can only come after China becomes a free country.
During the taping of NBC's "One on One" TV program, the conservative Republican leader told John McLaughlin that he approves of the installation of an anti-missile defense system on Taiwan.

When asked if he is willing to risk provoking military confrontation as Communist China regards the US providing Taiwan with a theater missile defense system as an intrusion into their "internal affairs," Bauer pointed out that the lesson of this century is that "the way to avoid military confrontation is to make it clear to our adversaries what we care about, what we're willing to defend."
Bauer added that the Clinton policy of appeasing Communist China may lead to a military confrontation, but "my policy will surely not lead to that."

He also criticized Texas Governor George W. Bush, who endorsed China's entry into the World Trade Organization and also most-favored-nation trading status for Beijing, for not being much different from Clinton and Vice President Gore on his China policy.

As to Communist China's internal suppression of non-government sponsored religion, Bauer said that if he were president, he would respond to it the same way that Ronald Reagan responded to it in the Soviet Union.

Bauer emphasized that "the first thing we need to do is turn our agenda with China upside down. Right now trade is first and everything else is a poor second, including our own national security. I would make it clear to them that if they want to continue to dump their goods in the US market, we're going to have to start seeing progress on human rights, on issues affecting our national security, and related matters."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN AT TOP OF MAN OF THE YEAR LIST AMONG COLLEGE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party ranked at the top of list for the man of the year in a survey of Taiwan college students, Chinese Culture Association said on Saturday.

The DPP candidate and former Taipei City Mayor garnered a 12.5 percent support rate, while independent presidential candidate and former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong was second with a support rate of 8.7 percent, and popular rock singer Wu Pai was third with a support rate of 8.6 percent.

The association conducted the survey at 15 of the 60 colleges and universities in Taiwan between Nov. 23 and Dec. 7. The total number of respondents to the questionnaire was 1,020, and the survey's margin of error is 2.5 percent.

President Lee Teng-hui placed fourth with a support rate of 8.1 percent, followed by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou with 7.3 percent, and Yuan T. Lee, president of the nation's top research institute Academia Sinica, with 6.9 percent.
Historian and critic Li Ao was seventh with a support rate of 6.8 percent, followed by business tycoon Y. C. Wang with 6.4 percent.
Vice President Lien Chan was ninth with 6.1 percent and Chairman Morris Chang of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. rounded out the top 10 with a support rate of 5.6 percent.

Chinese Culture Association President Fan Kuang-lin, commenting on the survey results, said the fact that popular singer Wu Pai outranked President Lee reflected a change in societal values among college students.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEW BUY ALLEGATIONS OF BEIJING FINANCING PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Not many people in Taiwan believe the allegations that independent presidential candidate James Soong has received donations from Beijing, according to a newly released survey.

Although his rivals have made strong suggestions that he has been financially aided by Beijing, 40.44 percent of the people interviewed by a local public relations firm , the Red Sky Poll Center, dismissed the accusations as a smear campaign.

On the other hand, 14.44 percent said they feel it was a trick used by Soong to make himself look like the victim of character assassination campaign, while only 5.98 percent said they believe Soong actually received funds from Beijing.

On the question of whether or not they believe Beijing has been trying to influence Taiwan's presidential election by providing money to specific presidential candidates, 46.36 percent said no, 28.22 percent said yes, and the rest said they weren't sure.

If the vote were held tomorrow, 27.74 percent of those interviewed said they would support Soong, 21.76 percent said they would support Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party, and 17.47 percent would support Kuomintang candidate Lien Chan. The rest of the respondents said they were still undecided.

Although Soong leads all other contestants as the most popular candidate, Lien is seen, by 34.93 percent of those surveyed, as the candidate most likely to win the election. He is followed by Soong at 27.35 percent and Chen at 6.49 percent.
The survey was conducted between Dec. 6-8, with 1,004 eligible voters from around the island being interviewed.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS HIGH DEMAND FOR HOUSING, DAY-CARE SERVICES

TEXT.P: The results of a recent opinion poll of salaried people in Taipei show that the expectations of government assistance in housing, day care and improvement of public order remain high.

The Taipei Salaried People Association has conducted an annual survey of salaried people's opinions about job, daily lives and work environment since 1996. The association began its 1999 survey in Septenber. It sent out 2,300 questionnaires and collected 2,184 valid replies, with 46.9 percent from male respondents and 53.1 percent from women. And the monthly income of those surveyed mostly ranges between NT$30,000 and NT$39,000.

On the everyday life-related demand, 56 percent of the respondents said the government should help resolve housing issue; 51 percent cited the need for government assistance in resolving children's day-care issue; and 37 percent said the government should work harder to improve public order to ensure a safer living environment.

Housing and day care issues have remained on the top two spots of the salaried people's service demand list for two years, indicating that the problems have continued to trouble young salaried people.

On the work-related expectations, nearly 60 percent said the government should organize training programs for salaried people to learn more professional skills or expertise other than their current work fields. Moreover, 52 percent said they hope the government will offer on-job training programs. The two figures indicate that a sense of unemployment crisis shadows many local salaried people.

On the working conditions, 70 percent of those interviewed said they hope a full five-day work week system can be implemented as soon as possible. Meanwhile, two-thirds said their companies have not yet implemented a retirement pension system.

As for expectations of their companies, the respondents cited a pay raise as their top desire; followed by the implementation of a retirement system, an annual leave sysem and a severance pay system in that order. Many female respondents also expressed their strong hope for improvement of workplace gender discriminations.

Turning to finances for post-retirement lives, 76.5 percent said personal savings will be the main source of finances for their lives after retirement, indicating that the government has not done its due in offering financial subsidies or support for the elderly.

Poll results also show that the concept of relying their children for the support of their post-retirement lives is no long a mainstream idea as only 7 percent said they will rely on their children for financial support after retirement.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN STRAIT' ISSUE WILL WORSEN IF NO ADJUSTMENT IS MADE: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The "Taiwan Strait" issue will worsen in the new millennium if no new strategy is worked to tackle it, a National Chengchi University professor warned on Saturday.

Professor Chao Chien-ming made the remarks at a symposium dubbed "Transformation and Development: Taiwan Marching Toward the New Century," which was sponsored by the ruling Kuomintang's manpower training institute.
Chao said although the Taiwan Strait has been a military confrontation high-risk area, it has not been included into any international security systems.

In fact, Chao said, Asian countries hold different views concerning strategies for addressing security issues. Generally speaking, Chao said, Southeast Asian countries prefer to incorporate mainland China into a collective security system through informal consultations, confidence-building and establishment of consensus.

As for Northeast Asian countries, Chao said, they opt for forging military alliances with the United States to ensure security. For instance, Japan and South Korea have respectively signed defense cooperation treaties with the United States. Chao attributed the phenomenon mainly to North Korea's hostility toward South Korea and a complicated historical complex between Japan and mainland China.
Chao pointed out that Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations and the ASEAN Regional Forum, and has not signed any bilateral defense agreement with other countries.
As a result, Chao said, the "Taiwan Strait" issue has been kept out of international or regional collective security mechanisms.

Noting that Beijing has never concealed its attempt to take Taiwan by force, Chao said the failure to put the cross-Taiwan Strait issue on the agenda of regional or international security forums is worrisome.
Because of Beijing's vociferous opposition, Chao said, it remains uncertain whether the US-proposed Northeast Asian theater missile defense system will cover the Taiwan Strait area.

With the dawn of the new millennium, Chao said Taiwan, mainland China and other countries in the nearby region should face the cross-strait issue squarely and make adjustments in strategies or attitudes in order to avoid a breakout of military conflicts in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA PROVIDES FREE WEB NEWS TO CHINESE-LANGUAGE NEWS MEDIA IN NYC
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By David Wang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: From now through Dec. 31, 2000, Chinese-language news media in greater New York City can adopt the full text of CNA-provided on-line Chinese-language news, news photos, financial and economic news, and CNA news story database data free of charge.

The CNA is providing the service at the request of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC). The website of the service is "www.cnataipei.org (user name: ocacnews, password: 2000)"

The OCAC asked those Chinese-language news media to observe the regulations governing the use of CNA news information, including giving credits to the CNA once they publish or disseminate in any form the news they downloaded from the CNA website and not distorting facts and meanings of articles of the CNA news stories.
The news service has been welcomed by the Chinese-language news media in greater New York City.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES SOONG TO EXPLAIN FINANCIAL SOURCES

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang on Saturday continued turning the heat up on independent presidential candidate James Soong to reveal the source of the huge sum of cash stashed in a bank account of his son Soong Chen-yuan.

Two days after a KMT legislator unearthed the existence of a NT$140 million-plus sum of cash deposited in the account of Soong Chen-yuan with a local bill and security company, the KMT campaign manager, Jason Hu urged Soong to honestly explain where the money came from.
"Privacy should not be an excuse to shield public figures from scrutiny," especially when he is aspiring to be the head of state, said Hu, calling on Soong to reveal the source of the money.
He denied the claim of a pro-Soong legislator Chou Shih-wei that the KMT has this month launched a "Soong-bashing campaign."
Taipei's KMT mayor Ma Ying-jeou joined the chorus in urging Soong to reveal the truth about the origin of the cash or else face public suspicions and damage to his credibility.
"Transparency of financial activities is what the public expects from their leaders, and political leaders should live up to their expectations," said Ma.
Meanwhile, Soong on Saturday continued to keep silent on the source of the money after having played it down as a loan from a unanimous family elder.

The terse explanation only stirred up more public suspicions and added fuel to the rumors saying that he received donations from suspected sources, leading to a decrease in Soong's lead in popularity polls.
Soong's popularity has sunk below thirty percent in various polls taken after the disclosure of the deposit as his political rivals in the Kuomintang keep tightening the screw on him.

Soong on Friday challenged other presidential contestants to make public the source of all their finances. The move was dismissed by critics as a futile attempt to deflect negative attention away from himself and didn't help much in defusing the flak from his political foes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST TAIWAN, CZECH REPUBLIC CO-PRODUCED PLANE ROLLS OFF ASSEMBLY LINE
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By W. H. Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The first commercial airplane co-produced by Taiwan's Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) and the Czech Republic's Aero Vodochody rolled off the assembly line on Friday.

Aero Vodochody chose the date of the company's 80th anniversary to hold the roll-off ceremony, showing the great importance it attaches to the joint-venture between the ROC and the Czech Republic, sources said.

Roy Wu, ROC representative to the Czech Republic, attended the ceremony on behalf of the ROC government. He voiced his great respect for the efforts made by both countries in developing the Ae270 commercial plane over the last two and a half years and expressed the hope that this model of cooperation could be used in the high-tech aviation industry in the future.

David Chu, director of the ROC's Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development under the Ministry of Economics Affairs, and AIDC Vice President Chou Yuan-yuan, both also expressed their appreciation for the efforts made by Aero Vodochody so that the Ae270 could roll off the assembly line on schedule.
Some 600 Czech dignitaries, including transportation, defense, and trade officials, parliamentarians and media reporters also attended the two-and-a-half-hour ceremony.

AIDC and Aero Vodochody joined hands in 1997 to invest more than US$50 million in developing the commercial plane, marking the first step by the Taiwan aviation industry in making inroads into the East European market.

Sources said that the project first came up in discussion when Vice President Lien Chan, then Premier, made a ground-breaking trip to the Czech Republic in mid-1995, when he expressed interest in cooperating with the most influential airplane manufacturer in East Europe to extend the tentacles of Taiwan's aviation industry into Eastern Europe.
Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-min, then director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau, then made two more trips to the Czech Republic to finalize the joint-venture project.
The Ae-270 commercial airplane is a 10-seat single-turbine propeller aircraft which has obtained certification from the US Federal Aviation Administration.
AIDC officials noted that Aero Vodochody was the largest airplane manufacturer in East Europe and has produced more than 5,000 military or civilian planes.

The officials paint a rosy picture for the joint venture, saying that with the cooperation over the Ae270 aircraft, the AIDC will make inroads into the international civil aviation airplane market, in addition to expanding its Asian and Pacific operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WINS ACROSS-THE-BOARD VICTORY AT CZECH TABLE TENNIS TOURNEY

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open on Saturday with its men and women players gaining both group singles and group doubles victories, according to reports from the Czech Republic.
Chen Ching beat a player from the Czech Republic 3 games to 0, while Hsu Ching defeated a French player 3-1 in Saturday's women's group singles matches.
The two Chinese Taipei women players also registered victory in Saturday's group doubles match, defeating a French pair 2-0.
Chang Yen-shu routed a Japanese player 3-2 and Chiang Peng-lung beat a player from Hungary 3 games to 1 in men's group singles matches.
The pair also recorded a 2-0 victory over the Hungarian team to win the group doubles contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS FINANCIAL DEALING SCANDAL HURTS SOONG'S IMAGE

TEXT.P: The results of a survey released on Saturday show that independent presidential candidate James Soong's clean image has been hurt by the latest accusations of financial impropriety against him.

The opinion poll, conducted by Gallup Taiwan Co. on Friday, also found that many respondents believe opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian's choice of Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu as his running mate is conducive to his presidential bid.
Gallup was commissioned by Sanlih Entertainment Television to conduct the survey to gauge the possible impact of the financial impropriety accusations on Soong's popular support rating.
The telephone poll of 1,069 randomly selected adults found that 54.1 percent of the respondents think the accusations have had an adverse impact on Soong's reputed clean image.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Yang Chi-hsiung said on Thursday that when Soong served as the KMT's secretary-general in 1992, which also happened to be an election year for the legislature, Soong's son Soong Chen-yuan, then just 24, bought NT$120 million worth of securities.
"At that time, the junior Soong had just been discharged from the military, and had no job to support himself -- how could he afford to buy securities worth NT$120 million?" Yang asked.

In response, Soong appeared to have shifted his stance on the issue three times in the past two days. According to Soong's latest version of the story in a statement released on Friday morning, Soong said he had returned the money to the as-yet unidentified person.

The latest Gallup poll found that 49.5 percent of the respondents do not think Soong's statement is true, 23.9 percent of whom expressed their extreme unbelief in the truth of Soong's statement. Only 14.3 percent said they believe that Soong's statement is true, while 36.1 percent said they don't know whether they should believe in Soong's statement.

Nevertheless, Soong continued to lead the pack of presidential hopefuls in terms of popularity. If the presidential election were to take place the following day, 28 percent of the respondents said they would still vote for Soong.
The same poll found that 21.4 percent would throw support behind the DPP standard-bearer Chen Shui-bian, and 17 percent would opt for the ruling Kuomintang candidate, Vice President Lien Chan.

On the other hand, Lien beat his two chief competitors in terms of the odds to win the 2000 presidential election. Poll results show that 32.2 percent of those interviewed said they think Lien would win the critical election, compared to Soong's 30.5 percent and Chen's 10.7 percent.

Turning to the impact of Chen's choice of fellow party member Annette Lu as his running mate, 43.5 percent said they believe that the decision will benefit Chen's presidential bid; 12 percent said the move will have a negative impact.
Meanwhile, 65.8 percent said they think that Lu will help boost Chen's support among women voters; but 16.4 percent said they don't think Lu can help Chen attract female supporters.

As much as 93.5 percent said they would go to the polls on the 2000 presidential election day, while 2 percent said they would not and 4.5 percent said they have yet to make a final decision on whether to cast their ballots.

In comparison, the results of a similar opinion survey conducted by the United Daily News on Friday show that Soong's support rating declined to 24 percent in the wake of the "financial impropriety allegations" against him. On the contrary, the supporting rates for Chen and Lien both surged to 23 percent. This was the first time that the three chief contestants' support ratings were so close in the paper's presidential election-related polls conducted over past few months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S LIEN-SIEW TEAM TO ANNOUNCE PLATFORM ON 8 MAJOR ISSUES

TEXT.P: The election campaign headquarters of the Kuomintang's presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate Vincent Siew said on Saturday that it will make public the Lien-Siew team's platform on eight major issues step by step from next week.

Former Foreign Minister Jason Hu, now serving as general executive of the ruling party's election campaign headquarters, told the media that the KMT "has confidence to reverse the election trend by engaging in a quality campaign, instead of joining in verbal attacks with other candidates."
He said that eight spokespersons, four men and four women, have been named to speak for the Lien-Siew team on the eight major issues.

Tsai Cheng-yuan will take charge of political issues, while Chu Li-lun will speak on economic and science and technology issues, Chen Hsueh-sheng on diplomatic affairs, Lu Hsiu-yen on national defense, Lee Ching-ping on mainland policy, Kuo Su-chun on internal and environmental issues, Nancy Chao on education and Chang Jen-hsiang on culture.
Hu said that the KMT election campaign headquarters will uphold the principles of "honesty, responsibility and courage" to speak out all facts without any hesitation during the campaign period.
The presidential election will be held on March 18, 2000. Besides the Lien-Siew team, Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu will represent the opposition Democratic Progressive Party in the race.

Former Taiwan Governor James Soong will team up with Chang Chao-hsiung, former director of Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, in the election. The tiny New Party's presidential nominee is writer-critic Li Ao.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF RARE BIRDS GRACE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is graced by the arrival of a record number of blackfaced spoonbills, an endangered species, this year, a wild bird conservation group reported Saturday.

As of Friday, 463 blackfaced spoonbills had been discovered in the area surrounding the mouth of the Tsengwenchi River in Chiku township of Tainan County in southern Taiwan, the Tainan Blackfaced Spoonbills Conservation Association said.

The number marked an increase of about 100 birds over the figure recorded last year, the association said, adding that the number has increased steadily since the first rare bird was spotted in the Chiku area in September.

The association said the increase might resulted from natural expansion of the species. It might also be triggered by certain problems seen in the species' other natural habitats, thus prompting a large number of the birds to fly to Taiwan to avoid frigid cold in the north.
Blackfaced spoonbills are migrant birds which usually fly to Taiwan from the north to spend winter and return to their original habitats the following spring.

A Hong Kong-based consulting company will conduct a global survey of blackfaced spoonbills in January next year. By then, the association said, the reasons behind the increase in the number of the rare birds to Taiwan will probably become clear.

An international survey conducted a few years ago shows that the number of surviving blackfaced spoonbills worldwide is about 600 to 700. As 300 to 400 of them consistently take shelter in Taiwan each winter, the phenomenon has attracted much attention from international wildlife conservation activists.

A large crowd of bird watchers have visited the Chiku area in recent days to observe the rare migrant birds. The association has sent instructors to brief wild bird lovers on the features of blackfaced spoonbills and the Chiku area ecological environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 600 FALUN GONG MEMBERS STAGE A DEMONSTRATION IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Some 600 Falun Gong followers from Hong Kong and at least seven countries in the world staged a demonstration here Saturday, calling for an end to the government crackdown on Falun Gong in China.

The demonstrators sat silently in rows outside the Hong Kong headquarters of China's official Xinhua News Agency first, and then paraded to a nearby park. A spokesman for the demonstrators told the press that they did not protest against anyone. He said they only wanted Beijing leaders to know that Falun Gong is good to its practitioners' health and mind, and that it won't hurt anyone.

The Falun Gong followers, who are from Hong Kong, the United States, Japan, Australia, Taiwan, Great Britain, Singapore, Indonesia and other countries, are in Hong Kong to participate in a two-day symposium on their experience in practicing Falun Gong. It is a mix of slow-motion Chinese traditional martial arts, meditation and breathing techniques, and the teachings of Buddhism and Taoism. The mainland Chinese government banned Falun Gong as an "evil cult" in July.

Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa Saturday expressed grave concern over the Falun Gong followers' activities in Hong Kong, saying that they must observe Hong Kong laws and avoid doing anything that may undermine the interest of Hong Kong, China, and their "one country, two systems". President Jiang Enzhu of Xinhua headquarters in Hong Kong also said Saturday that Hong Kong should not become a Falun Gong base for infiltration into the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT PLAYS GOLF WITH AIT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui played golf with Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), in suburban Taipei on Saturday.
While playing golf, Lee and Bush exchanged views on some topics related to Taipei-Washington relations, cross-Taiwan Strait ties, and Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization.
The friendly game was hosted by Ding Mou-shih, acting secretary general of the National Security Council.

Other Chinese officials invited to the game included Presidential Secretary-General John Chang, Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen, Defense Minister Tang Fei and Chairman P.K. Chiang of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Bush, who came to Taipei last Wednesday, will hold formal talks with Lee next week.
Among the main purposes of Bush's Taipei visit is to meet with some primary presidential candidates. This was the third Taipei visit by the AIT chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 12, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans-Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: German aeronautical engineer Hugo Junkers conducts a test flight of his all-metal plane, the world's first.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1925: Reza Khan, a cavalry officer, becomes shah of Iran and establishes the Pahlavi dynasty.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a US warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking, and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1975: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revised Factory Law.
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others, and a special prize at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1989: Petar Mladinov, first secretary of Bulgaria's Communist Party, announces free elections in Bulgaria, ending the party's monopoly on power.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian legislature for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: Chi Ta-chuan, a mainland Chinese national, hijacks a Xiamen Airlines plane to Taiwan.
1994: The Lien Chan cabinet is re-organized and new cabinet members are sworn in on Dec. 15.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning, in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:

genes needed for life.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONG COLD AIR MASS TO HIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A strong cold air mass from mainland China is moving southward, and will encompass Taiwan by Tuesday, predicted the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) on Sunday.

The expected cold front would lower the island's temperature to 13 degrees Celsius, and the coldest temperatures are expected to occur in the northern and central areas of Taiwan, said weather forecasters, noting that such chilly weather could last for a few days.
The cold air current is expected to continue to affect the island through at least next Sunday, the forecasters said.

At present Taiwan remains affected by northeasterly monsoon winds, which have led to pleasant weather. Sunday's daytime temperature in northern Taiwan was moving upward to 23 degrees Celsius from the early morning hours' 15 degrees, while that in the south was expected to level out at 27 or 28 degrees Celsius, the CWB reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, VIETNAM HAVE SUBSTANTIAL CLOSE TIES: ROC REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: A breakthrough in political relations with Vietnam is difficult to pursue, but the substantial trade relations between the Republic of China and that nation have always close, said ROC Representative to Vietnam Hu Chia-chi on Sunday.

Hu noted that Vietnam shares a border with mainland China, and considering the size contrast of the two nations, Vietnam is bound to side with the mainland, especially considering the fact that both are communist countries.
Therefore, Hu said, in the foreseeable future, it would be overly optimistic to expect a breakthrough in political relations with Vietnam.

But he also said both nations have developed close substantial trade relations and Vietnam has realized the friendship of the ROC and its contribution to that Southeast Asian nation's economy, believing that the Taiwan experience would be the best model for Vietnam in developing its economy and improving living standard of its people.

He noted that in November the first group of Vietnamese workers arrived in Taiwan, saying that their high quality have caught the attention of local people and predicting that there is room for further growth in the number of Vietnamese workers on the island.

Hu also said that the number of Vietnamese wives in Taiwan is estimated at 20,000 and Taiwan businessmen investing in Vietnam number 27,000. Civilian exchanges between the two nations are close, and the substantial relations are becoming closer and more important to both countries, he said.
With the recent signing of agreements on labor cooperation and cooperation in agricultural technology, relations between the two nations are expected to grow even closer, Hu said.

Hu added that his office is now working on several other goals, including implementation of the two recently signed agreements and revival of bilateral trade ministerial conferences. They are also working toward the signing of trade agreements, a temporary admission of goods agreement and memoranda of understanding on securities cooperation and on protection of wildlife.
Hu is scheduled to report on the current situation in Vietnam and ROC-Vietnam relations to a legislative committee on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIDOW OF 'WHITE TERROR' VICTIM TELLS TRUE STORY OF 50 YEARS AGO

TEXT.P: Scores of elders, former students of a contingent school in Penghu some 50 years ago, gathered Saturday at a Taipei church to commemorate their principal who was sacrificed in the White Terror campaign that bore numerous sad souls in Taiwan a half-century ago.

The senior citizens, in their 60s and 70s, prayed for Principal Chang Min-chih, who was executed by Kuomintang security forces on Dec. 11, 1949, for being a "communists' spy," and for peace for Chang's surviving family, including his wife, Wang Pei-wu.

Amid the sounds of solemn organ music, they read from the just-released book "Principle on the Cross," a compilation of true stories as told by the principal's wife, Wang, and jointly written by former Legislator Kao Huei-yu and Liu Tai-ping, a senior staff writer with the Taiwan Daily News.

The book, according to the authors, is a record of the death of Chang, principal of the Yentai Allied Middle School in Shandong, who was authorized in 1949 to lead some 8,000 students from that northern Chinese province to Taiwan in a national evacuation movement after the Kuomintang, or the Nationalists, lost the civil war against the Chinese communists.
Chang led the students to Penghu Island in the Taiwan Strait and settled there in early 1949.

On the morning of July 13, 1949, according to the book, the Nationalist army marched onto the campus of the contingent school in Penghu and ordered the students, ranging in age from 12 to 22, to lay down their pencils and take up arms "at a time of national crisis."

As no students showed willingness to join the military and some expressed opposition to its undemocratic moves, the army fired on the students, killing dozens and casting a shroud of deadly terror over the campus.

Chang, as head of the institute, shouted to the army officers his indignation over the murders and forced conscription. Following the event, he chose to protect the students and stand up to the military.

After one month of standoff against the military, Chang decided to go to the main island of Taiwan to meet with friends from Shandong who held high government positions to seek assistance in persuading the military to leave his students alone. He repeatedly failed to obtain passage to Taiwan.

On Sept. 15, when he was finally informed that there was a ticket available for the ship to Taiwan, he was arrested aboard the vessel. That was the last time that his wife and their 12-year-old son, Chang Ping, saw him.
Later that year, the Chang family was told that he had been executed in Taipei on Dec. 11, on charges of spying for the Chinese communists.
Before he was executed, Chang and some 40 students of the contingent school of Penghu were jailed in a prison in Taipei, all standing accused of spying for the communists.
On her own, Wang raised the six children she had with Chang, surviving on limited material supplies. All the children, however, received good education and later settled in the United States.

Their eldest son, Chang Ping, who has the clearest memory of the reign of White terror, returned to Taiwan as a scholar in the 1970s, seeking justice and trying to clear the name of his father. The six grown children jointly appealed to the government in 1989 to restore Chang's reputation. Their efforts, however, were in vain.
In that Penghu tragedy, some 100 students were victimized along with Principal Chang, according to the book.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEN ARE MAINSTREAM OF E-SHOPPERS IN ASIA

TEXT.P: So-called "E-shoppers" in Asia are mostly men, according to the latest survey on Asian consumers released Sunday by VISA International Service Association.

The survey, designed to study consumption via the Internet, showed that in Asia the number of male respondents who said they are willing to buy goods using computers is two times that of women who answered the questionnaire.

Forty percent of the surveyed Asians said they will spend more money on Internet shopping in the future, while one-third of those polled revealed their plan to buy Christmas gifts through the Internet.
Forty-two percent of survey respondents said they had shopped on Internet service networks. The figure is made up of 30 percent male and 12 percent female consumers, according to the poll.
Results also showed that 62 percent of E-shopping lovers are 30 years old or older, revealing that currently male 30-something consumers are the mainstream of E-shoppers in Asia.

Convenience, a variety of choices, and shopping with minimal physical exertion were cited as the main reasons why consumers want to buy things in cyberspace. The most popular Internet shops among Asian E-consumers are the Amazon bookstore and Yahoo, according to the VISA survey.
The poll pointed out that books, computers and related products, electronic household appliances, cosmetics, and jewels are the items most commonly purchased by E-shoppers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 PHILIPPINE OFFICIALS TO ARRIVE FOR AVIATION TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A group of three Philippine officials, including Jacinto F. Ortega, director of the Civil Aeronautic Board, will arrive in Taipei Monday to resume talks on the suspended Aviation Pact between Taiwan and the Philippines.
The two other members of the delegation are Eduardo C. Galang and Lito A. Mondragon, both members of the board.

The Civil Aeronautic Board comprises five members, and any decisions are made by a majority of votes. That three board members are traveling to Taipei to signify that they have the right to make a decision on the matter.

The Philippines unilaterally abrogated the Taipei-Manila Aviation Pact signed in 1996 after two rounds of talks were held. The two sides failed to reach an agreement because the Philippines insisted on cutting the weekly passenger quota for Taiwan air carriers from 9,600 to 3,000 seats and revoking the sixth flight right to continue to a third-country destination.

The suspended Taipei-Manila air links caused great inconvenience to those travelers going between Taipei and Manila, especially for those Filipinos who work in Taiwan. More than 200,000 Philippine workers are employed on the island. Most of them wish to return home for family reunions at Christmas and the New Year's holiday.
The Philippine side, therefore, reinstated its recognition of the 1996 Taipei-Manila Aviation Pact as one of the preconditions for resuming talks set forth by the Republic of China.
However, the remaining knotted issue is whether or not Taipei and Manila can agree on the disputed sixth flight right for third-country destinations during the upcoming talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR PANAMA

TEXT.P: A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departed Sunday for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the Republic of China and Central American countries.
Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Ou saw them off at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
The mission comprises Shen Fu-hsiung (DDP), Chiang Chi-wen (KMT), Lee Chu-feng (NP) and independent legislator Chen Chin-ting.
Hu Cheng-yao, director of the Central and South American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, also accompanied the mission to Panama.
Wang said before departing that participation in the forum will help further enhance ties between the Republic of China and Central American countries.
The group is expected to return on Dec. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO TO BRIDGE COMMUNICATION GAP BETWEEN TAIWAN AND MAINLAND: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Professor Chang Lin-cheng of National Taiwan University said she expects that frozen relations between Taiwan and mainland China will start thawing after the two sides join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The world trade regulatory body is expected to build a bridge of communication between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait, Chang said, explaining that under the WTO framework, Taiwan and the mainland can start their contact by opening negotiations on economic disputes.

If the talks proceed in a smooth manner and lead to good results, the two sides may be able to open talks on thorny political issues, Chang noted in her speech Sunday at the 1999 board and membership meeting of the Taipei-based Association for Promoting Peaceful Unification of China.

Chang indicated that she found Beijing has been anxious about the Taiwan problem since Hong Kong returned to mainland rule in July, 1997, and has maintained that stance, with Macau set to revert to its sovereignty from the Portuguese at the end of this year.

But mainland authorities will not use military forces against Taiwan in the near future because the United States has revealed that it will make every effort to maintain peace in the Asia-Pacific region, the professor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 82% OF PEOPLE IN FAVOR OF LONG-RANGE GROUND-TO-GROUND MISSILES: POLL

TEXT.P: An overwhelming majority of the people of Taiwan are in favor of Vice President Lien Chan's proposal to develop long-range ground-to-ground missiles, a recent poll showed on Sunday.

In the poll conducted by the Public Opinion Association of the Republic of China, 82 percent of those interviewed said they are supportive of Lien's proposal, while only 9.8 percent said they do not support the proposal, and 8.2 percent said they were unaware of it.

The public was also asked about Lien's proposal to visit the mainland if he is elected president next year and whether his strategy of "avoiding war, but not fearing war" would contribute to win-win cross-strait relations.

Some 50.9 percent of respondents said the strategy would contribute to win-win cross-strait relations; some 19.5 percent felt it unlikely to do so, while 29.7 percent said they had no opinion on the issue.

Professor Oung Ming-hsien of Tamkang University, in analyzing the latest public poll results, noted that mainland China has recently launched verbal attacks and a military intimidation campaign against Taiwan, so Lien's proposal has won the support of most people in this time of public aversion for Beijing's intimidation.
Oung said that policies on national defense, foreign affairs and cross-strait relations will be crucial in the presidential election and will be unavoidable issues for presidential candidates.
He said Lien's strategy has won the high approval rating of the public and the vice president is bound to win the approval and trust of the voters.

On Lien's proposal to visit mainland China if he wins the presidential election next year, in order to establish a high-ranking communications channel as a way to dissolve mainland threats, some 62.3 percent of respondents said they approved of the proposal; 13.9 percent said they are not supportive of it, and 23.8 percent had no opinion on the matter.

The survey also showed that 74.8 percent of respondents believed political leaders "should clearly explain their strategy on cross-strait relations and national defense," while only 8.5 percent said there is no need for clear explanation, and 16.7 percent had no opinion on that issue.
The association conducted the survey islandwide between Dec. 9 and 11 with participants over 20 years old; the effective sample totaled 1,207.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA, CAL TO REDUCE FLIGHTS AROUND Y2K ROLLOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan-based EVA Airways and China Airlines (CAL) will reduce the number of flights to and from Taiwan around the Y2K rollover, airline sources said on Friday.
EVA Airways decided to cancel flights between New York and Taipei and flights from Los Angeles to Taipei between midnight Dec. 31 and noon Jan. 1.

The reduction was designed on the grounds that people are psychologically influenced by possible Y2K-related flight security risks and an across-the-board reduction in the number flights, which was called by the International Civil Aeronautic Organization, effective during the rollover period between 1999 and the year 2000, according to an EVA official in Los Angeles.
CAL decided to cancel flights between Los Angeles and Taipei, flights between San Francisco and Taipei, and flights from Taipei to New York between 9 p.m. on Dec. 31 and 12 noon on Jan. 1.
A CAL representative called the reduction essential due to worries of would-be passengers about the Y2K effect, as well as an expected shortage of crew members during the holiday period.
All EVA Air and CAL flights between Taiwan and the United States are expected to resume normal operations beginning at noon on Jan. 1, 2000, the two airlines said.
In related news, Taiwan's Civil Aeronautic Administration (CAA) is planning to cancel 122 domestic and 57 international flights during the century changeover.
CAA officials said the move is aimed at eliminating the possibility of Y2K-related flight security risks during the rollover period.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN-SIEW TICKET COMES FROM BEHIND TO TAKE LEAD IN POPULARITY: POLL

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan and running mate Premier Vincent Siew came from behind and now lead the three main tickets of presidential hopefuls, according to results of the latest poll by the Public Opinions Association of the Republic of China.

The poll shows that 20 percent of respondents supported the Lien-Siew team, followed by former Taiwan Gov. James Soong and Chang Chao-hsiung with a 19.3 percent approval rating; 16.3 percent went to Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate, former Taipei mayor Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu.
However, 38.8 percent of respondents said they have not yet made a final decision on their choice, the poll shows.
The telephone survey of 1,207 adults throughout the island was conducted from Dec. 9 to 11 by the association.

Analysis by Chu Li-min of National Chengchi University revealed that Soong's popularity rating, apparently affected by his son's stock scandal, has dramatically dropped from the prior 30 percent to 19.3 percent when the survey was initiated, the same day news of the scandal broke.

The poll also shows that 53.5 percent of supporters of the ruling Kuomintang responded in support of the Lien-Siew combination, while 16.9 percent of the KMT-backers among the respondents expressed their support for the Soong-Chang ticket.
Liang Teh-sheng of Catholic Fujen University said this indicates that those who had previously backed Soong have switched their support to the Lien-Siew pair.
According to the poll, 64.5 percent of the opposition DPP's supporters favored the Chen-Lu combination.

The survey results also show that Lien led the pack in terms of odds to win the 2000 presidential election scheduled to be held on March 18, 2000, with 37.6 percent saying that they expect to see Lien's victory. Soong trailed in second place, with 22.4 percent believing he will be victorious; Chen ranked third, with only 7 percent predicting a win for him.

Among the three key presidential hopefuls, Chen topped the list as the least popular, with 21.1 percent of respondents saying they would dislike seeing Chen win the presidency; followed by Soong at 18.6 percent; and Lien with 8 percent.
The same survey results also indicate that 82 percent of respondents said they support Vice President Lien Chan's recent proposal to develop long-range ground-to-ground missiles

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLDEN HORSE AWARDS PRESENTED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Hong Kong movie director Hui Ann was presented the best-director award at the 36th Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony held Sunday evening in Taipei.

Well-known movie stars Chun Hsiung Ko and Rachel Lee won the titles of the best leading actor and the best leading actress respectively. The Golden Horse awards, the Taiwan version of the Oscars, are presented annually in honor of outstanding Chinese films and celebrities from Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Other winners of this year's awards are listed below:
Best Picture-- Ordinary Heroes
Best Supporting Actor-- Leon Dai
Best Supporting Actress-- Deanie Ip
Best Cinematography-- Arthur Wong (in the film Purple Storm)
Best Film Editing-- Po Wen Cheng (in Darkness and Light)
Best Sound Effects-- Kinson Tsang (in Purple Storm)
Best Make up and Costume Design-- Elbut Poon (in Ordinary Heroes)
Best Action Choreography-- Wai Tong (in Purple Storm)
Best Art Direction-- Elbut Poon and Ringo Fung (in Ordinary Heroes)
Best Animation-- Kaualan
Best Documentary-- The Redleave Legend
Best Short Film-- Layover
Best Original Film Score-- Peter Kan (in Purple Storm)
