DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 13, or the sixth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the Dictionary of the English Language and Lives of the Poets.
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: US President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first US president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city, in what became known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese suicide plane crashes into the US cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the United Nations Security Council, China vetoes admission of Outer Mongolia to the UN.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her primitive-style colorful paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber, Republic of China, announces the list of winners of the first "10 outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last US mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, which became an independent country from its previous position as a British crown colony in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth championships in that sport.
1976: Gen. Lee Hon Kon, Korean council chairman of the APACL, arrives in Taiwan for an executive board meeting.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1981: Communist martial law is imposed in Poland to crush the Solidarity movement.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: In Brazzaville, South Africa signs an accord granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1989: ANC leader Nelson Mandela meets with President F.W. de Klerk for the first time to discuss the prospects for negotiating an end to South Africa's racial conflict.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization (WTO) meeting in Singapore.
Confucius: "If in governing you depend upon laws, and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment, and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG HOPES TO VISIT TAIWAN BEFORE ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-huan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng told the CNA Sunday that if given the chance, he would like to visit Taiwan again before the March presidential election to view the progress of democracy on the island.
Wei said a first-hand observation of the presidential election, which is one of the most important democratic processes in Taiwan, would be absolutely beneficial to mainland China's democratization.

Wei added that he has attached great importance to Taiwan's democratic development because Taiwan remains the one and only area in the world politically controlled by Chinese people that is democratic.
Meanwhile, he said that maintaining Taiwan's interests is tantamount to maintaining a source of hope for democratization in mainland China.

Regarding the March presidential election, Wei said he is very concerned about two feelings that the Taiwanese public in general has that are not necessarily correct. One is that the Chinese communists will not attack Taiwan militarily, and the other is that the United States will intervene if military conflict erupts across the Taiwan Strait.

Wei warned that the Chinese communists, as a whole, are basically a daring group willing to take risks. Citing history as an example, Wei said that some 50 years ago the Chinese communists managed to defeat the Nationalist forces and take control of the whole mainland with proportionally fewer capabilities, simply because they "dared to."
He asked the people of Taiwan to avoid thinking that mainland Chinese forces will not attack Taiwan.
Wei also said that according to his information gathered from the United States, Washington would not come to Taiwan's rescue under any circumstances.

Wei, currently visiting Germany and scheduled to meet with Germany's Foreign Affairs Minister Joschka Fischer Monday afternoon, said Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder has been "too friendly" to China since he assumed office.

He said this policy is starkly different from that of the Social Democratic Party and the Greens to which he had close relations before becoming chancellor. Wei said he would try to find out the reasons behind Shroeder's changed attitude.
He said the German government must free itself from the illusion of the huge potential for economic opportunities in mainland China, saying that in fact there is not.
Wei, who had been imprisoned for 18 years in mainland China for his pro-democracy activities and criticism of Beijing authorities, last visited Taiwan in December 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTRODUCTION OF VIETNAMESE LABORERS SAID BENEFICIAL TO BOTH NATIONS

TEXT.P: The introduction of Vietnamese laborers to Taiwan has been beneficial to both countries, Hu Chia-chi, the Republic of China representative to Vietnam, said on Monday.

Hu, reporting to a legislative committee about the current situation in Vietnam and in ROC-Vietnam relations, noted the first group of Vietnamese laborers arrived in Taiwan late last month, and the high quality of their work has won the accolade of local employers.

He described the Vietnamese laborers as both diligent and intelligent and as sharing the same customs as the local people. He predicted that more Vietnamese laborers will likely be invited to come to work in Taiwan.
Answering questions from Legislator Hung Tu of the ruling Kuomintang, Hu said that the laborers first learned Mandarin Chinese before coming to Taiwan.
He noted that, along with English, the study of the Mandarin language has become popular in the southeast Asian nation.

Hu said that relations between the two countries are close and becoming increasingly important, noting that currently more than 20,000 Vietnamese women have married Taiwanese men, while more than 27,000 Taiwanese are doing business in Vietnam.

Legislator Trong Tsai of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party expressed his concern about a assessment report by the United States that stated the South China Sea could be the most likely spot of clashes, and asked Hu whether mainland China is likely to clash with Vietnam or the ROC in the area.
Hu said that he has not heard about the report or any related news.

Another DPP Legislator Parris Chang asked whether Hu has explained to Vietnam the ROC government's redefinition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship." Hu responded that he has elaborated on the redefinition which is based on historical fact.

Hu said that the Vietnamese government has kept a low profile on the redefinition, resulting in great discontent in Beijing. The mainland government has hoped that Vietnam will express clearly that it is opposed to the redefinition.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA QUESTIONS BENEFITS OF BEIJING'S NEW RULES ON TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Monday questioned the ultimate benefits of the new rules that Beijing unveiled recently on Taiwan investment in mainland China.

Officials from MOEA's Investment Commission said the new rules, which supplement regulations issued in 1994, are just part of the mainland's domestic laws and have not been endorsed by the relevant Taiwan authoritative agencies after bilateral consultations.

As prohibitively unclear as mainland China's investment environment is, it is hard to believe that it could be improved overnight simply by publicizing a notice of some new rules, Investment Commission officials said.
In addition, they pointed out that related articles pertaining to the property and personal security of Taiwanese business people in mainland China are virtually non-existent.

Commission officials believe that Beijing publicized the new rules at this time because both overall foreign investment and Taiwanese investment on the mainland have continued to diminish over the past year, with overall foreign capital inflows declining some 10 percent over the previous year's levels.

According to Investment Commission tallies, officially-approved Taiwan investment on the mainland was 21.57 percent lower in value and 28.9 percent lower in the number of investment projects in the first 10 months of this year as compared to the same period of the previous year.

The officials said the only way to properly protect the interests of Taiwan businesses on the mainland is for Beijing to put the issue of investment guarantees on the cross-strait dialogue agenda. Only an investment guarantee agreement stated in black and white terms could serve that purpose, they noted.

Meanwhile, Chen Po-chih, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, said Beijing's newly publicized rules for Taiwan investment could at best only offset a small portion of the impact on Taiwan businesses on the mainland after both Taiwan and mainland China are admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Foreseeing that the competitiveness of Taiwan businesses on the mainland could diminish after the two sides enter the WTO, Chen called for would-be Taiwanese investors on the mainland to think twice, particularly about their competitiveness, before making any moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-YEAR CONSCRIPTION TERM 'NOT IMPOSSIBLE': MINISTER

TEXT.P: A group of 43 legislators came up with a draft bill on Monday, calling for amendments to the existing Military Conscription Law to halve the mandatory service period to one year.
Commenting on the amendment bill, Defense Minister Tang Fei said shortening the conscription term is not a "mission impossible," but some prerequisites, particularly budgetary issues, must be met.

Opposition Legislator Chien Hsi-kun, who initiated the amendment bill, said at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's defense and interior affairs committees that since Taiwan has entered a high-tech combat preparation period, the importance of conscripted servicemen in its military build-up plans has declined.

Against this background, Chien said, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) should cut the conscription term to one year from the current two years so that more young men can enter the local job market and help upgrade Taiwan's national competitiveness.

Noting that only career soldiers are capable of operating the country's second-generation weaponry systems and high-tech defense equipment, Chien said mandatory-service personnel can only assume less-important combat preparatory tasks.

"Experiences of foreign countries that implement conscription systems show that it takes only about one year for conscripts to complete basic combat training," Chien said, adding that the current two-year conscription period is too long. "We should shorten the term in order to better use our manpower resources to upgrade our domestic labor participation rate and overall national competitiveness."

Moreover, Chien said he opposes the Cabinet's proposal to install an "alternative" military service system, which he said would give a false impression that the system is formulated for the privileged or for those who do not have a clean bill of health.
Chien said the MND should instead enforce a professional social service system for older conscripts or those who have minor physical problems.
Chien also proposed that the social service term be set at one and a half years because the work is less dangerous.

In response, Minister Tang said the Ministry of National Defense would not rule out the possibility of cutting the mandatory military service period so long as some conditions, particularly budgetary demands, can be met.
Under the MND's current troop-reduction plan, Tang said, the total number of the country's armed forces will be cut to 400,000 from the current 450,000.
In line with this policy, Tang said, the military can gradually reduce the number of conscripted servicemen while increasing the number of voluntary career soldiers.

Noting that Chien's proposal can be implemented when the ratio of career soldiers to overall armed forces roughly equals that of conscripted servicemen, Tang said the military needs a greatly increased budget to recruit additional career soldiers.
Tang said the MND has begun an in-depth study of the feasibility of cutting the mandatory military service period, including related budgetary and funding problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR COUNTRIES EXPECTED TO COME CLOSER TO COUNTER US, WEST

TEXT.P: Russia, mainland China, India and Indonesia are likely to come to some form of an alliance in order to balance the power of the United States and its Western allies, according to a report in the Australian Financial Review on Monday.
The daily quoted political experts as saying that Russian and Chinese leaders have called for a multi-polar world in their efforts to balance the Western hegemony in the post-Cold War era.

Russia, a crippled giant, has moved to improve relations with China, a second-rate power, and India, which does not enjoy the international power and status due to a country of its size and capabilities, according to a recent Stratfor intelligence update for Defense Data Ltd., the daily reported.

Both Russia and China also moved to build bridges to Indonesia, whose President Abdurrahman Wahid is looking to China as a possible source of weapons and spare parts after Jakarta suspended its military ties with Australia and the tougher US ban on military sales to Indonesia.
Wahid said recently that he looked forward to a possible alliance between India, China and Indonesia to help rectify the lopsided power of the West.
Russia and China have established close cooperation on space-related activities, with Moscow pledging to help Beijing conduct its first manned space flight early next year.

The US and its Western allies would likely view an alliance between the four powers with concern because Russia, China, India and Indonesia comprise most of the Eurasian land mass and roughly half the world's population, and they possess significant resources and formidable skills, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped 0.2 cents to close at 31.62 against the greenback on Monday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.
The currency opened at 31.618, and was traded between 31.608 and 31.62. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$195 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT INNER STRUGGLE BIGGEST THREAT TO NATIONAL SECURITY: CHEN

TEXT.P: The inner struggle of the ruling Kuomintang is the biggest threat to national security, said the presidential hopeful of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday.
Chen Shui-bian made the remark at a press conference after meeting with Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan.
Chen slammed Vice President and KMT-nominated presidential candidate Lien Chan's proposal that the Republic of China develop long-range surface-to-surface missiles, describing Lien as "hawkish."
The former Taipei mayor stressed the importance of national security and his determination to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen said he could not imagine that Lien is actually advocating that the ROC develop offensive weapons such as long-range (3,000 km to 5,000 km) surface-to-surface missiles, which could hit targets as far away as Xinjiang, northwestern China.
Chen said the DPP strongly asserts that Taiwan should focus on upgrading its defense capability, rather than on developing offensive weapons.

Chen said purchasing additional weapons is not the only way to safeguard Taiwan's security. He said that in addition to the procurement of weapons, national strategy as well as maintenance of security in national political, economic, social and energy-production fields should also be considered important, especially political security.
He indicated that unrest within the KMT caused by its inner struggle is to blame for national instability.
He again called for the KMT to end verbal attacks against its rival competitors in the 2000 presidential election and present a concrete platform on the ROC's future development.
Chen reiterated that if he wins the presidential election he would like to visit mainland China before the inauguration ceremony.

He also commented on the remark by mainland Chinese Ambassador to the United States Li Zhaoxing while meeting members of a pro-unification group from Taiwan that, as far as he was concerned, with the exception of Chen Shui-bian, any other candidate could be elected Taiwan's new leader in the 2000 presidential election.
Chen responded that no country's diplomat should interfere in any other country's internal affairs.

Li Zhaoxing was quoted by members of the Taiwan delegation as saying that although Chen has proposed a "new middle route," the DPP still insists that the party incorporate "Taiwan independence" into its platform, an ideal that is not acceptable to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE-STRICKEN PEOPLE FRET OVER TAIWAN'S OVERALL QUALITY OF LIFE

TEXT.P: While there's hardly anyone who showed indignation over the devastating 7.3-magnitude earthquake that hit Taiwan Sept. 21, more than half the people in earthquake-stricken areas said they are dissatisfied with the overall quality of life in Taiwan.

According to results of the latest opinion poll conducted by Academia Sinica's Institute of Social Sciences, there was hardly anyone in the earthquake-stricken areas of central Taiwan who showed indignation over the earthquake, which killed over 2,400 people, injured some 8,000 and left more than 100,000 others temporarily homeless.

Most of them, however, sustained mental and psychological wounds of various degrees and scopes in the wake of the deadly jolt. Moreover, according to the poll, about 9 percent of central Taiwan residents who had not incurred any property damage or losses also sustained certain degrees of mental injury, said Chu Hai-yuan, a researcher with the institute.

The poll found that 52 percent of respondents in earthquake-stricken areas said they are dissatisfied with Taiwan's overall quality of life, while 77 percent said they are angry about the island's public order.

While 50 percent of them considered the post-quake rescue and relief work carried out by the Executive Yuan and relevant county and city governments as "satisfactory," 45 percent of them considered the performances of lower-level public offices as "OK," the poll found.

About 36 percent of respondents said their economic situation has worsened and quality of life has been aggravated since the earthquake, as some 27 percent painted gloomy prospects of their future lives.

Compared with 97 percent of couples who said they had a close and harmonic relationship before the earthquake, nearly 20 percent said their husband-wife relations and relationships with other relatives became even closer and more cordial than before the quake, according to Hsiao Hsin-huang, another Academia Sinica researcher who cosponsored the poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES UP, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rebounded on Monday from a weeklong decline, ending with solid 1.9-percent gains as strong buying emerged in telecommunications and internet-related shares.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 149.84 points higher at 7,883.61, with turnover swelling to NT$120.09 billion (US$3.8 billion) and 2.3 billion shares changing handed amid active trading.
The surge also reflected the US NASDAQ's Friday gains and mainland Chinese easing of its restrictions on Taiwan investors.

Beijing unveiled looser regulations for Taiwan investment in the mainland, including allowing Taiwanese firms to set up joint venture or solely invested firms on the mainland and to remit their earnings outside mainland China, a move which sparked active buying in the so-called China-concept shares, whose firms have significant investments in the mainland.
Stocks in companies with investment in telecommunications and internet businesses were targeted by institutional investors as the two industries are experiencing a global boom.
All eight major stock categories enjoyed gains with the electronics sector posting the largest gains of 2.9 percent, followed by cement issues, which rose 2.8 percent.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 319 to 177, with 65 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market moved up 5.85 points to close at 189.69 on a turnover of NT$12.30 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December, January and next March posted gains, while those for next June and September had no transactions recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 150 points to close at 7,950 with 1,247 contract transactions. Those for January rose 156 points to finish at 7,980 with 1,040 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March advanced 195 points to close at 8,046 with three contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,800 points for December, 7,824 points for January, 7,851 points for next March, 7,882 points for next June, and 7,904 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, reported mixed results and gains.
December TE futures rose 11.45 points to close at 401.95 with 636 contract transactions, while January TE futures moved up 13.5 points to finish at 404 with 381 contract transactions.
Next March TE futures dipped 12.5 points to close at 388 with one contract transaction, and the rest had no transaction records.
December TF futures climbed 5.4 points to close at 956.4 with 80 contract transactions, and January TF futures rose 6.8 points to 974.8 with 52 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REITERATES 'SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' STANCE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui reiterated on Monday that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
Lee made the statement while meeting with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush, who is currently on a nine-day visit here.

Lee told the top US liaison officer with Taiwan that the ROC is willing to negotiate or handle any issue related to mainland China or adjust its strategy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait under the premise of "special state-to-state relationship."

Lee said for the first time in an interview with a German radio station on July 9 this year that cross-strait ties should be defined as a "special state-to-state relationship." His definition drew furious response from Beijing which has consistently downgraded the ROC as a local-level government and refused to treat it on an equal footing.

Noting that the ROC was established in 1912, Lee said it's an undeniable historical and legal fact that the ROC is an independent sovereign state. "The ROC was founded long before the People's Republic of China came into being in 1949."
Lee further stressed that the ROC, while recognizing the PRC's jurisdiction over the Chinese mainland, effectively controls the Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu areas.

Therefore, Lee told Bush that the "special state-to-state relationship" definition just affirms a cold reality, adding the ROC can never accept Beijing's claim that the PRC represents the central government while the ROC is only a local-level government.

The president went on to say that the ROC has formed a National Unification Council, with promoting China's reunification under freedom and democracy as its ultimate goal. "Nevertheless, before this goal is realized, the ROC's existence and development should not be denied and ignored," Lee added.

In the face of imminent accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Lee said that so long as Beijing shows enough goodwill toward Taiwan and make positive response to Taiwan's call for resumption of dialogue, the ROC is more than willing to review its current cross-strait trade policy in order to meet the world trade regulatory body's requirements and spirit.
Bush arrived in Taiwan last Tuesday to inspect the operations of the AIT Taipei office, also the de facto US embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Also present at the Lee-Bush meeting were ROC Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen; John Chang, secretary-general to the President; and AIT Taipei Office Director-General Raymond Burghardt.
Chen said the meeting proceeded in an amicable atmosphere and lasted longer than originally scheduled.
Asked whether Bush had brought any US message to President Lee, Chen said he is not in a position to answer the question.

This is Bush's third visit to Taiwan this year. In addition to inspecting AIT operations, Bush will also meet with senior ROC officials and the three main contestants for the ROC's presidential election scheduled for March 18, 2000. He will give a press conference on Wednesday to brief media on the results of his current visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANK SETTING UP MORE FOOTHOLDS

TEXT.P: The United States has approved an application by a subsidiary of Taiwan's First Commercial Bank (FCB) to set up a branch in Silicon Valley, California, said FCB officials on Monday.

The officials said the new branch of FCB Taiwan California Bank, which was set up in May 1997 in Alhambra, California, will be FCB's 18th branch worldwide, and it is expected to be operational by April next year.

The officials noted that the bank, which celebrated its 100th anniversary on Nov. 26, will continue to establish footholds in Taiwan and overseas where Chinese converge, hoping to provide its customers with better financial service.
They said that they are now working on setting up a branch in San Salvador and a representative office in Jakarta, hoping that FCB will have most overseas footholds among local banks.
The United States and Hong Kong are the favorite places among local banks to set up overseas footholds.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PARLIAMENTARY LEADER ARRIVES IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng arrived in Panama Sunday, where he will attend the Central American Parliament Forum scheduled to open on Wednesday.
During his stay, Wang will also take part in a ceremony to mark the official reversion of the United States' administration over the Panama Canal to Panamanian authorities.

Another purpose of the visit is to seek observer status for the Republic of China at the forum, Wang said at the airport, noting that the Legislative Yuan on Nov. 30 formally approved of the ROC application to participate in the Central American group.
He believes Republic of China stands a chance of joining the forum as an observer this year because all Central American forum members have expressed their welcome for ROC attendance, Wang said.
He added that ROC participation in the forum could further enhance bilateral and multilateral relations between the Republic of China and Central American countries.

Wang is accompanied by Legislators Shen Fu-hsiung of the Democratic Progressive Party, Chiang Chi-wen of the Kuomintang, Lee Chu-feng of the New Party and independent Legislator Chen Chin-ting on the weeklong visit.
They are scheduled to return to Taiwan on Dec. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE DRUMS UP SUPPORT IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: The vice presidential candidate of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday continued to seek support in Kinmen, the frontline island of the Republic of China opposite mainland China's Fujian Province.

Annette Lu, who escorted the torch of the national athletic games to Kinmen on Sunday and presented it to Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai, went to Kincheng, the most populated town on the island, to drum up support for her party in the 2000 presidential election.
Following stumping activities at Tungmen marketplace on Sunday, Lu again visited the marketplace early on Monday to appeal for support from stall keepers and shoppers.

Lu, who is the incumbent Taoyuan County magistrate, noted that Taoyuan and Kinmen counties have established sisterhood ties, and vowed that if she is elected as vice president to DPP presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian, Chen will not withdraw the armed forces personnel stationed on Kinmen and Matsu, another ROC frontline island opposite Fujian Province.
She also promised to open "three direct links" with mainland China -- transport, trade and postal services -- as well as strengthen Kinmen's development.

Kinmen County Magistrate Chen later returned the national athletic games torch to Lu so that it could continue its journey around the nation. The national athletic games are scheduled to be held from Dec. 25-31.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTREPRENEUR SEES `BOON' IN NEW BEIJING RULES FOR TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: New rules unveiled by Beijing governing Taiwan investment in mainland China will be a boon for Taiwan businessmen, a Taiwan entrepreneur said on Monday.

Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), said that the new rules are the result of years of effort by Taiwan businessmen, and that he believed all Taiwan businessmen will be glad to see their implementation.

Kao, who is also the chairman of Taiwan's President Group, is well-qualified to speak on the issue, as his group has invested in the mainland since 1992, but has only this year seen profits from its mainland foodstuff interests.

On whether President will continue to expand its investment in the mainland, Kao said that the Republic of China government-imposed investment ceiling on a Taiwan company's investment on the mainland has nearly been reached, and the group will need to conduct an overall assessment before investing further.

Kao noted that the new rules provide Taiwan businessmen with basic legal protection until the two sides of the Taiwan Strait join the World Trade Organization, which he described as "a boon" for Taiwan businessmen.
The rules unveiled by Beijing on Sunday came after Taiwan businessmen complained to Beijing that 1994 regulations governing Taiwan investment in the mainland are hollow and insubstantial.

The new rules, aimed at wooing further Taiwan investment, provide "national" treatment for Taiwan businessmen, giving them a level playing field in areas such as purchasing equipment and services, and obtaining credit and loans. Taiwan businessmen also get preferential treatment with regard to investment and tax.
However, there is still a dearth of substantial protection on the property and personal security of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE STUDENTS IN CHONGQING TO STAGE A PUBLIC PROTEST

TEXT.P: Thousands of Chinese students from two universities in Chongqing city in southwestern Sichuan province may stage a public protest in the city on Dec. 20, the day when Macau reverts to mainland China, a human rights group said here Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the students will march in a parade in protest against a government plan to merge Southwestern Political Science and Law University (SPSLU) and Chongqing University. The plan will be announced one day before the parade.

A big-character poster calling upon students to join in the protest appeared on the campus of SPSLU Sunday evening, but it was removed by university authorities soon afterwards, the information center said.

Students of Chongqing Architecture University, which will also be merged with Chongqing University under the government plan, may join the parade. The students are worried that the merge may jeopardize their job opportunities in the future, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE DRUGS SMUGGLED FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) announced on Monday that it has formed a special task force to investigate a large illegal drug smuggling case which police said might be masterminded by Taiwan ringleaders hiding in mainland China.
Police seized about 30 kilograms of high-grade heroin in Yungkang township in southern Taiwan's Tainan County on Sunday and arrested four suspects.

The 79 heroin bricks, with an estimated street value of NT$300 million (about US$9.5 million), were discovered in a Yungkang house rented by Wang Shui-lung, 49, who allegedly smuggled the contraband drugs from mainland China.

Police first spotted Wang in a rubber boat off the coast of the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung at 4 a.m. on Sunday. The CIB then deployed a large number of policemen in the vicinity of Wang's house.
Wang and his three accomplices, including an illegal mainland Chinese immigrant, were arrested as they were taking four travel bags containing the heroin into the house.
Wang's three accomplices were identified as his younger brother Wang Shui-sung, Chang Shih-ming and Lin Yueh-chi, an illegal mainland immigrant.
Both Wang and Chang have long criminal records, and Wang was also a key suspect in a 1983 Pingtung firearms smuggling case.
Initial investigations show that in recent years, Wang has used false or doctored passports to travel across the Taiwan Strait in order to smuggle drugs and firearms from mainland China to Taiwan.

Police said Wang's younger brother also traveled to the mainland in late November to assist Wang in handling the latest haul, and returned to Taiwan on Dec. 2. He had been kept under intensive surveillance since that time.

Sources close to the investigative team said a large portion of the heroin seized on Sunday belonged to a southern Taiwan-based drug dealer who allegedly had given Wang NT$50 million to purchase the drugs. Sources further said the dealer had close ties with Chan Lung-lan, a notorious local drug and firearms smuggler who is believed to be hiding on the mainland.

As the size of the haul was very large, police said they believe that in addition to the assistance of mainland-based drug traffickers, Wang could also have other accomplices in Taiwan, including downstream distributors, and vowed to bring all the suspects to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRONOLOGY OF THE 20TH CENTURY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: 1911: A revolt against China's Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupted on Oct. 10 in Wuchang and was followed by revolution throughout China. The Republic of China was founded on Jan. 1, 1912 with Dr. Sun Yat-sen as its first provisional president.

1912: The British luxury liner the "Titanic" sank after hitting an iceberg on April 14 during her maiden voyage from Southampton to New York. Over 1,500 people were drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.

1913: The Rockefeller Foundation, the largest philanthropic organization in the history of the world, was established by John Davison Rockefeller. It sponsored worldwide programs to fight hunger, improve health, and deal with the problems of overpopulation, environmental degradation, and international security.
1914: World War I broke out.
1915: Poison gas was used for the first time by German troops on a battlefield in Belgium.

1916: John Dewey, American philosopher and educator, published his work "Democracy and Education." He helped lead a philosophical movement called pragmatism and rejected traditional methods of teaching by rote in favor of a broad-based system of practical experience.
1917: The Russian masses overthrew the provisional government and formed a new (Soviet) government led by Nikolai Lenin.
1918: World War I, which began in 1914, was ended with the Triple Entente (Russia, France, and Britain) victory over the Triple Alliance, formed in 1882 by Austria-Hungary, Germany, and Italy.
1919: The Treaty of Versailles was signed in the Palace of Versailles near Paris on June 28.

1920: The League of Nations, an international association of countries created to maintain peace among the nations of the world, was established in January with its headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMES US$ 7.9 MILLION-WORTH OF MEDICINE PER DAY

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan consume an average total of NT$250 million (US$7.9 million)-worth of pharmaceuticals every day, the National Health Insurance Bureau said on Monday.
According to bureau tallies, spending on pharmaceuticals in the first 10 months of this year reached NT$76.9 billion, nearly double the level recorded four years ago.
The bureau said when the National Health Insurance Program was inaugurated in 1995, the annual pharmaceutical bill was slightly more than NT$40 billion.
The amount increased to NT$54 billion the following year, surged to NT$60 billion in 1997, and exceeded NT$70 billion in 1998, according to official statistics.

Bureau officials jokingly described the large increase in pharmaceutical consumption as another Taiwan "miracle," but pointed out on a more serious note that some local people seem to have developed an "addiction" to taking home large amounts of medicines, even when they do not have any serious illness.
Worse yet, the officials went on, some others have got into the habit of taking medicines without following doctors' instructions on dosage.

A comparative study conducted by the Cabinet-level Department of Health a few years ago found that local people take an average of 4.1 tablets at a time, more than double the average of between 1.7 and two tablets recorded in the United States and most European countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CRITICIZES CHEN SHUI-BIAN'S CONTRADICTION ON CROSS STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of the ruling Kuomintang on Monday criticized opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian's mainland China policy as a coin with two contradictory sides.

During a meeting with American Institute on Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush, Chang Jung-kung, director of the Mainland Research Department of the KMT Central Committee, said that on one side, Chen seeks "a battle" with mainland China over Taiwan's independent stance, while on the other, he seeks peace between Taiwan and the mainland.

Chang also pointed out that Chen on Monday criticized Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the KMT, for what he called a "hawkish" proposal to develop long-range surface-to-surface missiles.
Chang claimed that in fact, the KMT's mainland China policy provides firm security for Taiwan.

Chang went on to say that Chen shouted "long live Taiwan independence!" when he met with pro-independence "hawks" ten days ago, but that he told Bush on Monday that he will seek peaceful cross-strait ties if elected.

The pro-independence "hawks" gave very high marks to Chen's "third way" or "middle-of-the-road" policy because of Chen's firm insistence that Taiwan independence is the highest guiding principle for the DPP's mainland China policy, Chang said.
He claimed that Chen has no new middle-of-the-road line, describing Chen's stance as old pro-independence slogans mixed with some new ones.

If Chen is a "qualified politician with character," he should call on the people to prepare for "a battle for independence," according to Chang, who added that to do otherwise by seeking peace with the mainland at the same time as independence for Taiwan is no more than wishful thinking.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI LIFTS BAN ON VISITS TO MAINLAND CHINA BY POLICE OFFICERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Monday announced that regulations which prohibit local policemen from visiting relatives or attending relatives' funerals in mainland China have been lifted.

However, law-enforcement personnel who serve in executive positions or those who are in special task forces are not included under the terms of the newly relaxed restrictions, according to Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen.

Police officers wishing to travel to the mainland will have their applications screened by a joint examination commission formed by the MOI, the Bureau of National Security, the Ministry of Justice, and the Mainland Affairs Council, he added.
The MOI has assessed that more than 75,000 policemen around the island will benefit from the new policy, the minister noted.

The Republic of China government first opened the door for people in "non-sensitive" positions residing in the Taiwan area to visit mainland China in 1987, a move which broke a long-term state of complete estrangement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CONFERENCE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The annual National Conference on Aboriginal Affairs opened on Monday at the Chientan Overseas Youth Activity Center in Taipei, attended by representatives from 60 aboriginal townships throughout the island.

The two-day conference is designed to lay the basis for formulating government policy on the development of aboriginal tribes in the 21st century through discussions on political development, education, culture, and social welfare, as well as economy and land use.
Vice President Lien Chan attended the opening ceremony to listen to the opinions and suggestions of the representatives, and he pledged to seek more welfare for Taiwan's aborigines.

Most participants asked the government to legislate more protection of the interests of aborigines, to establish an information system for aboriginal regions, to promote international exchanges, and to improve the ethnic dignity of the island's original inhabitants.

Regarding improvement of the social and economic status of the aborigines, the participants shared the view that emphasis should be placed on the educational and cultural development of the aboriginal tribes.

They also pointed out the necessity of bringing down the aboriginal jobless rate that registered as high as 7.55 percent this year, compared with just 2.84 percent for the whole of the Taiwan population.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER STRESSES PROMOTION OF TIES WITH PRC ON EQUAL FOOTING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday that Taipei's policy of promoting exchanges with mainland China on an equal and mutually beneficial footing remains unchanged.
He made the remarks while receiving Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), who came to Taipei last Wednesday to inspect AIT operations in Taiwan.

Siew pointed out that Taiwan is adopting an "open" and "friendly" attitude to promote cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and added that Vice President Lien Chan has even recently expressed his wish to visit the mainland if he wins the presidential election next March.
In contrast, he said, Beijing has been doing whatever it can to isolate Taiwan in the international community and prevent Taiwan from joining international organizations.

Regarding World Trade Organization membership for Taiwan and mainland China, Bush said that negotiations between the United States and mainland China have progressed well, and that he expects both Taiwan and the mainland will enter the world trade regulatory body next year.
The AIT chief also told Siew that the United States will continue to carefully monitor the various campaigns for Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.
Earlier on Monday, Bush also held separate talks with President Lee Teng-hui and Democratic Progressive Party presidential nominee Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S RULES UNLIKELY TO SPARK NEW WAVE OF TAIWAN INVESTMENT: MAC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday that new rules unveiled by Beijing governing Taiwan investment in mainland China are unlikely to spark another wave of Taiwan investment in the mainland.
The MAC said that although the new rules address some existing concerns of Taiwan businessmen, they have not met their basic interests and needs.

It noted that Beijing, in order to lure Taiwan investment to the mainland, first presented regulations in 1988 to encourage Taiwan investment in the mainland, followed by promulgation in 1994 of regulations governing protection of Taiwan investments.

The MAC said the new rules unveiled on Sunday are similar to the 1994 regulations, and added that their unveiling at this time is on one hand part of a "united front" strategy, and on the other an attempt to reverse the slowdown of Taiwan investment in the mainland.

According to Investment Commission tallies, officially approved Taiwan investments on the mainland were 21.57 percent lower in value and 28.9 percent lower in the number of projects in the first 10 months of his year compared to the same period of the previous year.

The MAC noted that the economic situation in the mainland is unstable, and that Beijing has continued to display a two-handed strategy toward Taiwan. It urged Taiwan businessmen to carefully assess investment risks in the mainland before channeling their money there.

The council said Taiwan businesses should base themselves firmly in Taiwan, before investing in the mainland from a position of strength, adding that only in this way can a win-win situation be created for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
It further pointed out that the new rules are internal laws of the mainland, and do not respect the fact of separate rule on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The MAC urged the mainland authorities to see the importance of cross-strait dialogue in protecting the rights of Taiwan investors. It also urged an early resumption of cross-strait dialogue to discuss issues of greatest concern to Taiwan businessmen, including mediation and arbitration of cross-strait trade disputes and the protection of intellectual property rights.

Commenting on Beijing's new rules, an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that the rules, which were retroactive to Dec. 5, are bound to encourage Taiwan and foreign investors in the mainland in the short term, but warned that in the long term, Taiwan businessmen should take heed of investment risks in the mainland, as the mainland is not under the rule of law, and the new rules are only administrative orders.

Thomas Yeh, CEPD secretary-general, said that Taiwan and foreign investors have helped create rich export foreign exchange reserves for the mainland. To speed up its trade development, however, the mainland has to rely on more investment from Taiwan and foreign investors to deal with the increasingly fierce competition.

But Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said that the new rules will not spark new investment fever among Taiwan businessmen, saying that if the mainland authorities will not even allow Taiwan banks to set up representative offices in the mainland, it will be difficult for them to lure Taiwan businessmen.

The semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) also said that the new rules unveiled by Beijing are only a promulgation of the principles, and that they give substantial leeway to the mainland agencies who actually implement the rules.
Ricky Kao, CETRA secretary-general, said that Taiwan businessmen still have to be on guard when planning to invest in the mainland.
He added that it remains to be seen whether there will be further regulations to protect Taiwan businessmen once the two sides of the Taiwan Strait enter the World Trade Organization.

Beijing's new rules provide national treatment for Taiwan businessmen, giving them the same treatment as mainlanders in areas such as purchasing equipment and services and obtaining credit and loans. Taiwan businessmen also get preferential treatment with regard to tax and investment. Taiwan businessmen coming from third places are also afforded the same protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTIVITY IN TAIWAN'S MANUFACTURING SECTOR GROWS 7.3 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Productivity in Taiwan's manufacturing sector during the first three quarters of 1999 grew 7.3 percent year-on-year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Monday.
The annual growth rate was higher than Singapore's 6.9 percent and Japan's 1.3 percent, according to a DGBAS-issued report on Taiwan's current economic situation.

Average monthly pay for Taiwan's manufacturing sector employees between January and September this year was NT$38,286 (US$1,210), up 2.4 percent from the same period of last year, in comparison with South Korea's 10.2 percent, Singapore's 1.4 percent, and Japan's negative 2.1 percent, said an official with the Cabinet-level agency.

Affected by the slow growth in monthly pay and stabilized prices of international raw materials, Taiwan's wholesale prices dropped 5.1 percent in the nine-month period, compared with Japan's negative 3.7 percent, South Korea's negative 2.3 percent, and Singapore's 0.4 percent, the official noted.

As for interest rates, the report showed that Japan's basic rate on loans stood at 1.4 percent, the lowest among the four countries listed in the survey, followed by Singapore's 5.4 percent, Taiwan's 7.2 percent and South Korea's 8.8 percent.

Due to sustained inflow of foreign capital and growing expansion of Taiwan's trade surplus, the island's currency has recently recorded a gradual appreciation against the US dollar, according to the report.

However, the official said appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar against the greenback has been much lower than that of Japan's and South Korea's currencies. As of late November, the local unit had appreciated by 1.7 percent against the US dollar, while the yen and the won rose by 12.6 percent and 3.9 percent against the greenback, respectively, and the Singapore dollar depreciated by 1.5 percent during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO HEED BEIJING'S NEW RULES GOVERNING TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan entrepreneur on Monday urged the Republic of China government to deal with Beijing's new rules governing Taiwan investment in the mainland squarely to avoid more Taiwan manufacturers being lured to the mainland.

Tai Sheng-tung, chairman of the Association of Small- and Medium-sized Enterprises, said Taiwan's industrial base will be greatly affected by Beijing's unveiling of rules that give national treatment to Taiwan businessmen in areas such as purchasing equipment and service, and obtaining credit and loans.
Taiwan businessmen also get preferential treatment with regard to investment and tax, according to the new rules.
Tai said that if the government fails to address the situation squarely, Taiwan capital, manufacturers and talent will be gradually siphoned off to the mainland market.

He cited as an example the fact that Taiwan businessmen have invested a total of US$50 billion in the mainland over the past three decades, and that many of Taiwan's biggest entrepreneurs have established plants there.

Not only have traditional local industries such as shoe and umbrella manufacturers invested in the mainland, high-tech businesses such as the electronics and computer sectors have also ploughed money into the mainland.

Tai suggested that the government should open Taiwan to imports of mainland raw materials such as cotton, and review present trade policies to stop the mainland from using seemingly attractive measures to undermine Taiwan's industrial base and affect its long-term development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 14, or the seventh day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: George Washington, the first president of the United States, dies at the age of 67.
1819: Alabama becomes the 22nd state of the United States.
1895: George VI, English monarch, is born. He succeeded to the throne when his brother, Edward VIII, abdicated to marry the twice-divorced Mrs. Wallis Simpson.
1906: Germany's first submarine, the U1, is launched in the military port of Kiel in northern Germany.
1907: In St. Petersburg, 38 Russian soldiers are sentenced to life imprisonment for surrendering to the Japanese at Port Arthur.
1910: Scottish-born US steel industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie establishes the Carnegie Peace Foundation.
1911: Roald Amundsen, a Norwegian explorer, becomes the first person to reach the South Pole.
1916: The people of Denmark vote to sell the Danish West Indies to the United States for US$25 million.
1918: Six million British women cast their votes for the first time in general elections in Britain.
1927: Chinese government forces put down an attempted communist coup in Canton.
1927: The Republic of China breaks off relations with the Soviet Union.
1937: Japan sets up a puppet Chinese government in Peiping (Beijing).
1939: The Soviet Union is expelled from the League of Nations for invading Finland.
1941: During World War II, the US Marines make a stand in the battle for Wake Island in the Pacific.
1959: Archbishop Makarios is elected the first president of Cyprus.
1967: Scientists at Stanford University isolate nuclear DNA from a virus in a test tube.
1972: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: After three days of exploration on the lunar surface, US Apollo 17 astronauts blast off from the moon.
1975: Nam Duck Woo, deputy prime minister of South Korea, arrives in Taipei to take part in the 10th Sino-Korean Economic Cooperation Conference.
1975: Agustin Martines Varela, El Salvador interior minister, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: A two-day pre-conference executive committee meeting for the 23rd Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a six-member delegation from Japan led by Yoshiko Nakano, president of the Organization for Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement International.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives some 20 delegates to the pre-conference executive committee meeting for the 23rd conference of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League.
1978: The ROC armed forces manufacture missile-carrying vessels capable of traveling speeds up to 40 knots.
1981: Israel annexes the Golan Heights, which was captured from Syria in 1967.
1988: Eight million workers in Spain go on strike to protest government economic policies.
1990: Ten Vietnamese boat people set fire to themselves in Hong Kong to protest a screening policy that could prevent them from settling in the West.
1990: Chang Chun, senior adviser to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 102.
1991: Enrich Honecker, former East German leader, is offered asylum in North Korea.
1992: The United States allows its companies to sign contracts with Vietnam, easing a 17-year trade embargo.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The purpose of the magnanimous is to be found in procuring benefits for the world and eliminating its calamities."

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE ROC MIRAGE FIGHTER LOSES CONTACT

TEXT.P: An ROC Air Force Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter lost contact with the military flight control tower while on a routine training flight off the eastern coast of Taiwan on Tuesday, military sources said.

The Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) said the single-seater Mirage No. 2036 took off from the Hsinchu air base and disappeared from the military radar at around 11 a.m. when it was flying off the coast of Hualien in eastern Taiwan.
AFGH officials said the fighter was flown by Air Force pilot Chiang Chin-liang.
Meanwhile, reports from the northeastern fishing port of Suao said a Mirage plane was spotted off the Suao coast. The military has sent rescue teams to search for the plane and its pilot.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIRAGE FIGHTER MAY CRASH OFF NORTHEASTERN TAIWAN COAST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) and the Air Force General Headquarters confirmed Tuesday noon that an ROC air Force Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter disappeared from the military radar screen earlier in the day while on a routine training flight.

The French-made, single-seater fighter took off from the Hsinchu air base in northern Taiwan and was flying off the coast of Suao, a fishing port in the northeastern county of Ilan, when it disappeared from the radar screen, MND sources said.
The fighter jet No. 2036 was flown by Air Force pilot Chiang Chin-liang, a graduate of the Chinese Air Force Academy.

A report from the Ilan combat control center said the Mirage might have crashed into waters 30 nautical miles east of Loutung, Ilan County. The military and marine police have sent personnel and helicopters to search for the wreckage of the plane and its pilot.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP IN PANAMA FOR TALKS ON LAND BRIDGE

TEXT.P: A business group from Taiwan is currently in Panama for talks on a proposed land bridge near the Panama Canal linking the two oceans, according to a report in The Journal of Commerce today.

A group from the Kuomintang Business Management Committee has been in Panama City since last week to investigate the feasibility of joining the land bridge project. Included in the delegation are representatives from newly privatized Ret-Ser Engineering Agency and other Taiwan-based engineering firms.

Panamanian officials welcomed the Taiwanese group's interest in the land bridge project, which is open to bidding by any qualified engineering company, said the report. It added that talks have been held with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso, Public Engineering Minister Meises Castillo de Leon and officials from the Panama Canal Authority.

A Taiwanese presence would counterbalance that of Hutchison Port Holdings Ltd., feared by some as a stalking horse from mainland China because of its chairman Li Ka-Shing's close ties with Beijing, said the report.
Taiwan's ambassador in Panama, Lan Chih-min, recently donated US$1.4 million to help finance a river-diversion project in Los Santos province in central Panama, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REP. BROWN REQUESTS CLARIFICATION OF US CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: US Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) on Monday wrote to Secretary of State Madeleine Albright again seeking clarification on the Clinton administration's statements concerning the US "one China" policy, which he described as a "most important issue."

Brown said in the letter that he has not received a response to his Oct. 25 letter that sought similar clarification, adding that "this is particularly distressing in light of President Clinton's Dec. 8 statement that `our policy on China is crystal clear. We believe there is one China.'"
Brown pointed out that according to the 1972 Shanghai Communique, the United States simply "acknowledges" Communist China's view that there is only one China and that Taiwan is a part of that China.

But Brown stressed that "nowhere in that document are we bound to agree with the PRC's view that Taiwan is a part of China. Unfortunately, it appears the (Clinton) administration has assumed the People's Republic's view of `one China' as its own."

Earlier this year, Brown sponsored a House resolution that supports Taiwan's entry into the World Health Organization. The bill, signed into law by the president last week, requires Albright to report to Congress by Jan. 1, detailing the administration's efforts to actively support Taiwan's "appropriate and meaningful participation in the WHO and other international organizations."

DOC.HEADLINE: IF ELECTED, BUCHANAN WOULD PUSH BEIJING AGENTS OUT OF PANAMA

TEXT.P: Conservative American commentator Pat Buchanan said Monday that if he were US president, his first order of Western hemispheric business would be "to effect the peaceful expulsion of any and all agents of Beijing from Panama, and to reestablish a US presence in that country."

Buchanan, who recently bolted the Republican Party to seek nomination from the Reform Party for the year 2000 US presidential election, pointed out in a statement that a generation ago, along with Ronald Reagan, he opposed President Jimmy Carter's surrender of the Panama Canal.
"We insisted that the Canal was US property, its retention vital to US security, and its transfer an unacceptable risk," he said.

"History proved us right. To secure the Canal from a potential threat, a decade ago, President Bush invaded (Panama). Tuesday's transfer of all US bases in the former Canal Zone, as well as the Big Ditch itself, now leaves this strategic asset in different, and perhaps even hostile, hands," said the presidential hopeful.

"The US bases from which we monitored drug flights out of Colombia are gone. Critical US Army training facilities are gone. Now, the Canal, crucial to victory in World War II and our security and prosperity throughout this century, is gone. Ports at both ends of the Canal will now be controlled by a company that answers to the beck and call of an increasingly belligerent Beijing," continued Buchanan.

The renowned conservative commentator noted that "it is a mockery of the Monroe Doctrine for America to stand idly by as Communist Chinese reach for this vital artery of the US Navy and our $2 trillion world trade."

"Were Theodore Roosevelt alive today, to watch a successor bomb Serbia for 78 days because he said Kosovo was vital to us, as he giddily surrendered the Panama Canal to agents of a dictatorial China, the old Rough Rider would surely have concluded that his country had fallen into the hands of thundering incompetents. And he would be right," he pointed out.

Buchanan said that "only in some strange New World Order of President Clinton's imaginings can a US presence in Bosnia call for a four-year $12 billion US commitment, while the Panama Canal is let go, when a tiny investment of a few millions of dollars could have secured it."
Therefore, he added, his first order of Western hemispheric business as president would be to send Communist China packing from Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO TIGHTEN CONTROLS ON ON-LINE GAMBLING

TEXT.P: Australia is set to tighten controls or even ban on-line gambling because it has been found to be a bigger threat to the social fabric than earlier expected, according to federal cabinet talks on the issue.

Australia is home to roughly 20 percent of the world's gaming machines and some 330,000 Australians are problem gamblers, who pose a bigger threat to the community than had previously been believed, according to the talks.

At a discussion meeting on Monday, Queensland Treasurer David Hamill recommended that the number of poker machines be capped, grants to community and addict-support groups be increased, and that the risks of losing money on poker machines should be advertised to warn people against gambling.
Prime Minister John Howard will ask his minister to chair a federal-state ministerial committee with the task of creating tougher measures to regulate the gambling industry across Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA HANDS MEET IN TAIPEI TO REVIEW TAIWAN'S DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: A symposium on Taiwan's development in the 20th century opened in Taipei on Tuesday, with the participation of 13 world-renowned scholars on China affairs.

The two-day seminar is being co-sponsored by the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Government Information Office (GIO) as well as the China Quarterly, a flagship publication of the London University's School of Oriental and African Studies.

The British quarterly broached the idea of holding the seminar in view of Taiwan's increasingly important role in Taiwan Strait-related affairs following the reversion of Hong Kong and Macau to mainland Chinese rule.
After more than one yearof preparations, the authoritative quarterly decided to convene the seminar in Taipei in cooperation with the ROC's GIO and Foreign Ministry.
Thirteen noted scholars on China affairs from Britain, the United States, Japan, Hong Kong and the ROC were invited to present papers at the seminar.
Premier Vincent Siew issued a written message wishing the academic meeting a great success.

Siew said the seminar is of great significance as it brings together more than 10 outstanding academics at this historical juncture to review memorable events and changes in Taiwan over the past century.

The premier further said the people of Taiwan take pride in transforming the island from an agricultural backwater into an industrialized, democratic economic powerhouse in a relatively short period of time.

Addressing the opening ceremony, GIO Director-General Chao Yi said the ROC government and people attach great importance to the seminar which provides a forum for famous China experts to analyze Taiwan's developments in the 20th century from different angles and dimensions.
"We'll refer to all the opinions and suggestions made during the seminar in formulating our future policies," Chao said.

Major topics to be discussed at the seminar will include the ROC's political development, economic achievements, social reforms, Taiwan's relations with mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau, its interaction with the United States, Japan and other East Asian countries, as well as Taiwan's cultural and legal developments and geological changes.
In addition, the participants will also analyze major challenges Taiwan may face in the future.

Among the participants are Richard Louis Edmonds, editor-in-chief of the China Quarterly; Prof. Christopher Howe of the School of Oriental and African Studies; Prof. Michael Leifer of the London School of Economics and Political Science; Prof. Lynn T. White of Princeton University; Prof. Yoshihide Soeya of Japan's Keio University; and Prof. Angelina Chun-chu Yee of the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology.
