The currency opened at 31.621 and was traded between 31.62 and 31.65. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$272.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE FORMS TASK FORCE TO HANDLE MIRAGE MISHAP

TEXT.P: The Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) said on Tuesday it has formed a special task force to handle the latest flight mishap involving a French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter.

The single-seater Mirage, one of the 60 high-tech warplanes that Taiwan has purchased from France, went missing during an interception exercise off Taiwan's eastern coast near Hualien, AFGH officials said.

"The fighter, operated by Major Chiang Chin-liang, lost contact with the military flight controllers at around 10:53 a.m." an AFGH official said, adding that both the Air Force and the Navy have sent helicopters and warships to search for signs of the plane and its lone pilot.

According to AFGH sources, the Mirage fighter No. 2036 took off from the Hsinchu air base in northern Taiwan at 10 a.m. and flew to the eastern city of Hualien for interception exercise. The plane, however, lost contact with the flight controllers during its second interception drill.
Major Chiang, 31, was a graduate of the Chinese Air Force Academy. The father of two young sons had a flight record of 1,181 hours. The missing Mirage's flight record was 275 hours.

This was the second mishap involving a Mirage fighter in as many months. On Oct. 15, a twin-seater Mirage crashed into the Taiwan Strait after a bird was sucked into its engine. Two pilots aboard the plane parachuted to safety and were rescued.
Air Force authorities said it will carefully probe the cause of the latest Mirage mishap. If necessary, the AFGH said it may ground all Mirage fighters for comprehensive security checks.

Since March 1998, Taiwan has lost four of its 150 US-made F-16 fighters. It is demanding compensation from Pratt & Whitney, the US maker of the engines that power its F-16s, alleging that an Aug. 15 crash was due to an engine malfunction.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIA ECONOMIC CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 27th East Asia Economic Conference opened here on Tuesday with more than 250 representatives from Japan and the Republic of China participating.
Sino-Japanese Economic & Trade Foundation Chairman Ku Chen-fu and his Japanese counterpart Akio Kosai headed delegations from the two nations.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, remarking on the ceremony, said that though Taiwan's semiconductor industry was affected by the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, the island's high-tech industry has displayed resilience, rebounding quickly.
Wang predicted that Taiwan's economic growth this year could reach its target of 5.5 percent, ranking it the sixth worldwide in economic growth. Next year's growth could reach up to 6 percent.

Saying that Taiwan and Japan are geographically close and that each nation's economic development could complement the other's, Wang added that both countries excel in their own specific fields, creating ample trade opportunities for bilateral cooperation.
He expressed the hope that Japan could increase its investment in Taiwan's high-tech industry and that e-commerce could create more trade opportunities for the two nations.
Wang had earlier expressed the hope that Japan would increase purchases from Taiwan to help address the huge trade deficit on Taiwan's side.
Taiwan exports to Japan totaled US$9.3 billion last year, while Japan's exports to Taiwan almost tripled that amount at US$27 billion.
Chairman Koo said that he believed Taiwan-Japan trade relations will become closer due to the development of Internet industries and Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization.

Kosai said that Japanese private investment and consumption are still sluggish, but after the stimulus measures taken by the Japanese government, economic growth this year should reach 0.2 percent, up from the embarrassing negative growth over the past two years.

Major issues slated to be discussed at the one-day meeting included the current economic situation of the two nations, cooperation between the two on post-quake reconstruction, and measures to upgrade the national competitiveness of each country.
The economic conference has been held alternately in Japan and the ROC each year since the two nations severed diplomatic ties in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 MISCARRIAGE OF JUSTICE CASES TO BE COMPENSATED BY END OF YEAR

TEXT.P: Victims of 14 miscarriage of justice cases during Taiwan's martial law era will receive monetary compensation by the end of the year, a government foundation said on Tuesday.

The Cabinet-established foundation, responsible for screening miscarriage of justice cases for alleged spying and treason during the four decades of martial law that ended in 1987, said these are the first rulings out of the 5,000 cases it has received since its establishment earlier this year.
Members of the foundation's board of directors ruled on compensation for the 14 cases at a meeting held on Monday.

The highest sum of compensation from among the 14 wrongful convictions is NT$4.2 million (US$131,250) and the lowest amount is NT$1.9 million, with a total of NT$36 million to be handed over to victims, according to the foundation.

Out of consideration for the right to privacy, the foundation will not make public the names of those victims or family members who are entitled to receive compensation, the foundation said, adding that the government is expected to complete procedures for awarding the compensation money by the end of the year.
Author victim, Bo Yang (Kuo Yi-tung), who was jailed for eight years on charges of spying for Chinese communists, has not yet been notified of any ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER, FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 0.4 percent on Tuesday, failing to continue the previous trading session's surging trend over fears that fund managers could dump shares ahead of the year 2000.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 33.47 points lower at 7,850.14, and turnover expanded to NT$132.57 (US$4.20 billion), with 2.57 billion shares changing hands, of which selling greatly exceeded buying by 41 million shares.

Boosted by overnight gains on the US technology-heavy NASDAQ index, the market opened 37.59 points, or 0.6 percent, higher with recently popular internet-related stocks attracting the most attention, but profit-taking later in the session sent the index into negative territory.

According to dealers, uncertainty over the investment strategies of large funds leading up to the year 2000 triggered strong late selling and played a crucial role in dragging the index back into the red.
Most of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with the exception of the paper-making sector and the chemical and plastics sector, reporting gains of 1 percent and 0.4 percent, respectively.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 296 to 178, with 77 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market edged down 2.46 points to close at 187.23 on a turnover of NT$13.32 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, with the exception of June and September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved down 78 points to close at 7,872 with 765 contract transactions. Those for January declined 70 points to finish at 7,910 with 1,302 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March dipped 80 points to close at 7,966 with 28 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,950 points for December, 7,980 points for January, 8,046 points for next March, 8,032 points for next June, and 8,054 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported losses.
December TE futures shed 3.65 points to close at 398.3 with 269 contract transactions, and January TE futures moved down 4 points to finish at 400 with 450 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

December TF futures dropped 2.4 points to close at 954 with 116 contract transactions, and January TF futures moved up 3.2 points to close at 978 points with 113 contract transactions; no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-MANILA AVIATION TALKS BREAK DOWN

TEXT.P: Civil aeronautic authorities from Taipei and Manila failed to reach an agreement on the suspended aviation pact after a 50-minute meeting on Tuesday.

A three-member Philippine delegation led by Jacinto Ortega, director of the Civil Aeronautic Board, arrived in Taipei Monday afternoon to hold talks with their Taiwan counterparts on resumption of the Taipei-Manila air agreement, which was unilaterally abrogated by the Philippines on Oct. 1.

The Philippine mission met the Taiwan delegation headed by Chang Yu-heng, director general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), at 9:30 a.m. and ended the talks at 10:20 a.m.

Chang said at a press conference that because the Philippine side lacked sincerity and the two sides differ on the issue of sixth flight rights to third-country destinations, the two sides failed to reach an agreement, and the talks thus broke down.

It was understood that Manila was not fully prepared to hold talks on the aviation pact with Taipei. The Philippine Civil Aeronautics Board had only drafted a contract for Taipei-Manila air link resumption while stipulating restrictions against allowing sixth flight rights on flights between the two cities.

A CAA official said the Philippine side has not shown respect toward the Taiwan side. Not one aviation pact signed anywhere in the world includes a clause stipulating restrictions on the use of sixth flight rights, the official stressed.

The Taiwan official continued, saying that although "our side suggested a further 20 percent cut from the proposed weekly quota of 6,500 seats for Taiwan air carriers but withheld on the sixth flight rights, the new Taipei proposal was not accepted by the Philippine side."

However, the door will continue to be open for talks in the hope that those Philippine workers employed in Taiwan will be able to return to their homeland for family reunions, Christmas holidays and the New Year season, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HK, CHINA AMONG TOP TEN MARKETS FOR EDUCATION IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong are among the top ten educational markets for Australia, and the number of students from the greater China area will show an increase this year and in years to come due to a recovery in their economies.

In an interview with the CNA on Tuesday, Jan Kelly, manager of network services for IDP Education Australia, said the country's prospects for educational exports are "getting brighter this year and the years to come because of an economic recovery in Asia."

She cited a rise in the number of students from Taiwan, Hong Kong and China by 16 percent, 66 percent and 50 percent, respectively, between January and October 1999 from a year earlier, according to student visa statistics compiled by the Department of Immigration.
"I believe Taiwan, Hong Kong and China will continue to be major educational markets for Australia, especially mainland China," she said.

She said the Australian government has considerably relaxed its restrictions, allowing more Chinese students to study in Australia. In the past, Australia had been very strict about granting student visas to mainland Chinese students for fear they would stay on after finishing their schooling, she acknowledged.

"But the government has designated a number of Australian schools to be responsible for monitoring the studies of Chinese students so that they have to see them leave after they finish their studies in Australia," she said.

As for Taiwan and Hong Kong, she said IDP Education would continue its promotional efforts to lure more students to study in Australia, and she is confident that the prospects are getting bright due to the Asian economic recovery and because more Australian schools are gaining recognition in both places.

Dr. Chen Tung-jung, director of the Cultural Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra, also believed the number of students from Taiwan studying in Australia would increase in the years to come.

He said the Ministry of Education in Taiwan is encouraging more Taiwanese students to study in Australia because cultural ties between the two countries are getting closer thanks to increasing exchanges of educational programs and exchange visits by teachers.

In addition, the quality of life and education in Australia are being recognized by more and more students and their parents in Taiwan. Australian schools have the advantage of geographical proximity and cheaper fees compared to those in the United States, Japan and Britain, he said.

He said Australia now ranks third as a destination for Taiwanese students, trailing behind the United States and Britain. It is followed by Canada and Japan. "I believe Australia can attract more students from Taiwan if it increases its promotional efforts," he said. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD PUSH FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF REGIONAL SECURITY MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen said on Tuesday that the Republic of China should strengthen contact with Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries.
Chen also said the government should push for the establishment of a sub-region collective security system to ensure Taiwan's sustainable economic development.
He made the remarks at a seminar on Taiwan's strategy for taking part in Asia-Pacific regional cooperative systems, including collective security mechanisms.
Chen said Taiwan should study the possible impact on the security system of economic globalization and Internet service development.

The minister pointed out that two developments which are not in harmony with each other still exist in the Asia-Pacific region in the post-Cold War era. "They are arms races and mutual dependence," Chen said.

On the one hand, Chen went on, the Asia-Pacific has replaced the Middle East as the world's largest arms importing area. On the other hand, countries in the region have become more mutually dependent because of their fast economic development and the formation of various international cooperative organizations.

At present, Chen said, the region has several government-level international organizations, such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum and the ASEAN Regional Forum. In addition, the region also has various non-official dialogue mechanisms and conferences.
From a macro point of view, Chen said, there is still ample room for the ROC to help boost prosperity and security in the entire Asia-Pacific region.

First of all, Chen said, the ROC should promote the establishment of a sub-regional security mechanism which would cover several countries in the region. Chen said he believes that tension in the area can be reduced if countries in the region can seek a consensus through a sub-regional or a multilateral security mechanism to resolve the South China Sea disputes and problems related to mainland China's ballistic missile development and nuclear proliferation.

Second, he continued, Taiwan should increase contact with ASEAN countries. "Even though the ROC is still not an ASEAN dialogue partner, we can forge closer economic ties with Southeast Asian countries under the APEC framework and by supporting various APEC economic liberalization plans," the minister explained.

Third, the ROC should study the impact of economic globalization on existing international security systems. Noting that economic globalization and the development of Internet services and related technologies have rendered obsolete many traditional national security protection measures, Chen said the ROC should take into consideration all these new factors in tackling national and international security issues.

He further said the ROC should push for international cooperation on various global issues, integrate the research results of individual countries on regional issues, and lend substance to various cooperative projects under the APEC framework.

The seminar was co-sponsored by several local think tanks, including the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research, the Chinese-Taipei APEC research center, and National Chengchi University's Institute of International Relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA PRESIDENT MEETS WITH ROC PARLIAMENTARY LEADER IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, leading a four-member legislative group, met with Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez on Monday here.
During the meeting, Rodriguez told the legislators that he values the ROC-Costa Rica friendship very much.

Officials of the Costa Rica embassy in Panama said the visit was purely a courtesy meeting and the two sides did not talk about other issues, but Rodriguez accepted a formal invitation from Wang to visit Taiwan "at an appropriate time."
Also that day, Wang also paid a call on his Panamanian counterpart, Enrique Garrido, who expressed his hope of further boosting ties between the parliaments of the two countries.

Wang, accompanied by legislators Shen Fu-hsiung of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, Chiang Chi-wen of the ruling Kuomintang, Lee Chu-feng of the tiny opposition New Party, and independent Legislator Chen Chin-ting, arrived in Panama on Sunday for a week-long visit.
During their stay, Wang and the four lawmakers will take part in the Central American Parliament Forum scheduled to open on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN HOPES TO ENHANCE CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS THROUGH EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that the Republic of China has always hoped that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can enhance bilateral relations through exchanges.

Lien made the remarks during a meeting with Richard Bush, the Washington-based chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), who is currently on a nine-day visit to Taiwan to inspect AIT's Taiwan operation.

The ruling Kuomintang's presidential candidate in the 2000 election said Taiwan would be most reluctant to see military cross-strait confrontation, and that peace and stability is in the interests of both sides, the region, and even the world.

He stressed that national security is the primary concern of the nation, and added that he has already suggested that both sides of the Taiwan Strait actively work to establish a mechanism of military mutual trust and try to ease tensions.

This could be achieved, he said, through contact between relevant officials, the establishment of a system to notify the other side in advance of military exercises, and the setting up of a telephone hot line to avoid unnecessary overreaction from the other side.
The vice president said the areas for bilateral cooperation and exchanges are wide and varied, but he expressed regret that systematic cross-strait dialogue has yet to resume.

He noted that after a groundbreaking high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1993 during which both sides agreed to separate concepts of "one China," bilateral exchanges followed.
But he said mainland China later insisted that "one China" is the People's Republic of China, of which Taiwan is a province, which is unacceptable to the ROC.
Lien said Taiwan is willing to negotiate with the mainland on national unification on an equal footing once goodwill and consensus have been built up after cross-strait exchanges and cooperation.
He also said there is no timetable or set model for unification, and that both sides can negotiate in any feasible way.

The AIT head later called on Su Chi, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council during which he expressed his concern about the development of cross-strait relations after May or June next year.

Cross-strait relations were strained after President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship" in July, and Beijing canceled a scheduled Taiwan visit this fall by Wang Daohan, the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan.

Su reaffirmed that while Taiwan promotes cross-trait exchanges and dialogue, it has to take into consideration its security and dignity, and he expressed the hope that the US government understands this stance and the needs of the nation.

Su also told Bush that after both sides of the Taiwan Strait join the World Trade Organization (WTO) next year, a new bridge, not a new battlefield, will exist, and Taiwan will do its utmost to bring cross-strait ties back on track.

Su also cited President Lee's statement that if Beijing demonstrates enough goodwill and gives a substantial response, Taipei will be willing to review its cross-strait trade policy to be more in tune with the spirit of the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIRAGE FIGHTERS GROUNDED FOR SAFETY CHECKS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force General Headquarters (AFGHQ) has ordered all its French-made Mirage 2000-5 fighters grounded for thorough safety checks, an AFGHQ spokesman said on Tuesday.

The move came after a high-tech Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter, piloted by Squadron Leader Chiang Chin-liang, plunged into waters off the northeastern coast of Taiwan at around 10:53 a.m. in the morning, he said.

The fighter, accompanied by two twin-seater Mirages, took off at 10 a.m. from Hsinchu Air Base heading for waters off the northeastern coast of Taiwan to conduct a simulated air intercept exercise. The airplane lost contact with the control tower during the second stage of the exercise.

Two air force helicopters, a C-130 transport airplane, coast guard cutters and a navy destroyer rushed to the area in which the plane disappeared in the hope of rescuing the pilot and locating the wreckage of the plane within 12 hours, the spokesman said.
He added that if Chiang was able to eject from the aircraft before it hit the water, there is a 99-percent chance that the rescue will be successful.
However, he noted that locating the plane will be difficult since unlike the US-built F-16s owned by the air force, the French-built Mirage is not equipped with a location beacon.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,500 JOBLESS WORKERS PROTEST IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Some 1,500 Chinese workers of a state-run company in southwestern Sichuan province staged public protests Monday and Tuesday because they have not received their wages since May, a human rights group said here Tuesday.

The workers of Chengdu Auto Manufacturing Factory were dispersed Tuesday by 500 police when they staged a demonstration on National Highway 108 in suburban Chengdu, the Hong Kong-based Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said. One of the demonstrators was injured and detained by police.

The state-run auto maker suspended production due to poor management in May. It has not paid wages to the workers since then, and has not paid their monthly living allowances since October, the information center said.
Some 8,000 state-run enterprises went bankrupt or closed down in the first eight months of this year, according to reports by official newspapers in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST GROUP OF VIETNAMESE HOUSEMAIDS START NEW LIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of eight Vietnamese women, who arrived in Taiwan on Monday to work as housemaids or family helpers, met the local press on Tuesday.
Some of them impressed local journalists by speaking fluent Mandarin Chinese.

They are the second group of Vietnamese nationals to be legally introduced to work in Taiwan. The first group arrived in Taiwan a few weeks ago to work at a factory in the central Taiwan county of Taichung.
Chuang An-chi, a manpower agent who introduced the eight-member group to Taiwan, said the average age of the group is 28, with the youngest member aged 27 and the oldest 40.
All of the members are married and have children, Chuang said, adding that all of them have received either junior or senior high school education.

Noting that Vietnam implements a 12-year compulsory education system, Chuang said all Vietnamese nationals study English in elementary schools and are also required to study Chinese at the stage of senior high schools.

Manpower brokers also offer 150 hours of Chinese language training program and 30 hours of intensive course on Taiwan's legal system, customs and general living habits for Vietnamese nationals to be introduced to Taiwan.

A member of the Vietnamese group said she felt a little worry before coming to Taiwan as she knew she will look after elderly people and young children. "With the encouragement and support of my family, I finally decided to come in order to help family finances," she added.

Chuang said a Vietnamese college graduate can make an average of US$50 (about NT$1,600) a month, while the minimum monthly wage in Taiwan is NT$15,840. "It's a dream for many Vietnmaese people to work in Taiwan," he noted.
Many Taiwan employers also have an affection for Vietnamese workers because they are known for diligence and good work ethics, Chuang said.

Moreover, Chuang said, each Vietnamese manpower brokerage house is required to deposit US$10,000 in guaranty money in a Vietnamese government account, and each Vietnamese worker must also deposit US$300 as a personal guarantee. The Vietnamese government also has taken many other additional measures to prevent any overseas Vietnamese worker from absconding, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES OVERSEAS CHINESE MISSION FROM NEW YORK

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday talked about Taiwan's policy on mainland China during a reception for a 22-member delegation from the Chinese Benevolent Association of New York.

He reiterated his stance that the ROC is definitely an "independent sovereign country" legally and historically, as it was established in 1912, while the People's Republic of China was not established until 1949.
This, he went on, is why he redefined cross-Taiwan Strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship" last July.

Lee noted that freedom and democracy are the most useful weapons in Taiwan's arsenal to counter the challenge from mainland China, and added that Taiwan eagerly hopes to see the mainland people enjoy the fruits of democracy and freedom as soon as possible.
Only when the ideals of freedom, democracy and equal distribution of wealth is realized on the mainland, Lee said, can the two sides of the Taiwan Strait march down the road of unification.

Talking about the current cross-strait situation, Lee said that stability across the Taiwan Strait is vital to the peace and prosperity of the Asia-Pacific region, and he expressed the hope that Beijing will give up its outdated ideology and adopt a friendly attitude to strengthen dialogue with Taipei.

During the reception, Lee also expressed his appreciation for the contributions made by Chinese communities abroad for relief and reconstruction efforts in Taiwan after the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S WHO BID, SAYS LOCAL MEDICAL GROUP

TEXT.P: The US State Department has never said that the US government does not support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO), a Taiwan medical group said on Tuesday.

A spokesman for the Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan (MPAT) said the US State Department on Monday denied reports that it said that based on the "one China" policy, the US government does not support Taiwan's WHO bid and also opposes Taiwan's attempts to join any other international organizations for which statehood is a requirement.

Lin Shih-chia, director of the MPAT office, said the US State Department made the denial after relevant US officials were asked by the US-based Formosan Association of Public Affairs (FAPA) to explain the meaning of the alleged report.

Refuting the report as totally groundless, State Department officials told FAPA members that the State Department has made no such statement. Rather, they pointed out, President Bill Clinton has recently signed a bill actually supporting Taiwan's WHO membership.

Clinton on Dec. 7 signed into law a bill requiring a report to Congress from Secretary of State Madeleine Albright by Jan. 1, 2000, regarding the Clinton administration's efforts to secure Taiwan's "appropriate and meaningful participation" in the WHO.

Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-OH), who sponsored the legislation, said on Dec. 8 that this law compels the United States to abide by its 1994 Taiwan Policy Review to more actively support Taiwan's participation in the WHO and other international organizations.

"For too long, Taiwan's 21 million citizens have been denied access to the WHO and its medical expertise. The question is not whether Taiwan belongs in the WHO, but whether we support improving health care for children, the elderly, and the most vulnerable people in Taiwan. These are goals that our nation should support," Brown said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIA ECONOMIC CONFERENCE WRAPS UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 27th East Asia Economic Conference concluded on Tuesday with the participants agreeing that small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and technical manpower resources need to be nurtured.

More than 250 delegates from Japan and the Republic of China took part in the conference. Sino-Japanese Economic and Trade Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his Japanese counterpart Akio Kosai led the two delegations.

In a joint statement issued at the end of the one-day meeting, the participants said that both nations believe Asia has moved out of the economic doldrums caused by the Asian financial crisis of 1997, and it is now moving toward economic recovery.

The participants also said that in the future, they will deal with bad loans and foreign debts. In addition, to bolster the basis of the manufacturing industry and upgrade both countries' national competitiveness, they will ste0 up the nurturing of SMEs and technical talent.
The ROC and Japan should take the lead in helping Asian countries improve their banking and financial systems, and should review the possibility of regional financial cooperation.

The participants said that the regional financial crisis showed there is a complementary relationship between the two nations, and that there is an interdependence between Asian and Japanese economies.
They also urged both governments to adopt measures to address the trade imbalance in Japan's favor.
Taiwan exports to Japan totaled US$9.3 billion last year, while Japan's exports to Taiwan almost tripled that amount at NT$27 billion.
Both delegations agreed that both sides should increase bilateral investment and technological cooperation in high-tech industries.

In view of the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan on Sept. 21, the Japanese delegates also said that "as long as the ROC government puts forward the requests," Japan will provide assistance in the form of experience, technology and talent, and will also urge Japanese people to visit Taiwan as tourists.

The Japanese delegates also said that as Japan is pushing for restructuring of its financial and securities sectors, it will also invest in other nations in Asia so that other Asian countries can rebound quickly along with Japan.
Both sides also concluded that for the continued economic growth of both nations, the two nations need to pay more attention to environmental protection.
The economic conference has been held alternately in Japan and the ROC each year since the two nations severed diplomatic ties in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE WILL BE MOST AFFECTED BY TAIWAN'S WTO SEAT: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2000 will have the strongest impact on the country's agriculture sector, a high-ranking trade official said on Tuesday.

However, Chen Juei-lung, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), stressed that the government has already taken some precautionary measures to reduce the impact.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan hearing held by legislators Li Hsien-jen (KMT-Taipei County) and Chang Shi-liang (New Party-at large), Chen said that the government will also work to help the industrial and service sectors in the hope of opening up a more advantageous development phase for Taiwan.

He went on to say that since agriculture is one of the under-privileged industries in Taiwan, massive WTO impact on the sector is to be expected as the government gradually opens the country to imports of agricultural products and cuts tariffs and export subsidies.
He added, however, that as efforts have been made to secure more favorite conditions for Taiwan's agriculture, the impact will be less than originally expected.

Chen also pointed out that as far as the industrial sector is concerned, WTO entry will be beneficial, since Taiwan's exports are based mainly on industrial products, and WTO membership will give more freedom regarding exports.

Fu Dung-cheng, director of the Cabinet-level Department of Research and Planning under the Mainland Affairs Council, who also attended the hearing, said that as mainland China and Taiwan will both enter the WTO next year, it is expected that bilateral relations and interaction will be enhanced.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL ADVOCATES SEA-BORNE MISSILE DEFENSE FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Instead of giving Taiwan ballistic missiles, US senator John McCain advocated on Tuesday the development of a sea-borne missile system which can be moved into troubled areas or international waters if necessary.

In a debate between Republican presidential hopefuls in Des Moines, Iowa on Monday, McCain said a sea-borne missile system would achieve the same goals as a land-based system, and that if elected, he will help Taiwan acquire necessary weapons.

Noting that the "one China" policy followed by Washington is based on the fundamental principle of peaceful reunification of China, the senator warned that Beijing will violate this policy by committing aggression against Taiwan.

Describing the Beijing regime as "a group of people hell-bent on hanging onto power," the Vietnam War hero-turned-politician said Washington can convince them that it is in their interest to enter the world as a superpower, and in a peaceful, contributory fashion.

Sen. Orrin Hatch, another contender for the Republican nomination, boasted during the debate that he was one of the authors of the Taiwan Relations Act which is aimed at supporting Taiwan because "we don't want them walked all over."
"We owe an obligation to Taiwan ... I am for keeping those obligations," said Hatch.
As for mainland China, the senator said: "We can through good diplomacy and toughness, we can get China to back off on those types of (intimidation of Taiwan) activities."

Gary Bauer, a Reagan administration official, described his colleagues as naive about Beijing's leaders, and said the United States cannot duck the challenge that the mainland intends to replace the United States as the Pacific superpower.
Texas Governor George W. Bush, billionaire Steve Forbes and former State Department official Alan Keyes also took part in the debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL AID MOST URGENTLY NEEDED IN ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Medical care is the most urgent requirement in Taiwan's aboriginal communities at present, according to the results of a recent public opinion poll released on Tuesday.

Ninety percent of the aboriginal people who responded to the poll said the establishment of clinics, hospitals and other medical institutions in aboriginal communities is urgent and essential, as health care provisions for this specific group of citizens have long been neglected, said a spokesman for the private Luchu Society, which commissioned the poll.

Other urgent needs in the country's aboriginal communities include the establishment of nursing homes, state-run nurseries, activity centers and post offices, in that order, the spokesman quoted the poll results as indicating.

The Luchu Society is a group of doctors and other medical specialists who donate voluntary medical services at home and abroad. It commissioned the TVBS poll center to carry out the survey among 857 aborigines around Taiwan between May 1998 and August 1999.

According to the survey, only 15 percent of the aboriginal communities around the island have convenient piped water systems, while 75.2 percent of the respondents said they use mountain springs as their water source.

The same poll also found that most public roads in the areas populated by aborigines are in bad condition, with transportation connections to "outside" areas vulnerable to heavy traffic and natural disasters.
Aboriginal people have also long been plagued by a number of lifestyle-related problems such as alcoholism and high ratios of liver and lung disease, which was also reflected in the poll results.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIGGEST WINNER AT WORLD SOFT TENNIS CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The 11th World Soft Tennis Championship concluded in Taoyuan County on Tuesday, with Taiwan emerging the biggest winner with four gold, three silver and three bronze medals.

In addition to two golds already under the team's belt in the competition, Taiwan player Liu Chia-lun had to settle for a silver medal in the men's singles final on Tuesday after outlasting countryman Liao Nan-kai, who took the bronze, but falling to a South Korean player.

Meanwhile, Taiwan players Hsieh Shun-feng and Chen Hsin-heng beat their Japanese opponents to win the men's doubles final, while another Taiwan pair -- Kuo Hsu-tung and Feng Tung-hsien -- took the bronze.
In the women's singles, Taiwan players Wang Szu-ting, Peng Yi-chen, and Chien Chia-yu made a clean sweep, taking gold, silver and bronze, respectively.
In the women's doubles, Lin Li-jung and Cheng Shu-chen completed Taiwan's haul, taking the silver medal.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG SAYS SON'S `MYSTERY FUND' WAS FROM KMT

TEXT.P: Independent presidential candidate James Soong said late on Tuesday evening that a huge sum of money deposited in his son's account was from the ruling Kuomintang and approved by KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui in 1992.

He told a press conference that at the time he was KMT secretary-general and that at Lee's direction, he used the accounts of Soong Chen-yuan, his son, and Chen Pi-yun, sister of James Soong's wife, to deposit about NT$146,460,000 from the KMT.
Soong said the money was appropriated to take care of the families of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo and to carry out other "special missions" on Lee's express orders.
Over the seven intervening years, Soong stated, all the money could be traced through transaction records, and he stressed that he and his family have never used any of the money.

He said that because the KMT's leaders had launched merciless attacks against him since the second half of this year, he decided to stop carrying out the KMT-commissioned task, and withdrew NT$141,140,000 from his son's account on Oct. 4 for return to the KMT through "appropriate channels."
Soong apologized for the embarrassment to the Chiang family and other relevant people caused by the disclosures.
At the press conference, he said the money had been used to help finance a trip to the United States by Mrs. Chiang Ching-kuo in 1992, and to help with the maintenance of her residence.
After news of Soong's "mystery account" was made public last week by a KMT legislator, his presidential support rating slipped several notches.
Among the primary presidential hopefuls, Soong had enjoyed a consistent lead in support ratings over the KMT's Lien Chan and the Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Shui-bian.
Meanwhile, Su Chih-cheng, an official at the Presidential Office, branded Soong a liar, saying that the former Taiwan governor "is attempting to shift the focus."
Su told the media that while Lee did order the establishment of an education fund for Chiang's children, the fund was for only NT$30 million, far less than the figure claimed by Soong.
"I hope Soong will stop lying," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Both the Presidential Office and the ruling Kuomintang flatly reject independent presidential candidate James Soong's explanation of the source of his son's 'mystery fund.'
The China Times:

The Taipei Times:
Soong points finger at Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$ 930,000 TO PARAGUAY'S HEALTH MINISTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Huang Ming-hsing and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has donated US$930,000 to Paraguay's Public Health Ministry to help the country implement a series of health programs, Paraguayan news media Ultima Hora reported Tuesday.
Paraguay's Public Health Minister Martin Chiola told the press that his ministry has earmarked part of the money -- US$600,000 -- to be used for the construction of a children's hospital.

Chiola said the ministry will also use US$50,000 of the money to explain and publicize the government's public health policies. The remaining US$280,000 will be used for the procurement of advanced medical equipment in the hopes of establishing mobile hospitals and public health stations in inland areas and in areas near the capital city to take care of the poor.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REFUTES SOONG'S EXPLANATION ABOUT MONEY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday refuted former Taiwan Governor James Soong's explanation about the origin of the huge sum of money discovered in one of his son's bank accounts as "totally groundless and full of loopholes."

Asked by the media prior to a Kuomintang (KMT) Central Standing Committee meeting whether or not at the end of 1992 he gave or instructed the giving of NT$146 million (US$4.62 million) to Soong, who was KMT secretary-general at the time, Lee answered by asking, "Do you believe so? Can his (Soong's) remarks be believed?"

At the KMT meeting, Lee, in his capacity as chairman of the ruling party, condemned Soong's explanation, made during a televised press conference Tuesday night, as completely ridiculous, saying that "Soong thinks I am old, so he dared to fabricate such lies."

At Tuesday night's press conference, independent presidential candidate Soong, after six days of silence regarding the source of the money, announced that "under instructions from President Lee, NT$146 million was transferred to the accounts of my son and my sister-in-law in order to take care of the family and descendants of former President Chiang Ching-kuo and to conduct other political work for the party as specifically indicated by the chairman."

Ridiculing Soong's remarks, Lee said the KMT has well-established agencies to take care of Chiang's widow, Mme. Chiang Fang-liang and their remaining children with sufficient funds, and the funds have nothing to do with what Soong has claimed.

Lee stated that neither the KMT chairman nor the secretary-general have bank accounts in their names for the purpose of handling the party's funds. Lee added that anyone who uses the party's money for personal reasons will be dealt with squarely, indicating that Soong may be charged with the crime of embezzlement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 15, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1711: The plague breaks out in Copenhagen, Denmark.
1806: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte enter Warsaw, Poland.
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the US Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1916: The French defeat Germans in the Battle of Verdun in World War I.
1920: China and Austria are admitted to the League of Nations.
1927: The ROC government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following the attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires in the interests of party unity.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under the Sino-American tung oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The United Nations General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC's Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The United Nations General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit communist China as a member.
1965: The US Mariner spacecraft relays to Earth data about Venus as it flies past the planet.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the US animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to The International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: President Jimmy Carter announces he will establish diplomatic relations with communist China from January 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1979: The deposed Shah of Iran flies from the United States to exile in Panama.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The United Nations General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: British and Irish leaders sign a complex framework for negotiating peace in Northern Ireland, ending 25 years of conflict.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, which gives more autonomy to colleges and allows students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Members of ASEAN sign a treaty banning the possession, manufacture or acquisition of nuclear weapons and also creating a nuclear arms-free zone from Burma and Vietnam in the north to Indonesia in the south.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
Confucius: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIANG'S WIDOW WELL TAKEN CARE OF SAYS GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Relevant government officials on Wednesday said the wife of former President Chiang Ching-kuo, Mme. Chiang Fang-liang has been well taken care of by the government since her husband passed away in January 1988.

Presidential Office spokesman Ting Yuan-chao said Mme. Chiang has been taken care of by the Presidential Office and related government agencies over the past 11 years and has regularly received indemnities as the surviving wife of the head-of-state.

Quoting government records, Ting said Chiang's wife, a Russian-born Caucasian who has lived in China and Taiwan for more than five decades, has received more than NT$45 million (US$1.42 million) from the government since January 1988 under various pension, welfare and indemnity programs for public functionaries.

Ting made the remarks in refutation of former Taiwan Governor and independent presidential candidate James Soong's explanation on Tuesday at a press conference that he was given NT$146 million (US$4.62 million) seven years ago by the Kuomintang for the purposes of taking care of Mme. Chiang Fang-liang and the children of the Chiangs and for conducting other party work.
Ting said Soong's explanation that the huge sum that was discovered in one of his son's savings accounts was meant to be used to take care of the Chiangs' was totally groundless.
Ting noted that, over the past 11 years, the government has also footed the bill for chauffeurs, housekeeping, cars, gasoline and security at Mme. Chiang's residence.

Meanwhile, Kuomintang spokesman Huang Hui-chen also refuted Soong's explanation, saying that clear records of the money spent by the government on Mme. Chiang and her family can be checked at the Ministry of Personnel (MOP).

According to Chen Ching-tien, director of the MOP's Department of Retirement and Indemnity, Mme. Chiang was given some NT$8 million in 1988, during the first year after former President Chiang Ching-kuo's death, as the surviving wife of the head-of-state and a public functionary who had served the nation for more than 15 years.
In the 10 years between 1989 and November of this year, Mme. Chiang received about NT$34 million from the government for living expenses, added Chen.
