DOC.HEADLINE: IMPLICATION OF CHIANG FAMILY IN SOONG MONEY SCANDAL PROTESTED
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A daughter-in-law of the late Republic of China President Chiang Ching-kuo said on Tuesday that she strongly disagrees with independent presidential candidate James Soong's implication of her family in his funding scandal.

Fang Chih-yi, widow of the late president's youngest son Chiang Hsiao-yung, made the remarks after Soong claimed at a Taipei news conference that NT$140 million (US$4.43 million) deposited in his son Soong Chen-yuan's Chung Hsing Bills Finance Corp. account was entrusted by President and ruling Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui to care for the Chiang family.

Fang said she is still trying to grasp the full details of Soong's financial scandal. Nevertheless, she expressed her extreme annoyance at Soong's repeated mention of her Russian-born mother-in-law, Mrs. Faina Fang-liang Chiang, in his explanation of the source of his son's "mystery funds."

Fang, a member of the standing committee of the KMT's San Francisco branch, said she wonders why money allegedly to be used to care for the Chiang family would end up in the account of one of Soong's offspring.

"I especially take issue over Soong's repeated referrals to my mother-in-law during his `mystery fund' explanation news conference," Fang said, adding that the Chiang family would in any case not accept a penny that was not its due.
Fang further said she holds her mother-in-law in high respect, describing her as a woman of simplicity who has no ambition for fame or power.

"Even though my mother-in-law was once the first lady of the Republic of China, she has always thought of herself as an ordinary person and has led a low-profile, simple life," Fang said, adding that she earnestly hopes that nobody will sabotage her mother-in-law's peaceful life for political ends.
Chiang Ching-kuo died in 1988, while his three sons -- Chiang Hsiao-wen, Chiang Hsiao-wu and Chiang Hsiao-yung -- died in 1989, 1991 and 1996, respectively.

Soong, who was expelled from the KMT last month for his insistence on running as an independent candidate against the KMT's presidential ticket in the 2000 presidential election, told a Tuesday news conference that in 1992, while he was KMT secretary-general, that Lee instructed him to set up a fund to care for the Chiang family, and that the NT$140 million in his son's account was provided by the KMT for that purpose. As his relations with the KMT leadership have soured, Soong said he had long planned to return the money to the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: CYCLONE FORCES SHUTDOWNS IN W. AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Cyclone John -- rated five on a five-point scale, has forced a shutdown of offshore oil and gas production facilities and iron ore projects in Western Australia, and is likely to cause a temporary disruption of Australia's export shipments to importing countries, including Taiwan.

The cyclone was 265 kilometers west of Port Hedland, a leading detention center for refugees in Western Australia on Tuesday, but on Wednesday morning it was spotted crossing near Karratha, a major port used for exporting Australian crude oil, gas and iron ore to Taiwan and other Asian countries, according to industry sources.

The cyclone has increased in force, packing winds of up to 290 kilometers per hour and forcing the evacuation of some areas after Karratha and Port Hedland's shipping services were temporarily halted. The strong cyclone was sending waves as high as seven meters on Wednesday morning, causing fears of flooding in some areas.

Broken Hill Proprietary Pty. Ltd. said it had to shut down production at its crude oil facilities. "We have shut down the process and are watching the storm. The vessel is prepared to disconnect, but we will wait and see what the cyclone's path is," BHP Petroleum's spokesman Malcolm Garratt told reporters.

Meanwhile, Apache Energy has temporarily closed its oil platform, which produces 15,000 barrels of crude oil per day and Woodside Petroleum reported that it had pulled out non-essential staff from its production sites.
Australia produces about 600,000 barrels of crude oil per day, with Taiwan importing 10,000 barrels of that total.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEBEC LEADER ACCUSED OF CREATING CRISIS

TEXT.P: Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard's attempt to forge a united front against Ottawa's "clarity bill" hit a snag when the leader of Quebec's opposition Liberal Party accused him of using the proposed referendum legislation to fabricate a crisis Tuesday.
The "clarity" bill refers to the bill tabled by Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien which demands clarity on the question of secession and calls for a majority in a secession referendum.
Bouchard tried to enlist Jean Charest's support for his crusade against the federal referendum legislation, claiming that Quebec is facing an unprecedented attack from the federal government.

But Charest said the Quebec provincial government is fabricating a crisis in order to hold a referendum that Quebecers don't really want. Charest noted that the premier should be spending his time repairing government incompetence instead of promoting separatism.
Bouchard dismissed the comments, saying Charest should be willing to stand up to Ottawa and should decide where his loyalty lies- with Jean Chretien or with Quebec.

Charest countered by asking Bouchard whether his loyalty lies with Quebec or with his separatist agenda. Charest added that he opposes the prime minister's referendum legislation, but he also doesn't want to give the sovereignty movement any momentum.

"Their reaction has been so exaggerated since the moment that this happened," said Charest. "This is an opportunity for them to do what Quebecers don't want them to do and that's prepare another referendum."

The Quebec Liberals believe they can position themselves between Bouchard and Chretien. They think most Quebecers will agree with them that the government should focus on real issues like health care, the creation of jobs and reducing taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Y2K EXPECTED TO HAVE LITTLE BYTE

TEXT.P: The millennium bug, or Y2K, is not expected to trigger widespread havoc on a global scale, according to a new assessment by the United Nations.

The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday reported that the UN assessment, conducted by its International Y2K Cooperation Center in Washington, shows that the bug will likely cause many minor errors but only a few major and lasting crises.
The center is working with Y2K coordinators from 190 countries.

"Around the world, the great majority of organizations will experience only limited damage from the Y2K bug," said the center's director Bruce McConnell in a formal statement that accompanied the release of his report on the Y2K.

The report predicted "few serious" Y2K-caused effects in energy, telecommunications, finance, transportation, customs and immigration, food and water infrastructures because of the limited use of digital controls in most infrastructure and because of "society's general resilience," according to the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN GROWS 3.2 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Foreign and overseas Chinese investment in Taiwan during the period from January to October posted 3.2 percent growth compared with the year-earlier level, show latest statistics released by the Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC).
Most of the investment in the 10-month period was from the United States, totaling US$864.13 million, up 62.07 percent from the same period of last year.

Investment from British democratic monarchies and colonies in the Caribbean reached US$712.42 million, up 25.06 percent from the 1998 level. The showed the area to be the second-largest foreign investor in Taiwan, followed by Japan, whose investment on the island amounted to US$394.22 million in the 10-month period.

The investment from Japan posted a 14.1 percent decline, which was blamed on the facts that Japan itself was a victim of the Asian financial storm, and that Japan's bubble economy had come to an end, said IDIC Director-General Lin Neng-jong.

Lin said that promoting foreign investment in Taiwan will remain the key objective of the IDIC in the coming year, and pointed out that his center is currently working to secure 26 major foreign investments worth a total of NT$101.1 billion (US$3.2 billion).
These investments will mostly be in the semiconductor, communications, electronic and sophisticated machine manufacturing sectors, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP SCIENCE OFFICIAL REPEATS ATTEMPT TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top science official on Wednesday repeated an attempt to quit, saying that he tendered a formal resignation on Nov. 1 which clearly indicated his hope that the resignation would take effect on Dec. 15.

Huang Chen-tai, chairman of the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC), made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan, where he was blasted by Legislator Cheng Pao-ching for allegedly having been reluctant to take responsibility for delays in certain experimental programs of the ROCSAT-1, Taiwan's first wholly owned and operated satellite.

Cheng, a lawmaker from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said Huang should step down to take responsibility for the postponement of the ROCSAT-1's Ka-band communication experiment, one of the most important tasks the satellite is expected to do.

Huang pointed out that he did in fact tender his resignation to Premier Vincent Siew on Nov. 1 after the Ka-band communication experiment failed to meet the schedule of completion by the end of October as he had promised on March 31.
However, he went on, the resignation was rejected by Siew and the letter returned to Huang's office.

According to Huang, the Ka-band communication experiment was completed on Dec. 8 after the transmission wave transbonder assembly of the remote ground terminal to be installed in the ROCSAT's Experimental Communication Payload Ground System was repaired.
The National Space Program Office under the NSC, which is in charge of the ROCSAT-1 program, has already filed for compensation with relevant US companies for the delay, Huang added.

ROCSAT-1 was successfully launched into orbit in January of this year to begin a series of scientific experiments and tasks, including data collection on the effects of ionosphere plasma electrodynamics, taking pictures of the planet's oceans, and performing a variety of communications-related experiments.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dipped 0.3 cents to close at 31.64 against the greenback Wednesday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.
The currency opened at 31.652, and was traded between 31.637 and 31.659. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$274.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE HIGHER, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices edged up 0.1 percent on Wednesday as bargain-hunting by institutional buyers wiped off early losses.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 9.75 points higher at 7,859.89, with 2.73 billion shares changing hands on a turnover of NT$133.17 (US$4.21 billion).
Buying interest in stocks of companies with investment in telecom businesses remained strong in anticipation of high growth next year, dealers said.
All of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with the exception of the financial sector, which reported losses of 1.5 percent.
Cement issues enjoyed the largest gains of 3.4 percent, followed by textile shares, at 1.9 percent. The rest of the major stock categories posted only minor gains of under 1 percent.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 274 to 214, with 70 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market edged down 1.49 points to close at 188.72 on a turnover of NT$14.06 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for December moved up 11 points to close at 7,883, with 1,011 contract transactions. Those for January climbed 15 points to finish at 7,925, with 1,303 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for next March rose 34 points to close at 8,000, with six contract transactions, and those for June advanced 136 points to finish at 8,090, with four contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,872 points for December, 7,910 points for January, 7,966 points for next March, 7,954 points for next June, and 7,976 points for next September.

Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, reported mixed results and losses, respectively.

December TE futures shed 0.35 points to close at 397.95 with 372 contract transactions, and January TE futures moved up one point to finish at 401, with 451 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

December TF futures dropped 19 points to close at 935, with 144 contract transactions, and January TF futures moved down 20 points to close at 958 points, with 126 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERALL EDUCATION BUDGET PROPOSED AT 7% OF GDP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) of the Republic of China has proposed that the country's overall education budget should be set at 7 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP), a ministry spokesman said on Wednesday.
According to government statistics, the national education budget for fiscal 1999 totaled NT$550 billion, representing 6.75 percent of the GDP.
If this ratio had been set at no lower than 7 percent of the GDP, the education budget would have ranged from NT$580 billion to NT$600 billion, the spokesman added.

Education Minister Kirby Yang said that the MOE will set up an educational budget evaluation committee to compile the budget, and screen and provide estimates for education budgets for local governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT HEAD CONCLUDES TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said on Wednesday that the United States does not favor any one party or any one candidate in the 2000 presidential election in the Republic of China.
However, he went on, the country will work with whomever the Taiwan people choose to serve them as their leader.
The top US liaison official with the ROC, who arrived here last Wednesday, made the remarks at a press conference prior to his departure.

Bush said that he is not in a position to comment on the policies of the presidential candidates he met during his visit, but stressed that the United States "vigorously supports the transformation of Taiwan into a democratic system, and will work with whomever wins the election."

He refused to answer a question on whether Washington will make a move prior to the 2000 election similar to its actions in the runup to the 1996 presidential election when it deployed aircraft carriers in the Taiwan Strait. He said only that the US will closely monitor the situation in the Taiwan Strait, and that Taiwan people should be able to choose their leader without any threats.

He also said that the United States is very concerned about any rise in the level of tension across the Taiwan Strait, and expressed the hope that both sides will show restraint and engage in cross-strait dialogue to resolve differences in a peaceful way.

Asked about the conditions required to realize the stalled visit to Taiwan of Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Bush said that this will need to be worked out by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The visit, scheduled to take place this autumn, was canceled by Beijing in an angry reaction to President Lee Teng-hui July redefinition of cross-strait ties as "a special state-to-state relationship."

Bush reiterated that cross-strait misunderstandings need to be worked out through dialogue, and that after Taiwan and mainland China join the World Trade Organization, "an opportunity and atmosphere" will exist to move toward the resumption of cross-trait dialogue.

On Taiwan's proposed development of long-range surface-to-surface missiles to counter the military threat from the mainland, Bush said that Taiwan security cannot be achieved through weaponry alone, although he admitted that "military capability and deterrence" is important.
Bush said that the United States is also concerned about the deployment of missiles in coastal mainland China, and has expressed Taiwan's worry to the mainland.

He also addressed questions about the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) currently going through the US Congress, saying that some people in Taiwan might be under the wrong impression that Taiwan will be assured of "certain weapons systems" if the bill passes the legislature.
But he noted that the passing of the bill would raise the level of Taiwan-United States relations from unofficial to official level, which he said would have severe consequences.

He said that the premise of the TSEA is that the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) does not work well, which is not the case. The TRA is the US law governing unofficial US-Taiwan relations which provides for Taiwan's security through the sale of defensive arms, and other means.

Bush also extended his condolences to the victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake, and lauded Taiwan for its strength and resilience after the tragedy, saying the island's speedy recovery has made a deep impression on the United States.
Bush did not say whether he will visit Taiwan again before the March 18 election, saying only that it is customary for the AIT head to visit Taiwan to attend presidential inaugurations.

This was Bush's fifth visit to Taiwan as AIT head. During his stay in Taiwan, he met with the three major presidential candidates -- Vice President Lien Chan representing the ruling Kuomintang, Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, and independent presidential candidate James Soong.

He also called on President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew, and Chairman Su Chi of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, as well as paying a visit to Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CLARIFIES STANCE ON TAIWAN'S WHO PARTICIPATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US State Department on Tuesday clarified its stance on the Republic of China's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO), saying the United States supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.

State Department deputy spokesman James Foley said at a regular news briefing that the bill that President Bill Clinton signed into law last week does not require the United States to support Taiwan's WHO membership.

Foley said the bill only requires the US secretary of state to submit a report to Congress on the Clinton administration's efforts to "more actively support Taiwan's participation in international organizations, including, in particular, the World Health Organization."

In accordance with its "one China" policy, Foley said, the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in the WHO, or any other international organization that requires statehood as a condition of membership.
Nevertheless, Foley stressed that the United States believes that "the people of Taiwan should be able to contribute to, as well as to benefit from, the work of the WHO."

Foley further said the legislation passed by Congress and signed into law by Clinton relates to enhancing or encouraging Taiwan's participation in international organizations, including the WHO, but says nothing about membership.

While the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood as a condition for membership, Foley went on, the Clinton administration does want to encourage Taiwan's participation in such organizations.

"And we share the overall goal of the legislation, to facilitate appropriate ways for Taiwan to participate in international organizations," Foley said, adding that in fact, the Clinton administration has been working actively to identify appropriate ways for Taiwan's voice to be heard in the WHO and other international organizations from which it is currently barred.
"We have also supported Taiwan's membership in international organizations like the World Trade Organization, where statehood is not an issue," Foley added.

The legislation, initiated by Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-OH), supports Taiwan's "appropriate and meaningful participation" in the WHO, but does not push for Taiwan's full membership in the United Nations-affiliated organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN TO CONTINUE BAN ON CLOVEN-HOOFED ANIMALS FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China-controlled island of Kinmen off the coast of mainland China will maintain a ban on shipments from Taiwan of cloven-hoofed animals, their carcasses, offal or any other fresh products thereof for another six months.
The original six-month ban was imposed in June when several cases of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) were reported on Kinmen, in order to prevent the disease from being transmitted to other animals.
The ban expired on Wednesday, whereupon island authorities decided to extend it for another six months as a further precautionary measure.

The authorities noted that after the June FMD cases were reported, 189 of the island's cattle had to be killed, and stressed that prevention of further cases among cattle, goats and pigs, and careful monitoring of the situation, will continue to ensure the healthy development of Kinmen's livestock industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICE HIKE FOR DOMESTIC FLIGHT TICKETS TO TAKE EFFECT

TEXT.P: Driven up by the increasing price of crude oil, the prices of domestic flight tickets in Taiwan will be raised starting Thursday.
The price hike, announced about one month ago, will see air travel fares around the island and its off-coast isles increase by 14 percent to 68 percent.

The price of a one-way ticket on the busiest route from Taiwan to Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, will be raised from NT$1,409 to NT$1,900 on all air carriers except U-Land Air Lines, whose price will be NT$1,550.
The nearly NT$600 increase has triggered a rush among regular commuters to buy up old tickets, which will remain valid for another month.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CHINA HANDS MEET ON 'ONE CHINA' AND STRATEGIC AMBIGUITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A noted American China hand said on Tuesday that the United States should drop its "strategic ambiguity" stance on its reaction in the event of a military conflict in the Taiwan Strait.

David Shambaugh, director of the China Policy Program at the George Washington University, made the call at a seminar, sponsored by Georgetown University, on the US "one China" and strategic ambiguity policies toward Taiwan Strait issues.

Noting that the US government's "strategic ambiguity" concept is obsolete and needs adjustment, Shambaugh said mainland China believes that the United States would certainly intervene in a cross-strait military confrontation, and has incorporated this factor into its military build-up plans.

As for the "one China" policy, Shambaugh said Taiwan should pursue its own status under this framework. In his opinion, Shambaugh said, neither outright independence nor permanent separation from the Chinese mainland is feasible for Taiwan.
Shambaugh further warned that Taiwan's current practice of gradually moving toward separation might be dangerous and could cause instability in the area.
Nevertheless, Shambaugh was quick to add that Beijing should not ignore Taiwan's dignity and should give it great room in the international arenas.

Shambaugh also said he finds that the opportunities for Taiwan and mainland China to reach a compromise on their disputes are gradually fading away because mainland China is very likely to secure in five years military supremacy that it does not enjoy at the moment.
If Taiwan fails to reach an agreement with mainland China in the next few years, Shambaugh said it would be forced to negotiate with Beijing by then.

Speaking on the same occasion, Robert Kagan, a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, echoed Shambaugh's view that the United States should abandon its "strategic ambiguity" stance.
Kagan said the United States should let Beijing understand a new reality that the United States will help defend Taiwan in the event of a Beijing attack on Taiwan.

However, Larry Wortzei, director of the Heritage Foundation's Asian Studies Program, said it is necessary that the United States maintains an appropriate degree of ambiguity on its possible reaction in the event of a cross-strait war.

Alfred Wilhelm, executive vice president of the Atlantic Council, also said maintaining strategic ambiguity on the US part will be helpful to Taiwan's security because future developments are difficult to predict. "Strategic ambiguity is needed to ensure flexibility in handling related issues," he noted.

Both Wilhelm and Wortzei agreed that cross-strait issues should be resovled by Taiwan and mainland China themselves and that the US obligation lies in stressing that the issues should be resovled by purely peaceful means and in providing an environment conducive to peaceful solution to thorny cross-strait disputes.

Meanwhile, Patrick Cronin, director of the research and policy studies division of the US Institute of Peace, said Washington, Beijing and Taipei are like "three persons traveling in a canoe sailing in a rough, dangerous maritime area. If any of them stands up, the canoe would capsize. This means that if any party forsakes the "one China" policy, Cronin said, the United States, Taiwan and mainland China could all be losers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA: TAIPEI-MANILA AIR LINK WOULD RESUME IF NO RESTRICTION SET
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA): The suspended Taipei and Manila air link will immediately resume if the Philippine side showed a written document to recognize Taipei-Manila Aviation Pact signed in 1996 and no restriction was set, an official of the Civil Aeronautic Administration(CAA) of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications(MOTC) said on Wednesday.

"We have already expressed our stance in a written document addressed to them," MOTC Minister Lin Feng-cheng stressed, adding that the door will always open if the Philippine side accepts our proposal.
He described the statement of Philippine officials who left for home after negotiations broke down as "irresponsible".
Philippine officials said before departing for home that they were fooled by the Taiwanese side for the unsuccessful meeting on Tuesday.

The official further pointed out that if the Philippine side expressed in a written statement without conditions for resumption of the 1996 Taipei-Manila Aviation Pact, the air link between Taiwan and the Philippines will immediately resume.

Delegates from Taiwan and the Philippines resumed talks on the suspended 1996 Taipei-Manila Aviation Pact on Tuesday. However, both parties differred on the sixth flight right for the third destination and the character of the meeting, thus breaking down the meeting.
Taiwan and the Philippines have held third talks on the aviation pact but failed to reach a concrete conclusion, forcing the Philippines to unilaterally abrogate the pact on Oct. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SECURITY CONCERNS AFTER GROUNDING OF MIRAGE PLANES

TEXT.P: An Air Force official on Wednesday affirmed that there is no security problem in safeguarding the nation's territorial space after the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGHQ) grounded all its French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters for thorough safety checks.
You Liao-huo of Hsinchu Air Force Base in northern Taiwan said there are still four aircraft of other types on the base that can be used to conduct interception missions.
The grounding order was issued after a Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter, piloted by squadron leader Chiang Chin-liang, plunged into waters off the northeastern coast of Taiwan at around 10:53 a.m. Tuesday.

Though rescuers have thus far failed to locate the pilot and the aircraft, the Air Force had initially determined that it had crashed and said the cause would be determined after more evidence is collected.

Though the Mirage fighters were grounded, You said four other aircraft on the base can engage in reconnaissance or intercept enemy missions. If necessary, the Air Force will also use Taiwan-made Ching-Kuo indigenous defense fighters (IDF) and US-made F-16 jet fighters to help shoulder the responsibility of guarding air security in the Taiwan Strait.
People in Hsinchu could see flights by fighter jets Wednesday afternoon, but they were IDF planes, not Mirage fighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS ISSUE JOINT STATEMENT OPPOSING PASSAGE OF FARMLAND BILL

TEXT.P: A total of 105 local scholars, led by Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee, issued a joint statement on Wednesday, urging the Legislative Yuan not to deliberate any controversial farmland bills before the 2000 presidential election.

The Cabinet has proposed an agricultural development bill aimed at easing restrictions on the use of farmland to boost agricultural development, while some lawmakers have come up with another version allowing full liberalization of the use of farmland.

Noting that the proposals to liberalize farmland trade and construction of residential houses on newly purchased farmland will not necessarily benefit local farmers, the academics said the legislature should wait until after the next presidential election, scheduled for March 18, 2000, for tackling the controversial farmland liberalization issues.

The statement said the proposed release of a large amount of farmland for commercial or industrial use could probably trigger a dramatic decline in land and housing prices and eventually affect the country's overall economic development.

Moreover, the statement said, farmland trade liberalization could also hinder the country's agricultural development. Stressing that agriculture is critical to a country's overall economic well-being, the statement said the legislature should not mull the issue under political pressure or with any political purposes.
Therefore, the scholars said in the joint statement that they oppose hasty passage of any farmland liberalization bill before the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S FUTURE DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei is optimistic about Taiwan's future development and is in favor of Taiwan joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) as soon as possible, said AmCham President Paul Cassingham on Wednesday.
The head of the business organization made the remark at a year-end press conference held at the Lai-Lai Sheraton Hotel.

Cassingham said that in light of the 2000 presidential election, Taiwan's democratization is quite mature and no matter which candidate is elected as the new leader of Taiwan, AmCham is very optimistic about Taiwan's future development.

AmCham sponsored the press conference to present its goals for the year 2000 and to donate NT$5.68 million to the Tzu Chi Foundation and Puli Christian Hospital to help the two charity organizations' post-quake medical service and reconstruction efforts.

Cassingham said AmCham supports Taiwan in joining the WTO as soon as possible and is optimistic that Taiwan will soon achieve its goal of entering the world trade regulatory body, in light of the recent signing of a bilateral agreement between Washington and Beijing on mainland China's WTO entry.

He said it is expected that both sides of the Taiwan Strait will enter the WTO in the next few months. After Taiwan and mainland China join the WTO, markets in the two economies will further open and there will be greater liberalization, and that is the thing American businessmen are glad to see, he added.
Cassingham declined to comment on issues related to Taiwan's 2000 presidential election, saying AmCham is a business organization and it is not in a position to comment.

However, he added, the United States always encourages political democratization and judging from the 2000 presidential election, Taiwan's democratization is quite mature and no matter which candidate wins the election, AmCham is optimistic about the island's future development.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRONOLOGY OF THE 20TH CENTURY

TEXT.P: Following are some of the major events to have occurred during the 20th century:
1921: The Chinese Communist Party was established.
1922: The Washington conference on disarmament ended with the signing of a treaty limiting armaments for five naval powers.
1923: The Time magazine published its first issue.
1924: In January, a new political party, the Labour Party, came to power under James Ramsay MacDonald in the United Kingdom.

1925: German leader Adolf Hitler's work, "Mein Kampf," which embodied his fascist philosophy, was published. His aggressive policies resulted in the invasion of Poland and the outbreak of World War II.
1926: Benito Mussolini ruled Italy as a dictator. The Fascists organized young people, workers and employers into groups to pledge to support Mussolini, who was called "Il Duce" (The Leader).
1927: "The Jazz Singer," the first sound film to create a sensation, premiered in New York, ending the era of silent films.

1928: Representatives from 15 nations, including the United States and the United Kingdom, signed the "General Treaty of the Renunciation of War" in Paris, a treaty renouncing the use of force in solving international disputes.

1929: The Great Depression began in October when stock values in the United States dropped rapidly. The first Academy Awards, or Oscars, were presented for outstanding achievements in filmmaking during the preceding year.
1930: The first World Cup soccer championship was played in Monstevideo, Uruguay, with players from 13 countries participating. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE NEW HELICOPTERS TO JOIN TRAFFIC CONTROL MISSION NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: Five advanced helicopters, recently procured from France by the National Police Administration (NPA), will join its traffic control effort next month, said an official with the NPA Airborne Squadron on Wednesday.
The official noted that the newly-introduced AS365N helicopters are capable of taking pictures from the sky, and that they will carry out missions over the island's freeway on Jan. 1.

He said that the Airborne Squadron and the National Freeway Police Bureau will enforce traffic regulations from the air and will strengthen broadcast services on traffic and road conditions starting next month, in line with the government's policy to expedite handling of traffic accidents on the freeway and to improve the traffic situation.

The procurement of the five AS365N helicopters, which bring the Airborne Squadron's helicopter fleet to 12, will be deployed from Taipei's Sungshan Airport, Taichung's Shuinan Airport and Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang Airport. (by Victor Lai)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-NEW ZEALAND ECONOMIC CONFERENCE TO OPEN THURSDAY

TEXT.P: A visiting New Zealand official on Wednesday expressed keen interest in further stepping up exports of his country's agricultural products to Taiwan.
John Woods, deputy secretary of New Zealand's External Relations and Trade Ministry, expressed his interest when calling on Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday.

Tallies show that bilateral trade between the Republic of China and New Zealand totaled around US$500 million last year, with New Zealand enjoying a trade surplus, mainly due to that country's abundant exports of dairy and agricultural products to Taiwan.
Woods said he was hoping for continued trade exchanges, while Wang expressed his desire to sign an investment guarantee agreement and establish a ministerial-level consultation channel.
Woods and Wang also exchanged views on the latest round of World Trade Organization talks in Seattle.

Woods is leading a trade delegation here to take part in an ROC-New Zealand economic conference Thursday, which will cover the issues of investment, trade and the signing of a trade guarantee agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREA WILL WELCOME VISIT BY TAIWAN RUGBY TEAM

TEXT.P: South Korea will extend a warm welcome to a goodwill visit by Taiwan's national rugby team next April, Yi Je-hong, president of the South Korean National Rugby Association, said in Taipei on Wednesday.

Yi, accompanied by Tsai Chen-wei, president of the Chinese Taipei Rugby Association, called on Taiwan sports organization leaders, including Huang Wen-chung, vice chairman of the National Sports Council; Huang Ta-chung, president of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee; and Chang Wan-li, president of the National Chinese Athletic Association, to discuss sports exchanges between the nations.

During the meeting, Yi delivered the good news for rugby that the sport has officially been listed among those to be played at the upcoming Asian Games scheduled to be held in Pusan, South Korea, in 2002.
Yi then went to Kaohsiung where he is scheduled to attend the board of directors meeting of the Asian Rugby Confederation on Dec. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT TO ORGANIZE TRADE DELEGATION TO VISIT 4 NATIONS IN S. AMERICA

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) will organize a trade delegation to visit four nations in South America to tap business opportunities there, BOFT Director General Chen Ruey-long said on Wednesday.
Chen said the BOFT will organize a visit by 40 manufacturers to Brazil, Chile, Argentina and Paraguay next March.
Chen said South America has the greatest potential among the world's emerging markets, with nations in that region gradually shedding inflation and demolishing trade barriers.

South American nations are now dedicated to trade liberalization and regional integration, forming such organizations as the Southern Cone Common Market (Mercosur) and discussing the signing of free trade agreements with the United States and the European Union, which has already caused a dramatic increase in South American imports and exports, Chen added.
Brazil, Chile and Argentina are the three top trading partners of the Republic of China in South America, while Paraguay is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in that region.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAD WEATHER PREVENTS SEARCH FOR MISSING MIRAGE FIGHTER
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Bad weather has prevented a rescue mission from searching for the French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter that plunged into waters off the northeastern coast of Taiwan while involved in air-intercept training on Tuesday.

Police said they dispatched two patrol boats Wednesday morning to help search for the ill-fated single-seater Mirage, piloted by Major Chiang Chin-liang of the Taiwan Air Force. However, strong seasonal winds and waves prevented the patrol boats from conducting a search. The patrol boats returned to Suao Port and no signs of the aircraft were reported.
Police said the rescue team will set out again when weather conditions permit.
A task force was formed immediately after the hi-tech jet fighter lost contact with the air base control tower Tuesday.
Police said they called on fishing boats working in the area to help the rescue team search for pilot Chiang and the missing aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: PNG'S CHANGE IN RECOGNITION OF TAIPEI LISTED AS SCANDAL OF 1999

TEXT.P: Being named on the list of the top 10 scandals of the year by the Canadian edition of Time magazine is the price that Papua New Guinea (PNG) must pay for its capricious attitude, said the spokesman of the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Wednesday.

Chen Ming-cheng stated that the ROC had followed the normal procedures of the international community to forge diplomatic ties with PNG, and that the two had formally signed a communique on mutual recognition.

Only because PNG has a new prime minister, it denies all the facts and switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing at the drop of a hat, Chen said. Such capricious engagement with its so-called "friend" can only harm the country itself in the eyes of the international community, he continued.

Two days after forging formal relations with Taipei on July 5 for an alleged ROC loan amounting to US$2.3 billion, Bill Skate, the PNG prime minister who signed the recognition of ties, stepped down in anticipation of facing a no-confidence parliamentary vote.
In a short two weeks after that, a new government was built, and so were its foreign relations.

The top 10 scandals of 1999 listed in the latest Canadian edition of Time include a US congressman's controversial report that accuses Beijing of systematic actions to steal confidential US information relating to making nuclear weapons.
The weekly magazine in its Dec. 20 issue blamed the report for almost triggering a cold war between Washington and Beijing.

The events forcing former Indonesian President B.J. Habibie to withdraw from the presidential race after being exposed for attempted vote-buying, and former German Prime Minister Helmut Kohl's public confession of using money from deposits in a "secret bank account" to help his party win elections while he served as prime minister, were also listed as among 1999's biggest scandals worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER SAYS TAIWAN SHOULD BECOME MORE PROSPEROUS NEXT CENTURY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said in Chiayi City in central Taiwan on Wednesday that Taiwan should become more prosperous and safer in the next century.
He made the remarks while speaking at a gathering of Chiayi's Yushan Rotary Club in his capacity as a club member.

Stating that "politics is not tonight's topic," Siew, who is the running mate of the Kuomintang's presidential nominee Lien Chan, talked about the island's achievements in the past 50 years and its outlook for the next century.

He pointed out that Taiwan has attained a great deal of achievements in political democracy, economic development and social openness in the past half-century, although protection of the environment and of minorities still lags behind.
Siew said that the 21st century will be a century of globalization, full of information and intellectual competition.
He stressed that Taiwan should succeed in leaping onto the international stage in the new century to become "more prosperous and safer, with a better international reputation."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REBUTS SOONG'S CLAIMS ABOUT CASH STASHED IN SON'S BANK ACCOUNT

TEXT.P: Presidential aspirant James Soong's explanation about the huge sum deposited in his son's bank account drew a salvo of disputes and criticism from the ruling Kuomintang on Wednesday.

From KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who dismissed it as "groundless" Wednesday morning, on down, party officials scrambled to deny or contradict Soong's claim that the NT$140 million (US$4.37 million) was deposited in the bank account of his son Soong Chen-yuan on the order of Lee.
Party spokesman Huang Hwi-chen issued a five-point statement Wednesday, questioning the truth of Soong's claim.
In his statement, Huang said:

-- neither the KMT chairman nor the KMT secretary general, the post in which Soong served between 1989 and 1993, was allowed to operate a parallel bank account alongside the party account. This contradicts Soong's claim that the money in question was transferred to his son's bank account from the account of the KMT secretary general.
-- Lee said he didn't know Soong's son and Soong's sister-in-law, and wouldn't have asked Soong to keep the money in two strangers' accounts; and
-- If Lee did ask Soong to take care of Chiang's offspring with the money, why should Soong stash it in the bank accounts of two strangers unrelated to the matter?
Huang said that Lee did ask Soong to raise money to take care of Chiang's family when Chiang's last son died in 1991.

The fund, about NT$100 million, was used to pay for educational fees and the cost of a house for Chiang's descendants, after which only NT$26 million was left, Huang quoted Hsu Li-teh, who served as KMT deputy secretary-general and concurrently chairman of the Finance Committee under Soong, as saying.

Meanwhile, Hsu told a local radio station on Wednesday that the money to take care of Chiang's family was raised from KMT-run firms, and the remainder of it was deposited in an account opened by the KMT Central Committee at the KMT-owned Bank SinoPac, where it remains now.

Hsu, who disputed Soong's claims earlier the day at a meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, told the radio station that he has suggested that KMT authorities look into the source of the money.
Soong, who continued stumping in Pingtung County, remained silent on the criticism Wednesday, saying only that he would explain the misunderstanding to Lee later.

A survey conducted immediately after Soong's explanation on Tuesday night found that he was still supported by 29 percent of those interviewed, despite the fact that 51 percent of respondents considered him as having made mistakes on the whole matter.

Although KMT candidate Lien Chan was favored by only 11.7 percent of respondents, behind the 19.5 percent of Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian, 33.3 percent of those surveyed believed he will win the presidential race, compared to 20.1 percent for Soong, and 7.7 percent for Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 16, or the ninth day of the 11th of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1773: Boston residents dump 342 chests of tea worth 9,000 British pounds aboard a British ship overboard in Boston harbor in the so-called "The Boston Tea Party" incident.
1809: Napoleon Bonaparte divorces Josephine Beauharnais because she is not able to provide him with an heir.
1902: An earthquake racks Turkestan in Central Asia, killing 4,000 people.
1920: An earthquake estimated at over 8 points on the Richter scale devastates Kansu Province in China, killing 180,000 people and becoming one of the worse earthquake disasters of all time.
1921: Charles Camille Saint-Saens, a French composer whose works include operas, such as "Samson et Dalila", symphonies and symphonic poems, including "Dance Macabre," dies in Algiers, Algeria at the age of 86.
1922: Tu Chung-ming graduates from Kyoto University, becoming the first Taiwanese to earn a doctorate during the Japanese occupation of Taiwan.
1944: German troops begin the "Battle of the Bulge" in the Ardennes area of Belgium during World War II.
1949: Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung visits the Soviet Union for the first time.
1962: The United States launches the "Explorer 16" satellite, the first satellite purely for the purpose of meteoric research.
1963: Yen Chia-kan, new premier of the Republic of China, assumes office.
1971: After a war against rebels and their Indian allies, Pakistani forces surrender East Pakistan, which soon becomes the independent nation of Bangladesh.
1971: Foreign Minister S. K. Chow and Bolivian Foreign Minister Dr. Mario R. Gutierrez sign the Sino-Bolivian Scientific Technical Cooperation Agreement and the Sino-Bolivian Scientific Agriculture Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1975: Kang Sheng, deputy chairman of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, dies in Beijing at the age of 77.
1976: The 16-member Korean Pacific Cosmetics Company women's basketball team arrives in Taipei for an 11-day tour.
1976: A nine-member team headed by Hsieh Ching-chung, president of the Republic of China Cycling Association, leaves for Costa Rica to take part in an international marathon race.
1976: Everett Drumright, former US ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo strongly condemns the US decision to sever diplomatic relations with the Republic of China in favor of the Peking regime.
1986: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes revised provisions to laws governing medical doctors to establish a system of full time doctors.
1988: The United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization hold their first meeting in Tunis.
1989: A hijacked Air China plane is forced to land in Japan's Fukuoka airport. Hijacker Chang Chen-hai, who was injured after being pushed off the plane, is arrested by Japanese police.
1991: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan presides over the inauguration ceremony of the South Link Railway.
1991: The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits is set up in Beijing, with Wang Daohan as its chairman.
1992: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl announces 17.6 billion marks (US$11.2 billion) worth of debt relief for Russia.
1995: The presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia sign a peace treaty in Paris, ending years of civil war in the Bosnian region.
1995: British geologists say they have pinpointed the location of the biblical cities of Sodom and Gomorrah on a Dead Sea peninsula.
1996: A South Korean court of appeal reduces the sentences for former President Chun Doo Hwan to life in prison and former President Roh Tae Woo to 17 years in prison on the grounds that they had contributed to the democratic development in South Korea.
Confucius: "You look at how a man acts; consider his motives; find out his tastes. How can a man hide himself; how can he hide himself from you? If a man will constantly go over what he has acquired and keep continually adding to it new acquirements, he may become a teacher of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: US-TAIWAN TEMPORARY TAX-EXEMPTION PACT TAKES EFFECT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The bilateral agreement on temporary admission of goods (ATA) between the United States and Taiwan recently took effect, substantially reducing expenses and paperwork on goods entering each other's country for specific purposes.

The US Customs Bureau on Dec. 2 notified customs offices across the United States about the implementation of the agreement, dubbed the TECRO/AIT Carnet, said Yi-an Lee, director of the Taiwan Trade Center in New York.

The implementation of the TECRO/AIT Carnet, which will significantly reduce costs involving import taxes, pre-arrival deposits, brokerage and related handling fees, will mostly benefit commercial goods for business promotion, specialized professional equipment for academic or cultural activities, and artistic items for exhibition, according to Lee.

Taiwanese individuals or groups planning to ship equipment or goods to the United States for any of the above-mentioned purposes can contact the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council to apply for permission, while Americans planning to bring these types of goods into Taiwan can contact the United States Council for International Business, said Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS 'MYSTERY FUND' ISSUE TO HAVE ADVERSE IMPACT ON SOONG

TEXT.P: The majority of respondents to a recent Gallup poll say they believe that the "mystery fund" episode will have an adverse impact on independent presidential candidate James Soong's bid to win the next presidency.
Gallup Taiwan Co. conducted the telephone poll of 1,095 randomly selected adult residents throughout the island on Dec. 15 at the request of Sanlih Entertainment Television.

According to survey results, 73.4 percent of the respondents said they think that the NT$140 million (US$4.43 million) "mystery fund" deposited in the Chung Hsing Bills Finance Corp. account of Soong's son would have a harmful effect on Soong's presidential bid.

The poll also found that 42.1 percent of those interviewed do not buy Soong's explanation about the source of the "mystery fund." Soong told a Tuesday news conference that the fund was entrusted by President Lee Teng-hui in his capacity as the ruling Kuomintang chairman in 1992 to care for the late President Chiang ching-kuo's family.

Twenty percent of the respondents said they believe Soong's explanation, while 37.8 percent declined to express their opinion as they thought it's not easy to verify whether Soong had told the truth or not.

While President Lee on Wednesday flatly dismissed Soong's explanation as "a pack of nonsense," 38.3 percent said they don't think Lee's comment was true, compared with 19.3 percent who said they believe that Lee was telling the truth. Meanwhile, 42.5 percent said they don't know whether Lee was telling the truth or not.

Survey results further show that 69.8 percent of the respondents believe that the "mystery fund" episode will help boost opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian's presidential bid, and 41.8 percent said they think the incident will benefit KMT candidate Lien Chan's presidential campaign.

The poll also found that Chen for the first time took lead in support rating, with 24.6 percent of those interviewed throwing support behind him. In comparison, 23.8 percent said they would vote for Soong if the presidential election were to take place the following day, and 14.6 percent said they would cast ballots for Lien. Meanwhile, 28.2 percent said they have not yet made a decision on their choice.

On the odds to win the presidential election scheduled for March 18, 2000, 32.8 percent said they think that KMT's Lien would win the election, while 20.3 percent said they have confidence in Soong's success and 13.1 percent said they think DPP's Chen would claim a final victory.
