DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY BUOYANT, MORE INTEREST RATE HIKES SEEN

TEXT.P: Australia's economy grew at an annualized rate of 4.5 percent in September thanks to a strong housing industry and business service sector and rising consumer spending, which is returning to its pre-Asian financial crisis expansion pace.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on Wednesday released figures which show a rise of 1.6 percent in economic growth in the third quarter of this year. The quarter growth translates into a yearly growth rate of 4.5 percent in Australia's gross domestic product, higher than the government's earlier forecast of 3.5 percent.

Economists said that the strong growth was accompanied by low inflation of less than 2 percent and moderate increases in labor wages, and that the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hike its official interest rates again early next year to help prevent the economy from overheating.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S UNITY DEBATE FLARING UP

TEXT.P: Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard on Wednesday night took an unusual step by going on TV to ask all Quebecers to line up behind him in opposing Ottawa's referendum bill.

"I am inviting you to show your support to members of the legislature so we can all, and with a single vote, say to the parliament in Ottawa that only we (Quebecers) can decide on our future," Bouchard said.

Earlier in the day, his cabinet tabled a bill to counter what he called Ottawa's "frontal assault on democracy." He said the federal government's Clarity Bill restricts Quebec's right to choose its own destiny.

Refusing to support the Parti Quebecois bill, opposition Liberal Party leader Jean Charest accused the PQ government of creating "a virtual crisis, an artificial crisis, which only serves its partisan interests."
Charest said Quebecers want the government to concentrate on bread-and-butter issues and he asked people to tell the PQ members of the legislature.
"We must avoid this fresh escalation of an eye for an eye, a bill for a bill, and an ad for ad" about Ottawa and Quebec's public relations battle, he added.
In Ottawa, Canada's "Unity Minister" Stephane Dion said the PQ government is trying to strip Quebecers of their Canadian identity in legislation asserting the province's right to self-determination.
"It's a total negation of the Canadian dimension of Quebecers," Dion said. "This belongs to us. No bill, no law may eradicate our Canadian dimension. We are too proud of it," he stated.
Both Dion and Prime Minister Jean Chretien, the architect behind the tough anti-separation bill, are Quebecers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4TH-QUARTER GROWTH TO BE HIGHER THAN PREVIOUSLY EXPECTED: CIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall economic growth in the fourth quarter of this year is expected to reach 5.37 percent, 0.3 percent higher than previously estimated, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) reported on Thursday.

The private economic think-tank readjusted its quarterly forecast upward after CIER researchers found that the adverse impact on Taiwan's economy of the magnitude 7.3 earthquake which struck on Sep. 21 was lighter than expected.
With the brighter forecast for the fourth quarter, CIER researchers said the annual growth figure for 1999 will be readjusted upward to 5.37 percent from the previous estimate of 5.32 percent.

For the year 2000, the CIER forecasts a whopping growth of 6.17 percent for the first quarter and an average growth of 6.03 percent for the second half of the new year. Meanwhile, it is roughly estimated that growth for the whole year will be 6.05 percent.

CIER researchers in mid-October concluded that the Sept. 21 earthquake would have a tremendously negative impact on the country's economy, prompting them to lower their fourth quarter growth estimates by 1 percentage point to 5.07 percent.
However, they revised the forecast for the fourth quarter and also for the entire year of 1999 after realizing that the impact was not as serious as imagined.

CIER researchers mentioned that what is worth noting is that investment from the private sector grew 13.38 percent in the Oct-Dec. period, marking the first growth in quarterly figures over the last four quarters.
Growth in the private investment sector also helped shore up overall investment growth which hit 10.08 percent in the fourth quarter, the researchers noted.

Meanwhile, the CIER forecasts that Taiwan's currency, the New Taiwan dollar, will gradually appreciate against the US dollar over the next year, with the average ratio posting at NT$31.32 to one US dollar.

With domestic economic activity becoming more brisk and oil prices in the international crude market rising, Taiwan's consumer product index is expected to soar 2.07 percent next year, compared with this year's 0.17 percent, the researchers forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO LAUNCH HIGH-PROFILE PUBLICITY CAMPAIGN FOR Y2K

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Thursday passed a provisional act calling for a publicity campaign and stepped-up efforts to prepare for potential Y2K problems.

Yang Shih-chien, the minister without portfolio in charge of government work detecting and fixing potential Y2K problems, said all governmental offices and related agencies are fully Y2K-compliant, adding that Taiwan has been declared a low-Y2K-risk area by a number of international organizations.
However, he stressed that the Executive Yuan still cannot be too careful about Y2K preparedness, particularly in the private sector.

The just-passed provisional act features five ways for the government to communicate with the public over the next two weeks and assuage any doubts about Y2K compliance, Yang said, adding that the government hopes the general public will cooperate with preparedness directives and any necessary instructions.

The Executive Yuan will run print and television ads over the next two weeks to remind people of possible Y2K-related failures and anomalies, and how and where to get help in case of an emergency, Yang said.
On Dec. 23, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will preside over a press conference where the Executive Yuan Y2K Committee will make a final report on the country's Y2K preparedness.

On Dec. 31, Premier Vincent Siew will make a nationally televised appearance at noon and again in the evening to remind people about possible crises and the country's concerted effort to detect potential emergencies and take appropriate action.
Beginning at 2:00 p.m. on Dec. 31, the Executive Yuan Y2K Information and Contingency Center will become operational until the Y2K rollover has safely passed, Yang said.
At 1:00 a.m. on Jan. 1, Premier Siew will host a press conference to inform the whole country how Taiwan has coped with the Y2K bug.

Fears of the Y2K bug stem from older computer coding systems that signified years using only the last two digits -- "99" for 1999, for example. When the date switches to 2000, some computers with older coding may misinterpret the date to mean 1900, possibly causing the machines to malfunction or even crash, Yang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down 0.7 cent against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 31.647.
The local currency opened Thursday at 31.636 and was traded between 31.633 and 31.648.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$271.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRONOLOGY OF THE 20TH CENTURY

TEXT.P: Following are some of the major events to have occurred during the 20th century:
1931: Japanese troops occupied Mukden in a surprise attack. Important cities in Liaoning and Kirin provinces in Munchuria fell rapidly to the invading Japanese.
1932: Franklin D. Roosevelt won a landslide victory and beat Herbert C. Hoover in the US presidential election.
1933: President Franklin began his program for recovery and reform called the New Deal to end the Depression. He adopted a foreign policy of showing friendliness to other countries.

1934: Adolf Hitler declared himself "der Fuhrer" (the Leader) after the death of Paul von Hindenburg. Hitler destroyed the German constitution and built a dictatorship. He permitted only one political party -- the Nazis.
1935: The German Nazis decreed the law of Nuremberg, abolishing the rights of Jewish citizens. Facing persecution, more than half of Germany's 500,000 Jews left the country.

1936: Spanish army units stationed in Morocco proclaimed a revolution against Spain's government, and rebel leaders chose General Francisco Franco as their commander-in-chief, starting the three-year-long Spanish Civil War.
1937: Japanese troops in night maneuvers near Lukouchiao (Marco Polo Bridge), west of Peiping (Beijing), attacked the city of Wanping, starting war between China and Japan.
1938: Germany occupied Austria and made it part of the Third Reich (Third Empire).
1939: On Sept. 1, Germany invaded Poland and World War II began.
1940: The Allied rescue fleet evacuated about 338,000 troops between May 26 and June 4 from the French seaport of Dunkerque. The remaining Allied troops in Dunkerque surrendered on June 4.
1941: Japan attacked US military bases at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii on Dec. 7, bringing the United States into World War II.
1942: The Nazis ruthlessly murdered about 6 million European Jews and about 5 million Poles, Gypsies and others. Many of them died in Nazi concentration camps.

1943: The tide turned against Germany. The Soviets counterattacked in the east by stopping a massive German tank offensive near the city of Kursk. American and British troops drove the Germans out of North Africa and invaded Italy from the south.

1944: General Dwight D. Eisenhower chose Monday, June 5 as D-Day -- the date of the Normandy invasion. Troops from the United States, Britain, Canada and France stormed ashore a 60-mile front in the largest seaborne invasion in history.
1945: An atomic bomb was dropped on Nagasaki on Aug. 9 following an earlier one which was dropped on Hiroshima on Aug. 6, ending World War II.
1946: The United Nations was established with its headquarters in New York.
1947: US Secretary of State George C. Marshall organized the European Recovery Program, often called the "Marshall Plan" for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER, FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices declined 1.5 percent on Thursday as foreign funds' intensive selling in the previous trading session triggered panic as local investors feared fund managers would dump shares as the year 2000 draws near.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 120.13 points lower at 7,739.76, falling below the quarterly average, and turnover expanded to NT$156.58 (US$4.95 billion), with 3.15 billion shares changing hands, of which selling greatly exceeded buying by 28 million shares.
The market opened firmer as sentiment was buoyed by Wall Street's overnight gains and the government's move to allow the nation's four major pension funds to increase their investments in stocks.
But market confidence was undermined by heavy sell-offs by foreign institutional investors, who had been net buyers for 15 consecutive sessions, causing the index to fall more than 1.5 percent.

According to dealers, investors feel safer holding onto cash before the stock market closes for the year, and the index should head down in the near term as the market loses direction in the absence of foreign investors who close their books for 1999 in mid-December.

All eight major stock categories posted losses, with the cement sector suffering from the largest losses of 3.6 percent; foodstuff issues, textile shares and financial stocks also posted serious losses greater than 3 percent.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 351 to 140, with 65 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market edged down 0.81 point to close at 187.91 on a turnover of NT$15.1 billion.

All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted serious losses in line with the undesirable performance of the stock market, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved down 130 points to close at 7,795 with 2,224 contract transactions. Those for February declined 104 points to finish at 7,820 with 19 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March dipped 77 points to close at 7,900 with 12 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,925 points for January, 7,924 points for February, 7,977 points for March, 8,090 points for next June, and 7,987 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported losses.
January TE futures shed 3.05 points to close at 397.95 with 882 contract transactions, and March TE futures moved up 15 points to finish at 399 with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.
January TF futures dropped 30 points to close at 928 with 228 contract transactions; no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA FORESEES GOOD ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE IN 2000

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said it foresees good economic performance next year resulting from Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), steady growth of foreign trade and increased investments by the private sector.
A study by the MOEA research and development department also predicted that mainland China's economy will continue to grow amid some uncertain factors for the future.

The same study shows that Taiwan's WTO entry, steady growth of foreign trade, and investment increases by both the public and private sectors will be key factors in Taiwan's continued economic grow in the year 2000.

The study also shows that Taiwan's local economic structure should be readjusted to adapt to the new situation resulting from the anticipated accession of Taiwan and mainland China to the WTO. The readjustment would not only shock the domestic economy but would also bring opportunities to it.
The issuance of NT$80 billion in public bonds for the reconstruction of earthquake-stricken areas in central Taiwan will stimulate increased investment by the public sector, the study shows.

The eighth naptha cracking plant project, a series of syndicated industrial and commercial parks, the proposed high-speed railway project and liberalization of the telecommunications industry will stimulate increased investments by the private sector, the study added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROCER DONATES LAND FOR HOSPITAL CONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: An elderly grocer in Chinshan, a coastal township in Taipei County, has donated a large tract of land to accommodate a hospital to be built and operated by National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital.
Cheng Yu-lu, 65, presented the ownership certificate for his 1,926-ping (53.5-square-foot) property to NTU Hospital President Lee Chen-yuan in a ceremony held on Friday.
Addressing the audience at the ceremony, Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang said he appreciates Cheng's generosity in donating family assets for public use.

The hospital president also expressed his gratitude to Cheng, saying his generous move has helped the hospital realize its long-time plan to open a branch in the Chinshan area to offer convenient medical services to local residents.
For his part, Cheng said he feels no regret in donating the land, which he had inherited from his ancestors. Cheng said he used to harvest water bamboo on the land to support his family.

But now, Cheng said, all of his four children have grown up and established their own careers. Cheng and his wife now operate a grocery business. Since income from the grocery is enough to cover their daily expenses, Chen said he has stopped water bamboo cultivation and decided to donate the land for hospital construction.
"My family fully supports my decision," Cheng said, adding that he believes the souls of his ancestors would also back the donation.
As there is no large hospital in the Chinshan area, Cheng said many of his neighbors often have to make long trips to Keelung or Tamsui to receive medical treatment.
"So I'll be glad to see a hospital inaugurated in my hometown in the near future," Cheng said.
Official tallies show that there are only about a dozen private clinics in the island's four northernmost townships -- Chinshan, Wanli, Shihmen and Sanchi, also known as the North Beach area.

NTU Hospital President Lee said the hospital has long planned to build a branch in the area to serve its 70,000-plus residents. Taiwan Power Co., a state-owned enterprise, has agreed to offer NT$800 million to help finance the hospital project. "With the land donated by Cheng, I believe that the project will proceed smoothly," Lee noted.

According to Lee, the new Chinshan hospital will have 200 beds for in-patients as well as out-patient and emergency departments. NTU Hospital will send medical professionals and administrative staff to operate the new facility.
"If all goes smoothly, the Chinshan hospital will become operational in March 2002," Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BECOMES OBSERVER OF CENTRAL AMERICAN PARLIAMENT SPEAKERS FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Central American nations on Wednesday unanimously adopted a resolution to allow the Republic of China to become a permanent observer of the Central American Parliament Speakers Forum (CAPSF).
Speakers or deputy speakers of the parliaments of Panama, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Belize, Nicaragua and Guatemala passed the resolution at the CAPSF's ninth meeting, held in Panama.

The ROC application to join the CAPSF as an observer was at the top of the agenda. In addition to offering unanimous approval, representatives from the seven nations of Central America also stressed that ROC participation in the CAPSF will be conducive to the promotion of cooperation among the nations.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the CAPSF, Panamanian First Vice President Arturo Vallarino and Panamanian Parliament Speaker Enrique Garrido said the transfer of control of the Panama Canal from the United States to Panama is closely related to regional development as a whole, and they believe each Central American nation will actively participate in Panama Canal affairs in the future.

Wang Jin-pyng, the president of the ROC Legislative Yuan, who is on a tour of Panama, said he, on behalf of the ROC, had the honor of joining the CAPSF meeting and expressed the ROC's resolved willingness to take part in the forum.

Wang also thanked the Central American nations for their full support of the ROC after the 921 Earthquake that caused severe life and property losses in central Taiwan, saying the sincere friendship established between the ROC and the Central American nations provides proof of the proverb that "a friend in need is a friend indeed."

He indicated that the ROC and the Central American nations have maintained a long and close diplomatic relationship. In addition to consensus on the upholding of democracy, freedom and people's welfare, both sides have in common firsthand experience in the development of politics, culture and society, and they assist each other in economic, trade and technological development, he added.

Wang told the parliament speakers of the Central American nations that in the hope of seeking and expanding room in the international community for the ROC, the nation has been pushing for political democratization, economic and trade development, as well as pragmatic diplomacy in recent years, and such efforts have borne fruit.

Wang invited representatives attending the CAPSF meeting to visit the ROC and proposed that next year's meeting be held in Taipei. The proposal was welcomed by the representatives and will be discussed at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MADAME CHIANG KAI-SHEK KNOWS NOTHING ABOUT SOONG MONEY SCANDAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By David Wang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, a former Republic of China first lady, has no knowledge of the financial scandal involving Taiwan's independent presidential candidate James Soong, her closest relatives said here on Wednesday.

Kung Ling-yi, a niece of Madame Chiang, was responding to statements made by Soong at a Taipei news conference on Tuesday that ROC President and ruling Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui instructed Soong in 1992 to set up a fund to care for the widow and children of former President Chiang Ching-kuo, one of Madame Chiang's sons.
Kung told CNA in a telephone interview that she "feels regret" at seeing Soong in dispute with the KMT leadership over the issue.

Kung and her husband, Huang Hsiung-sheng, who have been responsible for taking care of Madame Chiang for the past 24 years, said they would not let their 102-year-old aunt know anything about the current KMT-Soong squabble.

"We don't want Madame Chiang to be bothered by such things," Kung said, adding that Madame Chiang has led a peaceful, reclusive life in New York for most of the 24 years since President Chiang Kai-shek died in 1975.
Over the past years, Kung said, Madame Chiang has never involved herself in Taiwan's politics, nor has she received any financial subsidies from Taipei.

"The only things that Madame Chiang has received from Taipei are notices from the KMT concerning various party conferences," Kung said, adding that Madame Chiang is still a member of the presidium of the KMT's Central Advisory Committee.
Kung further said she doesn't know whether any of the offspring of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo have received financial assistance from the KMT.

"Nobody has told us about that, and we can't make any comment on behalf of Chiang Ching-kuo's offspring," Kung said, adding that she did not think that Madame Chiang herself has any knowledge of the alleged KMT financial assistance.
Madame Chiang currently lives in an apartment in Manhattan. Its annual rental plus tax and management fees amounts to US$100,000, which is footed by Kung and her husband.

Sources close to the Chiang family said the ROC government has paid for aides, nurses and security personnel who serve Madame Chiang's apartment in accordance with its law governing privileges for widows of the country's late heads of state. Madame Chiang herself, however, has not received any government financial support.
Born Soong May-ling in 1898, Madame Chiang became widely known in the West as a diplomat and spokeswoman for the Chinese cause against the invading Japanese in the 1930s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland in 1949, the ROC government, under the leadership of Chiang Kai-shek, moved its seat to Taiwan and Chiang and his US-educated wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT PROMISES TO VISIT ROC NEXT YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso has accepted an invitation from Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui to visit Taiwan next year, a visiting ROC parliamentary leader said here on Wednesday.
Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, the ROC's parliament, made the statement after meeting with Moscoso.
Wang said he conveyed President Lee's invitation to Moscoso during their one-hour meeting.

"President Moscoso has accepted the invitation," Wang said, adding that the schedule and other details concerning the Panamanian president's Taipei visit will be worked out after further consultations between the two sides.
Wang told Moscoso that an ROC business delegation just concluded a fact-finding visit to Panama to study the feasibility of investing in a cross-ocean bridge to be built near the Panama Canal.
After a careful evaluation, Wang said ROC business groups may join an international bidding for the project.
Wang further told Moscoso that the ROC will seek investment opportunities to take part in development projects in the Panama Canal area.

Wang, who led a group of ROC legislators to attend a meeting of the Central American Parliament Speakers Forum, also exchanged views with Moscoso on measures to promote ROC-Panamanian cooperation in education, public health, environmental protection, agriculture and shipping services during their hour-long meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CARDINAL CATEGORICALLY DENIES VATICAN-BEIJING TIES

TEXT.P: Cardinal Paul Shan on Thursday categorically denied reports that the Vatican will soon set up diplomatic ties with Beijing.

The Roman Catholic Bishop of Taiwan District said that the Vatican and Beijing have not yet set up a mechanism for future negotiations, and added that the Vatican will not consider setting up diplomatic ties with Beijing until the regime's religious and human rights persecution has improved greatly.
Shan said that the Vatican has not informed him of the establishment of diplomatic ties between the Vatican and Beijing. "No news is good news," he pointed out.

He expressed his belief that the news was leaked by the Beijing regime with the aim of luring mainland China's more than 10 million Catholics to join the Beijing's official Catholic organization, The Patriotic Catholic Church.

He went to say that the Vatican knows that Beijing wants to set up diplomatic ties with the Vatican so as to control the mainland's Catholics. Beijing does not recognize the official Catholic Church, and insists that only communist authorities can appoint bishops in mainland China.
Shan stressed that the news was released by pro-Beijing sympathizers with the purpose of building a good image for the stalemated Vatican-Beijing ties.

He warned however that a wave of pro-Beijing feeling is mounting in the Holy See, and said that the Vatican might set up diplomatic relations with Beijing at the expense of Taiwan if the Vatican decides that human rights and the religious persecution in mainland China has improved.

Nevertheless, the cardinal stressed that the Vatican will send a representative, a position higher than that of charge d'affaires, to be stationed in Taiwan, signifying that the Vatican will not neglect the existence of the more than 300,000 Catholics in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER, GENERAL ELECTRIC FORGE E-COMMERCE JOINT VENTURE

TEXT.P: Taiwan computer giant Acer and the US-based General Electric Co. forged a joint venture on Thursday to explore the Asian e-commerce market.
Acer Digital Services Corp. (ADSC) and GE Information Services (GEIS), clinched the deal worth US$14 million at a ceremony in Taipei.

The new firm, in which Acer and GE will hold an 85 percent and 15 percent stake, respectively, expects to become Asia's largest e-commerce services-oriented company in two or three years, providing an efficient purchasing environment through the Internet to help businesses reduce production costs, according to ADSC President George Huang.

Due to Asia's role in global trade, GEIS is very optimistic about the future of e-commerce in Asia, said GEIS Vice President Ignatius Wei, expressing the belief that the formation of the partnership between ADSC and GEIS will enable both to further expand their existing market shares in this part of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINESE AUTHORITIES ACCUSED OF HARASSING RIGHTS GROUP IN HK

TEXT.P: Frank Lu, founder of a human rights group in Hong Kong, said Thursday that he plans to go to Macau Sunday to stage a public protest against mainland Chinese official harassment of his office by anonymous phone calls.

Lu, who founded the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China in 1993, said the telephone lines of his office have been jammed by numerous harassing phone calls from the mainland since May.

The 35-year-old dissident, who was a student leader during the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement, fled to Hong Kong in 1993 and established the center in the same year. The information center has been a major source of information on human right violations in mainland China since 1996.

The information center said Thursday that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin gave an order in March "to cut off Lu's sources of information as soon as possible." From May to October, his office received about 100 harassing phone calls from the mainland every day. The number jumped to about 1,000 per day at the end of October, because the office issued a lot of news about government crackdown on the Falun Gong sect, which was outlawed in July. The harassment is still going on.

Lu will stage the public protest on the eve of Macau's handover to mainland China, hoping that Jiang, who will officiate the handover celebration, will take notice of the protest, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER F-16 SQUADRON COMMISSIONED
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, Eastern Taiwan, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Thursday inaugurated another F-16 squadron at an air base in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

Presiding over the commission of the new squadron, which is also the second to be based at the Hualien base, Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min urged air force personnel to pay special attention to flight safety at a time when advanced fighters are being introduced to the air force.
The next squadron of the US-made fighters is scheduled to be commissioned early next year, also in Hualien.

Taiwan in 1992 struck a deal to purchase 150 F-16 MLUs (mid-life-upgrade) fighters from the United States, but since March 1998, it has lost four of them, and two of the 60 Mirage 2000-5s it bought from France, in a series of crashes.
Taiwan is demanding compensation from Pratt & Whitney, the US maker of the engines that power the F-16s, alleging that an Aug. 15 crash was caused by engine malfunction.
The F-16s and the Mirage 2000-5s, together with the locally developed IDFs (Indigenous Defense Fighters) now form the backbone of Taiwan's new generation fleet of jet fighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE WINE FROM SINGAPORE TO HIT TAIWAN SHELVES IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: The first batch of 5 million bottles of rice wine imported from Singapore are expected to enter Taiwan in January, the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) announced on Thursday.

The Singapore-made rice wine will arrive in Taipei around Jan. 20 as part of the TTWB's efforts to ease traditional strong demand for rice wine in the local market prior to the coming lunar new year holiday in February, said TTWB Director-General Shih Yen-shiang.

With the imports from Singapore, the TTWB from February will be able to supply at least 2.5 million cases of rice wine each month -- up from the previous maximum capacity of 2.1 million cases per month -- to satisfy public demand, Shih added.

Demand for locally produced rice wine has surged since November with the approach of winter and Taiwan's expected entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) next year, which will see the price of locally made "red-label" rice wine -- currently NT$24 per bottle -- rocket to NT$185 per bottle in line with WTO regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOLUME OF PASSENGERS' AND CARGO CARRYING RISE IN CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The volume of passengers and cargo handled by Chiang Kai-shek International Airport registered steady growth in the first five months of 1999, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEDP).

The statistics show that a total of 6.94 million passengers passed through the airport during the January-May period, ranking it ninth in the Asia-Pacific region, or one position up from last year in terms of handling volume.
During the same period, a total of 390,000 metric tons of cargo were handled by the airport, ranking 16th in the world and fifth in the Asian-Pacific region.
However, both passenger and cargo carrying volume lagged far behind the main airports of the four "Asian dragons."

In terms of cargo, Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok Airport topped the list with 720,000 metric tons, followed by Japan's Narita Airport at 710,000 metric tons, and Korea's Kimpo Airport at 630,000 metric tons.
Fourth place went to Singapore's Changi Airport, with 570,000 metric tons of goods handled.

In terms of passenger volume, Japan's Haneda Airport topped the list with a total of 21.24 million passengers, followed by Kimpo at 13.25 million, and trailed by Chek Lap Kok at 11.90 million passengers.
CKS was behind Thailand's Bangkok Airport, Changi, Narita, Australia's Sydney Airport and Japan's Kansei Airport but was ahead of Beijing's Metropolitan Airport.
CEDP forecast that CKS handling capacity will be greatly increased after a second-stage expansion project for the airport is completed.

Meanwhile, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), Taiwan's airports handled a total of 1,181,000 metric tons of cargo during the January-October period of 1999, an increase of 10.5 percent over the previous year, of which CKS handled 1,099,000 metric tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-NEW ZEALAND TRADE CONFAB OPENS

TEXT.P: The seventh ROC-New Zealand trade consultation conference opened here on Thursday, with the two sides agreeing to ink accords in several fields.

During the meeting, the New Zealand side announced that Wellington has completed the screening of several reports by the World Trade Organization (WTO) related to Taiwan's bid to join the world trade regulatory body, and expressed its support for Taiwan's membership in the WTO at an early date.

The Republic of China delegation, led by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Chen Ruey-long, and the New Zealand delegation, headed by the deputy secretary of the External Relations and Trade Ministry, also agreed to clinch agreements on bilateral investment guarantees, and protection of intellectual property rights and industrial products.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCH INSTITUTE: TAIWAN'S GROWTH RATE MAY REACH 6.8% NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Chung Hua Institute for Economic Research said on Thursday that Taiwan's real economic growth rate next year may reach 6.79 percent if annual exports can increase by NT$24 billion (US$750 million).

Institute researcher Chen Yuan-po told reporters that the basic growth rate for 2000 is predicted at 6.05 percent, a figure similar to the forecasts of other Taiwan research institutes. However, he went on, the figure might be higher if the economic performances of the United States and Japan continue to improve and spark increased exports from Taiwan.

Under those conditions, he said, the private sector's consumption will increase 6.16 percent, while private investment will go up 11.41 percent, while the value of Taiwan's currency will also rise to an exchange rate of NT$31 to the greenback.
The Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics predicts a 6.04 percent growth rate for next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOEING MAY COOPERATE WITH TAIWAN AIR CARRIERS

TEXT.P: US aircraft manufacturer Boeing Co. is likely to cooperate with Taiwan air carriers to refurbish passenger planes as cargo planes to meet market demand, a Boeing official revealed on Thursday.

The official made the remark shortly after the world's largest airliner manufacturer announced a new project under which it will procure 44 in-service passenger planes, refurbish them as cargo carriers, and then lease them to DHL Corporation, a world-renowned air freight company.

Several of Taiwan's major airlines, such as China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways Corp., as well as Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC), Taiwan's only aircraft manufacturer, are keenly interested in the proposed cooperative project with Boeing, the official said.
He said CAL, EVA Airways and AIDC plan to engage in the refurbishing of passenger aircraft in Taiwan and the Asia-Pacific area into cargo transporters by forging strategic alliances with Boeing.

The official added that Boeing is currently studying the feasibility of the idea. "In addition to Taiwan companies, Boeing is also working to negotiate similar projects with its counterparts in other countries and areas," he noted.

Aviation industry sources said the air freight business is expected to grow gradually to equal passenger transport business, so that more and more airlines will be eyeing international air freight markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Independent presidential candidate James Soong allegedly opened secret personal bank accounts during his stint as KMT secretary-general.
The China Times:
Soong clarifies that the KMT funds for caring for the Chiang family and for unidentified party operations total NT$240 million, not NT$140 million as previously claimed.
The United Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang is stepping up efforts to probe Soong-related money dealings.
The Liberty Times:
Soong allegedly used secret personal seal for issuing two checks worth a total of NT$140 million for deposits at his son's and his sister-in-law's accounts.
The China Post:
Rumors fly over Soong cash; more skeletons expected.
The Taiwan News:
Scandal focusing on 'party tasks'; KMT officials deny allegations Soong funds linked to previous KMT-DPP cooperation.
The Taipei Times:
Soong camp adds new twist to 'money' story.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS AS 9TH BIGGEST US CAR EXPORT MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked as the United States' ninth biggest car export market in the first 10 months of this year, according to statistics released Thursday by the US Department of Commerce (DOC).

DOC statistics showed that in the first 10 months of this year, the top three US automakers -- General Motor, Ford and Chrysler -- exported a total of US$116 million worth of cars to Taiwan, a decrease of 20 percent over the same period last year.
The top 10 biggest US car export markets in the first 10 months of this year were Canada, Mexico, Germany, Japan, Britain, Belgium, Saudi Arabia, Australia, Taiwan and Sweden, the statistics showed.
In the January-October period, US car exports to Taiwan decreased US$29 million compared with the same period last year. Taiwan was the seventh biggest export market for American cars last year.

DOC figures also revealed that Taiwan was placed the seventh position in terms of exports of auto parts to the US in the first 10 months of this year, behind Mexico, Canada, Japan, Germany, Brazil and Britain.
During the 10-month period, the United States bought a total of US$974 million worth of auto parts from Taiwan, an increase of 16.2 percent over the same period last year, the figures showed.

The DOC said that in the first 10 months of this year, US vehicle exports (including cars, trucks and auto parts) to Taiwan totaled US$202 million, while the value of these imports into the US from Taiwan amounted to US$1.013 billion, with Taiwan enjoying a surplus of US$811 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SUBSIDIZE CANADIAN MAGAZINES

TEXT.P: The Canadian government announced Thursday the establishment of the Canadian Magazine Fund which will provide C$150 million (US$102 million) to Canadian magazine publishers over the next three years.

The fund was set up after the government unsuccessfully tried to bring in a bill to keep Canadian editions of foreign magazines known as "split-runs" out of the country. Under US pressure, Canada backed down from its position and instead went the subsidy route.
The bulk of the magazine fund will go to publishers who create Canadian stories -- whose publications contain 80 percent or more Canadian editorial content.

Some money will be available for professional development, adapting to new technology, marketing and distribution. Funding will also be available to strengthen the infrastructure of the publication industry across the country.
The subsidy is the final chapter in the protracted magazine dispute that threatened to escalate into a full-scale trade war between Canada and the US last spring.
Under a compromise worked out in May, American publishers who produce Canadian magazines -- known as split-runs -- can print up to 18 percent Canadian advertising per issue.

Canadian publishers remain concerned that split-runs will skim off critical Canadian advertising dollars at little cost to the American publishers whose production costs have already been covered by their US run.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SAID LIKELY TO DEFEND TAIWAN, BUT RELUCTANT TO PROVOKE PRC

TEXT.P: In a full-blown conflict, the United States would probably not abandon Taiwan outright as it is strategically too essential to US policy in the region, but Washington will clearly do what it can to dampen independence sentiments on Taiwan, according to a Global Intelligence Update published Thursday.

Stratfor, Inc., a private global intelligence services company based in Austin, Texas, wrote in the analysis that the US has issued an unofficial ultimatum to Taiwan's presidential contenders not to provoke Beijing any further or risk losing US support.
"By doing so, Washington has announced that it wants no crisis during the upcoming US presidential campaign," said the report.
More importantly, the analysis said, Washington fears that Beijing may turn up pressure on Taiwan to deflect attention from its own economic and social problems.

On Dec. 15, Richard Bush, managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, sent a very clear message to Taiwan's presidential front-runners, stating that "if the new administration's policies converge with ours, then there won't be a problem. If they do not, then we will discuss the differences in a spirit of friendship." He added that the US will adhere to the "one China" policy.

Bush's statements revealed two important elements in the US position. First, Washington's interests demand continued peace in the Taiwan Straits. Second, Washington sees Communist China as increasingly cantankerous and unstable, ready to pounce if provoked, according to the analysis.

Stratfor, Inc. pointed out that Bush's statements make clear that the United States is reluctant to see cross-strait tensions escalate. The year 2000 is also an election year in the United States and China has already become a hot topic because of espionage and campaign finance scandals.

In economic terms as well, the United States does not want tension to burn the bridges that connect US business interests to mainland China. The United States has just reached an agreement with China that paves the way for the latter's entry into the World Trade Organization. Washington does not want a conflict to trip up the agreement before American investors reap the economic benefits of access to mainland China.

The United States also wants to maintain peace as the waters between mainland China and Taiwan are the most important shipping route in the region, said the analysis. A cross-strait conflict could halt the flow of trade through the region, potentially endangering Asia's faltering export-driven economic recovery. And if Beijing were to control these waters, Communist China could effectively control the region.

The analysis also mentions that Washington senses that Communist China is on edge and could very easily respond to any provocation with hostility. Moreover, China will regain control over Macau later this month, freeing Beijing to focus its efforts on Taiwan, one of its last unresolved territorial issues.

Washington may be sensing as well that confrontation with Taiwan could be a handy release valve for pressures building up within mainland China. A nationalistic campaign to recover what is viewed as a renegade province could successfully distract the mainland Chinese people from the economic malaise that has triggered over 60,000 protests this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 17, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: Pope Paul III excommunicates King Henry VIII of England.
1718: England declares war on Spain.
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy, and appoints Ting Ju-chang as commander-in-chief.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: School opens at The National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the first sustained flight over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, in a heavier-than-air vehicle they invented. It is the first successful airplane flight in history.
1909: Belgium's King Leopold II, who succeeded his father in 1868 and established the Congo Free State (now the Demoratic Republic of Congo), dies at the age of 70.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can," and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1939: "Graf Spree," a German battleship, is scuttled off Uruguay by its captain to prevent it from falling into British hands in World War II.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war with India in control of East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (former Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-Republic of China Association, arrives for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique pleading further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC taking part.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the US embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of US forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: Some 20 Tupac Amaru guerrillas take hundreds of diplomats and government officials hostage and demand the release of 300 imprisoned comrades after seizing the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, Peru.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES 30 MACEDONIAN-MADE BUSES TO KOSOVO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has purchased 30 Macedonian-made buses to donate to the Yugoslavian province of Kosovo, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Friday.

Kao An, an official with MOFA's European Affairs Department, said the bus donation is part of the US$300 million aid package to the war-torn Yugoslav province announced by President Lee Teng-hui earlier this year.
Kao said the ROC embassy in Macedonia signed a purchase contract with the Macedonian National Bus Co. in August during an official visit to the Balkan state by ROC Premier Vincent Siew.
According to the contract, the 30 buses are worth a total of US$2.34 million.

Kao said the first batch of 10 buses were delivered in late November, adding that more than 100 dignitaries, including Macedonia's foreign minister and science-technology minister, as well as Kosovo's provincial bus bureau chief, attended the delivery ceremony held at the ROC embassy in the Macedonian capital of Skopje.
The remaining 20 buses are scheduled to be delivered on Dec. 20, Kao said. Each bus has 36 seats plus space for 64 standing passengers.
Kao pointed out that the donation signifies the ROC's goodwill toward Kosovo, which borders Macedonia, one of the ROC's two diplomatic allies in Europe.
Moreover, he went on, the deal will also help Kosovo ease its shortage of mass transportation vehicles, as well as help increase the business volume of Macedonia's state-run bus manufacturing firm.

"We believe this deal is in the interest of all three parties -- the ROC, Macedonia and Kosovo," Kao said, adding that the ROC hopes this deal will have a positive effect on ROC relations with both Macedonia and Kosovo.
Kao further said the ROC will continue to implement other programs included in the US$300 million Kosovo-related aid package.
The ROC forged formal diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January this year, making the southern Balkan state Taiwan's second ally in Europe after the Vatican.
