DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved down one cent to close at 31.657 against the greenback on Wednesday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.
The currency opened at the day's high of 31.635, and had a low of 31.663. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$210 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES EDGE DOWN, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices edged down 0.2 percent on Friday, as investors ignored the latest Wall Street rally and remained on the sidelines as the New Year approaches.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 16.54 points lower at 7,723.22, on a turnover of NT$131.99 (US$4.17 billion), with 2.73 billion shares changing hands.

The market opened firm as sentiment was buoyed by an index surge in electronics shares, financial issues and chemical and plastic stocks, but ended lower as confidence waned due to fears of big fund selling in the final days before 2000.
According to dealers, investors will remain cautious up to the year's final trading day on Dec. 28.

All eight major stock categories posted losses, with the exception of the chemical and plastics sector, which enjoyed a gain of 1.1 percent. The losses ranged from 0.1 percent in the case of electronics shares, to 1.2 for textile issues.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 287 to 197, with 73 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 2.33 points to close at 190.24, on a turnover of NT$16.5 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted mixed results, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 21 points to close at 7,816, with 1,533 contract transactions. Those for February advanced 29 points to finish at 7,849, with 13 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March dipped 34 points to close at 7,866, with 32 contract transactions, while those for June climbed two points to finish at 7,927, with four contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,795 points for January, 7,820 points for February, 7,900 points for March, 7,925 points for next June, and 7,857 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported gains.
January TE futures rose 0.95 points to close at 398.9, with 600 contract transactions, while no transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

January TF futures climbed two points to close at 930, with 143 contract transactions. March TF futures hiked 61 points to close at 933.4, with nine contract transactions, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TTWB DENIES IMPORTED RICE WINE WILL COME FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Rice wine which is to be imported to Taiwan from Singapore to overcome a shortfall in domestic production capacity will not be produced in mainland China, the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) said on Friday.

TTWB officials noted that the winning bidder, Far East Distillers Pte. Ltd. of Singapore, will have to include a certificate of place of origin when it exports the rice wine to Taiwan, which will have to be reviewed before the wine gets import approval.
Local reports have noted that Far East Distillers is only a trading company, and have claimed that while Singapore is noted for its "Tiger" beer, it "cannot possibly" produce rice wine.
The mass-circulation United Daily News said the imported rice wine might be produced in the mainland, Thailand or Cambodia, where it is also popular.

TTWB officials pointed out that current regulations ban mainland alcohol products from being importing into Taiwan. Furthermore, foreign bidders have to present samples and certificates of place of origin in order to qualify to take part in the bidding.
The officials said that if the Singapore rice wine was from the mainland, they would not have been be allowed to even take part in the bidding, let alone win the contract.

The TTWB decided to address the domestic production shortfall by importing 15 million bottles of rice wine from Singapore, with the first batch of five million bottles arriving around Jan. 20, in time for the increasing demand around the lunar New Year, which falls on Feb. 5, 2000.

The officials noted that the taste and the flavor of the imported rice wine is similar to that of the local red label rice wine, a local kitchen staple, after they tested it by preparing rice wine chicken, a popular winter dish that requires a lot of rice wine.
They said local rice wine, which is currently sold at NT$24 per bottle, is bottled in brown glass, while the imported product, which will be sold at NT$24 or lower, is packaged in white PE bottles.

In anticipation of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, when the red label rice wine will be classified as a distillate, with a resulting high tax levy, many people have begun hoarding the local product, resulting in serious shortages which has forced the TTWB to adopt rationing measures.
The situation has been exacerbated with the coming of winter, when local people use rice wine much more frequently to prepare warming soups and stews.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUTUAL RESPECT KEY TO CHINA'S UNIFICATION: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met on Friday with foreign participants in the second general meeting of the Asia-Pacific Security Forum, to whom he stated the ROC's consistent efforts in the pursuit of stable cross-strait relations.

Lee told the visitors at the Presidential Office that only if Taipei and Beijing each respect the "fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are currently ruled by two separate governments with no attachment to one another, whereby two equitable political entities coexist," can they overcome their political differences and jointly develop their relations to benefit the peaceful unification of China.

Only if this fact is faced can the two sides engage in talks on an equal footing, Lee said, adding that this is the reason he put forward the "special state-to-state relationship" theory on July 9 to explain the current cross-strait situation.

The president said that the ROC government believes stable cross-strait relations is the key to maintaining peace in the Asia-Pacific region. Therefore, it consistently promotes a pragmatic cross-strait policy, he added.

He pointed out that the ROC in 1991 renounced the use of military force to solve the cross-cross dispute, and has since gradually relaxed bans on exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland in the hope of setting up a basis for cross-strait cooperation.
Despite the fact that Beijing has never made any goodwill response to Taipei's efforts, the ROC will continue its efforts to ease cross-strait, Lee said.

During the meeting, Lee also outlined his opinions on regional security, saying that the mutual military alliance headed by the United States plays an important role, and cited the increasing expansion of the US-Japan security mechanism in the Asia-Pacific region as evidence of this.

DOC.HEADLINE: SET UP IMPORT RELIEF FUND TO HELP FARMERS, URGES LIEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Friday the government should set up a NT$100 billion "import damage relief fund" to help local farmers cope with challenges brought by the Republic of China's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Lien, also the ruling Kuomintang's standard-bearer in the 2000 presidential election, made the statement at the opening ceremony of a joint annual meeting of domestic agricultural associations.

Noting that local farmers will face global competition in the domestic agricultural market following Taiwan's imminent WTO entry, Lien said the government should set aside enough funds to help those who are hurt by agricultural imports.

On the other hand, Lien said the government should help local farmers upgrade their competitiveness. "To reach this goal, we must push for agricultural reengineering, including production adjustment, ecological conservation, relaxation of restriction on farmland use, rural reconstruction, agricultural technology development, international and cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural cooperation," Lien explained.
In preparation for Taiwan's WTO entry, Lien said Taiwan must reorganize its agricultural structure, with upgrading of competitiveness as its top concern.

"We must develop a market-oriented and technology-centered agricultural production and marketing mechanism," Lien noted, adding that the government must adopt new strategies toward farmers organization restructuring, agricultural technology development, products marketing and agriculture-related financial services.

On the planned liberalization of farmland trade, Lien said the liberalization is mainly aimed at introducing entrepreneurship, business-style management and high technology into agricultural production.
Lien further said the government-proposed farmland trade liberalization does not mean that farmland can be freely used in the future.

"The bill is based on the principle that farmland can be used only for agricultural purposes," Lien said, adding under this principles, prior government approval is needed for turning farmland for non-agricultural usage.

Nevertheless, Lien said it's unreasonable to completely ban construction of facilities on newly purchased tracts of farmland. "No other country around the world has imposed such a restriction," Lien said, adding such a ban is not a good way to prevent farmland trade speculation and damage to rural landscape and soil conservation.

"The most effective way to curb illegal land specualtion and other farmland-related irregularities lies in the government's determination to formulate comprehensive regulations and to enforce all those regualtions," he added.
This was the first time that the vice president has spoken out his opinion concerning the controversial farmland trade liberalization and agricultural development bill.
In his speech, Lien further urged the government to develop a new farmland leasing system to facilitate more efficient use of farmland and expansion of the scale of agricultural operations.
Lien also called for the establishment of nationwide farmers' and fishermen's associations, national agricultural technology research institutes and a nationwide agriculture-related banking system.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, INDEPENDENCE CANDIDATES URGE TAIWANESE TO STAND UNITED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian and Taiwan Independence Party presidential hopeful Cheng Bang-chen on Friday urged Taiwanese to stand united in the 2000 presidential election.

Chen and Cheng made the statement at a meeting coordinated by senior leaders of Taiwan's independence movement including Peng Ming-min, the DPP's presidential candidate in 1996; Lee Chen-yuan, founder of the Taiwan Independence Party; and DPP factional leaders.

The senior leaders and Legislator Trong Tsay (DPP), one of the coordinators, expressed the hope that Cheng will withdraw from the presidential race, but Cheng made no comment on whether or not he would withdraw, and merely identified with the DPP's charter which advocates Taiwan independence.
Chen Shui-bian stressed that the election is just a single event, but Taiwan is forever. Taiwan is "our common language," Chen said, adding that Taiwan is also "our mother."
He also promised that members of the Taiwan Independence Party will not be left out of his proposed multiparty government if he wins the presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES INAUGURATES TAIPEI-CHIANG MAI ROUTE

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opened direct flights on Friday between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
The inauguration plane carried 149 passengers on the first of a twice weekly, Monday and Friday flight schedule using Boeing 737-800 jets.

Dignitaries who attended an inauguration ceremony for the new route at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport included Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Chang Yu-hern, Mandarin Airlines Chairman Chiang Hung-yi, and Thailand Trade and Economic Office director Jullapong Nonsrichai.
Chang noted that since its inception in June 1991, Mandarin Airlines has maintained a good flight safety record, which is why it was selected to ply the Taipei-Chiang Mai route.

Chiang said visits to Chiang Mai, a major tourist destination, could be combined in packages including visits to scenic spots in nearby mainland China such as Kunmin, and added that he envisions that Mandarin Airlines can cooperate with mainland airlines in the future to promote further tourist routes.
After it merged with Formosa Airlines in August, Mandarin Airlines took over Formosa Airlines' domestic flight services and its Taipei-Rangoon route.
The airline already operated flights to Australia (Sydney and Brisbane), and to Canada (Vancouver).
Chiang said China Airlines is scheduled to take over the Australian and Canadian routes in March or April next year, allowing Mandarin Airlines to step up its domestic and Southeast Asian flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SWEDEN INTER-PARLIAMENTARY AMITY ASSOCIATION INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-Sweden Inter-Parliamentary Amity Association was inaugurated on Friday at a ceremony attended by Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew, Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen, and Swedish Trade Council Director Ulf Sormark.
Speaking at the inauguration ceremony in Taipei, Siew said he is happy to see the formation of the association, and expressed hope that it will help promote the nation's diplomatic maneuvering space.
He stressed that the ROC is Sweden's third-largest trading partner in Asia, and that the inauguration of the body will bring about closer bilateral relations.
Legislative Vice President Yao Eng-chi noted that parliamentary diplomacy has become an indispensable part of the ROC's diplomatic work, and that the formation of the association is a necessity.
Legislator Huang Ming-ho of the ruling Kuomintang, who visited Sweden in August, was elected president of the association.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CRACKS DOWN ON CREDIT CARD CRIME

TEXT.P: Police on Friday raided a criminal organization from Hong Kong which was found to have stolen at least NT$500 million (US$15.82 million) from local five-star hotels and resorts since May using forged credit cards.
The ring was headed by 24-year-old Lee Chun-hsiung, who was arrested during the morning raid, said a spokesman for the police task force formed by the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB).
The spokesman added that more than 10 members of the group are still at large, and that the CIB is expanding its investigation.

The ring obtained the data required to forge the credit cards by first stealing credit card readers from hotel shops or restaurants, implanting a "spy" silicon chip, then replacing the machines, according to the CIB.
The modus operandi was sophisticated and would not have succeed without high-tech knowledge, the CIB said, adding that they suspect college or university students may have been involved.

Meanwhile, local newspapers reported that the credit card scam, the first of its kind discovered in Taiwan, is suspected to have been masterminded by several Hong Kong technicians dismissed by a credit card company in the former British colony.
Shortly after they were fired, Hong Kong police received reports of at least three similar credit card-related criminal cases which led to losses of several hundred million Hong Kong dollars.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPS TAIWAN TO OPEN SEMICONDUCTOR PLANT IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Philips Taiwan is planning to invest NT$16 billion over the next five years to set up a semiconductor production plant in the southern Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced on Friday.

Lin Neng-jong, director-general of the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center, disclosed the news following a visit by Taiwan Philips President Paul Zeven to Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang and personnel of the Export Processing Zone Administration.

According to Lin, Philips Taiwan has worked out a detailed plan and will soon file a formal application with the MOEA. Initial commercial production is expected to start by September next year at the earliest, he added.
Philips is the largest foreign investor in Taiwan, having poured NT$39.2 billion-worth of capital into the island, which is the international concern's operational hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DRIVE TO DEVELOP MISSILE SHIELD PROMPTED BY BEIJING THREATS

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Friday the Republic of China's drive to develop a missile shield is prompted by mainland China's mounting military threats, particularly its guided ballistic missile deployment.
Tang made the remarks at the opening ceremony of the second conference of the Asia-Pacific Security Forum, sponsored by the Institute for National Policy Research, a local private think tank.
This was also the first time that Tang has explained to the world the principal motivation behind the ROC's efforts to beef up its missile defense capabilities.

In his keynote speech, Tang also reaffirmed the ROC's commitment to contributing to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, adding he hopes the ROC's consistent efforts in this regard can receive recognition and support in the world community.
Because of a lack of consensus on the post-Cold War international order, Tang said, Asia-Pacific countries still fail to develop a full-fledged collective security mechanism.
"While the Western world has developed a 'safe community' concept, regional security frameworks in the Asia-Pacific and their functions still face many problems," Tang regretted.

Noting that historical national splits and territorial disputes have made the Asia-Pacific region a potential flash point in the next century in the eyes of many international affairs experts and scholars, Tang said a breakout of military confrontation will not only affect Asia-Pacific countries but will also have a strong impact on the global economy and even cause political instability.

Tang further pointed out that mainland China has continued increasing its military budget since the early 1980s with a view to establishing modernized armed forces to prevent US military intervention in its neighboring area so as to facilitate solution to Taiwan and South China Sea issues or at least to create a climate favorable to resolving these thorny issues.

Warning that mainland China's military build-up has prompted countries in the region to seek countermeasures, Tang said Asia-Pacific countries should establish a military mutual trust mechanism and keep defense transparency to ease mutual suspicion and curb possible arms races.

"We believe the most effective approach to tackle the post-Cold War Asia-Pacific security issues lies in the establishment of multilateral dialogue channels and a mutual trust mechanism," Tang stressed, adding that consultations on regional security issues should not exclude the ROC's participation. "Frequent compromise with mainland China would only encourage the rise of regional hegemony."

Tang further said the development and proliferation of guided missile technology has threatened security of the entire Asia-Pacific region, particularly in the Korean peninsula, Japan, Taiwan and South Asia.

"Frequent missile testing by mainland China and North Korea has forced their neighboring countries to seek effective ways to defend their national security and even triggered a controversy over the development a theater missile defense system," Tang noted.

As development and proliferation of guided missiles and cruise missiles would absolutely have a detrimental effect on regional security, Tang went on, those countries' failure to refrain from continuing such pursuit would eventually spark an arms race in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESS REPRESENTATIVE ARRIVING FOR 5-DAY VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: US Representative Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) will arrive in Taipei Saturday for a five-day visit to the Republic of China.

During her stay in Taipei, she will call on President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen and other government officials. She will also visit several cultural and economic establishments of the Republic of China before leaving on Dec. 22.

Meanwhile, a CNA dispatch from San Francisco said that Pelosi gave high marks for Taiwan's achievements in democratization and for President Lee's contribution to promoting the country's democratization.

Pelosi said at a press conference before departing her San Francisco district for a Taiwan trip that the progress and achievement registered by Taiwan was one of the greatest victories of the 20th century. The able leadership and courage of President Lee was worthy, she said.
Pelosi expressed the hope that she would have the chance to meet with the primary presidential hopefuls who are vying for the next presidency of the Republic of China.
The presidential election in Taiwan will signify a "new phenomenon" in Asia, especially for mainland China, she said, one that symbolizes that democratic politics will continue developing.
Speaking about mainland China, the congresswoman expressed her regret that the process of development of mainland China was proceeding in a direction opposite to that of Taiwan.
Mentioning Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO), she said the US Congress will firmly support Taiwan's WTO accession.
The United States should again review its policy of having China enter first before Taiwan if Beijing fails to meet regulations stipulated by the WTO, she stressed.

She also said the issue of WTO entry for mainland China and Taiwan will be taken up at the time when Congress begins to deliberate on giving mainland China permanent normal trade relations status (PNTRS), so as ensure Taiwan's WTO entry without political interference by Beijing.

Speaking on the current cross-strait situation, she said the Clinton administration should clearly tell the Beijing authorities that their intention to hinder democracy in Taiwan by using force would not be in Beijing's best interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENVOY REAFFIRMS SECURITY COMMITMENTS TO TAIWAN UNDER TRA

TEXT.P: The de facto US ambassador to Taiwan said on Friday that the United States will continue to uphold its security commitments to the Republic of China under the Taiwan Relations Act.

Raymond F. Burghardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, made the statement in a speech delivered at a seminar on Asia-Pacific security issues.

In his speech, titled "the Dynamics of Asia-Pacific Security: A Fin-de-siecle Assessment," Burghardt promised that the United States will help to maintain a climate of peace and stability in this region now and into the 21st century.
Nevertheless, Burghardt also took the occasion to reiterate the Clinton administration's strong opposition to the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA).

Quoting US Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Stanley Roth's testimony to Congress in August this year, Burghardt said the Clinton administration believes the TSEA could actually weaken Taiwan's security and have a negative effect on US security interests in the region.
"It certainly would be seen as a significant revision of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA)," noted Burghardt. The TRA is the US law that regulates exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Noting that the mechanisms that are already in place for US-Taiwan security cooperation are strong, proven and comprehensive, Burghardt said mainland China would interpret the TSEA as a direct challenge and would build up its missile deployments.

"So, rather than improving Taiwan's security situation, the new mechanisms under the TSEA could actually lead to an arms race that would move all parties one step farther from a peaceful cross-(Taiwan) Strait resolution," Burghardt said, adding: "We need to look objectively at the so-called Security Enhancement Act and whether it would really be in Taiwan's interests."

Touching on the topic whether Taiwan should take part in the theater missile defense (TMD) system, Burghardt said the TMD is still very much in conceptualization and development stage, and that deployment is still years away.
"We have briefed Taiwan, as we have other friends, on TMD. We do not preclude providing TMD to Taiwan, but it is premature to make the decision now," Burghardt said.

He further said security is more than military capability. "There are political, economic and social aspects that are just as important, or perhaps more important, than military hardware in maintaining the peace and in resolving differences."

Burghardt also said the Koo-Wang talks represented a significant step toward cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "We hope the two sides will be able to resume the series of talks in the near future," he added.

The "Koo-Wang talks" referred to meetings between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). The two elders were authorized by their respective governments to meet in Singapore in 1993 and in Shanghai in 1998 to discuss some bilateral issues in the absence of official contact.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC UNVEILS POSITION PAPER ON MACAU

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will continue to serve the people of both Taiwan and Macau, according to a government position paper on Macau unveiled Friday in the runup to the impending handover of the Portuguese colony to the rule of mainland China.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), in presenting its paper entitled "A Stable and Mutually Beneficial Relation -- The ROC's Stance on Macau in 1999," said it is happy to see that more than four centuries of colonial rule of Macau will end on Dec. 20.
MAC officials noted that around 6,000 Macau students have studied in Taiwan over the past decade, and that around 30,000 Macau laborers are now working in Taiwan.

Taiwan tourists made around 822,000 visits to Macau last year. Taiwan businessmen investing in the mainland from Macau totaled more than 700. All these figures show that Macau's relations with Taiwan have played an important role in the development of the casino enclave, the MAC said.

To protect the stability and prosperity of Macau, the MAC said, "we don't wish to see any backpedaling in Taiwan-Macau relations, nor do we wish to see the development of future Taiwan-Macau relations subject to any undue intervention or restraint."

Responding to the changed status of Macau after the handover, the MAC said the development of relations with Macau will be governed under the framework of the Hong Kong-Macau Relations Act and related regulations.

The MAC expressed the hope that Taiwan-Macau relations could contribute more to the stability and development of Macau after the handover. Therefore, the MAC hopes that bilateral relations will move along the following lines:
-- upgrading the service functions of Taiwan's representative office in Macau so as to provide better service to the people of both Taiwan and Macau; and
-- stepping up exchanges between Taiwan and Macau to promote understanding and cooperation.

The government body that is in charge of mainland policy also appealed to the mainland to abide by its pledge that "Macau people can rule Macau" and its "high autonomy" promise so as to lay the foundation for the development of Macau.
It said that mainland China, with its authoritarian system, may consider it a big step forward to practice its "one country, two systems" formula in Hong Kong and Macau.

However, the MAC continued, to impose the "two systems" policy on a democratic Taiwan would be a regression, stressing that the freedom and democracy of the ROC are not only lacking in Hong Kong and Macau, but are something that mainland authorities could not provide.
The MAC said the latest poll showed that up to 87 percent of Taiwan people do not favor the "one country, two systems" formula as a way to sort out cross-strait problems.

Rather than peddling the unpopular formula, the mainland should commit itself to democratic reforms so that the union of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will come naturally as the mainland gradually moves along the road to freedom, democracy and equal prosperity, the MAC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S WTO ENTRY A CHANCE FOR TAIWAN BIZMEN TO TRANSFORM BUSINESS

TEXT.P: Mainland China's World Trade Organization (WTO) accession will give Taiwan businessmen the chance to transform their businesses into advanced enterprises, said the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Friday.
The CEPD cited the latest analysis by Prof. Chen Tien-chih of National Taiwan University as the source of the supposition.

Prof. Chen said that after mainland China enters the WTO, Taiwan's traditional small-sized industries could create product brands of their own on the back of the vast hinterland of mainland China, or develop regional-characteristic production nets with the help of electronic commerce (e-commerce).

He also thought that Taiwan businessmen could establish production strongholds in mainland China or Southeast Asia through investing in the two regions, and could join forces with Western multilateral enterprises in the fields of marketing and design to take a seat in the international market.
Chen outlined the main reasons for the difficulties that Taiwan's traditional industries have faced in a report on "The Reconstruction of Traditional Industries."

He indicated that Taiwan's traditional small industries mainly play the role of manufacturing in the international division of labor system in the form of OEM (original equipment manufacturing), with product design and marketing being in inferior positions.
The lowering of manufacturing costs does have a limit, and once the traditional manufacturing industries can no longer cut costs, they teeter on the brink of being eliminated, he said.

Since 1986, Taiwan's government has unceasingly advocated the upgrading of traditional industries, but its effort has had little effect. This is mainly because emerging high-tech industries continuously sprang up like mushrooms, the report said.

Chen thought the problems that Taiwan's traditional industries have faced in recent years reveal that the government regulations concerning the upgrade of industries have their shortcomings because the regulations mainly encourage those high-tech industries to engage in research and development and automation of production.
He pointed out that there are three ways to upgrade traditional industries dominated by small- and medium-sized enterprises:
-- creating product brands of their own;
-- establishing regional-characteristic production nets via e-commerce; and
-- investing abroad and forming strategic alliances with Western multilateral enterprises in the fields of design and marketing to establish positions in international markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS IN MACAU CALL FOR AMENDMENT TO BASIC LAW

TEXT.P: Leaders of the United Committee for Democratic Development of Macau said in a press conference Friday that the Basic Law of Macau must be amended to ensure the protection of human rights and promotion of democratic development after the enclave is handed over to Beijing.
They said in a statement that they believe, if not amended, the basic law will hinder the democratic development of Macau and encroach on the human rights of the people living there.

Leaders of the committee also said that they were displeased with the government's recent move to prohibit overseas Falun Gong members from entering Macau on the occasion of it's handover to Beijing on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO CLAMP DOWN ON VISA OVERSTAYERS

TEXT.P: Australia will combat its problem of visa overstayers who compete in the labor market with Australians, the Immigration Department said on Friday.

In a statement faxed to the CNA, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said the government will try to make Australia less attractive to people working illegally because "they take jobs belonging to Australians, and can be used by unscrupulous employers to undercut responsible, law abiding organizations."
"A significant source of the problem has been with people who have overstayed their visas, and it is estimated that up to half of the overstaying population is working," Ruddock said.

In 1998-99, he said, 13,472 overstayers were found, representing a 6-percent increase over the previous year. In addition, more than 2,000 people in Australia lawfully were found working in contravention of their visa conditions, he added.

Most of the overstayers were British, a department spokesman said, followed by people from the United States and mainland China, and he added that the number is expected to increase with people coming to seek work opportunities opened up by the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney.
Ruddock said the government would make it tougher for both Australian employers and tourists who work illegally by boosting fines and imposing prison terms of up to two years for violators.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL CORP. AND YIEH LOONG FORM STRATEGIC ALLIANCE PACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest steel-manufacturer, China Steel Corp. (CSC), on Friday entered into a strategic alliance agreement with its rival, Yieh Loong Co. -- the island's No. 2 steel-maker.

A spokesman for CSC said the agreement, subject to approval by the Fair Trade Commission of the Executive Yuan, will empower the steel giant to acquire a controlling share in the industry's second largest company.
Under the agreement, CSC will spend NT$1.39 billion (US$43.76 million) on a 22.5-percent stake in debt-burdened Yieh Loong, thus controlling both shareholding and operations.
The CSC spokesman said the company will gradually increase its investment in Yieh Loong so as to upgrade its quality, efficiency and market competition.
Facing the impending shock of Taiwan's anticipated WTO entry, cooperation and strategic alliance are the best way to cope with the situation, he said.
He said the alliance will benefit both parties. CSC can expand its market share and increase production, while Yieh Loong will further cut its production costs and improve operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANK TO OPEN REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN JAKARTA

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of Indonesia has recently given the green light to Taipei-based First Commercial Bank's application to open a representative office in Jakarta, the local bank announced on Friday.

First Commercial Bank (FCB) will stride toward its objective of upgrading the planned office to branch category in order to improve its financial service to Taiwan business leaders in Indonesia, an official with FCB said.

According to the official, US authorities approved on Dec. 9 another application filed by an FCB-affiliated bank in California to inaugurate a branch in Silicon Valley to expand the bank's financial services abroad.
FCB, which celebrated its 100th anniversary on Nov. 26, has so far established 18 branch offices worldwide and is planning to set up a branch in San Salvador, the official added.

In addition to expanding its business operation footholds in foreign countries, FCB has actively pursued investments in various sectors over the past years, including the establishment of an investment consulting company and a leasing enterprise.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH MEDICAL JOURNAL LANCET SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Lancet, a prestigious British medical journal, has lent its voice to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).
In its Dec. 18 issue, the journal ran an article contributed by the Taipei representative office in London addressing the issue of why the Republic of China must join the WHO.

In conjunction with the article, the journal ran an editorial in support of Taiwan's bid to join the organization. The editorial urged the international community to address and rectify the injustice of Taiwan being excluded from the United Nations agency due to political factors and the resulting problems.

The editorial said that in order to continue improving the health of people in Taiwan, and for the added reason that it can contribute to the improvement of medical care worldwide, the ROC must be allowed to rejoin the WHO so that the organization can live up to its goal of seeking the greatest benefit for all the people of the world.

The editorial also stressed that the ROC, after being excluded from the WHO, has been denied access to exchanges of both information and mutual assistance with WHO members, and has been prevented from making contributions to global medical care.

The editorial said that the ROC should therefore be allowed to join the WHO, saying that only by doing so, can Taiwan contribute to global humanitarian health care projects and help alleviate human suffering.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE EXPLAINS USE OF 'SECRET FUND'

TEXT.P: Independent presidential candidate James Soong said on Friday night that the so-called "secret fund" he obtained seven years ago on instructions from Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui totaled NT$240 million.
That figure is NT$100 million higher than the one he gave at a press conference early this week.

Soong told reporters that Lee instructed him to use the fund to take care of family members of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo and to pay for expenses required for the smooth management of party and political affairs.

Due to his special relationship with Lee, the former KMT secretary general said, Lee entrusted him with the secret fund, which until recently was deposited in the accounts of Soong Chen-yuan, Soong's son, and Chen Pi-yun, sister of Soong's wife.

Of the secret fund, according to Soong, the NT$100 million for care of the Chiang family came from the Broadcasting Corporation of China, and so far about NT$90 million has been used, with NT$47 million (including interest) remaining unused.

Regarding the NT$146 million fund for management of political and party affairs, Soong said that about NT$60 million came from a special account which he used when he was KMT secretary general, and the remaining NT$86 million came from a KMT-run company.

At the press conference, Soong produced the certificate of a special account for the KMT secretary general issued by the Bank of Taiwan to rebut the KMT side's allegation that there was no such an account in existence.
He also said that the fund for the special account was from the contributions from the private sector.
KMT spokesman Huang Hui-chen criticized Soong, calling him "dishonest" because Soong's statement earlier Friday conflicted with his previous statement.

Former Foreign Minister Jason Hu, now serving as general executive of the campaign headquarters for the KMT's presidential nominee Lien Chan, said that the Lien camp has no intention of intervening in this matter.
He urged Soong "to face the truth with sincerity, and to shoulder responsibility with courage."

Soong denied allegations that he had "embezzled" the KMT fund, and stressed that almost all transactions relating to the fund could be traced through records. He especially listed some use of the fund for the Chiang families with concrete figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Independent presidential candidate James Soong gives new explanation of the origin of questionable funds.
The China Times:
Soong insists that there was really a special personal account for the ruling Kuomintang's secretary-general.
The United Daily News:
Soong unveils more detailed figures on the disputed funds.
The Liberty Times:
Soong says more than 10 politicians had received subsidies from the 'disputed funds' allegedly allocated for 'special party work.'
The China Post:
Soong says fund use 'sensitive, not illegal.'
The Taiwan News:
Soong unveils secret expenditures.
The Taipei Times:
Soong: the total is NT$246 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KIDNAPPED TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN RESCUED IN PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan businessmen kidnapped by five armed bandits in Quezon province in the northern Philippines in late October were rescued early on Saturday morning, sources with Philippine security forces said.
Chang Kuei-fang and Shen Ming-chi were rescued by anti-organized crime commandos under the jurisdiction of the Philippine Presidential Office.
The commandos raided the place where Chang and Shen were detained at around 6 a.m. and successfully rescued the two businessmen after a fierce gunfight, according to the sources.
Both men were in good condition, said the sources, but there was no immediate report on whether the commandos suffered casualties.

During the nearly two month period for which the men were held, the bandits asked their families several times to pay a ransom of US$1 million, but refused to allow the two businessmen to talk with their families on the phone.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL BLAMES MEDIA FOR WORSENING TIES WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official on mainland China affairs on Saturday blamed the media "in a certain place" for misleading reports which have poisoned Taiwan's ties with mainland China rather than improve mutual understanding.

Without naming names, Su Chi, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said certain media sources are responsible for bending facts to make sensational stories to the extent that they have thrown accuracy to the wind.

In a veiled denunciation of the Hong Kong press, which often releases false news about Beijing's military exercises in attempts to intimate Taiwan, Su said those newspapers have unwittingly played into Beijing's hands and have helped in its war of nerves with Taiwan.
Acknowledging the important role in a democracy of a free press -- including the right to make mistakes -- Su said the fragile ties between Taiwan and mainland China will brook no false reports.

Speaking at a prize-giving ceremony in honor of distinguished journalist coverage of bilateral ties, Su lauded the local media as "more balanced" than their counterparts in "a certain place" in reporting stories about Taiwan and mainalnd china.

He praised local journalists posted in mainland China for their "marvelous" coverage of mainland affairs given the numerous limitations imposed on their activities by Beijing, and the omnipresent threat of being accused of "leaking state secrets" hanging over their heads as they investigate stories.

In a prepared written statement, Su excoriated Beijing for what he called reducing the media into a government mouthpiece rather than making it a valuable instrument catering for the people's right to know.

Beijing's attitude has resulted in an unbalanced flow of news between Taiwan and mainalnd China, with Taiwan covering mainland Chinese affairs but mainland Chinese newspapers rarely publishing any news about Taiwan, said Su.

Mainland journalists chosen by Beijing to visit Taiwan under bilateral exchange programs often retire or give up their jobs after their journeys, suggesting that Beijing considers the exchange of visits as nothing more than a reward for outgoing press officials, said Su.

Taiwan leaders rarely make headlines in mainland Chinese newspapers. Although this situation altered somewhat after President Lee Teng-hui made his "special state-to-state relationship" claim regarding cross-strait ties, Taiwan leaders are cast in a negative light by mainland Chinese media, according to Su.
Much to Taipei's chagrin, Su said, some of those journalists who have visited Taiwan have also led in criticizing Lee for his advocacy of Taiwan's statehood status.

Su urged Beijing to open negotiations with Taipei on the permanent exchange of reporters, and he also called on mainland Chinese journalists to treat Taiwan fairly in their reports, in order to foster mutual trust.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA AIRWAYS STARTS TAIPEI-PHUKET ISLAND FLIGHT ROUTE
DOC.DATELINE: CKS Airport, northern Taiwan, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: TransAsia Airways formally opened passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket with an A320 plane on Saturday, becoming the third domestic airline to ply the route.

TransAsia Airways will operate twice-weekly return flights, on Wednesdays and Saturdays, in the initial stage of the service, and plans to increase the schedule to four weekly return flights, on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, beginning Feb. 1, 2000.
TransAsia Airways' scheduled international flight routes also include Taipei-Macau, Kaohsiung-Macau, and Taipei-Kota Kinabalu (Malaysia).
The airline also operates a Taipei-Ishigakijima (Japan) route on a charter basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR CLOSES FLAT ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar remained unchanged against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Saturday, closing at 31.657.
The local currency opened at 31.660 and was traded between 31.650 and 31.662.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$43 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT STABILITY NEEDS RESOLUTE US: ANALYST

TEXT.P: If the United States is resolute, peace can be maintained in the Taiwan Strait until a political settlement is reached, according to a foreign policy adviser to US Republican presidential hopeful George W. Bush.

Condoleezza Rice, professor of political science at Stanford University, wrote in the latest issue of "Foreign Affairs" quarterly magazine that only the US military has the power needed to deter trouble on the Korean peninsula or across the Taiwan Strait, with the goal being to make it inconceivable for North Korea or communist China to use force.

She said that for America and its allies, the most daunting task is to find the right policy balance toward Russia and communist China. Both are equally important to the future of international peace, but the challenges they pose are very different.

Mainland China is a rising power. In economic terms, that should be good news, because in order to maintain its economic dynamism, it must be more integrated into the international economy. This will require increased openness and transparency and the growth of private industry.

The political struggle in Beijing now is over how to maintain the Communist Party's monopoly on power. Some see economic reform, growth and a better life for the mainland Chinese people as the key. Others see the inherent contradiction in loosening economic control and maintaining the party's political dominance. As mainland China's economic problems multiply due to slowing growth rates, failing banks, inert state enterprises and rising unemployment, this struggle will intensify, noted Rice.

Even if there is an argument for economic interaction with Beijing, she said, "China is still a potential threat to stability in the Asia-Pacific region. Its military power is currently no match for that of the United States. But that condition is not necessarily permanent. What we do know is that China is a great power with unresolved vital interests, particularly concerning Taiwan and the South China Sea."

Mainland China resents the role of the United States in the Asia-Pacific region. This means that mainland China is not a "status quo" power but one that would like to alter Asia's balance of power in its own favor. That alone makes it a strategic competitor, not the "strategic partner" the Clinton administration once called it.

Add to this mainland China's record of cooperation with Iran and Pakistan in the proliferation of ballistic missile technology, and the security problem is obvious. "China will do what it can to enhance its position, whether by stealing nuclear secrets or by trying to intimidate Taiwan," wrote the senior fellow at the Hoover Institute.

Rice said mainland China's success in controlling the balance of power depends in large part on America's reaction to the challenge. The United States must deepen its cooperation with Japan and South Korea and maintain its commitment to a robust military presence in the region.

The United States also has a deep interest in the security of Taiwan, she stressed. It is a model of democratic and market-oriented development, and it invests significantly in the mainland's economy. The long-standing US commitment to a "one China" policy that leaves to a future date the resolution of the relationship between Taipei and Beijing is wise.
But that policy requires that neither side challenge the status quo and that Beijing, as the more powerful actor, renounce the use of force. US resolve anchors this policy.

The Clinton administration tilted toward Beijing, when, for instance, it used mainland China's formulation of the "Three Noes" during Clinton's trip there, and Taiwan has been looking for attention and reassurance since then, Rice concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ENTRY TO OFFER NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR TAIPEI-BEIJING EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The de facto US ambassador to Taiwan said on Saturday that the United States hopes the World Trade Organization (WTO) will provide a new forum for exchanges and interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Raymond F. Burghardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents US interests in the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, made the statement at an annual conference of the ROC's US Study Society.

Noting that both Taiwan and mainland China might be admitted to the WTO in the first half of next year, Burghardt said the United States will take delight in seeing the two sides become full members of the world trade regulatory body.
"We also hope that the WTO will offer new opportunities for cross-strait exchanges and interaction so as to reduce tension in the region," Burghardt said.

The top US representative in Taiwan further said the United States has worked out sound yet flexible policies and measures that meet its goal of promoting peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region in the 21st century.

In addition to upholding its security commitments to Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act, Burghardt said, the United States will also actively expand relations in political, economic and social dimensions.

Touching on the triangular Washington-Taipei-Beijing relations over the past 20 years, Burghardt said that in today's world, economic exchanges often precede political exchanges, adding that he believes booming commercial exchanges will help accelerate economic globalization in the coming century.

"And this is why the WTO has become increasingly important in the world economy," Burghardt said, adding that the United States encourages all countries around the world to take part in the WTO. Nevertheless, he admitted, the WTO cannot resolve all the world's trade issues.

Burghardt also referred to the fact that when AIT Chairman Richard Bush visited Taipei from Dec. 7-15, many local people asked him which Taiwan presidential candidate the United States most favors and least likes, and their odds for victory in the March 18, 2000 presidential election.

No matter how the question is pursued, Burghardt said, the US answer is the same: "The United States does not favor or oppose any political party or individual candidate in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election, and will work with whomever the people of Taiwan choose to serve as their leader through a free, fair and open election."

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMEMORATIVE SILVER MILLENNIUM COINS TO BE LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: A silver bullion coin, struck to mark the new millennium, will be officially issued on Tuesday by the Central Bank of China.
The coin, made of 99.9 percent silver, weighs 15.568 grams, has a diameter of 3.3 cm and a thickness of 0.225 cm.

One side of the coin features the celestial model created by ancient Chinese astrologers, and is dated "the 89th year of the Republic of China," along with the inscription: "ushering in 2000." The other side bears an illustration of a dragon which is both the symbol of ancient China and the sign of the Chinese zodiac for 2000.

Although stamped with a face value of NT$50 (US$1.50), the coin, which will have a run of 100,000, will be sold at NT$750 apiece by Taiwan Bank branches islandwide from Tuesday, on the basis of one coin per person, first come first served, said the CBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: COALITION GOVERNMENT POSSIBLE IF DPP WINS ELECTION: CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By K.M. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian has told a Japanese newspaper that he would not rule out the possibility of forming a coalition government with the Kuomintang if elected Taiwan's next president.
However, he vowed that he would not consider joining a coalition government if it were to be led by the ruling KMT.
The former mayor of Taipei, who is the main opposition party's standard-bearer in the island's presidential race slated for March 2000, made the remarks to the Sankei Shimbun in a recent interview.
The mass-circulation daily also reported that Chen's public support has surged noticeably following the eruption last week of a financial scandal which has engulfed independent contender James Soong.
Soong had enjoyed a comfortable lead over both Chen and the KMT's presidential candidate -- Vice President Lien Chan -- until recently, according to public opinion surveys.
The DPP stalwart said he is confident of winning the election because many eligible voters who are behind him have remained silent, resulting in a relatively lower support rate for him in the polls.

Describing both Soong and Lien as flag-bearers of Taiwan's notorious money politics, Chen said President Lee Teng-hui has failed to carry out a series of fundamental reforms on the island's judicial, administrative and educational fronts, although he conceded that Lee has played a major role in Taiwan's democratization.

Voicing his opinion that there is no need to write a new constitution to transform the Taiwan system of government into the model adopted by the United States, Chen also stressed that Taiwan-mainland China ties could move in a positive direction if Beijing recognized the fact that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state.
