DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE TAIWAN-MACAU TIES NOT TO BE SUBJECT TO `HONG KONG FORMULA'

TEXT.P: A senior mainland China affairs official said on Saturday that Taiwan-Macau relations will absolutely not be subject to the so-called "Hong Kong formula" after the Portuguese colony's reversion to mainland rule on Monday.

"Post-handover relations between Taiwan and Macau must be based on the principles of dignity, reciprocity and pragmatism," said Su Chi, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts the Republic of China's policy toward mainland China.

Su made the remarks in response to a press inquiry as to whether the ROC representative office in Macau will be closed or changes made to its official title to ensure its continued existence after the enclave's handover.

If the so-called "Hong Kong formula" were to be adopted, the ROC representative office would have to change its official designation from the current "Taipei Trade and Tourism Office, Macau" to "Chung Hwa Travel Service, Macau," and its liaison with the post-handover Macau government would rely on a special adviser to Macau Chief Executive Edmund Ho.

After Hong Kong reverted to Beijing's rule on July 1, 1997, Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa appointed his adviser, Paul Yip, to handle exchanges with Taiwan, while Taiwan's representative office there was named "Chung Hwa Travel Service, Hong Kong."
Noting that present Taiwan-Macau relations are very close, Su urged the Macau authorities to consider the issue of bilateral ties on a reciprocal basis.

Statistics show that about 6,000 Macau students have received education in Taiwan over the past 10 years. At present, more than 30,000 Macau residents are working in Taiwan, and Taiwan people made 822,000-plus visits to the enclave last year. In addition, more than 700 Taiwan companies have invested in mainland China via Macau.
"All these figures point to the fact that Taiwan has played an important role in Macau's development over the past decade," Su stressed.

To help maintain Macau's stability and prosperity, Su went on, the ROC does not want to see a downslide in its relations with Macau after the enclave's handover. "We also don't want to see future Taiwan-Macau relations impeded by any improper interference or restrictions."
In preparation for Macau's imminent handover, Su said the MAC will open a Macau affairs bureau on Dec. 20 to handle post-handover exchanges with the territory.
He also outlined three principal guidelines for promoting post-handover ties with Macau:
-- Upgrading the services and functions of the ROC's representative office in Macau to better serve Macau residents; and
-- Beefing up exchanges with Macau to enhance mutual understanding and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sriday, Dec. 18, or the 30th day of the 10th month in Year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past: 1865: The United States abolishes slavery. 1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government. 1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui. 1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan, which had been proclaimed capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927. 1941: German forces retreat in North Africa in World War II. 1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations. 1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta. 1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia. 1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty. 1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan, and Thailand. 1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by party secretary Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76. 1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia. 1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting from 1988. 1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung. 1992: Kim Young Sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, was elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
Confucius: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO CONSIDER UPGRADING NATIONAL POLICE ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Saturday that the government will give favorable consideration to a proposal to upgrade the National Police Administration (NPA) to a Cabinet-level agency.

Speaking at the opening of a conference on improving social order before the March 2000 presidential election, Lien, who is the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for the country's next president, gave his public support for the first time to an eight-point proposal submitted by the NPA to streamline its structure.

The proposal, worked out by Mei Ko-wang, former president of the Police University, calls for the transfer of the police administration from the Ministry of the Interior to the Cabinet, and for an increase in the number of senior officer posts in proportion to the NPA's expanding personnel and administration.

Pay and overtime compensation will also be adjusted upward, in addition to the establishment of a police fund to take care of officers who become handicapped because of injuries suffered in the line of duty.

Saturday's security conference brought together some 200 senior police officers from around the island, who were briefed on the major tasks facing them from Nov. 21 to May 20 to ensure social order before, during, and after the March 18 election.

During the conference, the attendants were asked to trace and seize illegal guns, crack down on gangsters, aggressively probe and break major violent criminal cases, block the smuggling of mainland Chinese into Taiwan, clear society of narcotics, and crack down on burglary.
They were also asked to protect the presidential candidates during the election campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES BOTH UP

TEXT.P: Encouraged by overnight gains on Wall Street and led by electronics and paper-and-pulp categories, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) recovered some of its steam in Saturday trading.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 74.65 points higher at 7,797.87, on a turnover of NT$108.14 billion (US$3.42 billion), with 2.19 billion shares changing hands.
The bourse opened high and maintained its upward trend until reaching the day's high of 7,841.5 before fluctuating until the closing level of 7,797.87.

Six of the eight major stock categories closed higher, with paper-and-pulp shares posting the biggest gain of 3.8 percent, followed by textile shares, up 1.7 percent, financial shares, up 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics issues, up 1 percent, cement issues, up 0.3 percent, and construction issues, up 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff stocks closed down 0.4 percent, while plastic and chemical stocks were down 0.2 percent.
Gainers led decliners 267 to 184, with 103 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 0.71 points to close at 190.95, on a turnover of NT$12.54 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) had a successful day, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 44 points to close at 7,860, with 1,496 contract transactions. Those for February advanced 18 points to finish at 7,867, with 16 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March jumped 59 points to close at 7,925, with seven contract transactions, while those for June climbed 53 points to finish at 7,980, with two contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 7,816 points for January, 7,849 points for February, 7,866 points for March, 7,927 points for next June, and 7,878 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported gains.
January TE futures rose 3.55 points to close at 402.45, with 510 contract transactions, while no transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.
January TF futures climbed eight points to close at 938, with 180 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF OUTLINES KEY ISSUES IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Disputes across the Taiwan Strait can be resolved only when mainland China has the courage and self-confidence to face a democratic new Taiwan, a senior mainland affairs official said on Saturday.

Su Chi, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks in a speech he delivered at the second conference of the Asia-Pacific Security Forum sponsored by the Institute for National Policy Research, a local think tank.

Su told scores of China affairs experts from around the world who attended the Taipei conference that mainland China has steadily shrunk its definition of "one China" while expanding its interpretation of "Taiwan independence."

In 1993, Su said, the two sides reached a consensus that each side could uphold its own definition of "one China." However, he went on, Beijing has unilaterally forsaken this consensus in recent years, saying it should not be applied to international relations or to political negotiations.
"Mainland China even demands that Taiwan accept its `one China' definition as a prerequisite for cross-strait exchanges and consultations," Su said.
Beijing defines "one China" as the People's Republic of China, and downgrades the Republic of China to the level of a local government under PRC sovereignty.

On the other hand, Su said, Beijing continues to expand its definition of Taiwan independence. "It even interprets our explanation of the ROC's existence as a move to advocate Taiwan independence," he noted.

Su stressed that President Lee Teng-hui's definition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" merely affirms a long-existing reality and is a defensive strategy to cope with Beijing's increasingly aggressive moves to minimize Taiwan's international space and diplomatic frontiers.
He further said that cross-strait issues cannot be resolved until mainland China can flatly face the facts of separate rule of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan's full democratization.

Another key problem lies in mainland China's "blind belief" in military force, Su said, adding that Beijing has begun evaluating Taiwan's importance from a regional strategic perspective since managing to upgrade its economic strength and improve its relations with its two closest neighbors -- Russia and Vietnam.

"We believe that mainland China's resistance to renouncing the use of force against Taiwan and its intensified military deployment in the Taiwan Strait are part of its strategies to seek a leading role in regional affairs," Su explained.
The ROC's top mainland policy planner further said mainland China has increasingly believed that it can ignore Taiwan and instead discuss Taiwan Strait issues with the United States.

In addition to blocking Taiwan's participation in international activities, Su said, mainland China is now attempting to pressure Taiwan via the US government to open direct cross-strait trade, mail and transport links. Mainland China is also pushing the United States to stop or reduce its arms sales to Taiwan.

Su said that even though the United States has a clear policy of maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and encouraging cross-strait dialogue, it should still pay more attention to mainland China's new strategies or moves regarding cross-strait issues.
"Only when regular cross-strait dialogue and consultations fully resume can Taipei-Beijing relations really improve," Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By K.M. Huang and Flor Wang)
DOC.TEXT:
Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian has told a Japanese newspaper that he would not rule out the possibility of forming a coalition government with the Kuomintang if elected Taiwan's next president.
However, he vowed that he would not consider joining a coalition government if it were to be led by the ruling KMT.
The former mayor of Taipei, who is the main opposition party's standard-bearer in the island's presidential race slated for March 2000, made the remarks to the Sankei Shimbun in a recent interview.
The mass-circulation daily also reported that Chen's public support has surged noticeably following the eruption last week of a financial scandal which has engulfed independent contender James Soong.
Soong had enjoyed a comfortable lead over both Chen and the KMT's presidential candidate -- Vice President Lien Chan -- until recently, according to public opinion surveys.
The DPP stalwart said he is confident of winning the election because many eligible voters who are behind him have remained silent, resulting in a relatively lower support rate for him in the polls.
Describing both Soong and Lien as flag-bearers of Taiwan's notorious money politics, Chen said President Lee Teng-hui has failed to carry out a series of fundamental reforms on the island's judicial, administrative and educational fronts, although he conceded that Lee has played a major role in Taiwan's democratization.
Voicing his opinion that there is a need to write a new constitution to transform the Taiwan system of government into the model adopted by the United States, Chen also stressed that Taiwan-mainland China ties could move in a positive direction if Beijing recognized the fact that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S US ENVOY TO REPORT TO LEGISLATURE ON TSEA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen is slated to make a report to the legislature late this month on his role in the US Congress' efforts to promote the passage of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA).

Under strong pressure from lawmakers of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the Foreign Affairs Committee under the Legislative Yuan has decided to recall Chen to make a full report on the issue on Dec. 29.

The DPP legislative caucus visited then-Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu in November to demand Chen's removal from his current post because of his "indifference" when certain US Congress members were pushing for the passage of the TSEA at the Senate and House of Representatives early this year.

Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Tawei David Lee and spokesman Henry Chen explained to the committee that it was better for Taipei not to "meddle in" the matter, although the Republic of China government welcomes the legislation by the US Congress of any bill which is conducive to Taiwan's security.

Chiu Yi-jen, a DPP representative stationed in the United States, also claimed that he would welcome the passage of the TSEA, but pointed out that it is not appropriate for the DPP to lobby for it publicly as it is an internal political matter which would have a profound impact on Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.

Chen also told a group of visiting ROC lawmakers which traveled to Washington last month to lobby for US congressional support for the approval of the TSEA that it is not appropriate for his office -- the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States -- to interfere in the legislation of a US domestic law.

The TSEA, initiated by Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC) at the Senate and Representative Tom DeLay (R-TX) at the House in spring this year, required the US administration to report to Congress every year on Taiwan's defense needs and related issues. However, the act failed to pass the floor of the Capitol Hill.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABNORMALITIES REPORTED IN QUAKE-STRICKEN AREAS OF CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Three months after the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan on Sept. 21, crops and plants in quake-stricken areas of central Taiwan are showing abnormalities, according to a report released on Saturday.

The report, compiled by National Taiwan University professors and commissioned by the Council of Agriculture (COA), said that one of the most common phenomena in the stricken areas is that a large number of crops have withered and died, much as if they had been struck by a drought.
The phenomena is most obvious in regions where there are faults or where the surface has moved, the report said.
In addition, crop growth appears to have slowed, evident in immature fruit crops and unhealthy rice.
Some plants have bloomed before the normal time, with peaches on Chushan (bamboo mountain) in central Taiwan's Nantou County coming into flower one month earlier than usual.
The report went on to say that due to liquefaction of the earth in Yuanlin, Chunghua County, flowers have actually changed color.
The report cited one Yuanlin resident who planted a red rose which produced a light yellow bloom, describing it as an unusual occurrence.
The report analyzed that the withering and slowing down of plant growth could be the result of the loss of irrigation water or changes to underground water caused by alteration to the terrain.

As for the early blooming and drastic changes in growth cycles, the report said that they could be the results of dramatic changes in the moisture and hardness of the earth, and in the concentration of carbon dioxide in the soil caused by the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER COMMENTS ON AIT CHAIRMAN'S STATEMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen said on Saturday that American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush's recent statement on Taiwan's presidential election carried no special message.

During a just-concluded visit to Taipei, Bush held separate talks with the top three leading presidential hopefuls -- independent candidate James Soong, Lien Chan of the ruling Kuomintang and Chen Shui-bian of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Before his departure early this week, Bush stated that the United States would not support any specific candidate over another in the 2000 presidential election.

Chen told the Broadcasting Corporation of China's "Face the Public" program that Bush had no special agenda in mind when he made the remarks, because "a diplomat usually refrains from commenting on the internal affairs and general elections of other countries."
He pointed out that Bush's attitude reflected the consistent policy of the US government.
Chen also said that Washington is adopting a "vague policy" on cross-Taiwan Strait issues by speaking more clearly on certain topics, while maintaining a flexible stance on others.

He also pointed out that a letter by an American columnist that appeared in the Los Angeles Times recently which slammed President Lee Teng-hui "was the personal view of the columnist, not the US government."

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU TO PLAY INCREASING ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT TRADE AFTER HANDOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Macau is expected to play an increasing role in indirect trade across the Taiwan Strait after its reversion to mainland China's rule on Dec. 20, local observers said on Saturday.
Many Taiwan business people in Macau also hope that the public order and business environment in the territory can be improved after the new Macau government is inaugurated.

Before the 1980s, Taiwan-Macau commercial exchanges were limited because of political factors. Trade and civilian exchanges between Taiwan and the Portuguese colony saw a breakthrough after the Republic of China allowed its nationals to visit mainland China via Hong Kong in 1987.

At that time, Portuguese colonial rulers in Macau also eased visa regulations to attract ROC visitors. They offered landing visas to ROC nationals to facilitate their travel to the mainland for family reunions.
In January 1990, the Macau colonial government even approved an ROC application to set up a representative office on the enclave to handle bilateral trade and tourist affairs.

Taiwan-Macau exchanges entered a new stage in October 1995 when direct flight services were inaugurated. Since then, Taiwan travelers can stay in Macau for up to 20 days with landing visas and can fly from Taiwan to mainland China after a stopover in Macau where the airplane from Taiwan just needs to change its flight number before flying to the mainland.

As the ticket price for Taiwan-Macau flight is 10 percent lower than that for Taiwan-Hong Kong flight and hotel and other service charges in Macau are also cheaper than in Hong Kong, many mainland China-bound Taiwan tourists and business people have chosen Macau as their transit stop. Taiwan is now Macau's third largest source of tourists.

According to Macau's official tallies, the number of Taiwan visitors to Macau has increased steadily since 1995 and reached 812,000 in 1998. In the first half of this year, the number stood at 474,000, up 24 percent from the same period of last year.

As a Portuguese colony, Macau enjoys many trade privileges in exporting goods to the European Union. An increasing number of Taiwan firms have shipped semi-finished products from the mainland to Macau for final assembly and then exported those finished products to EU countries. As a result, Taiwan-Macau trade has increased steadily in recent years.

According to Taiwan's tallies, Taiwan-Macau trade totaled a mere US$1.4 million in 1983 and surged to US$360 million in 1998. In the first eight months of this year, Taiwan-Macau trade amounted to US$243 million, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$200 million. Taiwan is now Macau's fourth largest trading partner, after Hong Kong, mainland China and Japan.

However, direct Taiwan investment in Macau remains limited because of a combination of factors, including Macau's failure to adopt any incentives to attract foreign investors official corruption, low administrative efficiency, limited supplies of parts and components, language barriers, and worsening public order.
Nevertheless, an estimated 1,500 Taiwan companies have made investment in the Pearl River Delta and other neighboring mainland areas via Macau, with an accumulated capital of US$1 billion.

Many Taiwan business people said they expect new trade opportunities and better business environment to follow the inauguration of the new Macau government which will adopt Chinese as its official language.

Many of them also urged the post-handover Macau government to give the top priority to improving the public order and investment climate. If so, they said Taiwan investment in Macau will increase and the territory will also be able to play a more important role in indirect trade across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEASON'S FIRST SNOW REPORTED ON HOHUANSHAN

TEXT.P: With the coming of a new cold front across Taiwan, the first snow of the season was reported on Saturday to have fallen on mountainous regions of central Taiwan.
Hundreds of enthusiasts who rushed to Hohuanshan to see the snow-shrouded mountain were elated, cheering and shouting in excitement while some rolled around on the snowy ground.
The Central Weather Bureau reported that morning temperatures were as low as negative 0.5 degrees Celsius, but the snow accumulation was less than 10 cm.

As the temperature continued to slide, the weathermen predicated that the snow will be more heavy from Sunday, and that with a steady low temperature and the right moisture conditions, there will be a chance of snow above 3,000 meters all over Taiwan.
The weathermen advised the public to stay warm while trying to enjoy the white landscape, and predicted that temperatures islandwide will hover around 10 degrees Celsius in the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
LOW TEMPERATURES AFFECTING TAIWAN; SNOW IN MOUNTAINOUS AREAS

TEXT.P: An increasingly strong cold air mass from mainland China continued affecting Taiwan on Sunday after generating snow in the upper elevations of Yushan (Jade Mountain) and Hohuanshan in central Taiwan, according to a recent weather report.

The Central Weather Bureau reported that snow started falling in the Jade Mountain area in the early hours Sunday, and that as of 9 a.m. the mountaintop had been blanketed with five centimeters of snow.

Overnight snowfall covered the mountainous area of Hohuanshan with a 50-centimeter-thick white shroud, according to the CWB, which issued a low temperature warning for the island at noon Sunday, and pointed out that Taiwan will continue to be affected by cold, moist weather until Dec. 22.
In the early morning hours, the temperature in Taipei was recorded at 12.6 degrees Celsius, the lowest reading islandwide, according to the Sunday report.

Chiayi, southern Taiwan, saw a 14-degree-Celsius temperature reading, while that of 14.2 degrees Celsius was recorded in Taichung, central Taiwan; in southern Taiwan, Tainan's temperature dipped to 14.6 degrees Celsius, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 19, or the twelfth day of the 11th month in Year of the Rabbit under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He was overthrown by the Uganda army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: US Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent and the Democratic Progressive Party 31.03 percent of the popular vote in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments in the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae Jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG STILL LEADS SUPPORT RATE AMID SCANDAL: POLL

TEXT.P: Independent presidential candidate James Soong still leads the other presidential hopefuls in support ratings despite the recent financial scandal, results of the latest poll showed.

However, the poll found, the gaps between the support ratings of the three main presidential candidates -- Soong, Vice President and Kuomintang presidential nominee Lien Chan, and opposition Democratic Progressive Party hopeful Chen Shui-bian -- have increasingly narrowed.

According to the poll, conducted by EX International P.R. Consultants, 24.5 percent of respondents said they would vote for Soong if the presidential election were held the following day, down a whopping 14 percent from a similar poll held in early November.
Twenty-three percent of respondents said they would vote for the DPP's Chen Shui-bian, while 20.2 percent supported Vice President Lien Chan, the poll found.
However, 24.5 percent of respondents stated that they have not decided whom they will support.
What is worth noting is that Lien is considered most likely to be elected, according to the poll.
Asked who they thought would win the election, 40.7 percent of respondents said Lien would be the next president, up 9.6 percent from a poll held in late November.

Odds for Soong trailed far behind, with 17.7 percent predicting he would win, while 8.4 percent said Chen would be victorious. Some 33 percent of respondents would not venture a guess as to the outcome of the March election.

The poll, conducted between Dec. 13 and 15, when the financial scandal involving Soong's alleged use of Kuomintang money for unexplainable reasons was beginning to loom, also found that most people were fretting over the significant influence of "black gold" money and organized crime on Taiwan politics.
Nearly 71 percent of respondents think the country's politics are "very seriously" influenced by "black gold" dealings, while 10.1 percent said the influence is "serious."

Asked who among the presidential hopefuls might be most capable of eradicating corruption and violence from politics, 33.8 percent of respondents said they believe the DPP's Chen is most capable, followed by Soong with 9 percent favoring his abilities, and Lien with 6.2 percent.
The same poll also found that 24.8 percent of respondents turned from "liking" Soong to "disliking" him in the wake of the eruption of the scandal.

Soong was accused of using KMT party funds for building private connections, and he seemed unable to provide convincing explanations in response to questions about the huge sums in his son's and sister-in-law's bank accounts.

Of the 1,220 adults polled islandwide, 38.6 percent did not believe Soong's statement at a Dec. 14 press conference that the NT$140 million (US$4.43 million) that had been kept in those two accounts was transferred there from the KMT on the instruction of party Chairman Lee Teng-hui in order to care for the widow and family of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo and for other party activities.

Only 5.6 percent of respondents said they "very much believe" Soong's explanation about the money, while 13.9 percent said they "believe" that Soong was telling the truth. About 22 percent of respondents said they have no idea about the veracity of his story.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 40 PERCENT IN TAIWAN FAVOR LONG-RANGE MISSILE DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The latest public opinion poll showed that more than 40 percent of Taiwan's people approve of Vice President Lien Chan's remark that the nation should develop long-range missiles in the face of increased military threats from mainland China.

The poll, conducted by EX International P.R. Consultants, found that 42.1 percent of respondents said the Republic of China should develop long-range missiles, while 26.2 percent said Taiwan shouldn't.
Nearly 40 percent of respondents said they worry that such missile development might cause an arms race across the Taiwan Strait, compared with 45.3 percent who said they don't.

According to the poll, 10.2 percent of respondents "very much approve" of the initiative to develop long-range missiles, while 31.9 said they "approve" of the initiative. Nineteen percent of respondents said they "sort of disapprove" of the idea, while 7.2 percent said they "very much disapprove" of it.
However, 31.7 percent of respondents either said they "do not know" or declined to answer the question about the prospect and justification of Taiwan's development of long-range missiles.

Asked whether they are worried that long-range missile development would trigger an arms race between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, 9.6 percent of respondents said they are "very much worried," while 29.3 percent said they "are worried."
Of the respondents, 31.2 percent said are "not worried much," while 14.1 percent said they are "not at all worried."
The other 15.8 percent either had "no idea" or declined to answer whether they worry or not.
The poll was conducted between Dec. 13 and 15 with the participation of 1,220 adults, and carried an error margin of 2.86 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MAINLAND CITIES TARGETED AS TOP CHOICES FOR DIRECT AIR LINKS

TEXT.P: Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou are the three mainland Chinese cities targeted by a government-run agency as the top destination choices for direct air links between Taiwan and mainland China once such relations become possible and feasible.

Describing the likelihood of direct air links between Taiwan and mainland China as "only a matter of time," researchers at the Institute of Transportation (IOT) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Taiwan should make relevant preparations for that possibility, although the existing political atmosphere across the Taiwan Strait makes it hardly feasible.
Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou, forming a golden triangle in the eastern part of mainland China, as a whole command about 80 percent of air transport for the entire mainland.
Beijing, taking the former place of Guangzhou, is now the busiest airport in mainland China, with the number of departures and arrivals growing at a pace of 12 percent yearly.

The annual total of departing and landing flights is expected to reach 180,000 by the year 2000, while the number of passengers traveling through Beijing's Capital Airport is expected to reach 35 million by 2005, with cargo transport amounting to 780,000 metric tons that year, according to IOT specialists.

Guangzhou's White Cloud airport is the most important air gateway in southern China. The capacity of the international airport is expected to be expanded substantially when its new terminal is completed in 2002, the specialists said.
The Shanghai New Airport, which opened in September this year, is currently the largest and most advanced airport in mainland China, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES TO UNDERGO WIDE FLUCTUATION DUE TO WTO IMPACT

TEXT.P: In the long term, Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) is expected to affect the local foreign exchange, capital and insurance markets, as well as the banking sector, according to a recent financial report by the Finance Ministry.

Domestic stock prices are expected to undergo wide fluctuation for a period of time after the island enters the world trade regulatory body, due to Taipei's lifting of most restrictions on capital investment, which will allow more funds to flow into the stock and futures markets.

Taiwan is expected to become a WTO member by next year, because its efforts to open its markets have been recognized by most members of the WTO, the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

The report on the impact of WTO membership on Taiwan's financial sectors, which was published on Sunday, predicted that the local capital market will further merge with the international financial market after Taiwan joins the WTO, whereby the island's globalization will be further developed.

Regarding the banking sector, the report said WTO membership will lead foreign competition directly to the island. No domestic bank that has never sought to enhance competitiveness can be spared from the impact, the report warned, saying the government is developing a program to encourage local banks to merge with each other, a strategy that could help strengthen the industry's competitive edge.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% BELIEVE SOONG HAS NOT FULLY EXPLAINED 'MYSTERY FUND': POLL

TEXT.P: Seventy percent of people surveyed said independent presidential candidate James Soong has not provided a full explanation of the "mystery fund" at Chuang Hsing Bills Finance Corp., the latest poll showed on Sunday.

The poll was conducted by New Image Opinion Center Dec. 15 - 17, right after Soong first tried on Tuesday to explain deposits in his son's account. The survey's effective sample totaled 971, with a margin of error of 3.21 percent.
Only 9.1 percent of respondents believed that Soong has fully explained the mystery fund, while 20.9 percent said they had no opinion.

Some 48 percent of those polled also said they do not agree that Soong is honest and a man of integrity as he claims to be; 21.1 percent said they believed his statements about his character, and 20.9 percent said they had no opinion.

Some 47.1 percent of respondents said they didn't believe that the money was turned over to Soong by now President Lee Teng-hui, while 19.3 percent said they believe Soong's claim. Some 33 percent said they had no opinion.

On the question of whether it is reasonable for Soong to have put the money, supposedly earmarked for taking care of the family of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, into his son's account, 65.1 percent of those polled said it was unreasonable. Some 11.3 percent deemed it reasonable, and 23.7 percent had no opinion.

Professor Lee Kuo-hsiung, in analyzing the poll, said the results showed that around one third of those polled could not make heads nor tails of the "mystery fund," illustrating the complexity of the case.

The controversial "mystery fund" has dealt a blow to the popularity of Soong, the front-runner in past polls, the survey showed, revealing that if the presidential election were held the following day, Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party would have a modest lead.

Chen lead with 22.3 percent saying they would vote for him, followed by 21.6 percent supporting Vice President Lien Chan of the ruling Kuomintang, and Soong's 20 percent. The other presidential hopefuls Hsu Hsin-liang and Li Ao garnered distant 1.1-percent and 0.8-percent support rates, respectively.

But Lien is still favored to win the presidential election, with 34.8 percent of those interviewed believing he will be the next leader. Soong was predicted victorious by 14.5 percent, and 10.3 percent thought Chen would be the winner.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL CRITICIZES KMT BUSINESS OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), on Sunday strongly criticized the ruling Kuomintang for its huge financial holdings and said he was ashamed of what the KMT had done.

Chen called on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 general election, and said he will do whatever he can to finish off the KMT's "black money" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
Chen pointed out in his campaign speech in Taipei County on Sunday morning that Macau's handover to mainland China rule is not in line with the will of the people of Macau.
He reiterated that the future destiny of Taiwan will be decided by its own people.

Chen said the KMT has accumulated a lot of historical burdens, such as running enterprises, creating a privileged class, engaging in "black money" politics and establishing a conservative government, during its many long years of power.

The upcoming vote will be the only way to implement political reform by exchanging the ruling party for another political party, in line with the system adopted by the democratic countries of the world, Chen said.
Chen also criticized President Lee Teng-hui's hand-picked successor Vice President Lien Chan as being unable to cope with the historical burdens accumulated by the KMT's long rule.
Chen described independent presidential hopeful and former Taiwan governor James Soong's cross-political-party concept as an "impractical and one-man political" approach.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAND CORPORATION RELEASES REPORT ON TAIWAN'S SECURITY POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Shu Lu-sheng & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A report released by the Rand Corporation on Saturday advises that the US military maintain close contact with Taiwan's defense policy makers and strengthen relations with the Taiwan military authorities.
But it also cautions that excessive closeness in the bilateral military relationship may irritate mainland China.
The report, commissioned by the Pentagon, was authored by a group headed by Michael D. Swaine, director of Rand Corporation's Asia-Pacific Policy Research Center.
It touches on Taiwan's national security, defense policy and arms procurement.
According to Swaine, Taiwan's defense policy and arms procurement have been influenced by some non-military factors, which have to some extent affected the actual usage of foreign-made arms.
He also asked those in charge of arms sales on the US side to make an effort to better understand, and therefore meet, Taiwan's actual requirements in terms of arms procurement.
Swaine said the formulation of Taiwan's security policy should be further strengthened, especially in terms of coordination between its security section and its military.

The report indicates that the US arms-sale policy has solidified the basis for stabilizing the East Asian situation over the past decade, but warns that it could also encourage an arms race between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT AND DPP TRADE CHARGES ON RESULTS OF PUBLIC OPINION SURVEY

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DDP) traded charges Sunday on the results of public opinion surveys.

The DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan charged that several public opinion survey centers directly or indirectly controlled by the Public Opinion Association of the Republic of China, have allegedly been involved in conducting polls in favor of a particular candidate.

Those polling institutes included: the survey center of the Business Faculty of National Taiwan University, the Mass Communications Institute of National Taiwan Normal University, and the Political Science Institute of National Chungshan University.

Chen Chi-mai (DPP-Kaohsiung City) said at a press conference Sunday that the support rating for DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian was reported at 12.4 percent and 16.3 percent in polls conducted by the Public Opinion Association of the Republic of China on Aug. 28 and Dec. 9, respectively.
At those same times, polls by TVBS showed a 28-percent and a 30.9-percent rate of support for the DPP candidate, said Chen Chi-mai.

He went on to say that results released by the aforementioned centers have not only differred from those of other polling institutes, but have also favored the ruling KMT's candidate, Vice President Lien Chan.
Chen Chi-mai further charged that the ruling KMT spent a large sum of money to purchase these survey institutes.
Meanwhile, Ting Yuan-tsao, spokesman for the Presidential Office, categorically refuted the DPP's charges and called on the opposition party to produce evidence of its claims.
Prof. Hsien Chang-bang, who was in charge of the surveys by the Public Opinion Association of the ROC, charged the DPP of mixing the survey with politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S TALLEST PERSON TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The world's tallest person has been invited to visit Taiwan next week, it was reported on Sunday.

Twenty-nine-year-old Nasir Ahmed Soomro of Pakistan, listed as the world's tallest person by the Guinness Book of World Records at a height of 236.2 cm, was invited to visit Taiwan by the Guinness museum in Taichung, central Taiwan.
To welcome the guest of distinguished height, the hotel Westin has made special arrangements for an extra-long bed to provide him with a comfortable night's sleep.
The museum in Taichung has also ordered special furniture to meet Soomro's needs.

Museum officials said they are also asking tailors to make an outfit especially for him, modeled on museum-displayed clothes once worn by the world's tallest woman, 248-cm Zeng Jinshen of Hunan, mainland China.

In addition to living in the museum for four months for the expressed purpose of allowing the public to learn more about his daily life, Soomro will also play the role of roving ambassador and visit primary and middle schools to encourage youth to do more exercises so that they can grow tall and strong.

Soomro took his compatriot's place as the world's tallest person. Asked why Pakistan is filled with tall people, museum officials said the question is better left for Soomro, who is scheduled to arrive Wednesday, to answer. (by Lilian Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEYS INDICATE AMERICANS CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN SITUATION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Recent surveys in the United States and Japan indicated that US citizens are more concerned than the Japanese about the Taiwan Strait situation.

The surveys were conducted by Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun daily newspaper among 3,000 eligible voters in that country in late October, and by the Gallop company among 1,002 voters in the United States between mid-October and mid-November.
When asked to name areas that would pose military threat to them, 52 percent of US respondents named the Middle East, while 51 percent pointed to the Taiwan Strait and 31 percent to Russia.
Seventy-nine percent of Japanese respondents said the Korean peninsula represents a potential military threat to Japan, while 25 percent listed the Taiwan Strait and 19 percent mentioned Russia.
The survey results were published in the Yomiuri Shimbun's Sunday issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 20, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Kim Young Sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by US Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of cerebral apoplexy at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The nation chooses 26 new members to the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Artur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 US troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae Jung pardons Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1999: Portugal hands Macau back to mainland China, ending 442 years of it colonial rule over the Asian gambling resort.
Confucius: "Now if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment, even if you would."
