DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOURNALIST RELEASED FROM POLICE CUSTODY IN MACAU
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Ken Su and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese journalist Ming-chen Chen was released by Macau police Sunday evening after being held in custody for seven hours.

Chen, a news reporter with the Taiwanese evening paper, the Power News, was taken away by police Sunday morning while covering a story in front of a downtown Macau hotel where Falun Gong practitioners were staging a demonstration against Beijing's suppression of the religious group.
Chen was hauled away together with a Hong Kong journalist and scores of Falun Gong members.
Officials from the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office, the de facto liaison office of the Republic of China in Macau, said they quickly came to Chen's assistance soon after her arrest.

Chen was released after the Macau authorities became aware that she was not involved in any illegal activities and had only forgotten to carry her identification papers with her while covering the story, said the Taiwan officials.

Chen was among some 2,100 journalists and news workers from around the world who swamped into the tiny enclave of Macau in southern China to cover its return to mainland Chinese control after 442 years of Portuguese rule.
Chen is scheduled to fly back to Taiwan on Tuesday, according to sources at her news organization in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' UNACCEPTABLE TO ROC: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Mainland China's "one country, two systems" unification scheme is unacceptable to the Republic of China on Taiwan, Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen said categorically on Money.

Chen was responding to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's speech delivered at the Macau handover ceremony, in which he said: "the implementation of the concept 'one country, two systems' in Hong Kong and Macau has played and will continue to play an important exemplary role for our eventual settlement of the Taiwan question."

Stressing that Taiwan's status is completely different from that of Macau and Hong Kong, Chen said both the ROC government and people cannot accept the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification formula.
Noting that both Hong Kong and Macau used to be colonies of Western countries, Chen said their residents had no choice but to accept their colonial rulers' decision on the territories' status.

In contrast, Chen said, the ROC is a sovereign democratic state. "We have strength to safeguard our national security. Our people can make choices out of their free will," Chen said, adding that the Beijing leader was absolutely wrong in attempting to apply to Taiwan the formula it had used to take over Hong Kong and Macau.

Moreover, Chen said, the results of a series of public opinion surveys conducted over the past decade consistently show that the majority of Taiwan people do not accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification formula.

Chen further said Hong Kong's reversion from British rule to mainland China's jurisdiction in 1997 has not had any significant impact on Taiwan's diplomatic relations nor its interaction with the mainland.

Against this backdrop, Chen said Macau's handover will have limited impact on Taiwan's external ties and its relations with mainland China as the former Portuguese colony possesses far less clout than Hong Kong.

Meanwhile, Chen said the international community generally understands the ROC's negative stance toward Beijing's "one country, two systems" scheme. Even the results of opinion polls conducted in Hong Kong a couple of years ago show that more than half of Hong Kong residents do not think that the formula is applicable to Taiwan, the minister added.
In related news, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Cheng An-kuo also said on Monday that Macau's handover is not expected to have great impact on relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Nevertheless, the former ROC representative to Hong Kong, said the MAC, a Cabinet-level agency which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, will work out measures to cope with Beijing's renewed advocacy of the so-called "one country, two systems" unification scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR DEFENSE SIRENS TO SOUND TUESDAY AFTERNOON

TEXT.P: Air defense sirens will sound in Taiwan and the Penghu area on Tuesday afternoon, the General Headquarters of the Air Force (GHQAF) said in a press release on Monday.
The GHQAF said the sirens will begin sounding at 2:30 p.m. to test the air defense system.
It said pedestrians and vehicles will not be subject to controls during the air raid warning test.
The sirens will sound for one and a half minutes, said the GHQAF.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTEMPT TO EXPAND HK, MACAU FORMULA TO TAIWAN `INSULTING': MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China's attempt to expand the "one country, two systems" formula in Hong Kong and Macau to Taiwan is both "insulting and provocative," the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday.

The MAC was responding to mainland China President Jiang Zemin's speech during the Macau handover ceremony early Monday when he said "the implementation of the concept of `one country, two systems' in Hong Kong and in Macau has played and will continue to play an important role for our eventual settlement of the Taiwan question."

The government body in charge of working out mainland policy said that it can understand why Beijing keeps harping on the "one country, two systems" formula, but it hopes that mainland authorities will understand that the majority of Taiwan's people won't accept it.
For the people on the island, who have long enjoyed freedom and democracy, the MAC said that to expand the same formula to Taiwan would be both "insulting and provocative."

The MAC noted that the concept was first broached by mainland leader Deng Xiaoping in the 1980s to handle the Hong Kong and Macau turnovers, and that the mainland is now trying to force cross-strait unification by imposing the same formula on Taiwan.

The MAC pointed out Beijing's total disregard of the fact that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been ruled separately for a long period of time. If Beijing does not face the issue pragmatically and continues to harp the same tune, it will not be conducive to cross-strait development, the MAC said.

The MAC expressed the hope that mainland authorities will "address the cross-strait situation, respect the wishes of the people of Taiwan, and forego its rigid way of thinking" in order to handle relations in a pragmatic manner and create a favorable situation for the positive development of cross-strait relations in the next millennium.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TAKING PART IN WORLD LEAGUE FOR FREEDOM & DEMOCRACY CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Twenty delegates from the Republic of China are attending a conference of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in Brisbane along with scores of representatives from 15 other countries, organizers said.

The ROC delegation, led by Yao Yin-chi, deputy speaker of the Legislative Yuan, includes former Ambassador Tien Pao-tai, secretary general of the Asian Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy and other members of Parliament.
Most of the participating delegates are from other countries, including Russia, Japan, New Zealand, Malaysia, Vietnam, Singapore, Thailand, Fiji, Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines.
The delegates are discussing better ways of promoting freedom and democracy in the Asian and Pacific region by influencing their respective governments, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU'S HANDOVER TO HAVE LITTLE IMPACT ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Macau's return to mainland Chinese rule will have little impact on cross Taiwan Strait relations, a government official said on Monday.

Cheng An-kuo, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's top agency in charge of mainland Chinese affairs, said that although mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's statement during the hand-over ceremony that "the Taiwan issue will be solved with the `one China, two systems' formula" is nothing new, it is causing concern in Taiwan.

Commenting on Jiang's remarks that Beijing is confident and is capable of handling the cross-strait issue with the "one country, two systems" formula, Cheng said it clearly shows that Beijing authorities still don't understand what the Taiwanese people are thinking.

Or else, Cheng said, it simply shows that Beijing does not respect the will of the people of Taiwan and cannot face the fact that Taiwan and mainland China exist as two separate political entities across the Taiwan Strait.

Cheng, who was Taiwan's chief liaison officer in Hong Kong before being appointed the MAC vice chairman early this month, reiterated that the "one country, two systems" formula, which was imposed by Beijing on Hong Kong, cannot be applied to Taiwan because the ROC on Taiwan is a sovereign state and not a colony like Hong Kong or Macau before the handovers.
He stressed that the "one country, two systems" formula is not conducive to better cross-strait relations and will also never be acceptable to the Taiwanese people.

Currently, the ROC's cross-strait policy remains the same, to facilitate bilateral exchanges and consultations so as to help remove hostility and build mutual trust between the two sides, Cheng noted.

Meanwhile, Cheng, who maintains close connections with both Hong Kong and Macau, said he hopes that Taiwan's office in Macau will be allowed to maintain normal operations after Macau's return to Chinese control.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS US CONGRESSWOMAN PELOSI

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Monday that the Republic of China's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
While looking forward to seeing the mainland turn into a society with greater freedom and democracy, Taiwan is doing its utmost to maintain sustainable development, Lee said.
It is hoped that the social and political gaps between Taiwan and mainland China will continue to narrow so as to accelerate the process toward the ultimate goal of peaceful reunification, Lee added.
President Lee made the remarks when he met with US congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif) at the Presidential Office Monday morning. Pelosi and her husband are currently visiting in Taipei.
Lee welcomed Pelosi's visit and thanked her for making the trip to gain a first-hand understanding of Taiwan's situation after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake that struck on Sept. 21.
In addition to discussing earthquake-related matters, Lee also informed Pelosi of Taiwan's efforts to protect human rights.
Meanwhile, the president expressed gratitude to the US Congress for its long-term support for the Republic of China and its people on various issues.
For her part, Pelosi said she was impressed with the changes and progress she has seen in Taiwan in various fields.
The House representative from California said Taiwan has been an example for many other Asian countries to emulate and she will continue to seek US congressional support for Taiwan's cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TO HOLD LIVE AMMUNITION DRILLS DEC. 22-24

TEXT.P: The Air Force will hold live ammunition firing practice in the offshore Penghu islands Dec. 22-24 as part of its annual training sessions, the General Headquarters of the Air Force (GHQAF) said in a press release on Monday.

The GHQAF said the Air Force will stage the live fire drills in the R-7 aviation restricted zone, located on Tsao Yu island in the Penghu island group, from 7:00 a.m to 10 a.m. on each of the three days.
The GHQAF urged aircraft and ships not to approach the area during the period and apologized to the public for inconvenience caused by the practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE BRIGHT FOR ROC-AUSTRALIA TIES: ROC REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: The future looks bright for development of substantial relations between Australia and the Republic of China, the ROC representative to Australia said on Monday.

Liu Po-lun, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Australia, made the remarks when he reported on current relations between the ROC and Australia to a committee at the Legislative Yuan.
Liu said the ROC and Australia are both democratic countries and share the same ideals of upholding freedom and rule of law.

He also noted that during mainland China President Jiang Zemin's trip to Australia three months ago, Australian Prime Minister John Howard said in a luncheon speech on Sept. 8 that while Australia will uphold its "one China" policy, it will also continue its commercial and economic relations with Taiwan.
Howard said any issue between the ROC and Australia will be resolved in a friendly and peaceful way, as that solution would be in the best interest of the region.

Liu said that at a joint press conference on the same day, Howard both reaffirmed that point and said Australia encourages both sides of the Taiwan Strait to settle their differences by non-military means.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped 0.4 cents to close at 31.661 against the greenback on Monday on the Taipei foreign change market.
The currency opened at the day's high of 31.652, and had a low of 31.661. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$149.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES EDGE DOWN, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices edged down 0.2 percent Monday on sluggish trading as investors took quick profits after Saturday's rebound.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 14.93 points lower at 7,782.94 on a largely shrinking turnover of NT$90.50 (US$2.86 billion), with only 1.8 billion shares changing hands.

According to brokers, investors started hunting for bargains among shares that have been suffering from lackluster performance for some time, in order to establish their positions for stock investment in 2000, a year seen by analysts as promising to be bullish and profitable.
In the near term, there is not expected to be any strong movement in the market, dealers added.

Most of the eight major stock categories posted gentle gains, with the paper-making sector enjoying the largest gains of 1.3 percent. Only electronics shares, construction stocks and financial issues reported losses, down 0.4 percent, 0.9 percent and 0.8 percent, respectively.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 261 to 196, with 97 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 1.87 points to close at 192.82 on a turnover of NT$12.98 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted mixed results, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved down 19 points to close at 7,841 with 1,010 contract transactions. Those for February declined 17 points to finish at 7,850 with 10 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March rose six points to close at 7,924 with three contract transactions, while those for June dipped eight points to finish at 7,972 with five contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,860 points for January, 7,867 points for February, 7,918 points for March, 7,980 points for next June, and 7,922 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported losses.
January TE futures shed 1.55 points to close at 409 with 302 contract transactions, while no transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.
January TF futures declined 11 points to close at 927 with 99 contract transactions, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETURN OF MACAU DOESN'T END E. ASIAN DISPUTES: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: The return of Macau to China will not end the territorial disputes in East Asia as Beijing is working hard to resume sovereignty over its next target, Taiwan, according to Australian experts.

Greg Sheridan, foreign editor of the Australian, and other experts believe the handover of Macau early Monday morning is significant to a new, sovereign China, which sees this as the final step before the return of Taiwan to its fold.
The return of Macau marks the end of more than four hundred years of European colonization and will act as a salve to the nationalism which is the most powerful popular force in China today, he said.
In an article in the daily on Monday, Sheridan said that "one thing Macau does not do is bring a resolution to the tension between China and Taiwan any closer."

He added that "Taiwan, unlike Macau and Hong Kong, is not and has not in recent times been a colony of a Western power and is instead entirely self-governing. It will not accept any similarity between itself and Macau or Hong Kong and continues to reject the "one country, two systems" approach on offer from Beijing."

Sheridan and other experts agree that Chinese adherence to the "one country, two systems" approach in Macau, like Hong Kong, will be intensely scrutinized by the international community after Macau returns to Chinese rule

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO GOV. ISHIHARA HAILS PRES. LEE'S ABLE LEADERSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara on Monday praised Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's able leadership, especially his role in implementing relief measures in the wake of Taiwan's Sept. 21 earthquake, which claimed more than 2,400 lives.
Meeting with more than 150 local and foreign correspondents at Japan's National Press Club, the writer-turned-politician said he will visit Taiwan again if he is invited.

He rejected Beijing's criticism of his recent trip to Taiwan and publicly requested that Beijing authorities explain why they termed his trip to Taiwan "criminal." He furiously told the Beijing authorities to shut up because the matter was none of their concern.

Ishihara said he visited central Taiwan on his trip and found that the government, under the leadership of Lee, was efficiently carrying out reconstruction of those areas affected by the quake, which was 10 times more grave than the one which hit the Kobe area in 1995.

Ishihara also made a field visit to Shikang Dam, which was heavily damaged by the quake, and saw the hard work of soldiers who reached the earthquake-stricken areas three hours after the disaster occurred.

The appropriate ROC government agencies have amended or modified the relevant regulations and rules to more efficiently carry out rescue and reconstruction work, he observed, saying that Japan has a lot to learn from Taiwan on these points.
Remarking on Taipei-Tokyo-Beijing ties, Ishihara said Japan should maintain good relations with Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen) (By Peter Chen & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The last word of the first paragraph of CEP item No. 5 should read "Monday," not "Money." Sorry for misspelling. ROC TAKES PART IN WORLD LEAGUE FOR FREEDOM AND DEMOCRACY MEETING

Canberra, Dec. 20 (CNA) A 20-member Republic of China delegation, led by Legislative Yuan Vice President Rau Yin-chi, attended the World League for Freedom and Democracy's 1999 convention in Canberra.
In addition to the representatives from Taiwan, delegations from 15 countries, including host country Australia, participated in the annual meeting, which opened on Sunday.
Russia, Japan, New Zealand, Malaysia, Vietnam, Singapore, Thailand, Fiji, Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines were among the nations that sent delegates to take part in the two-day event.
Discussion at the meeting centered on how to promote freedom and democracy in the Asia-Pacific region.
The ROC delegation was scheduled to leave Canberra Tuesday and return home after the convention closed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE:
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Peter Chen & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A 20-member Republic of China delegation, led by Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Yin-chi, attended the World League for Freedom and Democracy's 1999 convention in Brisbane. In addition to the representatives from Taiwan, delegations from 15 countries, including host country Australia, participated in the annual meeting, which opened on Sunday.
Russia, Japan, New Zealand, Malaysia, Vietnam, Singapore, Thailand, Fiji, Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines were among the nations that sent delegates to take part in the two-day event.
Discussion at the meeting centered on how to promote freedom and democracy in the Asia-Pacific region.
The ROC delegation was scheduled to leave Canberra Tuesday and return home after the convention closed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE CONGRATULATES NEW MACAU HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Macau congratulated newly sworn-in Macau chief executive Edmund Ho on Monday, one day after the Portuguese enclave of 442 years was returned to mainland Chinese rule.

In a congratulatory letter to Ho, William Li, director of Macau's Taipei Trade and Tourism Office, praised Ho's talent and capability which, he said, is well suited to his job as chief executive of the Macau Special Administrative Region government.
Noting the close trade and economic ties between Taiwan and Macau, Li vowed to do his best to create stable and mutually beneficial bilateral ties.
Like Hong Kong, Macau maintains no official ties with Taiwan, and Li is Taiwan's representative to the former Portuguese enclave.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS EASED ON VISITS BY MAINLAND CHINESE TRADE PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: Restrictions on the number of mainland Chinese economic and trade professionals that can be invited to Taiwan have been eased, the Investment Commission (IC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Monday.

According to the old regulations, a maximum of ten mainland business professionals was permitted to be included in each invitation to Taiwan issued by a Taiwan businessman, and the IC said this number has been increased to 30.

The IC said the amendment has been adopted by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, and will be formally made public by the Exit and Entry Bureau of Immigration under the National Police Administration.
Related government departments have also amended the qualifications required for a local businessman to be able to issue such invitations to mainland Chinese economic and trade professionals.

Under the terms of the amended regulations, Taiwan businessmen who intend to invite mainland trade professionals to Taiwan must own company capital of more than NT$10 million, while their most recent annual turnover must surpass NT$10 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG KUAN-YING LIBRARY INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Wang Kuan-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ordinary man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to local and overseas institutions, was inaugurated in Taipei on Monday.

The new library has been set up in a section of the Taipei Municipal Library's Kuting branch which was extensively renovated using donations from various social quarters, and now accommodates the books and artifacts left by Wang.
A memorial park bearing Wang's name has been constructed in a courtyard adjacent to the library, on one wall of which is inscribed a poem extolling Wang's philanthropic spirit and deeds.
The inaugural ceremony was jointly presided over by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Lin Cheng-chih, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Cultural Affairs.
Ma said at the ceremony that Wang overturned two conventional Chinese concepts in his lifetime -- a "small potato" cannot achieve a great task and an individual person's strength is minimal.

"Wang's life story proves that a small potato can accomplish a great mission and that an individual person's strength can be great," Ma said, adding that so long as a person works diligently toward a single ultimate goal, he or she will eventually succeed.

Wang, born in 1905 in a small township in Shandong province in northeastern mainland China, moved to Taiwan in 1949 along with the Kuomintang (Nationalist) government after the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland.
After retiring from the military, Wang began his scavenging business at the age of 50, with purchasing books for donation to domestic or overseas institutions as his only goal.

He led a simple life but was generous in donating books, and during his lifetime donated more than 400,000 books to over 30 nations, including Britain, Germany, France, Uruguay, Paraguay, the United States, Canada, Australia and Argentina.
Wang died of heart failure at the age of 94 on Dec. 15, 1998, and he was given a posthumous medal by the ruling Kuomintang in recognition of his long-term contribution to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S RIGHTS NOT ADEQUATELY PROTECTED; 4.66 RAPES PER DAY LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Women's rights are still not adequately protected, and their degree of personal safety is actually declining, a women's group said in a report on Monday.
The Awakening Foundation in its 1999 report reviewed women's marriages and family life, job rights, personal safety, and their participation in political affairs last year.
The foundation reported that there was an average of 4.66 rape cases reported each day last year, and the success rate for solving those cases declined.

The foundation cited statistics from the National Police Administration to show that reported rape cases rose to 1,701 in 1998 from 605 in 1989. But the success rate for solving the crimes slipped to 63.6 percent in 1998 from 84.6 percent in 1989.
Women not only have to worry about personal safety in public places, they are not even safe in their own homes.

Tallies from a hotline set up to help protect women's rights showed that last year 15 percent of all women who called for assistance had been abused by their spouses; 2 percent were so severely abused that they could no longer tolerate the violence.

One month after the implementation of the domestic violence prevention law, local courts had received 886 applications for restraining orders, illustrating the extent of rampant domestic violence in Taiwan.

Statistics from a consultation hotline established by the foundation showed that inquires regarding divorce accounted for 30 percent of all questions over the past year, and in most cases the trouble could be attributed to extramarital affairs by the husband or the husband refusing to provide living expenses.

The report did find that the number of college and university lecturers was roughly evenly divided between men and women, but the number of female assistant professors was sharply lower than that of men employed at the same level . The number of male full professors is seven times that of their female counterparts.
On job rights, the low participation rate of Taiwan women has to do with the societal expectation that women shoulder the responsibility of taking care of the family, the report said.

Last year's government survey said that of 4.49 million non-working women, 58.6 percent have not sought jobs because they want to take care of their families, and 25.8 percent women do not solicit jobs at the request of their families.
Those who venture into the job market face such difficulties as sex discrimination and sexual harassment in the workplace.

Women's participation in politics made great strides over the past decade. In 1998, the ratio of women legislators voted into office rose to 19.1 percent from 14 percent in the previous election three years before, ranking Taiwan 22nd in terms of women's participation among parliaments worldwide.
Just last year Wu Pi-chu made political history when she was elected speaker of the Taipei City Council, becoming the first woman in all of Taiwan to ever hold such a post.
Currently five women serve as government Ministers, accounting for 15.6 percent of the Cabinet headed by Vincent Siew. The figure is the highest it has ever been in the history of Taiwan.

The foundation concluded that with the promulgation of such laws as the sexual abuse prevention law, the domestic violence prevention law and others, the inequality that women have suffered under Taiwan's legal system has been somewhat corrected, but those efforts are not sufficient enough to really improve women's plight.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA SPARES NO EFFORTS TO SET UP GLOBAL TRADE INFORMATION NETWORK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) is planning to build a global network on the Internet to integrate trade information of Taiwan businessmen living all over the world.

CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-kuo said on Monday that the planned Taiwan business "e-community" network will be designed to serve as a bridge allowing information exchanges on trade and investment and the launch of trade orders between local and foreign enterprises.

The Chinese community controls 70 percent of the economic power in the Southeast Asian area, while other regions of the world are also home to many Taiwan businesses, CETRA Secretary-General Ricky Y. S. Kuo pointed out.

The planned network will contain e-mail addresses and company data of Taiwan businesses overseas, and will lead to the emergence of a comprehensive Taiwan business society, which could provide fertile ground for creating trade opportunities, Kuo added, noting that the network is expected to be on line within the next six months.
In related news, meanwhile, CETRA statistics show that since the council's opening of Taiwan's first e-commerce operation in March, 30,000 business deals have been clinched through the new channel.
At present, nearly 50,000 domestic and foreign enterprises use the Internet to expand their positions in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: NET CAPITAL INFLOW SETS NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Net capital inflow in mid-November totaled US$22 billion, setting a record high and showing that foreign capital is continuing to flow into the local bourse, Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan said on Monday.

Perng made the remarks as he reported to the Financial Committee of the Legislative Yuan on the impact of Taiwan's membership in the World Trade Organization on the financial services industry, and measures to cope with it.

Perng noted that since the beginning of this year, foreign capital has continued to enter the domestic stock market. Compared with the same period of last year, net capital inflow has increased by US$11.4 billion, up by more than 100 percent.
The ratio of foreign capital invested in the domestic stock market accounted for 5.5 percent of its total market value, up from 2 percent or 3 percent in the past.

Perng also said that the CBC is planning to set up a system to monitor the foreign capital situation in order to maintain the stability of the domestic foreign exchange market and cushion the impact caused by WTO entry.
CBC officials said that to this end, the CBC will ask banks for notification of any large foreign exchange transactions so that they can be checked by the CBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE ANNOUNCES CONSTITUTIONAL POLICY

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian on Monday announced his constitutional policy, and said that if elected president in March, he will call a national conference on constitutional reform.
The conference would bring together representatives from all parties, scholars and experts, as well as civic leaders, to thoroughly discuss relevant issues, he said.

Describing the present constitution as "full of loopholes," Chen said that he intends to adopt a political system based on the three government powers -- administration, legislature and judiciary -- instead of the existing five powers -- administration, judiciary, legislature, examination and control.

He went on to say that he hopes to combine the functions of the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan (Cabinet) and the Examination Yuan into an administrative branch, while forming a more powerful parliament through the merger of the Legislative Yuan, the Control Yuan and the National Assembly.

On the status of Taiwan's identity, the former Taipei mayor said that the renovated constitution should acknowledge the fact that Taiwan is a sovereign country, and any change to that status must be decided by public plebiscite.
The presidential hopeful said that Beijing's claim that Taiwan is no more than a regional government is totally unacceptable.
He also said that he wants to adopt a presidential system rather than the present dual-leadership system which places political power on the president and the premier.

Chen said that the present constitution was introduced when the Republic of China was still based in mainland China over half a century ago, and that despite revisions by the ruling Kuomintang over the years, many constitutional problems remain unresolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER OUTLINES AIR FORCE PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday that he feels deep regret over a string of flight mishaps involving military aircraft over the past two years.

Tang, a former air force commander-in-chief and chief of the General Staff, said he wishes the civilian sector would give military servicemen more encouragement and less condemnation in order to boost their morale.
Tang made the remarks in an interview with a radio station concerning the Ministry of National Defense's stance on handling flight accidents involving the country's second-generation warplanes.

Since March 1998, four of Taiwan's US-made F-16 jet fighters and two French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters have crashed during training flights, causing widespread concern over the air force's flight safety control measures.
Tang said the Republic of China Air Force, like many of its foreign counterparts, faces manpower shortage problems which result mainly from the low pay and heavy work pressure in the military.

The ROC Air Force faces even heavier work pressure than its foreign counterparts because it took delivery of four different types of aircraft -- locally developed Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs), F-16s, Mirage 2000-5s and E2T early warning/command aircraft -- at almost same time, Tang said, adding that nearly no other country's air force is burdened with this kind of workload.

Because of structural and budgetary restrictions, Tang said, the air force was not well prepared to cope with the challenges presented by the almost simultaneous delivery of four different types of warplane, all requiring specialist maintenance and pilot training.

Tang said he has discussed feasible ways to tackle the issues with Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming. "We have tentatively decided not to let the air force investigate flight mishaps and study preventive and improvement measures alone. We agree that the defense ministry and even the entire government should use their resources and strengths to assist the air force to improve flight safety."

As commercial airline companies have offered higher pay to lure air force pilots and aircraft maintenance personnel, Tang said, the air force faces a serious manpower shortage problem. Heavy workload and pressure from the public's high expectations of their performance are also factors prompting air force pilots and maintenance technicians to leave the military, Tang added.

Against this background, Tang said the government should work out effective ways to retain trained military pilots and maintenance officers. In addition to raising pay, fringe benefits and welfare services, Tang said the public should give military servicemen more respect and encouragement to boost their morale and sense of honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REVISES REGULATIONS TO ALLOW POLICEMEN TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Interior Ministry on Monday approved revised regulations which will allow more than 75,000 local policemen to visit mainland China for family reunions or to visit sick relatives.
The old regulations prohibited Taiwan policemen from visiting the mainland for any purpose.
Under the revised regulations, the restrictions will be limited to around 340 officers with "special" administrative responsibilities and those with sensitive missions.

These policemen will still be able to apply to visit the mainland, but the applications will be subject to approval from a screening panel formed by the National Security Bureau, the Justice Ministry and the Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD LEARN FROM ITS OWN REUNIFICATION FORMULA

TEXT.P: Beijing should use the "one country, two systems" formula to catch up with Macau and Hong Kong in democratic and economic development rather than use it to woo Taiwan into reuniting with mainland China, a Kuomintang official said on Monday.

Chang Jung-kung, KMT director-general of the Mainland Affairs Research Department made the statement to dispute Beijing leader Jiang Zemin's statement on Sunday night that the implementation of "one country, two systems" in Hong Kong and now in Macau should play an exemplary role for the settlement of the Taiwan question.

Chang said the fact that the formula coined by late Beijing leader Deng Xiaoping as a way to reunify with Taiwan had to be tested in Hong Kong and Macau first indicates the complexity and difficulty of unifying Taiwan. However, he went on, Taiwan is beyond the control of Beijing and its situation is not all like the historically inevitable return of Hong Kong and Macau.

Beijing should learn from the economic prosperity and democracy of Hong Kong and Macau under the formula, rather than pitch it to Taiwan, because Taiwan is more developed than Hong Kong and Macau in both these fields, and has nothing to learn from either the former British colony or the Portuguese enclave which was handed back to Beijing on Sunday after 442 years of Western rule, said Chang.

With Hong Kong and Macau returning to the mainland fold, Chang said it is understandable that Beijing is raring to also take over Taiwan, the last piece of its claimed territory still outwith its control, and he added that he will not be surprised if Beijing reiterates its determination to claim the island.

Although Jiang could be pressed by his more hawkish colleagues to consider the idea of a deadline for taking over Taiwan, the mainland affairs expert said he does not expect Beijing to announce any time schedule for reunification, because this would only further alienate Taiwan, and rob the communist regime of any leeway regarding a recovery action.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 21, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims from the ship Mayflower go ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony.
1846: Anesthetic is used for the first time in a British hospital when Scottish physician Robert Liston amputates a leg at University College Hospital in London.
1898: Scientists Pierre and his wife Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases to publish after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the jazz age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany in World War II, dies as a result of a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the US' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to Earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to imprisonment term of more than 10 years for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just then the people will not submit."
