DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FOREIGN MINISTER COLD TO JIANG'S TAIWAN COMMENTS

TEXT.P: Australia's Foreign Minister threw cold water on China's goal of an early reunification with Taiwan after President Jiang Zemin's comments during the Macau handover ceremony that Beijing could apply the "one country, two systems" formula to Taiwan at an earlier date.

In a dispatch from Macau, the Sydney Morning Herald's China correspondent David Lague on Monday quoted Downer as saying that he did not see any prospects of such a development in the foreseeable future.
"I certainly don't think at this stage in history that Taiwan is quite ready to endorse the `one-country, two systems' approach that has been embraced by Hong Kong and Macau," he said.

Downer's comment was in response to the Herald's question after Jiang's comment on Monday that "the implementation of the `one country, two systems' concept in Hong Kong and Macau has played and will continue to play an exemplary role for our eventual settlement of the Taiwan question."
"The Chinese government and people are confident and capable of an early settlement of the Taiwan question and complete national reunification," Jiang added.

But Downer, who led the Australian delegation to the handover ceremony, said he did not see any likelihood of such a reunification any time soon and instead mentioned that Australia was "anxious" for a reduction in tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Tension between Taiwan and China remains high with Beijing threatening to use force if Taipei resorts to independence.
Jiang's goal of expanding the present formula to Taiwan's reunification with the mainland is "unacceptable," said Republic of China Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen in response to Jiang's speech.
The Mainland Affairs Council in Taiwan even described Jiang's statements during the speech as "insulting and provocative."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEPUTY SPEAKER URGES AUSTRALIA TO SEND MINISTERS TO BOOST TIES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's vice president Yao Yin-chi, leader of the Republic of China delegation to the World League for Freedom and Democracy conference in Brisbane, has asked Australian parliamentarians and senior officials to urge their government to send ministers to help boost trade ties between Australia and Taiwan.

In an interview with the CNA prior to his return to Taipei following the two-day conference, Yao said he held talks with MPs, including Ray Hollis, speaker of the Queensland Parliament, and also with Brisbane's Lord Mayor Jim Soorley in separate meetings.
Yao said he encouraged them to urge their federal government to send ministers to Taiwan so that they could work toward strengthening economic relations between the two countries.

He also told them that the Legislative Yuan is expected to approve legislation aimed at further liberalizing agricultural imports for many countries, including Australia, ahead of Taiwan's likely entry into the World Trade Organization.

"I told Australian MPs and officials that the liberalization would offer huge opportunities to Australia in their agricultural exports to Taiwan. They were impressed with my information and look forward to the opportunity of selling more farm products to our country," Yao said.

Yao led a 20-member delegation to the World League for Freedom and Democracy conference. Scores of delegates from 15 other countries, including Russia, Japan, New Zealand, Malaysia, Singapore, South Korea, India, Indonesia and the United States, also attended the meeting, which focused on discussions for further promoting freedom and democracy around the world.

At a speech on Monday, Yao said many MPs and government officials from other countries are not denied the right to speak and meet with their counterparts while visiting other countries. But MPs and officials from Taiwan are restricted in their activities during their visits to other countries because the hosts want to appease mainland China.
China always tries to strangle Taiwan's international presence by pressuring other countries with its political and economic clout, Yao said.
He added that Taiwan, a newly developed country, also has a lot of economic clout and strong purchasing power.

He said that although Taiwan is not a big country, it is a major economic power with huge foreign exchange reserves of more than US$103 billion that also ranks as the 14th biggest trading country in the world.
"How can so many countries bend to Chinese demands and threats in such an unreasonable way and keep their distance from Taiwan, which is a free and democratic country," he asked.
Yao and the rest of the ROC delegates are heading back to Taipei on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OECD SAYS AUSTRALIA'S NEW GST WILL INCREASE INFLATION

TEXT.P: Australia will face sustained inflation if it implements a new 10 percent goods and services tax in July 2000, according to a survey by the Organization for Economic and Cooperation Development (OECD).

The OECD said authorities must be wary of the higher prices that the 10 percent GST will lead to and it called on the Australian government to boost assistance to the unemployed and unskilled workers.

The OECD predicts that Australia's unemployment rate could fall to 6.5 percent from the current 6.7 percent in 2001 but its inflation would stand at around 2.25 percent, excluding the impact of the GST. Its economy is expected to grow at an average if 3 percent, dragged down by lower business investment as a result of the introduction of the GST.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOBILE PHONE BILLS HIGHER IN AUSTRALIA THAN MANY NATIONS

TEXT.P: Mobile phone bills in Australia are higher than the average in many other countries despite deregulation, a new survey shows.

The survey by the Australian Productivity Commission shows Australia is in the mid-range for overall telecommunications prices when compared with major competitors such as Japan, the US, Sweden, Canada, France and Britain.

The average price of mobile phone calls declined by just 1 percent between February 1998 and June of this year. Over the same period, New Zealand cut the price of mobile telephone calls by 55 percent, France by 49 percent and Sweden by 23 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU DETAINEES TO BE HELD ALONGSIDE MAINLAND COMPATRIOTS

TEXT.P: Stowaways from Macau who try to enter Taiwan will be dealt with according to the Republic of China's Hong Kong-Macau Relations Act beginning with Monday's return of the Portuguese enclave to mainland Chinese rule.

From now on, any Macau resident found guilty of violating the law in Taiwan, including stowaways and those who overstay their visas or engage in activities incompatible with their visa status, will be sent to the detention center in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, which was established for people from the two former colonies to await repatriation.
The act was promulgated by the Republic of China government in 1997.
Starting Dec. 20, there is no longer any division in housing areas at the Hsinchu detention center for people from Macau, Hong Kong and mainland China.

As a matter of fact, the "Hong Kong and Macau People's Detention Center" was opened back in 1997 following the reversion of the British colony to mainland Chinese rule. But over the past two years, only six people from Macau or Hong Kong have been temporarily detained at the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHER REPORTS ON PROPAGATION OF ASIA'S BIGGEST GROUPER

TEXT.P: A researcher in eastern Taiwan has reported the first successful artificial breeding of the biggest giant grouper found in Asian waters, after more than two years of effort.

Ho Yuan-shing, a researcher at the Taitung branch of the Taiwan Fisheries Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture, said the first batch of adult Epinephelus lanceolatus, each weighing around 50 kg, have already been exported to Hong Kong and Japan.

The giant grouper (called lungpan by local fishermen), which can grow to at least 288 kg, is treasured for its delicate meat, while its gall is used in traditional Chinese medicine to treat stomach ailments.

Because of the exorbitantly high prices which the fish commands -- between NT$800-NT$1,000 per catty, although prices have gone as high as NT$1,250 per catty on occasion -- most of the giant groupers caught by Taiwan fishermen are sent to Japan, Hong Kong or Singapore, and local people rarely have the opportunity to taste the delicacy.

Ho said that he is now providing counseling for aquaculturists in Taitung and Pingtung counties, and will soon do the same in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County, before promoting full-scale E. lanceolatus breeding around the island.
Ho noted that a successful breeding program for the giant grouper will mark a step forward in turning Taiwan into a high-value brood fish hub in the Asia-Pacific region.
The giant grouper is common throughout Southeast Asia, although numbers are limited in the waters around Taiwan.
He said that Singapore and Australia began research into the artificial breeding of the giant grouper in the early 1990s, but have made no breakthrough in their research work.

Ho said that with the high economic value of the fish, the institute started experimenting with artificial propagation in mid-1996 after obtaining a government subsidy to carry out the work, which involved importing brood fish from Indonesia and embarking on the complicated process of finding the most suitable water temperature and salinity to create a viable environment for hatching the eggs and raising the fry.

Other problems which Ho had to overcome were the facts that the gender of the fish is unidentifiable outside the spawning season, while it is also difficult to establish doses when administering fertility hormones.
However, he said that his techniques can be used in tuna and other high-value fish to produce fry for export to other countries, thereby enhancing the competitive edge of local fish breeders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HAS HIGHEST RATIO OF OLD TO YOUNG WORLDWIDE

TEXT.P: The ratio of senior citizens to youngsters in Taipei is higher than that in Taiwan and in the world in general, announced the Taipei City government on Tuesday.

Taipei City government officials said the ratio of those over 65 to those under 15 is 1-to-4.4 worldwide, while in Taiwan the proportion was 1-to-2.8, and in Taipei City the figure was 1-to-2.2 last year.

The officials noted that the number of elderly people rises every year in the capital city, and they accounted for 9.22 percent of the total population last year. Among seniors, those without spouses accounted for 36.62 percent. While the number of unmarried senior citizens has dropped gradually, the number of those who are divorced rises every year.
The number of senior citizens in Taipei City who live alone totaled 5,616 as of October this year, the officials said.

Last year the number one cause of death among the elderly was cancer, while cardiopulmonary diseases, such as high blood pressure, bronchitis, emphysema and other diseases also accounted for a great number of deaths.

The officials noted that most elderly men who passed away last year had suffered physically before their deaths, even losing their ability to take care of themselves and becoming completely dependent on their families.

The officials estimated that seniors who have lost the ability to live independently and must rely on others to care for them account for five out of every 100 elderly people. The long-term responsibility of families having to care for them has become a consistent pressure, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU URGED TO FORM AD HOC DEPARTMENT TO DEAL WITH TAIWAN AFFAIRS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Macau still hoped Monday that the Macau Special Administrative Region (SAR) government would set up an ad hoc organization to deal with affairs relating to Taiwan following the Portuguese enclave's return to mainland Chinese rule.

William Li made the statement in response to Macau Chief Executive Edmund Ho's remarks at a post-handover press conference that the Republic of China can maintain contact with the appropriate Macau government departments regarding affairs involving Taiwan.

In other words, Ho will not follow the example of Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, who assigned a specialist to communicate with Taiwan's representative to Hong Kong in dealing with affairs involving the Republic of China.

Ho explained that because exchanges between Macau and Taiwan are mainly in the fields of trade, tourism and culture, relevant departments of the Macau SAR government can maintain contact with the Republic of China in dealing with affairs involving Taiwan, instead of setting up any ad hoc department or appointing any person expressly for that purpose.
Li told the CNA that just having the various departments of the Macau SAR government deal with affairs involving Taiwan would probably result in unharmonious operations when such issues arise.
He hoped that the SAR government would form an ad hoc department or assign a specialist for the purpose of dealing with Taiwan-Macau relations effectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed sharply higher Tuesday on heavy buying of technology shares amid bullish sentiment and easing worries over the year 2000.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 151.32 points higher, or 1.9 percent, at 7,934.26 on an expanded turnover of NT$136.29 billion (US$4.3 billion), compared to the previous session's NT$90.50 billion, with 2.69 billion shares changing hands.

Buying interest was focused on high-technology shares, especially stocks of DRAM chip makers, since market prices of dynamic random access memory chips were expected to rise due to strong demand overseas.
Of the total turnover, nearly 80 percent was traded in electronics shares.
Active foreign fund buying and bargain hunting were also factors behind the day's sound gains.

Led by the financial sector and electronics sector, all of the eight major stock categories posted gains, and the financial sector, which had been suffering from long-term shoddy performance, enjoyed the largest gains of 2.7 percent. Electronics shares reported the second-largest gains of 2.2 percent.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 363 to 115, with 76 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 4.19 points to close at 197.01 on a turnover of NT$18.41 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 129 points to close at 7,970 with 1,884 contract transactions. Those for February advanced 154 points to finish at 8,000 with 35 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 154 points to close at 8,078 with 13 contract transactions, while those for June climbed 162 points to finish at 8,123 with seven contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,841 points for January, 7,846 points for February, 7,924 points for March, 7,961 points for next June, and 7,903 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported gains.
January TE futures rose 5.9 points to close at 406.8 with 727 contract transactions, while no transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.
January TF futures hiked 21 points to close at 948 with 187 contract transactions, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STRESSES WORLD PEACE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday stressed world peace as the Republic of China government's ultimate goal in Taiwan's development of relations with mainland China.

Delivering a speech to more than 300 attendees from the local medical community at Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Siew said the ROC's basic stance on cross-strait ties encompasses the following points:
-- resolving bilateral disputes while sticking to the ROC stance;
-- pursuing world peace while safeguarding Taiwan's security;
-- seeking continued progress for Taiwan while developing mutually beneficial ties with the mainland;
-- strengthening Taiwan-mainland exchanges;
-- pushing for two-way dialogue without attached preconditions.

Siew, who once served as chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, the ROC government's highest agency charting Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said the mainland remains hostile toward Taiwan even now, although it has been a decade since the ROC government terminated the period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion in 1989.
Beijing's continued bullyragging of Taipei in the international community is what causes the greatest concern among ROC government officials posted overseas, he pointed out.

Against such a backdrop, reducing hostility between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be the top issue on Taiwan's agenda in promoting ties with the mainland, the premier stressed. He warned, however, that Taiwan cannot compromise its defense needs in the face of the mainland's growing military clout.
Pointing to Switzerland as an example, he claimed that even a neutral nation needs a strong defense capability to maintain its status.

Refuting some media reports that Taiwan is Beijing's next target following Macau's reversion to mainland Chinese rule on Monday, Siew argued that Taiwan is not a colony as Macau was, and that Taiwan-mainland links are effectively as same as what President Lee Teng-hui described as a "special state-to-state relationship."

The premier, who has been fielded by the ruling Kuomintang as Vice President Lien Chan's running mate in Taiwan's upcoming presidential race slated for March 2000, vowed that the ROC government will continue its current mainland policy if the pair wins the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:
DOC.TEXT:
A researcher in eastern Taiwan has reported the first successful artificial breeding of the biggest giant grouper found in Asian waters, after more than two years of effort.
Ho Yuan-shing, a researcher at the Taitung branch of the Taiwan Fisheries Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture, said the first batch of adult Epinephelus lanceolatus, each weighing around 50 kg, have already been exported to Hong Kong and Japan.
The giant grouper (called lungtan by local fishermen), which can grow to at least 288 kg, is treasured for its delicate meat, while its gall is used in traditional Chinese medicine to treat stomach ailments.
Because of the exorbitantly high prices which the fish commands -- between NT$800-NT$1,000 per catty, although prices have gone as high as NT$1,250 per catty on occasion -- most of the giant groupers caught by Taiwan fishermen are sent to Japan, Hong Kong or Singapore, and local people rarely have the opportunity to taste the delicacy.
Ho said that he is now providing counseling for aquaculturists in Taitung and Pingtung counties, and will soon do the same in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County, before promoting full-scale E. lanceolatus breeding around the island.
Ho noted that a successful breeding program for the giant grouper will mark a step forward in turning Taiwan into a high-value brood fish hub in the Asia-Pacific region.
The giant grouper is common throughout Southeast Asia, although numbers are limited in the waters around Taiwan.
He said that Singapore and Australia began research into the artificial breeding of the giant grouper in the early 1990s, but have made no breakthrough in their research work.
Ho said that with the high economic value of the fish, the institute started experimenting with artificial propagation in mid-1996 after obtaining a government subsidy to carry out the work, which involved importing brood fish from Indonesia and embarking on the complicated process of finding the most suitable water temperature and salinity to create a viable environment for hatching the eggs and raising the fry.
Other problems which Ho had to overcome were the facts that the gender of the fish is unidentifiable outside the spawning season, while it is also difficult to establish doses when administering fertility hormones.
However, he said that his techniques can be used in tuna and other high-value fish to produce fry for export to other countries, thereby enhancing the competitive edge of local fish breeders.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER COUNTY SPEAKER CHARGED WITH EXTORTION

TEXT.P: Former Speaker of Chiayi County Council Hsiao Teng-piao, among others, was charged with extortion on Tuesday, and prosecutors are seeking a harsher-than-usual penalty for him.

In the indictment unsealed on Tuesday, the prosecutors accused Hsiao of involvement in gambling on professional baseball in 1996, and trying to rig the outcomes of baseball games by using violence and extortion.
He was therefore listed as a gangster in 1996, but has eluded arrest for nearly three years until Sept. 18, when he turned himself in to prosecutors.
After a three-month investigation, Hsiao was also charged with obtaining loans using false documents; coercion; and rigging the election of the Farmers Association in Taipao City, Chiayi County.
Hsiao, who has been held in custody since turning himself in, was transferred to the Chiayi District Court for continued detention.

Since several of the six counts of charges against Hsiao are for the same offense, the prosecutor asked the court to mete out a harsher punishment than the maximum penalty carried by each of the offenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: DASSAULT EXPERTS IN TAIWAN TO HELP PROBE MIRAGE 2000-5 ACCIDENTS

TEXT.P: Two aircraft specialists from France's Dassault Corp., the builder of Mirage 2000-5s, flew to Taipei Tuesday to help probe the cause of the recent disappearance of one of the French-made jet fighters belonging to the ROC Air Force.

According to Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman Kung Fan-ting, the two French specialists will compile information gathered from radars, and by using flight simulations, try to determine the spot where the single-seat Mirage 2000-5 went missing.

The specialists will particularly examine information regarding the missing jet's sudden descent from a height of 15,300 feet to 3,300 feet, which could provide some clues about the accident, Kung said.

Answering a reporter's question at a press conference on why the missing Mirage 2000-5 had not been equipped with a position beacon to allow it to be located after a mishap, a spokesman for the Air Force said the position beacons were not requested by the ROC Air Force when it first placed its orders with Dassault.

But after assessing the equipment's importance, the Air Force asked for a supply this year. So far 15 of the French-made fighters have been equipped with the devices, and 32 other position beacons are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Wednesday to be delivered to the Air Force, the spokesman said.

The single-seat Mirage 2000-5 plunged into waters off the coast of the northern county of Ilan on Dec. 14 during a simulated air intercept exercise. The jet lost contact with the control tower when it went down.
On Oct. 15, a twin-seat Mirage 2000-5 crashed on a routine training mission, offshore from Hsinchu. The two pilots ejected to safety and were rescued.

Meanwhile, the Air Force spokesman said that among other reasons behind the five accidents involving Air Force fighters this year, the great pressure that the Air Force pilots have sustained amid tension across the Taiwan Strait should not be ignored.

Sustaining immense physical and psychological pressure, the pilots usually carry out their flying duties under tight schedules without complaint. The spokesman said the wives and families of the Air Force pilots should be offered the deep gratitude of the nation for their thoughtfulness and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EVOLVING INTO ELDERLY SOCIETY

TEXT.P: The 1999 percentage of elderly people among Taiwan's population surged to 8.5 percent, marking the island's evolution into a geriatric society, official statistics show.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) released the news on Tuesday, saying that at present in Taiwan, each pensioner aged 65 or above is supported by an average of eight workers aged between 20 and 64.
CEPD officials predicted that in the next 30 years, the number of supporters per senior citizen will drop to four because of a gradual decline in the island's birthrate.

In the next 50 years the growth rate of Taiwan's population aged over 15 is expected to drop to negative 0.2 percent from the current 1.5 percent, while the island's proportion of people aged between 45 and 64 will increase to 40 percent from 26 percent now.

The CEPD officials warned that the indices of aging signify that Taiwan will in the future be challenged by increases in welfare spending, expansion of demand for social care, and declines in the labor force and the size of its school-aged population.
However, viewed from a different angle, the officials said, the expected decrease in the school-aged population could help reduce spending on the country's educational resources.

The CEPD assessed that in the next half-century, the number of Taiwan's primary school children will sustain a decline by 190,000, while that of junior and senior high school students will drop by 370,000, and that of college and university students will fall by about 400,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAKISTAN TO INAUGURATE AGOSTA SUBMARINE TUESDAY

TEXT.P: Pakistan's first Agosta 90-B submarine, the PNS Khalid which was built for the nation by France, is to be formally inaugurated for use by the Pakistan navy on Tuesday, reported an English-language newspaper in that country on Monday.

According to Business Recorder, a contract to construct three Agosta submarines was signed in 1994 with France under a transfer of technology agreement. The first one of the three was built entirely in France and arrived in Pakistan last week.
The second submarine is currently under construction at Pakistan's naval shipyard. That submarine will be sent to port for a trial run in 2001.

The second and third submarines are being constructed by Pakistani engineers and technicians. The construction of these vessels will place Pakistan alongside countries that are capable of building modern submarines. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: WIPE OUT MONEY, GANG IN POLITICS TO SAVE TAIWAN: FORMER MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China must wipe out money- and gang-linked politics, otherwise its national strength will decline, former Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao said on Tuesday.

Liao made the appeal at a seminar on the influence of gangsters, local political factions and large buisness groups in domestic politics, sponsored by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Noting that money power and gang influence are inextricable in domestic politics, Liao said he had placed the top priority on eradicating such complexes during his stint as justice minister.
However, Liao lamented that many of his anti-organized crime and anti-corruption programs were not continued after his departure from the top law enforcement officer post.

Liao warned that if Taiwan fails to face such problems flatly and work out measures to improve the situation, criminal rings could first control township politics and then gradually expand their influence to county-level politics and eventually to national-level political arenas. "Many countries lost their competitiveness and glamor due to corruption and gang influence in politics," he noted.

Liao further said determination and courage are needed to fight official corrpution and gang influence in politics. "Anti-corruption and anti-crime missions are tough jobs which will certainly face great pressure from various social quarters and encounter many hurdles," he stressed.

Liao resigned as justice minister in July 1998 amid controversy surrounding then-Investigation Bureau chief Cheng Chuan's sexual harassment scandal. Speculation is rife in recent months that Liao may throw his support behind independent presidential candidate James Soong instead of behind the ruling Kuomintang ticket of incumbent Vice Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew.
On Tuesday, Liao clarified that he has yet to make a final decision on for whom to support in the 2000 presidential election.

Liao explained that the presidential candidate for whom he will support must have an unswerving love for the land and people of Taiwan and must be able to pragmatically face issues troubled Taiwan and present effective ways to cope with those problems.

"The candidate that I will support must also have the determination, courage and capability to broach and complete various reform programs," Liao said, adding that he will unveil his presidential choice at an appropriate time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LISTED 12TH-MOST IMPORTANT MARITIME COUNTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was listed as the 12th-most important maritime country of the world this year, according to the latest report released by the United Nations.
The report reviewed the tonnage of cargo handled by 35 primary maritime countries in 1999, and Taiwan ranked 12th place with 17.99 million tons.

The eleven countries which outranked Taiwan were: Greece, 119.85 million tons; Japan, 94.79 million tons; Norway, 54.11 million tons; the United States, 45.62 million tons; mainland China; 38.35 million tons; Hong Kong, 32.65 million tons; Germany, 27 million tons; South Korea, 25.17 million tons; Sweden, 20.79 million tons; Britain, 19.89 million tons; and Singapore, 19.05 million tons.
The report said that the growth rate of cargo transportation for 1999 was just 2.2 percent, the lowest growth since 1987, mainly because of the aftermath of the Asian financial turmoil.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMEMORATIVE SILVER COINS SELLING LIKE HOT CAKES

TEXT.P: Thousands of people around the island braved the chill of the latest cold front on Tuesday to try to get hold of one of the 100,000 silver coins struck to commemorate the new millennium.
The coins were reported to be selling like hot cakes, and only those who were very lucky and patient were able to lay hands on one.
The coins, issued by the Central Bank of China, are made of 99.9 percent silver, weigh 15.568 grams, have a diameter of 3.3 cm and a thickness of 0.225 cm.

One side of the coin features the celestial model created by ancient Chinese astrologers, and is dated the "88th year of the Republic of China," along with the inscription "ushering in 2000." The other side bears an illustration of a dragon which is both the symbol of ancient China and the sign of the Chinese zodiac for 2000.

As sales were limited to one coin per person at a cost of NT$750 (around US$23.7) each, many enthusiasts started to line up long before the Bank of Taiwan, which was commissioned by CBC to sell the coins, opened for business.

Liu Le-wei and his son Liu Yang-wu, who live in Los Angeles and returned here for a winter holiday, were the first to get hold of the coins, and the younger Liu said excitedly: "It will be the best souvenir for when I get married."
Eight other members of the Liu family started to line up on Sunday night, using sleeping bags to keep warm and taking turns to eat, go to the restroom, and walk around.
But things promise to be a little easier early in the new year when the CBC has decided to hold draws for the rest of the year of the dragon commemorative coins.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD MEETS WITH US CONGRESSWOMAN

TEXT.P: Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi met on Tuesday with visiting US Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi, and decried Beijing's proposal to unify with Taiwan through the "one country, two systems" formula.

Describing the proposal as an insult to the people of Taiwan, the MAC head also stressed that Beijing's thoughts and ideas will not only hurt cross-Taiwan Strait relations, but also impede the chances of future reunification.
In return, Pelosi spoke highly of the Republic of China's progress in the fields of politics, economics and human rights.
Pelosi is on a five-day visit, her first to the ROC, at the invitation of the ROC government.
Speaking on Beijing's "one country, two system" proposal, Su firmly pointed out that it is unacceptable to Taiwan.

Su told his visitor that the ROC's mainland China policy is to pursue peace and stability between Taiwan and mainland China. As to the future of cross-strait relations, "we are still optimistic and confident," he added.
However, Beijing's fear of facing the democratization of Taiwan has temporarily crippled cross-strait relations, he went on.

Su called on the Beijing authorities to leave behind the Cold War mindset of the 20th century and enter the coming century with new ideas to forge good relations with Taiwan and its other neighbors. This, he pointed out, would be good for mainland China and Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLACES TO SEE FIRST RAY OF MILLENNIUM RECOMMENDED

TEXT.P: With only 10 days to go before 2000, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said on Tuesday that local people who cannot travel to the international date line to see the dawn of the new millennium will still be able to see the sun rise in Taiwan.

The CWB said the first rays of the first sun of the next millennium will hit Taiwan on offshore Orchid Island on Jan. 1, 2000 at 6:33 a.m., followed by Oluanpi on the Hengchun peninsula and Shanhsientai on the eastern coast of Taiwan at 6:35 a.m.
People in the northern part of Taiwan will have to wait another couple of minutes to see the sun come up at Shantiaochiao, in northeastern Taiwan.
The weathermen advised the public to wear black glasses and not to stare directly at the sun to avoid damage to the eyes.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSTAL SAVINGS HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: As of the end of November, the Directorate General of Postal Remittances and Savings Banks had absorbed savings of NT$2.55 trillion (US$80.7 billion), the highest level in the bureau's history, according to the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The amount, up NT$11.3 billion from the October level, represented an annual growth of 13.59 percent, according to the CBC statistics released on Tuesday.
Some NT$1.03 trillion of the savings, or 40.49 percent, had been deposited at the CBC as of the end of November, the second-largest figure since 1994, the tallies indicate.

Director-General Lee Sheng-yen of the CBC Banking Department said that loosening capital in the domestic market was the reason for the significant surge of postal savings, while the island has enjoyed trade surpluses and continued inflow of foreign capital.

In addition, 5.35 percent interest on one-year time deposits offered by the postal bureau, a rate higher than those of most banking institutes around Taiwan, has also significantly helped the growth, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIC PRESSURE ON TAIWAN STUDENTS `AGGRAVATING': POLL

TEXT.P: Excessive academic pressure on primary and junior high school students is the most urgent issue concerning education and educational reforms in Taiwan, according to the results of a recent opinion poll.

According to the poll, conducted by National Taipei Teachers' College (NTTC), 47 percent of the respondents said the academic pressure on primary school students is too heavy, while 66 percent said junior high students are subject to excessive academic pressure.

Pressure to succeed academically among Taiwan's primary school and junior high students has become more severe over the years, evident in the fact that a 1992 poll gave results of 37.3 percent and 47.9 percent, respectively, for the same question, said NTTC pollsters.

NTTC conducted the poll on the commission of the Ministry of Education, and received 3,225 valid responses from teachers, students, parents and scholars, with 2,063 responses from primary schools and 1,162 from junior high schools.
The 1999 survey found that the top three most pressing issues of primary education are pupils' myopia, intense academic pressure, and too much cram-style after-school activity, in that order.
In a similar poll seven years ago, the top three most pressing issues in primary education were myopia, lack of teaching faculty and too much extra-curricular activity, in that order.

With regard to junior high school, the top three urgent issues requiring attention are intense academic pressure, too many examinations, and too much cram-style after-school study, in that order, compared with seven years ago, when the sequence was academic pressure, after-school studies, and exams.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE SECRETARY-GENERAL APOLOGIZES FOR SEX SCANDAL

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's presidential office, apologized on Tuesday for an extra-marital affair with an unnamed woman which has shocked Taipei political circles.

Speaking through Presidential Office spokesman Ting Yuan-chao, the former Kuomintang secretary-general who was reassigned to his current job on Nov. 15 issued a five-point apology in which he admitted that he "made a mistake" in being unfaithful to his wife.
The spokesman quoted Chang as apologizing to his family, especially his wife Huang Mei-lun, his unnamed mistress, and the general public.
Chang attributed his infidelity to indiscretion in his associations, and said he feels deeply sorry for having "sowed wild oats," despite the fact that his wife has forgiven him.

Ting said Chang has briefed President Lee Teng-hui on the scandal which began about six month ago, and that he has no intention of taking a leave of absence or quitting his job because of his debauched private life.

Ting was speaking at a press conference called after a local evening newspaper broke the news on Tuesday afternoon that Chang had signed a written memorandum promising to divorce his wife before next June.
The memorandum, dated Nov. 10, allegedly reads: "I promise to finish divorce proceedings with her before June of next year, John Chang."
The newspaper said Chang's mistress is a well-educated woman teaching at a local university who obtained the written promise after negotiations with Chang which were mediated by a third party.

The newspaper quoted anonymous sources as saying that after learning of the report, Chang's wife refused to believe that her husband could do such a thing, and vigorously denied that Chang had ever asked for a divorce.
Neither Chang nor Huang could be immediately reached for comment.

Chang, himself the illegitimate son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, is a political star of the ruling Kuomintang. He served as minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, minister of foreign affairs, and vice premier before being named KMT secretary-general in 1997. He and his graceful wife are considered an attractive pair in Taipei political circles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CELLULAR TELEPHONE USERS TOP 10 MILLION

TEXT.P: The number of cellular telephone users in Taiwan totaled 10,173,000 as of the end of October, the Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Tuesday.
The figure represents a three-fold increase over March 1998, when the government opened the portable telephone market to the private sector.
The DGBAS said that the private sector now occupies 68.9 percent of the island's cellular telephone market, compared with 28.8 percent in March 1998.
It further said that it expects cellular telephone users to surpass traditional telephone subscribers, which numbered 11.19 million as of the end of October, by early 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS IN MACAU STRONGLY OPPOSE NEW ENTRY RULES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative in Macau said on Tuesday in Taipei that he strongly opposes new Macau rules for ROC passport holders wishing to enter Macau.

Li, head of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau, who arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for home consultations, stressed that Taiwan will not accept the new measures adopted by the new Macau Special Administrative Region government regarding the entry to the former Portuguese enclave by ROC nationals.

Li suggested that Macau, which returned to mainland Chinese rule on Dec. 20, should maintain the current system of recognizing ROC passports because interchanges between Taiwan and Macau are based on mutually beneficial principles.

If ROC passports are no longer permitted for entry to Macau and ROC nationals have to use a travel document called the "Taiwan Compatriot Certificate" instead, it will not only cause inconvenience to the people of Taiwan but will also heavily affect the rights and interests of Taiwan people who travel to Macau for cultural, economic and tourist interchanges, Li said.
He confirmed that the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau has already been forced to take down its nameplate as the Macau SAR government has yielded to Beijing's political pressure.
Officials took down the nameplate one hour before Portugal formally handed over Macau to mainland China after receiving a warning from an official of the newly established SAR government, Li said.
Ever since the Macau authorities began allowing ROC nationals to enter the enclave on their own passports, it has emerged as a bridge serving travelers going between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOONS TO HAVE NEW DESIGNATIONS

TEXT.P: Typhoons will have new designations along with the dawn of the new millennium, with Western names giving way to serial numbers and Oriental monikers, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said on Tuesday.

In line with a decision by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) to do away with the old system of names for the violent tropical storms and ring in some changes, the bureau said it will mainly use serial numbers to designate typhoons.
For instance, the first typhoon to form in the northwestern Pacific and South China Sea areas in 2000 will be given the designation No. 0001.
Meanwhile, the bureau said it will also refer to a new WMO-sanctioned list of 140 different names for identifying typhoons which only appear in the northwestern Pacific and South China Sea areas.

The 140 names were provided by 14 WMO members, including Hong Kong, mainland China, Japan, and North Korea. As the Republic of China is not a United Nations member, it was denied the right to provide opinions on typhoon name changes. The WMO is a UN affiliate.
According to a WMO decision, countries are free to decide how they will identify typhoons in their domestic news reports.
After extensive internal discussions and public opinion surveys, the CWB said it has decided to designate typhoons mainly with serial numbers.
"Of course, we'll also refer to international designations in reporting typhoon-related news," said Chen Lai-fa, director of the CWB's weather forecast center.

The new international designations include names of animals, plants, places, people, and mythological characters. As the names came from different sources, the bureau translated them into Chinese based mainly on their pronunciations.

The new WMO-sanctioned typhoon names will include Wu-kung -- the Monkey King from the ancient Chinese epic Journey to the West -- and Lung Wang, or Dragon King, who is portrayed as the king of the seas in Chinese mythology.
These two names are particularly apt, CWB officials pointed out, because in ancient Chinese legend, both characters are endowed with the power to control the weather.
Other new typhoon names include Hai-ma (sea-horse), Mei-hua (plum flower), Chen-chu (pearl), Lien-hua (lotus), Shan-hu (coral), and Yu-tu (the magic rabbit in the moon).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG TO HOST LITTLE LEAGUE BASEBALL INTERNATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Twelve Little League baseball teams, including three teams from Japan and South Korea, will compete in the annual Hsieh Kuo-cheng Cup International Little League Baseball Championship in Taitung from Dec. 28-Jan. 3.
Sadaharu Oh, manager of Japan's Daiei Hawks, has been invited to attend the opening ceremony as a distinguished guest. The Hawks won this year's Japan Series.

The Hsieh Kuo-cheng cup is usually held in Taipei, but the Republic of China Baseball Association decided to change the venue to Taitung this year to express its affirmation of Taitung's outstanding contribution to the promotion of little league baseball.
In addition to the teams from Japan and South Korea, other participating teams will come from Taiwan's Ilan County, Hualien County, Tainan City, Pingtung County, Taipei City and Taitung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP BROADCASTING SERVICE
LAWMAKERS APPROVE CHUNGHWA TELECOM CO. OVERSEAS IPO PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan at its plenary session on Tuesday approved the first stage of a Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. overseas initial public offering (IPO) project.
However, the session cut the proposed proportion of IPO from 14 percent to 12 percent, and decided to cut the tariff for cellular phones by 30 percent by next March.
The Legislative Yuan session also approved a clause of the proposal that stipulates that the overseas IPO will be sold abroad through American depository receipts (ADRs).

ADRs are instruments issued by US banks to American buyers as a convenient substitute for direct ownership of stock in foreign companies. A prospective Taiwan company must first sign an agreement with a US bank for ADR issuance and it must also deposit its stock in a Taiwan bank.
ADRs can be traded on American stock exchanges or on over-the-counter markets, like stocks of American firms. Both institutional and individual investors can buy ADRs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKED SECOND-FREEST COUNTRY IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan rates second in Asia in terms of political rights and civil liberties, according to a US human rights group.

The Washington-based Freedom House on Tuesday released the results of its 2000 survey on the level of freedom enjoyed by 192 countries around the world, and posted the results on its website, revealing Japan to be the freest country in Asia.
Taiwan, with a score of two points, tied with South Korea, Greece and Bolivia.

Mainland China, with a score of 6.5, was rated as not a free country, while Hong Kong and Macau, the two former Western colonies handed over to Beijing, were ranked as partly free territories, and Tibet was rated not free.
A total of 85 countries were listed as free, 59 countries as partly fee, and 48 countries not free.
The survey measured the political rights and civil liberties of the people in the countries surveyed with scores of one to seven, with one the most free and seven the least free.

The survey said that although two-thirds of the countries were rated as free, their combined population of 2.34 billion accounts for only 39 percent of the world, compared to 2.1 billion, or 36 percent, who live in countries which are not free, among whom, half live in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 22, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1895: Using his newly discovered X-ray technology, German physicist Willhelm Konrad Roentgen photographs his wife's hand to reveal the bones beneath the skin.
1905: The Ching court signs a treaty on Manchuria affairs with Japan in Peking, following Japan's victory over Russia in the Russo-Japanese War.
1907: The Ching government sets up the Directorate General of Railways, and appoints Liang Shih-yu as director-general.
1909: Korean Prime Minister Yi Wanyong, who agreed to a merger of Korea with Japan, is badly injured by assassins. Japan took complete control of Korea less than a year later.
1915: China's Ministry of Education sets up a training center to teach the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1936: Noted Chinese writer Yu Ta-fu visits Taiwan
1936: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, accompanied by W. H. Donald and T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen), fly to Sian.
1938: Japanese Prime Minister Prince Konoye lays down a three-point guiding principle for the settlement of the Sino-Japanese conflict and the establishment of a "New Order in East Asia."
1942: US heavy bombers raid Japanese-occupied Rangoon, Burma.
1945: General George Marshall arrives in Chungking as US President Truman's special envoy.
1945: The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union hold a meeting in Moscow.
1961: James Davis becomes the first American soldier to die in Vietnam since America's involvement in the Southeast Asian country.
1968: North Korea releases 82 crewmen of the US intelligence ship Pueblo at the truce village of Panmunjom, 11 months after their capture off the North Korean coast.
1971: Austrian envoy Kurt Waldheim becomes secretary-general of the United Nations.
1989: Civil war in Romania ends the 24-year-long reign of terror by Nicolae Ceausescu, who flees Bucharest with his wife Elena. Both were later executed.
1991: Dissident mainland Chinese astrophysicist Fang Li-chih visits Taipei.
1996: Chiang Hsiao-yung, the third son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, dies of cancer in Taipei at the age of 49.
1997: Hong Kong authorities decide to destroy all chickens imported from mainland China, after three people die of what is thought to be a strain of flu carried by poultry.
Confucius lesson for the day: "Treat people with seriousness and they will respect you. Let them see that you honor your parents and your prince, and are considerate of the welfare of those under you, and the people will be loyal to you. Advance those who excel in anything and educate the ignorant, and the people will exert themselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Independent presidential candidate James Soong's campaign adviser admitted that an additional NT$477 million in his sister-in-law's accounts was surplus cash left over after the provincial governor's election in 1994.
The China Times:
Presidential Secretary-General John Chang admits to extramarital affairs.
The United Daily News:
Top presidential aide John Chang apologizes for extramarital affairs.
The Liberty Times:
Bank of Taiwan confirms that independent presidential candidate James Soong's sister-in-law Chen Pi-yun had bought NT$470 million worth of financial bills at Chung Hsing Bills Finance Corp.
The China Post:
The government is urged to fight corruption; former justice minister Liao warns of instability if situation goes unchecked.
The Taiwan News:
Presidential Office Secretary-General John Chang says wife forgives him for extramarital affairs.
The Taipei Times:
The Ministry of Justice says 'bandit law' to be axed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCU CAMPUS ON YANGMINGSHAN SEES SNOW

TEXT.P: White feather-like snowflakes fell on the the Chinese Culture University's campus on Yangmingshan on Wednesday morning, marking the first snowfall of this year anywhere in the area near Taipei.

The snowfall was the first ever in the university's 37 year history. Such a phenomenon is so rare that some students at first wondered what it was and were later amazed when peers from the Meteorology Department confirmed that it was snow.
The snowfall lasted for about one hour.

Central Weather Bureau forecasters on Wednesday continued to warn that Taiwan will get a taste of genuine winter weather this week, with temperatures dropping to as low as 6 degrees Celsius in low-lying areas.
The forecasters said that the air was wet enough Wednesday morning on Yangmingshan and Tahchienshan in northern Taipei to allow it to snow.
In central Taiwan, snow has covered all mountain peaks over 2,000 meters since Sunday. Hohuanshan has been blanketed in a 60-centimeter-thick white shroud of snow.

Tamshui, a coastal township in Taipei County, recorded a temperature of 6.2 degrees Celsius in the early morning hours Wednesday, the lowest reading islandwide, excluding mountains, said CWB meteorologists.

They said that with the increasingly strong cold air mass from mainland China continuing to affect Taiwan's weather, temperatures are expected to be as low as 7 to 10 degrees Celsius islandwide on Thursday.
Low temperatures are expected throughout this week, with the weather not beginning to get warmer until Saturday, they said.

Sources from southern and eastern Taiwan said that large amounts of milk fish raised in beach-side fresh water ponds in Chiayi, Yunlin and Ilan were frozen to death Tuesday, incurring losses of over NT$70 million (US$2.2 million) for fishermen there.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUILDINGS PRODUCE MOST WASTE WATER

TEXT.P: Waste water discharged from buildings has replaced water discharged by industries as the leading source of Taiwan's water pollution, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said on Wednesday.

The EPA attributed this to the low installation rate of sewage systems on the island and the poor handling of waste water discharged from general households, pointing out that Taiwan's sewerage installation rate is only 6.4 percent. It added that rivers and buildings located on the fringes of major Taiwanese cities produce more than 60 percent of the island's overall waste water.
Waste water produced by industries and the livestock sector has been reduced by 94.5 percent in recent years, thanks to stricter governmental control, the EPA added.
