DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER THANKS WHO FOR EARTHQUAKE HELP, URGES TAIWAN'S ENTRY

TEXT.P: The premier of the Republic of China, Vincent C. Siew, thanked the world community for its swift and generous rescue assistance in response to the devastating earthquake that struck Taiwan on Sept. 21 and urged support for Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization in an article published in the Daily Oklahoman on Tuesday.

Siew wrote in the major mid-West US newspaper that such an altruistic response to a natural disaster reflects the spirit behind the everyday activities of the WHO, whose mission is to ensure the health and safety of people around the world by coordinating medical resources.

Yet, Siew pointed out, when it comes to Taiwan, the WHO must rely on non official, private sector channels to offer assistance because Taiwan has been excluded from this world body since 1972, and the UN remains under pressure from Beijing to keep things that way, despite all the changes in the world order since then.
Unable to offer direct help to Taiwan, the WHO used indirect channels to assess the magnitude of the earthquake disaster and donated US$50,000 to the Red Cross for use in relief aid, said Siew.

Siew noted that although Taiwan's medical and disaster relief resources were appraised by the WHO as being up to the challenge posed by the earthquake, "it is a great pity that the important long-term mission of the WHO remains compromised by Taiwan's exclusion."

As a non member, Taiwan has no access to information concerning global regulations on the laboratory testing of bioproducts. It cannot participate in the development of bioproduct standards, and its own bioproducts cannot be recognized by other countries.

"Taiwan's massive earthquake dramatically underscored how strong our ties are with other countries in the international community. My country has applied for observer status in the WHO, a humanitarian organization where common global medical and public health concerns should take priority over pedestrian political issues," stressed Siew.

He concluded that there could be no more appropriate time than the present to eliminate the artificial barriers hampering the WHO's coordination of global resources to ensure the safety of all people in all countries.

"Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO not only compromises the public health interests of the 22 million people living in Taiwan, but also represents a loss for the entire world. There is a role in the WHO for Taiwan to play that will make the world a healthier and safer place."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR DEFENSE DRILL STAGED IN PENGHU ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Penghu Defense Command staged an air defense drill early on Wednesday morning on the southern tip of one of the islands of the Taiwan Strait archipelago to test the defensive capabilities of the joint branch brigade on the island.

Supervised by Lt. Gen. Lu Hua-ning, commander of Penghu Defense Command, artillery and air defense troops stationed on Hsi Yu Island simultaneously fired 105mm howitzers, 42mm mortars and T82 20mm anti-aircraft machine guns at 4:30 a.m. to counter an imaginary attack.
The drill, part of a series of similar exercises carried out this year, was successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 4,000 CASES OF CHILD ABUSE REPORTED ANNUALLY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: More than 4,000 cases of child abuse are reported to government authorities every year, the Children's Affairs Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior said on Wednesday.

In a bid to provide more comprehensive protection to children islandwide and hammer out an efficient way to deal with the issue, the government is working out legislation to ensure children's personal safety and interests, Bureau head Liu Pang-fu said in an address at the opening of a seminar on child protection being held at Tunghai University in the central Taiwan city of Taichung.

Citing statistics released by the ministry's Social Affairs Administration, Liu said that as of the end of 1998, a total of 4,112 cases related to abused children were reported to government authorities islandwide.

Some 2,915 of these cases occurred in Taiwan Province, followed by 884 and 313 in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Taiwan's two largest cities, according to Liu. More boys were abused than girls, with children in the 6 - 11 age group making up the bulk of the victims, and parents and caregivers were usually the abusers, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER EXPORT ORDERS SECOND HIGHEST SINGLE-MONTH TOTAL

TEXT.P: Export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers and exporters in November amounted to US$11.56 billion, marking the second highest single-month total in Taiwan's foreign trade history, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Wednesday.

The figure was a 18.59 percent increase over the previous November, with orders received by electronics, information technology (IT), and telecommunications manufacturing sectors posting record-high monthly growth rates, said Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department.
The November figure was the second highest for any single month in history, behind only the record US$11.75 billion in export orders posted in October of this year, according to Chang.
Chang added that, with the brilliant performance in November and with a continued upward trend in December, Taiwan's annual export order growth could reach 6.5 percent or higher for 1999.
Cumulatively, Taiwan received US$116.33 billion worth of orders from abroad in the first 11 months of this year, up 6.88 percent over the same period the previous year, according to MOEA statistics.

Meanwhile, industrial production in November increased by 11.39 percent over the same month the year before. Chang forecasts that the country's industrial production for 1999 may post a growth of 7 percent or 7.5 percent if both export orders and industrial production remain as brisk in December as in November.
If the annual growth rate of industrial production reaches 7.5 percent this year, it would represent a 12-year high, Chang noted.
Responding to worries that the rising value of Taiwan's currency may drag down the volume of exports, Chang said the chances are slim.

Chang added that if the currencies of Japan and South Korea, Taiwan's two major rivals in export trade, also appreciate against the US dollar, the NT dollar's rise against the greenback should not affect Taiwan's exports.

In addition, he said, export orders for Taiwan-made products, particularly electronics-related goods, will remain steady, given that Taiwan's products are high in quality and are delivered punctually, making them difficult to replace.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA'S RATE OF RETURN ON REAL ESTATE HIGHEST IN ASIA: RICHARD ELLIS

TEXT.P: The best country for real estate investment in Asia over the next year will possibly be India, according to the Global realty research firm, Richard Ellis.

"Returns on housing or commercial property investment in India are 13 to 15 percent by way of rentals alone. This is 4 to 5 percent higher than returns in other Asian countries," Siddharth Yog, Associate Director with Richard Ellis said.
Despite the 13 to 15 percent returns, which do not include capital appreciation, foreign investment in the sector has been minimal.

The yields in 1999 for the commercial areas in Delhi and Mumbai stood at 13.20 percent and 13.60 percent respectively, while for Hong Kong and Bangkok they ranged from 10.6 to 11.1 percent, the report said.
The yields have withstood the property value erosion witnessed in the mid-90's, with returns showing an upward trend of 9 to 10 percent in 1995 and 13.3 to 13.9 percent in 1998.
Similar trends prevailed for residential premises where yields in Delhi stood at 15.11 percent, behind only the Jakarta market at 19.20 percent in 1999.
Though non-resident Indians and overseas corporate bodies were free to invest in the real estate sector, not even 10 percent of the projected foreign investment has flowed in.

DOC.HEADLINE: `SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY VOTED YEAR'S TOP DOMESTIC NEWS STORY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's definition of cross-Taiwan Strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" has been voted the year's most important news story in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, the deadly Sept. 21 earthquake that ripped through mountainous central areas of Taiwan and the follow-up temblor in the southern Chiayi area on Oct. 22 ranked number two in the list of the top 10 domestic news events of 1999.
The list was compiled by the Central News Agency after a poll of editors-in-chief and news department directors of the country's domestic news organizations.
Other news stories rounding out of the top 10 list in descending order are:

-- the unveiling of the list of hopefuls for the 2000 presidential election, including ruling Kuomintang nominee Vice President Lien Chan, main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian and New Party candidate Li Ao, as well as the announcement by former Taiwan Governor James Soong and former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang that they are running as independents;

-- the passage of a controversial bill by the National Assembly to extend the tenures of NA deputies and members of the Legislative Yuan, which led to the KMT's expulsion of then-Speaker Su Nan-cheng and cancellation of Su's status as a KMT NA deputy-at-large;
-- the collapse of a Taiwan Power Co. electricity pylon on July 29 which caused a rare islandwide blackout;

-- the resignation of Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Peng Tso-kuei over controversy surrounding the legislature's proposed revisions to the COA-drafted agricultural development bill concerning the liberalization of farmland trade and construction of housing units on newly purchased farmland;
-- the execution of Chen Chin-hsing, the convicted ringleader of the high-profile Pai Hsiao-yen kidnap-murder case;
-- the abolishment of the outdated 70-year-old Publications Law;

-- the KMT's ouster of former Taiwan Governor James Soong for his insistence on running in the 2000 presidential election as an independent, and Soong's selection of non-partisan heart surgeon Chang Chao-hsiung as his running mate; and
-- Pfizer's marketing of the anti-impotence drug Viagra.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA SUES TOBACCO GIANTS FOR C$ 1 BILLION IN DAMAGES

TEXT.P: Canada's federal government has filed a C$1 billion lawsuit against some giant tobacco companies, announced Justice Minister Anne McLellan on Tuesday.

She said the government is taking R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc., RJR- Macdonald Canada, the Canadian Tobacco Manufacturers Council, and several related companies to court in the US on charges of fraud and racketeering.

Ottawa made the unprecedented move following a court case that wrapped up in Binghampton, New York on Monday where six men were convicted of taking part in a multimillion-dollar smuggling ring that brought tobacco and liquor into Canada illegally. The ringleader was sentenced to 17 and a half years in jail and fined US$20,000.

McLellan said there is evidence to prove that in 1991 the big tobacco companies established an "elaborate network of smugglers and shell companies." Their aim, she noted, was to "undermine" Canada's policy to reduce tobacco use by increasing the price of cigarettes.
That policy, especially aimed at preventing young Canadians from starting to smoke, was "frustrated by tobacco smuggling," said the minister, and Canada was "forced to reduce taxes and duties."
She said the case was filed in the US because much of the smuggling took place there and many of the witnesses are US citizens.
Her government will seek to restrain the defendants from engaging in further smuggling, compel them to surrender their profits, and force them to pay substantial damages of at least C$1 billion.
Allan Rock, Canada's health minister, said the lawsuit should send a clear message to the tobacco industry that it "cannot and will not be allowed to frustrate Canadian health policy."

Lawyers for the Canadian government filed papers at the US Federal Court in Syracuse, New York. The lawsuit is being launched under the statute known as the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO).

The lawsuit also names the Canadian Tobacco Manufacturers Council because it was used to throw the Canadian government off the smuggling trail. The government alleges that RJR-Macdonald used the Council to blame organized crime while pretending it was trying to stop smuggling. At the same time it was alleged that RJR-Macdonald set up a shell company in the US to deceive investigators.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAID TO BE LEADING WAY IN INTERNET POLICY

TEXT.P: Australia leads many countries in the world in establishing internet policy and is set to play a crucial role in setting the standards in the coming future, according to industry experts.

They said issues such as the protection of personal data and customs duties on electronically transmitted goods and services are becoming increasingly controversial as the large trading blocs slug it out on which way policy should go. Critical e-commerce issues were cast adrift when the recent round of WTO talks in Seattle broke down.

The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday quoted experts as saying Australia has become a familiar participant in international forums designed to thrash out internet tax issues through organizations such as the Australian Internet Industry Association and the National Office for the Information Economy.
They believe Australia will also play a major role in setting up global standards on other emerging internet related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX INDEX RECLAIMS 8,000-POINT LEVEL, INDEX FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices continued to rise on Wednesday on strong buying of technology shares, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index reclaiming the 8,000-point level.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 68.5 points higher at 8,002.76 on an expanded turnover of NT$164.33 billion (US$5.19 billion) compared with the previous session's NT$136.29 billion, with 2.9 billion shares changing hands.
Decliners led gainers 250 to 231, with 80 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market dropped 0.51 points to close at 196.5 on a turnover of NT$18.69 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) also posted gains, with the exception of June and September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 50 points to close at 8,020, with 1,763 contract transactions. Those for February advanced 48 points to finish at 8,048, with 40 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 89 points to close at 8,131, with nine contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,970 points for January, 8,000 points for February, 8,042 points for March, 8,123 points for next June, and 8,032 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, closed mixed.

January TE futures rose 7.7 points to close at 414.5, with 653 contract transactions, and February TE futures were up 7.1 points to close at 413, with one contract transaction. March TE futures climbed 7.15 points to 415, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

January TF futures slipped nine points to close at 939, with 122 contract transactions, while March TF futures were up 3.6 points to 955, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for TF futures for February, June or September.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATION URGED TO PREVENT SEXUAL HARASSMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan people, both male and female, want legislation to punish and prevent indecent assault and sexual violence, according to the results of a recent public opinion poll.

The poll, conducted by Chinese Television Network (CTN) and commissioned by the Modern Women's Foundation, found that 90 percent of the respondents think there should be distinct laws enacted by the Legislative Yuan to deal with sexual harassment and indecent assault.
In addition, 92 percent of the respondents said an exclusive government agency should be set up to take charge of the eradication of sexual violence and related crimes.
CTN conducted the poll of adults islandwide by telephone in September, and received 1,068 valid responses equally distributed between men and women, according to a foundation spokeswoman.

The poll also found that Taiwan's general public have diverse perceptions of what constitutes sexual harassment and sexual offenses, with 34.5 percent of the respondents saying sexual harassment is a physical act, 33.4 percent saying they consider threats or demands for sexual services as sexual harassment, 9.8 percent describing the telling of dirty jokes as harassment, and 22.4 percent thinking public exposure of the sex organs or the display of obscene pictures is a sexual offense.

Kuomintang Legislator Pan Wei-kang said the results of the poll should serve as a basis on which sexual assault legislation can be promulgated, although she admitted that the poll results reflect the difficulty of properly defining sexual harassment and sexual offenses.
The poll also found that 75.9 percent of the respondents worry about themselves or members of their families being sexually harassed or assaulted.
Statistics show that 63 percent of sexual harassment occurs on public transport, while three times as women as men complain that they have been victims of sexual harassment.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING POLLED AS NO. 1 THREAT TO US

TEXT.P: The Chinese communists are commonly viewed by the American people as the biggest threat to the United States, a Republic of China government official in charge of mainland China affairs said on Wednesday.

Citing a recent poll conducted in the United States, Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said 36 percent of the American people think mainland China poses the biggest threat to America, ahead of 21 percent who cited Iraq as America's bogeyman.

In addition, some 55 percent of the respondents voiced support for Taiwan independence because the island is a democracy, while 37 percent of them support current US policy which does not condone Taiwan independence, but also does not condone mainland China's military threats against Taiwan.
Around 61 percent of Republican Party members expressed support for Taiwan independence, while 51 percent of Democratic Party members voiced the same opinion, Lin said, citing the poll results.

Despite the fact that Washington's China policy seems to lean toward favoring Beijing, the MAC deputy chief called on the public to pay close attention to any major changes in the United States which may provide Taipei with a good opportunity to gain an advantage.
He urged the government to thoroughly study the issue, and further step up understanding and communication with the rest of the world.
Lin made the remarks while attending the launch of the Chinese version of an English book by William C. Triplett and Edward Timperlake.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAITS GREATEST THREAT TO ASIAN STABILITY: US THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Although the economic fortunes of many Asian nations began to brighten over the past year, long-festering standoffs continue to prevent the advancement of peace and stability in Asia, and the serious deterioration of relations across the Taiwan Straits marks perhaps the gravest threat to security in the region, according to a Washington-based think tank.

The Heritage Foundation wrote in its newly published "US and Asia Statistical Handbook 1999-2000" that the latest round in the decades-old tug-of-war over the sovereignty of Taiwan was set off in July 1999 when Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui indicated that Taipei's relations with Beijing should be conducted on a "special state-to-state" basis.
The Communist leadership viewed President Lee's statement as tantamount to a declaration of independence and promptly instituted a campaign of intimidation against Taiwan.

In the face of tensions that threatened to spin out of control, the conservative think tank pointed out, "the Clinton administration remained strangely aloof, seemingly nonplused and offended by President Lee's statement of reality."

Instead of dispatching aircraft carrier battle groups to the area, as it had done in 1996 when missile tests by Communist China threatened to disrupt Taiwan's presidential election, the Clinton administration spoke of canceling all visits to Taiwan by US officials as well as shipments of defense-related spare parts, said the think tank.

The upshot of the administration's performance in the crisis, however , was to energize the US Congress once again to consider the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA), which would authorize the sale of advanced defensive weaponry to Taiwan, such as satellite early warning data, missile defense systems, modern air defense equipment, said the foundation.

It stressed that the TSEA has gained support in Congress precisely because of growing doubts about the Clinton administration's willingness to live up to the letter and not the spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act, which requires the US to sell Taiwan sufficient defensive weapons for the island to provide for its defense.

Because Beijing has reacted harshly to congressional calls to step up efforts to provide for Taiwan's defense, warning against interference in mainland China's "domestic affairs," the debate over the TSEA is likely to become politically charged as it will be played out during the presidential campaign seasons in both Taiwan and the United States, said the think tank.
But the question of the US role in the defense of Taiwan is just one of a host of sticking points plaguing an already contentious US-PRC relationship, noted the foundation.

Relations were strained by the House Cox Committee's investigation into Beijing's theft of US nuclear weapons secrets. Then the accidental bombing by US planes of the Communist Chinese embassy in Belgrade in May 1999 sent US-PRC relations plummeting to depths unseen since the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989, and perhaps since the Korean War in the early 1950s.

Tensions also persist over human rights concerns, as Beijing continues to crack down on religious leaders, Tibetans, and any other perceived threat to the dominance of the Communist Party, such as the Falun Gong meditation sect, added the think tank.

Even the ongoing efforts to bring mainland China into the World Trade Organization have increased frictions rather than eased them. The Communist Chinese were greatly offended when President Bill Clinton, reportedly for political reasons, rejected Premier Zhu Rongji's accession proposal and then publicly revealed Zhu's concessions.

Finally, The Heritage Foundation added, the large and growing US trade deficit with mainland China threatens to become yet another sore spot, especially if problems in other aspects of the overall relationship continue.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCANDAL-PLAGUED KMT OFFICIAL RESIGNS

TEXT.P: Presidential Secretary-General John Chang resigned on Wednesday over extra-marital affairs, Deputy Director Ting Yuan-chao of Presidential Public Affairs Department announced at a news conference at the Presidential Office.
Senior Presidential Adviser Ding Mou-shih was immediately named as his successor.
Chang 59, is an illegitimate son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, and the shortest-serving presidential secretary-general ever. He took the job on Nov. 15.
Ting said that Chang met President Lee Teng-hui at noon to tender his resignation which was immediately approved by the president.
Chang formerly served as minister of overseas Chinese affairs, minister of foreign affairs, vice premier and secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang.

Chang, accompanied by his wife Huang Mei-lun, acknowledged at the press conference the mistake he has committed and apologized for the damage that has caused to his wife, children and the general public.
Huang said that she and their children have "all forgiven Chang and will continue giving him the greatest support, in the hope that he will be able to rise again in the future."
Ding, 75, has served as ROC representative to the United States, foreign affairs minister, and secretary-general of the National Security Council.
Chang issued a statement admitting the affairs on Tuesday after a Taipei evening newspaper broke the story on its front page, shocking Taiwan political circles.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TAIWAN `SISTERS' FOUND TO BE BROTHERS

TEXT.P: Doctors in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung reported on Wednesday that three sisters undergoing treatment for a rare chromosomal anomaly have broken off contact with the hospital.
The three siblings were raised as girls until puberty, when the anomalies became apparent, said Dr. Juan Cheng-chao of the Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.

The oldest sister first came to the hospital at the age of 17, when her condition, which included no sign of menstruation, continuing growth, and a prominent Adam's apple, became increasingly serious, Juan noted.

Juan conducted tests on the young woman and discovered that in fact she had male chromosomes, together with cryptorchism, a developmental defect marked by the failure of the testes to descend into the scrotum.

Her two younger sisters, who checked into the same hospital at the ages of 14 and 12, respectively, were found to have the same condition, which Juan described as a first in Taiwan, and probably an extreme rarity anywhere in the world.
Juan was then appointed by the Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital to head up a research team to exclusively study the case of the three "sister men."
After receiving some medical treatment and psychological counseling, all three decided to undergo sex change operations to allow them to continue to live as women.

However, they stopped attending the hospital for follow-up treatment soon after the sex change procedure, and now, over three years later, they are 20, 17 and 15 years old, respectively, and the hospital has been unable to contact them, said Juan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIGNS FOR TAIPEI DE FACTO CONSULATE IN MACAU IN VISIBLE POSITION

TEXT.P: A problem surrounding the signboard for Taipei's de facto consulate in Macau was resolved on Wednesday after one of the office's sign plaques was rehung after being tampered with.

The Taipei Trade and Tourism Office is located in the former Portuguese enclave's Commercial Central building. One hour before Macau reverted to Beijing's rule on Sunday, the sign in the building's lobby was flipped over, said Tsai Jy-jon of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Tsai told local reporters that office chief William Li was to blame for not stopping the move, which apparently was prompted by "unfriendly" warnings over the name of the organization.
Before the incident, Li had removed signs from the hallways of the ninth and 15th floors of the building, placing them inside the offices out of safety considerations.

But the sign in the lobby was interfered with without Li's instruction or consent, and he was required to fly back to Taiwan to give an explanation to his superiors on Tuesday. At a news conference, the Taipei envoy to Macau admitted his error.
Asked whether or not Taipei will have to rename the office due to demands from Beijing, which regards the present name as too official, Tsai said discussions of the issue are still under way.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rebounded against the greenback on Wednesday on the Taipei foreign exchange market after dropping after the past 12 consecutive trading days.
The currency opened at 31.66 on Wednesday. It was traded between 31.659 and 31.664 before closing at 31.662.
Compared with the previous session, the unit saw an appreciation of 0.1 cent against the US dollar.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$218 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S TALLEST PERSON ARRIVES FOR 4-MONTH VISIT

TEXT.P: Nasir Ahmed Sooro, listed as the world's tallest person by the Guinness Book of World Records, met the local press Wednesday as he started his four-month visit to Taiwan.
The 29-year-old Pakistani, who stands 236.2 cm tall, arrived in Taipei Tuesday evening at the invitation of the Guinness museum in the central Taiwan city of Taichung.

Sooro told local journalists that he once felt ashamed of his height. "But now I have overcome my 'inferiority complex' and dare to serve as a sports promoter," he explained joyfully and optimistically.

At the news conference, Sooro wished all Taiwan people a Merry Christmas and sang a Pakistani folk song in his mother tongue. He also jokingly said he hopes he will be able to find a tall girlfriend during his stay here.

Sooro recalled that he was of average height before age 10, but has since grown continually because of abnormal secretions of his pituitary gland. "One of my current troubles is that doctors had told me that I'll gain at least an additional eight centimeters in height in the future," he said, adding that all of his siblings are of average height.

Sooro and his elder brother now work for Pakistan Airlines. "Because of my work, I have managed to make trips to five countries. I felt most inconvenienced while I was in Japan, as all things there are small."

To welcome the guest of distinguished height, the hotel Westin has made special arrangements for an extra-long bed to offer Sooro a comfortable night's sleep. According to hotel staff, Sooro doesn't eat meat, except for fish.
Sooro will soon travel to the Guinness Taichung museum which has ordered special furniture to meet Sooro's needs.
Over the next four months, visitors to the Taichung museum can play basketball with Sooro and try on his extra-large outfit.

Sooro will greet the dawn of the year 2000 and spend the lunar Chinese New Year and Valentine's Day in Taiwan. In addition to taking part in various festivities, Sooro will also play the role of roving ambassador and visit primary and middle schools to encourage local youngsters to do more exercises so that they can grow tall and strong.

Sooro will also meet with Taiwan's tallest and shortest persons during his stay here. Medical experts said the probability of a person growing taller than 230 cm is one in 1 billion. A man from the United States and a mainland Chinese woman both surpassed Sooro's height, measuring 272 cm and 248 cm, respectively, but neither of them is still living.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AIR FORCE TO ESTABLISH 'ELECTRONIC WAR' UNIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Air Force will soon inaugurate an electronic war unit to enhance combat capability, Air Force Chief Staff Chou Wen-chung said on Wednesday,
"We will formally establish the electronic war unit next month as part of our efforts to streamline our air defense," Chou said at a legislative hearing session on Taiwan's new-generation fighters.

Chou also said that the United States is scheduled to deliver air-launched harpoon missiles to Taiwan next month, and the missiles, to be installed on Taiwan's F-16 fighters, will largely enhance the fighters' long-distance strike capability.

On the development of Taiwan's "stealth" fighters, Chou said the Air Force has contracted several institutes to conduct research on the issue and has achieved "positive results," especially in plans for the structure and coating of the proposed aircraft.

Also addressing the session, Vice Defense Minister Sun Tao-yu denied allegations that the new-generation fighters that Taiwan has purchased from foreign countries are all "outdated" and are not nearly as efficient as had been claimed.
Sun said the F-16 has been proven in previous battles as one of the most advanced warplanes, and the French-made Mirage 2000-5s are the best in free world.
Sun said the untrue allegations may have been generated by Beijing because Taiwan's newly-acquired fighter jets are better than theirs.
In addition to its 130 locally developed IDFs (Indigenous Defense Fighters), Taiwan has bought 150 F-16s and 60 Mirage 2000-5s, enabling the Air Force to retire its aging fleet of F-5Es.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE CHINA' POSSIBLE, BUT NOT RIGHT NOW: PRESIDENT LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui has said in a recent interview with a Japanese weekly that "one China" is possible but not right now.
Lee said in the interview, published in the latest issue of the "Shin Cho (New Wave)" weekly magazine which hit newsstand on Wednesday, that "one China" could be a reality in the future.
But Lee said he still cannot answer the question at the moment whether the possible future "one China" would be a cultural existence or a geographic one.
Lee gave the interview in Taipei on Dec. 11 with Yoshiko Sakurai, a Japanese columnist who had served as a television news anchor before beginning her writing career.

In the interview, Lee pointed out unequivocally that cross-Taiwan Strait ties must be on a "special state-to-state" basis, noting that the Republic of China, established in 1912, is like a father while the "People's Republic of China," founded in 1949, is like a son. The "PRC" separated from the ROC to become a new country after the Chinese communists took control of the Chinese mainland, and the ROC continues to exist in Taiwan.

Lee went on to say that Taiwan must develop a new culture different from the Chinese culture. "It must be a culture of integrity and sincerity, charactered by respect for freedom, democracy, equality and human rights," Lee said, adding: "In other words, Taiwan must become a mature, full-fledged democracy."

Noting that Taiwan must signifies its existence through democratization, Lee said the ROC as a sovereign state must exercise wisdom, prudence and patience to avoid provoking a military attack from mainland China.

While stressing the importance of beefing up Taiwan's military strength to safeguard its national security, Lee also said he believes freedom and democracy can better protect Taiwan than military forces.

As for the US-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) program, Lee said it's still premature to discuss whether Taiwan should take part in the TMD project since the system is still in the planning stage. Nevertheless, he added that Taiwan must forge a missile defense shield in view of mounting missile threats from the mainland.
Lee also said the "Taiwanization" means a Taiwanese cultural renaissance or revival. "We must teach our younger generation valuable Taiwanese cultural heritage and relics," he noted.

Meanwhile, Lee said "Taiwanization" also means "democratization." Lee said he believes that making Taiwan a model of democratization for entire Asia could help safeguard Taiwan's security in the face of mainland China's threat in the new millennium.

Lee further suggested that Japan revise its constitution to give more powers to its prime minister in policy decisions. "I believe it is necessary for Japan to establish a system under which its prime minister can play a leading role in policy making so that it will be able to more actively participate in regional affairs in the face of quickly changing Asian situation."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MILITARY PREPARED FOR Y2K CRISIS

TEXT.P: The military has completed its Y2K tests on all computer systems, said a spokesman of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Wednesday, expressing that the military is confident of passing through the rollover to the year 2000 safely.
Some of the tests were particularly designed for the air-raid warning systems as well as the warfare monitoring and guiding systems at the central warfare command headquarters, the spokesman noted.
In the days leading up to the beginning of the year 2000, MND special personnel will be standing by at the Executive Yuan's Y2K crisis management center, on full alert for sudden incidents.

On Dec. 1, the MND established a command headquarters for urgent missions, with operations divided into two stages, the first beginning at 10 a.m. on Dec. 31 and ending at noon on Jan. 4, said military officers involved in the project.
The first-stage work, to be in operation round-the-clock, is aimed at ensuring that all public and civil institutes will operate normally, sustaining no assault from the Y2K computer bug.
The Y2K bug refers to the possibility that older computer systems using two digits to record dates may sustain malfunctions or crashes on Jan. 1, 2000, after confusing 2000 with 1900.
The potential Y2K disruptions have been regarded as a "time bomb," able to paralyze a country's military, financial and economic systems, triggering civil unrest.

The second stage of operations for the military's Y2K headquarters was designed because 2000 is a leap year. Stage two, which will be in effect from 10 a.m. on Feb. 28 to noon on March 1, is designed to secure all military systems for Feb. 29, according to the officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER CHINCHIANG-CLASS PATROL BOAT LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Navy's ninth Chinchiang-class coastal patrol boat was launched at the southern port of Kaohsiung on Wednesday.

Presiding over a ceremony marking the launch of the new boat, christened "Pochiang," at the shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CPC), Navy Fleet Commander Hu Tsai-kwei said that a series of weapon-installations and performance tests will be conducted before it is formally delivered to the Navy.
With the latest addition, the Navy will have a total of 11 Chinchiang-class vessels.
The boat is 61.4 meters long, and has a beam of 9.5 meters and a displacement of 540 tons. It will be able to travel at a speed of 25 knots.

The vessels will be used for patrolling Taiwan's coastal waters and for conducting patrol and protection missions in certain other areas. In times of war, they will be equipped with additional weapons systems and deployed on combat operations with the Navy's much larger warships. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TWO-WAY TRADE HIT TWO-DIGIT GROWTH IN EARLY DECEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two-way trade has expanded stably, with imports and exports each recording two-digit growth for the first half of December, official data showed Wednesday.

According to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF), Taiwan's exports for the period of Dec. 1-18 moved up 14.3 percent, compared with the 1998 figure, to US$7.08 billion, while imports grew 17.4 percent to US$6.64 billion, thus leaving a trade surplus of US$440 million in favor of the island nation.

Taiwan's exports and imports for the whole month of December are expected to move up 20 percent and 13 percent, respectively, due to the ongoing recovery of the global economy, an official with the ministry said.

During the period from Jan. 1 to Dec. 18 this year, the country's exports amounted to US$116.83 billion in total, up 9.5 percent from 1998, while imports reached US$106.19 billion, up 6 percent from the same period last year, the MOF-compiled data showed.
As a result, Taiwan has recorded a trade surplus of US$10.640 billion for the year so far, the statistics revealed.

The ministry pointed out that Taiwan's foreign trade will continue prospering thanks to the sustained global economic growth, a robust US economy, steady growth in Europe and stronger recovery in Asian economies. (by Luis Huang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EDITORS SELECT RETURN OF MACAU AS YEAR'S TOP MAINLAND NEWS

TEXT.P: The return of Macau to mainland China on Dec. 20 was selected as the top mainland Chinese news story of 1999 by editors of news organizations in the Republic of China.
The top international news story was the introduction of the euro on Jan. 1.
The top ten mainland Chinese news stories this year, as selected by Taiwan editors, were:
1. Macau reverted from Portuguese rule to that of mainland China.
2. Falun Gong members demonstrated at the Zhongnanhai center of the mainland government.
3. Beijing suspended dialogue with Taipei after ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-Taiwan Strait relations as "a special state-to-state relationship" in July.
4. Mainland China test-fired an intercontinental ground-to-ground missile capable of reaching Europe and the United States.
5. Mainland China launched an unmanned spacecraft from the Qiuquan satellite center.
6. The mainland Chinese embassy in Belgrade was bombed by NATO forces.
7. Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin stated that "dialogue and negotiation" would be the main emphasis of Beijing's Taiwan policy in 1999.
8. Mainland China and the United States signed an agreement in Beijing that allows the mainland to join the World Trade Organization.
9. The National People's Congress approved constitutional revisions and stressed the importance of Deng Xiaoping's theories.
10. Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin presided over an Oct. 1 military parade.
Meanwhile, the top international news stories were:
1. The euro was introduced.
2. Y2K computer problems were widely anticipated.
3. US President Bill Clinton escaped being impeached by the Senate on charges of perjury.
4. East Timor voted overwhelmingly for independence from Indonesia in a public plebiscite under UN supervision.

5. Beijing-Washington relations worsened following the bombing of the PRC embassy in Belgrade, but bilateral relations improved after an agreement on the PRC's entry to the World Trade Organization was concluded.
6. Devastating earthquakes struck Colombia, Turkey, Greece and Taiwan.
7. The global boom of the Internet was on the rise, with related stocks soaring high.
8. A group of scientists decoded the 22nd human chromosome gene.
9. NATO forces bombed Yugoslavia for 78 days.
10. Participants at the World Trade Organization ministerial meeting failed to reach an agreement in Seattle.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO REJECTS LA TIMES' CRITICISM OF LEE

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles Times on Tuesday ran a letter from the Government Information Office (GIO) of the Republic of China rejecting the Dec. 15 criticism of President Lee Teng-hui in an article by Washington, D.C., correspondent Jim Mann, the GIO said.

Mann, in his article titled "President Caught in a Whopper," accused Lee of stretching the truth during a recent campaign rally for Kuomintang presidential candidate and Vice President Lien Chan, by saying that "Taiwan's friends overseas, especially the United States and Japan, want to see the Kuomintang win the presidential election next March," lest Asia become unstable.
Mann said that in fact "not a single US official, scholar or expert has voiced the fear of instability if your party (the KMT) should fall from power. Not one."

The GIO said the senior journalist's citation was not totally in line with the statement in Lee's speech, which read: "Friends in America, Japan and other countries are extremely concerned about Taiwan's election, because the stability and development of Asia and the rest of the world will be greatly affected should the KMT fail to win. So everyone is really concerned."

With regard to Mann's remarks that some Americans "are afraid that you (Lee) might try to touch off a military conflict with China during your last months in office, or that you might even come up with some excuse for putting off the elections and keeping yourself in power as president," the GIO said Taiwan has experienced a peaceful transition of power with each new ROC president for the past five decades.
Taiwan will hold its second direct presidential election on March 18 next year, and Lee's tenure expires two months later on May 20.

"Mann can rest assured that the voters of Taiwan will exercise their will at the ballot box next March just as they did four years ago. And however they vote, Asia and the world will witness Taiwan's democracy becoming stronger and more mature than ever," the GIO continued.
The Los Angeles Times, with a circulation of about 1 million, is the third largest newspaper in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of finance says independent presidential candidate James Soong's controversial 'mystery fund' totals NT$1 billion, some NT$333 million more than earlier thought.
The China Times:
National Security Council (NSC) acting chief Ding Mou-shih succeeds John Chang as Presidential Office secretary-general. Chang resigned due to extramarital affairs.
The United Daily News:
John Chang resigns as presidential secretary-general amid infidelity controversy, and NSC acting chief Ding Mou-shih fills the vacancy left by Chang.
The Liberty Times:
Soong allegedly has many other 'mystery' bank accounts.
The China Post:
Infidelity forces John Chang to resign as presidential secretary-general.
The Taiwan News:
John Chang resigns over extramarital affairs.
The Taipei Times:
Tent-dwellers in earthquake-affected central Taiwan regions face a bleak Christmas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 23, or the 16th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: Andrew Jackson halts British forces at New Orleans.
1832: French troops take Antwerp, forcing Holland to recognize the independence of Belgium.
1888: Vincent van Gogh, Dutch post-impressionist painter whose works included "The Potato Eaters" and "Starry Night," cuts off his earlobe in a fit of madness. His long struggle with depression ended in suicide.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen meets in Kweilin, Kwangsi province, with Marin, a representative of the Comintern (Communist International), to discuss such issues as cooperation with Russia. The Comintern, which was established in 1919 by V.I. Lenin, founder of the Communist Party in Russia, helped Outer Mongolia set up a Communist government in the early 1920s.
1922: German statesman Helmut Schmidt, former chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, is born.
1933, Akihito, emperor of Japan, is born.
1934: Chen Sao-pai, one of an early supporters of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in the Chinese revolution, dies in Peiping (Beijing) at the age of 66.
1941: US forces on Wake Island in Pacific surrender to Japan in World War II.
1948: Japanese Prime Minister Hideki Tojo and six other Japanese leaders are hanged in Tokyo as World War II war criminals.
1957: The Control Yuan impeaches Premier Yu Hung-chun for transgressions and negligence of duty.
1958: The construction of the 333-meter-high Tokyo Tower is completed.
1972: An earthquake strikes Managua, Nicaragua, killing 10,000.
1972: Elections for members to the National Assembly, the Legislative Yuan and the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, as well as elections for mayors and country magistrates, are held in Taiwan, Kinmen, and Matsu.
1974: The first test-flight of the United States' B-1 bomber is successful.
1986: The US aircraft Voyager lands in the Mojave desert in California after becoming first aircraft to circumnavigate the globe nonstop without refueling.
1986: Dr. Andrei Sakarov, the Soviet dissident and physicist who was released on Dec. 19 from the closed city of Gorka, returns to Moscow with his wife Yelena Bonner.
1989: The Romanian army announces the capture of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife Elena, both of whom fled Bucharest on Dec. 22.
1996: The five-day National Development Conference begins. Discussion focuses on three major topics: enhancing constitutional systems of government and multiparty politics; economic development; and cross-strait relations.
1998: South Korean police use water cannons and tear gas to disperse a group of monks from Chogye temple after the monks cast firebombs and rocks at them. The clash ends a 40-day standoff between rival monks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not know how men get along without good faith. A cart without a yoke and a carriage without a harness, how could they go?"

DOC.HEADLINE: DING MOU-SHIH TAKES OVER AS PRESIDENTIAL SECRETARY GENERAL

TEXT.P: Secretary General Ding Mou-shih of the National Security Council took over the post of presidential secretary general on Thursday, replacing sex scandal-plagued former secretary general John Chang.
The handing over ceremony was presided over by Vice President Lien Chan at the Presidential Office.

Ding, 75, has served as the Republic of China representative to the United States, director general of the Government Information Office, foreign affairs minister, and secretary general of the National Security Council (NSC).
He still serves concurrently as secretary general of the NSC.
Chang, 59, is the shortest-serving presidential secretary general ever, taking the post on Nov. 15 of this year.
Chang tendered his resignation to President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday and it was immediately approved.

Chang, an illegitimate son of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, resigned after an extra-marital affair he was involved in came to public attention. A local evening newspaper broke the story on its front page on Tuesday, shocking Taiwan political circles.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM FACES DECLINING FOREIGN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Vietnam continues to suffer from a drop in foreign investment despite a decision by the Vietnamese government in March on incentives for foreign direct investment (FDI) activities in the country.
Foreign investment in Vietnam in 1998 and 1999 was only half the annual average recorded a decade ago, which was over US$ 3 billion, according to the official Vietnam News Agency.
There are now nearly 2,300 valid foreign-investment projects in operation in Vietnam with combined registered capital of over US$ 35.5 billion.

At present, there are about 290,000 people working in this sector and hundreds of thousands of others in related businesses. The sector's production value makes up nearly 35 percent of Vietnam's total industrial production value while its export turnover represents 22 percent of the country's total.

Businesses with foreign direct investment are expected to obtain a combined revenue of US$ 3.5 billion and an export value of US$ 2.4 billion this year for an increase of between 21 and 25 percent over last year. The growth of the FDI sector becomes more impressive as other sectors of the country's economy face declining growth rates.

Foreign investors have brought advanced technology to the country's various industries such as motorbike and car assembling, electronics, pesticide and fertilizer production, and chemicals to name a few.

The garment-textile and footwear sectors are expected to export a combined US$ 3 billion worth of products in 1999. The increase is attributed to capital sources coming from over 240 FDI projects in these sectors.
However, according to economic experts, the number of FDI businesses investing in export production development made up only 20 percent of the total, far below the government's expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOOMSDAY CULTS MAY TRIGGER Y2K VIOLENCE: REPORT

TEXT.P: The Canadian Security and Intelligence Service (CSIS) has warned that some doomsday cults may trigger violence as the year 2000 arrives.

"One estimation indicates that there are 1,200 active cults throughout the world, and that roughly 400 subscribe to doomsday philosophies which foresee catastrophe on or around the year 2000," a CSIS report says.

"While it is not known which cults have the potential for violence, this does not imply that possible threats posed by doomsday religious movements should be ignored, as they can quickly manifest themselves in a variety of forms," the report adds.
The spy agency warns that there is an increased danger of terrorist incidents in Canada over the next few months.

The study, titled "Doomsday Religious Movements" says that several irrational groups foresee catastrophe on or around the year 2000. Given the controversy over when the millennium ends, with most experts agreeing that it doesn't happen until next year, CSIS says it's not clear when trouble might occur.

DOC.HEADLINE: HISTORIC CHANGE IN AUSTRALIAN MILITARY POLICY

TEXT.P: In a historic policy change, Australia is stepping up its military readiness in order to prepare for active duty overseas, including combat, peace-keeping and disaster relief.
The policy change ends a 50-year period where the call-out of reserve units was prohibited unless it was for the direct defense of the country.

The policy change was announced on Wednesday by Defense Minister John Moore, who called for an increase in the recruitment of reserves following the leading role Australia played in the UN peacekeeping force in East Timor.

The move is seen as crucial to the long-sought integration of reserves into the active force. Moore said the government would be negotiating with employers over compensation for the loss of staff who are reservists who could be called up for service for months at a time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKING ON SUBSTITUTE MILITARY SERVICE

TEXT.P: To resolve the military's oversupply of human resources, Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior is working on a scheme for substitute service by some of those who are obliged to participate in compulsory military service.
Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen revealed at a legislative meeting that the plan is part of the military's effort to downsize its ranks, a move aimed at seeking operational efficiency.

By studying similar programs in European countries, such as civil service schemes, and considering Taiwan's needs, the ministry has drafted a bill which includes plans for implementation of substitute service for those who cite religious reasons for not participating in traditional military service.

There will be an examination committee to screen applications for the proposed service, Huang told legislators, stressing that the planned examination and review procedures are designed out of consideration for freedom of religion.

Huang noted that according to the bill, the substitute service is set to be implemented on July 1, 2000. There will be room for 10,000 participants per year in alternative conscription, the minister said.
The substitute service bill is now under legislative review.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed higher for the third straight day on Thursday as institutional investors started building up their 2000 stock portfolios amid optimistic predictions for next year's economic outlook.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 80.73 points, or 1 percent, higher at 8,083.49 on a turnover of NT$133.86 billion (US$4.22 billion), with 2.65 billion shares changing hands.
Continuing heavy buying by foreign investors and institutional buyers reinforced local investors' optimism over Taiwan's economic prospects for 2000, according to dealers.

Investors have shaken off worries about potential Y2K problems, which had previously slowed down trading on the bourse, yet profit-taking could still emerge before the Christmas holiday following several days of gains, dealers added.

Led by the financial sector and the electronics sector, the majority of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with the exception of textile issues, plastics and chemical shares, and the paper-making sector, posting losses ranging from 1.8 percent to 0.1 percent.

Financial shares enjoyed the largest gains of 2.5 percent, while electronics shares reported the second-largest gains of 2.2 percent. The rest posted minor gains ranging from 0.6 percent to 1 percent.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 263 to 215, with 79 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 2.24 points to close at 198.74 on a turnover of NT$14.58 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted gains, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 86 points to close at 8,106 with 1,721 contract transactions. Those for February advanced 77 points to finish at 8,125 with 42 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 63 points to close at 8,136 with 19 contract transactions, while those for June climbed 97 points to finish at 8,273 with 13 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were: 8,020 points for January, 8,048 points for February, 8,073 points for March, 8,173 points for next June, and 8,082 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported gains.

January TE futures rose 6.5 points to close at 421 with 638 contract transactions; February TE futures gained 8.4 points to close at 422 with one contract transaction, while no transactions were recorded for TE futures for other months.

January TF futures hiked 18 points to close at 957 with 199 contract transactions; March TF futures moved up 10 points to finish at 965 with one contract transaction, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS MEDIA SELECT TOP 10 EVENTS OF 20TH CENTURY

TEXT.P: Major Taiwan news media have selected the establishment of Asia's first republic -- the Republic of China -- in 1911 as the fourth most important event in the 20th century.
Meanwhile, the flight of the first powered airplane by the Wright brothers of the United States in 1903 was voted the century's top news story.

The list of the top 10 events of the century was compiled by the Central News Agency after a poll of editors-in-chief and news department directors of local newspapers, radio stations, television companies and magazines.

The outbreak of World War I in 1914 ranked number two, followed by the US drop of two atomic bombs on two Japanese cities -- Hiroshima and Nagasaki -- in 1945, which prompted Japan to surrender and ended World War II.
Other events rounding out of the top 10 list in that order are:
-- the beginning of World War II with German invasion of Poland in 1939;
-- the landing of US astronaut Neal Armstrong on moon in 1969;
-- the presentation by German scientist Albert Einstein of his first relativity theory in 1905;
-- the unification of East and West Germany in 1990;
-- the demise of the Soviet Union and the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war in 1991;
-- the inauguration of the United Nations in 1945, with its headquarters located in New York.
