DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE DECORATES KAO CHING-YUAN, PRESIDENT OF PRESIDENT GROUP

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday conferred the second grade of the Brilliant Star Medal on President Group President Kao Ching-yuan in recognition of his contributions to promoting economic and industrial development.
A score of government officials witnessed the presentation ceremony, which was held at the Presidential Office on Thursday afternoon.

Witnesses at the ceremony included Presidential Office Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang and 31 business circle leaders, including Koichi Toyozawa, president of Mitsubishi Co., Ltd.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES ROC-MALAWI TECHNOLOGY & VOCATIONAL TRAINING ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Cabinet at its weekly meeting Thursday approved the Republic of China-Malawi Technology and Vocational Training Cooperation Accord proposed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

MOFA said that in order to further promote established bilateral relations and technology and vocational training cooperation, the two countries inked an agreement on Dec. 3 in Taipei. Chairman of the ROC Labor Council Chan Hou-sheng and Malawi Minister for Foreign Affairs and concurrently International Cooperation Brown Mpinganjira signed the agreement on behalf of their respective governments.
Under the agreement, the ROC will send four experts in the fields of computers, electrical appliances, car maintenance and furniture tools to assist with a Malawi vocational training project.
The ROC will also send experts to help set up vocational training centers and provide necessary equipment.
The agreement is valid through Dec. 31, 2000, and can be extended for another year upon agreement by the two parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO FOCUS ON ANTI-CORRUPTION MEASURES IN 2000

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou revealed Thursday that in the coming year his administration will focus on the job of cracking down on corruption among public servants.

Ma assumed the office of mayor last Dec. 25. On Thursday, two days before his one-year anniversary at the post, Ma called a meeting with local reporters to talk about his policy over the past year and his future administrative plans.

As part of his efforts to improve social order, Ma indicated that he will promote the establishment of an anti-corruption department at the Taipei City Police Headquarters to implement plans to eliminate bribery, especially that involved with public construction projects.

Asked about reports charging that under Ma's administration, problems with the capital city's traffic and social order have gotten worse, the mayor explained that he was lacking knowledge of the city's affairs when he took the post one year ago.
Now he is better able to handle the situation, and believes he will become even more efficient in managing city affairs, Ma said.
During the meeting, the mayor also disclosed new strategies for the promotion of city-to-city diplomacy, which include promoting cultural and technology exchanges among major Asian cities.
Ma will not exclude mainland Chinese cities from the city-to-city exchange scheme, he stated.

The mayor also revealed that with the goal of strengthening Taipei's international profile, he will embark on visits to a number of European, Asian and American countries in the year 2000, possibly including Iceland and Russia.
Taipei now maintains sister-city relations with 44 metropolitan areas around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES ROC BASEBALL STAR SADAHARU OH

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday received Sadaharu Oh, the Republic of China baseball star residing in Japan, to praise him for his contributions to the development of ROC sports and thank him for his concern over Taiwan's 921 earthquake disaster.

Oh has donated NT$1 million and provided baseball uniforms, bats and gloves bearing his signature for charitable sale to help relieve the situation faced by Taiwan's quake victims following the devastating temblor that caused severe losses of life and property in the central part of the island.

Accompanied by Chao Li-yun, chairman of the Cabinet-level Physical Education Commission, and Peng Cheng-hao, president of the ROC Amateur Baseball Association, Oh went to the Presidential Office to call on Lee. Also present was Presidential Office Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih.

Before calling on the president, Oh received an ROC sports medal of the first degree, conferred on him by Chao, in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of the development of ROC baseball and to sports exchanges between the two nations, as well as the assistance he has extended since the 921 earthquake.
Oh joined the Japanese professional baseball team the Yomiuri Giants in 1960. His unique flamingo batting stance has attracted hundreds of thousands of baseball fans.

Oh hit a total of 868 home runs during his 20-year professional baseball career. Since retiring from playing, he has devoted himself to training baseball players in Japan. In his position as head coach, Oh led the Pacific League Daiei Hawks to win the national title in Japan's 1999 professional baseball championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOLFERS TO PARTICIPATE IN 2000 DAVIDOFF TOUR

TEXT.P: Fifteen golfers from Taiwan will participate in the 2000 Davidoff Tour to be sponsored by the Asian Professional Golf Association (Asian PGA).
The tour, part of the Asian circuit, has been upgraded to world ranking status, effective from Jan. 1, 2000.

The Asian circuit will start with the Benson & Hedges Malaysian Golf Open Championship on Jan. 14. This open will also be combined with the European circuit. South African golfer Peter Goosen has already confirmed his entry to the tournament.
The tour will be followed by the Philippine Open and the Indian Open in March, the Korean open in April, the Macau Open, the Volvo China Open, and the Taiwan Ericsson Classic in June.
The Singapore Open, the Omega PGA Championship in mainland China, the Volvo Malaysian Open, and the Thai Open will be held in the second half of 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EMBASSY IN VATICAN DONATES US$1,000 TO VENEZUELA
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By P.C. Fang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Ramond R.M. Tai, ambassador of the Republic of China to the Vatican, on Thursday donated US$1,000 on behalf of embassy staff to impoverished victims of the recent flooding in Venezuela.

In a letter to a committee under the Catholic Church, Tai expressed the embassy's grave concern over the flooding and resultant mudslides which have killed at least 5,000 people and injured 20,000 more, saying the people of Taiwan are especially sympathetic to the plight of the people of Venezuela, as the devastation of the Sept. 21 earthquake is still fresh in their minds.
As the eve of the new millennium grows ever closer, Tai voiced the hope that the Vatican committee will send the money to the central American country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CHECKING REPORTS ON ESTABLISHMENT OF BEIJING-VATICAN TIES

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen said on Thursday that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has ordered the Republic of China Embassy in the Vatican to check reports that the Holy See and mainland China are ready to forge ties.
Chen made the statement after the French daily Le Figaro reported on Wednesday that the Vatican and Beijing are negotiating a joint communique on the establishment of formal diplomatic relations.

According to the French paper, Beijing and Vatican officials have over the past year held more than 20 rounds of talks at the mainland embassy in Rome on mutual recognition. It said the two sides have reached the stage of negotiating the wording of a joint communique on the exchange of diplomatic recognition.
Le Figaro said Cardinal Claudio Celli is the Vatican's chief negotiator with the mainland and is waiting for a Beijing invitation to visit the mainland.

The daily further said Celli has tentatively agreed to Beijing's demand that the Vatican cut diplomatic ties with the ROC. At Beijing's insistence, Le Figaro said, the Vatican also plans to downgrade Taiwan's Catholic bishop curia to local-level status.
In response, Chen said a Vatican spokesman just last week denied a Hong Kong newspaper report that the Vatican has negotiated terms for establishing diplomatic ties with mainland China.
"At that time, ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Ramond Tai also said the report concerning the Vatican drafting a joint communique with the mainland was unfounded," Chen said.
Nevertheless, Chen said the Foreign Ministry has ordered the ROC Embassy in the Vatican to carefully check the latest Le Figaro report.

"We also hope that the Vatican, while showing concern about the rights of Catholics on the mainland, will also not forget Taiwan Catholics' rights," Chen said, adding that the ROC hopes Pope John Paul II will uphold religious freedom and the Holy See's right to name Catholic clergy when considering ties with the mainland.
Beijing regularly persecutes mainland people who follow religions not sanctioned by the Chinese Communist Party, and insists that only Beijing can appoint Catholic bishops in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA BECOMES 3RD COUNTRY TO SET UP NUKE TEST MONITORING STATION

TEXT.P: Australia will follow the United States and Russia to become the third country to establish a nuclear test monitoring station to help detect nuclear test explosions.
In a Thursday afternoon press release, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said the station will be established at Cape Leeuwin in western Australia at a cost of around US$6.5 billion.

"The Cape Leeuwin station is part of an international monitoring network set up under the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) to detect any explosive nuclear tests. When completed, the network will have 337 facilities around the world, including 21 in Australia," he said.
Only the United States, which, incidentally, recently failed to ratify the treaty, and Russia have a greater number of such facilities.

He said the station will include an assortment of underwater hydrophones to detect sounds generated by explosions, in particular by nuclear explosions, carried out on or below the surface of the ocean. "It will be one of eleven hydroacoustic monitoring stations in the International Monitoring System," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO PROMOTE TURN-KEY PLANT EXPORTS TO DEVELOPING COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will promote turn-key plant exports to developing countries, a MOEA official said on Thursday.
The official said that exports areas will be confined to developing countries such as mainland China, Southeast Asia, the Middle East, East Europe and Latin America.
At a meeting on Thursday, the MOEA mapped out an export strategy for turn-key plants for the coming two years.
The ministry also decided to set up cooperative and strategic alliances with business institutions in Europe and the United States to help local manufacturers enter the foreign market.
In addition to the turn-key plants, the exports will include capital incentives and information systems, together with marketing, technology and circulation expertise.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS CONCERNED ABOUT FATE OF BLACKFACED SPOONBILLS

TEXT.P: A group of foreign conservation scholars have come to Taipei to look into Taiwan's blackfaced spoonbill conservation measures.

The 10-plus conservation experts from the United States, Japan, South Korea, Holland, Hong Kong, Vietnam and several other countries were invited by the Republic of China's Council of Agriculture (COA) to attend a seminar on blackfaced spoonbill conservation.

Nearly all of them expressed concern about the ROC government's approval of a plan to build an industrial park in the southern Tainan county's coastal Pingnan area near the Chiku tial pond and the mouth of the Tsengwenchi River where a number of endangered blackfaced spoonbills visit every winter to shun rigid cold in the north.

An international survey conducted a few years ago shows that the number of surviving blackfaced spoonbills worldwide is about 600 to 700. As 300 to 400 of them consistently take shelter in Taiwan, mainly in the Chiku and Tsengwenchi River mouth area, both local and foreign conservation scholars are worried about possible damage to the area's natural ecology after the controerial Pingnan industrial park is built.

The private Tainan Blackfaced Spoonbills Conservation Association reported last week that a record number of blackfaced spoonbills have graced Taiwan this winter. As of Dec. 10, the association said, 463 of the species had been discovered in the Chiku area. The number of marked an increase of about 100 birds over the figure recorded last year, the association added.

"The arrival of a record number of blackfaced spponbills is encouraging news, but it's worrisome that the government has given a green light to the construction of an industrial park near one of the world's most important natural habitat of the rare bird," said an asociation spokesman.

The foreign participants to the COA-sponsored blackfaced spoonbill conservation seminar will pay a visit to COA Chairman Lin Shiang-nun on Friday to express their concern about the Pingnan industrial park project.

Meanwhile, the ROC Wild Birds Society said it plans to organize a demonstration against the Pingnan industrial park project which the society said will have a detrimental effect on the Chikuo area's natural ecology and may discourage the endangered rare species from visiting Taiwan again.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER AGREES TO PROPOSED STATE BANK MERGER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Thursday that he has agreed in principle to a Ministry of Finance (MOF)-proposed merger of the Bank of Taiwan (BOT), the Land Bank of Taiwan (LBT) and the Central Trust China (CTC).
He told reporters that while the details and the date for the merger of the state-run banks have yet to be announced, it will serve as a model for future mergers of private banking institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPERATURE HITS YEAR'S LOW IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Temperatures in flatland areas of Taiwan dipped to the year's low on Thursday morning, with the mercury dropping below 10 degrees Celsius in western Taiwan, and hitting 4.1 degrees Celsius in Chiayi, said the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

Owing to the "radiation chill effect" -- the land giving off heat after sunset -- temperatures in central and southern Taiwan kept falling throughout Wednesday evening and Thursday morning, CWB officials said.

Besides Chiayi, the thermometer plummeted to 4.7 degrees Celsius in Taichung, 6.1 degrees Celsius in Tainan, 6.9 degrees Celsius in Tamshui, 7.6 degrees Celsius in Hsinchu, and 8.2 degrees Celsius in Taipei, according to the CWB.
The cold snap which has gripped the island since last week has caused serious damage to milk fish aquaculturists in Tainan County, which has about 4,000 hectares of fishponds.

The Tainan Fishery Association estimated that 80 million milk fish, with a total market value of between NT$500 million and NT$600 million (US$15.62 million and US$18.75 million), had died of cold as of Thursday morning, as the fish cannot survive in water of less than 10 degrees Celsius.
On the other hand, the cold snap has brought shoals of young eels to the coast of northern Taiwan, much to the delight of anglers in Keelung Harbor.
The CWB forecasts the cold snap will continue until Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EXPORT GROWTH LEADS ASIAN DRAGONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan led the other three Asian dragons in export growth in 1999, posting a 9.5 percent increase rate as of the middle of December, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) estimated on Thursday.

The Sept. 21 earthquake, the worst natural disaster to hit Taiwan in a century, did not hinder Taiwan's overall exports from January to the middle of this month, according to a panel set up under the MOEA.

It pointed out that Taiwan's outbound shipments had a total worth of US$116.8 billion from January to Dec. 18, up 9.5 percent over the same period of 1998, an indication that the tremor did not affect the island's exports.
The panel added that export expansion has become the major factor behind the continued growth of Taiwan's gross national product.

Taiwan's top five export items are electronics, information and telecommunications products, yarn, machinery and steel, in that order, with increases registering between 27.6 percent to 2.6 percent, it noted.

The United States, Hong Kong, Europe, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and Japan are Taiwan's leading five export markets, and exports to these regions have all posted growth over the past year, the panel said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO RENAME ITS REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN MACAU

TEXT.P: Taipei will rename its representative office in Macau as the Taipei Economic and Culture Center, effective from Dec. 27, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced on Thursday.

Meanwhile, Taipei's representative to Macau, William Li, who caused an uproar in Taipei for removing the name plate of his office before the Dec. 20 handover of Macau to Beijing, will stay on in his job for the time being, according to the Cabinet-level organization which charts Taiwan's mainland China policy.

Li was recalled by Taipei for an explanation as to why he removed the name plate of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau on Dec. 19 just an hour before Macau was due to return to Beijing's rule.

Macau had warned Taipei to rename its representative office to play down any official overtone in the existing name before the Portuguese colony was handed over, but Taipei had not done so by Dec. 20 because Beijing has shut down all channels of contact with Taiwan since President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relationship" statement in July.
Li therefore removed his office's name plate before midnight on Dec. 19, when Beijing leaders descended on the Portuguese colony in flocks for the handover ceremony.

Li's move, which was not approved by Taipei in advance, drew fire from critics at home who blamed him for "running ahead of himself," and there were suggestions that he would be sacked for his mistake.
The new name of Taiwan's representative office is consistent with Taipei's offices in other countries which have no official ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE FERRY CAPSIZE CLAIMS SEVERAL LIVES

TEXT.P: Philippine civil defense officials in Cebu City reported on Thursday that six persons were confirmed dead, several were missing, and 539 had survived following the capsize of a ferry.
The officials said the M/V Trans-Asia Korea left Cebu port at about 11 p.m. on Wednesday for Iloilo City carrying 606 people and 56 crew members.
The Philippine Coast Guard was continuing a search and rescue operation, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE DOWN IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate in November registered 2.94 percent, down 0.11 percentage points over the preceding month, the Executive Yuan's Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Thursday.
The number of jobless workers was listed at 287,000, down 10,000 from October.

DGBAS officials attributed the improvement in employment figures to the gradual recovery of the international economy, continuing growth of the island's exports, and smooth progress of post-earthquake reconstruction.
Taiwan's employed labor force in November was put at 9.47 million, up 54,000 over October and up 140,000 over the same month of 1998.
The DGBAS also pointed out that the 2.94 percent jobless rate in Taiwan for November was lower than Hong Kong's 6.1 percent, South Korea's 4.8 percent, and Singapore's 4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT VISITS RESIDENTS OF PREFABRICATED HOUSES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday visited victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake living in prefabricated houses in Taichung County and presented them with cash-containing "red envelopes."

Accompanied by Taiwan Governor Chao Shou-po and Tang Yao-ming, chief of the general staff of the ROC armed forces, Lee visited Fengyuan City and Tungshih Township to be briefed on the post-quake reconstruction.

He expressed his concern about their living conditions in the prefabricated houses that were erected for the quake survivors whose homes were destroyed or rendered unsafe for habitation by the devastating temblor.
Some residents voiced their worries that they might not able to rebuild their houses before their one-year permits allowing them to live in the prefabricated houses expires.
Lee assured them that he would take action to coordinate the matter, and asked them not to worry about the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL RE-IMPOSE MARTIAL LAW IF ATTACKED BY BEIJING: MND

TEXT.P: Taiwan will re-impose martial law if attacked by Beijing in the run-up to the presidential election in March, Minister of National Defense Tang Fei said on Thursday.

Answering questions from reporters, Tang said his ministry will recommend that the president impose martial law if Beijing invades the island during Taiwan's second popular presidential election slated for March 18 next year.

However, the armed forces will not be put on a higher level of alert simply because of Beijing's military drills, or by isolated incidents of provocation of Taiwan's frontline islands, said his vice minister Wu Shih-wen earlier in the day at the Legislative Yuan.

In a report to the legislature, Wu said the Ministry of National Defense has taken precautions against possible military provocation, infiltration or sabotage by Beijing's military in the run up to the presidential election.
Taiwan abolished nearly four decades of martial law in 1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO GROW 6.07 PERCENT NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) on Thursday predicted that the island's real economic growth rate next year will grow 6.07 percent.
After the devastating earthquake that ripped apart parts of central Taiwan on Sept. 21, the CBC revised the growth rate for this year downward from 5.74 percent to 5.46 percent.

Bank officials based their rosy prediction for next year on an optimistic outlook for the global economy, continuing growth in Taiwan's exports, and implementation of post-quake reconstruction projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 25, or the seventh day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
440: The leaders of the Christian Church decide that the date of the birth of Jesus Christ should be fixed. The date chosen is Dec. 25, the day that the Romans celebrate the winter solstice.
1800: Britain's first Christmas tree is put up at Windsor by Queen Charlottee.
1818: The Christmas carol "Silent Night" is sung for the first time in Austrian village of Oberndorff.
1863: Spain declares war on France.
1913: A couple are arrested for kissing in the street in New York.
1914: Tsai O, Tang Chi-yao and Li Lieh-chun revolt against Yuan Shih-kai in Yunnan province.
1926: Hirohito accedes to the throne of Japan on the death of his father, Emperor Yoshihito.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang accompanies Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Madame Chiang to Loyang, en route to Nanking, after mutinous warlords kidnapped Chiang and held him for 12 days.
1941: British troops in Hong Kong surrender to Japan in World War II.
1945: National Taiwan University makes public the results of its first entrance examination and accepts 36 students who have passed the examination.
1946: The National Assembly completes the drafting of the Republic of China's new constitution.
1947: The Constitution of the ROC, which was promulgated on Jan. 1, 1947, goes into effect.
1948: The Gwoyeu Ryhbaw (Mandarin Daily News) publishes its premier issue in Taipei, becoming the first and only daily newspaper to publish stories written in the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1950: The 15-year-old Dalai Lama, the temporal and religious leader of Tibet, flees the Tibetan capital, Lhasa.
1962: The government formally proclaims Dec. 25 Constitution Day, a public holiday.
1969: The first Taipei City Council is established, with Lin Ting-sheng serving as speaker.
1969: Luo Chia-lun, senior advisor to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1973: Construction of the Suao-Hualien railroad is launched.
1977: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, the British-born actor, director and producer who gained fame for his role as a tramp in baggy trousers and a bowler hat, dies at his home in Switzerland at the age of 88.
1986: Sixty-two people die as an Iraqi Airways jetliner with 107 people aboard explodes and burns when it attempts a forced landing at a remote desert airstrip in Saudi Arabia.
1989: Deposed Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife Elena are executed by the Romanian army after a secret court-martial in Romania.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev formally resigns as president of the Soviet Union.
1996: A tropical storm lashes the Pacific island of Borneo, killing at least 120 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man is without moral character, what good can the use of the fine arts do him? If a man is without moral character, what good can the use of music do him?"

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Cabinet has agreed to merger of three state-owned banks -- Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan and the Central Trust of China.
The China Times:
Independent presidential candidate James Soong entrusts New Party Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta to help clarify capital flows of all Soong-related bank accounts.
The United Daily News:
Premier Vincent Siew confirms that Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan and the Central Trust of China would merge by year-end.

The China Post:
Premier confirms 3-in-1 bank merger.
The Taiwan News:

The Taipei Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO HIKE HOUSEHOLD-USED NATURAL GAS PRICES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's household-used natural gas prices are expected to be hiked by the beginning of the year 2000, state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) officials revealed on Friday.

The current prices have been maintained for the past six months, and officials said now is the time to adjust them to reflect costs. They disclosed that prices might be hiked by more than 3 percent, and even as high as 5 percent.
A CPC executive explained that since July, the company has increased industry-used natural gas prices three times, for an accumulated increase of nearly 9 percent.

In July, the CPC raised the price of domestically-produced natural gas for household use to NT$7.04 (US$0.22) per cubic meter from NT$6.83. The price of imported natural gas for family use was hiked to NT$7.83 from NT$7.6, according to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ARMS BUILD-UP A DETERRENT, NOT AN INSTIGATION SAYS SIEW

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's arms build-up is aimed solely at securing an effective deterrent to military threats from mainland China, but absolutely not at igniting an arms race in the Taiwan Strait, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.

Citing a recent analysis compiled by the Pentagon, Siew said the People's Liberation Army (PLA) will hold military superiority over Taiwan by the year 2005. Taiwan's seeking to beef up its military muscle is only a natural development in consequence of the PLA's accelerated arms modernization and build-up, he noted.

Siew, making his remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, stressed that Taiwan is virtually racing against time in the face of the growing threat from Beijing as its military capabilities are expected to increase at a startling pace over the next six years.

To beef up Taiwan's defensive prowess, Siew said the military is making an effort to upgrade its pre-warning and surveillance capabilities, strengthen its anti-missile muscle, and sharpen up the combat capabilities of the three branches of its armed forces.
Siew also stressed that Taiwan will never develop or research the development of nuclear weapons under any circumstances.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONSIDERING CHANGING REPRESENTATIVE TO MACAU

TEXT.P: Taipei's representative in Macau, William Li, publicly admitted that it was an "administrative error" to give instructions to turn the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office's sign against the wall, concealing it from public view, one hour before the Dec. 20 handover of Macau to Beijing was to take place, a spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Friday.

Lin Chong-pin, the MAC spokesman and vice chairman, said Li, who has been recalled to Taipei since Dec. 21, ordered the removal of the signs from the ninth and 15th floors of the Macau building where the office is located an hour before the handover ceremony under the directive of Taipei.
Li then ordered his staff to turn the business sign located on the first floor of the building against the wall, a move not approved by Taipei, said Lin.
Li agreed that the move was an "administrative error" and is willing to accept any punishment his superiors feel is appropriate, said Lin.

It was learned that MAC Chairman Su Chi is considering a replacement for Li, and rumors are that Tsai Chih-chung, director of the MAC Department of Hong Kong & Macau Affairs, may be appointed as his successor.
Lin, who would not confirm the allegations, noted that the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau, would be renamed the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, effective from Dec. 27.

Lin said this office in Macau is expected to function more smoothly in the new century, to be marked by a new Taiwan-Macau relation defined as a new relationship between Chinese people from Taiwan and Chinese people from Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA KEEPING CLOSE WATCH ON VATICAN-BEIJING DEVELOPMENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday it is closely watching developments in relations between the Vatican and mainland China.
The ministry made the statement amid reports that mainland China and the Holy See are ready to forge diplomatic ties.

MOFA spokesman Henry M.C. Chen said the Republic of China has consistently attached great importance to its relations with the Vatican and is concerned about any reports concerning changes in the Vatican's attitude toward the ROC.

Chen said initial contacts between MOFA and a Vatican official in charge of China affairs on Thursday show that there is a wide gap between the press reports and the actual situation regarding current ROC-Vatican ties.
The French daily Le Figaro reported on Wednesday that the Vatican and Beijing are negotiating a joint communique on the establishment of formal diplomatic relations.
A Hong Kong newspaper also reported last week that the Vatican has negotiated terms for establishing diplomatic ties with mainland China. However, a Vatican spokesman has flatly denied the report.
As the Vatican is one of the ROC's only two diplomatic allies in Europe, Chen said the ROC never ignores reports concerning ROC-Vatican ties.

Asked whether the prospects for ROC-Vatican relations are brighter or gloomier than the picture painted by foreign news media, Chen did not respond directly, but stressed instead that the ROC treasures its ties with the Vatican and respects religious freedom and the Holy See's right to appoint Catholic clergy.

Noting that Beijing has never ceased its attempts to squeeze the ROC's diplomatic frontiers and block its participation in international organizations and activities, Chen said MOFA has ordered ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Ramond Tai to carefully check the recent press reports concerning Vatican-Beijing engagements.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOW MORE THAN EVER, TAIWAN BELONGS IN WHO, SAYS ROC PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exclusion from the World Health Organization (WHO) not only compromises Taiwan's public health, it also represents a loss for the entire world, Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said in an article published on Thursday.

In an article carried in The Providence Journal of Rhode Island, Siew said there could be no more appropriate time than now to eliminate the artificial barriers hampering the WHO's coordination of global resources to ensure the safety of people in all countries and to make possible Taiwan's access to the WHO.

In the article titled "Now more than ever, Taiwan belongs in WHO," Siew said when a 7.3-magnitude earthquake shook central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, the world immediately recognized that a concerted and immediate effort was necessary to save lives and limit collateral damage.

The international community responded swiftly with generous support and expert assistance for locating survivors. For this, the people and government of the ROC are very grateful, he said. The arrival of rescue specialists from all over the world was a powerful reminder of the basic human impulse to come together in the face of adversity, he went on.

This is in fact the same spirit behind the everyday activities of the WHO, he said, adding that its mission is to ensure the health of people around the world by coordinating medical resources. To do this, it works to save lives and limit damage caused by disease outbreaks on a daily basis in the absence of such high-profile events as earthquakes, hurricanes or volcanic eruptions.

This is the same spirit as that demonstrated by international search and rescue specialists working alongside Taiwan's emergency response workers -- an unselfish sharing of resources and expertise for the benefit of all, he said.

WHO assistance and expertise would be very welcome in Taiwan in the aftermath of the earthquake, he said. "My country has completed the first phase of earthquake disaster response, but the next step involves housing victims and continuing efforts to contain the health threat posed by the earthquake and its aftermath. The greatest threat to the well-being of survivors now is no longer structurally unsafe buildings, but rather a disrupted public sanitation infrastructure that inevitably follows in the wake of such a large-scale disaster."

Under such circumstances, he said, any country would turn to the WHO for expert consultation and coordination. Yet, when it comes to Taiwan, the WHO must rely on non-official, private-sector channels to offer assistance. "My country has been excluded from the organization since 1972, and the UN remains under pressure from Beijing to keep things that way, despite all the changes that have taken place in the world order since then."

Fortunately, this time the WHO was able to make use of indirect channels to assess the magnitude of the problem and offer its help. For instance, it donated US$50,000 to the Red Cross for use as relief aid. The people and government of the ROC greatly appreciate this gesture of concern.

And by not being permitted a role in the WHO, Taiwan has no access to information concerning global regulations on the laboratory testing of bio-products. It cannot participate in the development of bio-product standards, and its bio-products cannot be recognized by other countries. This is a particularly unfortunate way to start the 21st century when this technology will have such an important role to play for many decades to come, Siew said.
He added that Taiwan has applied for observer status in the WHO, an organization where common global medical and public health concerns should clearly take priority over pedestrian political issues.
There could be no more appropriate time than this to eliminate the artificial barriers hampering the WHO's coordination of global resources to ensure the safety of people in all countries, he said.

Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO not only compromises the public health interests of the 22 million people of Taiwan, but also represents a loss for the entire world, he said, adding that the exigencies of disaster have demonstrated that its non-political priorities accord with the human heart.
"Let us go on listening to our hearts," he said, adding: "There is a role in the WHO for Taiwan that will make the world a healthier and safer place."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar climbed 1.8 cents to close at 31.608 against the greenback on Friday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.
The currency opened at 31.611, and was traded between 31.601 and 31.624. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$373 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWER SUPPLY DEFECT CAUSES LOSSES AT SCIENCE-BASED PARK

TEXT.P: High-tech manufacturing lines in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan sustained losses estimated at millions of new Taiwan dollars on Friday following two sudden drops in the power supply.

The first drop occurred at 6:45 p.m. on Thursday, while the second incident occurred on Friday at 1:14 a.m., when the electric power vital to the park's round-the-clock operation dropped suddenly by between 10 percent and 30 percent.
Although the plunge lasted only several seconds, it affected the whole park, home to most leading semiconductor manufacturers in Taiwan, according to the park administration.

Macronix International, which makes silicon wafers, lost the use of several vital pieces of machinery, forcing the plant to temporarily close down, leading to losses of several million Taiwan dollars, the company said.

Taiwan Power Company technicians said that based on a preliminary investigation, the power drops occurred after two electric wires touched, tripping a circuit-breaker. An in-depth investigation is now under way to discover the cause of the short, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed higher for the fourth straight day on Friday on news of the merger of three major state-run banks and overnight gains on Wall Street.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 135.96 points, or 1.7 percent, higher at 8,219.45, on a huge turnover of NT$170.44 billion (US$5.41 billion), even larger than Thursday's NT$133.86 billion.
The index has added 5.61 percent over the four-day rise.
Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday confirmed a merger between three major banks in order to consolidate Taiwan's overcrowded financial industry.

According to dealers, the first merger between major banks triggers hopes that more tie-ups will follow in the near future. The move, though it may not show an immediate effect in improved profitability, will surely help banks upgrade their competitiveness and promise for future profitability.

Led by the cement sector, which registered gains of 4.09 percent, the majority of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with the exception of the paper-making sector, which posting losses of 1.8 percent.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 303 to 182, with 78 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 2.76 points to close at 201.5 on a turnover of NT$18.44 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN EFFECTIVELY FORCES DELAY OF HEROIN INJECTING ROOMS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The UN Narcotics Control Board has effectively forced the delayed opening of planned heroin injecting rooms in New South Wales, Victoria and Canberra after it warned that the rooms would be illegal and would be damaging to the image of the Sydney Olympic Games.

The governments of NSW, Victoria and Canberra are likely to cooperate with the UN body and delay their plans to begin operating the injecting rooms by reexamining the scheme, which is designed to help drug addicts find a venue to reduce their addiction and finally eliminate it.

Drug addiction is one of the most serious problems in Australia as the suicide rate among drug-users is on the rise and the age of drug-users is getting younger and younger. Crime rates are also on the rise in Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra and other cities due to the impact of drug addiction and gambling.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN TAIWAN EXPORTS REPORTED

TEXT.P: Taiwan has for the most part recovered from the September earthquake as its exports have increased significantly, the leading French newspaper Le Figaro reported on Thursday.

It has done so by taking advantage of the on-going Asian recovery and the rising investment trends from Europe and the United States regarding information technologies and electronic products, the paper reported.

Quoting the most recent statistics published by the Taipei government, Le Figaro said that exports from the island in November were 18.6 percent higher than the same month last year, reaching US$ 11.56 billion.

These figures are impressive given the seriousness of the quake, which caused an estimated US$ 2.15 billion in losses to the manufacturing sector, with US$ 400 million worth of damage to equipment. The government has estimated that reconstruction efforts will cost a total of about US$ 12.5 billion.

Yet Republic of China government authorities have calculated that the earthquake will only have a limited overall effect on the country's economy, with the growth rate for this year expected to stay at 5%, the French daily said.
For the month of November, total exports to the United States, Taiwan's biggest market, increased 4.5 percent to US$ 28.2 billion and exports to Europe rose 2.5 percent to US$ 18.4 billion.

Meanwhile, a positive balance of trade and a regular inflow of foreign capital have enabled Taiwan to reach a record-high foreign currency reserve level of US$ 103.5 billion at the end of November, representing a rise of over US$20 billion from the end of October, reported the paper.

At the same time, the people of Taiwan are also still continuing to invest, according to La Figaro, while companies continue to expand and open new plants. Microelectronics, the second largest semi-conductor producer in the country, is about to open a new plant worth several hundred million US dollars.

Le Figaro recalled that while Communist Chinese President Jiang Zemin re-affirmed during a speech at the Macau handover ceremony that he wants to see the island "come back to China as soon as possible," Taiwan, which has just recently obtained a wider access to mainland capital markets, is presently focusing all its energy on gaining entry into the World Trade Organization to further strengthen its already strong economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP RESPONDS TO COMPARISON OF TAIWAN TO MACAU

TEXT.P: USA Today published Thursday a letter from the Republic of China representative office in Washington, D.C. criticizing a British reader for comparing Taiwan's status to that of Macau and suggesting that those who don't want to live under mainland Chinese rule should leave Taiwan now to facilitate the reunification of China.

Eric Chiang, information division director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office, responded to the Dec. 7 letter-to-the-editor by saying that "it is incomprehensible that an Englishman, whose ancestors drafted the Magna Carta, should make such a suggestion to clear up unfinished business" over the future of Taiwan.

"How in the world could one who enjoys the blessings of civil liberties and democracy propose that the 22 million peace-loving free citizens of the Republic of China on Taiwan be subjected to the ruthless rulers of a Communist dictatorship?" Chiang questioned.

He pointed out that the ROC has been a sovereign state since its founding in 1912, even though it now only effectively controls Taiwan and a few other islands, and has worked to realize its goal of a democratic government and free-market economy.
He stressed that according to opinion polls, more than 80 per cent of Taiwan's population opposes Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, and for obvious reasons.

"There is no convincing argument to sacrifice our hard-earned democracy in exchange for trusting our future to the same regime that readily persecutes religious followers and guns down its own people. We all know that Beijing does not have a sterling track record in such areas as human rights or the rule of law," said Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui reorders mobilization of party members to rally support for KMT presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate, Vincent Siew.
The China Times:
Defense Ministry plans to dissolve its General Political Warfare Department as time changed.
The United Daily News:
Investigation Bureau probing financial scandal involving independent presidential candidate James Soong.
The Liberty Times:
At least on person dead and 27 released unharmed as of Saturday after the hijacked Indian Airliner carrying 161 people landed in Afghanistan; the hijackers' intentions remain unclear.
The China Post:
India jet lands in Afghanistan; Hijackers demand release of Pakistani religious leader.
The Taiwan News:
Airline hijackers seek release of prisoners in India; Plane carrying as many as 161 people lands in Afghanistan on second day of terrorism.
The Taipei Times:
Activists say local trees endangered -- Demonstrators say making a national park at Chilan Mountain will help save a forest and aid in preserving biodiversity in an area that is being logged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY TO PROMOTE BURIAL ROTATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is working to promote an alternative way of using public cemeteries by introducing a rotation scheme, to allow limited burial space to be distributed more fairly, MOI sources said on Sunday.

After years of deliberation, the MOI has recently completed drafting an amendment to the existing cemetery management bill, which is expected to help rectify the long-insufficient regulation of burial practices in Taiwan, MOI officials said.

With the number of annual deaths increasing steadily, expected to total 170,000 for the year 2001, while the acreage of public cemeteries remains the same, about 11,000 hectares islandwide, the areas used for burying the dead must be regulated more efficiently and rationally to meet demand, the officials noted.
The amended bill stipulates that graveyard plots must be vacated after being used for eight to 10 years so as to allow the spaces to be used in rotation.
The bill encourages private business groups to join the government in developing and managing public cemeteries under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) program.
Private companies will also be allowed to operate privately-owned public cemeteries, each with an area of at least five hectares, if they are found to meet specifications, according to the bill.
The bill prohibits burial on private land or in neighborhood, and violators will be dealt with according to guidelines outlined in the bill.
In addition, the bill for the first time recommends "ocean burial" -- spreading ashes of the deceased over the sea -- as an alternative to traditional burial.
The amended bill is expected to be approved by the Legislative Yuan and become effective immediately, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 26, or the nineteenth day of the 11th month in Year of the Rabbit under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1791: Charles Babbage, English mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1893: Mao Tse-tung (Zedong), chairman of Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establish of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay, Sydney, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back US$11 million, the remainder of a large sum of indemnities China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of the National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye's statement clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The Royal Navy of Britain sink the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen US veterans of Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: Harry S. Truman, American statesman and Democratic president (1945-53), dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN PROMISES TO MAKE TAICHUNG SPECIAL ZONE IF ELECTED PRES.

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan, the Kuomintang's presidential candidate, on Sunday promised to make the central city of Taichung a special business operation zone if he is elected the next president of the Republic of China.

Soliciting support at a campaign rally in Taichung, the third largest city in Taiwan, Lien promised potential voters that if he is elected the next president, he will see to it that an international airport and a mass rapid transportation system are developed in the greater Taichung area.
Lien said Taichung should also have a science-based industrial park to further develop industries and businesses.

With its relatively close proximity to mainland China, Lien added, Taichung can be developed into a special business operation zone as a base where direct and more frequent bilateral business interchanges between Taiwan and mainland China can be carried out when the time is ripe.

Meanwhile, Lien promised to upgrade the government's classification of Taichung to the level of "metropolis," making it the Taiwan's third behind Taipei and Kaohsiung, since the city's population now exceeds 1 million and improvement projects are in order.
Lien made a campaign speech on the occasion of the founding of his central Taiwan campaign headquarters in downtown Taichung, as a sea of campaign banners swayed in the background.
Lien said he and his running mate, Premier Vincent Siew, are the only ticket that the people can rely on for a brighter future.

Together, Lien added, he and Siew have held the posts of eight ministry heads and two premierships, making them seasoned and experienced government executives who have been largely instrumental in making possible Taiwan's national health insurance program, the national defense's "lean and mean" plans, telecommunications liberalization and the Asia-Pacific business operations center.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC URGED TO ABANDON ONE-PARTY RULE

TEXT.P: The China Democracy Party banned by Beijing a year ago issued a bold call Friday to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.

The "Voice of America" radio station reported from Beijing that the China Democracy Party sent a lengthy declaration to foreign news media in the mainland capital Friday, rejecting key Chinese Communist doctrines as well as accusing Beijing of using the defense of national sovereignty as an excuse to commit human rights abuses.

The China Democracy Party stopped short of calling for the overthrow of the Communist Chinese government, but it argued that people have the right to abolish the government when their human rights are systematically and persistently violated, said the VOA, which expresses the policies of the United States government.
The VOA quoted He Depu, a China Democracy Party member in Beijing, as saying that there was no immediate government response, but he believed the declaration could bring on more repression.
The Beijing regime has cracked down on the group, which it has declared illegal, arresting many members and handing down stiff jail sentences, the radio station told listeners.
When it was founded in June 1998, the China Democracy Party said it had 500 members across the mainland. But Mr. He declined to say how many members the opposition party has now, reported the VOA.

He noted that the declaration released Friday was written by a group from the China Democracy Party's Beijing headquarters, and was based on the ideas of longtime dissident and Party leader Xu Wenli, who was sentenced last year to 13 years in prison. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM AND INDONESIA DRAWING ATTENTION OF TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Southeast Asian countries, like Vietnam and Indonesia, could take mainland China's place in the spotlight of Taiwan investors sometime in the near future, said an economics official of the Republic of China.

Director General Lin Neng-chung of the Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) was cited by the Economic Daily News on Sunday as saying that that trend is emerging as the investment environment on the mainland is becoming worse for Taiwan investors.

Recently, Beijing has adjusted its trade and economic policy, and its policy on foreign investment in mainland China, numerous times without prior notice, Lin stated, noting that Taiwan business leaders are quite confused by the changes, according to the newspaper.

Lin, leading an economic and trade delegation, left Taiwan Sunday on a trip to Southeast Asian countries including Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam. During the journey, the mission is planning to visit factories owned by Taiwan enterprises to study their operation.
The group is also scheduled to call on relevant officials during its stay, to discuss operational difficulties and investment challenges facing Taiwan businesses.

Lin indicated that Taiwan's current investment in Southeast Asia accounts for 40 percent of the island's total foreign investment. Most of the island's Southeast Asian investment is concentrated in Indonesia, followed by Thailand, Malaysia and Vietnam, IDIC statistics show.

As Southeast Asian countries are gradually walking out of the shadow of the Asian financial storm, which broke out in July 1997, they are at the same time promoting investment incentives, such as tax reductions, to draw foreign capital in the hope of speeding up their economic recovery, Lin said.
In addition, the official said, in a country like Vietnam, there is a diligent labor force, and sometimes production costs there are lower than those in mainland China.

If a particular country has signed a trade accord with the United States to qualify for reductions in US import tariffs, any Taiwan investment in that country could potentially benefit from such an agreement, Lin added.
As for the current investment climate in Indonesia, Lin said production costs and prices of raw materials there have sustained big drops after the two-year-long political and economic disturbance.

If the country's new government, which was formed in early November, can maintain stable political development and appear friendly to Chinese people, Indonesia would be an ideal place for Taiwan businesses to build factories which rely on an intensive labor force for operations, Lin noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED REACTIONS TO POST-HANDOVER MACAU SITUATION

TEXT.P: Scholars' reactions to the effect on Taiwan-Macau relations and cross-strait relations after Macau reverted to the rule of mainland China on Dec. 20 were mixed.

On one hand, scholars said there is more room for developments between Taiwan and Macau after the handover. On the other hand, Beijing may feel it is more urgent to try to unify with Taiwan after its two former colonies have rejoined the fold, said the scholars on Sunday at a seminar sponsored by the Association for Chinese Academic and Cultural Exchange Across the Strait.

Professor Pan Hsi-tang of Tamkang University said at the seminar that there will now be more room for relations to develop between Taiwan and Macau than there was between Taiwan and Hong Kong after its handover.

Pan envisioned Macau as acting as an intermediary bridge between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, adding that though there is not much trade opportunity in the former Portuguese colony, it will be a good place for Taiwan businessmen to establish overseas operations centers for making inroads into the mainland.
Professor Kuo Chan-li of Chinese Culture University said that Macau, if it continues to develop into a prosperous society, could serve as the midpoint of cross-strait communication.

Kuo said that a high degree of autonomy will be the key to whether Macau will be able to rule itself as promised by mainland China. He also said that if the current cross-strait stalemate is not resolved after the handover, cross-strait relations will enter into a period of confrontation and adversity.
Especially after both sides of the Taiwan Strait enter the World Trade Organization next year, the economies of both sides will have more exchanges but will also suffer under the impact, Kuo said.

He said that if both sides of the Taiwan Strait handle the situation well, then it will either be a chance for positive development between the two sides or relations will enter into a dangerous period.

Professor Wu Heng-yu of the College of Political Warfare said that after the handover, Macau will follow the example of Hong Kong and become a special administration region in carrying out the mainland's "one country, two systems" formula.

Wu noted that the formula, first broached by Deng Xiaoping in 1980s with the intention of reunification with Taiwan, is being put to the test in Hong Kong and Macau. The mainland definitely wants the test to be successful so it will be attractive to Taiwan.

Wu said that after Hong Kong and Macau are back in the fold of mainland China, the desire to unify with Taiwan will pose new pressure on mainland leader Jiang Zemin, so Wu envisions that Beijing will refine its "one country, two system" rhetoric, perhaps by offering a more flexible time span than the "50 years of an unchangeable system" offered to Hong Kong and Macau.

Beijing could also permit more Taiwan people and businessmen who live in the mainland to participate at various levels of the government. Beijing could also unveil more substantial details of the government's legislative act to protect Taiwan businesses that was announced earlier this month, he said.
Beijing could also establish a National Unification Council, and work out national unification guidelines just like Taipei has done, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK BEAR SEEN AS MOST REPRESENTATIVE OF TAIWAN'S INDIGENOUS ANIMALS

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Sunday chose the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
Lien made the choice when he was invited to attend a meeting of a wildlife foundation in Taichung on the sidelines of the inauguration of his presidential campaign office in that central Taiwan city.
Lien chose the Taiwan black bear as the symbol of indigenous wildlife, but he also gave praise to the Taiwan water-buffalo, though it was not listed among the choices.
Senior Presidential Advisor Wu Poh-hsiung, attending the same event, also chose the Taiwan black bear.

The wildlife selection activity, which will last until the end of the month, has seen the Taiwan black bear garnering the most votes, with a total of 92,000. The black bear is 10,000 votes ahead of number-two contender the Taiwan rhesus monkey.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF MRT PASSENGERS TRANSPORTED

TEXT.P: With the opening to traffic of a small part of the new Panchiao-Nankang (PN) line of Taipei's mass rapid transit (MRT) system, the volume of passengers transported by Taiwan's only subway system continued to hit record highs over the past two days.

Officials from Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) attributed the remarkable increase in MRT passengers to the opening of a 7.7-kilometer route, connecting Lungshan Temple in western downtown Taipei to Taipei City Hall in the east, on Dec. 24, or Christmas Eve, when the number of people traveling on board MRT totaled a record high of 734,000.
Of that number of passengers traveling on all lines of the MRT Friday, the number of those traveling on the PN line totaled 83,000, according to TRTC officials.

On Saturday, when the total MRT transport volume amounted to 672,000, the number of those traveling on the PN line shot up to 120,000, indicating that the PN line is the "goose that lays golden eggs" of TRTC.

The PN line is popular because it allows people from western Taipei, including those from other satellite cities of suburban Taipei, to reach the Wenshan District in southern Taipei, the Taipei City Hall district in the east, and northern Taipei, in a fast 14 minutes -- speed that was just a dream back when such travel took at least an hour by bus or car during peak hours.

The PN line, when it is completed in two years, will allow passengers to travel from Panchiao in Taipei County, located to the southwest of Taipei, to Nankang in the northeast of suburban Taipei, in about 30 minutes.

The PN line is the third major line of the Taipei MRT system, joining the line connecting Mucha and Chungshan, a mid-capacity route, and the line connecting Taipei Railway Station in downtown Taipei and Tamshui in Taipei County, a mass-capacity route.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF'S SOUTHERN AREA BRANCH OFFICE TO BE INAUGURATED DEC. 28

TEXT.P: The Southern Area Branch Office of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will be formally inaugurated in Kaohsiung on Tuesday to render services for people residing in southern part of Taiwan.
The office's main services will include certification of documents from the mainland China area and consultation for cultural, economic, trade, law and tourism interchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

The SEF is a semi-official organization which was founded to promote interchanges between Taiwan and mainland China, as Taiwan and the mainland do not maintain official relations. The foundation has achieved fruitful results in exchanges across the Taiwan Strait since it was formally inaugurated in 1983.
The new SEF branch office will be located at the Second Combined Office of the Executive Yuan in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE VISITS QUAKE VICTIMS IN NANTOU COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, Central Taiwan, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui visited victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Puli Chen, Nantou County, on Sunday morning.

The Chinese head of state, accompanied by Taiwan Governor Chao Shou-po, Nantou Magistrate Peng Pei-hsian and Puli Town Chief Chang Hong-ming, visited quake victims now living in tents and prefabricated houses to view in person their current living situation.
Lee also gave them cash as a token of his concern.
The president told them that the government will do whatever it can to help them resolve their problems and reconstruct their homes.
Later in the afternoon, Lee visited victims in Chungliao Hsiang and Nantou City.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIFTER CHEN HSUEH-MEI SETS WOMEN'S WEIGHT-LIFTING RECORD
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, Northern Taiwan, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Chen Hsueh-mei, of Tainan County, set a new record for women's weight-lifting to win a gold medal on Sunday at the 1999 Taiwan National Games now being held in Taoyuan.

She lifted 100 kilograms in the clean and jerk to break the record of 97.5 kilograms set by Chu Nan-mei last July. In the snatch lift, she raised 75 kilograms to win the gold with a total of 175 kilograms.

Meanwhile, Chang Ming-huang, a senior high school student from Taichung County, won the gold in the discus competition with a 50.43-meter-throw to defeat senior athletes Lin Chung-tso, Yang Po-tsao and Wang Kuang-hui.
The 1999 National Games opened on Saturday at the Taoyuan County Stadium with President Lee Teng-hui in attendance.

Chang Ko-hsin, a teenager from Nantou County, captured the gold in the pole-vault event by clearing the 3.90-meter mark. She was followed by Kuan Mei-lian, also of Nantou County, who won the silver by surpassing a height of 3.7 meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FM SEES CHINA LIBERALIZING POLITICS, NOT UPPING ANTE IN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer predicted mainland China will have to liberalize its political system, and he believed current Taiwan-Strait tensions would not worsen, despite growing worry in the international community.

In an interview with a newspaper in Adelaide this week following his return from attending the handover ceremonies of Macau to China on Dec. 20, Downer said: "As China's economy liberalizes, as it becomes more engaged in the global economy, it will have no choice over the medium to long term but to progressively liberalize its political system.

"I don't think there is any reason to believe that tensions will automatically increase" in the Taiwan Strait. "There's an election in Taiwan up in the early part of next year and we'll have to see what happens in that election process. I don't just mean in terms of the actual outcome of the election, but how the campaign finally unfolds.

"And those sorts of issues are obviously sensitive issues both in Taipei itself and in Beijing. So there's unknown. And the second thing is that after election, you'll have a new administration in place, the existing president isn't going to be re-elected, isn't standing for re-election. You'll have a new administration in place and all of us will just have to wait and see what sort of approach that administration takes."

"So what could you say? That there's a certain amount of uncertainty, certainly, but an electoral process to go through in Taiwan," he said in an excerpt of the transcript faxed to CNA late Friday night.

Downer said the international community is gravely concerned about the current tensions between Taiwan and China and wanted to see both sides able to resolve their problems peacefully. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: SUMMARY OF RAND REPORT ON PRC ARMS SALES

TEXT.P: Communist China's arms sales pose a moderate threat to US interests, and further sales will make the future security environment more dangerous. Although Beijing's behavior is improving, continued pressure is necessary to minimize Communist China's most dangerous sales, particularly those to rogue regimes, according to a new report by the Rand Corporation in the United States.

The Rand report, titled "China's Arms Sales: Motivations and Implications," pointed out that Communist China has been, and can be, influenced by US pressure, although some level of sales is likely to continue. Thus, Washington must hedge against the likelihood of sales, developing offsets in concert with allies to minimize danger.

Communist China emerged as a major source of arms transfers in the 1980s, and by 1987 was the world's fourth largest seller of conventional arms, said the report. However, Chinese weapons sales diminished sharply after the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988, and demand for Communist Chinese weapons fell further after "Operation Desert Storm" dramatically demonstrated the superiority of Western high-tech weaponry over low-tech Chinese and Russian systems. The growing availability of cheap -- and more advanced -- Russian weapons also reduced demand for Chinese weapons.

Rand noted that as Communist China's conventional weapons sales began to taper off, it began transferring systems and technology that were much more worrisome: those associated with missiles and nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. The decisions to engage in such transfers had been made well before the slump in the demand for Chinese conventional arms, but these transactions did not begin to receive public attention until the late 1980s.

In 1988, US intelligence revealed that Communist China had sold nuclear-capable intermediate-range ballistic missiles to Saudi Arabia. This was followed by reports that Beijing was assisting ballistic missile programs in Iran and Pakistan.

Even more alarming was Communist China's assistance to several countries' nuclear, biological and chemical programs. The most extensive assistance was to Pakistan, where Beijing apparently provided Islamabad with both nuclear weapon designs and fissile material. Communist China also aided the nuclear programs of Iran and Algeria as well as Iran's chemical and biological weapons programs.

The level of Communist China's arms sales has fallen in recent years, and Beijing has shown restraint in its transfers to rogue states such as Iran and Iraq. In addition, Beijing has increased its adherence to international agreements regulating the sale and spread of dangerous arms, "although it is still not committed to the spirit of many of these agreements," said the Rand Corporation.

Six countries -- Pakistan, Iran, Iraq, North Korea, Myanmar and Thailand -- have been Communist China's primary arms transfer recipients since the 1980s, added the report. In general, strategic factors outweigh commercial ones with regard to Communist Chinese arms sales.

These sales represented a significant portion (roughly 7 percent) of mainland China's export earnings in the 1980s, but today they are only a small fraction of Communist China's total sales abroad. Many of Beijing's recent transfers were subsidized, and it has refrained from sales to possible foes, indicating that strategic concerns guided most arms sales.

The Rand Corporation stressed that regardless of US efforts to limit Communist China's arms sales, some transfers will inevitably occur. Most of Beijing's conventional weapons are unsophisticated and do not present a significant threat to the United States if transferred.

Of most concern are Communist China's transfers of technology related to nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and missiles. "Given the limitations on the US ability to stop these transfers, the US military in general, and the US Air Force in particular, must prepare for the possibility of future conflict with regional adversaries, such as Iran, who are armed with longer-range ballistic missiles and perhaps even nuclear or chemical weapons," concluded the report. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX UNDERGROUND CHURCH LEADERS SENT TO LABOR CAMP IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Six underground Christian church leaders in Nanyang city in Henan province of China were given last week without trial two to three years in labor camp on charges of "using evil religion" to hinder enforcement of law.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Sunday that the six were among the 40 religious leaders from Henan, who gathered together to discuss religious matters and were arrested during the meeting at the end of August. After being detained by police for four months, the six were sent to labor camp and the rest were fined up to 10,000 yuan renminbi (US$1,200).
The information center said this is a dangerous indication that the underground Christian churches in China, which have some 40 million worshipers, may be treated as "evil cults."
These underground churches and the so-called "patriotic churches" are differently treated in China. The former are Christian churches not sanctioned by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: `SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' RELATIONS SPELL OUT SOLID TRUTH: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of Taiwan's relationship with mainland China as a "special state-to-state" one explicitly states the true situation in the Taiwan Strait and is also a clear reflection of the opinion of most Taiwanese citizens, said government spokesman Chen Chien-jen on Monday.

The "special state-to-state" theory, the most explicit definition of cross Taiwan Strait relations to date, also helps Taiwan by providing a clearer status when dealing with other countries in the international diplomatic arena, Chen noted.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Chen, director-general of the Government Information Office, said Taiwan is prepared to return to the negotiating table with South Korea today if authorities in Seoul respect the two principles Taiwan insists on concerning resuming bilateral talks: mutual respect and reciprocity.
Taiwan and South Korea severed formal diplomatic relations nearly eight years ago.
To resume the bilateral aviation talks, Chen said, the two sides must first settle the content of an agreement before deciding which authorities should represent each side in signing the new accord.

In regard to Beijing's much-talked-about relations with the Vatican, Chen said he is positive that Beijing has not gained an inch over the past four months in its attempt to establish formal ties with the Holy See and to sabotage the Taipei-Vatican relationship.
Chen, however, promised legislators that he will keep a close watch on any new developments in relations between the Vatican and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC FACING NEW PRESSURE TO HIKE OIL PRICE

TEXT.P: An official of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said on Monday that the price of petroleum products will be adjusted according to market forces and will not be affected by political factors.
CPC President Pan Wen-yen made the remarks while responding to questions on whether to raise the prices of petroleum products in the wake of new pressure from rising world crude prices.
The CPC hiked its petroleum prices again earlier this month, basing its price on crude at US$19.5 per barrel and an exchange rate of NT$31.64 to one US dollar at the time.
Pan noted that world crude now stands at US$25 per barrel and that the CPC's petroleum price has not fully reflected the trend of rising world crude prices.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs has authorized the CPC to adopt a floating price system, but the adjustment will not exceed 6 percent within three months. As the CPC has raised its prices in November and December by nearly 6 percent, petroleum sources said the price of oil is not expected to go up in January.
But as Chinese New Year falls on February 5 and the upcoming presidential election is scheduled for March 18, Pan was asked if the CPC would suspend adjustments for a while due to political factors.

Pan said the floating price system will respect market forces and cut the influence of political factors. He noted that whether or not the CPC hikes oil prices in February will depend on a review of the cost of purchased petroleum and the company's revenue at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER HACKERS EXPECTED TO USE Y2K BUG AS A COVER

TEXT.P: Computer hackers are expected to create and release viruses under the cover of the Y2K bug during the New Year period, according to warnings from Australian authorities.
Federal Attorney General Daryl Williams and Senator Ian Campbell urged Australian consumers to beware of hacker attacks and viruses over the New Year period.
Campbell said he issued the warning after receiving advice from the US and "our own sources that hackers and virus makers will create and release viruses under the cover of the Y2K bug."
"It's an expectation based on previous experience," he said, adding that some viruses have been specifically written for Jan. 1, 2000.

Campbell pointed out that the W32/Mypics virus had been designed to reform a hard disk on January 1 while others, such as the W95.Babylonia virus, have already taken advantage of the paranoia that has come with talk of the millennium bug.
Many have been distributed disguised as program fixes for the date problem and some 24 viruses have already been detected with that theme, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAW FOOD DIET REDUCES CHOLESTEROL

TEXT.P: A growing new fad diet consisting only of raw foods has dethroned veganism as the most rigid diet in North America, while a new study has found that eating in this way actually reduces cholesterol to the same extent as cholesterol-reducing drugs, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported on Sunday.

"Living foods" enthusiasts' idea of trying to stay healthy by not eating any cooked foods has been around for decades, the CBC pointed out, but the message is just now catching on, with Web sites and books on how "not" to cook.

Bill Nasby frequents Super Sprouts, Canada's first store to promote raw foodism. Nasby, 72, used to tire easily and was overweight. He went on the raw food diet four months ago and soon lost 30 pounds and gained new energy, reported the CBC.
"With this type of diet, you're totally alive. It's unbelievable," said Nasby.

Catererer George Zuwala said raw foodists feel an energy boost because cooking kills enzymes in food that the body needs for digestion. "We take more energy to digest that food, and instead of doing whatever it is that we want to do, we're sitting there after a three or four-course meal, we're just kind of just dead."

Nutritionist Carol Greenwood of University of Toronto said the raw food concept is flawed, because only the body's enzymes break down food. She does agree that the diet is healthy, but doubts it will catch on.
"Just from that long-term perspective of palatability, it's unlikely that somebody would be on it for a long period of time," Greenwood added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESSNESS THE WORST PROBLEM IN EARTHQUAKE-STRICKEN AREAS

TEXT.P: Joblessness is expected to become the most serious problem in areas struck by the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake on Sept. 21, academician and social activist Chu Hai-yuan said on Monday.

Chu, a researcher with Taiwan's top research institute Academia Sinica and executive director of the National Alliance of Private Post-Disaster Rehabilitation Work, said the worst phenomenon in the earthquake-stricken areas to date is not that people are still living in tents in open fields during winter, but is the looming shroud of joblessness in the wake of the destruction.

Chu urged quick passage of the proposed "9-21 Earthquake Rehabilitation Draft" in the Legislative Yuan so as to provide a legitimate basis for the use and allocation of the huge amount of funds donated by people at home and abroad since the deadly jolt hit Taiwan.

But even if the draft is quickly passed into law, Chu noted that unemployment will still pose a problem in affected areas, adding that the people there do not feel they have been sufficiently taken care of by the government.

Many people have lost their jobs or their means of making living because of the earthquake and this has not only affected their financial situation but has also strained their family relations, Chu added.
Chu disclosed that the affected people are planning to demonstrate their grief and anger by busing to Taipei Wednesday to rally in front of the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
