Confucius lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: CNFI SELECTS EARTHQUAKE AS TOP TAIWAN NEWS OF 1999

TEXT.P: The devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake that struck Taiwan on Sept. 21 was selected as Taiwan's top news story in 1999 by the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) on Monday.

CNFI's Industry Magazine compiled the list of the top 10 news stories of 1999 in Taiwan after conducting a poll of industrial and business journalists from Taiwan's leading mass media from Dec. 5 to 20.

The Sept. 21 earthquake was voted the top news story of the year, as the temblor incurred more than NT$300 billion (US$9.49 billion) worth of property damage islandwide, which represented a 3.3-percent reduction in the country's gross national product (GNP) for 1999, according to a magazine spokesman.

The islandwide blackout on July 29 caused huge property damage to Taiwan's industrial sector, and President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of Taiwan's relationship with mainland China as a "special state-to-state" one were voted as the second- and third-most influential industrial news stories in Taiwan this year, the spokesman said.
The other news stories or events that were selected by the magazine, ranking from fourth to 10th were:
-- the arrival of the digital era and the prospects of e-commerce;
-- the pending accession to the World Trade Organization of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait;
-- the industrial sector being on full alert for the Y2K bug;
-- controversies triggered by the amended agricultural development bill;
-- the 2000 presidential election;
-- Taiwan Fertilizer Corp.'s financial scandal; and
-- the merger of two major stock brokerages.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES BASEBALL STAR SADAHARU OH

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Monday expressed his appreciation of Chinese-Japanese baseball star Sadaharu Oh for his active participation in quake-relief efforts after the devastating earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21.

Oh, currently head coach of Japan's Daiei Hawks baseball team, presented Lien with a check for 2 million Japanese yen (around US$19,600) to be added to quake-relief efforts. Oh previously donated autographed baseball uniforms and equipment for auction, and the proceeds have been used for the relief effort.
The vice president thanked Oh for his sympathy and generosity after the deadly temblor. He also congratulated the coach for leading his team to win the all-Japan championship in October.

Lien noted that more than 20 countries sent 37 rescue teams to take part in the rescue work after the earthquake, adding that their actions are the embodiment of love and good-Samaritan deeds and he has the deepest admiration for them.
Lien said that love transcends national borders, adding that Taiwan has sent rescue teams to Central and South America, Asia and Pacific and African countries.

"We are good neighbors in a global village," Lien said, adding that he led a team to Central America to help with sanitation, medical and health care work after the region was ravaged by hurricane Mitch last year.

Oh echoed Lien's words by saying that international cooperation is important, and that such actions will help resolve many problems. He said he felt sad about the heavy causalities following the Sept. 21 earthquake, which killed more than 2,400 people, adding that Japan is very concerned about the quake.
The owner of the Daiei Hawks had earlier donated 1 million Japanese yen for quake relief.

Oh, who arrived here last Wednesday for a weeklong stay, was accompanied by Chao Li-yun, chairperson of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, and by Chinese Taipei Baseball Association President Tom Peng for the visit to the vice president.
Oh called on President Lee Teng-hui last Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES SOAR 2.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed much higher Monday in the fifth consecutive session of gains as mid- and long-term investors rushed to buy technology shares amid bullish sentiment before the market closes Wednesday for year-end holiday.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 195.62 points, or 2.4 percent, higher at 8,415.07 on an expanded turnover of NT$189.59 billion (US$6.0 billion), with 3.48 billion shares changing hands.

Sentiment was boosted by widespread gains in stock markets worldwide on Friday, and investors were also encouraged by anticipation that there will be more foreign institutional buying before Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) raises Taiwan's weighting in its global indices.
MSCI is slated to raise Taiwan's stock weighting on its major indices from 50 percent to 100 percent in three phases starting in May 2000.

As the primary target for foreign institutional buying, electronics shares took the lead in the rally, posting 3.8-percent gains, but stocks of the conventional manufacturing industries, such as foodstuff issues and paper-making issues, failed to attracted investors' attention, and both reported losses.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 268 to 231, with 63 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 3.43 points to close at 204.93 on a turnover of NT$19.31 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted solid gains, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.
TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 231 points to close at 8,560 with 2,234 contract transactions. Those for February advanced 222 points to finish at 8,550 with 63 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 185 points to close at 8,575 with 27 contract transactions, while those for June climbed 171 points to finish at 8,602 with 11 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 8,329 points for January, 8,328 points for February, 8,390 points for March, 8,431 points for next June, and 8,500 points for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported gains.

January TE futures rose 22.85 points to close at 459.8 with 1,211 contract transactions; February TE futures gained 25.1 points to close at 456.1 with 23 contract transactions; March TE futures hiked 20 points to finish at 461 with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for TE futures for June or September.
January TF futures hiked 1.4 points to close at 963.2 with 160 contract transactions, and no transactions were recorded for TF futures for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AUSTRALIANS D0 INTERNET SHOPPING

TEXT.P: More and more Australians are going crazy about shopping via the Internet as they see it as a way of avoiding jostling with huge crowds at shopping centers or supermarkets during the holiday season.

Government-owned telecommunications giant -- Telstra Inc. -- has been flooded with retail subscribers and its Big Pond Internet service alone has exceeded 500,000 because more and more Australians are using the Internet to buy their daily necessities and other luxury products.

Another survey shows the number of Australians online was 2 million between July and September and the figure in December could surge to a record high as the number of people who use the Internet for shopping increases.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY SHIFT ITS DIPLOMATIC POLICY

TEXT.P: Beijing is considering putting a halt to spending huge sums of money on winning over Taipei's diplomatic allies, the Hong Kong Standard reported today.

Through such a truce, the mainland hopes to warm relations across the straits, paving the way for the resumption of dialogue with Taiwan, said the sources, adding that this largely depends on Taipei's response.

"In other words, if the ruling Kuomintang refuses to stop paying huge amounts of money under the auspices of aid to lure mainland diplomatic allies, Beijing will have to fight back", the report quoted the same sources as saying.

"On the other hand, Beijing has discovered that more work is needed in strengthening relations with leading countries which exert substantial influence in international affairs, such as the US, Japan, and members of the European Union."
According to the report, Beijing believes that its decades-long policy of focusing on improving ties with these key nations rather than the smaller, poorer nations works well.

"Certainly, Beijing could not refuse to talk to nations who wanted to switch recognition from Taipei to Beijing based on non-economic motivations, such as the widely anticipated formalization of diplomatic ties between Beijing and the Vatican," noted the report.
"For Beijing, forging diplomatic relations with the Holy See is, above all, an issue of religion and social stability that has little to do with any intent to isolate Taiwan," it said.

Besides, the report revealed that when the timing is good next year, Beijing hopes to resume the suspended talks between Wang Daohan of the semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu, head of the Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES UP BEFORE YEAR-END HOLIDAYS

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index climbed 33.77 points to close at 8,448.84 on an expanded turnover of NT$193.58 billion (US$6.3 billion), with 3.68 billion shares changing hands.
The year-end trading sentiment was relatively calm, in contrast to the typical emergence of heavy sales before long holidays, dealers said.

Among the eight major stock categories, cement stocks saw the largest gain of 3.4 percent, while financial and paper-making issues each rose 2.1 percent; foodstuff issues grew 0.3 percent; and construction shares posted a modest growth of 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemical stocks slid 0.8 percent, while textile issues declined 0.5 percent, and technology stocks moved down 0.2 percent.
Advancers led decliners 250 to 239, with 75 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 2.25 points to finish at 187.31 on a turnover of NT$18.73 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted slight gains, with the exception of September futures, for which no transactions were recorded.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 8,560 points for January, 8,550 points for February, 8,575 points for March, 8,602 points for next June, and 8,731 points for next September.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S NEW MISSILE BASE IN ZHANGZHOU POSES NO THREAT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday that mainland China's new missile base in Zhangzhou in its southeastern province of Fujian is not expected to pose a substantive threat to Taiwan's security.

Quoting military intelligence reports, MND spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding said mainland China will mainly deploy its indigenous Hungqi (Redflag) No. 2 surface-to-air missiles and Russian-made S-300 surface-to-air missiles at the new base.
According to Kung, the S-300 missile has a range of 90 km, while the mainland-made Hungqi No. 2 has a range of about 30 km.

The Washington Times reported on Dec. 22 that a US spy satellite had detected in late November that mainland China was constructing an air-defense missile base in Zhangzhou, which is located opposite Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait.

US intelligence officers further said the base is scheduled to be inaugurated in the coming spring. However, they added that they still could not ascertain which types of missiles will be deployed there.

Noting that Zhangzhou is one of mainland China's most important air bases, Kung said the mainland air force has long deployed J-8 jet fighters for reconnaissance missions at the Zhangzhou base. In recent years, Kung said, the mainland military has also deployed 24 fighter-bombers and six J-7 jet fighters at Zhangzhou.
Against this background, Kung said the MND has concluded that the main purpose of the new missile base is to better protect the existing Zhangzhou facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE TO ALLOW QUOTAS ON US IMPORTED LIVESTOCK

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to allow the import of livestock from the United States next year before it enters the World Trade Organization (WTO), a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said on Tuesday.

As part of its efforts to secure WTO entry, Taiwan agreed to allow a "down payment system," under which the import of 10,000 tons of chicken, 5,000 tons of pork belly, and 7,500 tons each of pork and beef offal would be permitted from June 1, 1998.
COA Chairman Ling Shiang-nung said the quotas for the United States, as well as similar global quotas for WTO members other than the United States, will stand next year.

The COA announced on May 13 this year that it would give WTO members other than the United States accumulated quotas of 9,163 tons of chicken and 1,160 tons of pork belly to further facilitate its efforts to join the world trade regulatory organization.
The COA promised that the implementation of the global quota will last until the end of the year, when it will be reviewed.
Ling noted that the total quotas are equal to the amount Taiwan promises to open its market to other countries in its first year of WTO membership.

Ling said that the quota system actually allows domestic industry to face the pressure of international competition earlier so that they have the opportunity to make the adjustments needed to cope with WTO membership.
He also said that if the system is scrapped suddenly, and imports shrink, it will also throw the local livestock industry into disarray.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCHANGES CAN DEVELOP CONSTRUCTIVE CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that the government hopes to step up exchanges and dialogues with mainland China based on equality and mutual respect.
He also said that both sides could discuss any issues, including political issues, so that two sides across the Taiwan Strait can develop a constructive relationship.
Siew made the remarks during a report to the members of the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, who were making their annual rounds of the government agencies.
Siew reported on the major tasks of his Cabinet over the past year, including the restructuring of the government, or the downsizing of the provincial government.

He also described the Cabinet's efforts to overcome the Asian financial storm, noting that the nation has shed the influence of the regional financial storm since the second quarter of this year, with a dramatic increase in exports.
Taiwan's exports in the first eight months totaled US$78.1 billion, up 7 percent from the same period of last year, the best performance among the four Asian dragons.

Export orders in August totaled US$10.95 billion, up 9.73 percent from the same period of last year, or the sixth consecutive month orders have topped US$10 billion, making it the prime mover behind the country's economic growth, Siew said.

The government is also doing its best to improve social order, and has engaged in campaigns to crack down on gangsters, guns, drugs and robberies, and bringing down the number of reported criminal cases in the first 10 months from the corresponding period of last year.

In addition, the government is also dedicated to caring for children, teenagers, women, aboriginal people, the elderly, laborers, farmers and fishermen, low-income households, the disabled, and residents of Taiwan's offshore islands, Siew said.
The premier said the government plans to earmark NT$157 billion over the next five years to promote educational reform.

In addition, he said, the government will pursue peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, but will step up national defense to ensure the survival of the nation and actively promote diplomatic relations.
He said that the government has made its top priority respecting historical facts and ensuring the continued existence of the nation and the welfare of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF TO ISSUE NT$150 BILLION IN BONDS IN FIRST QUARTER OF 2000

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance plans to issue NT$150 billion worth of bonds during the January-March period of 2000, a spokesman for the MOF said on Tuesday.
The first NT$50 billion in bonds will be formally issued on Jan. 18, with a 20-year period of maturity.
The second NT$50 billion worth will be issued Feb. 15, with a seven-year maturity period.
The remainder will be issued on March 14, with a maturity period of 15 years.
The ministry is also scheduled to pay the principal on bonds totaling NT$40 billion on Feb. 18, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF EXPLAINS TAIWAN'S MACAU OFFICE NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan renamed its representative office in Macau to serve the interests of both Taiwan, Macau and mainland China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said on Tuesday.

On the first day of Macau's Taipei Trade and Tourism Office operations under its new name of Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau, Su told a group of legislators that the renaming has upgraded the office to the level of a visa-issuing center in the former Portuguese enclave.
From now on, Su said, foreigners, mainland Chinese and residents of Macau will be able to apply to the renamed office for travel documents to Taiwan.

As for Taipei's representative to Macau William Li, who has been reprimanded for covering the office's nameplate before Macau was handed over to Beijing on Sept. 19, he will remain in his job because of his familiarity with the situation in Macau and his good connections with the people there.
Li was recalled by Taipei to explain his decision to cover the plate, a move which was criticized at home as self-demeaning for the sake of wooing the Macau authorities.
Macau had asked Taipei to change the name of the office and play down its official overtones before Dec. 20.
Su also called on Beijing to shift away from its advocacy of the "one country, two systems" formula as a way of reunifying with Taiwan.

Citing a candidate who came out in favor of the formula during Taiwan's 1998 legislative elections and got only about 1,000 votes, Su said "one country two systems" is totally unacceptable to the Taiwan people.
Beijing's adherence to the formula will only further alienate the Taiwan people, said Su.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCTOBER BUSINESS TURNOVER INCREASES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs on Tuesday released statistics showing that Taiwan's total business turnover in October amounted to NT$656.9 billion (US$20.53 billion), an increase of 9.28 percent compared to the previous month.
The international trade sector shared the largest growth of 12.03 percent, followed by the food and restaurant sector with 10.04 percent growth.

Business turnover in the first 10 months of 1999 accumulated to NT$6,486.3 billion (US$180.18 billion), a rise of 9.04 percent compared with the corresponding period of last year, with the international trade sector sharing the largest gain of 11.04 percent, followed by the food and restaurant sector with 10.99 percent growth.
The retail and wholesale sectors also saw 9.14 percent and 5.71 percent growth, respectively.

October business turnover in the wholesale sector totaled NT$151 billion, growing 5.76 percent from the same period of a year earlier, with the petrochemical industry, boosted by the growth of international crude oil prices, enjoying the largest increase of 20.13 percent.
The retail sector (including the general merchandise retailing sector) had October turnover of NT$247.7 billion, an increase of 8.85 percent over the same period of 1998.
The general merchandise retail sector's business volume totaled NT$43 billion, a rise of 7.69 percent over the year-earlier level, but a drop of 0.26 percent compared with the previous month.
Business turnover in the international trade sector accumulated to NT$239.3 billion, up 12.03 percent compared with the year-earlier level, and down 2.54 percent compared with the previous month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC FIND CORRUPTION, GANG-LINKED POLITICS MOST DISGUSTING: POLL

TEXT.P: One in four people in Taiwan has complained that rampant official corruption and gang-linked politics have made them feel ashamed or unable to take pride in living in Taiwan, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Tuesday.

The telephone poll of 1,112 adults conducted by the CommonWealth magazine between Dec. 9 and Dec. 14, found that nearly 25 percent of those interviewed cited "money- and gang-linked politics" as Taiwan's most serious drawback that makes them feel ashamed to live on the island.
The survey results also show that the majority of the respondents feel the government's most urgent tasks are to crack down on organized crime and improve public order.

This is the first time since 1996 that the monthly business magazine's annual state-of-the-nation survey has found that improvement of public order has replaced educational reforms or economic development as the thing that members of the general public most want the government to tackle immediately.
Analyzing the results, the magazine said many local people feel that Taiwan's public order has worsened over the past four years.

Worse yet, the magazine said, many people are worrying about the phenomenon whereby criminal ring members manage to win seats in law-making bodies at national or local levels and then abuse their status to gain windfalls or illegal profits.
Quoting the poll results, the magazine said many local people fret that the situation might have distorted the direction of Taiwan's political development.
One of the most adverse impacts on local society of "money- and gang-linked politics" is the widening of the gap between the rich and the poor, according to the poll.

About 60 percent of the respondents cited "money- and gang-linked politics" as the No. 1 reason behind the widening wealth gap in local society. Other reasons mentioned by those interviewed included stock speculation, unfair taxation policy and land speculation.

Meanwhile, 68.5 percent said the president and Cabinet members should be held responsible for the widening wealth gap, and 60 percent said legislators and county and city councilors should also be blamed.
Asked to name their top expectation of the new millennium, many respondents said "a safe, secure living environment" is their most fervent hope.
The poll also found that public order, personal/family livelihood, and political stability are the respondents' top three concerns.
The survey results further show that local people are more concerned about domestic reforms than diplomatic affairs and relations across the Taiwan Strait.

The government's eight most urgent tasks as cited by the respondents are: cracking down on organized crime; improving educational quality; beefing up economic strength; upgrading administrative efficiency; wiping out corruption; strengthening defense capabilities; improving cross-strait relations; and enhancing international status, in that order.
Meanwhile, more than 60 percent said they do not think that the country's existing judicial system is fair and just enough to safeguard social justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHINKANSEN MAY EDGE OUT EURO-CONSORTIUM TO WIN TAIWAN RAIL CONTRACT

TEXT.P: Japan's Shinkansen may come from behind to win the contract from the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) to build Taiwan's first high-speed railway, industrial sources said on Tuesday.

THSRC officials announced that the corporation has decided to give up plans to cooperate with the Eurotrain Consortium to build the high-speed railway system, choosing instead Shinkansen as the "first priority for negotiation."

The Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC) will be given priority consideration for the building of core systems of the multi-billion dollar bullet train, including carriages, locomotives, power supply and overhead container systems, transmission systems, signals and telecommunications systems, according to THSRC General Manager Liu Kuo-chih.

TSC is a business consortium of leading Japanese firms including Mitsui & Co., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Toshiba Corp. The consortium has become more aggressive since last year as a rival to compete with Eurotrain for the project.
Liu said the decision to give up Eurotrain was made solely out of consideration of business clauses and technical assessments, and he denied that the change was the result of any political influence.

Upon hearing of the THSRC decision to seek partners other than Eurotrain, Ambroise Cariou, vice president of Eurotrain's Taiwan high-speed rail project, said the news took him by surprise and that he is deeply disappointed with the development.
Cariou noted that Eurotrain has been working with THSRC for three years on the project, and said that THSRC has done a u-turn by opting for Shinkansen.
However, he took the blow like a gentleman, saying that Eurotrain respects any decision that is made by THSRC.

Announcing that the TSC is now considered the first priority for negotiation, Liu said the TSC has demonstrated greater flexibility in coping with schedules of land development and construction of the railway and depots. TSC also promised after-sales service commitment, and the telecommunications systems to be installed on the high-speed rail system will better cope with THSRC demands, he added.

Liu added that choosing the first priority for negotiation does not necessarily mean that the decision is final. A formal contract will not be signed until certain important business clauses and technical details are settled and mutually recognized, he said.

New rounds of negotiations between THSRC and TSC are expected to begin in mid-January, Lin said, adding that if the negotiations do not mature into formal agreement in a few months, THSRC will turn to the "second priority" for talks.
Trains traveling on the envisaged high-speed railway will operate at a maximum speed of 300 kilometers per hour and will shuttle passengers from Taipei to Kaohsiung in 90 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PUBLIC TV TO LINK UP WITH WORLD NETWORKS FOR `2000 TODAY'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's public television network will be linking up with other television networks around the world to jointly broadcast events and celebrations showing how people around the globe meet the first dawn of the new millennium.

Beginning at 5:30 p.m. on Dec. 31, Chinese Public Television (CPT) will field five pairs of hosts to join counterparts from 74 television channels in 70 countries in five continents for a 25-hour marathon-style broadcast to witness the turn of the century and the dawning of the new millennium.

The worldwide link up, to be presented in a relay manner and titled "2000 Today," has been planned jointly since 1997 by British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) and the Boston public television station WGBH.

The Taiwan part of the activities, to be shown in the seventh and 13th hours of the program, will be a sky-lantern festival to be held in the mountainuous township of Pingshi in Taipei County, and a ritual dance to be offered by aboriginal performers in eastern Hualien County, according to CPT officials.

"2000 Today" is a US$600 million production with input from more than 2,000 producers, 1,200 performing groups, 1,000 cameras and 37 helicopters around the world. More than 2,300 people will be working on the program in the Taiwan area alone, said the CPT officials.
More than 2 billion people around the world are expected to be watching the program at the countdown of the new millennium, marking the greatest television show ever made.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSE SHARES TRANSACTIONS TOTAL NT$2.93 TRILLION IN 1999

TEXT.P: Share transactions at the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) in 1999 totaled NT$2.93 trillion, a decrease of NT$141.84 billion in comparison with the year-earlier level, according to TSE statistics.
TSE officials said that a total of 677.46 billion shares changed hands on the market, with daily transactions averaging out at about NT$110.8 billion.
In terms of volume, transactions increased by 736.9 billion shares, while the worth decreased by NT$141.84 billion as of Dec. 28, in comparison with the same period of last year.
The largest transaction value in a single day was recorded on June 23, amounting to NT$230.8 billion, while the lowest -- NT$10.84 billion -- was recorded on Sept. 27.
The highest closing index was on June 22, when the weighted price index closed at 8,608.91 points, while the lowest price index was on Feb. 5, when the weighted price index closed at 5,474.79 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA URGED TO CONTROL NUMBER OF FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: A group of aboriginal legislators on Tuesday urged the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to pay attention to the squeezing out of aboriginal workers from the local job market by foreign laborers.

Yang Jen-fu, a ruling Kuomintang legislator elected from aboriginal communities on plains, said the number of legally imported foreign laborers has increased steadily since incumbent CLA Chairman Chan Hou-sheng assumed the top labor administrative post on Feb. 5, 1998.
On the other hand, Yang said, the jobless rate of aborigines has continued rising to record highs.

By the end of this year, Yang said, the number of legally imported foreign workers will approach 300,000, while the aboriginal unemployment rate will reach 7.55 percent, up 3 percent from the year-earlier level.
This year's aboriginal jobless rate will also more than double the nation's average unemployment rate of 3.22 percent, Yang said.
Yang made the remarks during a meeting with CLA Vice Chairman Wang San-chung, Aboriginal Affairs Commission Vice Chairman Chung Fu-shanand several other aboriginal legislators.
Speaking on the same occasion, another aboriginal legislator, Lin Cheng-er said the aboriginal workers' average working day has declined from 20 days a month to only 12 days.

"The unemployment issue among aborigines has become very serious," Lin warned, adding that if the number of illegal foreign workers is taken into consideration, the total number of foreign nationals in the domestic job market should reach about 600,000.
Against this backdrop, Lin said it has become increasingly difficult for aboriginal youths to land jobs.
Lin blamed the CLA for failing to control the number of blue-collar foreign laborers and the kinds of enterprises to be allowed to recruit foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COUNTY INTENDING TO FORGE SISTER TIES WITH TURKISH CITY

TEXT.P: Nantou County, the epicenter of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, intends to enter a sisterhood relationship with Alanya, a sightseeing city in southern Turkey.
A Nantou County government official said on Tuesday that Alanya is seeking to establish sister ties with a suitable Taiwan city or county.
Because Nantou is well-known as a sightseeing destination, he said, the county government believes a sister relationship arrangement with Alanya will be helpful for the two sides to promote tourism.
The official acknowledged that the Nantou County government has expressed its desire to the Republic of China Interior Ministry for approval.
Like Taiwan, Turkey was also stricken by strong earthquakes recently. Both sides extended assistance to the other side, bringing them closer together.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS SENT TO LABOR CAMP IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Four practitioners of Falun Gong in Dalian city in the northeastern Chinese province of Liaoning have recently been sent to labor camps for reeducation after they posted on the internet pictures and stories about police mistreatment of them.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Tuesday that Zhang Chunqing, a college girl student, was detained by police for 15 days in September for practicing Falun Gong in public. She was forced to walk with 10-kilogram shackles on her feet, after she was found practicing Falun Gong even in the detention center.

After her release, she posted on the internet pictures of her ankles which were injured during her detention, as well as stories of her sad experience in the detention center. The pictures were used by certain human rights groups in their recent petitions to the United Nations Human Rights Commission. As a result, she was given last week three years in labor camp by the public security authorities of Dalian city, the information center said.
Three other Falun Gong members in the city -- Liang Qing, Li Duo, and Sha Yusung-- were also sent to labor camps last week because they recently posted on the internet police mistreatment of them.
The four Falun Gong members are being kept in three "education through labor camps" in the city, the information center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CALLS FOR EXCHANGES BETWEEN TAIWAN AND MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Tuesday called on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to promote exchanges on the basis of mutual benefit, peace, equity, and rationality, saying both sides care about the development of cross-strait relations.

Lien said there is no reason that Taiwan and mainland China should threaten each other with military force. He reiterated that Taiwan will not seek independence, but "will never accept Beijing's description of Taipei as a local government of mainland China."
The vice president made the remarks in a meeting with representatives of the Kinmen Women's Association.

Speaking of efforts to develop the front-line island stronghold, Lien recalled that in his former tenure as premier which began in 1993, he launched a 10-project construction program with a total value of NT$5 billion (US$158.73 million) on the island, which was in 1992 released from military administration.

In July, the central government expanded Kinmen's development plan and injected another NT$19.56 billion, Lien noted, adding that the offshore island has sacrificed its urban development for Taiwan's safety for nearly fifty years.
Now, as the hostility fades in the face of the promotion of mutual cross-strait understanding, the government should start repaying Kinmen, Lien said.
Building Kinmen into the most beautiful ocean-surrounded park in the Taiwan Strait region should be "our joint prospect and a goal to fight for," Lien added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF BRANCH OFFICE TO BENEFIT SOUTHERN RESIDENTS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The establishment of a southern area branch office of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) was done to expand services to people in the south of Taiwan and has nothing to do with politics, SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow said on Tuesday.
Shi said that ever since its establishment in 1983, the semi-official body in charge of contact with mainland China has served as a bridge between Taiwan and the mainland.

He dismissed speculation that the office was set up based on political considerations, and noted that it will handle only business matters such as notarizing documents and providing consultation services on cultural, economic and trade, legal and tourism interchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
The newly established office is located on the Kaohsiung City premises of the Southern Service Center of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL RECORDS CONTINUE TO CRASH AT TAIWAN GAMES

TEXT.P: Six new national records were set on Tuesday, the fourth day of the Taiwan National Games now being held at Taoyuan County Stadium.
Hsu Yu-feng of Taipei County won gold in the women's 5,000 meters with a time of 17.11.84 to break the previous record of 17.13.33 held by Wu Hsiao-chiu of Penghu County.

Weightlifters Weng Chen-yen of Pintung County and Chiang Ming-cheng of Taipei City smashed the record held by Weng for the men's 94 kg division, with lifts of 152.5 kg and 155 kg, respectively, in the snatch.
Wu Mei-yi and Kuo Yi-han also broke the snatch record in the women's 75 kg division with lifts of 133.5 kg and 135 kg, respectively.
In swimming, Huang Chi-yung of Kaohsiung City won gold in the men's 100 meter freestyle with a time of 52.02 seconds to break the national record of 52.07.
Tseng Cheng-hua of Taichung County, rewrote the record in the men's 100 meter back stroke with a time of 59.36.
By the end of Tuesday's competition, the organizing committee had awarded 189 golds, 188 silvers and 219 bronze medals.
Taipei County topped the list of gold-winners with 34, followed by Taoyuan County with 32 and Kaohsiung City trailing with 15.
The games opened on Dec. 25 and will close on Dec. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR PREDICTED TO MOVE BETWEEN 31 AND 32 AGAINST US DOLLAR

TEXT.P: Pressure to drive down the new Taiwan dollar will ease next year, the Central Trust of China (CTC) said on Tuesday, predicting that the currency will fluctuate between 31 and 32 against the greenback.
The NT dollar closed at 31.052 against the US unit at the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, which will close on Wednesday for the New Year holiday.
The CTC said in a press release that the NT dollar's value against the greenback peaked at 31.45 and had a low of 33.257 in 1999.

Citing the island's booming exports and the continuous inflow of foreign capital, the CTC predicted that the local currency will rise slightly in the next year, unless non-economic factors interfere with the course of events.

Given that Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan has vowed not to sit on the sidelines if an inflow of hot cash starts to influence the rate of the NT dollar, the CTC said it is unlikely that the unit will rise or fall sharply against the greenback in the next year, providing uncertainty over Taiwan's ties with mainland China do not interrupt normal patterns.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANDLING OF QUAKE DEBRIS TO COST NT$2.3 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) estimated on Tuesday that the disposal of the debris caused by the Sept. 21 earthquake will cost NT$2.3 billion (US$71.88 million).

According to the EPA, the debris from buildings destroyed or rendered too dangerous for habitation by the quake will amount to some 25 million metric tons, and the cost of handling the material will be appropriated from the disaster-relief fund.
So far, about 26,000 destroyed or dangerous buildings of less than four stories have been dismantled by the army.
About 120 high-rise buildings and over 5,000 other apartment complexes higher than four stories are to be dismantled by other government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DISMISSES `ROTATING RULE' OR 'NON-PARTISAN GOVERNMENT'

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday dismissed the ideas of "rotation of rule among political parties," or "a non-partisan government" as unrealistic.

Lee, who is also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, told a group local KMT branch chiefs that Taiwan's politics are not fully mature, and that no political party other that the KMT can be entrusted with the task of ruling the country.

He dismissed the advocacy by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party of a system of alternating ruling parties as "impractical," and he also lambasted a promise by independent presidential candidate James Soong to form a non-partisan coalition as "unfeasible."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang describes independent presidential candidate James Soong's latest press conference as just another self-directed 'talk show,' failing to clarify sources of his 'mystery funds.'
The China Times:
Soong holds two-hour-long press conference to reveal details of financial transactions in his relatives' accounts.
The United Daily News:
Soong admits to have use gubernatorial campaign funds to help finance some provincial assembly hopefuls' campaign activities.
The Liberty Times:
The Industrial Upgrade Promotion Act, which offers tax credits and other special benefits for certain strategic industries, will be extended for at least a decade.
The China Post:
Soong, lawmaker detail money trail.
The Taiwan News:
Soong, KMT at odds once more on funds.
The Taipei Times:
Soong makes another appeal to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING BOAT DISAPPEARS AFTER PICKING UP M'LAND WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Suao-based Taiwanese fishing boat "Hsin Hung Hsiang No. 1" has been missing for 10 days since it disappeared Dec. 18 after sailing to Xiamen to pick up mainland Chinese fishermen to work on board, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Wednesday.
The last time "Hsin Hung Hsiang No. 1" was heard from was on the evening of Dec. 18, a couple of hours after it picked up the 36 mainland workers and was on its way back home via the Taiwan Strait.

The location of the fishing boat, with its four Taiwanese crew members and 36 mainland workers, was roughly 60 nautical miles west of the offshore island of Penghu when last heard from, according to officials from the COA's Fisheries Department.

According to the officials, the Taiwanese owners of the fishing boat said they do not know the whereabouts of the boat and that they hope relevant government agencies will assist in tracing the location of the boat.
However, the families of the four Taiwanese crewmen, including skipper Chen Ke-ming and head mechanic Chen Yao-kun, on Wednesday expressed their anger toward the boat owners.

They condemned the boat owners for lying, saying that they were informed on Tuesday by families of the mainland fishermen that the "Hsin Hung Hsiang No. 1" capsized in the Taiwan Strait on Dec. 18 and all the people on board were killed.

Meanwhile, COA officials said they wrote a formal letter to the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Wednesday, asking the Taipei-based intermediary body to contact its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), for concerted efforts in finding the missing fishing boat.
SEF and ARATS, both quasi-official organizations, were authorized by their respective governments to handle civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal contacts.

Fishing sources in Penghu said the disappearance of the "Hsin Hung Hsiang No. 1" is surrounded in mystery, noting that if the fishing boat did sink, remains of the wreckage or related debris should have been found floating on nearby surface waters. But Penghu fishing boats so far haven't found anything up to Tuesday.
The fishing sources said the boat may have been confiscated by the mainland's public security authorities or may have been hijacked by unknown vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TAIWAN FIRMS ON FORBES `MOST WORTHY STOCKS' LIST
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 28 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese firms were included on Forbes magazine's list of "the most worthy listed companies around the world to invest in," sources from the magazine said on Tuesday.
The three Taiwanese firms chosen by Forbes as the most worthy listed companies in Taiwan were United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), Acer Ltd., and Nanya Plastics.
In its assessment of the world's A-class manufacturing companies, the Forbes report surveyed 27 categories of different industries.

UMC, a chip maker, ranked as the 10th best in the Forbes high-tech category, but its growth of unit stock dividend is expected to top a whopping 166.4 percent next year, far higher than any other company in the world in this category. UMC's current market value is about US$199.39 billion.
Taiwan's computer giant Acer, its current market value totaling about US$7.8 billion, is expected by Forbes to have a unit stock dividend growth of 25.5 percent next year.

Nanya Plastics, meanwhile, ranked third in the world's chemical manufacturing category, and is expected to post a unit stock dividend growth of 31 percent in 2000. Nanya's current market value is around US$9.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 29, or the 22nd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1170: Thomas Becket, archbishop of Canterbury, is murdered by four of King Henry II's knights at the altar of Canterbury Cathedral in England.
1503: Spain conquers Naples.
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1860: The "Warrior," the world's first true ironclad warship, is launched at Blackwall on the River Thames.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang, pledges allegiance to the national government, which leads to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan, and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1965: Ho Chi Minh, president of North Vietnam, rejects a US offer of unconditional peace talks.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Chinese Communists, is inaugurated.
1973: Costa Rica's Labor Minister Francisco Morales Hernandez arrives in Taipei for a 12-day visit.
1973: Fernando Ricardo, new Colombian charge d'affaires in Taipei, arrives.
1973: An 18-member Chinese ski team leaves for Innsbruck, Austria, for a month of training.
1974: Jose Leido, the Philippines minister for natural resources, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives visiting Greek Congressman Georgios Vasilio Mangakis.
1976: A two-week telecommunications exhibition opens at the Taiwan Communications Administration Building.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: US President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general election.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese boat people battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC air force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict bringing Central America's last and longest civil war to a close.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL FACE 5 CRISES IN 21ST CENTURY: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will face five crises in the 21st century, independent presidential candidate Hsu Hsin-liang warned on Wednesday.

Hsu, a former chairman of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who quit the party in May to run in the 2000 presidential election, told a news conference that the first crisis Taiwan will face is a military conflict across the Taiwan Strait.

"My observation is that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are very likely to engage in a full-blown military confrontation in the new millennium because of their failure to conduct rational, peaceful dialogue, plus irresponsible political provocation," Hsu explained.
The second crisis, he went on, will be the loss of many traditional industries because of economic globalization.

Hsu predicted that many of Taiwan's traditional industries, which have little global competitiveness, will be edged out following the island's entry into the World Trade Organization, a Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

"The demise of such traditional industries will not only bring economic problems but may also trigger a series of social problems due to decreased job opportunities and a rising unemployment rate," Hsu noted.

Third, Hsu said, Taiwan will face a crisis of ethnic conflict. According to Hsu, Taiwan originally had no ethnic hatred problems. However, he said Taiwan's three major political parties -- the ruling Kuomintang, the pro-independence DPP and the pro-unification New Party -- have been formed along an ethnic bias.

"Ethnic sentiment has repeatedly been stirred up in every political election of the past decade," Hsu said, adding that he believes the same will happen in the presidential election scheduled for March 18, 2000.
"Unless we manage to form a new political party based on a wide social spectrum, the potential ethnic conflict crisis cannot be resolved," Hsu claimed.
Taiwan's fourth crisis, he continued, lies in the fact that news stories will come to overshadow local people's everyday lives.

"News should have a shelf life of only one day. However, in Taiwan, all people live their lives guided by news stories," Hsu lamented, adding that most of Taiwan's active political figures lack a genuine, lasting concern for the island's sustainable well-being and development.

The fifth crisis Taiwan will face lies in the loss of national identity and values. "Except for ethnic identification, there are many other values-related issues worth considering. However, politicization of ethnic issues has left little room for local people to think about other values-related subjects," he noted.

In fact, Hsu said, the root cause of the first three crises lies in ethnic hatred, which he said mainly results from major local political parties' irresponsible abuse of ethnic sentiment as an electoral campaign tactic.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER EDUCATION MINISTER DIES

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Minister of Education Lin Ching-jiang died on Wednesday of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
Lin assumed the post of education minister in February 1998, but resigned in June the following year due to deteriorating health after doctors discovered that he was suffering from a brain tumor.
Last October, Lin checked in to a local hospital to undergo surgery after the tumor began to affect the movement of his right leg.
Lin, born in 1940 in central Taiwan's Yunlin County, graduated from National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) and had a doctoral degree from Britain's University of Liverpool.

Before his resignation, Lin had been a NTNU professor, president of National Kaohsiung Teachers' College, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Department of Education, president of National Chung Cheng University, a member of the Examination Yuan, director of the higher education department of the Ministry of Education, and vice minister of education.

During his tenure as education minister, Lin drew a concrete and detailed blueprint for promoting educational reforms, including plans to abolish the yearly high school entrance examination by the 2001 academic year.
His performance and his efforts to build Taiwan into a "learning society" earned Lin the unofficial title of Taiwan's "engineer" of educational reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 ANOTHER BANNER YEAR FOR HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED PARK
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, home to many of Taiwan's most successful high-tech companies, witnessed another banner year in 1999, park administration sources said on Wednesday.
The park's total production is expected to top NT$600 billion (US$18.99 billion) in 1999, up a whopping 50 percent over last year's NT$400 billion, said park administrator Huang Wen-hsiung.

The Hsinchu park, a collection of 290 high-tech factories that have been an engine of Taiwan's economic growth for 15 years, stunned the world this year by remaining relatively unscathed by an islandwide power blackout on July 29 and the devastating 7.3-magnitude earthquake that struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, Huang noted.
He quoted park tallies as showing that business turnover at the park totaled NT$507.5 billion in the first 10 months of this year with a workforce of 79,000 persons.
It is estimated that the annual turnover will break the NT$600 billion mark for the whole of 1999, with the workforce increasing to 80,000 people.

With investment in the Hsinchu companies continuing to expand, the park's overall production is expected to grow by between 25 percent and 30 percent to reach NT$780 billion in the year 2000, with the workforce growing to 85,000 persons.

Huang said he is confident that the park's business will continue to pick up steam next year. Meanwhile, he added, efforts will be made to develop the park into a "town of culture" as well, beginning with efforts to conserve the environment and improve neighborhood relations.
