DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF OUTBOUND TOURISTS LIKELY TO SET NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan's outbound tourists in 1999 is expected to hit around 6.5 million, as the figure for the first 11 months of the year has already surpassed 6 million, according to statistics released on Wednesday by the Tourism Bureau.

Since the figure posted during the period from January to November has already overtaken the level of 6.16 million registered for the whole of 1998, bureau officials said they expect the 1999 total to set a record high, especially as another wave of outbound tourists is evident in the run up to the start of the new millennium.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST INTERNATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS MEETINGS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taipei is scheduled to host three international communications meetings next year.
The 18th Asian Council for the Facilitation of Procedures and Practices for Administration, Commerce and Transport (AFACT) will be held in Taipei from Sept. 11-15, 2000.
Taiwan was admitted as a full member of AFACT last April at a meeting held in Singapore. Prior to its admittance as a full member, Taiwan was an associate member of the council.

A seminar on electronic and digital commerce will also be held in conjunction with the AFACT meeting, an official of the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said.
Another global meeting on electronic commerce under the joint sponsorship of Taiwan and the United Nations-related institute will be held in Taipei on Sept. 4-8, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE RELEASES ADMINISTRATION BLUEPRINT

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday released his administration blueprint titled "Rebuilding the Government," aimed at constructing an efficient government for Taiwan.
Accompanied by his running mate Annette Lu, the presidential hopeful said at a press conference that rebuilding the government is a prerequisite for any other national reforms.

Chen said that he has set out five goals which the ideal government should strive for: to be able to respond to the people's demands; to be competitive; to be efficient; to be flexible; and to be always ready to learn.
Under the goals, he said, he hopes to rebuild the central government into an administration which is full of energy and worthy of the people's trust.

In addition, the former Taipei mayor said he believes the existing government structure should be further simplified, and suggested a two-level government mechanism of central government with county and municipality governments.

The planned central government should be granted the right of legislature, the right to formulate national development and construction projects, and the right to adjust and monitor local autonomy, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA NERVOUS CLEARING Y2K HURDLE

TEXT.P: Despite the huge amount of money spent and the enormous advanced efforts made on fixing any potential millennium bug problems, Australia remains nervous about clearing the Y2K hurdle as it will be one of the first countries to enter the new year, according to the National Coordination Center (NCC).

Senator Ian Campbell, who is in charge of all Y2K-related matters for the Australian government, described his feelings heading into the new year as "slightly anxious but mostly fascinated," while playing down any suggestions of an emergency.
"I think we'll get there, but I'd be lying if I didn't say there's a bit of anxiety around," he told reporters on Tuesday.
Businesses, state governments and federal agencies will report any Y2K problems to the NCC, which will then pass the information on to Campbell who will inform the public and react accordingly.

Campbell is expected to spend much of the time from December 31 to January 7 answering international media queries about Y2K problems and giving reassurances about the dependability of Australia as a responsible financial center.
The government will increase the number of staff, especially computer experts, on standby during the new year period to deal with any problems that may arise.
Australia, among the countries with the largest number of computers, has spent tens of millions of dollars on millennium bug preparedness.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN MOST POPULAR DESTINATION FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS: POLL

TEXT.P: Japan and Tokyo remain the favorite foreign country and city visited by Taiwan tourists, according to the results of a recent survey.

In addition to Japan, New Zealand was named on the list of the top ten most popular countries for the first time, while Singapore, Kyoto, Hong Kong, San Francisco, Paris, Vancouver, Venice and New York were among the leading ten most popular cities, the poll conducted by tourist magazine To Go found.

Despite the fact that Japan and Tokyo were polled as the best foreign country and city ever visited by Taiwan people, Western countries and cities made up more than half of the top ten spots on the two lists.
While Canada was selected as the country which most tourists from Taiwan want to visit, Paris was the city named as most popular destination, according to the poll.

The United States was cited as the most popular country among Taiwan people for short-term study visits, while the Maldives was the most often-mentioned island for a dream vacation, followed by Bali, Guam, Tahiti, Palau and Phuket.
At the same time, Hawaii, Venice, Paris, Bali, and Hamilton, Australia were the leading five most popular honeymoon destinations for Taiwan people, the poll indicated.

In terms of travel budget, only 9.7 percent of the respondents said they would earmark NT$100,000 (about US$3,180) or more for travel each year, while less than 50 percent travel as part of package tours, and 32 percent travel independently.
The rest of the respondents said they go abroad mainly to visit friends and family members or for business purposes.

Among the ten best aviation companies, according to the respondents, are Taiwan's EVA Airways, Singapore Airlines, Japan Asia Airways, Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways, Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL), and Northwest Airlines of the United States.
In related news, meanwhile, the top three travel-related news headlines of 1999 were as follows:
-- Local tourism industry hit hard by Sept. 21 earthquake;
-- Legally binding guidelines worked out by Consumer Foundation to provide greater protection for tourists involved in disputes with travel agents; and
-- Three killed and more than 100 injured in a CAL jet incident in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ISSUES Y2K-COMPLIANCE CERTIFICATE FOR ROC F-16S

TEXT.P: The United States has assured the Republic of China that the US-made F-16 jet fighters it has bought will not be affected by the Y2K bug, an air force official said on Wednesday.
"The United States has issued a Y2K-compliance certificate for our F-16 fighters," said Chien Chien-chun, political warfare division chief at the Chiayi air base in southern Taiwan.

The ROC Air Force has taken delivery of more than 100 of an order of 150 F-16s from the United States as part of its arsenal modernization plan. As four of the planes have crashed in less than two years, concern has been mounting as to whether the advanced fighters are prepared for millennium bug-related problems.
In an apparent effort to allay these public misgivings, Chien said the air force has made full preparations to counter any possible millennium bug glitch during the rollover into the new millennium.
"All of our F-16s have undergone intensive Y2K testing," Chien said, adding that the Y2K testing also covers all air force logistic support services.

Chien further said the air force is confident that its F-16s will be able to cope well with any Y2K problems. "We firmly believe that our air defense safety dragnet will not be affected by any millennium bug glitches."
Even if computer systems break down, Chien said the air force personnel have practiced manual operation of all related systems.
Still, he went on, air force authorities have decided to reduce training flights during the Y2K high-risk period from Dec. 31 through Jan. 4.
"The reduction, however, will not affect our combat preparedness," Chien stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS INSOLVENCIES IN AUSTRALIA SEEN RISING IN 2000

TEXT.P: Business insolvencies in Australia are expected to drop in calendar 1999, but will surge by the year 2000 thanks to the introduction of a 10 percent goods and services tax (GST), to be implemented on July 1 of next year, according to the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.
The commission said business insolvencies dropped to 5877 in the first nine months of 1999, compared to 6410 over the same period a year earlier.

But Australian accountants believe the GST will likely be a catalyst for increased business insolvencies because companies must pay the tax before they can claim credits for the 10 percent tax on their inputs.
They expect an increase in company failures in the new year, with a peak in the second half of 2000.

"There will be general uncertainty arising from the unknown consumer reaction to the introduction of the GST," Tim Jonas, managing partner of the Pitcher Partners in Sydney, told the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday.
The "pay as you go" tax collection system could also cause problems for companies that did not plan ahead because it will bring forward income tax payments, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ATHLETES' LEADER WANTS UPDATED ANTI-DOPING RULES BEFORE

TEXT.P: An Australian athlete appointed to the International Olympic Committee this month has called for anti-doping rules to be updated before the Olympic Games in Sydney begin next September.
Olympic gold medalist speed-skater Johann Olav Koss, said the list of banned drugs in the new anti-doping code should be revised "absolutely in time for Sydney," the Australian reported on Wednesday.
He questioned the inclusion of some medical drugs on the list and suggested that an alternative list of banned substances be drawn up for use in out-of-competition doping tests.
He proposed that the review be given priority by the World Anti-doping Agency (WADA) at a meeting in Switzerland on January 13.

"I believe there are certain drugs which have been shown to be helpful in medical treatment but are not performance-enhancing," said Koss, questioning whether these should be included on the banned-substance list.

The new Olympic anti-doping code, to come into force on the first of January, provides for million-dollar fines for athletes found to be using performance-enhancing drugs. The code fines first-time offenders up to US$100,000 and suspends them from competition for at least two years, although the sports federation can shorten the suspension in exceptional circumstances, the daily reported.
Repeat cheats can be fined up to US$1 million with a life-time suspension under the new code.
But Koss said the Olympic code still gives sports federations discretionary powers to test or punish athletes for using banned drugs in the lead-up to the Olympic Games.
"Now, the list of (banned) substance depends on the federation. For one federation marijuana is not on the list, but for another it is," he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, losing NT$0.017 to close at NT$31.485.
A total of US$401.5 million changed hands during Wednesday's session.
It was the sixth consecutive day that the greenback has slid against the New Taiwan dollar, and the downward trend was predicted by local analysts to continue for a while.
The US currency opened at NT$31.482, and was traded between NT$31.471 and NT$31.506.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROTRAIN STILL HAS CHANCE TO WIN TAIWAN HIGH SPEED RAIL PROJECT

TEXT.P: Although Japan's Shinkansen consortium has been chosen as the priority bidder for Taiwan's proposed high speed rail system, the Eurotrain consortium still has a chance to win the contract, said an official of Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC).

THSRC, which was contracted to build and operate the railway, will begin negotiations in January with Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium on the NT$95 billion (US$3 billion) contract to provide the island with electric locomotives and rail cars, as well as the electric system to run the trains.

If the negotiations with Shinkansen, which are expected to conclude by the end of January, were to fall through, its European rival would automatically fill Shinkansen's place as the alternative bidder, said the THSRC official.

Eurotrain, which is led by Germany's Siemens and France's Alstom, was initially selected as the "preferred bidder" for the project two years ago, but Shinkansen bent over backwards to win the project and sweetened its offer by providing soft loans with money from the Japanese government.

Once the contract for the rail system's machinery and electrical equipment is concluded, Shinkansen will begin to build the system, and construction of the railway will start in the first quarter of next year, said the official.
Taiwan's high speed railway is scheduled to become operational in October 2005, but the system should be ready for a test run two years before it begins operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRONOLOGY OF THE 20TH CENTURY

TEXT.P: Following are some of the major events to have occurred during the 20th century:
1948: South Africa's National Party came to power and began its system of apartheid.
1949: Mao Tse-tung (Zedong) proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China.
1950: The Korean War broke out.
1951: The world's first color TV program was broadcast by the Columbia Broadcasting System of the United States.
1952: The United States held its first H-bomb test in the Marshall Islands.
1953: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, ascended to the throne upon the death of her father, George VI.
1954: The Vietminh defeated the French in the Battle of Dien Bien Phu. The Geneva Conference divided Vietnam into two nations.
1955: Civil war broke out in Vietnam.
1956: As Soviet premier, Nikita S. Khrushchev denounced Joseph V. Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution.
1957: Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite, was launched by the Soviet Union. It transmitted radio signals that were received on earth.
1958: The European Economic Community and the European Organization for Nuclear Research were formally established.
1959: Fidel Castro became the head of the Cuban government after he and his supporters overthrew the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista.
1960: A US U-2 spy plane was shot down over the USSR by Soviet missiles.
1961: The East German Communists built the Berlin Wall to prevent East Germans from escaping to West Berlin.
1962: The Cuban missile crisis occurred in October when the United States learned that the Soviet Union had secretly installed missiles in Cuba.
1963: US President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas.
1964: Soviet Premier Nikita S. Krushchev was deposed for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1965: Singapore withdrew from the Federation of Malaysia and became an independent nation.
1966: Mao Tse-tung launched the "Cultural Revolution," which disrupted education, government and daily life on the Chinese mainland.
1967: South African surgeon Christiaan N. Barnard performed the first human heart transplant.

1968: Martin Luther King, Jr., the US cleric whose eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.
1969: As US astronaut Neil A. Armstrong took the historic first step on the moon on July 20, he said: "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind."
1970: In April, after Norodom Sihanouk was overthrown, US and South Vietnamese troops entered Cambodia to cut off the Communist supply bases there.
1971: Computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography (CAT) was invented. Doctors use CT scans to diagnose many conditions, such as tumors, infections, blood clots and broken bones.
1972: US President Richard M. Nixon visited mainland China.
1973: The first oil crisis occurred.
1974: President Richard M. Nixon resigned from office on Aug. 9 after the US Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for his involvement in the Watergate scandal.
1975: The Vietnam War ended with the Communists capturing South Vietnam.
1976: Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung (Zedong) died.
1977: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt made a historic trip to Israel, marking the dawn of peace in the Middle East.
1978: The first test-tube baby was born in Britain. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER VIRUS DESIGNER HIRED BY INTERNET SERVICE PROVIDER

TEXT.P: A college student arrested for designing the Chernobyl computer virus was hired by an Internet service provider after his case was dismissed in court, an official from the company said on Wednesday.

Chen Ying-hau, a student at the Ta-Tung Institute of Technology, was arrested after police found he had allegedly designed the computer virus and purposely transmitted the virus to many computers around the world.
However, the Taipei prosecutors' office investigation found that Chen did not spread the virus deliberately, and determined not to indict him.
Wahoo International Enterprise, a Taiwan-based Internet-related software and service provider, immediately decided to invite Chen to work in the company's research and development section.

Chen, who is currently working in Wahoo's headquarters in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung, said he had no idea of how his legal case was progressing, and that he had to "sort himself out" in order to maintain a normal life after the case broke.

He went on to say that many computer companies in Taipei and the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park wanted to hire him after he finished his national service in July, and he finally decided to join Wahoo, which offers Internet services on the Linux operating system, a system which can be downloaded for free and is in direct competition with Microsoft's Windows.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE APPOINTS JOHN C. CHANG AS SENIOR ADVISER TO THE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui appointed John C. Chang, former secretary-general of the Presidential Office, as senior adviser to the president, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said on Wednesday.

The spokesman said that the appointment will be retroactive to be considered effective Dec. 23, the day which Chang stepped down from his position as secretary-general following his involvement in a sex scandal.
Former Senior Adviser to the President Ding Mou-shih replaced Chang as secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
In stepping down from his post, Chang said he had been having an extramarital affair with former actress Wang Hsiao-tsan. However, Wang categorically denied playing any role in the scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PASSENGER MISSING FROM LUXURY LINER

TEXT.P: A passenger on a luxury liner tour was reported missing after taking part in a four-day tour to Okinawa, Japan, police said on Wednesday.
Police said Chou Tzu-ming, 34, and his wife, Liang Yu-feng, boarded the Star Cruises Co.'s Aquarius liner in Keelung, northern Taiwan, on Sunday.
Liang reported to police that around 11 p.m. Tuesday, her husband told her that he wanted to go to the casino on the ship. But as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, she had not seen her husband again.
After the cruise ship docked at Keelung Harbor at 3 p.m. Wednesday, and all passengers had disembarked, Chou was nowhere to be seen. "I am very worried about my husband's safety," Liang said.
Police at Keelung Harbor boarded the ship to search for clues as to whether Chou had fallen overboard or disappeared for some other reason.
An official from a local Star Cruises agent said the company will work closely with police to try to discover Chou's whereabouts.
This is the second case this year involving the disappearance of a passenger of Star Cruises, which is owned by a Malaysian business group but headquartered in Singapore.
In mid-September, Taipei resident Lin Tze-huang, 30, was reported missing from aboard another Star Cruises liner on his way home from a five-day voyage through waters around Singapore and Malaysia.

Lin's family had solicited assistance from the government. However, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said that of all Star Cruises-owned liners, it only has regulation to govern the Aquarius liner, which operates in waters around Taiwan and Okinawa, and makes regular stops at Keelung Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PROMISES NOT TO EXCLUDE ROC FROM TMD PROJECT: ENVOY

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen said on Wednesday that the Clinton administration has promised not to exclude the Republic of China from the US-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) system.
Chen, who returned to Taipei earlier this week for home consultations, made the statement in a report to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee.
The ROC's de facto ambassador to the United States said senior officials from both sides have exchanged views on TMD-related issues.

"In addition to expressing our interest in participating in the TMD project, we have also told American officials that our Ministry of National Defense is carefully evaluating whether to take part in the project," Chen said.
As the project is still in the planning stage, Chen said the ROC has asked the Clinton administration not to hastily deny Taiwan's access to the TMD.

Noting that the US executive branch has adopted an open-minded attitude toward the project at the moment, Chen said it has promised not to rule out the possibility of Taiwan's participation at this stage.
Nevertheless, Chen said the United States absolutely does not want to see the outbreak of a military confrontation in the Taiwan Strait.

"The United States hopes to maintain prosperity and development in the Taiwan Strait and entire Asia-Pacific regions, and this is why it has repeatedly stressed its stance on peaceful solution to cross-strait issues," Chen explained.

The career diplomat pointed out that the US State Department, Pentagon and even President Bill Clinton have on many occasions expressed grave concern about mainland China's mounting missile threat to Taiwan and its construction of new missile bases along its southeastern coast in recent years.
According to Chen, the US administration's strong reaction to Beijing's intensified military buildup fully reflects the great importance it has attached to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that the Clinton administration announced its decision in late July to sell US$550 million worth of spare parts for F-16 jet fighters and E2T early warning aircraft to Taiwan, Chen said the US government has not changed its security commitment to the ROC after President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" on July 9.
However, Chen admitted that it is difficult to upgrade substantive ties between Taipei and Washington before the inauguration of a new US president in January 2001.
With a view to maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, Chen said the United States now adopts a strategy of "de-politicizing security issues."
Under this strategy, Chen said the United States is not expected to adopt steps detrimental to cross-strait stability when it comes to arms sales issues.

Nevertheless, Chen went on: "From the US viewpoint, the ROC government's failure to consult with the United States before unveiling its 'special state-to-state relationship' theory has affected mutual trust."

Chen further predicted that the US executive branch may impose some hurdles to its working relationship with the ROC's representative office in Washington, D.C. because of the "special state-to-state" theory.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA COURT ISSUES HABEAS CORPUS WRIT FOR TAIWANESE-AMERICAN

TEXT.P: The Manila Regional Trial Court (MRTC) on Tuesday granted a request for the issuance of a writ of habeas corpus for a Taiwanese-American businesswoman who is protesting her continued detention at the Bureau of Immigration.

The issuance of the writ was ordered by Presiding Judge Vicente A. Hidalgo of MRTC Branch 37 after hearing the petition of Mary Yen, who was arrested Sept. 23 for allegedly trying to escort two aliens out of the country.
She was arrested by immigration agents at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport while waiting for her flight to Vancouver, Canada.
The Dec. 28 writ required that Yen be brought before the court for the purpose of determining the legality of her detention.

The case against her was ordered dismissed by Judge Francisco Mendiola of the Pasay City Regional Trial Court on Nov. 25. However, she remained detained for alleged failure to pay an administrative fine of 500,000 pesos.
Yen appealed to President Estrada and the Bureau of Immigration for a reduction of the fine to 50,000 pesos.
After considering the status of her case, however, Yen announced through her counsel, Ricardo Juan Jr., that she will not pay the fine because the case has been ordered dismissed by the court.
Juan added that because of the court's order to dismiss her case, there is no legal basis for the imposition of the fine or her continued detention. (by Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S ENVOY TO US BRIEFS LEGISLATURE ON TIES WITH WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: Taipei caught Washington off guard last summer by claiming to have "special state-to-state" ties with Beijing without consulting the United States in advance, said Taipei's envoy to Washington on Wednesday.

Stephen Chen, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, told the Legislative Yuan that the trust between Taipei and Washington was damaged despite Taipei's efforts afterward to limit the impact of its claims.
President Lee Teng-hui stated in July that relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be characterized as a "special state-to-state" relationship.

In addition to the anticipated fierce criticism from Beijing, the remark, designed to foil Beijing's claims of sovereignty over Taiwan, got the cold shoulder from Washington, which expressed its veiled disapproval by reiterating its adherence to the "one China" policy.

As a result, the envoy cautioned, Washington might curtail arms sales to Taiwan somewhat in the future, but, he believes, not to the extent that it would tilt the military balance across the Taiwan Strait, which the United States has taken pains to maintain.
Chen, who is in Taipei on a routine visit, met with President Lee Teng-hui on Monday and is slated to return to his Washington office on Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO SEND TEAM TO RECEIVE RESCUE TRAINING IN US

TEXT.P: A Taipei rescue team will be sent to the United States for special training, an official of the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior said on Wednesday.
The official said the rescue team members will receive training, to be funded by private donations, which is patterned after programs offered by US Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).
The official noted that FEMA has set up 28 urban search and rescue program systems in major US cities to carry out rescue operations.

He said that each rescue team member will receive training in all kinds of rescue operations, which will include learning about the basic structure of buildings, how to identify potential dangers in collapsed buildings and giving medial assistance.

The rescue operations also involve selecting one-year-old dogs for six-month training courses. The dogs will then be dispatched to work with team members for another 30-day period of intensive rescue operation training.
It is estimated that every team member will have to undergo six to 12 months training and will then be eligible to take part in rescue operations after being tested and certified.
Taipei was alerted to its lack of sufficient search and rescue training and poor equipment after the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan on Sept. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONSIDERING FILING SUIT AGAINST FORMER TAIWAN GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said on Wednesday that it will consider filing a lawsuit against independent presidential candidate James Soong charging him with embezzling party funds.
The KMT Central Standing Committee heard and discussed an investigative report on Soong's suspicious accounts at Chung Hsing Bills Finance Corp. during Wednesday's regular meeting.
The report noted that Soong had removed millions of dollars of KMT money through the accounts of his son and his relatives and was suspected of forgery, breach of trust and misappropriation of funds.
The KMT said it will consult with attorneys and bring the case to the courts.

Soong reiterated Tuesday night that he has not embezzled a single penny of KMT funds although he had been authorized by KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui to manage a large sum of money when he was KMT secretary-general.
He stated that the secret fund was to be used to take care of the family members of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo and to finance other special party assignments at the direction of Lee.
The former Taiwan governor had assigned New Party Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta to check all transactions relating to the money since 1991.
Hsieh defended Soong on Tuesday night, saying that her investigation of his accounts had indicated no wrongdoing in handling the money.
But Lee branded Soong "a thief," "a big liar" and "shameless" on Wednesday when he commented on Soong's explanations regarding the questionable accounts.

In addition to Lee, other prominent KMT figures directed their criticism against Soong. They included KMT Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei, former KMT Secretary-General Hsu Shui-teh, former Vice Premier Hsu Li-teh, and Lee's close aide Su Chih-cheng.

Public opinion surveys showed that among the major presidential candidates, Soong continues to take lead in support ratings, but his rating had fallen several notches since the issue of party funds was raised weeks ago. But the approval rating of KMT presidential nominee Lien Chan has not benefited much from the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAM BREAKING EVEN IN ITS 5TH YEAR

TEXT.P: Five years after the implementation of the national health insurance project, the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) reported on Wednesday that it is breaking even with its finances.
A BNHI official said that surplus revenue during the first half of the project is making up for a shortage of funds in the second half.

The official said she is optimistic about the bureau's finances next year, adding that the tobacco health tax, vocational injury compensation, and compulsory motorcycle and automobile tax will all help its financial situation.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 30, or the 23rd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1884: Hideki Tojo, Japanese army official and politician, is born as Tojo Eiki. He governed Japan's progress through World War II, and was executed as a war criminal.
1887: Britain's Queen Victoria receives a unique celebration of her Jubilee year from the women of England -- a petition signed by 1,132,608 women in favor of the Sunday closing of English public houses and the banning of sales of intoxicating liquor on the Lord's Day.
1903: A raging fire breaks out in the Iroquois Theater in Chicago during a performance, killing 578 people.
1918: Dr. Sun Yat-sen finishes his book titled "The Tenets of Sun Yat-sen," and writes a preface to explain the philosophical principle that "it is easier to do something than to understand why."
1922: Russia is renamed the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or USSR.
1925: Hsu Soo-cheng, special envoy of the Peiyang government, is arrested and killed by troops loyal to Feng Yu-siang at the Langfang railway station in mainland China's Hopei Province.
1927: The first section of the Tokyo subway between the districts of Ueno and Asakusa is opened to traffic.
1929: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs proclaims the nullification of consular jurisdiction in China to rid China of foreign privileges.
1939: Wang Ching-wei, who on Dec. 29, 1938 called for suspension of China's war of resistance and negotiations for peace with Japan, signs a secret agreement with Japan.
1940: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt indicates in a "fireside" talk that the United States will provide military aid to China.
1944: Romain Rolland, the French writer who won the 1915 Nobel Prize for literature, dies at the age of 78.
1946: The Chinese communists use the "Shen Chung incident" to instigate students in Beijing to launch an anti-US campaign.
1947: Romanian communists under the protection of Soviet troops force King Michael to give up his throne and declare Romania an "independent people's democracy."
1949: The Republic of China announces severance of diplomatic relations with India.
1965: Ferdinand E. Marcos becomes president of the Philippines.
1966: The ROC and Botswana establish diplomatic relations.
1968: Trygve Lie, Norwegian politician and first secretary-general of the United Nations, dies at the age of 72.
1975: The United States Little League Baseball allows teams from foreign countries to take part in its world series competition.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Ahmad Mohammed Mahmoud, editor of the Arab News in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.
1979: Richard Rodgers, the American composer known for his musical comedies, especially his collaborations with Oscar Hammerstein II, including "Oklahoma," "South Pacific," and "The Sound of Music," dies in New York City at the age of 77.
1988: Colonel Oliver North subpoenas President Ronald Reagan and President-elect George Bush to testify in the Iran-Contra trial.
1989: The United States renegotiates with the Vatican to bring an end to the refuge of Panamanian dictator General Manuel Noriega in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. Noreiga fled to the embassy on Christmas Eve to escape the clutches of US marines sent by President George Bush to arrest him.
1993: Israel signs mutual recognition treaty with the Vatican, ending nearly 2,000 years of antagonism between the Orthodox Jews and the Roman Catholics.
1997: South Africa establishes diplomatic ties with mainland China. The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs formally severed diplomatic relations with South Africa on Dec. 31, 1997.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A man without moral character cannot long put up with adversity, nor can he long enjoy prosperity. Men of moral character find themselves at home in being moral; men of intelligence find it advantageous to be moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ISSUES DIRECTIVES AIMED AT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN 2000

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday issued four administrative directives, in the hope that his Cabinet will lead Taiwan to achieve the targeted 6.1 percent economic growth rate in 2000.

Siew gave the instructions after hearing a report on the island's economic situation at the Executive Yuan's last plenary session for 1999. The report was delivered by P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

Chiang indicated that Taiwan's foreign trade continued its double-digit growth in November, with exports amounting to US$11.55 billion, up 11 percent from that period one year ago. The figure marked a record single-month high in the island's history.

November imports were posted at US$10.11 billion, up 14.5 percent from the same month last year, Chiang reported, noting that imports of mechanical products saw 31.8 percent growth in November, reflecting that the private sector is gearing up for increased investment activity.
Chiang added that in the first half month of this month, Taiwan's imports registered 17.4 percent growth.

Commenting on the report, Siew said all 1999 economic indices are reflecting economic development greater than that of last year, thanks to the strong and solid economic fundamentals that the island now enjoys.

Although Taiwan was hit hard on Sept. 21 by the magnitude 7.4 earthquake, which killed some 4,000 people and left thousands injured and homeless, it nevertheless registered economic growth of 5.5 percent for the year, one of the highest figures among Asian countries, the premier said.

However, the figure does not mean that everything is OK regarding Taiwan's economic development, Siew warned, saying that declining tax revenues and surging crude oil prices in the international market are affecting the island.
Unemployment and continuing recession in some sectors, such as the residential building sector, are also potential challenges for Taiwan's economic development, Siew added.
To maintain a prosperous economy, the premier said that official efforts in the coming year should focus on four areas:

-- completing post-quake rehabilitation work: the government should make a comprehensive effort to implement an NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) reconstruction budget, and ensure that the work will improve economic development;
-- preparing for the possible impact of Taiwan entering the World Trade Organization;
-- encouraging the on-time completion of important private investment projects, such as the high-speed rail system;
-- and strengthening the overall economy, as well as overhauling the domestic financial market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRONOLOGY OF THE 20TH CENTURY

TEXT.P: Following are some of the major events to have occurred during the 20th century:
1979: The Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan with thousands of troops.
1980: The Polish government recognized Solidarity, the organization of free trade unions headed by Lech Walesa.
1981: The first case of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), the final, life-threatening stage of infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), was made public.
1982: Argentina lost the war with Britain over control of the Falkland Islands.
1983: Troops of the United States military invaded Grenada on Oct. 25.
1984: Indira Gandhi, the first female prime minister of India, was assassinated.
1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev became head of the Soviet Communist Party.

1986: The Chernobyl power plant, located near Kiev in Ukraine, was the scene of the worst nuclear accident in history, when an explosion and fire ripped apart the reactor and released large amounts of radioactive substances into the atmosphere.
1987: The US stock market decline, in an incident known as "Black Monday," sent shock waves through all stock markets worldwide.
1988: The war between Iran and Iraq ended.

1989: Student protesters erected a statue called the Goddess of Democracy at Beijing's Tiananmen Square in a protest for greater democracy in China. The military crushed the demonstration, killing hundreds of unarmed protesters.
1990: Unification of East Germany and West Germany took place on Oct. 3.
1991: Communist rule ended, and the Soviet Union was dissolved. A coalition of 39 nations, including the United States and Canada, defeated Iraq in the Persian Gulf War.
1992: The United States and Russia agreed to limit production of nuclear weapons, ending the Cold War.

1993: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) signed an agreement to work to end their conflicts. The agreement included implementation of a plan for Israel's withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
1994: Nelson Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, was elected president of South Africa in the country's first elections to be open to all races.
1995: Civil war broke out in Bosnia. Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel was assassinated.
1996: Bill Clinton was reelected president of the United States. Boris N. Yeltsin was reelected president of Russia.
1997: Princess Diana of Wales was killed in a traffic accident near Paris. Hong Kong was returned to Communist China.
1998: The Asian economic crisis spread. US President Bill Clinton was involved in a sex scandal with a White House intern.
1999: Nations of The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) sent troops to Kosovo in Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK SEES ROSY ECONOMIC OUTLOOK IN NEW MILLENNIUM

TEXT.P: The world's economies are generally headed for a revival in the new millennium as an acceleration in overseas activity offsets a cooling in the red-hot American economy, reported a Canadian bank on Wednesday.
The Bank of Nova Scotia, in its latest Global Economic Outlook, said Asia will bounce back, the situation in Europe is already looking up and even Latin America's prospects seem good.
Asia is reviving, led by an impressive economic rebound in Korea, continuing momentum in mainland China and recovery in Japan, the outlook report said.

In the US, the bank said interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve will slow the economy. However, its analysts believe consumers and businesses will stay in a spending mood, contributing to solid gross domestic product growth of 3.3 percent in 2000 and 3.0 percent in 2001.

"Since more than half of Canada's private sector activity is geared to exports, buoyant conditions in the United States and abroad will be good news for Canada through 2001," said Warren Jestin, Scotiabank's chief economist.
He forecast the Canadian GDP will grow 3.7 percent in 2000 and 3.2 percent in 2001.
The global revival will kindle inflationary pressures, Jestin noted. That will result in rate hikes in the US of 50-75 basis points by late summer 2000, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO'S INFORMATION DIVISION HEAD DEFENDS TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: A director at Taiwan's de facto embassy in Australia has defended the sovereignty of the Republic of China and clearly stated Taiwan is not a colony like Hong Kong and Macau and is therefore not interested in the "one country, two systems" formula being offered by Beijing.

In a letter sent to the Australian Financial Review, Pong, director of the Information Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Sydney, mentioned that both Vice President Lien Chan and presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian have said that Taiwan is a sovereign state and not a colony.
He cited the arrest of 13 street theater actors in Macau as an example on how Beijing authorities are treating the people of the former Portuguese colony.
"Can you imagine that 13 players of street theater staged outside St. Paul's Church (in Macau) were arrested just because one of the players wore a Jiang mask?" Chang asked.
He mentioned that the people of Taiwan not only can select their leader through popular election, but also have an independent judicial system.
"Who can expect Taiwan to return to a totalitarian regime and to let its people live as colonial citizens?" he asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SUPPORT FOR OLYMPIC GAMES HITS RECORD LOW DUE TO SCANDALS

TEXT.P: Australian support for the year 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney has hit a record low thanks to a series of scandals, including the preferential sale of premium tickets to the rich at inflated prices, according to a new survey by the Australian.

The daily's survey showed that only 37 percent of the people interviewed expressed their support for the Olympic Games, compared to 51 percent in a survey earlier this year and 58 percent in a similar survey last year.
The same survey shows 62 percent of Australians are no longer interested in supporting the Olympics, compared to 49 percent in early 1999 and 42 percent in 1998.
The daily quoted Lee Naylor, chair of the Athlete's Commission for Track and Field, as saying that it was frustrating that the job of promoting the Games was not being done properly.

"It's the ticketing, it's just everything. It's definitely an indicator that the SOCOG isn't doing the job it should be doing. The survey is just amazing. I guess it's a case of enough is enough. People are being so disheartened by everything and I don't blame them," she said.

The Sydney Organizing Commission for Olympic Games (SOCOG) was hit first by scandal last year when one of its senior officials was involved in accepting expensive gifts and trips to the US and other countries. Then this year, organizers came under attack by the public for selling tickets to the rich at high prices for major events, including the opening and closing ceremonies.

"There's no doubt the Olympics today, compared to five or 10 years ago, doesn't enjoy the same pristine standing in the community. It's become related to big business and big politics," said Mara Bun, public affairs manager of the Australian Consumer Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SENDS 25 CHINESE ILLEGALS HOME

TEXT.P: Australia has deported 25 Chinese illegal immigrants to southern China, but 3000 other illegals from other Asian countries and the Middle East remain in detention centers, causing headaches for Canberra.
Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock told reporters on Wednesday that 23 of the 25 Chinese citizens landed on Christmas Island in November and the other two breached visa conditions.

The surge in illegal arrivals to Australia from China and several Middle Eastern countries is the result of an increase in human smuggling operations in China, Indonesia and elsewhere, Australian immigration officials said.

Ruddock is set to go to Afghanistan, Iraq, Jordan and Turkey to directly ask those governments to help Australia stop smuggling operations, making him the first senior Australian official to resort to such a strategy.
The Australian government is worried that more illegals are expected to attempt entry into the country in the coming weeks or months.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITNEY HOUSTON TO SING AT HK TYCOON LI'S MILLENNIUM PARTY

TEXT.P: Pop star Whitney Houston and Taiwan's Dick and the Cowboy will be among the acts performing at an exclusive multi-million-dollar New Year's party hosted by tycoon Richard Li Tzar-kai in Hong Kong on Friday night.
Li is spending more than $20 million on flying in Whitney Houston and a host of other overseas music names for a millennium show at the Convention and Exhibition Center.

The marathon 11-hour event, pulled together only within the last month, is aimed at promoting Li's Cyber-Port development abroad and at putting Hong Kong on the global map as an information technology hub.
Besides Whitney Houston, Dick and Cowboy, the bands Sister Sledge and All-4-one, Canto-pop singer Eason Chan and Beijing music group Tang Dynasty will perform at the event.
During the evening, giant video screens will show live digital video coverage of a 20 minute laser and multi-media show being staged at the Cyber-Port site in Pokfulam.
After midnight, another 2,000 invited guests will enter the ballroom and Houston will sing for about an hour starting at 1 am. The party is scheduled to run until 7 am.
Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Cancer Fund has officially organized the "Ultimate Millennium Party - Utopia," which they have been planning for about six years.
Li is understood to have stepped in and booked up to half of the 90 tables for that event, with each table for 12 people costing between $60,000 and $100,000.
