DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS SOONG'S RATING DECLINING OVER 'MYSTERY FUNDS'

TEXT.P: The results of a series of Gallup polls show that independent presidential candidate James Soong's support rating has declined steadily since the outbreak of controversy over his finances.
According to Wednesday's Gallup poll, Soong's support rating dropped to a new low of 21.7 percent from a high of 35.5 percent recorded in a similar Nov. 11 survey.
Gallup Taiwan Co., commissioned by Sanlih Entertainment Television, began to conduct a series of 2000 presidential election-related public opinion surveys on Sept. 29.

Poll results find that Soong's popularity has shown a downward trend after reaching a peak in the Nov. 11 survey. His support rating was 33.1 percent in the Nov. 16 Gallup poll, 28 percent in the Dec. 10 survey, 23.6 percent in the Dec. 15 poll and 22.1 percent in the Dec. 23 survey.
In contrast, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian's support rating has risen mildly since Soong's finances drew skepticism in early December.
Chen's rating in the first Gallup poll was 16.9 percent and rose to 24.3 percent in Wednesday's survey, making him the most popular of the three key presidential contestants.

In the same series of surveys, ruling Kuomintang presidential candidate Lien Chan's support rating has hovered in a narrow range, with the number edging down to 10.41 percent in the latest Gallup poll from 10.5 percent in the Sept. 29 poll. Another noteworthy trend is that the percentage of swing voters has climbed steadily since the exposure of huge "mystery funds" in the Soong son's account at the Chung Hsing Bills Finance Corporation (CHBFC). In the Dec. 10 survey, 28 percent of those interviewed said they have not yet made a decision on their choice, and the ratio surged to 32.4 percent in the Wednesday poll.

Survey results also show that Lien continues to take the lead in terms of the odds to win the 2000 presidential election, with the percentage of those who believed in Lien's final electoral success picking up from 30.3 percent in the Nov. 16 poll to 33.3 percent in the latest survey.

During the same period, the number of people who bet on Soong's victory has fallen from 34 percent to 14.3 percent, while the number of those who bet on Chen's win has edged up modestly from 9.1 percent to 14.8 percent.
A total of 998 adult residents responded to Wednesday's Gallup poll.
Survey results released on Thursday show that 31.9 percent of those interviewed do not buy Soong's lengthy explanations of financial transactions in his relatives' accounts.

Meanwhile, 42.4 percent said they think that the acrimonious, pungent mutual criticisms between the ruling Kuomintang and the Soong camp would have negative effects on Taiwan's democratic development. Soong, a former KMT powerhouse and Taiwan governor, was expelled from the party for his insistence on running in the 2000 presidential election as an independent.
The same poll also found that 68 percent of the respondents support the enactment of a law requiring candidates in political elections to report their assets.

Asked about their opinions concerning President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui's criticism of Soong as a "shameless liar and thief" for alleged financial dishonesty over the CHBFC case, 50.9 percent said they disagree with Lee's criticism. Only 17.3 percent said they back Lee's criticism and 31.8 percent said they have no opinion about Lee's remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BUILD LIGHT-RAIL VEHICLES DOMESTICALLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's official Chung San Institute of Science and Technology and several local manufacturers on Thursday signed a cooperation contract to jointly develop and build light rail vehicles domestically.

The institute was commissioned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to develop the technology to manufacture vehicles for light rail transit systems, which are increasingly in demand by the local transportation market after the establishment of a rapid transit system in Taipei and the promotion of a high-speed railway connecting the northern and southern parts of the island.

On Thursday the institute released its project development results and also forged the cooperation deal with China Steel Corp., Tang Eng Iron Works Corp., Long Cheng Fa Corp. and Lio Ho Mechanical Corp. in Hsinchu, according to MOEA officials.

In addition, the Chung San Institute signed an accord with more than 20 factories that are making related parts and components, in order to form a strategic alliance aimed at integrating Taiwan's resources to establish a light-rail vehicle industry on the island.
The move will help Taiwan quickly rid itself of dependence on imported light-rail products, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET OKS ROC-GUATEMALA INVESTMENT PROMOTION & PROTECTION PACT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet at its weekly meeting on Thursday approved the Republic of China-Guatemala Investment Promotion and Protection Agreement proposed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
ROC Ambassador to Guatemala Wu Jen-hsiu and Guatemalan Acting Economics Minister A. Castillo inked the pact on behalf of their respective governments in Guatemala City on Nov. 12.
The agreement will go into effect in one month, after notes are exchanged between the two parties, and it will automatically be extended for another 10 years after the first 10-year period expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK ACCOUNT BALANCE SURGES TENFOLD ALLEGEDLY DUE TO Y2K BUG

TEXT.P: Allegations of a Y2K bug attack on a Taiwan bank emerged one day before the rollover to the year 2000, as one Taichung resident found her bank account had swelled tenfold when she checked her account balance on Thursday morning.

Fearing effects of the Y2K bug, Chang Ching-yi used an automatic teller machine (ATM) at Chung Hwa Commercial Bank's Taichung branch to check the balance of her account at the Bank of Taiwan (BOT). Surprised to find a balance of over NT$860,000 -- more than 10 times the anticipated NT$80,000 -- she checked again an hour later, only to find the same result.
Chang inquired at both banks about the mistaken balance, in order to find out which bank was affected by the Y2K bug, she said.

In response to Chang's case, Vice General Manager of Chung Hwa Commercial Bank Chang Sung-o clarified that the situation has nothing to do with the Y2K bug, as the overall balance of Chang's current and time-deposit accounts totals NT$860,000.

The bank manager reiterated that there is absolutely no problem with Chung Hwa's ATM, and stated that the customer's confusion has nothing to do with the Y2K bug, speculating that she must have forgotten that she has two accounts or that she was overly nervous about potential Y2K problems.

According to the Chung Hwa official, if an account holder uses certain ATM functions to check an account balance, all of the customer's account balances will be summed up and printed out as one total figure.
He further stated that no technical problems or malfunctions have occurred with Chung Hwa ATM machines, as no other account holders have reported having the same problem.
Meanwhile, the Bank of Taiwan claimed that the inflated balance simply resulted from a printing error by the ATM machine and would have no effect on Chang's actual account balance. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND PALAU FORGE DIPLOMATIC TIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the Republic of Palau forged full diplomatic relations on Thursday, ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chen Chien-jen announced on Thursday.

Chen, who had just returned from a 30-hour whirlwind visit to the West Pacific island state, told a hastily called press conference that a communique declaring diplomatic ties had been signed at Palau's capital, Koror, earlier the day.

The minister said official ties with Palau have been developing for many years, as the ROC signed a technological cooperation pact with Palau in 1984, and sent an agriculture mission to Palau in 1985.
In the joint communique on the establishment of diplomatic relations, the two sides agreed to exchange embassies in Koror and Taipei at "an appropriate time."
Palau, with a total land area of 487 square kilometers and a population of 18,000, becomes the ROC's 29th diplomatic ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO MEMBERSHIP TO AFFECT TAIWAN'S RICE OUTPUT: COA

TEXT.P: Over 80,000 hectares of farmland in Taiwan may be left to lie fallow over the next six years, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Ling Shiang-nung said on Thursday.

Due to the government's farm land liberalization policy and Taiwan's impending membership of the World Trade Organization (WTO), Ling said Taiwan's cropland will gradually be fully released for other uses in the future.
As Taiwan has promised to open up its farm produce market after joining the WTO, Ling said the local agricultural sector, and in particular the rice industry, will be hard-hit.
He added that COA has compiled a report focusing on the reduction of land given over to rice, which is Taiwan's No. 1 crop, with a total of 360,000-hectares given over to paddy.

According to Ling, more than 140,000 metric tons of imported rice will be allowed to enter Taiwan under the island's terms for joining the WTO, a move which may initially affect NT$3.4 billion (US$109.7 million)-worth of rice production on 32,000 hectares, along with the livelihoods of about 800,000 farmers.

Since rice production will eventually come to a halt on as much as 80,000 hectares, the COA head stressed that it is very important for the government to help affected farmers to find other crops to grow.
In line with the COA's program to reduce local rice output, Ling claimed that his council will assist rice farmers in developing "refined agriculture with domestic characteristics."

DOC.HEADLINE: SAVING IN YEN YIELDS MOST PROFITS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Savings in yen yielded a profit of 7.94 percent over the past year, the highest ratio of returns to investment among 15 foreign currencies in Taiwan, according to data compiled by the Central Trust of China (CTC).
The Belgian franc brought up the rear with a return of -17.39 percent.

Returns on the other thirteen currencies in descending order were: the Canadian dollar, at 7.49 percent; the Australian dollar, at 6.93 percent; the Hong Kong dollar, at 2.1 percent; the US dollar, at 1.78 percent; the British pound, at -0.92 percent; the Singapore dollar, at -1.77 percent; the Swedish krona, at -6.41 percent; the German mark, at -14.15 percent; the Dutch guilder, at -14.24 percent; the European Union's euro, at -14.26 percent; the French franc, at -14.43 percent; the Austrian schilling, at -14.6 percent; and the Swiss franc, at -15.22 percent.

The CTC said the strength of the yen against the greenback has driven up its returns to investment ratio, while the weakness of European Union's single currency, the euro, has dragged down profits on savings in European currencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO RETURN HUGE SUM TO KMT

TEXT.P: Independent presidential candidate James Soong on Thursday entrusted an attorney to return more than NT$240 million (NT$7.5 million) to the ruling Kuomintang and to terminate his commission relationship with KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui.
In the past few weeks, the KMT has charged Soong with embezzling party funds, and said is considering legal actions against the former party secretary-general.

Soong has reiterated that the party funds he deposited in accounts belonging to his son and his sister-in-law at Chung Hsing Bills Finance were authorized by Lee to pay for care for the family of late President Chiang Ching-kuo and for helping to finance "special political assignments" on Lee's instruction.
However, Lee denied that he had authorized Soong to handle these matters, and openly criticized Soong as "shameless" and "a liar."
Soong on Thursday asked his attorney, Huang Tung-hsiung, to end his commission relationship with Lee and to return the balance of the party funds, a sum amounting to NT$247.9 million.
The attorney said that he will try to establish written contact with Lee, but added that he would consider other methods if that one fails to bring a response.

Meanwhile, Soong said during a campaign tour of Miaoli in central Taiwan that he and his running mate Chang Chao-hsiung will not withdraw from the presidential race, scotching rumors that he was to abort his bid to win the 2000 presidential election.

He stated that he has never embezzled "a single penny" during his public office, and that if he is found to have embezzled public funds, he will withdraw from the election and retire from politics without any hesitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN AND OVERSEAS CHINESE INVESTMENTS TO HIT US$4 BILLION

TEXT.P: Foreign and overseas Chinese investments in Taiwan will hit the US$4 billion mark in 1999, the highest level since 1997, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Foreign and overseas Chinese investment totaled US$4.26 billion in 1997.

The statistics show that foreign and overseas Chinese investments in Taiwan in the first 11 months of 1999 accumulated to US$3.51 billion, an increase of 16 percent in comparison with the same period of a year ago.
In November alone, such investment amounted to US$564 million.
The main investment areas included electronics, electrical appliances, finance and insurance, the service industry, wholesale and retail sales, and international trade.
Taiwan's investment in mainland China in the first 11 months of this year totaled US$1.19 billion, a decrease of 11.16 percent as compared with the year-earlier period.
The main investment areas included electronics and electrical appliances, chemical manufacturing, the basic metal industry, plastics, foodstuffs and soft drinks.

Taiwan's outbound investment to areas other than the mainland in the January-November period accumulated to US$3.07 billion, a slight increase of 0.88 percent over last year, with investment going chiefly to the finance and insurance sector, electronics and electrical appliances, transportation, and international trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU HOSPITAL COMPLETES LIVER TRANSPLANT FOR 9-MONTH BABY

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital announced on Thursday it has successfully completed a liver transplant for a nine-month baby girl using a liver segment donated by the baby's mother.
The 5.5-kilogram baby, nicknamed Hsuan-hsuan, is the lightest and youngest liver transplant recipient that the hospital has ever treated, said NTU Hospital President Lee Yuan-teh.
"The surgery was conducted on Dec. 6 and the baby has since been in stable condition," said Dr. Lee Po-huang, head of the medical team which performed the transplant.
The announcement was made while the hospital held a party to celebrate the success of the surgery and the baby's "re-birth."
Lee said Hsuan-hsuan had suffered from a disease known as biliary atria (BA). "She underwent surgery when she was two months old, but it failed to improve her health," he said.

In the past, Lee said, a child BA patient usually had to wait until he or she was 10 kg in weight to receive a liver transplant. "However, as Hsuan-hsuan's condition was very serious, we decided to take a risk and give her a ray of hope," the doctor said.

"The biggest challenge in performing the surgery lay in the thinness of Hsuan-hsuan's blood vessels," Lee said, adding that another hurdle is the intensive care required after the surgery to protect the baby from complications. He also noted that Japan's Kyoto University once unsuccessfully performed a liver transplant for a 3.5 kg baby.
Lee said that the incidence rate of BA is high among Asian people, but the cause of the disease remains unknown.

In Taiwan, child BA patients are usually given liver segments donated by their mothers, as was the case with Hsuan-hsuan's mother. "Hsuan-hsuan's mother has been recovering well," Lee said, pointing out that humans can theoretically survive the loss of as much as 80 percent of their liver, as the organ can regenerate itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY BARRACKS RECONSTRUCTION PLAN LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's military barracks reconstruction plan got underway on Thursday as part of its efforts to improve the quality of life of its armed forces.

Gen. Tang Yao-ming, chief of the General Staff, presided over a ground-breaking ceremony for the Kaoshanting military barracks reconstruction project in Yangmei, Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei, in the morning.
It was the first barracks reconstruction and refurbishment project under a newly formed military barracks reconstruction fund.

Tang said the barracks reconstruction project is part of the country's trans-century military buildup plan. "In addition to arsenal modernization and organizational restructuring, we'll also improve the living environment and quality of all servicemen," he noted.

As weaponry modernization and organizational restructuring need huge funds, Tang said the Cabinet has arrpoved a Ministry of National Defense (MND) proposal to establish a special fund to finance the military barracks renewal project.

"The reconstruction fund will mainly rely on money raised from sales of idled or unsuitable military barracks," Tang said, adding that due to urban development, some military barracks in downtown areas will be relocated to suburban or rural areas under the reconstruction plan.

Many of the existing barracks were constructed by military servicemen in the 1950s. Most of them were poorly equipped and had limited living spaces. Moreover, many of them are now in a dreadful state of dilapidation. Some county governments have often pushed the military to relocate barracks to make way for major economic development projects.
Against this background, the MND has drawn up an overall blueprint for military barracks reconstruction.
According to an MND estimate, the reconstruction plan will call for a total outlay of NT$130 billion and is scheduled to be completed by 2017.

In fact, the MND said a total of 80 army barracks have been reconstructed or refurbished since 1981, and 22 other barracks are now under reconstruction. There are still 70 barracks to be relocated or renovated in the next two decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT GUATEMALA, SENEGAL IN MID-JANUARY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen is scheduled to visit Guatemala and Senegal in mid-January, Foreign Ministry sources said on Thursday.
Chen will accompany a yet-to-be-named ROC special envoy to attend the inauguration of Guatemalan President-elect Alfonso Portillo scheduled to be held on Jan. 14.
He will then proceed from the Central American state to the West African nation of Senegal, where he will preside over a working meeting of heads of ROC diplomatic missions stationed in West Africa.
Chen is also expected to visit the Gambia -- another of the ROC's West African diplomatic allies -- before returning to Taipei toward the end of January.

DOC.HEADLINE: `CHINCHIANG-CLASS' COASTAL PATROL FLEET COMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: A "Chinchiang-class" coastal patrol fleet was commissioned on Thursday at the Tsoying naval base in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung, in a ceremony attended by more than 100 naval officers.
The nine patrol vessels commissioned on Thursday will be joined in May 2000 by two further ships currently being built by the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC), naval authorities said.

The locally produced "Chinchiang-class" patrol craft -- weighing more than 500 tons, measuring 61 meters in length, and with a beam of nine meters -- are especially suited for information gathering and patrol missions and comply fully with the navy's requirements, the authorities noted.
The fast patrol ships will be equipped with search and sonar systems, as well as domestically developed "Hsiungfeng" missiles, according to the authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES COMPLETE Y2K READINESS

TEXT.P: A survey conducted by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has found that all 5,450 major companies throughout Taiwan have completed their Y2K preparations.

Taiwan Power Company, Chinese Petroleum Corp. and water supply organizations are all Y2K compliant, ensuring that residents will have normal supplies of electricity, gasoline and water during the rollover to the new millennium, an MOEA official said on Thursday.
The official said the MOEA has spent over NT$500 million (US$15.6 million) to help Taiwan's business operators take steps to deal with possible glitches caused by the Y2K bug.
The MOEA's "Y2K Information and Emergency Center" will operate from 2 p.m. on Dec. 31 until Jan. 4, run by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu.

Seven divisions have been set up under the center, covering the areas of administrative institutions, government enterprises, industries, enterprises, energy, news, and information. Simulated maneuvers were conducted on Dec. 2, 21 and 23.
Meanwhile, a separate survey by the "Y2K Service Corps" showed that 99.7 percent of 9,000 non-manufacturing companies surveyed had completed Y2K preparations as of Dec. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGES THE PUBLIC TO BEWARE OF Y2K PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: A government panel set up to deal with the Y2K bug urged the public on Thursday to be alert to the possibility of trouble caused by computers which crash in the transition to the new millennium.

Although the government has assured the public that all computers used by the public sector are Y2K-compliant, Minister of State Yang Shih-chien, who is presiding over the country's preparedness for the date rollover, urged the public to take precautions against possible disruption of public services.

In a statement issued by his panel, Yang advised the public to prepare flashlights or other forms of lighting, telephones which do not depend on electricity, and to stock up on batteries for mobile phones and radios in case of power failures.
Bank account holders and credit card owners should keep records of their last transactions and update records of their account books ahead of the nation's banks close before the new millennium.
The public should also make sure they have enough cash on hand, and should stock up on medicine. Those who depend on medical aid equipment should make sure their equipment is Y2K-compliant.

Yang urged the public to refrain from making long trips during the turn of the century, unless they have checked that the ships and planes they will travel on, and the hotels they will stay in, are Y2K-ready.

Date-dependent electrical appliances such as personal computers, fax machines, cameras, and video cassette recorders should be checked after midnight at year's end, and computer users should make backups of their files.

As a precaution, the panel said a crisis management center under the Cabinet will begin operating from Friday afternoon, and Premier Vincent Siew will visit the center and hold a press briefing early Saturday morning to announce any consequences of the rollover.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Palau becomes the Republic of China's 29th diplomatic ally.
The China Times:
The world is on full alert over Y2K crisis.
The United Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance will report to the watchdog Control Yuan the investigative results concerning independent presidential candidate James Soong's finances.
The Liberty Times:
Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hau says his 1991 NT$100 million political donation was intended for the ruling Kuomintang, not for Soong himself.
The China Post:
The ROC, Palau set up diplomatic relations.
The Taiwan News:
Palau establishes diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The Taipei Times:
Palau becomes Taiwan's 29th ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 31, or the 24th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: The Dutch Administration in Batavia (now Jakarta) takes over the Dutch East India Company's territories in Indonesia.
1869: Henri Matisse, French artist and a leading fauvist who employed pure color, simple shapes, and an exquisite sense of design to produce paintings, is born.
1879: Thomas A. Edison, American inventor, demonstrates for the first time his electric incandescent light at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1880: George Marshall, American general and statesman, is born. As secretary of state, he devised the Marshall Plan for post-war economic recovery in Europe.
1909: The Manhattan Bridge, a two-section suspension bridge, is opened to traffic in New York.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, who promised to establish a republican government when he assumed the provisional presidency of the Republic of China, orders the restoration of the imperial system, with himself on the throne, beginning from 1916.
1919: The United States, Britain and Japan sign an agreement on East Siberia.
1924: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had fallen ill earlier, arrives in Peking from Tientsin to hold talks with Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government. While in Peking, Dr. Sun succumbed to liver cancer and died on March 25, 1925.
1946: US President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of World War II.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates the government's policy of continuing attempts to settle disputes with the communists by political means.
1946: Chang Hsueh-ling, the commander of the Northeastern Army who played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Xian, is escorted to Taiwan and put under house arrest at the Chingshang hot spring in Hsinchu. The Xian Incident was a severe setback to Chiang's efforts to subjugate the communists.
1946: Tea from Taiwan is exported to New York for the first time.
1956: President Sukarno proclaims a state of siege in Sumatra, Indonesia.
1964: President Sukarno threatens to quit the United Nations if Malaysia is given a seat on the Security Council.
1971: Kurt Waldheim of Austria takes over as United Nations secretary-general after U Thant retired.
1975: More than 1,600 foreign students presented an autographed album to Premier Chinag Ching-kuo at a year-end meeting.
1976: Education Minister Y. S. Tsiang hosts a dinner to honor foreign students and visiting professors at the Chientan Youth Activity Center with more than 1,000 students and teachers from 30 countries attending.
1976: James Shen, Chinese ambassador to the United States, returns home for consultation.
1977: Cambodia breaks off diplomatic relations with Vietnam and suspends all air services between the two countries.
1979: The Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty against the Chinese communists in the area is ended.
1981: Former Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings overthrows the government of President Hilla Limann and seizes power again in Ghana.
1983: The United States deploys Cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles in Britain and West Germany.
1985: The Taipei World Trade Center is inaugurated.
1988: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto sign the first agreement between India and Pakistan in 16 years, agreeing not to attack each others' nuclear facilities.
1991: All senior delegates to the ROC's First National Assembly, Control Yuan, and Legislative Yuan retire from office.
1996: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong submits his resignation to Premier Lien Chan.
1996: An explosion on a train in India kills at least 300 people.
1997: Mohammed Rafiq Tarar becomes the ninth president of Pakistan.
1998: Finance ministers of the European Union announce definite rates for converting the currencies of the 11 nations due to launch the single euro currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only men of moral character who know how to love men or to hate men. If you fix your mind upon a moral life, you will be free from evil."

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION WON'T DRASTICALLY CHANGE ROC'S FOREIGN POLICY SAYS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taipei will not change its current basic foreign policy no matter who is elected as the Republic of China's next president in March 2000, Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen said on Friday.

Speaking at a year-end news conference, Chen said the government's present foreign policy, arrived at after many adjustments since 1949, is the best one for ROC nationals. Although each presidential candidate has a different viewpoint on foreign affairs, he stressed that the foreign ministry will not rashly change its current policy so as to avoid risks.

Turning to speculation that President Lee Teng-hui may visit Japan in October next year after stepping down from his current post, Chen said the president will be a private citizen by then and will be able to choose on his own where he wants to go. However, he added that his ministry will advise Lee based on the principle of national interest due to the sensitive nature of his position as the nation's former head of state.

Commenting on Taiwan's prospects for joining the World Trade Organization (WTO), Chen expressed the belief that Taiwan will be granted membership in the world trade regulatory body soon after mainland China gains entry, noting that the mainland already reached a bilateral agreement on its WTO membership with the United States on November 15.

The foreign minister also stressed that his ministry will further step up its efforts to take part in non-governmental activities in the international community. Currently, Taiwan is a member of 962 non-governmental organizations, he noted.

Looking back over the past year, Chen pointed to the forging of diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January and the establishment of such links with Palau just 24 hours ago to demonstrate that the ROC government is still willing to set up formal relations with friendly countries around the world.

Regarding the resumption of aviation talks with South Korea and the Philippines, the foreign minister emphasized that Taipei will reopen such talks with Seoul and Manila, respectively, as long as the negotiations are mutually-beneficial and reciprocal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER OUTLINES POLICIES FOR 2000

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Friday that his ministry will advocate an investment-oriented policy to further sharpen the competitiveness of Taiwan's industrial sector.

Although the government will not take the lead in pushing for mergers among enterprises, Wang said it has worked out laws to provide tax incentives to encourage business mergers as part of an effort to create an unfettered investment climate in Taiwan.

Citing statistics compiled by the Industrial Development Bureau, the economics minister disclosed that 182 investment projects, each worth at least NT$200 million, will be accomplished in 2000, with the overall investment amount totaling NT$482.7 billion (US$15.33 billion).

As the Taiwan economy has gradually recovered from the Asian financial crisis which broke out more than two years ago, Wang predicted that Taiwan's economic growth in 1999 will reach 5.5 percent, while the rate estimated for 2000 will be around 6 percent.
He made the remarks at a year-end news conference in which the minister also drew up the following seven major policies for Taiwan's economic development in the coming year:
-- implementing an investment-oriented policy to boost the competitive edge of Taiwan's industrial sector;
-- building an E-commerce economy by getting 24,500 businesses on-line;
-- embracing 2000 as an information year by sponsoring a series of international activities with world-class industry leaders;
-- fully developing electrical power supplies;
-- comprehensively opening up the local market for imports of petroleum products by June of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE GENERAL NAMED DEPUTY TO NEW UN PEACEKEEPING FORCE IN E.TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australia's Major General Mike Smith has been appointed by the United Nations as a deputy to its new peacekeeping force in East Timor following the conclusion of the Australian-led International Force (Interfet) mission in the former Portuguese colony in January.

Smith was Australia's first choice as deputy for the UNTAET, which will be led by Major-General Jaime de los Santos of the Philippines. The 49-year-old Smith was formerly commander of the Townsville-based 3rd Brigade, which formed the core of Australia's contribution to Interfet.

Military experts said the appointment of an Australian general to the new UN peacekeeping force in East Timor means that Australia will continue to play a major role in the rebuilding of East Timor in coming years.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STOCK MARKET TO KEEP BOOMING IN EARLY 2000

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market closed to a record high on the eve of the new millennium and economists on Friday predicted that it will rise further in January thanks to bullish sentiments amid strong economic growth in Australia and elsewhere.
The All Ordinaries Index rose 11.4 points to close at 3152.5 on Thursday, topping the previous record high of 3145.4 set in April of this year. The close at the end of last year was 2813.4.

Brokers attributed the rise to a wave of Australian retailers cashing in on strong gains on Walls Street and other major markets. The gains however were limited by cautious investment by major Australian institutions.
"Many Australian investors remained cautious in their investment, compared to the aggressive and bullish campaign by American investors," one broker said.

The index only added 12.1 percent for the year, which was below the percentage gains set on the Wall Street and many other markets around the world, particularly the record-breaking gains in the Dow Jones, economists said.

The year 1999 witnessed a flood of 141 new listings, including the government-owned telecommunications giant Telstra Inc. Many new Internet firms were the biggest winners with their stock prices increasing two to four times as a result of a flood of investment by Australian institutions as well as individuals, they said.

"It has been the year of the new economy with technology stocks the strongest performers over the past 12 months," said Greg Matthews, chief investment officer at Macquarie Investment Management in Sydney.

The year also witnessed Australian share market capitalization soaring to A$652 (nearly US$435) billion by the end of 1999 from A$536 (over US$357) billion. Trading records were also smashed during the year, including the highest single day trading volume when shares worth A$6.98 (over US$4.59) billion changed hands on June 22.
1999 was the best year ever for many Australian stockbrokers, who scored the most ever transactions and handsome profits, according to Australian stock broking industry sources.

The number of transactions skyrocketed 51.3 percent to 10.2 million from 6.7 million last year, while the average daily volume surged 20 percent to A$1.21 billion (US$807 million) from A$1.02 billion (US$680 million).
The public floating of the second tranche of Telstra shares pushed Australia to the world's highest ranking in terms of the number of stock investors, taking the lead from the United States.

The Telstra shares brought the total number of stock investors to over 45 percent of Australia's 19 million population. Economists believe more people are expected to jump on the bandwagon in the coming weeks and months of the new millennium because of the higher earnings to be had than from bank interest rates or property markets.

Salomon Smith Barney predicts that the Australian stock market index could peak at 3250 in the first quarter of 2000 and then come under pressure by inching inflationary increases and bank interest rate hikes.

Australia's gross domestic product is expected to grow by more than 4 percent during the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, 2000, with an unemployment rate of below 7 percent and a low inflation rate of about 2-2.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN, US SECURITY OFFICIALS MEET ON BORDER SECURITY

TEXT.P: Canadian law enforcement and security intelligence officials met with FBI Director Louis Freeh in Washington, D.C. Thursday to strengthen cooperation on border security measures during the New Year holidays.
This was a follow-up to recent discussions between US Attorney General Janet Reno and Solicitor General of Canada Lawrence MacAulay.

The two countries have been closely cooperatiing in dealing with any potential threat to the security of residents of both countries, especially after several terrorist suspects were arrested trying to sneak into the US from Canada.

Meeting with Freeh were Ward Elcock, director of the Canadian Security Intelligence Service, Paul Kennedy, senior assistant deputy solicitor general of Canada and deputy commissioner Giuliano Zaccardelli of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

They reaffirmed their commitment to a seamless enforcement program to detect threats and protect the security of citizens of Canada and the US. They agreed to continue their cooperation and vigilance into the New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSE SETS GOAL OF OVER 500 LISTED COMPANIES IN 2000

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's (TSE) new year resolution is to invite more qualified firms to apply for their company's stocks to be listed in a bid to expand the scale of Taiwan's stock market, TSE officials said on Friday.
The TSE's goal is to bring the number of listed companies from the current level of 463 to over 500, the officials added.

The TSE listing department, which regularly makes predictions on the coming year's business, has in recent years attempted to enlarge the scale of the local bourse and reach international standards by keenly interviewing companies issuing shares and encouraging them to apply to have their shares listed.

Fifty firms applied to be listed on the stock market last year, while 43 handed in their application this year, according to TSE figures. Based on the number of applications submitted during these two years, the TSE listing department set a goal of 40 new listed companies for next year.
The TSE figures showed that 33 of last year's 50 applications were approved, with 14 of those firms coming from electronics-related industries.

A total number of 463 companies are presently listed on the Taiwan stock market, surpassing the 395 companies listed on Thailand's stock market, the 317 on Singapore's, and lagging behind the 709 listed on South Korea's, the 694 on Hong Kong's and the 1907 companies listed on Japan's stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FOUNDATION SET TO HELP ANIMAL HUSBANDRY DEAL WITH WTO IMPACT

TEXT.P: A National Animal Industry Foundation (NAIF) is to start operations on Saturday to help local stock raisers deal with Taiwan's World Trade Organization (WTO) membership, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said on Friday.
The NAIF was established with NT$1.1 billion donated jointly by the COA and the Foundation of Meat and Domestic Fowl, and COA Vice Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung has been named as its first president.

According to COA Animal Industry Department Director Chen Po-chih, NAIF will play the role of mediator between the government and the industry while designing measures to help stock raisers to meet with WTO demands.
The organization will also be responsible for coordinating import and export orders within the industry, stabilizing prices, and protecting customers' interests, Chen added.
In addition, an information system on products and the market, as well as a set of prewarning systems, will be set up to help maintain a correct understanding of market supply and demand.

Other functions provided by NAIF will include health insurance for animals, sanitation inspections, quality control, establishment of a high-quality sperm bank, and marketing of a specific brand image for the nation's livestock produce.
